body:
<email>
From: Akiko Tanaka <atanaka@university.edu>
To: David Rosenberg <drosenberg@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Interesting find - mathematical principles in Meiji-era art

David,

I'm thrilled that you're as enthusiastic about this discovery as I am! I've attached images of the painting and a brief summary of my initial findings. As you'll see, the arrangement of the motifs follows a specific geometric pattern that seems to be based on trigonometric principles.

While this particular painting is the most striking example I've found so far, I believe the use of mathematical principles in Japanese art and design during the Meiji era was more widespread than previously thought. I've come across several other examples that suggest a growing interest in incorporating geometric and mathematical concepts into artistic compositions during this period.

I think this discovery could have significant implications for our understanding of the cultural and intellectual exchanges between Japan and the West during the Meiji era. It may also shed light on the ways in which Japanese artists and designers were adapting and integrating new ideas from the West while maintaining a distinct cultural identity.

I'm excited to discuss this further and explore the potential for collaboration. I think we could develop a compelling joint publication that combines our expertise in art history and mathematics to shed new light on this fascinating aspect of Japanese art and culture.

Please let me know your thoughts on the attached materials, and if you have any suggestions for further research or analysis.

Best regards,
Akiko
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sjohnson@mathedconsulting.com>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakvilleschools.org>
Subject: RE: Great to meet you at the conference!

Hi Michael,

The real-world problem-solving strategy you mentioned sounds fascinating! In fact, I recently attended a seminar where the presenter shared some compelling research on the effectiveness of this approach in promoting higher-order thinking skills and engagement.

I have a few articles and case studies that might be of interest to you. I'll send them your way shortly.

You know, I've been thinking about how we could collaborate on this. What if we both implemented the real-world problem-solving strategy in our classrooms and collected data on its impact? We could compare our findings and even consider writing a paper together about our experience.

Let me know what you think! I'm excited about the possibility of working together on this project.

Best,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@geoenergyresearch.org>
To: Jordan Davis <jordan.davis@renewabletech.com>
Subject: Exciting opportunity for collaboration

Hi Jordan,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been a while since we connected, but I wanted to reach out because I think you might be interested in a new project we're working on at RenewableTech.

We're in the early stages of developing a new geothermal power plant in the Cascades region of the Pacific Northwest. As you know, this area has significant geothermal potential, and we believe it's an ideal location for a large-scale geothermal energy project.

Given your extensive research on the geological characteristics of the Cascades and their implications for geothermal energy production, I think your insights could be incredibly valuable to our team. I was wondering if you'd be interested in discussing potential collaboration opportunities, either as a consultant or a research partner.

If you're open to the idea, I'd be happy to set up a call to discuss the project in more detail and answer any questions you might have. Let me know your thoughts!

Best regards,
Jordan

body:
<email>
From: Zack Wallace <zack.wallace@satiremaster.com>
To: Ananya Iyer <ananya.iyer@telanganahistory.org>
Subject: RE: Satire and Social Change

Ananya,

Great to hear from you! I've been meaning to email you as well. Your lecture on the Telangana movement was fascinating, and I've been thinking about the parallels between political satire and grassroots activism ever since.

I'd be happy to share some thoughts on satire and social change for your book. In my experience, humor has the power to cut through political rhetoric and speak to people's shared values and experiences. By holding up a mirror to society's absurdities, satirical fiction can inspire people to question the status quo and push for change.

As for my new novel, it's been a wild ride so far. The more I delve into the commercialization of holidays, the more I realize how deeply it reflects our society's priorities and values. It's a rich vein of material, to say the least.

I'm also excited to explore the city and connect with the local literary community. If you have any recommendations for writers' groups or book clubs, I'd be grateful for the introduction.

Looking forward to our continued collaboration!

Best,
Zack
label: research

We are currently back-testing the storage model. 
The enclosed version contains deltas and decision 
variable.

model.

very well.  The Enron Research storage model  is a lot like that, although 
implementation may be
different.  

Let me know if you have any questions.

Zimin

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Thompson <jthompson@oakwoodes.org>
To: Alex Rivera <arivera@oakwoodes.org>
Subject: RE: Introducing myself and an idea

Hi Alex,

Thank you so much for your thoughtful response and for all of the great suggestions! I really appreciate you taking the time to brainstorm with me and am excited to explore these ideas further. 

The visual storytelling and theater concepts sound especially promising, and I'd love to connect with the organization you mentioned to learn more about their approach. Similarly, the music ideas are fascinating - I've seen some of those vibration-based programs and think they could be really impactful for our kids.

Getting family involvement will be key, you're absolutely right. I'm hoping this program can be a way to help the students' families feel more connected to the school community as well.

I'll definitely take you up on that offer for a letter of support, that would be hugely helpful for the grant application. I'll send over the details and a draft of the proposal early next week.

And yes, I'd love to grab coffee sometime soon! It would be great to meet in person and for you to introduce me to some of your colleagues. Just let me know when works well for you.

Thank you again for all of your support and enthusiasm. I'm really looking forward to working together!

Best,
Jenna
label: research

From: k..allen@enron.com
To: mery.l.brown@accenture.com
Subject: RE: Interface Design Update
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-To: 'mery.l.brown@accenture.com@ENRON'
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Sent Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Mery,

This sounds better than the limitations you were describing in the meeting.  We should be able to work with this.

Phillip

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	mery.l.brown@accenture.com@ENRON  
Sent:	Monday, November 05, 2001 5:11 PM
To:	pallen@enron.com
Cc:	donald.l.barnhart@accenture.com; kmcdani@enron.com
Subject:	Interface Design Update

Phillip,

The purpose of this e-mail is to explain the results of our discussions
with the technical team after our meeting with you. We need to get your
approval of the points listed below so that we can begin building the
application.

We can have the Position and P&L Reports show the results of the learner's
decisions in previous periods, which will allow the learner move forward in
time with wrong answers. This will achieve our goal of giving the learners
"more rope" and letting them see the results of their mistakes. In order to
achieve this, we will have the following constraints:
   The feedback will be fairly high-level, as we discussed in Thursday's
   meeting. We will be able to provide feedback on cumulative P&L and
   positions, but not about specific actions the learner took in a previous
   period. We will not, for example, be able to say things like "In
   November, when we were headed into a cold winter, you chose to withdraw
   gas. What you should have done was..."
   We cannot save the P&L and position numbers. This means that if the
   learner leaves the simulation, returns to the main menu, or experiences
   a computer crash, his decisions will not be saved and he will need to
   start over at time period one.
   We cannot have the learner calculate P&L on storage costs,
   transportation costs, or hedging instruments. This is because the right
   answer and the available answer choices would have to depend on the
   decisions the learner has made. Now that the learner can go down any
   path he chooses, the number of possible answers is extremely large, and
   the right answers are variable. I believe these tasks will be actually
   better if we don't have the learner calculate P&L because he has already
   calculated P&L numerous times in the structurer/customer scenarios and
   conversion and arbitrage scenarios. Furthermore, the type of feedback we
   would have to give about specific P&L numbers will not flow well with
   the high-level, global-type feedback we are now planning to give in this
   task.

We cannot export price numbers into Excel because the Indeliq framework
does not support the downloading of data into external applications. The
technical effort required to add this functionality far exceeds our current
development budget. We can, however, do some calculations for the learner
on the screen. We can also try to somehow allow the learner to make the
mistake of using future prices instead of discounted prices.

If you could please respond with your approval or concerns by end of day
Wednesday, it will allow us to move forward with the development of this
simulation. I would be happy to discuss these points with you; please let
me know if you would like to set up a meeting.

Thank you.
Mery

use of the email by you is prohibited.

body:
<email>
From: Amelia Novak <amnovak@university.edu>
To: Ethan Faulkner <ethanf@college.edu>
Subject: Re: Collaborative paper - final revisions

Ethan,

I couldn't agree more about strengthening the conclusion. Let's schedule a call this week to brainstorm some ideas for tying our findings to the broader debates in the field. I'm confident that with a little more work, this paper will be ready to submit to the journal.

And thank you for your kind words about our collaboration. I feel the same way - it's been wonderful to have a partner in this project who understands the challenges of balancing academic and family life. We'll have to celebrate our success (and commiserate about the struggles) over a glass of wine at the conference!

Let me know your availability for a call this week and we'll pin down a time. I'm looking forward to our next steps!

Best,
Amelia

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sthompson@oakdaleelementary.org>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakdaleelementary.org>
Subject: RE: Literacy Event Planning

Emily,

Your enthusiasm is contagious! I'm so excited to see all these fantastic activities come to life. The students are going to have a blast, and I'm sure their families will appreciate the effort we've put into creating a fun and educational event.

I'll start gathering materials for the creative writing and bookmark-making stations right away. I have some great ideas for prompts and supplies that will spark the students' creativity.

During our next meeting, let's discuss the logistics of setting up the "book swap," "story walk," and "costume corner." We can also finalize the event schedule and make sure we have all the necessary resources and volunteers.

I'm so grateful to have you as my colleague and collaborator, Emily. Your structured approach and dedication to immersive learning are truly inspiring. I can't wait to see the impact this event will have on our students' love for reading and writing.

Let's do this!

Best,
Sarah

George,

The probability of building a house this year is increasing.  I have shifted 
to a slightly different plan.  There were too many design items that I could 
not work out in the plan we discussed previously.  Now, I am leaning more 
towards a plan with two wings and a covered courtyard in the center.  One 
wing would have a living/dining kitchen plus master bedroom downstairs with 3 
kid bedrooms + a laundry room upstairs.  The other wing would have a garage + 
guestroom downstairs with a game room + office/exercise room upstairs.  This 
plan still has the same number of rooms as the other plan but with the 
courtyard and pool in the center this plan should promote more outdoor 
living.  I am planning to orient the house so that the garage faces the west. 
 The center courtyard would be covered with a metal roof with some fiberglass 
skylights supported by metal posts.  I am envisioning the two wings to have 
single slope roofs that are not connected to the center building.  

I don't know if you can imagine the house I am trying to describe.  I would 
like to come and visit you again this month.  If it would work for you, I 
would like to drive up on Sunday afternoon on Feb. 18 around 2 or 3 pm.  I 
would like to see the progress on the house we looked at and tour the one we 
didn't have time for.  I can bring more detailed drawings of my new plan. 

Call or email to let me know if this would work for you.  
pallen70@hotmail.com or 713-463-8626(home), 713-853-7041(work)


Phillip Allen


PS.  Channel 2 in Houston ran a story yesterday (Feb. 2) about a home in 
Kingwood that had a poisonous strain of mold growing in the walls.  You 
should try their website or call the station to get the full story.  It would 
makes a good case for breathable walls.

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 09/08/2000 
12:28 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls


Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austin
that we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this project
should produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.
This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong as
Austin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range for
this market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that we
have uncovered to date in the Austin market.
The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  As
it is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austin
for preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be complete
in less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severe
water treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lot
improvement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in North
Austin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and street
widening.  Even though this property is not likely to require street
widening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pond
requirement, I used this data to be cautious.
 The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is not
expected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quite
successful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as the
adjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.
As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoods
is uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but may
only put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are far
preferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyer
preferences.
The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 and
an extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved site
plan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close into
an A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.
This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in the
profits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discuss
having you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entity
with your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a
1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is a
rental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would then
be the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with an
exchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in San
Antonio if you do not know anyone.
I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,
by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.
Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want to
schedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon as
your schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at any
time.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either
512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is
512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with you
on this project that is sure to be a major winner.
I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusual
events these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpg
downdrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.
One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled to
start the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enough
to knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it took
another week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to take
my wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebra
in her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden this
past week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realize
the enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks as
if she will be ok in the long run.
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC


 - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

body:
<email>
From: Robert Thompson <robert.thompson@university.edu>
To: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Environmental Justice course collaboration

Hi Emily,

Thanks for reaching out about the Environmental Justice course. I'm glad to hear you're enthusiastic about this collaboration. I agree that it's important for us to find a balance between theory and application in the course content.

I've been thinking about how we can incorporate case studies and real-world examples to help students see the practical implications of the theories we'll be discussing. I have a few ideas for topics and readings, but I'd love to hear your suggestions as well.

As for our teaching styles, I know we have some differences in our approaches. I think it could be beneficial for us to have a conversation about how we can complement each other's strengths and find a way to create a cohesive learning experience for our students.

I'm happy to meet next Wednesday afternoon to discuss our plans further. Let me know what time works best for you.

Looking forward to our collaboration!

Best,
Robert

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: Pierre Dubois <pdubois@university.eu>
Subject: Exciting new data from the Cascadia subduction zone

Dear Pierre,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to share some intriguing data we recently obtained from a seismic survey in the Cascadia subduction zone. The results have shed new light on the accretionary processes in this area, and I believe they could have significant implications for our research.

I've attached a preliminary analysis of the data, and I would love to hear your thoughts. Do you have time for a video call next week to discuss this further? I'm available on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning, if that works for you.

Best regards,
Emily

Date: Mon, 31 Dec 1979 16:00:00 -0800 (PST)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: tom.wilbeck@enron.com
Subject: RE: technical help for interviewing traders
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Tom Wilbeck
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Oct2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

In regards to gas:
what signals do you for in determining your view?
 no right answer.  some examples are  strength or weakness in financial basis 
and index markets, customer flow, cash/futures spread, technical  analysis, 
storage projections, price action, etc.
what resources do you use to formulate a price view?
 goal is to see how much he analyzes the fundamentals of the market
  weather - does candidate look at weather models such as american, european, 
and canadian operational runs or does he just     subscribe to  a weather 
service
  storage - has he built an aga forecasting model or does he just wait for 
others to tell him projections
  production - has candidate dug into eia production data, company specific 
drilling results, or state specific (such as texas railroad     commission 
reports)
  end of season storage number - has candidate built a longer term forecast 
of where we end up in storage.  
give example of complex transaction you've structured for a customer.
where is storage now relative to history? what is the highest and lowest 
level we've been at in past 5 years?
what are your short, medium, and long term views of gas market?
what major basis changes have occured in the market over the past 5 years? 
What do you expect in the next 5?
how should a storage operator decide whether or not to inject on any given 
day?

In regards to derivatives in order of difficulty
What are delta/gamma/theta?
if you buy a put spread, is your delta positive, negative, or zero?
Is swap price equal to simple average of futures contracts?
If interest rates go up what happens to option prices all else equal?
what is the value of a european $1 call expiring in 12 months if 
corresponding futures are trading $5?
what happens to delta of an option if volatility increase?

be a great resource for other interviewers.

Thanks again,

Tom Wilbeck

<email>
From: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@hardwareguru.net>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@techsavvy.com>
Subject: RE: Memory Management System Update

Hi Alex,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad to know that the project at TechSavvy is moving forward. Regarding the cache performance issue, I think non-uniform cache architectures could indeed be a viable solution. I've done some research on the topic, and I believe it could help alleviate the bottlenecks you're experiencing.

I can share some papers and resources that might be useful for your implementation. Let's schedule a call this week to discuss it in more detail.

As for the research paper, I'm excited to see your outline! I've been reviewing the data as well, and I think we have a strong case for the benefits of our proposed memory management techniques. If you can send me your outline, I'll provide my feedback and suggestions.

It's been a while since we caught up, so I'd love to hear more about your new role at TechSavvy. Are you enjoying it so far?

Looking forward to our call and collaborating on the paper!

Best,
Jordan

body:
<email>
From: Robert Thompson <robert.thompson@mathhigh.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@techacademy.edu>
Subject: RE: Arduino-based math projects

Emily,

Thanks so much for sending over those project ideas! I've had a chance to look through them and I think they're great. The idea of using Arduino to teach concepts like graphing linear equations and exploring trigonometric functions is really exciting.

I'm definitely interested in collaborating on a workshop proposal for the STEM Educators Conference. I think we could put together something really compelling that showcases the potential of Arduino in both math and electronics education. I'll start brainstorming some potential project ideas and will send them your way for feedback.

In the meantime, I'd love to try out some of the projects you sent with my students. I'll let you know how it goes and will be sure to send along any suggestions for improvements.

Thanks again for reaching out!

Best,
Robert

Subject: Finalizing our grant proposal

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I've been working on the grant proposal for our educational materials project and I think we're almost ready to submit it. I just need your input on a few final details.

Can we schedule a virtual meeting for this Friday at 2 PM EST? I'd like to go over the proposal together and make sure we haven't missed anything important. It should only take an hour or so.

Let me know if this works for you or if you need to reschedule. I'm excited to finalize our proposal and submit it to the Digital Literacy for Children Foundation!

Best regards,
Samantha

body:
<email>
From: Michael Lee <michael.lee@buddhistartgallery.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@asianartmuseum.org>
Subject: RE: Book launch event planning

Emily,

Inviting Prof. Gupta to give the keynote speech is an excellent idea! He's been a guiding light in our academic journey, and it would be wonderful to have him celebrate this milestone with us.

I'll start putting together a list of artifacts for the exhibition. We should also consider creating a small catalog to accompany the exhibition, with photographs and descriptions of the pieces. It could be a nice keepsake for the attendees.

I've heard back from the Asian Art Museum, and they have a few dates available in mid-September. I'll send you the options, and we can decide which one works best for us.

Thanks for all your hard work on this, Emily. I couldn't ask for a better co-author and friend to share this journey with.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@oncoinnovations.com>
To: Michael Rodriguez <michael.rodriguez@dermedu.com>
Subject: Collaborating on a Journal Article?

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I was just browsing through the latest issue of the Journal of Dermatological Research and noticed a call for proposals for a special issue on "Innovations in Skin Cancer Treatment and Prevention." I immediately thought of our conversations about collaborating on a project related to our overlapping interests.

I think this could be a great opportunity for us to showcase our combined expertise in emerging skin cancer treatments and patient education. What do you think about submitting a proposal for an article that highlights some of the cutting-edge technologies and preventive strategies we've been discussing?

If you're interested, I'd love to set up a time to brainstorm some potential angles and divide up the research and writing responsibilities. Let me know your thoughts!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@geothermalenergy.org>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@ridgemontschool.edu>
Subject: RE: Guest Lecture at Ridgemont High School

Jordan,

April 20th at 1:30 PM works perfectly for me. I'll make sure to focus my presentation on the basics of geothermal energy, its applications, and its potential for the future. I'm confident that the students will find the topic engaging and inspiring.

The audiovisual setup you described should be more than sufficient for my needs. I'll bring my laptop and a few handouts to supplement my presentation.

I appreciate you accommodating my requests and for all the hard work you've put into organizing this workshop series. It's partnerships like these that will help us create a more sustainable future.

Looking forward to meeting you and your students on April 20th!

Best regards,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Whalesong <sarah.whalesong@oceanresearch.org>
To: Alex Lambda <alex.lambda@functionalcode.net>
Subject: Reaching out about functional programming in marine biology

Hi Alex,

It was great meeting you at the interdisciplinary research conference last month. I really enjoyed our conversation about the parallels between our fields, and I've been thinking about how I could incorporate some of the functional programming concepts you mentioned into my work on whale migration patterns.

I'm writing to ask if you'd be open to chatting more about this. I'm particularly interested in learning how to use functional programming to process and analyze the large datasets I work with, and I'd love to get your insights on best practices and resources for learning. If you're up for it, I'd be happy to buy you a coffee or lunch to pick your brain!

Best regards,
Sarah
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Liam O'Neill <loneill@linguisticsinstitute.org>
To: Emily Chen <emily.chen@meduniversity.edu>
Subject: Re: Following up from the conference

Hi Emily,

Thanks for reaching out! I'm glad my presentation resonated with you. I've definitely considered the linguistic aspects of respiratory conditions, but haven't had the opportunity to explore it in depth. It would be fascinating to see how language use might vary based on different medical factors. I'd be happy to discuss this further and see if we might be able to collaborate on a project.

Let me know if you'd like to set up a call to brainstorm ideas.

Best,
Liam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@sciencetoday.com>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@discoveriesmag.com>
Subject: Climate change series update

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking about our climate change series and wanted to touch base with you about the progress so far. I've finished the draft for the first article on the potential health impacts of climate change, and I think it's shaping up nicely. I'd love to get your feedback on it before we move forward.

Also, I was wondering if you've had a chance to start working on the economics piece? I know you've been swamped with other projects lately, so no worries if you haven't had the time yet. If you need any help or want to brainstorm ideas, just let me know.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts and catching up soon!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Johnson <ejohnson@prenatalcareclinic.com>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@prenatalcareclinic.com>
Subject: New study on the safety of Tdap vaccine during pregnancy

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share with you a new study I came across that provides further evidence supporting the safety and efficacy of the Tdap vaccine during pregnancy. The study, published in the Journal of Obstetric Medicine, followed a large cohort of pregnant women who received the Tdap vaccine and found no increased risk of adverse outcomes for either the mother or the baby.

I think this information could be valuable to include in the pamphlet we're working on. What do you think about updating our current recommendations to strongly encourage expectant mothers to receive the Tdap vaccine during their third trimester, as per the study's findings?

Let me know your thoughts, and if you have any other suggestions for the pamphlet.

Best,
Emily
label: research

From: jim.cole@enron.com
To: chris.gaskill@enron.com, martin.cuilla@enron.com, john.arnold@enron.com
Subject: St. Croix refinery
Cc: jennifer.fraser@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: jennifer.fraser@enron.com
X-From: Jim Cole
X-To: Chris Gaskill, Martin Cuilla, John Arnold
X-cc: Jennifer Fraser
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Jun2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Jennifer asked me to explain about the effect of the refinery fire.

The St. Croix refinery has their reformer offline.  The reformer is used to 
convert straight-run naphtha into a high octane blending component called 
reformate as well as some butane and lighter gases.  The effect would not 
really be a reduction in gasoline, but a reduction in a high quality blending 
component which would make it harder to make RFG.

As of this writing, the fire is out. If you have any further questions, feel 
free to contact me.

Jim
36970

To: michael.gapinski@painewebber.com
Subject: RE: Buying back calls
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: "Gapinski, Michael" <michael.gapinski@painewebber.com> @ ENRON
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Jun2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

How about drinks at 5:30 on Thursday.   I try not to interrupt work with 
personal business.




"Gapinski, Michael" <michael.gapinski@painewebber.com> on 02/25/2001 03:13:29 
PM
To: "'John.Arnold@enron.com'" <John.Arnold@enron.com>
cc:  
Subject: RE: Buying back calls


John -

I completely understand your point of view.  PaineWebber knows affluent
investors such as yourself want access to alternative investments such as
private equity and hedge funds.  Our group has also found that high net
worth individuals prefer a consultative relationship where we help you
structure a complete asset allocation based on your objectives.  We then
provide you with access to, and help you select, third-party institutional
money managers to make the day-to-day investment decisions.  We also provide
the ongoing performance monitoring of those managers, including correlations
to the appropriate indices.

I believe you will find our approach to be appreciably different from your
previous contacts with financial advisors, where you have felt the advisor
was 'pushing' a house fund or stock du jour.  If your schedule permits, I
would like to meet with you on Thursday afternoon to discuss this in more
detail.  How does 4 PM sound?

- Mike



-----Original Message-----
From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]
Sent: Saturday, February 24, 2001 10:41 AM
To: michael.gapinski@painewebber.com
Subject: RE: Buying back calls



Michael:
Thanks for putting the paperwork together.

I would have interest in meeting if you can present unique investment
opportunities that I don't have access to now.  Most of my contact with
financial advisors in the past has consisted of them suggesting a mutual
fund, telling me to invest in Home Depot, Sun, and Coke, or trying to pass
off their banks' biased research reports as something valuable.  The above
services provide no value to me personally.  If you can present
opportunities such as access to private equity or hedge funds, or other
ideas with strong growth potential and low correlation to the S@P, I'd
listen.

John





"Michael Gapinski" <michael.gapinski@painewebber.com> on 02/21/2001
08:23:04 AM

To:   "'John.Arnold@enron.com'" <John.Arnold@enron.com>
cc:   "'Rafael Herrera'" <rafael.herrera@painewebber.com>
Subject:  RE: Buying back calls


John -

We'll get the paperwork together and sent to you for naked options.  At
some point, I'd like to talk about the diversification strategy in more
detail -- perhaps over dinner or a quick meeting after the markets close?

Michael Gapinski
Account Vice President
Emery Financial Group
PaineWebber, Inc.
713-654-0365
800-553-3119 x365
Fax: 713-654-1281
Cell: 281-435-0295

-----Original Message-----
From:     John.Arnold@enron.com [SMTP:John.Arnold@enron.com]
Sent:     Tuesday, February 20, 2001 10:14 PM
To:  michael.gapinski@painewebber.com
Subject:  Re: Buying back calls


Michael:
Appreciate the idea.  However, with my natural long, I'm not looking to
really trade around the position.  I believe ENE will continue to be range
bound, but in case it is not, I don't want to forgo 50% of my option
premium.
I have price targets of where I would like to lighten up exposure to ENE
and will use calls to implement the stategy.  To that regards, I noticed I
was not approved to sell naked calls.  I would like that ability in order
to hedge some exposure I have of unexercised vested options.  Please look
into that for me.
John.




"Michael Gapinski" <michael.gapinski@painewebber.com> on 02/20/2001
06:28:27 PM

To:   "'Arnold, John'" <john.arnold@enron.com>
cc:
Subject:  Buying back calls


John -

I was looking at the recent pullback in ENE and thinking it might be an
opportunity to buy back the calls you sold.  Of course, you would then be
in a position to sell calls again if the stock makes a bounce.  I'm not
sure that ENE @ 75 is the place, but maybe @ 73.  Call me if you're
interested.

Michael Gapinski
Account Vice President
Emery Financial Group
PaineWebber, Inc.

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@hospital.org>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Reaching out for your expertise

Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad my research resonated with your current project. The long-term health impacts of the Civil War on children is a fascinating topic, and I'd be happy to share my thoughts and insights.

I recently published a study that found a significant correlation between early puberty and socioeconomic status, which could indeed be relevant to your work. The stress and hardships experienced by children during times of economic instability and war can certainly have lasting effects on their physical development and overall health.

I'm available for a video call next Friday, April 14th, at 10 am EST if that works for you. Alternatively, we could have an email exchange if you prefer. Let me know what suits you best.

Looking forward to our discussion and learning more about your book project.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Petrov <alex.petrov@university.edu>
To: Jamie Thompson <jamie.thompson@scienceworld.com>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Jamie,

I'm glad you're interested in writing about our new project! I'll keep you posted on our progress and will definitely share some results with you once we have something solid. 

As for your question about science and policy, I could write a whole book on that topic. One example that comes to mind is the debate over hydraulic fracturing (fracking). There's a lot of really good scientific evidence that fracking can cause earthquakes, but the industry keeps trying to downplay or deny that risk. It's frustrating to see decision-makers ignoring or cherry-picking the science like that.

I'd be happy to talk more about this with you, either over email or in person if you're ever in town. I'm actually going to be at a conference in Seattle next month - any chance you'll be there too?

Best,
Alex
label: research

Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
X-From: TD Waterhouse <customerservice@tdwaterhouse.com>@ENRON

X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


 [IMAGE]  Market  Insight for November 26, 2001  From    [IMAGE]    The  Gl=
obal Online Financial Services Firm   Introducing  Goldman Sachs PrimeAcces=
ssm Research  As a TD Waterhouse customer,  you now have online access to G=
oldman Sachs PrimeAccesssm  Research. Just login at tdwaterhouse.com ,  cli=
ck on 'News & Research', and then on 'Goldman Sachs'.   We  See Upswing Con=
tinuing   By Arnie Kaufman, Editor, The Outlook   Selective  accumulation r=
emains in order.  The  early stages of recoveries from bear markets vary wi=
dely in degree.  As time passes, however, deviations from the norm become f=
ar less  dramatic.   Through  last Wednesday, when we went to press early b=
ecause of the holiday,  31% of the bear market loss from March 27, 2000 to =
September 21,  2001 had been recaptured. That's about average for rebounds =
in  the postwar period. As shown in the table at the bottom right  of this =
week's edition of The Outlook, at the two-month point  in the recoveries fr=
om the nine former bear markets since World  War II, the S&P 500 had won ba=
ck an average of 33% of the  bear market loss.   In  each of the nine insta=
nces, the gain at the end of six months  was greater than that after two mo=
nths and the gain at the end  of 12 months was greater than that after six =
months. On average,  nearly two-thirds of the bear market loss was recovere=
d after  six months and almost all of the bear market loss was recouped  in=
 a year.  Economic  and corporate news will remain bad for a while, but tha=
t's typically  the case in the early part of a bull market that is associat=
ed  with an economic recession. Stock prices start recovering well  before =
the headlines improve. The September upturn in stocks would  be consistent =
with the start of an economic expansion in the first  quarter of next year.=
   While  P/E ratios currently are high, that won't necessarily keep the  b=
ull market from progressing. The preceding economic expansion  was the long=
est in history and gave rise to "new era"  optimism. Corporations, especial=
ly in information technology,  built production and sales capacity to level=
s far greater than  proved justified. Those excesses are now being correcte=
d, painfully.  Corporate earnings are in a severe contraction. Once the eco=
nomy  begins to grow again, however, profits will rebound and P/Es will  st=
art looking much more reasonable. Low inflation, low interest  rates, rapid=
 technological innovation and above-average productivity  growth should hel=
p support elevated stock valuations.   As  a TD Waterhouse customer, you ca=
n view a complete copy of S&P's  The Outlook (a $298 value) for FREE. Just =
select 'News &  Research' when you login  to yourTD Waterhouse account . Th=
e Outlook is available under 'Other  Reports.'    Why  You Should Consider =
a Margin Account  When you add margin borrowing features to your account,  =
you've got a lot of possibilities. While margin involves risk, it  also can=
 provide greater investing flexibility, a source of low-cost  borrowing and=
 a form of "overdraft protection." Click  here to learn more .  Add  Margin=
 Privileges to your Account .        Your feedback is important to us! Emai=
l us with any questions or  comments at eServices@tdwaterhouse.com       TD=
  Waterhouse Investor Services, Inc. Member NYSE/SIPC.  Access  to services=
 and your account may be affected by market conditions,  system performance=
 or for other reasons. Under no circumstances should the information  herei=
n be construed as a recommendation, offer to sell or solicitation  of an of=
fer to buy a particular security. The article and opinions  herein are obta=
ined from unaffiliated third parties and are provided  for informational pu=
rposes only. While the information is deemed  reliable, TD Waterhouse canno=
t guarantee its accuracy, completeness  or suitability for any purpose and =
makes no warranties with regard  to the results to be obtained from its use=
.   To unsubscribe  from this email, login to  your account  and select "My=
 Account' then 'My Info'. Or email us at eServices@tdwaterhouse.com     =09

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sthompson@oakridge.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakridge.edu>
Subject: RE: New Curriculum Project

Hi Emily,

Thanks for reaching out! I'm thrilled to be working with you on this exciting project. I've reviewed the list of digital tools you sent over, and I think they have great potential for enhancing our language arts curriculum. I've also added a few more resources to the shared document that I believe could be valuable.

Regarding our budget for educational software, I've started researching some options and have a few initial recommendations. I think we should prioritize tools that are user-friendly, compatible with our existing systems, and offer strong support for reading comprehension and vocabulary acquisition. Let's discuss this further when we meet next week.

I'm confident that with our combined expertise and creativity, we'll create a cutting-edge curriculum that will engage and inspire our students. I'll be in touch soon to schedule our brainstorming session.

Best,
Sarah
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@countyhealth.org>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@envirohealth.org>
Subject: RE: Finalizing project materials

Michael,

I completely agree on doing a joint presentation at the conference. It will definitely showcase our collaboration more effectively. I'll start working on an outline for the presentation and send it your way for input.

Writing a paper on our work is an excellent idea! It would be a great way to share our findings with a wider audience and potentially inspire others to take similar action in their communities. We can discuss this further once the project is launched and we've recovered from the conference.

I think we're just about ready to launch the project. I'll send out a final reminder to our contacts at the schools and community centers to ensure they're prepared to distribute the materials and promote the workshops.

Thanks for your hard work and dedication to this project. It's been a pleasure working with you!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: drjones@pawspatients.com
To: MariaHuber@gmx.de
Subject: RE: Heartworm prevention for German Shepherds

Dear Maria,

You're most welcome! I'm confident that with the right prevention and care, your future German Shepherd will lead a happy and healthy life.

I'll take care of gathering the educational materials for the pet adoption event. If you could help me set up the booth and distribute the information to the adopters, that would be fantastic. We can also create some simple flyers with key points about heartworm prevention that people can take home with them.

I'm glad to have you on board for this event. Together, we can make a real difference in the lives of pets and their owners!

Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or if there's anything else I can help you with.

Warm regards,
Dr. Sarah Jones

body:
<email>
From: Juan Hernandez <juan.hernandez@email.com>
To: Maria Rodriguez <maria.rodriguez@email.com>
Subject: RE: Interesting article on infrastructure and colonialism

Maria,

Thanks for sharing this article. It's a fascinating perspective that I haven't fully considered in my work. While I believe that infrastructure development is essential for improving quality of life, I can see how it can also perpetuate dependence if not done with the needs and desires of the community in mind.

In my current project, we've been working closely with local leaders and residents to ensure that the new roads and bridges we're building serve the community's needs and are maintained sustainably. It's a challenge, but I believe it's the right approach.

I'm curious to learn more about the history of infrastructure development in Puerto Rico and how it has influenced the current state of affairs. Maybe we can grab coffee sometime and discuss further?

Best,
Juan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Johnson <sjohnson@spaceethics.org>
To: David Thompson <dthompson@eco.space>
Subject: RE: Sustainable Space Exploration Symposium

Dear David,

I'm thrilled to hear that you'll be joining us as the keynote speaker! Your presence will undoubtedly make the symposium a success. I completely agree with you about the importance of discussing our personal connections to this work. It's often those experiences that drive our passion and dedication to finding solutions.

On a more personal note, I've been grappling with my own concerns about the future of space exploration, particularly when it comes to my child's interest in pursuing a career in the industry. I worry about the challenges they may face and the impact their work could have on the environment. I'm curious to hear your thoughts on balancing our professional and personal lives when it comes to this issue.

I'll keep you updated on the symposium's progress and will be in touch with more details as the event approaches. Thank you again for your support and participation.

Best regards,
Samantha
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <athompson@university.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: RE: Transitioning to Environmental Science

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm so glad our work together has inspired you to consider a career in environmental science. It's a field with so many opportunities to make a real difference, and I think your programming skills could be a valuable asset.

I'd be more than happy to chat with you about making the transition. My journey into environmental science was a bit unconventional, but I've found that diverse backgrounds and skill sets are often an advantage in this field. I can share some resources and introduce you to some colleagues who might be able to provide more specific guidance based on your interests.

What does your schedule look like next week? I'm free Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning if you'd like to meet for coffee and discuss this further.

Looking forward to talking with you more about this exciting next step in your career!

Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@university.edu>
To: Emily Smith <emily.smith@university.edu>
Subject: RE: New fossil site analysis

Hi Emily,

Thanks for the update. I'm equally excited about the potential of this new site. From the data you've shared, it looks like we might be able to shed some light on the evolutionary timeline of this dinosaur species. I'm particularly interested in the sedimentary structures and how they can help us understand the depositional environment.

I'm available for a video call this Friday at 2 PM if that works for you. In the meantime, I'll reach out to the paleo lab and see if they can allocate some resources to help us with the extraction and analysis.

Great work so far, Emily. This could be a game-changer for our research!

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
Message-ID: <9492096.1075855690610.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Mon, 12 Jun 2000 03:56:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: matthew.lenhart@enron.com
Subject: Thoughts on Presentation
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Matthew Lenhart
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 06/12/2000 
10:55 AM ---------------------------
   
	
	
	From:  Tim Belden                           06/11/2000 07:26 PM
	

To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Thoughts on Presentation

It is a shame that the CAISO doesn't provide actual generation by unit.  The 
WSCC data, which is dicey and we don't have until July 1999, and the CEMMS, 
which comes on a delay, are ultimately our best sources.  For your purposes 
the CAISO may suffice.  I think that you probably know this already, but 
there can be a siginificant difference between "scheduled" and "actual" 
generation.  You are pulling "scheduled."  If someone doesn't schedule their 
generation and then generates, either instructed or uninstructed, then you 
will miss that.  You may also miss generation of the northern california 
munis such as smud who only schedule their net load to the caiso.  That is, 
if they have 1500 MW of load and 1200 MW of generation, they may simply 
schedule 300 MW of load and sc transfers or imports of 300 MW.  Having said 
all of that, it is probably close enough and better than your alternatives on 
the generation side.

On the load side I think that I would simply use CAISO actual load.  While 
they don't split out NP15 from SP15, I think that using the actual number is 
better than the "scheduled" number.  The utilities play lots of game on the 
load side, usually under-scheduling depending on price.

I think the presentation looks good.  It would be useful to share this with 
others up here once you have it finished.  I'd like to see how much gas 
demand goes up with each additional GW of gas-generated electricity, 
especially compared to all gas consumption.  I was surprised by how small the 
UEG consumption was compared to other uses.  If it is the largest marginal 
consumer then it is obviously a different story.

Let's talk.
label: corporate

Would we have interest in any storage capacity in the proposed facility?

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Schwieger, Jim  
Sent:	Wednesday, June 20, 2001 10:07 AM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.
Cc:	Rainer, Eva
Subject:	FW: Crossroads Storage Project

Phillip:
I believe this is a facility that the West Desk may be interested in. 
	Thanks,  Jim

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Rainer, Eva  
Sent:	Tuesday, June 19, 2001 4:08 PM
To:	Schwieger, Jim
Cc:	Wilson, Garry D.; Bieniawski, Paul; Higgins, Ned
Subject:	Crossroads Storage Project

Jim, 

Following up on the message I left you, I thought I'd send you some of the basic information on the Crossroads project to see if you have any interest in that area:

The facility will be a high flexibility, bedded salt cavern
Initial startup is expected in summer 2002 with 2 bcf working gas, eventual rampup to 3 bcf 
75 MMCF/D injection (at 2 bcf working)
200 MMCF/D withdrawal (at 2 bcf working)
Located near Brush, Colorado, in Morgan County.
Located at far east end of PSCo system, 7 miles from CIG and 10 miles from Kinder Morgan

This is all the information I have at the moment, in addition to some maps which you are welcomed to look at.  Garry Wilson and I will be meeting with the developer in Denver on Monday, but he'd like to see if we have interest sooner than that.  I apologize for the last-minute nature of the request, but we were just hoping for an initial gauge of your interest.  

Do you have any use for this capacity?  If so, at what price?  What would your timing requirements be?  Would you have any other conditions that would increase interest in this capacity?

Thanks for your attention.  Please feel free to call me if you have any questions, I'll try following up with you tomorrow if you ahve any free time.  Thanks!

Eva Rainer
Storage Products Group
713-853-9679

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@unm.edu>
To: Michael Lee <mlee@ubc.ca>
Subject: Triassic reptile phylogeny question

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking about the phylogenetic relationships between the archosaur groups we discussed during our last call. I keep getting stuck on the placement of the suchians – do you have any new insights or ideas?

I'm attaching a draft of the phylogenetic tree we've been working on. Let me know if you have any suggestions for improvements or additional data we could include.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@oakvillehighschool.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@stemresources.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on Chemistry Educational Resources

Hi Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm excited about the possibility of collaborating with you. Your work in developing effective teaching strategies for STEM education is impressive, and I believe our combined expertise could lead to some great outcomes.

I'm glad you found my presentation interesting. I completely agree that incorporating hands-on experiments and real-world applications is crucial for engaging students in chemistry. I have some ideas that I think would work well with your approach to creating learning materials.

I'm available for a call next Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon, if that works for you. Please let me know what time suits you best.

Looking forward to our collaboration!

Best,
Michael Thompson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Amanda Patel <amanda.patel@westfieldacademy.org>
To: Rebecca Jennings <rebecca.jennings@westfieldacademy.org>
Subject: RE: Feeling a bit stuck

Hi Rebecca,

Thank you for opening up to me. I'm so glad you feel you can confide in me. I hear you 100% on the self-doubt and pushback from parents. It's something I've definitely struggled with too, especially being a young, new teacher. There have been times I've questioned whether I'm really making a difference.

But you know what? The connections we make with students, the lightbulb moments, the skills they develop - that's what really matters. Not whether we're following some arbitrary traditional model. You are an incredible teacher. Your passion and creativity are gifts to your students. Don't ever forget that.

I have so much more I want to say, but I think it'd be better discussed in person. What do you say we make a plan to get together soon? I'd love for you to come visit me at my parents' house in Springfield. It's a really charming small town and there's lots of good hiking nearby. My family would love to meet you, and I think it'd be a nice chance for us to relax and talk more. You can even stay over if you want. 

Let me know what you think! And definitely keep me posted on your Spain plans, that sounds amazing. 

You've got this, Rebecca. Don't give up on yourself. The world needs teachers like you.

Amanda
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Reynolds <olivia.reynolds@cedarvalleyastronomy.org>
To: Ethan Walters <ethan.walters@cedarvalleyastronomy.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting news about the club anniversary event!

Ethan,

That's amazing news about the transit of Venus! Your observation sounds incredible, and I'm sure our members and the public would love to hear about it at the anniversary event. Great idea!

I reached out to Dr. Novak, and she's excited to give a talk at our event. She's planning to discuss her latest research on potentially habitable exoplanets, which should be really engaging for everyone.

I'll send out a newsletter to the club members next week with updates on the event schedule and Dr. Novak's talk. Let's set up a time to meet and finalize the details for the stargazing party, too.

Looking forward to catching up and celebrating our club's 10th anniversary!

Best,
Olivia

Subject: CBS SPORTSLINE.COM FANTASY FOOTBALL NEWSLETTER
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: "CBS SportsLine.com" <noreply@ccomad3.uu.commissioner.com>@ENRON
X-To: pallen@enron.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


[IMAGE]	Fantasy Football Newsletter	
  November 16, 2001  		


	
     [IMAGE]Fantasy Sports     [IMAGE]Fantasy Football     [IMAGE]CBS SportsLine.com 	
	


  Welcome to another edition of the 2001 Fantasy Football Newsletter!      The Fantasy Football newsletter will arrive in your e-mail inbox every Friday. We'll include news about the web site; tips on using all the features available; and answers to your player-related questions from the "Gridiron Guru."   	[IMAGE]	Inside      ? Plan for the Playoffs   ? Game-by-Game Analysis   ? Gridiron Guru   ? Tip of the Week   	


 [IMAGE]  [IMAGE]  [IMAGE]  	


    Plan for the Playoffs     The Fantasy season is nearing its end, and the playoffs are on the horizon. For Fantasy 2001 players, the playoffs begin with NFL week 15 (games of Dec. 22-23) and last two weeks, with the championship game in week 16 (games of Dec. 29-30.)  If you're in a Football Commissioner league, go to Schedule, Playoffs to see when your playoffs start and how many rounds they last. Of course, the matchups are probably still not determined, so you may not see teams listed in the brackets. The commissioner of your league is responsible for adding the teams to your playoff brackets at the end of your regular season.  If your team is still in contention, go to NFL Teams, Schedule and take note of the NFL teams with byes during your playoff weeks, so you know which players will be available if - and WHEN - your team competes in a playoff matchup.  	


    Game-by-Game Analysis     Go to Players, Game Log to see how a particular player did in each game this season. The player's statistics in the common categories will be displayed for each game. If you are breaking down free agents, the game log is great way to see who's been getting the most consistent production.  	


    Gridiron Guru     Welcome to Gridiron Guru, where we'll answer your questions about players and offer Fantasy Football roster advice. We invite you to send your own scouting reports and comments on players to: gridguru@commissioner.com . You'll get the chance to be heard by thousands of Fantasy players just like yourself!   	


  Question - Mike Blake     I'm having trouble filling my No. 2 WR spot. Should I start Az-Zahir Hakim, Todd Pinkston or Muhsin Muhammad in week ten?    Answer - GG     Hakim is a hit-or-miss type, so he's risky. Pinkston has done nothing in his last four games, and he's losing playing time to Freddie Mitchell. Muhammad bounced back from a few bad performances to catch six passes for 75 yards last weekend against St. Louis, and has had some past success against this week's opponent, San Francisco. Go with Muhammad.  	


  Question - Russell Brown     My league starts 2 QBs. Donovan McNabb is one  of my starters. Who else should I start? I have Tom Brady,  Vinny Testaverde and Doug Flutie.    Answer - GG     Testaverde's Fantasy value has taken a real hit this  season because of the Jets' conservative offense. Flutie  struggled last week against a bad Denver secondary, and  won't have an easier time against Oakland. We'd suggest  playing Brady, who will start against St. Louis despite the  return of Drew Bledsoe. Brady has thrown 11 touchdowns in  his last five games, and is playing too well to bench.   	


  Question - Chris Gilcrest     Who would you start at QB this weekend: Rich  Gannon or Kerry Collins? Which one of these four RBs would  you bench: Eddie George, Michael Pittman, Mike Anderson,  Curtis Martin?     Answer - GG     Collins has the better matchup of the two QBs, but  he's far too inconsistent to start over a player like  Gannon. Oakland will be looking to bounce back from a subpar  performance against Seattle, so look for Gannon to have a  solid game. As for your second question, bench Mike  Anderson. You can't bench Martin, no matter how bad the  matchup may be. George has four touchdowns in his last three  games against Cincinnati, and is worth starting despite his  struggles this season; and Pittman's matchup against Detroit  is too good to ignore.   	


    Tip of the Week      Keith Simmons, Boulder, CO: Can Terrell Davis ever stay  healthy? He comes back and teases Fantasy owners with his  solid play over the last two weeks, only to fall prey to  another knee injury this past Sunday. He was once the best  Fantasy player in the league, but now Davis is an  unreliable, injury-prone shell of his former self.    	


  This message has been sent to pallen@enron.com, provided free of charge and free of obligation. If you prefer not to receive emails of this nature please send an email to remove@commissioner.com . Do not respond to this email directly.
label: student

For those of you that will be in the office after New Year's, we will begin an informal fundies meeting each day to cover what has happened in the market since we filed for bankruptcy.  We will go over pipeline flows, storage balances, weather, monthly and daily prices, etc. With a few of the Banks showing interest in showing a bid, I thought it would be good for us to begin our preparation to trade the market.

Chris Gaskill will be providing the daily packet and Patti Sullivan will provide the daily operations report.   

I was thinking that we should start around 9:30 each morning.

Grigsby

Hi John,

Thanks so much for the offer! I would love to take you up on the tour of your power plant. Friday at 2 pm works perfectly for me. I'm really curious to learn more about how everything works and see if there are any lessons I can apply to my own operation.

Thanks again for setting this up. I'm looking forward to it!

label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alice Thompson <athompson@university.edu>
To: Robert Smith <rsmith@college.edu>
Subject: RE: Heliocentric Theory and the Catholic Church

Dear Robert,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to share some exciting news with you regarding our research project. I recently stumbled upon a rare, unpublished manuscript while conducting research at the Vatican Secret Archives. The manuscript appears to be a letter written by a lesser-known astronomer during the Renaissance, discussing the implications of the heliocentric theory and its potential conflict with the Church's teachings.

I believe this manuscript could provide valuable insights into the relationship between science and religion during this period, and I'm eager to incorporate it into our research. I've attached a scanned copy of the manuscript for your review. Please let me know your thoughts on its potential significance and how we might use it in our project.

Looking forward to hearing from you soon!

Best regards,
Alice

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@asianartmuseum.org>
To: Michael Lee <michael.lee@buddhistartgallery.com>
Subject: Book launch event planning

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I can't believe our book is finally out. I'm so excited to share our work with the world and get feedback from our colleagues.

I was thinking about the book launch event. How about we host it at the Asian Art Museum here in San Francisco? They have a great space for events like this, and it would be a perfect fit for our book's theme. We could invite some of our colleagues from the museum and the university, as well as some local art enthusiasts and collectors.

What do you think? Let me know if you have any other ideas or suggestions.

Looking forward to hearing back from you and planning this event together!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@civilwarinstitute.org>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@historyuniversity.edu>
Subject: RE: RE: RE: RE: Paper for American Historical Review

Hi Emily,

Wednesday at the National Archives sounds perfect. I'll book a room for us to work in. 

I'm excited to finalize our paper and submit it to the American Historical Review. I really think we've put together a compelling argument that will make a significant contribution to the field.

See you next week!

Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@conservation.org>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@quantumexplorer.com>
Subject: RE: Invitation to participate in our upcoming seminar

Dear Alex,

I couldn't agree more with your sentiment about the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration and the exploration of unconventional ideas. While we may approach things from different angles, our shared passion for understanding and protecting the natural world unites us.

I believe that our seminar will be a great opportunity for all participants to learn from one another and gain new insights. I'm particularly looking forward to our discussion and the potential for a fruitful exchange of ideas.

Thank you for your willingness to engage in this dialogue and contribute to the seminar. I'm confident that your unique perspective will enrich the conversation and inspire others to think outside the box.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Chen <mchen@heartkids.org>
To: Dr. Emily Harris <eharris@triasaur.com>
Subject: RE: Reconnecting and collaboration idea

Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I have been thinking about our conversation at the conference as well, and I agree that there is great potential for collaboration between our fields. Your idea of creating interactive online modules for children is very intriguing, and I would be delighted to explore it further with you.

I believe that by combining the fascinating world of paleontology with the importance of heart health, we can create an engaging and educational experience for children that will inspire them to learn more about science and take care of their bodies. 

Please let me know when you are available for a call to discuss this further. I am excited to see where this collaboration might lead!

Best regards,
Michael
label: research

body:
Dear Professor,
 I'm having trouble grasping the concept of hypothesis testing. Could you provide some additional examples or real-world scenarios to illustrate how it's applied? I'm particularly interested in understanding the difference between the null and alternative hypotheses.
 Thank you for your time,

<email>
From: Lila Patel <lila.patel@techsolutions.com>
To: Jordan Ellis <jordan.ellis@earthscape.org>
Subject: RE: Memory Leak Issue in Java Simulation Software

Hi Jordan,

Thanks for reaching out! I've taken a look at the code and identified the cause of the memory leak. It appears that the issue is related to the way objects are being allocated and not properly garbage collected within the simulation loop.

I've provided a detailed explanation of the problem and suggested a solution in the attached document. Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to schedule a video call so I can walk you through the code and help implement the fix.

Best,
Lila
