body:
Message-ID: <32925685.1075855676912.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 24 Oct 2000 06:29:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: keith.holst@enron.com
Subject: Investment Structure
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Keith Holst
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\Discussion threads
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 10/24/2000 
01:29 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/26/2000 01:18:45 PM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net>, "Claudia L. Crocker" 
<clclegal2@aol.com> 
Subject: Investment Structure


STRUCTURE:
Typically the structure is a limited partnership with a corporate (or LLC)
general partner.  The General Partner owns 1% of the project and carries the
liability of construction.

LAND OWNERSHIP & LOANS
The property would be purchased in the name of the limited partnership and
any land loans, land improvements loans and construction loans would be in
the name of the limited partnership.  Each of the individual investors and
all of the principals in Creekside would also personally guarantee the
loans.  If the investor(s) do not sign on the loans, this generally means
that a larger amount of cash is required and the investor's share of profits
is reduced.

All loans for residential construction, that are intended for re-sale, are
full recourse loans.  If we are pursuing multifamily rental developments,
the construction loans are still full recourse but the mortgage can often be
non-recourse.

USE OF INITIAL INVESTMENT
The initial investment is used for land deposit, engineering &
architectural design, soils tests, surveys, filing fees, legal fees for
organization and condominium association formation,  and appraisals.  Unlike
many real estate investment programs, none of the funds are used for fees to
Creekside Builders, LLC.  These professional expenses will be incurred over
the estimated 6 month design and approval period.

EARLY LAND COSTS
The $4,000 per month costs listed in the cash flow as part of land cost
represent the extension fees due to the seller for up to 4 months of
extensions on closing.  As an alternative, we can close into a land loan at
probably 70% of appraised value.  With a land value equal to the purchase
price of $680,000 this would mean a land loan of $476,000 with estimated
monthly interest payments of $3,966, given a 10% annual interest rate, plus
approximately 1.25% of the loan amount for closing costs and loan fees.

EQUITY AT IMPROVEMENT LOAN
Once the site plan is approved by the City of Austin, the City will require
the development entity to post funds for fiscal improvements, referred to as
the "fiscals".  This cost represents a bond for the completion of
improvements that COA considers vital and these funds are released once the
improvements have been completed and accepted by COA.  This release will be
for 90% of the cost with the remaining 10% released one year after
completion.  Releases can be granted once every 90 days and you should
expect that the release would occur 6 months after the start of lot
improvement construction.  These fiscals are usually posted in cash or an
irrevocable letter of credit.  As such, they have to be counted as a
development cost, even though they are not spent.  Because they are not
spent no interest is charged on these funds.

The lot improvement loan is typically 75% of the appraised value of a
finished lot, which I suspect will be at least $20,000 and potentially as
high as $25,000.  This would produce a loan amount of  $15,000 on $20,000
per lot.  With estimated per lot improvement costs of $9,000, 'fiscals' at
$2,000 and the land cost at $8,000 , total improved lot cost is $19,000
which means $0 to $4,000 per lot in total equity.  The investment prior to
obtaining the improvement loan would count towards any equity requirement
provided it was for direct costs.  Thus, the additional equity for the
improvement loan would be $0-$184,000.   Even if the maximum loan would
cover all costs, it is unlikely the bank would allow reimbursement of funds
spent. The higher estimates of equity investments are shown in the
preliminary proforma to be on the safe side.  The engineer is preparing a
tentative site layout with an initial evaluation of the phasing, which can
significantly reduce the cash equity requirement.

Phasing works as follows.  If the first phase was say 40 units, the total
lot improvement cost might average $31,000 per lot.   Of this, probably
$13,000 would be for improvements and $19,000 for the land cost.  The
improvements are higher to cover large one time up front costs for design
costs, the entry road, water treatment costs, perimeter fencing and
landscaping, and so on, as well as for 100% of the land.  The land loan for
undeveloped lots would be 70% of the appraised raw lot value, which I would
estimate as $10,000 per lot for a loan value of $7,000 per lot.  Then the
loan value for each improved lot would be $15,000 per lot.  This would give
you a total loan of $992,000, total cost of $1,232,645 for equity required
of $241,000.  This was not presented in the initial analysis as the phasing
is depended on a more careful assessment by the Civil Engineer as the
separate phases must each be able to stand on its own from a utility
standpoint.

CONSTRUCTION LOANS
There are three types of  construction loans.  First, is a speculative
(spec) loan that is taken out prior to any pre-sales activity.  Second,  is
a construction loan for a pre-sold unit, but the loan remains in the
builder/developers name.  Third, is a pre-sold unit with the construction
loan in the name of the buyer.  We expect to have up to 8 spec loans to
start the project and expect all other loans to be pre-sold units with loans
in the name of the builder/developer.  We do not expect to have any
construction loans in the name of the buyers, as such loans are too
difficult to manage and please new buyers unfamiliar with the process.

Spec loans will be for 70% to 75% of value and construction loans for
pre-sold units, if the construction loan is from the mortgage lender,  will
be from 80% to 95% of value.

DISBURSEMENTS
Disbursements will be handled by the General Partner to cover current and
near term third party costs, then to necessary reserves, then to priority
payments and then to the partners per the agreement.  The General Partner
will contract with Creekside Builders, LLC to construct the units and the
fee to CB will include a construction management and overhead fee equal to
15% of the direct hard cost excluding land, financing and sales costs.
These fees are the only monies to Creekside, Larry Lewter or myself prior to
calculation of profit, except for a) direct reimbursement for partnership
expenses and b) direct payment to CB for any subcontractor costs that it has
to perform.  For example, if CB cannot find a good trim carpenter sub, or
cannot find enough trim carpenters, etc., and it decides to undertake this
function, it will charge the partnership the same fee it was able to obtain
from third parties and will disclose those cases to the partnership.
Finally, CB will receive a fee for the use of any of its equipment if it is
used in lieu of leasing equipment from others.  At present CB does not own
any significant equipment, but it is considering the purchase of a sky track
to facilitate and speed up framing, cornice, roofing and drywall spreading.

REPORTING
We are more than willing to provide reports to track expenses vs. plan.
What did you have in mind?  I would like to use some form of internet based
reporting.

BOOKKEEPING
I am not sure what you are referring to by the question, "Bookkeeping
procedures to record actual expenses?"  Please expand.

INVESTOR INPUT
We are glad to have the investor's input on design and materials.  As always
the question will be who has final say if there is disagreement, but in my
experience I have always been able to reach consensus. As you, and I presume
Keith, want to be involved to learn as much as possible we would make every
effort to be accommodating.

CREEKSIDE PROCEEDURES
CB procedures for dealing with subs, vendors and professionals is not as
formal as your question indicates.  In the EXTREMELY tight labor market
obtaining 3 bids for each labor trade is not feasible.  For the professional
subs we use those with whom we have developed a previous rapport.  Finally,
for vendors they are constantly shopped.

PRE-SELECTED PROFESSIONALS, SUBS AND VENDORS
Yes there are many different subs that have been identified and I can
provide these if you are interested.

I know I have not answered everything, but this is a starting point.  Call
when you have reviewed and we can discuss further.

Sincerely,

George Richards
President, Creekside Builders, LLC




 - winmail.dat
label: student

body:
Message-ID: <14585828.1075855716009.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Mon, 5 Mar 2001 22:56:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
Subject: 
Cc: llewter@austin.rr.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: llewter@austin.rr.com
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
X-cc: llewter@austin.rr.com
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\Sent
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

George,

I am back in the office and ready to focus on the project.  I still have
the concerns that I had last week.  Specifically that the costs of our
project are too high.  I have gathered more information that support my
concerns.  Based on my research, I believe the project should cost around
$10.5 million.  The components are as follows:

     Unit Cost, Site work, &
     builders profit($52/sf)             $7.6 million

     Land                      1.15

     Interim Financing               .85

     Common Areas                     .80

     Total                         $10.4

Since Reagan's last 12 units are selling for around $190,000, I am unable
to get comfortable building a larger project at over $95,000/unit in costs.

Also, the comps used in the appraisal from Austin appear to be class A
properties.  It seems unlikely that student housing in San Marcos can
produce the same rent or sales price.  There should adjustments for
location and the seasonal nature of student rental property.  I recognize
that Sagewood is currently performing at occupancy and $/foot rental rates
that are closer to the appraisal and your pro formas, however, we do not
believe that the market will sustain these levels on a permanent basis.
Supply will inevitablely increase to drive this market more in balance.

After the real estate expert from Houston reviewed the proforma and cost
estimates, his comments were that the appraisal is overly optimistic.  He
feels that the permanent financing would potentially be around $9.8
million.  We would not even be able to cover the interim financing.

Keith and I have reviewed the project thoroughly and are in agreement that
we cannot proceed with total cost estimates significantly above $10.5
million.   We would like to have a conference call Tuesday afternoon to 
discuss
alternatives.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Michael Johnson <mjohnson@usgs.gov>
To: Emily Davis <edavis@uw.edu>
Subject: RE: Fingers crossed for our Cascadia proposal!

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I've definitely been thinking a lot about our proposal and the potential for some exciting fieldwork. I'm glad you were able to get it submitted without any hiccups.

I'm really keen to get back out there and collect some new data. There's still so much we don't understand about the seismic hazards in that region, and I think our collaboration could lead to some important discoveries.

I'll be eagerly awaiting any news from the NSF. In the meantime, let's plan to catch up soon, maybe over a virtual coffee? It would be great to chat more about our respective projects and how they might intersect with the Cascadia work.

All the best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Johnson <samantha.johnson@earlyamericanhistory.org>
To: David Thompson <david.thompson@jacksonianera.com>
Subject: Following up from the AHA conference

Hi David,

It was great meeting you at the American Historical Association conference last month. I really enjoyed our conversation about the political developments in the early 19th century and the impact of the War of 1812 on American politics. Your presentation on Andrew Jackson's presidency was fascinating, and it got me thinking about the continuities and changes in American political culture during this period.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in staying in touch and perhaps collaborating on a project that explores these themes further. I'm currently working on an article about the Federalist Party's strategies during the War of 1812, and I think your insights on the Jacksonian era could help me situate my research within the broader historical context.

Let me know if you're up for a chat or a virtual coffee sometime soon.

Best regards,
Samantha

To: Casey Brennan <casey.brennan@urbanforests.org>
Subject: RE: Website feedback from the grant committee

Hi Casey,

Thanks for reaching out. I had a chance to review the feedback from the grant committee, and I think we can definitely make some improvements to the website to make it more engaging and interactive.

One idea I had was to incorporate more multimedia elements, such as videos and audio descriptions of the different urban forests we're featuring. We could also add interactive maps that allow users to explore the different green spaces in the city and learn more about their ecological importance.

I'd be happy to set up a meeting with you to discuss these ideas further and come up with a plan for revamping the website. Let me know what works best for your schedule.

Looking forward to working together on this project!

Best,
Jordan

Hi Emily,

It's so great to hear from you! Thank you for sending the article, I just finished reading it and found it incredibly insightful. The history of genetics is truly fascinating, and it's amazing to see how far we've come.

I would love to meet up with you while you're in town! It would be fantastic to catch up and discuss the article in more detail. body:
<email>
From: Michael Chen <michael.chen@eslprofessor.net>
To: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@eslteacher.com>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Sarah,

Thank you for reaching out! It's great to hear from you. I'm glad you found our conversation at the conference interesting and valuable.

Regarding your question about incorporating conversational practice into a unit about grocery shopping, I have a few ideas. One activity I've found effective is a role-play where students work in pairs to practice asking and answering questions about grocery items, prices, and quantities. Another idea is to have students create a dialogue or short skit about a shopping scenario, which they can then perform for the class.

I'd be happy to share more ideas and collaborate on developing some lesson plans together. Let me know if you're interested!

Best,
Michael

Gentlemen,

Today I finally received some information on the status of the work done to 
date.  I spoke to Hugo Alexandro at Cuatro Consultants.  The property is 
still in two parcels.  Hugo has completed a platt to combine into one  lot 
and is ready to submit it to the city of San Marcos.  He has also completed a 
topographical survey and a tree survey.  In addition, he has begun to 
coordinate with the city on the replatting and a couple of easements on the 
smaller parcel, as well as, beginning the work on the grading.  Hugo is going 
to fax me a written letter of the scope of work he has been engaged to 
complete.  The total cost of his services are estimated at $38,000 of which 
$14,000 are due now for work completed.  

We are trying to resolve the issues of outstanding work and bills incurred by 
the original developer so we can obtain the title to the land.  If we can 
continue to use Cuatro then it would be one less point of contention.  Hugo's 
number is 512-295-8052.  I thought you might want to contact him directly and 
ask him some questions.  I spoke to him about the possibility of your call 
and he was fine with that.  

Now we are going to try and determine if any of the work performed by Kipp 
Flores can be used.

Keith and I appreciate you meeting with us on Sunday.  We left very 
optimistic about the prospect of working with you on this project.

Call me with feedback after you speak to Hugo or with any other ideas about 
moving this project forward.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Hans Müller <hans.mueller@germangrammarpro.com>
To: Elisabeth Schneider <elisabeth.schneider@germanlinguist.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking recommendations for Berlin language conference

Hallo Elisabeth,

It's great to hear from you, and I'm thrilled that you'll be visiting Berlin for the conference! The city has so much to offer, and I'm happy to share some recommendations with you.

As for must-see attractions, you should definitely visit the Brandenburg Gate, Reichstag Building, and the East Side Gallery. These landmarks are not only historically significant but also visually stunning. For a unique perspective on the city, I recommend taking a river cruise along the Spree.

When it comes to dining, Berlin has an incredible food scene. Some of my personal favorites are:

1. Horváth: A Michelin-starred restaurant serving modern Austrian cuisine.
2. Nobelhart & Schmutzig: Known for its focus on local, seasonal ingredients.
3. Mustafa's Gemüse Kebap: A popular street food stand in the Kreuzberg neighborhood, famous for its delicious kebabs.

As for networking events during the conference, there will be a welcome reception on the first evening, which is a great opportunity to meet fellow attendees. Additionally, many attendees gather at the nearby biergarten after the conference sessions. I'll be there too, so let's catch up in person!

I hope this information helps you plan your trip. If you have any more questions, feel free to reach out. I look forward to seeing you in Berlin!

Best wishes,
Hans Müller

To: Olivia Nguyen <olivia.nguyen@ridgemont.edu>
Subject: RE: New Chemistry Curriculum - Lab Activities

Olivia,

Thanks for sharing those resources! I'll take a look and see if we can incorporate some of those ideas into our lab activities. I'm glad you're making progress on the assessment plan and rubrics. I think it's crucial that we align our assessments with the learning objectives and ensure they are measuring the skills and knowledge we want our students to develop.

I agree that we should discuss formative assessments. I was thinking about incorporating some interactive simulations and quizzes using the new learning management system we're implementing. It could be a great way to track student progress and provide immediate feedback.

I've been working on the lesson plans for the first few chapters, and I'll send them your way for review soon. I'm excited to see how everything is coming together!

Talk to you soon,
Ethan

<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@ridgemont.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@ridgemont.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on Urbanization and Climate Change Project

Hi Michael,

Thank you so much for the suggestions! The World Bank dataset and MapBox tool sound perfect for what I'm trying to accomplish. I really appreciate you sharing those resources.

I love the idea of co-teaching a lesson on demographic analysis and population trends. It would be great for the students to have access to your expertise. In fact, I was thinking we could take this collaboration a step further.

What if we designed a joint assignment where students from both our classes work together on a research project examining the impact of population growth on climate change in a specific city or region? They could use the datasets and tools we introduce in the lesson to conduct their analysis.

If you're on board, I'd be happy to work with you to design the assignment and assess the students' work.

Let me know what you think!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@inclusiveschools.org>
To: Jenna Thompson <jenna.thompson@dhhedconsultant.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on creating an inclusive environment

Hi Jenna,

It sounds like you're off to a great start in your new role! Your plans for building relationships and providing professional development are exactly the right approach. 

In terms of specific strategies, one thing I've found effective is to use a Universal Design for Learning (UDL) framework. UDL is all about designing instruction and environments that are accessible and engaging for all learners from the start, rather than trying to retrofit accommodations after the fact. There are some great resources available from CAST, the organization that developed the UDL framework, that could be really helpful for your trainings.

Another strategy that's worked well for me is to establish a clear protocol for identifying and addressing barriers to access and inclusion. This could involve regular audits of classrooms and school facilities, as well as soliciting feedback from students, parents, and teachers about any challenges they're experiencing. The key is to have a systematic way of identifying issues and then collaboratively developing solutions.

In terms of challenges, one of the biggest hurdles I've faced is resistance to change from some stakeholders who are comfortable with the status quo. In those situations, I've found it helpful to focus on building relationships and finding common ground, while also being clear and direct about the needs of our students and the legal requirements we must meet.

I'm happy to share more about my experiences and strategies in future emails. I'm also excited to hear about the progress you make in your new role and to support you however I can!
Best,
Alex

From: Emily Nguyen <emily@midlandhistory.org>
To: Dr. Ryan Patel <ryan.patel@petrotex.com>
Subject: Speaking invitation for Heritage Days festival

Hi Ryan,

I hope you're doing well and not working too hard! I wanted to reach out because I'm on the planning committee for this year's Heritage Days festival, and I think it would be great if you could give a talk. Specifically, we're looking for someone to speak about the recent shale oil boom and its impact from a geologist's perspective.

I know your schedule is crazy busy, but I really think our audience would find your insights fascinating. Even a short 20-30 minute talk would be great. Please let me know if you'd be willing and able to participate. The festival is the second weekend of October.

Looking forward to hearing back from you and hopefully seeing you there!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Sanjay Patel <sanjay.patel@university.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@college.edu>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference

Emily,

Thank you for sharing your syllabus. I'm impressed by the depth and breadth of the material you cover in your course. It's fascinating to see how the interpretation of foundational documents has evolved over time in response to social justice issues in the United States.

Your course reminded me of a book I recently read titled "The Evolution of Civil Rights: Exploring the Intersection of Law and Social Change" by Dr. Lila Gupta. I think you might find it relevant to your work, as it examines the interplay between legal frameworks and social movements in advancing civil rights.

I'm also intrigued by the idea of comparing our respective approaches to teaching about historical conflicts. In my courses, I often emphasize the role of colonial legacies and modern geopolitics in shaping the Kashmir conflict. I wonder if there are parallels to be drawn with the role of historical documents and social movements in the American context.

I would be interested in exploring potential collaboration opportunities, perhaps in the form of a comparative analysis or a co-taught course.

Sanjay
label: research

----- Forwarded by Susan J Mara/NA/Enron on 01/30/2001 10:02 AM -----

=09"Daniel Douglass" <Douglass@ArterHadden.com>

=20
<curt.Hatton@gen.pge.com>, <foothill@lmi.net>, <camiessn@newwestenergy.com>=
,=20
<jcgardin@newwestenergy.com>, <jsmollon@newwestenergy.com>,=20
<rsnichol@newwestenergy.com>, <Curtis_L_Kebler@reliantenergy.com>,=20
<rllamkin@seiworldwide.com>
=09=09 cc:=20
=09=09 Subject: CPUC Audit Report on Edison

The following are the highlights from the Executive Summary of the KPMG aud=
it=20
report on Southern California Edison:
=20
I. Cash Needs
Highlights:
SCE=01,s original cash forecast, dated as December 28, 2000, projects a com=
plete=20
cash depletion date of February 1, 2001. Since then SCE has instituted a=20
program of cash conservation that includes suspension of certain obligation=
s=20
and other measures.=20
Based on daily cash forecasts and cash conservation activities, SCE=01,s=20
available cash improved through January 19 from an original estimate of $51=
.8=20
million to $1.226 billion. The actual cash flow, given these cash=20
conservation activities, extends the cash depletion date.
II. Credit Relationships
Highlights:
SCE has exercised all available lines of credit and has not been able to=20
extend or renew credit as it has become due.
At present, there are no additional sources of credit open to SCE.
SCE=01,s loan agreements provide for specific clauses with respect to defau=
lt.=20
Generally, these agreements provide for the debt becoming immediately due a=
nd=20
payable.
SCE=01,s utility plant assets are used to secure outstanding mortgage bond=
=20
indebtedness, although there is some statutory capacity to issue more=20
indebtedness if it were feasible to do so.
Credit ratings agencies have downgraded SCE=01,s credit ratings on most of =
its=20
rated indebtedness from solid corporate ratings to below investment grade=
=20
issues within the last three weeks.
III. Energy Cost Scenarios
Highlights
This report section uses different CPUC supplied assumptions to assess=20
various price scenarios upon SCE=01,s projected cash depletion dates. Under=
 such=20
scenarios, SCE would have a positive cash balance until March 30, 2001.
IV. Cost Containment Initiatives
Highlights
SCE has adopted a $460 million Cost Reduction Plan for the year 2001.
The Plan consists of an operation and maintenance component and a capital=
=20
improvement component as follows (in millions):
Operating and maintenance costs     $ 77
Capital Improvement Costs                383
Total                                             $ 460
The Plan provides for up to 2,000 full, part-time and contract positions to=
=20
be eliminated with approximately 75% of the total staff reduction coming fr=
om=20
contract employees.
Under the Plan, Capital Improvement Costs totaling $383 million are for the=
=20
most part being deferred to a future date.
SCE dividends to its common shareholder and preferred stockholders and=20
executive bonuses have been suspended, resulting in an additional cost=20
savings of approximately $92 million.
V. Accounting Mechanisms to Track Stranded Cost Recovery (TRA and TCBA=20
Activity)
Highlights:
As of December 31, 2000, SCE reported an overcollected balance in the=20
Transition Cost Balancing Account (TCBA) Account of $494.5 million. This=20
includes an estimated market valuation of its hydro facilities of $500=20
million and accelerated revenues of $175 million.
As of December 31, 2000, SCE reported an undercollected balance in SCE=01,s=
=20
Transition Account (TRA) of $4.49 billion.
Normally, the generation memorandum accounts are credited to the TCBA at th=
e=20
end of each year. However, the current generation memorandum account credit=
=20
balance of $1.5 billion has not been credited to the TCBA, pursuant to=20
D.01-01-018.
Costs of purchasing generation are tracked in the TRA and revenues from=20
generation are tracked in the TCBA. Because these costs and revenues are=20
tracked separately, the net liability from procuring electric power, as=20
expressed in the TRA, are overstated.
TURN Proposal
As part of our review, the CPUC asked that we comment on the proposal of TU=
RN=20
to change certain aspects of the regulatory accounting for transition asset=
s.=20
Our comments are summarized as follows:
The Proposal would have no direct impact on the cash flows of SCE in that i=
t=20
would not directly generate nor use cash.
The Proposal=01,s impact on SCE=01,s balance sheet would initially be to sh=
ift=20
costs between two regulatory assets.
TURN=01,s proposal recognizes that because the costs of procuring power and=
 the=20
revenues from generating power are tracked separately, the undercollection =
in=20
the TRA is overstated.
VI. Flow of Funds Analysis
Highlights:
In the last five years, SCE had generated net income of $2.7 billion and a=
=20
positive cash flow from operations of $7 billion.
During the same time period, SCE paid dividends and other distributions to=
=20
its parent, Edison International, of approximately $4.8 billion.
Edison International used the funds from dividends to pay dividends to its=
=20
shareholders of $1.6 billion and repurchased shares of its outstanding comm=
on=20
stock of $2.7 billion, with the remaining funds being used for administrati=
ve=20
and general costs, investments, and other corporate purposes.
[there is no Section VII]
=20
VIII. Earnings of California Affiliates
SCE=01,s payments for power to its affiliates were approximately $400-$500=
=20
million annually and remained relatively stable from 1996 through 1999.=20
In 2000, the payments increased by approximately 50% to over $600 million.=
=20
This increase correlates to the increase in market prices
for natural gas for the same period.
A copy of the report is available on the Commission website at=20
www.cpuc.ca.gov.
=20
Dan

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Smith <jenna.smith@nursing.edu>
To: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@biologyuniversity.edu>
Subject: RE: Draft of my guest post - "My Journey in Respiratory Physiology"

Hi Alex,

Thank you for sending over the draft of your guest post. I had a chance to read through it, and I think you've done a fantastic job! Your writing is clear and engaging, and you've included some great personal anecdotes and insights.

I have a few minor suggestions for revisions, which I've noted in the attached document. Overall, though, I think this post will be a great addition to my blog and will resonate with our readers.

Once you've had a chance to review and incorporate my feedback, please send the revised draft back to me. I'll then give it a final review and let you know when it's scheduled to be published.

Thank you again for your hard work on this post. I'm confident that our readers will find your journey and insights valuable and inspiring.

Best regards,
Jenna Smith, RN

body:
<email>
From: Alexei Ivanov <alexei.ivanov@spbhistory.ru>
To: Maria Petrova <maria.petrova@spbhistory.ru>
Subject: Alaska Purchase Exhibit - Educational Component

Maria,

I hope you're doing well. As you know, I'm currently working on a new exhibit about the Alaska Purchase and its impact on Russo-American relations. I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on an interactive educational component for children visiting the exhibit.

I think your expertise in creating engaging science content for kids could be invaluable in making this historical event more accessible and exciting for younger audiences. Perhaps we could create a game or a hands-on activity that demonstrates the geographical and cultural significance of the Alaska Purchase.

Let me know if you have any ideas or if you'd like to discuss this further. I'd be happy to meet and brainstorm together.

Best regards,
Alexei

i actually started writing this on thursday.  got distracted and left late 
morning to go to Vail.  Apparently I missed a little craziness.  My point on 
v/x is that forward spreads, months 3/4 and back, don't necessarily trade on 
value, they trade on drawing a forward curve that makes equilibrium between 
hedging and spec demand.  Look at k/m... do you think k cash will average 3 
cents above m.  i don't really see that scenario.  yet that's what it is 
worth because the market says jv is worth $x and to get there k/m=3.  The 
same argument applies to v/x.  i think this summer will be exceptionally 
strong as we try to inject 2 bcf/d more gas than last year.  But cal 2 will 
lag the move.  It's the main thing customers are selling right now because 
every equity analyst and even Pira are telling their customers that cal 2 
will average 3.50.  so either the v/x and x/z spreads come in or f/g g/h h/j 
blow out.  After this winter, who in there right mind wants to buy f/g or g/h 
again.  my thought is that the primary juice will be h/j but v/x and x/z will 
be under some pressure.  i'm a seller at 9 and buyer at 5-6.  Not much in it 
either way though.

body:
<email>
From: Eleanor McDougall <eleanor.mcdougall@orkneyarchaeology.org>
To: Finn Mackenzie <finn.mackenzie@volcanostudies.com>
Subject: RE: Neolithic Burial Site in the Orkneys

Finn,

I'm thrilled that we'll be able to connect on Tuesday afternoon. I've sent you a calendar invite for the call, and I'll include the relevant files and data in advance so you can review them beforehand.

Your idea to consult with a paleoclimatologist is brilliant. Understanding the environmental context of the site will undoubtedly provide crucial insights into the lives of the Neolithic people and how they adapted to the challenges posed by the volcanic eruption and changing climate.

I've been giving some thought to the potential impact of the eruption on the surrounding landscape, and I believe it could have had a significant effect on the placement and design of the burial site. The presence of volcanic ash and other deposits in the area may have influenced the choice of burial locations and the materials used in the construction of the tombs.

I'm also curious to explore any potential ritual or symbolic significance the Neolithic people may have attributed to the volcanic event. It's possible that the eruption and its aftermath played a role in their spiritual beliefs and burial practices.

I'll be sure to include these thoughts in our discussion on Tuesday, and I look forward to hearing your perspective on these ideas.

Thank you again for your collaboration and enthusiasm, Finn. I have no doubt that our combined expertise will lead to a groundbreaking understanding of this remarkable site and the people who lived through such a transformative event.

Best regards,
Eleanor

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <ajohnson@university.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Davis <edavis@university.edu>
Subject: Seeking advice on cache memory optimization project

Dear Dr. Davis,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Alex Johnson, and I am a student in your Mathematical Problem-Solving in Computer Science course. I am currently working on a project related to cache memory optimization in computer architecture, and I was hoping to seek your advice on how to approach the problem using mathematical modeling techniques.

I have been struggling to find an effective way to model the behavior of cache memories and optimize their performance. I believe that your expertise in mathematical modeling and problem-solving could provide valuable insights into this challenge.

Would it be possible to schedule a meeting with you to discuss my project in more detail? I would greatly appreciate any guidance you could offer.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Best regards,
Alex Johnson

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@healthnews.com>
To: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@econocollege.edu>
Subject: RE: Thoughts on the latest COVID-19 economic data?

Hi Emily,

Great to hear from you! I'm glad the class went well and that the students found it valuable. I'd definitely be interested in discussing the latest economic data with you further.

In terms of the new variants, it's a bit of a mixed bag. On one hand, the increased transmissibility is concerning from a public health perspective. But from an economic standpoint, the fact that they seem to be leading to fewer hospitalizations and deaths is a positive sign.

I'm also very interested in moving forward with that research paper idea. I think there's a lot of potential there to explore the cost-effectiveness of different containment strategies. Let me know when you're available to brainstorm next steps.

Looking forward to catching up more soon!

Best,
Alex
label: research

There have been some updates to the cost.  The principal change is in the
addition of masonry on the front of the buildings, which I estimate will
costs at least $84,000 additional.  Also, the trim material and labor costs
have been increased.  I still believe that the total cost is more than
sufficient, but there will be additional updates.

The manager's unit is columns J-L, but the total is not included in the B&N
total of rentable units.  Rather, the total cost for the manager's unit and
office is included as a lump sum under amenities.  I may add this back in as
a rentable unit and delete is as an amenity.

The financing cost has been changed in that the cost of the permanent
mortgage has been deleted because we will not need to obtain this for the
construction loan approval, therefore, its cost will be absorbed when this
loan is obtained.

Based on either a loan equal to 75% of value or 80% of cost, the
construction profit should cover any equity required beyond the land.

George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Steinman <olivia.steinman@marineconservation.org>
To: Ethan Chen <ethan.chen@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Request for Python programming assistance with whale migration data analysis

Dear Ethan,

Thank you so much for your enthusiastic response! I am thrilled to have your expertise on board for this project. Your experience with Python libraries and machine learning will be invaluable in helping us uncover the full potential of the data we have collected.

I have attached a sample of the satellite data we have gathered, which includes information on the migration routes of humpback, gray, and blue whales over the past five years. Our primary research questions include:

1. Identifying key migration routes and timing for each species
2. Investigating potential environmental factors influencing migration patterns (e.g., sea surface temperature, prey availability)
3. Assessing potential threats to whale populations along their migration routes (e.g., shipping lanes, coastal development)

I would be happy to have a call next week to discuss these questions in more detail and begin planning our analysis. I am available Tuesday after 2 PM or Wednesday any time. Please let me know what works best for you.

Once again, I am excited to collaborate with you on this project and look forward to combining our skills to make a meaningful impact on whale conservation.

Best regards,
Olivia Steinman
Marine Biologist
Marine Conservation Organization

body:
<email>
From: Alex Ramirez <aramirez@urbanmigration.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@environmentaledu.org>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on Climate Change Lesson

Hi Emily,

The week after next works great for me! I think your lecture will be a fantastic supplement to the lessons we've been doing on migration and urbanization. Please do send over the outline whenever you have a chance.

I took a look at the lesson plan you sent and I think it looks really strong! You've done a great job incorporating the resources and making the connections between climate change and human impacts clear. One suggestion I had was to maybe include a section on potential solutions or actions individuals can take to mitigate the effects of climate change. I think that could empower your students and give them a sense of agency.

I'm looking forward to our continued collaboration and to your guest lecture!

Best,
Alex

Learn Technical Analysis
Two Full Days, December 4-5, 2001 
Early Bird Discount Until October 31, 2001
 [IMAGE]
 Marriott West Loop, Houston, Texas 
Energy Traders, Marketers and Buyers.   This two full day class serves as both an introduction to those new to technical analysis and a refresher for experienced traders. Technicals are taught in a logical, systematic manner oriented to equip both physical and paper traders to buy low, sell high and manage risk in the real world in a logical, methodical manner.  	


 

 In this class you will:   Ascertain when and how to take profit and cut losses.  Find out how to set up a strategy by identifying probable market direction and turns as well as likely targets using chart patterns.  Learn to use both traditional indicators like moving averages and stochastics, as well the state-of-the-art methods which won Cynthia Kase the coveted Market Technicians Association's "Best of the Best" award.  	 Content   Charting Basics, Types of Charts, Support and Resistance  When to Buy or Sell (Entry Techniques)  When to Exit Based on Signals (Momentum and Divergence)  How to Exit Based on Stops (Managing Trade Risk)  Chart Patterns and Forecasting Basics (Candlesticks, Elliott  Wave, Flags, etc.)  Statistical Hedging  	


 Early Bird Special $845.00 Two or More Early Bird $795.00 Regular: $995.00 Two or More: $895.00	 *** Register Now! ***      Click Here for More Information   About the Presenters   Who Should Attend  Detailed Agenda and Schedule  Other Classes Offered By Kase 	   [IMAGE] Kase and Company also offers In House Training Classes. For more information please email us at kase@kaseco.com  or call at (505) 237-1600

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@hillsideacademy.com>
To: Dr. Michael Russo <michael.russo@learncorp.com>
Subject: RE: Strategies for kinesthetic learners

Dear Dr. Russo,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to thank you again for the valuable insights you shared during our panel discussion at the Special Education Conference last month. Your expertise in individualized learning strategies for kinesthetic learners was truly inspiring.

I've been implementing some of the techniques we discussed, such as incorporating more hands-on activities and group projects into my lessons. I've noticed a significant improvement in my students' engagement and comprehension. I would love to hear about any new strategies you've been exploring recently.

Additionally, I've been giving some thought to pursuing a career in educational psychology. I believe it would allow me to have a greater impact on the lives of students with diverse learning needs. I would greatly appreciate any advice or guidance you could offer.

I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Best regards,
Emily

<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@email.com>
To: Alex Chen <alex.chen@email.com>
Subject: Chemistry exam help

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out because I have a chemistry exam coming up next week, and I could really use your help. We've been working together for a while now, and your explanations have been so helpful in improving my understanding of the subject.

Would you be available for a study session this weekend? I'd really appreciate if we could go over some of the key concepts that will be on the exam, like stoichiometry, the periodic table, and chemical reactions. I've attached some practice problems that my teacher gave us to work on.

Let me know if you have time to help me out. I'm feeling pretty confident, but I want to make sure I'm fully prepared for the exam.

Thanks in advance,
Sarah

Looks like we are dead in the water based on this message and the one Glenn 
got. Let's meet to review this morning.

-------------------------------------------------------------
Gary Waxman
Director, Enterprise Group
Enron Broadband Services
2100 SW River Parkway
Portland, OR 97201
Mobile: 503-807-8923
Desk:   503-886-0196
Fax:     503-886-0441
-------------------------------------------------------------
----- Forwarded by Gary Waxman/Enron Communications on 12/15/00 08:32 AM -----

	curtis.meyer@sap.com
	12/15/00 05:54 AM
		 
		 To: Gary Waxman/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: 
		 Subject: FW: SAP information for your proposal



Gary,
   FYI....

-----Original Message-----
From: Bruder, Dietmar
Sent: Friday, December 15, 2000 6:44 AM
To: Meyer, Curtis
Cc: Lingner, Annett
Subject: RE: SAP information for your proposal


Hello Curtis,

sorry for the late response.
An upgrade from E1 to E3 is not an option for the mentioned locations, for
the foreseeable future.
The 2. proposal is also not an option for us, because we buy bandwidth on
demand and the demands change very dynamically, therefore such a plan would
not fit our requirements.

best regards Dietmar

-----------------------


-----Original Message-----
From: Meyer, Curtis
Sent: Montag, 11. Dezember 2000 17:22
To: Bruder, Dietmar
Cc: Gooden, Dennis; Bannon, Michael
Subject: FW: SAP information for your proposal
Importance: High


Dietmar,
   Attached is a message from Enron Broadband Services on sizing the
proposal back to SAP.
Hopefully his attached message is clear in terms of finding a way to
structure it
for growth based on your needs.  This would increase the size of our
arrangement if it
makes good sense for you.  Please get back to me with your thoughts.

-----Original Message-----
From: Gary_Waxman@enron.net [mailto:Gary_Waxman@enron.net]
Sent: Friday, December 08, 2000 2:19 PM
To: Meyer, Curtis
Cc: Glenn_Surowiec@enron.net; Matt_Harris@enron.net
Subject: Re: SAP information for your proposal




Curtis - following our phone call this morning I met with Matt Harris and
our
structuring person (Glenn Surowiec) to review the deal. After some quick
analysis it looks like we overestimated the opportunity.

The circuits Dietmar is requesting is a european E1 which equates to a US
T1.
The hub (Wallfdorf) -and-spoke (Hungary, Netherlands, UK) model SAP requires
works out to roughly a $2.09M deal.

Clearly this is smaller than both parties would prefer.Thus we would like to
know if there are growth plans for one or more of these connections so that
we
can we propose a larger pipe (i.e. European E3/US DS3).

For example if just one of the connections can be an E3 for the entire
contract
(ten years) it would bump the value up to $8.5M. Please review this and
let's
plan on talking later today. Another model to consider would be to
progressively
bump up the pipe size across all the connections at set intervals (i.e.
years
1-3 = E1, years 4-6 = E2, years 7-10 = E3).

Please let me know what your thoughts are and let's talk ASAP.

-------------------------------------------------------------
Gary Waxman
Director, Enterprise Group
Enron Broadband Services
2100 SW River Parkway
Portland, OR 97201
Mobile: 503-807-8923
Desk:   503-886-0196
Fax:     503-886-0441

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Chen <mchen@skinoncology.com>
To: Samantha Smith <samantha.smith@oncologynews.com>
Subject: RE: Interview Request for Article on New Melanoma Treatment

Dear Samantha,

Thank you for reaching out, and it's great to hear from you again. I remember our brief interaction at the conference last year and appreciate your interest in our work.

I would be happy to provide an interview for your article on the new melanoma treatment. As one of the lead researchers on the clinical trial, I can share insights into the treatment's mechanism of action, its potential benefits, and the next steps for further research and development.

I'm available for a phone interview next week, either on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning. Please let me know which time works best for you, and feel free to send me any specific questions you have in advance.

I also noticed that you mentioned a passion for hiking and camping in your email signature. My wife and I are planning a hiking trip in the Rocky Mountains next month. Do you have any favorite spots or trails you'd recommend?

I look forward to our interview and to sharing more about our exciting research.

Best regards,
Dr. Michael Chen
Skin Oncology Research Institute
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: Robert Thompson <rthompson@college.edu>
Subject: RE: Following up from the conference

Dear Robert,

Thank you for your feedback on my draft and for sharing your outline for our discussion. I have reviewed your comments and found them to be extremely helpful. I think your suggestions will strengthen the paper and help us to better integrate our research.

I have also looked over your outline and agree that the points you have listed are crucial for our collaboration. I have added a few additional topics that I think we should cover during our meeting:

1. The role of Galileo's trial in shaping the public perception of the heliocentric theory
2. The impact of the Protestant Reformation on the reception of the heliocentric theory in different European regions
3. Potential implications of our research for contemporary debates about science and religion

I look forward to discussing these topics and more during our video conference on Wednesday.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
label: research

=09     AXP   29.17 -0.15    American Express Company Reports Third Quarter=
 Net Income of $298 Million=1D(millions, except per share amounts) Quarter =
Percentage Nine Percentage Ended Inc/ Months Inc/ September 30 (Dec) Ended =
(Dec) September 30 2001 2000 2001 2000 Net Income* $298 $737 (60%) $1,014 $=
2,133 (52%) Net Revenues** $5,478 $5,554 (1%) $15,770 $16,371 (4%) Per Shar=
e Net Income Basic $0  23 $0.56 (59%) $0.77 $1.61 (52%) Diluted $0.22 $0.54=
 (59%) $0.76 $1.57 (52%) Average Common Shares Outstanding Basic 1,324 1,32=
6 -- 1,323 1,328 -- Diluted 1,335 1,361 (2%) 1,338 1,361 (2%) Return on Ave=
rage Equity 14.2% 25.5% -- 14.2% 25.5% --   NEW YORK, Oct 22, 2001 /PRNewsw=
ire via COMTEX/ -- American Express Company (NYSE: AXP) today reported thir=
d quarter net income of $298 million, down 60 percent from $737 million in =
the same period a year ago. Diluted earnings per share were $.22, down 59 p=
ercent from a year ago. Net revenues on a managed basis totaled $5.5 billio=
n, down one percent from $5.6 billion a year ago. The company's return on e=
quity was 14.2 percent.   Results for the third quarter were negatively aff=
ected by two significant items: a previously announced restructuring charge=
 of $352 million pre-tax ($232 million after-tax) and the impacts from the =
September 11th terrorist attacks.   The September 11th events resulted in c=
ertain one-time costs and business interruption losses, including: provisio=
ns related to credit exposures to travel industry service establishments, i=
nsurance claims, and waived finance charges and late fees. The combination =
of these items totaled approximately $98 million pre-tax ($65 million after=
-tax).   The company also incurred costs of approximately $42 million since=
 September 11th, which are expected to be covered by insurance. Consequentl=
y, these costs did not impact the quarterly results. These include the cost=
 of duplicate facilities and equipment associated with the relocation of th=
e company's offices in lower Manhattan and certain other business recovery =
expenses. Costs associated with the damage to the company's offices, extra =
operating expenses and business interruption losses are still being evaluat=
ed. The company expects that a substantial portion ofgh its Ists and losses=
 will be covered by insurance.   The third quarter restructuring charge inc=
ludes severance costs for the elimination of approximately 6,100 jobs and a=
sset impairment and other costs, all relating to the consolidation and reor=
ganization of certain business units, the scale back of corporate lending i=
n certain regions, the migration of certain processes to lower cost locatio=
ns, the outsourcing of certain activities, and the transition of certain pr=
ocessing and service functions to the Internet. These initiatives are expec=
ted to produce expense savings of approximately $325 million in 2002. A por=
tion of these savings is expected to flow through to earnings in the form o=
f improved operating expense margins and the rest is expected to be reinves=
ted back into high-growth areas of the business.   In addition to the activ=
ities related to the restructuring charge, the company made strong progress=
 on its global reengineering efforts initiated in the first half of the yea=
r and, as of September 30, had realized savings in excess of $700 million. =
  Net income for the third quarter, adjusted for the restructuring and one-=
time costs related to September 11th, was approximately $595 million, down =
19 percent. On a similar basis, earnings per share were $.45, down 17 perce=
nt. The company's adjusted return on equity was 16.7 percent.   "While we w=
ere on target to meet prior consensus for third quarter earnings, the terro=
rist attacks obviously had a significant impact on the overall economy and =
we saw clear evidence of that as consumer spending, business travel and inv=
estment activity slowed after September 11th," said Kenneth I. Chenault, ch=
airman and chief executive officer, American Express Company. "In light of =
the weak economy and financial markets, we are moving aggressively to lower=
 our operating expenses. The progress we are making on our reengineering in=
itiatives has freed up substantial resources for investment in our business=
es with the strongest growth potential. This, along with the anticipated be=
nefit of lower interest rates and the strategies in place to grow our franc=
hise, positions us well to benefit when we see even a modest improvement in=
 the economy."   Travel Related Services (TRS) reported quarterly net incom=
e of $248 million, down 51 percent from $507 million in the third quarter a=
 year ago. Included in third quarter results are $195 million pre-tax ($127=
 million after-tax) of the restructuring charge noted earlier. Also include=
d in the results are $87 million pre-tax ($57 million after-tax) of one-tim=
e costs and waived fees directly related to the September 11th terrorist at=
tacks. Excluding these costs and the restructuring charge, TRS' net income =
would have been $432 million, down 15 percent from the third quarter last y=
ear.   TRS' net revenues rose two percent, as growth in loans and fee reven=
ues were partly offset by a three percent decline in billed business and a =
28 percent fall in travel sales. These declines reflect a substantial decre=
ase in corporate travel and entertainment spending and consumer travel sinc=
e September 11th. Prior to September, billed business growth for the quarte=
r was about two percent as higher consumer and small business spending offs=
et a decline in corporate travel and entertainment spending. Net finance ch=
arge revenues were higher, due to balance growth and wider net interest yie=
lds. This increase reflects a smaller percentage of loan balances on introd=
uctory rates and the benefit of declining interest rates during the quarter=
.   The provision for losses on the lending portfolios grew as a result of =
higher volumes and an increase in U.S. lending write-off rates and delinque=
ncies. Marketing and promotion expenses were lower as TRS scaled back certa=
in marketing efforts in light of the weaker business environment. Operating=
 expenses rose, reflecting increased Cardmember loyalty programs and busine=
ss volumes. These expenses were partly offset by the benefits of reengineer=
ing and cost-control efforts.   The above discussion presents TRS results "=
on a managed basis" as if there had been no securitization transactions, wh=
ich conforms to industry practice. The attached financials present TRS resu=
lts on both a managed and reported basis. Net income is the same in both fo=
rmats.   On a reported basis, TRS' results included securitization gains of=
 $29 million pre-tax ($19 million after-tax) and $26 million pre-tax ($17 m=
illion after-tax) in the third quarters of 2001 and 2000, respectively. The=
se gains were offset by expenses related to card acquisition activities and=
 therefore had no material impact on net income or total expenses.   Americ=
an Express Financial Advisors (AEFA) reported quarterly net income of $145 =
million, down 46 percent from $269 million in the third quarter a year ago.=
 Net revenues decreased 14 percent. Included in third quarter results are $=
62 million pre-tax ($41 million after-tax) of the restructuring charge note=
d earlier and $11 million pre-tax ($8 million after-tax) of insurance claim=
s directly related to September 11th. Excluding these items, AEFA's net inc=
ome would have been $194 million, down 28 percent from last year.   AEFA re=
sults reflect continued weakness in equity markets and narrower spreads on =
the investment portfolio. The weakened equity markets led to significantly =
lower asset levels and lower sales of investment products. As a result, man=
agement and distribution fees fell 15 percent.   Operating expenses, exclud=
ing the above-mentioned charges, decreased four percent from a year ago due=
 primarily to lower sales commissions and continued reengineering and cost-=
control initiatives.   As of September 30th, approximately 4 percent of the=
 company's $33 billion investment portfolio consisted of high-yield securit=
ies, down from 12 percent a year ago and 8 percent last quarter. The reduct=
ion reflects the activities to date to lower the risk profile of the portfo=
lio and concentrate on stronger credits.   American Express Bank (AEB) repo=
rted a quarterly net loss of $43 million, compared with $7 million of net i=
ncome a year ago. Included in third quarter results are $84 million pre-tax=
 ($57 million after-tax) of the restructuring charge noted earlier. Excludi=
ng these charges, AEB's net income would have been $15 million, approximate=
ly double the earnings recorded in the same period last year.   While AEB s=
ustained damage to its premises due to the September 11th terrorist attacks=
, the costs are expected to be covered by insurance. Consequently, these co=
sts did not impact AEB's quarterly results.   AEB's business results reflec=
t strong performance in Personal Financial Services and Private Banking. Re=
sults also benefited from lower funding costs and lower operating expenses =
as a result of AEB's reengineering efforts. These were offset in part by hi=
gher provisions for losses due to higher Personal Financial Services loan b=
alances, and lower revenue from Corporate Banking as the company continues =
to shift its focus to Personal Financial Services and Private Banking.   Co=
rporate and Other reported net expenses of $52 million, compared with $46 m=
illion a year ago. Included in third quarter 2001 results are $11 million p=
re-tax ($7 million after-tax) of the restructuring charge noted earlier.   =
American Express Company (http://www.americanexpress.com ), founded in 1850=
, is a global travel, financial and network services provider.   Note: The =
2001 Third Quarter Earnings Supplement will be available today on the Ameri=
can Express web site at http://ir.americanexpress.com . In addition, an inv=
estor conference call to discuss third quarter earnings results, operating =
performance and other topics that may be raised during the discussion will =
be held at 5:00 p.m. (ET) today. Live audio of the conference call will be =
accessible to the general public on the American Express web site at http:/=
/ir.americanexpress.com . A replay of the conference call also will be avai=
lable today at the same web site address.   This document contains forward-=
looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. The words "=
believe", "expect", "anticipate", "intend", "aim", "will", "should", and si=
milar expressions are intended to identify these forward-looking statements=
. The Company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-look=
ing statements. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materiall=
y from these forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, th=
e following:   Fluctuation in the equity markets, which can affect the amou=
nt and types of investment products sold by AEFA, the market value of its m=
anaged assets, and management and distribution fees received based on those=
 assets; potential deterioration in the high-yield sector and other investm=
ent areas, which could result in further losses in AEFA's investment portfo=
lio; the ability of AEFA to sell certain high- yield investments at expecte=
d values and within anticipated time frames and to maintain its high-yield =
portfolio at certain levels in the future; developments relating to AEFA's =
new platform structure for financial advisors, including the ability to inc=
rease advisor productivity, moderate the growth of new advisors and create =
efficiencies in the infrastructure; AEFA's ability to effectively manage th=
e economics in selling a growing volume of non-proprietary products to clie=
nts; investment performance in AEFA's businesses; the success, timeliness a=
nd financial impact, including costs, cost savings and other benefits, of r=
eengineering initiatives being implemented or considered by the Company, in=
cluding cost management, structural and strategic measures such as vendor, =
process, facilities and operations consolidation, outsourcing, relocating c=
ertain functions to lower cost overseas locations, moving internal and exte=
rnal functions to the Internet to save costs, the scale back of corporate l=
ending in certain regions, and planned staff reductions relating to certain=
 of such reengineering actions; the ability to control and manage operating=

body:
<email>
From: Rajesh Patel <rpatel@university.edu>
To: Aisha Khan <a.khan@institute.org>
Subject: RE: Continuing our discussion on Kashmir

Aisha,

I completely agree with your suggestion for structuring the paper. Having each of us take the lead on sections that align with our expertise and perspectives, while ensuring an overall balanced approach, will make for a stronger and more compelling piece.

As for specific aspects to focus on, I think it's crucial that we examine the historical context of the conflict, particularly the events leading up to the current flare-up in violence. We should also analyze the geopolitical implications, both in terms of India-Pakistan relations and the broader regional dynamics (e.g., China's role, the impact on Afghanistan, etc.).

Additionally, I believe we should address the human rights issues at play, particularly the plight of the Kashmiri people caught in the middle of this long-standing dispute. This is an area where I think your insights and expertise would be particularly valuable.

Let's touch base next week to finalize our outline and divide up the research and writing tasks. I'm happy to take the lead on the historical and geopolitical sections, while you focus on the human rights aspects and the Kashmiri perspective.

Looking forward to our continued collaboration!

Best regards,
Rajesh

<email>
From: Daniel Evans <daniel.evans@boston.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@richmond.edu>
Subject: RE: New Document Discovery

Emily,

Thank you for sharing this incredible find! I've reviewed the letter, and I agree that it provides valuable insights into the economic motivations behind the Southern perspective. It's a fascinating piece of history that could really enhance our presentation.

I think we should definitely incorporate this new information. It might require some last-minute adjustments, but I believe it will be worth it. We'll need to carefully consider how this letter fits into our overall narrative and how it supports our thesis.

I suggest we set up a video call to discuss our strategy for integrating this new document. Are you available tomorrow afternoon, say around 2 PM EST? If not, let me know what works best for you.

I'm looking forward to diving deeper into this new material and refining our presentation.

Best,
Daniel

To: Dr. Emily Harris <eharris@triasaur.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration update and next steps

Emily,

This is fantastic news! Congratulations on securing the funding from the National Science Education Foundation. It is a testament to the potential of our collaboration and the impact we can have on children's lives.

I am eager to discuss the next steps and explore how we can leverage our expertise to create the most engaging and effective educational materials possible. I am available for a call next Wednesday afternoon or Thursday morning. Please let me know which time works best for you.

Once again, congratulations on this exciting development. I look forward to working with you to bring our vision to life.

Best regards,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@university.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: National Science Education Conference Invitation

Hi Emily,

That's fantastic news! I'm thrilled that we have the opportunity to present our work at such a prestigious conference. I completely agree that our collaborative approach and the innovative teaching materials we've created would be of great interest to the conference attendees.

I'm available next Tuesday afternoon, around 2 PM, for a planning session. Does that work for you? If not, let me know your preferred day and time, and I'll do my best to accommodate.

I've been giving some thought to the workshop content, and I think we should focus on demonstrating how our teaching materials engage students and foster a deeper understanding of chemistry concepts. We could also discuss the process we went through to develop these materials and how we've incorporated feedback from our students to refine them.

Looking forward to our meeting and the exciting work ahead!

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@university.edu>
Subject: National Science Education Conference Invitation

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I have some exciting news to share! We've been invited to present a joint workshop at the upcoming National Science Education Conference. The conference theme is "Innovative Teaching Methods in STEM Education: Empowering the Next Generation of Scientists," and I think it's a perfect opportunity for us to showcase our collaborative work and the unique teaching materials we've developed together.

I would love to meet and discuss our ideas for the workshop. Are you available next week for a planning session? Let me know what day and time work best for you.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@university.edu>
To: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@observatory.org>
Subject: New telescope proposal

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I'm reaching out because I'm working on a proposal for a new solar telescope that could revolutionize our understanding of the sun's atmosphere. I remember you mentioned at the conference a few years ago that you were interested in how stellar evolution impacts galaxy formation, and I think this technology could be a game-changer for your research as well.

The proposed telescope would use advanced adaptive optics to achieve unprecedented resolution and sensitivity in the UV and X-ray wavelengths, allowing us to study the sun's magnetic field and coronal mass ejections in much greater detail than ever before. I'm thinking this could also be applied to studying the formation and evolution of massive stars in distant galaxies, which could shed light on the role of dark matter in galaxy formation.

I'd love to get your thoughts on this and see if you'd be interested in collaborating on the proposal. Let me know if you have any questions or ideas!

Best,
Sarah
label: research

Phillip,

Thank you for meeting with us today. I want to take a few minutes to
summarize the decisions that came out of our meeting.

1. Feedback Approach: We will incorporate the ideas and suggestions you
gave us and move forward with this approach.

2. SME Review of Knowledge System Topics: When the time comes for Topics
reviews, we will send you the name of the SME who is responsible for
sign-off on each topic.

3. Conversion and Arbitrage Problems: We will brainstorm ways to
incorporate more problems without going over our 4-6 hour target. We will
meet with you next Tuesday at 10:00 to review the problems as we've
designed them so far and arrive at a solution. (I will send an e-mail
Monday with the room number.)

Have a good weekend.
Mery

Subject: Our first HTML and Paleontology session!

Hi Ethan,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to touch base with you regarding our first knowledge exchange session at the hobby club this weekend. I'm really excited to learn the basics of HTML and CSS from you, and I hope my paleontology crash course will be just as engaging for you!

Please let me know if there's anything I should prepare or bring to the session. I'll have my laptop and some resources on Triassic reptiles ready to share.

Looking forward to seeing you soon!

Best,
Olivia
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Liam Thompson <lthompson@oxford.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@cambridge.edu>
Subject: RE: Our joint paper

Emily,

I'm glad my advice was helpful! I think you'd be a great fit for a museum role, given your passion for archaeological research and your excellent communication skills. I'll reach out to a few colleagues and put you in touch with them.

In the meantime, I'd recommend updating your CV to highlight your relevant experience and skills. When I was applying for museum jobs, I focused on my research expertise, my ability to interpret and present complex information to diverse audiences, and my experience with project management and collaboration.

Feel free to send me your updated CV, and I can provide feedback and suggestions based on what I've learned through my own job search.

Best of luck with your career transition! I'm here to support you every step of the way.
Liam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Amelia Hartman <ahartman@riverdalecollege.edu>
To: Liam Donovan <ldonovan@riverdalecollege.edu>
Subject: RE: Interdisciplinary course collaboration

Hi Liam,

Tuesday at 2 PM works perfectly for me. Let's meet in the faculty lounge – it's a nice, relaxed setting for brainstorming.

I've been thinking about how we can incorporate cost-benefit analysis and production theory into the course while also addressing social and emotional development. I believe that by providing students with a strong foundation in economic principles, we can then explore how these concepts play out in real-world scenarios, particularly in terms of social dynamics and equity.

I'd love to hear your initial thoughts on this approach and any ideas you have for specific topics or activities we could include in the course.

See you on Tuesday!

Best,
Amelia
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@artexplorers.com>
To: Jenna Smith <jenna.smith@artinspired.org>
Subject: RE: Summer Art Camp Ideas

Jenna,

I'm so glad you brought this up! I've been brainstorming ideas as well and absolutely love the concept of focusing on modern and contemporary art. The students will be thrilled to learn about these iconic art movements and create their own masterpieces.

I think we should also consider incorporating some interactive art projects, like a collaborative mural or a sculpture garden. This will allow the kids to work together and engage with art in a more hands-on way.

Let's set up a video call next week to discuss our plans in more detail. I can't wait to see what we come up with for the camp!

Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Rodriguez <michael.rodriguez@westelementary.org>
To: Olivia Thompson <olivia.thompson@environmentaldefender.org>
Subject: RE: Tree-Planting Project in Our Neighborhood

Hi Olivia,

Thank you for reaching out about this fantastic project! I think it's a wonderful idea and a great opportunity for my students to learn about the environment and the role of trees in our ecosystem.

I would love to integrate this project into our curriculum. We could teach the students about the science behind trees, their importance, and how they can contribute to the health of our planet. It would be great if you could come to our classroom to give a presentation about your work and the importance of environmental conservation.

Additionally, I was thinking we could organize a field trip to a local nature reserve or forest to give the students a real-life experience of the topics we'll be learning about. What do you think?

I'm excited to collaborate on this project and look forward to your thoughts.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@ridgemontschools.org>
To: Thomas Green <thomasgreen@gardeningexpert.com>
Subject: Seeking gardening advice for student project

Dear Mr. Green,

I hope this email finds you well. I'm Emily Johnson, a mathematics teacher at Ridgemont Middle School, and I believe we are neighbors. I'm reaching out to you because my students are working on a project that involves using coding to optimize garden layouts and planting schedules. Given your expertise in gardening, particularly in USDA Hardiness Zone 8, I was wondering if you might be willing to share some insights with us.

The students are participating in a school-wide science fair, and their project aims to create a sustainable garden using computational thinking. Your advice on gardening techniques specific to our climate zone would be invaluable in helping them create more accurate and effective garden plans.

If you have any time in the coming weeks, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to discuss this project with you further. Please let me know if you would be interested in mentoring my students or providing any guidance on this project.

Thank you for considering my request. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
label: research

The project coordinators believe they can reach a solution with Accenture in which Enron pays no additional fees but the project is completed in a slightly scaled back form.  This allows Accenture to have a completed project and no more cash goes out the door.

The effort from the SME's should be complete by Christmas.  Please push forward with the review of the knowledge layer.

Phillip





 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Frolov, Yevgeny  
Sent:	Tuesday, November 20, 2001 2:51 PM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.
Cc:	O'rourke, Tim; Coleman, Brad; McDaniel, Kirk
Subject:	Zero Option


Phillip,


It will go along this lines: (Conservative)

*****************************************************
We pay "0" going forward
We have already played 300K in 3Q2001
Outstanding bill for $27,740 will hit Enron Q1, 2002

Enron and surviving entity will have the right to use it internally

We value Enrons SME time @ around 300K

Accenture will have the right to use it internally and modify the product at its will for internal & external use.

This arrangement will void 900K Enrons Revenue from Accenture

Enron would receive 0% royalty on all external sales.  I was thinking to stay away from royalty as we do not know what will be new company position on this matter. Also,  I do not think Accenture will want to enter into partnership structure with a ghost company unless we get Dinergy involved.

***********************************************************************

If we do not reach the agreement: 1. Terminate and pay around 500-600k (estimate)  The payment could be deferred in to 2Q 2002 or
				 2. Continue "as is" with payment differed for 90 days or merger.

We are sending Accenture official notice as of tomorrow we have 10 business days to workout solution or terminate.	

Any comments or suggestions?


Regards,

Yevgeny

 
 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Allen, Phillip K.  
Sent:	Tuesday, November 20, 2001 12:32 PM
To:	Frolov, Yevgeny
Subject:	RE: BRM Case & Options

Yevgeny,

Please send me an email describing the zero option so I can pass it along to the other SME's.

Phillip

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Frolov, Yevgeny  
Sent:	Monday, November 19, 2001 10:26 AM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.
Cc:	McDaniel, Kirk; Coleman, Brad; O'rourke, Tim
Subject:	BRM Case & Options
Importance:	High

Phillip,

I am following up to our BRM conversation from Friday.  Obviously it is a valid questions to ask and as you requested I am attaching two documents: one summarizing the options and  2nd cash flow impact.  In the cash flow impact Case 2 & 3 already account for additional cut of 100k from existing cost.  (it comes from Expenses such as projected traveling 30K+Cut in Media 20K + Cut in sim exercises 50K)  The cut in sim exercises need to be confirmed with you. A total of two sims could be cut one.  Accenture will address this question tomorrow during the meeting.  Also,  I will ask them to cut the meeting by 10 min, thus we can go over the documents and can answer your questions.  I am not sure what is Tim's schedule for tomorrow, but at least Kirk and myself will be around. 

Obviously cutting sims is not the best options but we are considering all alternatives at this time.  We will continue to review how to cut labor and expenses.
One question that it would be good if you think about it before we meet is as follow.  Is BRM "core" to the Enron for next few months or new organization?  Please consider the costs of finishing this project.


Sincerely,


Yevgeny Frolov
713-345-8250 w
 << File: BRM Cash Flow Cases.xls >>  << File: BRM Contingency Numbers Rev3.xls >>

body:
<email>
From: Emily Davis <emily.davis@university.edu>
To: Robert Thompson <robert.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: Grant Proposal Collaboration

Hi Robert,

I hope you're doing well. As you know, our department chair has asked us to collaborate on a grant proposal for a research project on the application of econometric models in economic forecasting. I think this is a great opportunity for us to combine our expertise and work on a project that could have a significant impact on our field.

I was thinking about potential research questions, and I believe we should focus on the following: "How can econometric models be used to improve short-term and long-term economic forecasting accuracy?" What are your thoughts on this? Do you have any suggestions for refining the question or other aspects of the proposal?

Please let me know your availability for a meeting to discuss this further. I'm excited to work with you on this project!

Best regards,
Emily
label: research
