body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@who.int>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@university.edu>
Subject: Quick update on our grant proposal

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I have some exciting news to share. Our grant proposal for the "Multi-level Intervention to Prevent Adolescent Obesity in LMICs" has been accepted! I'm thrilled that we'll have the opportunity to work together on this important project.

I've attached the official acceptance letter and the grant agreement for your review. Please take a look and let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

I think it would be best for us to meet in person to finalize the study design and plan for data collection. Would you be available to meet in Geneva next month? I can arrange for a meeting room at the WHO headquarters. Let me know your preferred dates, and I'll make the necessary arrangements.

Looking forward to hearing from you and getting started on this exciting project!

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Emily Chen <emily.chen@chemteacher.com>
To: Alex Ramirez <alex.ramirez@weatherwhiz.com>
Subject: Collaborative project idea

Hi Alex,

It was great meeting you at the science education conference last week! I really enjoyed your presentation on engaging ways to explain weather phenomena. As I mentioned, I'm a high school chemistry teacher focused on molecular orbital theory and atomic structure. I think our areas of expertise could complement each other well for a collaborative project.

I had an idea: what if we create a series of blog posts and videos that explore the connections between chemistry and weather? For example, we could look at how atomic structure relates to the formation of clouds or how molecular orbital theory can help explain the formation of ozone. We could share these materials on our social media channels and websites to reach a wider audience.

What do you think? If you're interested, we can discuss the logistics of the project, such as timelines, content creation, and promotion strategies.

I look forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best regards,
Emily Chen
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@uwm.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@unc.edu>
Subject: Collaborative research idea

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! It's been a while since we last chatted, but I've been thinking about our conversations about teaching introductory econometrics and thought of an idea for a potential research project.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on a study examining the effectiveness of different instructional methods in intro econ courses. I've been experimenting with some new approaches in my classes and have been curious to see if they make a significant difference in student learning outcomes. I know you've also been doing some innovative things in your classes at UNC.

If you're open to it, I'd love to discuss the possibility of designing a study together. We could potentially apply for grant funding to support the work.

Let me know if this piques your interest! I'd be happy to set up a call to brainstorm further.

Best,
Emily
label: research

I can't wait to see your list of must-visit places! I'll start looking into any additional activities or experiences we might want to include in our itinerary.

Thanks again for everything, Jamal. I'm so grateful to have you as my guide and friend on this adventure. Let's make some unforgettable memories together!

Best regards,
Petra

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@university.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@college.edu>
Subject: Draft of the dictionary project

Hey Michael,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out because I've finally completed the draft for the first section of our dictionary project. I've attached the file to this email, and I would really appreciate it if you could take a look and provide some feedback.

As I was working on this, I started thinking about how our research could potentially contribute to the field of lexicography. What do you think about the idea of co-authoring a paper on our findings once the dictionary is complete? I think it could be a great opportunity to share our work with the wider linguistic community.

Let me know your thoughts on both the draft and the paper idea. I'm excited to hear your feedback and continue working on this project together.

Best regards,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakvillehigh.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: Exciting New Teaching Method

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share something exciting with you that I learned at the chemistry education conference last week. I attended a session on a new teaching method called "Modeling Instruction" that I think could be really beneficial for our students.

The basic idea behind Modeling Instruction is to engage students in building and testing mental models of chemical concepts through a series of guided inquiries and activities. The goal is to help students develop a deeper understanding of the underlying principles and mechanisms of chemistry.

I've attached a few resources that provide an overview of the method and some example activities. I'd love to hear your thoughts on it and discuss whether we might be able to incorporate some of these ideas into our curriculum.

Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to chat more about this!

Best,
Emily

<email>
From: Maria Petrova <maria.petrova@spbhistory.ru>
To: Alexei Ivanov <alexei.ivanov@spbhistory.ru>
Subject: RE: Alaska Purchase Exhibit - Educational Component

Alexei,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm thrilled to hear about your new exhibit and would love to collaborate on an educational component for children. I agree that creating a game or hands-on activity could be a great way to engage young visitors and help them understand the significance of the Alaska Purchase.

I've been working on a new science curriculum for local elementary schools and have been looking for ways to incorporate local history and our museum's exhibits into the program. This could be a perfect opportunity to combine our efforts and create something truly unique and educational.

I'm free to meet next week to discuss ideas and plan our next steps. Please let me know your availability.

Best,
Maria

I'm looking forward to the conference and catching up with you in person!

Best,
Michael

Message-ID: <4452937.1075855715625.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 14 Mar 2001 04:18:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: gthorse@keyad.com, djack@keyad.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: gthorse@keyad.com, djack@keyad.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\Sent
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Gentlemen,

Today I finally received some information on the status of the work done to 
date.  I spoke to Hugo Alexandro at Cuatro Consultants.  The property is 
still in two parcels.  Hugo has completed a platt to combine into one  lot 
and is ready to submit it to the city of San Marcos.  He has also completed a 
topographical survey and a tree survey.  In addition, he has begun to 
coordinate with the city on the replatting and a couple of easements on the 
smaller parcel, as well as, beginning the work on the grading.  Hugo is going 
to fax me a written letter of the scope of work he has been engaged to 
complete.  The total cost of his services are estimated at $38,000 of which 
$14,000 are due now for work completed.  

We are trying to resolve the issues of outstanding work and bills incurred by 
the original developer so we can obtain the title to the land.  If we can 
continue to use Cuatro then it would be one less point of contention.  Hugo's 
number is 512-295-8052.  I thought you might want to contact him directly and 
ask him some questions.  I spoke to him about the possibility of your call 
and he was fine with that.  

Now we are going to try and determine if any of the work performed by Kipp 
Flores can be used.

Keith and I appreciate you meeting with us on Sunday.  We left very 
optimistic about the prospect of working with you on this project.

Call me with feedback after you speak to Hugo or with any other ideas about 
moving this project forward.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Dr. James Thompson <jthompson@hawaii.edu>
To: Dr. Maria Silva <msilva@ufrj.br>
Subject: RE: Following up on our conversation at the Galapagos Conference

Dear Dr. Silva,

Thank you for reaching out and for your interest in a potential collaboration. I, too, found our conversation at the conference to be thought-provoking and believe that our respective fields of research could complement each other well.

Your work on the political factors influencing environmental policy in Brazil is particularly relevant to my research on the Galapagos Islands, where government policy plays a crucial role in managing invasive species and protecting the unique ecosystems. I would be very interested in exploring how the transition from authoritarianism to democracy in Brazil has impacted environmental policy and conservation efforts, and how this might compare to other island contexts.

I will send you some of my recent publications on invasive species management in the Galapagos, and I would be keen to read your work on Brazilian environmental policy. Perhaps we could arrange a video call in the coming weeks to discuss our research in more detail and brainstorm potential collaborative projects?

Please let me know your availability, and I will be happy to coordinate a time that works for both of us.

Best regards,
James

John,

Thanks for the email and the offer to route my resume in the most
expeditious way.  I saw only one job that was posted on Enron's website that
looked like a good fit.  It was an asset evaluation and integration job for
Enron North America: job # 0000105886.

My primary strengths are:

Natural gas asset acquisition and management
Supporting a trading organization by providing excellent futures and
derivatives execution
Trading proprietary books (fixed price or otherwise)where there is a
competitive reason to be     in the market, i.e. transportation spreads,
storage, physical presence
Good customer relations/account development
Ability to focus on and analyze a wide range of problems/opportunities
Stong negotiator

I know that Enron is a big, happening place and it is invaluble to have
someone like you to help me sort out the opportunities.  Where I am coming
from is that I have to more valuble to Enron than I am to Oxy because Oxy is
doing frustratingly little to leverage itself and Enron is setting every
trend imaginable in leveraging itself.

I appreciate any help you can provide.

Thanks.

Alan

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <athompson@marinescience.org>
To: Dr. Emily Johnson <ejohnson@marinescience.org>
Subject: New software tool for Gulf Stream project

Hi Emily,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some exciting news with you regarding our Gulf Stream project. Over the past few weeks, I've been working on a new software tool that I believe could significantly improve the efficiency of our model.

The tool utilizes a novel algorithm to optimize the computational process, potentially reducing the time required for simulations by up to 50%. I've conducted some initial tests, and the results look promising.

Before presenting this tool to the rest of the team, I wanted to get your feedback. Would you be available for a quick call this week to discuss the tool and its potential implications for our research? I'd be happy to provide a demo and answer any questions you may have.

Let me know your availability, and I'll set up a meeting.

Best regards,
Alex

body:
Message-ID: <7181067.1075857602318.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2000 11:22:00 -0800 (PST)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: john.lavorato@enron.com, jeffrey.shankman@enron.com, mike.maggi@enron.com
Subject: New curve generation methodology
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: John J Lavorato, Jeffrey A Shankman, Mike Maggi
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

I am changing the way the curve is generated starting in Jan 2004 to better 
replicate seasonal fundamentals.  There are convincing arguments as to why 
the summer/winter spreads should tighten over time.  However, in the previous 
methodology they blew out.  For instance summer/winter in Cal 3 was .232 
while Cal 10 was .256.  
I have added a seasonality dampening function that both contracts the 
summer/winter spread and applies a premium to the electric load demand months 
of July and August over time.

The formula for the curve remains the same except for a premium lookup for 
the month as well as for the year.  These premiums are as follows:

Jan  -.008
Feb -.004
Mar -.001
Apr .002
May .003
Jun .004
Jul .004
Aug .004
Sep .003
Oct .002
Nov -.003
Dec -.006


These premiums start in Jan 2004
On Wednesday Jan 2003 settled 2.959,  the 3/4 spread was marked at .0375, the 
4/5 spread was marked at .0475.  
In the old methodology
Jan 2003  = 2.959
Jan 2004  = 2.959 + .0375 = 2.9965
Jan 2005  =          2.9965 + .0475 = 3.044


In the new methodology
Jan 2003  = 2.959
Jan 2004  = 2.959 + .0375 - .008 =2.9885
Jan 2005  = 2.9885 + .0475 -.008 = 3.028

The only change in the formula is from:
Month x = Month (x- 1 year) + lookup on year on year table
to
Month x = Month (x- 1 year) + lookup on year on year table + lookup on month 
premium table

The seasonality premiums will change over time and I will let you know when I 
change them
label: student

body:
<email>
From: David Thompson <david.thompson@conservation.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Final touches on the grant proposal

Emily,

Thank you for your email and suggestions. I agree with all of your points and think they will greatly strengthen our proposal.

I particularly like your idea of emphasizing the potential impact of our research in the introduction. Highlighting the recent droughts and the urgency of the issue will certainly grab the reviewers' attention.

I also think providing more details on the polymers and their synthesis is crucial. We want to make sure the reviewers understand the technical aspects of our project and how it differs from previous approaches.

As for the scalability discussion, I believe it's essential to show that our research has the potential to make a significant impact beyond the local level. I can draft a brief section on this and send it to you for your input.

Please go ahead and make the changes you suggested. I'll review the updated draft on Friday and provide any feedback I may have. We should definitely have enough time to make any final adjustments before the deadline.

I echo your sentiment – it's been a pleasure collaborating with you on this project. Your expertise in biochemistry has been invaluable, and I believe our interdisciplinary approach will make our proposal stand out.

Best regards,
David
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Smith <michael.smith@oakvilleschools.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@radiobiology.org>
Subject: RE: Science Fair Judging

Hi Emily,

I just had a chance to read through your TED Talk script and I think it's fantastic! You've done a great job weaving in relatable examples and storytelling to make the science accessible. I especially loved the analogy about the radiation therapy being like a precisely targeted "tiny army" attacking the cancer cells. That's such a powerful way to help people understand the concept.

I think this talk is going to be a huge hit and I'm so excited for you! Your work is making such an impact and it's wonderful that you're sharing it with the world in such an engaging way.

I'll see you soon at the science fair! Let me know if you need anything else.

Best,
Michael

label: student

body:
<email>
From: Sophia Nguyen <sophia.nguyen@who.int>
To: Liam O'Connor <liam.oconnor@littlelearnersdaycare.com>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on a project to promote child health through storytelling

Liam,

Thank you for sending the calendar invite. I've accepted it and added the Zoom link to my schedule.

I completely agree with the themes you've suggested for the stories. Focusing on healthy eating habits, physical activity, emotional well-being, and hygiene and disease prevention is crucial, especially in the current context. We could also consider incorporating messages about the importance of sleep and limiting screen time, as these are often overlooked aspects of child health.

Your idea to create a framework or guidelines for adapting the stories to different cultural contexts is brilliant. We could consult with experts in cultural competence and early childhood education to ensure our approach is inclusive and effective.

I've been thinking about potential funding sources for our project. I have some contacts at the World Health Organization and UNICEF who might be interested in supporting our initiative. I'd be happy to reach out to them and explore the possibilities.

Looking forward to our call next week to discuss these ideas further!

Best,
Sophia
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sthompson@riverdalems.org>
To: Dr. Michael Johnson <mjohnson@earlyamerica.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborative project idea - History and Art

Dear Dr. Johnson,

Our meeting on Tuesday was incredibly productive, and I'm thrilled with the direction we've decided to take the project. The students will be researching and creating digital art pieces based on the following events:

1. The signing of the Treaty of Paris (1783)
2. The Whiskey Rebellion (1794)
3. The Louisiana Purchase (1803)
4. The Battle of New Orleans (1815)

I've created a shared folder with resources for each event, which I've shared with you. Please feel free to add any additional resources you think would be helpful for the students.

I'll introduce the project to the students next week and begin the research phase. We'll keep you updated on their progress, and we can schedule another meeting to discuss their initial ideas for the digital art pieces.

Thank you again for your collaboration and expertise. I know this project will be a success thanks to your involvement.

Best regards,
Sarah Thompson
label: research

Subject:	FERC Special Meetings on Friday 10/26/01 and Monday 10/29/01

The Capitol Connection is pleased to announce that it will broadcast (via
the internet and telephone Only) the following Federal Energy Regulatory
Commission Special Meetings:

Friday, October 26, 9.30 a.m. ET
Topic: Interstate Natural Gas Facility Planning Seminar, Presentation of
Staff Findings

Monday, October 29, 1:00 p.m. ET
Topic: Technical Conference Concerning West-Wide Price Mitigation for
Winter Season & Procedures for seeking participation

If you have an annual subscription to the Capitol Connection internet
service, these meetings are included in the annual fee.  Please contact us
if you are interested in signing up for either of these meetings or want to
get an annual subscription to our internet service.

The Capitol Connection offers FERC meetings live via the Internet, as well
as via Phone Bridge, and satellite, please visit our website at
www.capitolconnection.org <http://www.capitolconnection.org>. or send e-mail to capcon@gmu.edu <mailto:capcon@gmu.edu> for more
information. If there is a meeting you are interested in receiving, please
call 703-993-3100.

David Reininger


Meeting dates and times are subject to change without notice. For current
information, you can go to our website at www.capitolconnection.org <http://www.capitolconnection.org> and
select the FERC link or you can go to the FERC web page at www.ferc.fed.us <http://www.ferc.fed.us>.
The FERC Office of the Secretary can be reached at 202.208.0400.

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@inclusiveschools.org>
To: Jenna Thompson <jenna.thompson@dhhedconsultant.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on creating an inclusive environment

Hi Jenna,

It's great to hear from you! Congratulations on your new position - that's exciting news. I'm happy to share some insights and strategies that have worked well for me in creating inclusive school environments.

One of the most important things, I've found, is to start by building relationships with key stakeholders - administrators, teachers, parents, and students. It's crucial to have open and honest conversations about the needs of students with disabilities and to collaborate on developing policies and practices that support their success.

Another key strategy is to provide ongoing professional development and training for educators, focusing on best practices for teaching and supporting students with disabilities. It's also important to ensure that accommodations and modifications are consistently implemented and that students have access to the tools and resources they need to thrive academically and socially.

I'd be happy to share more detailed recommendations and resources, and I'm also curious to learn more about your new role and the specific challenges you anticipate. It sounds like an exciting opportunity to make a real difference for your students!

Best,
Alex
label: research

Subject: Re: HP -- confidential internal document
Cc: dale.clark@enron.com, jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: dale.clark@enron.com, jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
X-From: Matt Harris
X-To: Patrick Tucker
X-cc: Dale Clark, Jennifer Medcalf
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Good plan.

I agree re SJ.  She is on the ball.

mh



	Patrick Tucker
	12/14/00 04:28 PM
		
		 To: Matt Harris/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: Dale Clark/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 Subject: Re: HP -- confidential internal document

I agree.  Sarah-Joy and I had a detailed follow-on conversation today about 
this topic, and we're in agreement as to how things can move forward.  I'd 
definitely like to have Bill rejoin our conversation with our new overall 
commercial contact at HP, whose name Greg Pyle and Bill Lovejoy will supply 
in the very near future.  I understand that Peter Goebel was quite clear with 
HP in today's meetings regarding the imminent nature of his wireless 
decision, the breadth of vendors with whom he could conceivably do business, 
and the fact that the wireless deal and the Enron sell side are inextricably 
linked.  Sarah-Joy mentioned that Gerry has not been present in the more 
recent conversations, which we're taking to indicate that Bill and Greg 
understand that his focus was different than ours.  

Sarah-Joy has brought immense focus and organization to this process.  I have 
certainly found her involvement invaluable.  

Patrick





	Matt Harris
	12/14/00 10:51 AM
		
		 To: Sarah-Joy Hunter/NA/Enron@ENRON
		 cc: Dale Clark/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Jennifer 
Medcalf/NA/Enron@Enron, Patrick Tucker/Enron Communications@Enron 
Communications, Peter Goebel/NA/Enron@Enron
		 Subject: Re: HP -- confidential internal document

This is an excellent update.  Thanks for putting this together.

Dale/Patrick - lets regroup on how we want to move this onward.  Seems like 
SJ's suggestion of our spending more time with Bill Dwyer is a good one.

Thanks
Matt



	Sarah-Joy Hunter@ENRON
	12/12/00 02:42 PM
		 
		 To: Matt Harris/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: Patrick Tucker/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Peter 
Goebel/NA/Enron@Enron, Dale Clark/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, 
Jennifer Medcalf/NA/Enron@Enron
		 Subject: HP -- confidential internal document

Matt:

As GSS Business Development transitions the HP relationship for broadband to 
your team, there are several issues I wanted to clarify in terms of how the 
relationship has been developed and who the contacts have been to date.  
Additionally, I outlined the discussion points/action items from this 
morning's meeting you held with Jennifer Medcalf and myself.  Per your 
request, the HP presentation complete with a listing of HP's business 
partners was e-mailed to you this morning.

HP contacts to date: 

Bill Lovejoy, Western Gulf Area Sales Manager
Houston, TX
#(713)-439-5587
(Gerry Cashiola's boss)

Gerry Cashiola, sales representative 
Houston, TX
#(713)-439-5555
(To date, HP person coordinating the relationship--seeking a short term play)

Greg Pyle, Solution Control Manager
Southeast Region
Austin, TX 
(#(512)-257-5735
(Pyle has been playing the business developer role but continues to defer 
leadership of the process to Gerry Cashiola)

Daniel Morgridge, Manager of Internet - E-Services long term alliances
Austin, TX
#(512)-257-5736
(Interested in E-services/wireless longer term alliances)

Bill Dwyer, Chief Architect, e-Services Solutions
Cupertino, CA
#(408)-447-5240
(To date, clearly the most knowledgeable person on HP's business 
propositions; strong technical, financial background to craft value 
propositions.  Gerry Cashiola and Greg Pyle deferred to his judgement in the 
11/16th meeting)

Matt,
 
On November 10th, GSS Business Development took HP through a tour of Enron's 
trading floor, the gas control center, and the peaking power plant unit 
center on the trading floor.  This tour was one meeting, amongst several, 
held in October and November to provide HP a full overview of Enron's 
products and services and introduce them to appropriate contacts at Enron 
(EBS, GSS buy side -- Peter Goebel).

On November 16th GSS Business Development,  Patrick Tucker, and Dale Clark 
outlined 3 possible EBS/HP focus areas  --  connectivity, storage, and 
wireless.  Three EBS action items were defined in that meeting:

1) HP was to provide an HP contact on connectivity (to date, Gerry Cashiola 
has stalled on providing this).  Sarah-Joy will continue to pursue this 
information and get a sense from Gerry Cashiola of what he means by short 
term opportunity.  What is HP's time horizon for short term?

2) EBS and GSS/BD was to facilitate a conference call on Storage with Ravi to 
explore size and potential scope of opportunity (completed 12/8)

3) GSS/BD was to facilitate a conference call with Peter Goebel, GSS IT 
Sourcing Portfolio Leader (set for 12/14)   

In conversations with you, Jennifer Medcalf and myself this morning, several 
decisions on forward-looking strategy with HP/EBS were confirmed:


Gerry Cashiola has been unable to take control of the process.  More 
importantly, despite numerous visits to Enron in which he has had overviews 
of Enron's products and services; met with Peter Goebel and his team on the 
GSS buy side, and participated in an Experience Enron tour, Gerry has been 
unable to define an HP business proposition.  The coordination between 
Cashiola (short term initiative) Morgridge (long term, 12-24 months) has 
remained unorganized.  These initiatives need to be developed separately.


Clearly,  the conversations with HP need to be elevated to a more senior 
level so EBS can work with HP decision makers who can move the relationship 
forward at a strategic level.  As the relationship is developed at this 
strategic level, shorter term opportunities will crop up along the way.  But 
Gerry's short term plans will not be the focus of the EBS/HP relationship, 
rather a by-product.  To facilitate this process of elevating the 
relationship, Jennifer Medcalf and I are following up with Bill Lovejoy and 
Greg Pyle.  Lovejoy's boss is Dan Sytsma, VP of  HP's America's Central 
Region.

 In the conference call Thursday, 12/14 with Peter Goebel and HP regarding 
wireless initiatives, Peter will support the GSS/BD push for the HP/EBS 
initiative by reiterating the following two points:  

 a) Enron is already an HP customer; the onus is on HP  to move forward on 
the process of building a strategic  relationship  (IBM and Lexmark are only 
some of the HP competitors who could push them out of the running)

 b) HP's ability to bring the right people to the table will influence HP's 
business relationship process with Enron

 Patrick Tucker and Dale Clark could build their relationship with Bill 
Dwyer, Chief Architect e-Services Solutions, (met at the meeting 11/16) in 
the near term.  Perhaps, plan a visit to Cupertino, California to see Dwyer 
in person.  


We look forward to continuing close collaboration with your team on this and 
other opportunities. 

Sarah-Joy Hunter
Enron Corporation
Global Strategic Sourcing - Business Development
#(713)-345-6541

i'll pay a grand total of 0




"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/10/2001 05:15:59 PM

Please respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>

To:   <jarnold@enron.com>
cc:
Subject:  try this one...


 Please read the following problem very carefully, and write in a number at
the end.  You should be ready to defend your answer.  Only a number is
allowed, not an algebraic equation.

Acquiring a Company

     In the following exercise you will represent Company A (the acquirer),
which is currently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means of
a tender offer.  You plan to tender in cash for 100% of Company T's shares
but are unsure how high a price to offer.  The main complication is this:
the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oil
exploration project it is currently undertaking.  Indeed, the very
viability
of Company T depends on the exploration outcome.  If the project fails, the
company under current management will be worth nothing--$0/share.  But if
the project succeeds, the value of the company under current management
could be as high as $100/share.  All share values between $0 and $100 are
considered equally likely.  By all estimates, the company will be worth
considerably more in the hands of Company A than under current management.
In fact, whatever the ultimate value under current management, the company
will be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than under
Company T.  If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share under
either
management.  If the exploration project generates a $50/share value under
current management, the value under Company A is $75/share.  Similarly, a
$100/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under Company
A,
and so on.

     The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine the
price
they should offer for Company T's shares.  This offer must be made now,
before the outcome of the drilling project is known.  From all indications,
Company T would be happy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at a
profitable price.  Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at all cost, the
potential of a takeover bid by any other firm.  You expect Company T to
delay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, then
accept or reject your offer before the news of the drilling results reaches
the press.

     Thus, you (Company A) will not know the results of the exploration
project
when submitting your price offer, but Company T will know the results when
deciding whether or not to accept your offer.  In addition, Company T will
accept any offer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value of
the company under current management.  Thus, if you offer $50/share, for
instance, Company T will accept if the value of the company to Company T is
anything less than $50.

     As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over price
offers
in the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offer at all) to
$150/share.  What price offer per share would you tender for Company T's
stock?

     $______ per/share

body:
<email>
From: Jessica Thompson <jthompson@stem-education.org>
To: Dr. Liam Patel <lpatel@nanomed-research.org>
Subject: Following up from the conference

Hi Dr. Patel,

It was great to meet you at the conference last week and learn more about your fascinating research in nanotechnology and gene therapy. I was really impressed by your presentation and the potential impact your work could have on medicine.

As I mentioned, I'm always looking for ways to bring cutting-edge science into the classroom and make it accessible to students. I think there could be a great opportunity to collaborate on some educational materials that showcase the real-world applications of your research. I'd love to brainstorm some ideas with you and see if we can come up with a project that would be engaging for high school students.

Let me know if you'd be interested in chatting further. I'm happy to set up a call or meet for coffee if you're in the area.

Best regards,
Jessica
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@cybersecure.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@cybersecure.com>
Subject: New malware targeting financial institutions

Hi Emily,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some important information with you that I learned at the recent cybersecurity conference I attended. It appears that there's a new type of malware that has been targeting financial institutions, and I believe it could pose a significant threat to our clients.

The malware, dubbed "FinStealer," is designed to infiltrate banking systems and steal sensitive customer data. It uses advanced evasion techniques to avoid detection by traditional antivirus software, making it particularly dangerous.

I think we need to act quickly to develop a solution to protect our clients from this threat. Can we schedule a meeting to discuss this further and brainstorm some ideas?

Let me know your availability.

Best regards,
John
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Oliver Benson <oliver.benson@quantumgravity.org>
To: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@sciencenow.com>
Subject: RE: Gravity manipulation article - your expert insights needed!

Dear Sarah,

It's great to hear from you! I remember our conversation at the conference and I'm flattered that you thought of me for your article. I'd be more than happy to discuss my research and the potential applications of gravity manipulation.

In fact, I recently published a paper on a new theory related to gravity manipulation that I think your readers would find fascinating. I could provide you with a copy of the paper and we could discuss it in more detail.

Please let me know when would be a good time for you to chat. I'm looking forward to our collaboration!

Best regards,
Oliver
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Davis <emily.davis@oncologynews.com>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@history.edu>
Subject: Catching up and a potential collaboration

Hey Michael,

It's been great keeping in touch since we met at the conference in Philadelphia last year. I've been thinking a lot about our discussions on making complex topics more accessible to the general public. I believe our collaboration could lead to something truly unique, combining our expertise in oncology and colonial-era history.

I have an idea for a project that explores the history of skin cancer treatments and how they've evolved over time. I think it would be fascinating to compare modern treatments with the practices used during the colonial era. Your insights into the historical context would be invaluable.

Let me know if you're interested in discussing this further. I'd love to brainstorm some ideas and see if we can develop a proposal.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: David Thompson <dthompson@biomedlab.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@paleouniversity.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting new theropod fossil discovery!

Emily,

It's always a pleasure to hear from you! Congratulations on this incredible fossil find - I can only imagine the excitement at your lab right now. I'd be delighted to take a look at the preliminary data and discuss how it might relate to our previous work.

I'm available for a video call next Wednesday afternoon, if that works for you. Just send over the images and data whenever convenient, and I'll review them before our chat.

This discovery could be a game-changer for our understanding of dinosaur biology and evolution. I'm eager to see where this leads and to collaborate with you once again.

All the best,
David
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@riverdalehigh.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@renewableenergy.org>
Subject: STEM Education Event Follow-up

Dear Dr. Thompson,

It was great meeting you at the STEM education event last weekend. I really enjoyed our conversation about the importance of promoting science and mathematics to young students. As I mentioned, I'm a high school math teacher specializing in geometry, and I'm always looking for ways to make the subject more engaging and relevant for my students.

I was wondering if you would be interested in keeping in touch and sharing ideas related to our respective fields. I'm particularly curious about how you use geometry and spatial reasoning in your research on renewable energy. I think there could be some interesting overlaps that we could explore together.

Please let me know if you'd like to continue our discussion. I'd be happy to grab a coffee sometime and chat more.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Airways which will save us circa $3m a year vs Continental Airlines. I know 
there are existing and potential links with Continental, so please let me 
know if this causes you a problem. Colin Bailey is in Houston next week if 
you need or want to know any of the detail.

Regards

Date: Thu, 7 Dec 2000 01:53:00 -0800 (PST)
From: jeff.youngflesh@enron.com
To: jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
Subject: Re: Bristol Babcock/Pagosa Energy - Well Master/Enron meeting notes
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Jeff Youngflesh
X-To: Jennifer Medcalf
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Jennifer,
I had forgotten to invite Roy, but I did tell him about the meeting, and he 
was OK w/getting the notes after the fact.  I also told him I would not 
forget to keep him in the loop and invited to any future meetings.

As for Ron Smith, I really have egg on my face.  I totally forgot about Ron 
(I was thinking only Instromet, and S-J was running with that).  I think that 
in my excitement and effort to get this meeting put together, I overlooked a 
few important details.  I will certainly do a better job next time!

Thanks for the reminder!

JY
p.s. I was unable to get w/George during the day yesterday, but I did catch 
him at about 6:35pm.  I gave him my update on the latest BMC/EBS activities 
(Crowder is going to meet w/Philippe today).  He gave me some good feedback, 
and I think that for the most part, I'm on the right track.  The only thing 
I've done which I feel could provide (potential) negative exposure, based on 
feedback from George; is discussing w/BMC the idea that perhaps EBS could do 
the buy/take $1MM, and pay/keep credit of $2MM...I wasn't admonished, but KGW 
felt that I would have been better off not discussing that w/BMC...You and I 
can talk, though, because I'm not so sure that it was a bad thing, in this 
case.  But next time, there won't be a next time - so that won't be an issue 
anyway!



	Jennifer Medcalf@ECT
	12/07/2000 08:45 AM
		
		 To: Jeff Youngflesh/NA/Enron@ENRON
		 cc: 
		 Subject: Re: Bristol Babcock/Pagosa Energy - Well Master/Enron meeting notes

Jeff,
The meeting minutes look great and that it was a very beneficial meeting for 
all parties.  Was Roy or Ron invited?  If not let's make sure that they are 
at the next meeting so we do not get any static from them.
Jennifer

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: Robert Thompson <rthompson@college.edu>
Subject: RE: Following up from the conference

Dear Robert,

I'm glad to hear that you're interested in collaborating! I think this project has the potential to make a significant contribution to our field. I am available for a video conference next Wednesday at 10 AM EST, if that suits you. We can discuss our research findings and ideas for the paper in more detail.

In the meantime, I have attached a draft of the first section of my paper, focusing on the initial reactions to the heliocentric theory within the Catholic Church. Please feel free to provide any feedback or suggestions.

Looking forward to our discussion next week.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Jennings <olivia.jennings@montanamuseum.org>
To: Liam Nakamura <liam.nakamura@cretaeceousdinofossils.com>
Subject: Exciting new theropod discovery!

Hey Liam,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to reach out because I recently made a fascinating discovery at one of our dig sites in Montana. We uncovered a new theropod fossil that exhibits some unique features, and I think it could have significant implications for our understanding of theropod evolution.

I was hoping to collaborate with you on a research paper analyzing the fossil and its potential impact. Your expertise in Cretaceous theropods would be invaluable. Are you interested in working together on this project?

Let me know your thoughts!

Best regards,
Olivia

body:
Message-ID: <32362089.1075849624300.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Thu, 30 Nov 2000 10:13:00 -0800 (PST)
From: jeff.youngflesh@enron.com
To: chaz.vaughan@enron.com, stephen.morse@enron.com
Subject: EBS opp'ty w/BMC
Cc: jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
X-From: Jeff Youngflesh
X-To: Chaz Vaughan, Stephen Morse
X-cc: Jennifer Medcalf
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Chaz & Steve,

I was able to review our recently completed conference call w/BMC with 
Jennifer Medcalf.  

During the call, Bernie Goicoechea and Ann(e?) Munson expressed that during 
their last few months of interaction with Enron Net Works, they have 
attempted to understand the exact issues and concerns which Net Works has 
with regard to selection/use of BMC's products.  Bernie voiced that he hasn't 
been able to get more detail on the problems or nature of concerns that Net 
Works has, beyond what you and I know.  The BMC account team feels that 
without specifics, they cannot address the issues accurately or in a timely 
fashion.

The Enron Net Works team has expressed concern that various BMC products are 
not Windows 2000 certified (at least, not the ones they are focused on, and 
not in writing).  Net Works also have some other concerns relative to the 
(Net Works) team's feelings that the BMC products (in some areas) "...haven't 
kept up with the industry", and that they (Net Works) have some residual 
issues with the BMC account support in general.  Bottom Line, expressed by 
Net Works, is that there is a low probability of their purchasing enough BMC 
software product this year to enable EBS to clinch its deal with BMC.

You related Jim Crowder's suggestion related to the use of indemnification 
and liquidated damages clauses being implemented.  Jennifer and I discussed 
this situation, and our meetings with your team, in context.  We have a 
possible alternative for you to consider:  perhaps EBS might provide a hedge 
for Net Works in the form of "advance purchase" of BMC product.

For example, EBS is poised to buy about $1 million worth of BMC software, but 
needs to show BMC a firm purchase commitment for about $3 million in total 
Enron purchases from BMC.  A way in which you could reach the $3 million mark 
with BMC; while also allowing the relationships between Net Works and BMC 
time to "click" might be this:  EBS buys all $3 million worth of BMC 
software, but $1 million is used to actually take product now, and the other 
$2 million is used as a "future purchases" fund, in which EBS buys, but does 
not take immediate delivery of, the (remaining $2 million worth of) current 
software...

THEN, future Enron Net Works (and any other ENE business unit) purchases of 
BMC software would be executed such that EBS is paid, and the software is 
delivered from/by BMC.  That way, EBS gets its $2 million back, the other 
business units aren't spending any of today's dollars for product which they 
seem to have some concerns about (but they can get current/certified product 
when they need it in the future).  In addition, you secure the business with 
BMC right now.  I'm sure you could also figure out how to account for the 
time value of money in this, so that there is further leverage advantage to 
you.

If all else fails, you may wish to consider something like this...In the 
meantime, we will continue along the current path and keep you posted on 
progress.

Thanks,

Jeff

Jeff Youngflesh
Director, Business Development
Global Strategic Sourcing
Enron Corp.
333 Clay Street, 11th Floor
Houston, TX 77002
t:  713-345-5968
f:  713-646-2450
c:  713-410-6716

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <jsmith@historyteacher.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@historyprof.com>
Subject: RE: Fascinating new book on WWII

Hi Emily,

Thank you for the recommendations! I've added them to my reading list and look forward to exploring them further. I'd love to see your lesson plans that incorporate these topics, so please do share when you have a chance.

I am planning to attend the NCHE conference next month! It will be my first time attending, and I'm really looking forward to it. It would be fantastic to meet up and discuss our experiences in person. Perhaps we could even co-present a session on incorporating lesser-known aspects of WWII into our curricula?

I'll send you my schedule once I have it, and we can find a time to meet up.

Thanks again for the resources and the invitation!

Best,
John

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@hillsideacademy.edu>
To: Michael Chen <michael.chen@oakwoodschool.org>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the workshop!

Hi Michael,

I'm thrilled that you're on board with the cross-curricular project! It sounds like our students will have a fantastic learning experience working together on creating interactive math lessons.

Presenting our collaboration at the "Innovations in Math Education" conference is a brilliant idea! It would be a wonderful opportunity to share our experiences and insights with other educators. We could showcase the projects created by our students and discuss the benefits of integrating coding into math education.

I'm happy to take the lead on preparing the presentation and coordinating with the conference organizers. We can work together on putting together the content and deciding how best to present our students' work.

I can't wait to see the amazing projects our students will create together! This collaboration is going to be a great learning experience for all of us.

Let's touch base soon to discuss the project timeline and start planning our conference presentation.

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@digitalliteracyforall.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@cybersafekids.org>
Subject: RE: National Digital Literacy Conference

Emily,

That's fantastic news! I'm thrilled that our hard work is being recognized on a national level. I completely agree with your suggestion to focus our presentation on our successful school programs and our expansion plans. It's also a great opportunity to emphasize the importance of collaboration between different experts in this field.

For the presentation, I think we should include some specific case studies from the schools we've worked with, highlighting the positive impact our program has had on students' digital literacy skills and online safety awareness. We could also discuss the challenges we faced and how we overcame them, to provide a more comprehensive picture of our journey.

I'll start looking into travel arrangements and lodging options, and will send you the details as soon as I have them. Let's also schedule a call next week to brainstorm further and divide the tasks for the presentation.

Congratulations again, Emily! This is a major milestone for our collaboration, and I'm excited to take our work to the next level.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@university.edu>
To: Jenna Summers <jenna.summers@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Draft of the research paper

Hi Jenna,

Thanks for sending over the latest draft. I've had a chance to review it and I think it looks great! You've done an excellent job of incorporating our discussion points and strengthening the overall argument.

I have a few minor suggestions for wording and formatting, but overall I think we're in a good place to start submitting to journals. I'm excited to see where this goes!

Also, I've been thinking about our discussion on potential applications of our findings. I did some research and found a few industries that could benefit from our method. I'd love to brainstorm some ideas for future projects based on this.

Let me know when you're available to chat more.

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Emily Hartley <ehartley@healthsciencewriting.com>
To: Dr. Gregory Howell <ghowell@botanyuniversity.edu>
Subject: Seeking expertise for an article on medicinal plants

Dear Dr. Howell,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Emily Hartley, and I'm a health science writer currently working on a series of articles about the potential medicinal uses of plants. Our mutual acquaintance, Dr. Sarah Thompson, suggested that I reach out to you for your expertise in plant reproduction and life cycles.

I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to discuss your research and insights on this topic, as I believe your knowledge could significantly contribute to the accuracy and depth of my articles. If you're willing to help, I'd be happy to schedule a call at your convenience to discuss further.

Thank you for considering my request. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Best regards,
Emily Hartley

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@mail.com>
To: Dr. Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@gamedesigntheorist.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on game design and economics

Dear Dr. Nguyen,

Thank you so much for your prompt and informative response. I really appreciate you taking the time to share these valuable resources and insights with me.

The concept of using incentives and rewards to drive player behavior is particularly intriguing to me. I can see how carefully designing the economic systems within a game can create a more engaging and motivating experience for players.

I will definitely dive into the resources you recommended. "The Art of Game Design" and "Rules of Play" sound like essential reads for anyone looking to deepen their understanding of game design principles. I'm also excited to check out the Extra Credits YouTube channel and explore their series on video game economies.

As I progress with my game development projects, I will likely have more specific questions related to applying economic principles. It's reassuring to know that I can reach out to you for guidance.

Thank you once again for your generosity in sharing your knowledge. Your expertise is greatly appreciated, and I'm excited to continue learning from you.

Best regards,
Alex Thompson
label: research

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 09/08/2000 
12:29 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:35:20 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net>, "Diana Zuniga" 
<invest@bga.com> 
Subject: Sagewood Town Homes


I was aware that Regan Lehman, the lot developer for the entire 70 lot
duplex project, was selling his units in the $180's,  He does have a much
lower basis in the lots than anyone else, but the prime differences are due
to a) he is selling them during construction and b) they are smaller units.
We do not know the exact size of each of his units, but we believe one of
the duplexes is a 1164/1302 sq ft. plan.  This would produce an average sq
footage of 1233, which would be $73.80 psf at $182,000.  (I thought his
sales price was $187,000.)  At this price psf our 1,376 sf unit would sell
for $203,108.
What is more important, in my view, is a) the rental rate and b) the
rent-ability.  You have all of our current rental and cost data for your own
evaluation.  As for rent-ability, I believe that we have shown that the
3-bedroom, 3.5 bath is strongly preferred in this market.    In fact, if we
were able to purchase additional lots from Regan we would build 4 bedroom
units along with the 3-bedroom plan.
Phillip, I will call you today to go over this more thoroughly.
Sincerely,
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC

Hi Alex,

I love the idea of inviting a local politician to the workshop! It would definitely provide a valuable perspective on the importance of critical thinking and reasoning skills in real-world decision-making. I'm excited to see how the students will react to this addition.

Thank you for offering to handle the invitation and coordination with the politician. That would be a great help, and it allows me to focus on finalizing the math game and preparing other materials for the workshop.

I'm looking forward to our collaboration and making this workshop a success. Please keep me updated on the progress with the politician, and let's schedule a meeting soon to discuss the game and other workshop details.

Best,
Jenna

Message-ID: <7524774.1075849624553.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Sat, 2 Dec 2000 04:23:00 -0800 (PST)
From: sarah-joy.hunter@enron.com
To: jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
Subject: broadband solutions architect
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Sarah-Joy Hunter
X-To: Jennifer Medcalf
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Jennifer:

Mike Rabon had just forwarded to me this helpful synopsis of the opportunity 
with Kinko's as he sees it.  I would like to forward this on to James 
Thompson to assist him in targeting the right person for us to work with (and 
cc Mike Rabon).  Is this a good idea to forward on the e-mail or is it 
overkill given the e-mail I sent yesterday? Second, could I mention "Gary 
King" Mike Rabon's Kinko's contact in the e-mail?

Thanks for your suggestion!  SJ




Mr. Thompson:

Here are several "touchpoints" identified by Mike Rabon, the Enron Broadband 
Services originator, which may facilitate your finding the appropriate 
broadband solutions architect at Kinko's.  You may recall having met Mike 
Rabon in the October 6th meeting. 

Kinko's has an IP network today with access to all branches.  Kinko's had 
expressed the need to add more hubs to that network and make some changes to 
it in the spring 2001 time frame.  Enron's goal would be to make a needs 
assessment for the desired structure that Kinko's would like to see as it 
pertains to:
Near term network planning.
IP Transport - Capacity requirements for Mbps, and burst potential.
IP Transit - Capacity requirements and current contract usage for internet 
transit. Kinkos.com in particular has a high potential for IP transit 
capacity.
Storage - As the hubs and branch numbers grow, there may be a need for 
managed storage. Enron's solution will reduce, or eliminate the need to buy 
storage devices. Mike Rabon would like to speak with someone at Kinko's about 
your storage strategy and growth.
Collocation - There is a substantial opportunity for Enron to provide the 
actual space to be used for the hubs, as well as the IP transport from the 
hubs.
Interactive Video - Enron's IPNet Connect product will allow high quality 
H.323 video conferencing at bandwidths well above 768K. Utilizing the Enron 
IPNet Connect network installed to branches can allow video costs to be 
significantly reduced, and allow much higher video quality.  Enron's 
utilization of IP precedence will allow business traffic, internet traffic 
and video traffic to traverse the same network.  Mike Rabon would like to 
speak to the Video Conferencing product manager.
Risk Management - Enron's expertise in Risk Management needs to be 
communicated to the proper person.

body:
<email>
From: Raj Patel <raj.patel@globalhealth.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@washadvocates.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting new water purification technology

Hi Emily,

Thank you for sharing this exciting news! I had not heard of the Solar Water Purifier before, but it sounds like a promising solution for our projects. I would definitely be interested in learning more about its technical specifications, cost, and implementation requirements.

I think this technology could have a significant impact on the communities we serve, especially in remote areas where access to clean water is limited. It would be great to discuss this further and explore the possibility of a pilot project in either Kenya or India.

Speaking of which, I have been invited to speak at the Global Health Conference in Geneva next month and would love to include some of our collaborative work in my presentation. I think our projects could serve as great case studies for innovative WASH solutions. Would you be open to discussing this further and providing some input on the content?

I'm available for a call next week, so please let me know what works best for you.

Best,
Raj

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Carlisle <ecarlisle@londonuni.ac.uk>
To: James Thompson <jthompson@chicagopostalhistory.org>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the World Stamp Show!

Dear James,

Thank you for your email! It was wonderful to meet you as well, and I thoroughly enjoyed our dinner conversation. It's always a pleasure to connect with someone who shares my passion for postal history.

The conference was indeed quite an experience. It was my first time attending the World Stamp Show, and I was blown away by the sheer scale of it all. The exhibits were incredible, and I came away with several new additions to my own collection.

I would be delighted to collaborate with you on a research project. In fact, I've been working on an article about the role of the postal system in the spread of information during the 19th century, and I think your expertise would be invaluable. Perhaps we could set up a video call to discuss this further?

Please do keep me updated on your collection, and if I come across any interesting pieces, I'll be sure to let you know.

Best wishes,
Emily
label: research

Although I would prefer to see the counterparty name for failed transactions, 
it is not of great importance and I certainly understand a third party system 
not supplying us with that info.




Andy Zipper@ENRON
07/31/2000 01:51 PM
To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Houston Street

John,

As you are probably aware we did a click through deal with Houston Street, 
whereby EOL prices would be posted on their platform. The initial thought was 
that this would be transparent to the trading desks; they wouldn't care 
whether the trade came from Houston Street, True Quote or EOL (although we 
could make the platform name available to you if you so desired.) This still 
will be the case except for one problem: Houston Street does not want us to 
reveal the counterparty name to the trader in the event of a failed 
transaction. I don't know whether this is an issue for you or not, but I 
would like to know. We will probably run into this issue with any platform we 
deal with for obvious anonymity reasons. I would really appreciate your 
thoughts/concerns.

-Andy
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Sanjay Patel <spatel@berkeley.edu>
To: Margaret Thompson <mthompson@sbts.edu>
Subject: Great to meet you at the conference!

Hi Margaret,

It was such a pleasure to meet you at the Religion, Culture, and the Environment conference last week. I really enjoyed your presentation on the environmental stewardship mandate in the Geneva Bible and its influence on American history. As someone who teaches and writes about environmental ethics from a more secular perspective, I found your talk really fascinating and thought-provoking.

I would love to continue our conversation about the intersections of religion, philosophy, and environmental responsibility. I'm curious to hear more about your perspective on the role of faith communities in addressing environmental issues today. Do you see this as an important priority for your church and denominational community?

I'd also be happy to share more about my work on eco-feminism and animal rights if you're interested. I think there could be some interesting parallels and points of connection with your own scholarship, even though we're coming from quite different angles.

Let me know if you'd like to continue the conversation via email or even set up a time to chat by phone or video. I'd be glad to hear your thoughts!

All the best,
Sanjay

body:
Message-ID: <29461819.1075858635353.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 24 Oct 2001 19:22:28 -0700 (PDT)
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: Natural Gas Origination
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Enron Americas - Office of the Chairman@ENRON
X-To: All Enron Employees North America@ENRON <??SAll Enron Employees North America@ENRON>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


Our natural gas business continues to benefit from effective account management and resource allocation focused on identifying and responding to the needs of our varied customers.  In order to keep our organization optimally structured and to facilitate additional growth, we are making the following changes:

Producer/Wellhead Group 
The current mid-market, origination and wellhead pricing activity currently within the Central and Eastern Gas Regions will be consolidated with the Derivatives group under Fred Lagrasta.  This will create a single business unit focused upon the needs of the producing industry within the Eastern U.S.  The producer focus in the Western U.S. and Texas will remain unchanged reporting  to Mark Whitt and Brian Redmond respectively.

Strategic Asset  Development
Laura Luce will move from her role in the Central Region to lead an effort focused strictly on identifying and entering into long-term strategic arrangements within the Central and Eastern Regions.  This initiative will focus on a limited number of selected markets that provide strategic opportunities for partnering in asset development, asset management and optimization.  This effort will continue to work very closely with the regional leads.

Central Origination and Mid-Market
Frank Vickers will continue his current role in the Eastern Region and will assume the leadership role for Mid-Market and Origination activity in the Central Region. 
 

There will be no changes to the West and Texas Origination groups headed respectively by Barry Tycholiz and Brian Redmond. 

Please join us in congratulating Fred, Laura and Frank in their new roles.

Louise & John

Sent:	Monday, November 19, 2001 10:26 AM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.
Cc:	McDaniel, Kirk; Coleman, Brad; O'rourke, Tim
Subject:	BRM Case & Options
Importance:	High

Phillip,

I am following up to our BRM conversation from Friday.  Obviously it is a valid questions to ask and as you requested I am attaching two documents: one summarizing the options and  2nd cash flow impact.  In the cash flow impact Case 2 & 3 already account for additional cut of 100k from existing cost.  (it comes from Expenses such as projected traveling 30K+Cut in Media 20K + Cut in sim exercises 50K)  The cut in sim exercises need to be confirmed with you. A total of two sims could be cut one.  Accenture will address this question tomorrow during the meeting.  Also,  I will ask them to cut the meeting by 10 min, thus we can go over the documents and can answer your questions.  I am not sure what is Tim's schedule for tomorrow, but at least Kirk and myself will be around. 

Obviously cutting sims is not the best options but we are considering all alternatives at this time.  We will continue to review how to cut labor and expenses.
One question that it would be good if you think about it before we meet is as follow.  Is BRM "core" to the Enron for next few months or new organization?  Please consider the costs of finishing this project.


Sincerely,


Yevgeny Frolov
713-345-8250 w

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: David Smith <dsmith@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Interesting article on Homo erectus diet

Hi David,

That's great that you've been finding some interesting things in Africa. I'm really excited to hear all about it when you get back. It sounds like we may have a lot to discuss and potentially some new directions to explore in our research.

In the meantime, I'll start digging into this new evidence about Homo erectus' diet and see if I can find any other articles or studies that support or refute it. If we can incorporate this into our research, it could really strengthen our arguments.

Safe travels and I'll talk to you soon!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@conservation.org>
To: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@waterquality.net>
Subject: RE: Collaborative Project Proposal

Michael,

Next Wednesday at 2 PM EST works perfectly for me. I'll keep an eye out for the Zoom link.

That's a great idea to involve local stakeholders. I have some contacts at the Chesapeake Bay Foundation and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources who might be interested in collaborating. I'll reach out to them to gauge their interest and see if they can provide any insights or resources for our project.

In terms of funding, I came across a few potential opportunities that I think we should explore:

1. The National Science Foundation's Environmental Biology Program
2. The EPA's STAR (Science to Achieve Results) Grants
3. The Chesapeake Bay Trust's Research and Innovation Grants

I'll gather more information on each of these and send it your way before our call.

I'm really excited about the potential of this project and the impact we could make together. See you next Wednesday!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@radiationresponse.org>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@emergencymanagement.gov>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference on radiological disaster response

Sarah,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out because I recently received an invitation to speak at the National Radiological Disaster Response Conference in Atlanta next month. I was thinking about our experiences working together on the Piedmont incident and the paper we co-authored. Would you be interested in presenting with me? I think our unique perspective would be valuable to the attendees.

Let me know if you're available and if you have any other ideas for the presentation. I'm happy to take the lead on the slides if you'd like.

Best regards,
John

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <ethompson@oakvillees.org>
To: Rachel Nguyen <rnguyen@oakvillees.org>
Subject: Health-Themed Reading Fair Planning

Hi Rachel,

I hope you're doing well! As you know, our school's wellness committee has been discussing the idea of hosting a health-themed reading fair for our students and their families. I think this is a great opportunity to promote literacy and healthy habits in our community.

I was thinking we could hold the event on Saturday, May 15th, from 10 am to 2 pm. We could feature interactive reading stations, health screenings, and a special guest speaker. What do you think about this plan? Do you have any suggestions or ideas for activities?

I'd love to hear your thoughts and start working together to make this event a success. Let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Liam O'Connor <liam.oconnor@university.edu.au>
To: Emily Ashton <emily.ashton@university.co.uk>
Subject: Draft chapter for review

Hi Emily,

I hope you're doing well. I've just finished drafting the chapter on the impact of English colonization on Aboriginal Australian cultures during the 17th century. I've attached the draft for your review and feedback.

As you'll see, I've tried to integrate our discussions on the political and cultural context of Restoration England with my research on the early European exploration and mapping of Australia. Please let me know if you think I've misrepresented or overlooked any key points.

I'm also planning to send the full draft of the manuscript to the publisher by the end of next month. Do you think we'll be able to finalize everything by then?

Looking forward to your thoughts!

Best,
Liam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Rodriguez <mrodriguez@university.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@suburbanhealth.org>
Subject: RE: Urgent: Lyme disease outbreak in Oakwood

Hi Emily,

I'm so sorry to hear about the outbreak in Oakwood. Lyme disease can be particularly challenging to control, but I'm confident that with the right strategies, you can get it under control.

I'd be more than happy to discuss this with you further. How about we schedule a call for tomorrow afternoon? I have some time between 2-4 PM. Let me know what works best for you.

In the meantime, I'll gather some resources and case studies that might be helpful for your team. I'll send them over before our call.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@healthsciencewriters.com>
To: Dr. Emily Davis <emily.davis@envirosciences.org>
Subject: RE: Interview Request for Upcoming Article Series

Dear Dr. Davis,

Thank you so much for agreeing to the interview! I greatly appreciate your willingness to share your expertise with my readers.

September 15th works perfectly for me. I will be attending the conference from the beginning, so I can meet you at the venue during one of the breaks, as you suggested. Please let me know which break would be most convenient for you, and I will ensure to be there.

I am truly excited about our collaboration and the opportunity to learn more about your groundbreaking research. Your work is crucial in raising awareness about the impact of environmental factors on human health, and I am honored to have the chance to share it with my audience.

Thank you once again, and I look forward to meeting you in person at the conference.

Best regards,
Sarah Johnson
Health Science Writer
label: research

Subject: RE: Sun Safety App for Kids

Hi Emily,

Thanks for sharing this! The "SunSmart Kids" app sounds like a fantastic resource for our little ones. I'm always on the lookout for innovative tools to help children learn about important topics like sun safety.

I would greatly appreciate it if you could send me more information about the app, including any research findings and user reviews you have. I'd love to try it out with my students and see how effective it is in teaching them about the importance of sun protection.

Thank you for thinking of me and for your commitment to promoting health and wellness in our community!

Best,
Jake

body:
<email>
From: Liam Patel <liam.patel@oakwoodhigh.edu>
To: Dr. Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@who.int>
Subject: RE: Request for expert input on school nutrition programs

Dear Dr. Thompson,

Thank you so much for your detailed and insightful response. Your expertise has provided me with a much deeper understanding of the topic and will be invaluable in strengthening my essay.

I was particularly struck by your point about the importance of nutrition education and promoting healthy eating habits. In my research, I've found that many school nutrition programs have focused primarily on providing healthy meals, but less on educating students about making healthy choices. Do you think this is a significant gap in current approaches, and if so, what strategies do you believe would be most effective in addressing it?

I'd also be interested to hear more about your current research project on the effectiveness of school nutrition programs across Europe. What have been some of the key findings so far, and are there any particular success stories or best practices that stand out?

Thank you again for taking the time to share your knowledge and insights. I greatly appreciate your support and encouragement.

Best regards,
Liam Patel
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@spacepolicy.org>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@spacelaw.org>
Subject: RE: Space debris mitigation paper

Hi Jordan,

I hope you're doing well. I've been reviewing our draft and I think we have a strong argument, but I'm a bit concerned about the conflicting opinion from Dr. Richardson. Do you think we should address it directly in our paper, or is it better to focus on strengthening our own position?

I'm also excited about the opportunity to present at the Global Space Policy Conference next month. It's a great chance to get our research in front of key decision-makers. We should start thinking about how we want to structure our presentation and what key points we want to emphasize.

Let me know your thoughts on both of these matters. I'm happy to discuss further and work on revisions to the paper.

Best regards,
Alex

Message-ID: <2761027.1075849624277.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Thu, 30 Nov 2000 09:43:00 -0800 (PST)
From: sarah-joy.hunter@enron.com
To: jeffrey.shankman@enron.com
Subject: Continental/Enron meeting, December 11th, 2-3 PM
Cc: jennifer.burns@enron.com, jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: jennifer.burns@enron.com, jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
X-From: Sarah-Joy Hunter
X-To: Jeffrey A Shankman
X-cc: jennifer.burns@enron.com, Jennifer Medcalf
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Mr. Shankman:

In preparation for the meeting on December 11th with Larry Kellner, CFO, 
Continental Airlines I have noted below some background on the 
Enron/Continental relationship and the purpose for the meeting.  We would 
appreciate your answers to a couple of questions below.

Background:

Ron Howard, Vice President, Continental Food Services, met earlier this year 
with George Wasaff, Managing Director, Enron Corporation Global Strategic 
Sourcing and Tracy Ramsey, Sourcing Portfolio Leader,  to review the strong 
business relationship in fuel management and travel services which  Enron has 
had with Continental Airlines.  Discussions were held as to how this 
relationship could be expanded favorably for both companies.

A subsequent meeting held October 25th enabled decision makers from both 
companies to act on these earlier discussions and explore opportunities to 
expand beyond the current fuel management and travel initiatives to those in 
weather derivatives and plastics hedging.

December 11th Meeting Purpose:  Follow-up from October 25th meeting to 
specifically address Larry Kellner (who could not make the October 25th 
meeting) on three initiatives in order of $ magnitude:  (1) fuel management, 
(2) weather derivatives, and (3) plastics hedging -- VaR analysis.

Location:  Larry Kellner's office will be getting back to us regarding his 
availability to do a quick tour of the trading floor.  If he can make it for 
a trading floor tour Kellner would meet at Enron Corporation; otherwise, he 
is requesting that Enron Executives meet in his executive offices at 1600 
Smith Street.  Is either location fine for you or do you have a specific 
preference?

Meeting Attendees from Continental Airlines:

Ron Howard, Vice President, Food Services
Larry Kellner, Chief Financial Officer
Greg Hartford, Vice President, Fuel Management Company
Jeff Misner, Vice President and Treasurer (tentative)

Mr. Shankman, who would you like to have at the meeting from Enron? To date, 
we have coordinated through John Nowlan.  At the October 25th meeting,  Alan 
Engberg and Mark Tawney presented the plastics hedging and weather 
derivatives opportunities, respectively.  

Next week, I will be forwarding a short briefing which outlines  Enron's 
current relationship with Continental in fuel management and the proposed 
initiatives in both weather derivatives and plastics hedging.  Larry 
Gagliardi, Craig Breslau, Alan Engberg, and Gary Taylor are all providing 
input on this.

Sarah-Joy Hunter
Enron Corporation
Global Strategic Sourcing -- Business Development
#(713)-345-6541

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Marcus Tanaka <marcus.tanaka@wbpediatrics.com>
To: Evelyn Jennings <evelyn.jennings@willowbrook.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on the Community Health & Science Fair Exhibit

Dear Evelyn,

Thank you for reaching out about the Community Health & Science Fair exhibit. I'm delighted to have the opportunity to collaborate with you on this important project.

I think your idea of incorporating a paleontological perspective is fascinating and could provide a unique context for understanding the history of disease and immunity. As a pediatrician specializing in adolescent medicine, I'm particularly interested in highlighting the impact of vaccinations on young people's health and the ongoing challenges in preventing the spread of infectious diseases.

I would be happy to meet for coffee next week to discuss our ideas further. How about we meet at the Willowbrook Café on Tuesday morning, say around 9 AM? Let me know if that works for you.

I look forward to working together to create an engaging and informative exhibit for the community.

Best regards,
Dr. Marcus Tanaka

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Jones <samantha.jones@cybersecure.com>
To: Michael Chen <michael.chen@cybersecure.com>
Subject: RE: Urgent: Multiple clients targeted by sophisticated malware attack

Michael,

I agree with your approach. We need to be cautious and limit the information we share with the client until we can rule out any potential moles. I've already started working on a containment plan, and I'll share it with you during our call at 2 PM.

In the meantime, I'll continue analyzing the malware samples to see if I can find any clues about the attackers' identity or their motivations. I'll also reach out to our contacts in the cybersecurity community to see if they have any information that could help us with our investigation.

Let's reconvene after our call and develop a comprehensive plan to deal with this threat.

Best,
Samantha
