cc:  
Subject: Site Location Advisory Service




I am pleased to inform you that one of Canada's leading business service
providers, Grant Thornton LLP, is now offering US firms a full Site Location
Advisory Service.

With over forty offices across Canada, Grant Thornton LLP knows Canada.  We
are finding that more and more US corporations are looking north as they are
faced with fewer satisfactory location alternatives in which to expand.
Canada, with its relatively large and well trained work force, not to
mention lower operating costs, is increasingly being considered by companies
such as yours.

Grant Thornton LLP would be pleased to discuss this service with you.  It is
a full service that includes, on your behalf, real estate sourcing, labor
force analysis and verification, tax analysis and comparison, and incentive
negotiations.

Should you be considering expanding your operations and interested in
discussing our service, please give us a call.  More and more United States
firms, from call centers to manufacturers are locating in Canada to serve
both their US and Canadian customers.

Based in Moncton, New Brunswick Canada, I can be reached at:

 Telephone     (506) 857-0100
 Cell Phone    (506) 381-1450
 E-Mail           mmacbride@grantthornton.ca


Michael S. MacBride, CMA
Senior Consultant

Grant Thornton LLP
Chartered Accountants
PO Box 1005
633 Main Street Suite 500
Moncton New Brunswick Canada  E1C 8P2


This e-mail is intended solely for the person or entity to which it is
addressed and may contain confidential and/or privileged information.  Any
review, dissemination, copying, printing or other use of this e-mail by
persons or entities other than the addressee is prohibited.  If you have
received this e-mail in error, please contact the sender immediately and
delete the material from any computer.
label: corporate

body:
Dear Ma'am, 

     Hope this mail finds you well.
I am Dhruv Gupta, an undergraduate student currently in my second year. I am writing this mail to you on behalf of my teammates regarding a project we need to do for the MA202 course. 

     The project revolves around the concepts of probability distribution and data analysis. We are required to find a mentor and do the project under her guidance. Therefore, I would like to meet you with my teammates to go through the various options for any such project in your area of expertise.

Thanks and regards
label: student

body:
<email>
From: MariaHuber@gmx.de
To: drjones@pawspatients.com
Subject: RE: Heartworm prevention for German Shepherds

Hi Dr. Jones,

Thank you so much for your helpful advice! I appreciate you taking the time to share your knowledge with me. "Heartgard Plus" sounds like a great option for heartworm prevention. I'll make sure to get a supply once I adopt my German Shepherd.

I love the idea of having educational materials and a booth at the pet adoption event. It would be wonderful if we could work together to help new pet owners understand the importance of heartworm prevention and overall pet health. Please let me know what I can do to assist you in setting this up.

Once again, thank you for your support. I'm looking forward to becoming a responsible dog owner and making a positive impact at the adoption event.

Best regards,
Maria Huber
label: research

Message-ID: <2386080.1075858636077.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Thu, 25 Oct 2001 21:43:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: IMPORTANT-To All Domestic Employees who Participate in the Enron
 Corp Savings Plan
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Corporate Benefits@ENRON
X-To: All Enron Employees United States Group@ENRON <??SAll Enron Employees United States Group@ENRON>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


If you are a participant in the Enron Corp. Savings Plan, please read this very important message.

We understand that you are concerned about the timing of the move to a new Savings Plan administrator and the restricted access to your investment funds during the upcoming transition period scheduled to take place beginning at 3:00PM CST on October 26 and ending at 8:00AM CST on November 20.  

We have been working with Hewitt and Northern Trust since July.  We understand your concerns and are committed to making this transition period as short as possible without jeopardizing the reconciliation of both the Plan in total or your account in particular.  

Remember that the Enron Corp. Savings Plan is an investment vehicle for your long-term financial goals.  The Enron plan will continue to offer a variety of investment opportunities with different levels of risk.  

As always, we advise you to review your overall investment strategy and carefully weigh the potential earnings of each investment choice against its risk before making investment decisions that are aligned with your long-term financial plans and your risk tolerance. 

For that reason, it is critical that ALL trades among your investment funds be completed by 3:00 PM CST Friday, October 26 before the transition period begins.
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Emily Holloway <emily.holloway@university.edu>
To: David Rosenberg <david.rosenberg@academia.com>
Subject: Upcoming Conference on Human Evolution

Hi David,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to touch base with you about the upcoming conference on human evolution in Chicago next month. I'm planning to attend and present some of our latest findings on the comparison of Homo erectus and Homo sapiens migration patterns. It would be great if you could join me as a co-presenter for our session. I think it would be an excellent opportunity to showcase our collaborative work and engage with the academic community.

Let me know if you're interested and available to join me. I'd be happy to discuss the details further and help with any arrangements needed.

Looking forward to hearing from you and hopefully seeing you at the conference!

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Jennings <ejennings@treesforfuture.org>
To: David Thompson <dthompson@forestecology.net>
Subject: Exciting opportunity to collaborate

Hi David,

It was great to meet you at the forest conservation conference last week. I really enjoyed our conversation about the potential for sustainable forestry practices to mitigate climate change. I think our research interests align very well, and I would love to explore opportunities to collaborate.

I'm particularly interested in your work on the impact of forest restoration on carbon sequestration and biodiversity. I believe that combining our expertise could lead to some significant contributions to the field.

Would you be interested in co-authoring a research paper on this topic? I think we could put together a compelling proposal for the upcoming international conference on climate change mitigation strategies.

Let me know your thoughts!

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Message-ID: <24917045.1075849627545.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 19 Dec 2000 02:22:00 -0800 (PST)
From: kim.godfrey@enron.com
To: jeff.gooden@compaq.com, david.spurlin@compaq.com, bob.jordan@compaq.com
Subject: RE: Compaq / EBS Relationship
Cc: jim.crowder@enron.com, tracy.prater@enron.com, gil.melman@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: jim.crowder@enron.com, tracy.prater@enron.com, gil.melman@enron.com
X-From: Kim Godfrey
X-To: Jeff.Gooden@compaq.com, david.spurlin@compaq.com, bob.jordan@compaq.com
X-cc: Jim Crowder, Tracy Prater, Gil Melman
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Jeff,

As of Dec 14th, Enron received the message regarding David Spurlin greater 
involvement in the EBS relationship.   In the past, EBS had included David on 
the direction of our relationship and not the details.   Our prior direction 
was to have Derrick Deakins as our key point of communication.   

In regards to your comment about amending the Agreement.   I would like to 
fill yourself, David and Bob in on some history.   During the meetings in 
August 2000,  EBS and Compaq reviewed the Agreement line by line and 
identified 5 sections to be clarified / amended.  There was a group of at 
least 8 Compaq attendees (Chris Sweet took extensive notes for Compaq).  Both 
EBS and Compaq agreed on the methodology to calculate the value of the Compaq 
Minimum Annual Spend of EBS Services.   Spreadsheets were exchanged between 
both Parties and the amounts were agreed upon.   A significant amount of time 
was spent in this process between August through October.   EBS and Compaq 
(Derrick Deakins) developed contract language to clarify the outstanding 5 
sections.   This contract amendment was sent to Compaq (Rob and Derrick) for 
comments in November.   EBS has not heard anything regarding the language.  
During the course of these discussions, EBS agreed to concede on certain 
points of interpretation on the Server Purchase Agreement and Compaq agreed 
to work with EBS to achieve revenue recognition in 2000.   The EBS 
concessions were used by both Parties to develop the methodology to calculate 
the Compaq Minimum Spend toward EBS Services.  This was reason for the 
development of the EBS Consulting Payment ($832,000).   

EBS looks forward to the resolution of these issues and moving forward with 
our relationship.

Kim Godfrey
Director, Enterprise Services
Enron Broadband Services
phone : 713 345 8813
cell :      713 501 8105
fax:        713 853 7354



	Jeff.Gooden@compaq.com
	12/18/00 07:58 PM
		 
		 To: Kim Godfrey/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: 
		 Subject: RE: Compaq / EBS Relationship 

Kim,

Thank you for including me in this email...I agree, without question, Dave
Spurlin "Owns" the Enron/Compaq relationship, from Compaq's perspective.
All matters should go through Dave...Thank you, this will make your life
easier.

Although I was not in the entire meeting with yourself, Keith and Rob; My
reaction was that this agreement needs to be amended to protect both Enron
and Compaq.  We are both exposed to potential unnecessary pitfalls that are
clearly evident in the original agreement.

We look forward to resolving this issue, amending this agreement, and moving
forward in the partnership between Enron and Compaq.

Sincerely,  

Jeff Gooden
Enterprise Sales Manager
Compaq Computer Corporation
(281) 927-3500


-----Original Message-----
From: Kim_Godfrey@enron.net [mailto:Kim_Godfrey@enron.net]
Sent: Monday, December 18, 2000 5:54 PM
To: Gooden, Jeff
Subject: Compaq / EBS Relationship 




Jeff,

David asked that I include you in future Emails.

thanks,

Kim G
----- Forwarded by Kim Godfrey/Enron Communications on 12/18/00 05:57 PM
-----
|--------+----------------------->
|        |          Kim Godfrey  |
|        |                       |
|        |          12/18/00     |
|        |          05:49 PM     |
|        |                       |
|--------+----------------------->
 
>---------------------------------------------------------------------------
-|
  |
|
  |       To:     bob.jordan@compaq.com, david.spurlin@compaq.com
|
  |       cc:     Jim Crowder/Enron Communications@Enron Communications,
|
  |       Everett Plante/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Tracy
|
  |       Prater/Enron Communications@Enron Communications,
|
  |       derrick.deakins@compaq.com, Gil Melman/Enron Communications@Enron
|
  |       Communications
|
  |       Subject:     Compaq / EBS Relationship
|
 
>---------------------------------------------------------------------------
-|



David and Bob,

We look forward to working with you to strengthen the Compaq and EBS
relationship.   EBS has identified potential server business opportunities
(storage, streaming media) where our two organizations can work together.
After
our meeting on Dec 14th, EBS now understands to utilize David Spurlin as the
point person for these communications.  EBS had prior direction from Compaq
to
direct our discussions to Derrick Deakins, Rob Senders, Keith McAuliffe or
Kent
Major.  Tracy Prater and myself look forward to spending additional time
with
David to ensure that he is aware of the EBS business opportunities and
issues.

EBS had invested significant dollars, time and energy with Compaq to develop
the
streaming media server solutions.  We discussed during the Dec 14th meeting
that
there are decisions to be made regarding the existing Product and Server
Supply
Agreement that are contingent on those streaming media solutions.  EBS and
Compaq have both acted in good faith to achieve the intent of the Product
and
Server Supply Agreement in pursuing these solutions.  To that end, EBS has
had
internal discussions regarding the appropriate next steps to further our
relationship.

The January 2000 Product and Service Supply Agreement is the legal framework
for
our relationship until both parties mutually agree to change.  Until those
changes are made:
1) 2000 Compaq Annual Purchase of ECI Services:  Per the Agreement, Compaq
was
invoiced for the 2000 Minimum Annual Purchase of ECI Services on November 7,
2000 as per Sections 3.1, 3.2 and 3.3.  Compaq had agreed  to the invoice
amount.  EBS expects payment for the total invoice as outlined in Section
3.0 on
or before December 31,2000.
2) Potential for Agreement Termination:  Prior to the Dec 14th meeting,
Compaq
(Keith and Rob) have discussed this with EBS (Jim Crowder, myself).   The
understanding between both Parties was that EBS would need a written notice
and
payment by Compaq of $2,500,000.  The concept to start over with a new
contractual agreement was again discussed during the Dec 14th meeting.  EBS
strongly believes in the value of the Compaq and EBS relationship, if Compaq
believes that to start over with a new agreement is necessary then we look
forward to working with Compaq to achieve that goal.

Again, we look forward to working with yourselves to identify and create
strategic business opportunities for both EBS and Compaq.

Kim Godfrey
Director, Enterprise Services
Enron Broadband Services
phone : 713 345 8813
cell :      713 501 8105
fax:        713 853 7354

body:
<email>
From: Liam Nakamura <liam.nakamura@logictec.edu>
To: Aria Kapoor <aria.kapoor@cosmosresearch.org>
Subject: RE: Collaborative project idea

Aria,

Thank you for sending over the project details. I've reviewed the document, and I have a better understanding of the device's requirements and its role in your research.

I've started sketching out some initial designs and components that we might need. I'm thinking we can use a combination of FPGA and microcontroller units to handle the data processing and interface with the telescope's systems.

I've also been doing some research on the James Webb Space Telescope, and I'm blown away by its capabilities. It's incredible to think that our collaboration could contribute to unraveling the mysteries of the early universe.

I'm looking forward to our call on Tuesday to discuss the next steps and dive deeper into the technical aspects of the project. Please let me know if there's anything else I can do to prepare.

Best,
Liam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@berkeley.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@berkeley.edu>
Subject: RE: Progress update on our research project

Dear Dr. Thompson,

Thank you for your response and your willingness to meet next week. Tuesday at 2 PM works perfectly for me. I'll prepare a presentation to discuss the results in more detail.

I've also started working on the NSF grant application. I've outlined the key points we need to address in the proposal, including the significance of our research, the novelty of our approach, and the potential impact of our findings. I'll send you a draft of the proposal by the end of this week for your feedback and suggestions.

I greatly appreciate your support and guidance throughout this process. I couldn't ask for a better research advisor and mentor.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

just when i'm turning really bearish you're starting to turn bullish on me.  
weather to me relatively unimportant.  yes, it will leave us with 30 bcf or 
so less in storage than if we had mild weather.  i think it is masking a 
major demand problem.  think what the aga numbers would be with moderate 
weather.  when we get into injections, i think we'll see a big push down.  
spec and trade seem bearish but hesitant to get short.  customer buying still 
strong.  thus even with the demand picture becoming clearer, we haven't moved 
down.  however i think when the picture becomes clearer (i.e.-when we start 
beating last year's injections by 20 bcf a week), trade will get short.  
customers very unsophistocated.  the story they keep telling us is we're 
coming out 400 bcf less than last year, thus the summer has to be strong.  
when we start inj, customers will start seeing other side of story.  pira 
finally came out this week and said stop buying.  to me, the mrkt just a 
timing issue.  i want to be short before the rest of the idiots get short.  i 
continue buying m,f puts.  projecting k to settle 450 and m 400.

cc:

regards

Talk to you soon,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: David Rosenberg <david.rosenberg@hrconsulting.com>
To: Emily Jennings <emily.jennings@historybuffs.com>
Subject: RE: Rare stamp discovery

Emily,

Creating a narrative around the stamp and the Centennial Exposition is a fantastic idea. It'll definitely make the history more relatable and engaging for our audience. I'm excited to brainstorm with you on Saturday and finalize the structure of our presentation.

As for your idea of expanding our project to include workshops or seminars, I think it's a great initiative. Engaging the community and promoting a sense of pride and belonging through history is a powerful concept. We could potentially collaborate with local schools, libraries, and community centers to reach a wider audience.

I'll come prepared with some ideas on how we can structure these workshops and the key messages we want to convey. We can also discuss the logistics and potential partnerships during our meeting.

Looking forward to a productive discussion on Saturday!

Best,
David
label: research

Phillip

If you receive a call from someone identifying themselves as part of a government organization, please refer the caller to the legal department.  Please refer calls from the trade press and other media inquiries to the Public Relations group.  And otherwise, please treat Enron information as confidential.

To: Sam Patel <sam.patel@spacegovernance.org>
Subject: RE: Space resources and sustainable development

Hi Sam,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking more about our discussion on using space resources to support sustainable development on Earth, and I think we might be onto something really exciting here.

I've attached a draft outline for our research proposal to the Space Policy Institute. Let me know what you think and if you have any suggestions for improvement. I think if we can make a strong case for the potential benefits of this approach, we might have a good shot at getting funded.

Looking forward to your thoughts!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakvilleschool.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakvilleschool.edu>
Subject: RE: Staff meeting presentation

Hi Michael,

I love your ideas! Including student work and quotes is a great way to show the real impact coding can have. And I completely agree about creating a handout with resources - that will be so helpful for teachers who want to get started.

The Scratch project is a perfect example to showcase. It really demonstrates how coding can spark creativity and problem-solving skills. I'm also thinking about including the data analysis project my students did using Python. They were so excited to see how they could use coding to make sense of real-world data.

How about we divide and conquer? I can work on the intro and the student work examples, and you can put together the resources and tips handout. We can meet on Wednesday afternoon to put it all together and practice our presentation.

I'm so excited about this! I think it's going to be a great presentation.

Best,
Emily

Please add the following names to the mailing list:  Mike Grigsby, Frank Ermis, Keith Holst, Matt Smith, Janie Tholt

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Lawner, Leslie  
Sent:	Friday, July 13, 2001 6:21 AM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.; Kingerski, Harry; Kaufman, Paul; Tycholiz, Barry; Miller, Stephanie; Ponce, Roger; Black, Don; Hewitt, Jess; Shireman, Kristann; Courtney, Mark; Elliott, Chris; Dasovich, Jeff; Becky McCabe; Fulton, Donna; Steffes, Darla; Stoness, Scott; Johnson, Tamara
Cc:	Nicolay, Christi
Subject:	CA Instrate Gas matters

This is to quickly summarize our call on July 11 on California gas intrastate matters and set a direction for future activity.

Unbundling:	 PG&E has a Gas Accord in effect through 12/31/03, which is generally positive.  We will participate in the development of a successor plan, and attempt to improve it if we can.
  		SoCalGas attempted its own version of a gas accord, but the CPUC refused to approve.  We will attempt to resurrect this accord and obtain CPUC approval. 

Hedging:  No proceeding currently exists to address gas hedging by LDCs.  (draft legislation does exist on the electric side to allow hedging and passthrough of costs).  Jeff has recommended that we approach the LDCs to begin discussing the issue and developing a strategy to take to the CPUC.  I suggest we develop an ENA-EES hedging proposal for CA and then take that to the LDCs.  I will attempt to put this is writing.

Infrastructure:  CPUC has undertaken a proceeding to determine the need to improve infrastructure.  SoCal Gas and PG&E are responding with proposals.  We want to revitalize the infrastructure and ensure real markets exist and can develop.  Our task is to participate in these proceedings.

(Please let me know who I left off the mailing list).

To: Luisa Fernández <luisa.fernandez@bosquesverdes.org>
Subject: Exciting opportunity for collaboration

Hey Luisa,

I hope you're doing well! I was just looking through the latest newsletter from the Global Forest Network and saw that they're organizing a special issue of the International Journal of Forest Science focused on innovative approaches to sustainable forestry. I immediately thought of our ongoing research project and the paper we've been planning to write.

I think this could be a perfect opportunity to showcase our work and get our message out to a wider audience. What do you think about submitting a proposal for the special issue? We could focus on the comparative analysis of the forestry practices in Canada and Colombia and their impacts on carbon sequestration and biodiversity.

Let me know your thoughts! I'd be happy to take the lead on drafting the proposal if you're on board.

Best,
Jordan

body:
<email>
From: Mei Ling Chen <meiling.chen@asianartmuseum.org>
To: Hiroshi Nakamura <nakamura@museum-kyoto.jp>
Subject: RE: Advice on Heian period exhibit

Hiroshi,

It's wonderful to hear from you, and I'm so excited to learn about your new exhibit project. The pieces you've shared look absolutely stunning, and I can already tell this is going to be a truly exceptional showcase of Heian period Buddhist art.

I'd be more than happy to provide whatever insights and advice I can to help bring your curatorial vision to life. After looking through the images, a few key themes and ideas immediately jumped out at me that I think could be really powerful to explore in the exhibit:

1. The evolution of Buddhist iconography over the course of the Heian period, and how changes in artistic style and representation reflect the shifting religious and political landscape of the time.

2. The role of art and aesthetics in Heian period Buddhist practice, and how these artifacts would have functioned within ritual and devotional contexts.

3. The influence of Chinese and Korean Buddhist art on Heian period artists and artisans, and the ways in which they adapted and transformed these foreign styles to create something uniquely Japanese.

I'd be happy to expand on any of these ideas further, and to offer suggestions on how you might group and present the artifacts to bring out these themes most effectively. I'm also happy to look over any labels or interpretive text you're developing to provide feedback and edits.

It's been far too long since we last saw each other, and I would love to find an opportunity to meet up again soon. Perhaps I could plan a trip to Kyoto once the exhibit is installed? It would be wonderful to see it in person and to catch up properly.

I'm also curious to hear more about how things are going at your museum, and if there have been any exciting new acquisitions or projects since we last spoke.

Thank you again for reaching out, and for trusting me with your curatorial process. I'm honored to be able to play even a small role in bringing this important exhibit to life.

Warmest regards,

Mei Ling

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@feministhistory.org>
To: Mark Thompson <mark.thompson@missiledefense.com>
Subject: Follow-up from the History of Technology Conference

Dear Mark,

I hope this email finds you well. We met briefly at the History of Technology Conference last month, and I was intrigued by your work on Cold War-era space-based missile defense technology. I'm a high school history teacher, and I'm currently developing a lesson plan on the role of women in the development of this technology during the Cold War.

I was wondering if you might be willing to share any resources or insights that could help me better understand this topic from a technical perspective. I would be particularly interested in learning more about the challenges and opportunities that women faced in this field during the Cold War era.

If you have any time in the coming weeks, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to learn from your expertise. Please let me know if you would be willing to chat further, either by email or by phone.

Best regards,
Sarah Johnson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Julia Rocha <julia.rocha@ufmg.br>
To: Marco Santos <marco.santos@unb.br>
Subject: RE: Potential collaboration on Amazon infrastructure project

Hi Marco,

It's great to hear from you! I've also been thinking a lot about our discussion at the conference. A collaborative project on the socio-political and ecological impacts of that new Amazon infrastructure project sounds like a fascinating and important undertaking. 

I did some preliminary research on the project and it looks like it could have severe consequences for several sensitive wetland ecosystems and protected indigenous territories in the region. Analyzing the political drivers and decision-making behind it from your perspective could really shed light on how these kinds of large-scale projects get approved despite major environmental and social costs.

I'd definitely be interested in exploring a collaboration further. Do you want to set up a video call next week to discuss potential approaches and next steps? Let me know what works for your schedule.

Best,
Julia

<email>
From: Daniel Rodriguez <drodriguez@harmonyelementary.org>
To: Samantha Lee <slee@harmonyelementary.org>
Subject: RE: Multicultural Storybook Project Update

Hi Samantha,

Thank you for the update! I'm equally impressed with our students' dedication and creativity. They've truly embraced the spirit of this project.

Regarding the storybook layout, I think it would be great to group the pages by culture or region. This way, readers can easily follow the different stories and appreciate the cultural connections. We could also include a world map at the beginning of the book, highlighting the various countries and regions represented.

I've spoken with Principal Johnson, and she suggested holding the event on the last Friday of this month, from 6-8 PM. This should give us enough time to finalize preparations and promote the event to our school community. What do you think?

I'm excited to see our students' hard work come to fruition! Let's touch base early next week to discuss any additional details and make sure we're on track.

Best,
Daniel

To: jeff.richter@enron.com
Subject: Behind the Stage Two
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: jeff.richter@enron.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\Sent
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 03/15/2001 
02:22 PM ---------------------------


"Arthur O'Donnell" <aod@newsdata.com> on 03/15/2001 11:35:55 AM
Please respond to aod@newsdata.com
To: Western.Price.Survey.contacts@ren-10.cais.net
cc: Fellow.power.reporters@ren-10.cais.net 
Subject: Behind the Stage Two


FYI Western Price Survey Contacts

Cal-ISO's declaration of Stage Two alert this morning was triggered
in part by decision of Bonneville Power Administration to cease
hour-to-hour sales into California of between 600 MW and 1,000
MW that it had been making for the past week. According to BPA,
it had excess energy to sell as a result of running water to meet
biological opinion flow standards, but it has stopped doing so in
order to allow reservoirs to fill from runoff. The agency said it had
been telling California's Department of Water Resources that the
sales could cease at any time, and this morning they ended.

Cal-ISO reported about 1,600 MW less imports today than
yesterday, so it appears other sellers have also cut back.
Yesterday, PowerEx said it was not selling into California because
of concerns about its water reserves. BPA said it is still sending
exchange energy into California, however.

More details, if available, will be included in the Friday edition of the
Western Price Survey and in California Energy Markets newsletter.

body:
<email>
From: Rajesh Patel <rajesh.patel@who.int>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@globalaccessinitiative.org>
Subject: RE: Catching up and sharing resources

Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad to know that our work in India continues to inspire and inform your efforts back home. The project you mentioned sounds fantastic – I'm not surprised that you're leading the charge on creating more inclusive learning environments for DHH students. Your dedication to your students is truly admirable.

Thank you for sharing that report. It's a timely and relevant resource, given my current work on a global sanitation campaign. We're focusing on promoting handwashing habits and improving access to clean water in schools, which aligns perfectly with the findings in the report. I'll definitely share it with my team and see how we can incorporate some of those insights into our strategy.

I'm currently based in Geneva, but I do have some travel planned in the coming months. I'll keep you posted on my schedule and would love to take you up on that offer to meet up if I find myself in Seattle. It would be great to reconnect in person and learn more about the work you're doing.

Take care,
Rajesh

<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@dataarchive.com>
To: Dr. Samantha Jones <samantha.jones@insectecology.com>
Subject: RE: Archiving your research data

Hi Sam,

Great, I'm glad we can work together on this. I'm available on Tuesday afternoon, so let's plan to meet then. I'll send you the details once we confirm a time and place.

Regarding the archived environmental data, I think you'll find it quite useful for your research. I'll compile the relevant datasets and bring them to our meeting. 

After reviewing your research, I think there could be potential for a collaboration that combines your expertise in soil insects with my knowledge of data preservation. Perhaps we could discuss the possibility of co-authoring a paper on the subject.

I look forward to our meeting on Tuesday!

Best,
Alex

Great, 4pm it is! I'll send you a Zoom link.

For memoir, I love using short excerpts from popular memoirs like The Glass Castle, Educated, and Born a Crime. But I've also had success with having kids interview family members and write about a relative's life. They get so into it! 

I'm attaching a doc with some prompts and resources I've used. Feel free to steal and modify anything that might work for your kids. Let me know if you want me to elaborate on anything.

See you Friday!
Sarah

"Tracey Bradley" <tbradley@bracepatt.com <mailto:tbradley@bracepatt.com>> on 07/10/2001 02:10:18 PM
To:	<jlimone@aeglobalmarkets.com <mailto:jlimone@aeglobalmarkets.com>>, "Charles Shoneman" <cshoneman@bracepatt.com <mailto:cshoneman@bracepatt.com>>, "Randall Rich" <rrich@bracepatt.com <mailto:rrich@bracepatt.com>>, <rreilley@coral-energy.com <mailto:rreilley@coral-energy.com>>, <Rebecca.W.Cantrell@enron.com <mailto:Rebecca.W.Cantrell@enron.com>>
cc:	 

Subject:	El Paso Announces Binding Open Season for Additional Capacity	on Line 2000


FYI

Tuesday July 10, 9:21 am Eastern Time

Press Release
SOURCE: El Paso Corporation

El Paso Announces Binding Open Season for Additional Capacity on Line 2000

HOUSTON, July 10 /PRNewswire/ -- El Paso Natural Gas Company, a subsidiary of El Paso Corporation (NYSE: EPG - news), announced today a binding open season for 320 million cubic feet per day (MMcf/d) of pipeline capacity from the Keystone and Waha areas of the Permian Basin in West Texas to the California border near Ehrenberg, Arizona. The binding open season, which began July 5, 2001 and closes on August 2, 2001, is in response to the interest expressed during El Paso's non-binding open season in March 2001 soliciting shippers for potential system expansions.

The expansion capacity will be made available by adding compression to El Paso's Line 2000 from McCamey, Texas to the California border near Ehrenberg, Arizona. The expansion capacity will be sold at El Paso's existing maximum California tariff rate, and the fuel charge is estimated to be 5 percent. The projected in-service date of the expansion facilities is mid-2003 subject to the receipt of all necessary regulatory, environmental, and right-of-way authorizations.

The receipt points on El Paso's system for this capacity will be the Waha and Keystone pools in the Permian Basin area of West Texas. The delivery points will be Southern California Gas Company (SoCal) and PG&E's proposed North Baja Pipeline, El Paso's bi-directional lateral (Line 1903), any future incremental capacity on the SoCal system from Ehrenberg, Arizona into the State of California, and any upstream points on El Paso's south mainline system where capacity exists.

``This system expansion will add incremental interstate capacity to California, Arizona, New Mexico, and West Texas to meet increasing natural gas demands including the demand for natural gas to generate electricity for the western United States,'' said Patricia A. Shelton, president of El Paso Natural Gas Company.

Interested parties can contact their transportation marketing representative or Mr. Jerry W. Strange at (719) 520-4687.

El Paso Corporation is committed to meeting energy needs throughout North America and the world with operations that span the energy value chain from wellhead to electron. The company is focused on speeding the development of new technologies, such as clean coal and liquefied natural gas, to address critical energy shortages across the globe. Visit El Paso at www.elpaso.com <http://www.elpaso.com>.

CAUTIONARY STATEMENT REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS

This release includes forward-looking statements and projections, made in reliance on the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. The company has made every reasonable effort to ensure that the information and assumptions on which these statements and projections are based are current, reasonable, and complete. However, a variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from the projections, anticipated results or other expectations expressed in this release. While the company makes these statements and projections in good faith, neither the company nor its management can guarantee that the anticipated future results will be achieved. Reference should be made to the company's (and its affiliates') Securities and Exchange Commission filings for additional important factors that may affect actual results.

SOURCE: El Paso Corporation

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <alex.novak@autotech.com>
To: Priya Singh <priya.singh@avtech.com>
Subject: RE: Progress on the AV sensor integration paper

Hi Priya,

Thanks for your thoughtful response. You raise some excellent points about the limitations of speed sensors in certain conditions, and I agree that we need to address these issues in the paper. I think a balanced approach that acknowledges both the strengths and weaknesses of each technology is the way to go.

I'm happy to meet next week to discuss this further. Tuesday afternoon works well for me – how about we meet at 2 PM in the AVTech conference room? That should give us plenty of time to dig into the details and find a way forward.

In the meantime, I'll send you the latest draft of the paper so you can review it before our meeting. Please feel free to make any edits or suggestions directly in the document.

Looking forward to our discussion and to continuing to work together on this important project.

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@triassicreptiles.com>
To: David Lee <dlee@numericalcoder.com>
Subject: RE: Need help with paleontology data analysis

Hi David,

Thank you so much for your willingness to help with this project! I'm excited to collaborate with you and combine our expertise in biology and computer science.

I've attached a sample dataset of some of the fossil measurements I've collected, along with a document outlining the specific statistical analyses I'd like to perform. The dataset includes measurements of various anatomical features, such as limb lengths, skull dimensions, and tooth sizes, as well as information about the geological context of each specimen.

The main analyses I'm interested in are:

1. Descriptive statistics (means, standard deviations, etc.) for each anatomical feature, broken down by taxonomic group and geological formation.
2. Principal component analysis (PCA) to identify patterns of morphological variation within and among taxa.
3. Phylogenetic analyses to reconstruct the evolutionary relationships among the specimens, based on their morphological data.

I'd also like to be able to visualize the data in various ways, such as scatterplots, histograms, and phylogenetic trees.

Please let me know if you have any questions or need any additional information. I'm happy to provide more details about my research and the geological context of the specimens.

Thanks again for your help, and I look forward to working with you on this project!

Best regards,
Emily Johnson

October 26 is fast approaching!  

Mark your calendar-- 
	as the Enron Corp. Savings Plan moves to a new administrator!

As a Savings Plan Participant, Friday, October 26 at 3:00pm CST will be your last day to:

?    Transfer Investment Fund Balances and make Contribution Allocation Changes

?	Enroll if you were hired before October 1

TWO important reminders:

Should you need assistance during the transition period, call ext. 3-7979 and press Option 6.  This option will be available from 8:00am CST October 29 until 5:00pm CST November 19.

Enron Benefits... keeping pace with your lifestyle.

X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Thanks.  That is an interesting idea.  I'd like to keep the rear stairway
but that might still be possible.  Anyway, let's see what happens with the
variance.  I appreciate your efforts.

By the way, did you have any problems with any of the neighbors?

Bob

----- Original Message -----
From: <Phillip.K.Allen@enron.com>
To: <wise.counsel@lpl.com>
Sent: Wednesday, November 14, 2001 8:19 AM
Subject: RE: word file as promised


Bob,

I turned in the application for a variance yesterday.  The hearing will be
on January 8th.  In order to get on the calendar for the Dec 4th hearing,
the application had to be in by November 9th.  I was under the impression
that yesterday was the deadline.  Sorry if I dropped the ball.

On another note, I spoke to Joe Edwards yesterday and he had some useful
suggestions about the addition.   It might be possible to move the addition
forward and open up the bedroom at the top of the stairs into the new
space.  You could convert the modified bedroom into a media room and use
the new space for your game/play/music room.  Then you could close off the
existing play room to replace the bedroom lost.  Part of the play room that
is bordered by the stair rail and looks down to the living room could be
used for a built in desk with a couple of computers.  This way you would
not have to add a second staircase.  The walls needed to convert the
playroom to a bedroom should be minor construction.  In the back you could
slope the roof until you were within the setback.  Then you could place a
large dormer facing the back of the property or bring a wall straight up.
>From the driveway the addition would have the same elevation as your
drawing but intwould be brought forward with a covered parking area below
the addition.  The kitchen and dining room windows would still open to the
driveway but they would be more shaded.  That is the west side of the house
so that might not be a bad thing.  Your ideas about opening up the kitchen
to the living room or dining room would still be possible.  Personally, I
think opening the dining room would be the better idea.

I don't know if you can visualize this or if you are even interested in
exploring anything except your original plan.  But I wanted to suggest
something in case the variance was not granted.  Let me know if you want me
to try and sketch out these ideas.

Phillip
      -----Original Message-----
     From:   "Robert W. Huntley, CFP" <wise.counsel@lpl.com>@ENRON
     Sent:   Monday, November 12, 2001 11:45 AM
     To:     Allen, Phillip K.
     Subject:  word file as promised



      - Allen 8855 Merlin lttr.doc << File: Allen 8855 Merlin lttr.doc >>

fyi - our position is either pay the $2.5 million termination fee or pay the 
$4.1 million toward Compaq future purchases.  You will see a bcc of my EMail 
to Bob and Rob.  My reason for the blind copy is that I want to ensure that 
this communication is between Bob and our group.  

Kim 
----- Forwarded by Kim Godfrey/Enron Communications on 12/18/00 11:35 AM -----

	Jim Crowder
	12/17/00 07:23 PM
		
		 To: Kim Godfrey/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: Bryan Williams/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Everett 
Plante/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Marie Thibaut/Enron 
Communications@Enron Communications
		 bcc: 
		 Subject: Re: Compaq Update
		

832k is not going to have a dramatic impact on our business.  Stick with the 
2.5 number and ensure that Global Sourcing holds the line.c



	Kim Godfrey
	12/15/00 09:01 AM
		 
		 To: Everett Plante/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Jim 
Crowder/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: Marie Thibaut/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Bryan 
Williams/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 Subject: Compaq Update


	


Everett and Jim,

I have phone calls into both of you to gain your feedback and support on 
appropriate next steps with Compaq.   Everett, I am asking for your input as 
it is your cost center that purchases the Compaq servers and hence one of the 
relationship owners.  During the meeting yesterday - the following happened :
 a) Keith McAuliffe announced that he is leaving Compaq effective immediately 
(his replacement has yet to be named).  My perception is that Keith took the 
hit for Compaq missing their 4th quarter Server Business Unit sales 
projections.   EBS is not their only account who did not meet projected 
targets.  
 b) Bob Jordan - Director NA Sales reporting to Jerry Earle will expand his 
existing Enron sales relationship to include ownership of the EBS Server 
Agreement 
 c) EBS Server Agreement - Under the agreement Compaq was to buy EBS 
Services.   For the first two quarters - the Compaq purchase amount was fixed 
at $1.72 million and starting with the third month then would be based on an 
8% value of the total EBS Server spend for the prior two quarters.  EBS sent 
Compaq an invoice for $4,134,229 on November 7th.   Compaq has not paid the 
invoice.  Lou Casari's team is handling the delinquency and notifying 
Compaq.  Compaq ( Keith M.'s stewardship) had agreed to pay.  Bob stated that 
EBS has not performed to Compaq's satisfaction under the Server Agreement and 
Compaq does not believe that Compaq should be accountable to buy any EBS 
services (Bob's first negotiation position).   
 d) EBS and Compaq have different viewpoints on what should be included in 
the EBS Server Spend amount.    
  Compaq (Bob Jordan) value  - EBS purchase of $5.1 million for servers and 
hardware in 2000
  EBS (added)    - EBS purchase value would add an additional $1.0 million 
for servers and hardware in 2000
  EBS (added)   - EBS purchase of $4.9 million for servers and hardware in 
1999
  EBS (added)   - EBS purchase of $3.1 million in Compaq professional 
services (costs for Server deployment)

 From these viewpoints - if one was to set a Compaq purchase amount then the 
following might occur
  EBS total is $14.1 million spend for 1999/2000  at 8% would equal a Compaq 
purchase amount of $1.128 million (w/out the 2 fixed quarters)
  Compaq total is $5.1 million spend  at 8% would equal a Compaq purchase 
amount of $408,000
  EBS Viewpoint - Per the signed EBS Server Purchase Agreement - the amount 
is $4,134,229. (I did not concede) 

 e) 2000 income.   Per the signed EBS Server Purchase Agreement - Compaq had 
to pay for the Compaq Purchase amount before or by Dec 31, 2000 but could 
defer identifying the services to be used against the amount until Dec 31, 
2002.  If Compaq had not used the services by Dec 31, 2002 then they lost the 
right to spend against the amount.  To gain 2000 income recognition, EBS 
worked with Keith M and Rob Senders to invoice for $832,000 to cover EBS 
consulting services provided to Compaq.   Again, under Keith M's stewardship 
- they verbally agreed to pay. 

Now with the above information - my offered next steps :
 a) Until everything is done - maintain the "stick" of the EBS invoice ($4.1 
million).  This is being done.
 b) Termination fee - the contract does not state a termination fee.   It 
does state a value of $2.5 million max for liquidated damages.  Prior 
conversations have discussed Compaq paying a $2.5 million termination fee 
(again with Keith M).   This could be recognized as yr 2000 income. 
 c) Consulting Fee - The recognition of the $832,000 would be a 20% return on 
services of $4.1 million.   This is a good return for a commodity 
transaction.  So.... do we accept a lower amount to maintain a healthier 
relationship.   

 So...... please let me know your thougths.   We have countered with the $2.5 
million with the understanding that the lower end would be $832,000.  

Please let me know your thoughts

Kim Godfrey
Director, Enterprise Services
Enron Broadband Services
phone : 713 345 8813
cell :      713 501 8105
fax:        713 853 7354

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu.au>
To: David Thompson <dthompson@research.org>
Subject: Exciting collaboration opportunity

Hi David,

It was great meeting you at the climate change conference a few months ago. I really enjoyed our conversation about the impacts of sea level rise on coastal regions and the potential for combining our expertise in history and climate science.

I've been thinking about our discussion and had an idea for a research project that I think you might be interested in. I'm proposing we collaborate on a study examining the impacts of sea level rise on significant cultural heritage sites along the Australian coastline. I believe that by combining our knowledge and skills, we could produce a unique and impactful study that contributes to the preservation of these important sites.

I'd love to discuss this further with you and hear your thoughts on the idea. Please let me know if you're interested in exploring this collaboration opportunity.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@nyuhistorians.org>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@ucla.edu>
Subject: RE: Upcoming Conference Panel

Michael,

That sounds like a great plan. I'll start working on the social factors and how they contributed to the growing divisions between the North and the South. I think it's crucial to highlight the role of abolitionist movements and the underground railroad in shaping public opinion and creating tensions between the two regions.

I'll also look into the cultural differences between the North and the South, such as the importance of honor and family in Southern society, and how these values influenced the region's response to Northern criticism of slavery.

Please let me know if you need any assistance with the economic aspects of the presentation. I have some resources that might be helpful for your research.

I'll send you a draft of my portion by the end of next week. We can then review each other's work and make any necessary revisions before submitting the final version to the conference organizers.

Thanks for your collaboration on this project. I'm confident that our combined efforts will result in a compelling and informative presentation.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@mail.com>
To: Emily Wong <emily.wong@mail.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration opportunity for our blog and your classroom

Emily,

What a fantastic idea! I'm thrilled that you reached out, and I would absolutely love to collaborate with you on this project. I think it's a wonderful way to make history and geography more relatable and exciting for my students.

I particularly like your idea of exploring the history of Thanksgiving dishes and the geography of chocolate production. Those are both topics that I know my students would be fascinated by, and I think hands-on experiments would be a great way to engage them in the learning process.

I would be happy to share some of my lesson plans with you and work together to develop content that aligns with my curriculum. I'm also open to the idea of co-authoring some blog posts, if you think that would be helpful.

Let me know when you're available to chat further about this. I'm excited to get started!

Best,
Michael

Hi Arielle,

That sounds like a great plan. I think it's best if we divide and conquer - you take the lead on drafting the letter, and I can work on researching the relevant regulatory bodies and potential media outlets for the op-ed.

Once you have a draft, we can set up a call to discuss and refine it together. I'm available next week on Tuesday or Thursday afternoon if that works for you.

Let me know if you need any additional information or resources for the draft.

Best,
Zain

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Lena Patel <lena.patel@bioinfo.org>
To: Alex Novak <alex.novak@stargazer.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting collaboration opportunity

Alex,

I'm thrilled by your proposal! The idea of combining our expertise to create an educational resource on the intersection of astronomy and biology is fascinating. I believe this project has great potential to engage and inspire learners of all ages.

I agree that applying for a grant is an excellent idea. We could use the funds to cover research, materials, and dissemination of our work. I'd be happy to take the lead on drafting the grant proposal, focusing on the biology aspects and how our project aligns with current funding priorities.

Let's set up a call to discuss our next steps and divide tasks based on our respective expertise. I'm available next week on Tuesday and Thursday afternoons. Please let me know which day works best for you.

I'm looking forward to working together on this exciting project!

Best regards,
Lena
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@university.edu>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@weforum.org>
Subject: Collaborating on physics and environmental science content

Hey Alex,

It was great meeting you at the science communication workshop last week! I really enjoyed our conversation about making complex topics more accessible to the general public. I think our expertise in physics and environmental journalism could be a great combination for creating engaging content.

I'm currently working on a series of educational videos about the physics behind climate change, and I think your insights on deforestation and sustainable development would be a valuable addition. Would you be interested in collaborating on this project? We could create a series of articles and videos that explore the intersection of physics and environmental science, and submit them to various online platforms and educational institutions.

Let me know what you think!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Chen <michael.chen@dentalhealth.com>
To: Jessica Langford <jessica.langford@ecu.edu>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Jessica,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm so glad you enjoyed my presentation. Your talk on environmental factors affecting health was eye-opening, and I've been thinking about the potential connections between our fields as well.

I have considered the environmental impact of dental products, but I haven't had the opportunity to delve into it deeply. I would be very interested in collaborating with you on a project exploring this topic. It's an area that deserves more attention, and I believe our combined expertise could lead to some valuable insights.

I'm happy to set up a call to discuss our ideas further and see how we can move forward with this. Please let me know your availability, and we can schedule something.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Parker <jordan.parker@waterai.co.uk>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@spacesustainability.org>
Subject: RE: Project update and next steps

Hi Alex,

I completely agree with the summary and next steps you've outlined. I'm happy to take on the research task and will start looking into existing treaties and frameworks.

I'll also review the outline you send and start drafting content for my assigned sections. Let's touch base in a couple of weeks to discuss our progress and make any necessary revisions to the plan.

Thanks for taking the lead on this, Alex. I'm confident that our collaboration will result in a strong and impactful proposal.

Best,
Jordan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <arivera@unm.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <ethompson@multcohealth.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from SEHP conference

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I've also been thinking a lot about our conversation at the conference, and I'm excited to explore potential collaborations between our fields.

I completely agree that there is a lot of potential for archaeological research to inform the design and siting of urban green spaces. In fact, I'm currently working on a project that uses GIS data to map the location of archaeological sites in relation to urban green spaces in Albuquerque. I think this approach could be valuable for your work in Portland as well.

I'd be happy to schedule a call to discuss this further. How about next Friday at 11am MST/10am PST? Let me know if that works for you.

Best,
Alex
label: research

X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Kirk,

I would modify this document slightly.  The first section is titled "Introduction to Risk Management" and the second section is "Hedging Instruments/Risk Management Products".  However, many of the bullet points in the first section are describing hedging instruments that belong in second section.  I would limit the introduction to types of risk, identifying risk, and examples when risks are not hedged.  Then the second section should contain all the details of hedging tools.  Definitions of derivatives and how they can be used to manage the risk in the first section would be in this section.  The third section would include the roles and accounting basics.  You might want to include the commodity 101 info here, at least gas and power.

Phillip

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	McDaniel, Kirk  
Sent:	Tuesday, September 25, 2001 4:10 PM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.; Arnold, John; O'rourke, Tim; Frolov, Yevgeny
Subject:	Final Internal Review for Sign Off: Topics and Related Objectives

Gentlemen
Please take  a look at the attached document. Provide me with your final input, if any, in so that I can give Accenture Sign off acceptance. This document includes input Accenture received or derived from yesterday's Design Scope meeting.

I request everyone's input by COB, Thursday 9/27 in so that if changes are needed we can still get final sign off by COB Friday 9/28 or Monday 10/1. Thanks

Cheers
Kirk

body:
<email>
From: Emily Langton <emily.langton@oldenglishdict.com>
To: Robert Sinclair <robert.sinclair@linguisticsresearch.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting manuscript discovery!

Robert,

I'm so glad you're as excited about this as I am. I've attached scans of some of the most fascinating texts from the manuscript. Take a look at the word "æðeling" in Text 3 - it seems to have a different meaning than what we've previously understood.

I agree that we should apply for a grant. I have a few contacts at the Historical Linguistics Research Foundation who might be interested in funding our project. I'll reach out to them and draft a proposal.

Keep me posted on your thoughts and analyses of the texts. I can't wait to dive deeper into this research with you.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@prosthodontics.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@dentaltech.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on a challenging prosthodontics case

Dear Emily,

I've reviewed the case information you sent over, and I must say, it's quite a complex one. However, I'm confident that with some creative problem-solving and a few adjustments to your technique, we can develop a treatment plan that will work well for your patient.

During our call on Wednesday, I'd like to discuss the specific issues you've encountered and brainstorm some potential solutions. I've also been working on a research project related to new impression materials that might be applicable to this case, and I'd be happy to share some of my findings with you.

If you're interested, I could also send you some additional resources and case studies that might provide some valuable insights. Let me know if you'd like me to put together a few materials for you to review.

I'm looking forward to our call and working together to find the best solution for your patient. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns before then.

Best regards,
Dr. Michael Thompson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@university.edu>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@university.edu>
Subject: Seeking advice on teaching introductory econometrics

Hi Emily,

I hope you're doing well. I'm reaching out to you because I've been having some difficulty with my introductory econometrics course. I recently received feedback from students that they're finding the material too difficult to understand, and I'm looking for ways to simplify the concepts without sacrificing the necessary technical details.

I know you have a reputation for being an excellent educator, and I was wondering if you had any advice on how I could improve my teaching methods. I've heard about a new teaching methodology that focuses on using real-world examples and case studies to teach econometrics, and I'm considering implementing it in my course. I would love to get your thoughts on this approach and whether you think it would be helpful for my students.

I know we have a meeting scheduled next week to discuss this further, but I wanted to get your initial thoughts before we meet. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or resources that you think might be helpful.

Thank you for your time and assistance.

Best regards,
John
label: research

Please let me know your availability.

Best regards,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: David Thompson <david.thompson@research.org.au>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@university.edu.au>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on British colonialism in Australia research

Dear Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I remember our meeting at the conference fondly. Your research project sounds fascinating, and I would be more than happy to discuss it with you further. In fact, I am currently organizing a symposium on the legacy of the British Empire in Australia, and I believe your work would make an excellent contribution to the event.

The symposium will take place in Sydney from September 15-17, and I would like to invite you to present your research findings. It would be an excellent opportunity to share your work with other scholars in the field and engage in fruitful discussions.

If you're interested in participating, please let me know, and I will send you more details about the event, including the submission guidelines and deadlines. I can also arrange accommodations for you during your stay in Sydney.

I look forward to hearing back from you and potentially collaborating on this exciting project.

Best wishes,
David Thompson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Novak <olivia.novak@astrophysics.com>
To: Ethan Roberts <ethan.roberts@worldhistory.edu>
Subject: Exciting opportunity and request for advice

Hey Ethan,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to reach out and thank you again for mentioning the international conference on the history of science. I'm thrilled about the prospect of presenting our collaborative research to such a distinguished audience.

However, I must admit that I'm feeling a bit daunted by the idea of preparing for a presentation of this caliber. As you know, my primary focus has been on research rather than public speaking, and I'm not entirely sure how to effectively convey our complex ideas to a broad audience.

I was wondering if you had any advice or tips for crafting a compelling presentation that would engage both experts in our fields and those with a more general interest in the history of science. I would be immensely grateful for any insights you could share, given your extensive experience in teaching and public speaking.

Please let me know if you have any thoughts or suggestions. I'm eager to make the most of this incredible opportunity and to do justice to the work we've done together.

Best regards,
Olivia
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Holloway <eholloway@university.edu>
To: Dr. James Tremblay <jtremblay@university.edu>
Subject: Conference preparations and travel arrangements

Dear James,

I hope this email finds you well. As the conference date approaches, I wanted to touch base with you regarding our presentation and travel plans. Have you had a chance to review the latest draft of our paper? I made a few revisions based on our last discussion and would love to hear your thoughts.

Also, have you booked your flights and accommodations yet? I was thinking we could coordinate our travel schedules to ensure we arrive in time for the pre-conference events. It would be great to catch up with our colleagues and attend some of the workshops before our presentation.

Let me know if you have any questions or concerns. I'm looking forward to showcasing our work and the potential implications for our understanding of early human migrations and interspecies interactions.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@fosterschools.org>
To: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@jeffersonacademy.org>
Subject: Interdisciplinary Curriculum Project

Hi Michael,

I hope this email finds you well. It was great to meet you at the history teachers' conference last month and learn about your work on American geography and history. I think our curricula could complement each other nicely.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on an interdisciplinary project that connects World War II to American history and geography. I believe this approach could help our students better understand the global context of the war and its impact on the United States.

Please let me know if you're open to discussing this further. I'd be happy to share some of my initial ideas and hear your thoughts.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Rally is not different for products. 92% of heating oil is made ondemand  
(storage is not as important as in nat gas) Heat will get ugly this October 
and then give it up (unless we have 7 blizzzards in the Northeast very 
early). 
SOme things to consider :
1- in the next 3-4 weeks we will finish the very heavy maintenance season and 
be in full blown gasoline season.
- yields will be preferentially shifted for HU
3- nobody will pay any attention to HO
2-HO will have incremental demand due to utlity switching and will quietly 
build slower than last year 
4- therefore by September everyone will freak out
5- After the OCtober contract expires (HO) , everyone will realize (similar 
to NG) that the world will not end.

Where does this get us:
1- Sell q3 HU crack and by Q4HO crack (By the time q3 prices out--the wind 
will have been taken out of HU sails - plus you can do it month 
avg--therefore less noise)
2-Benefit from heat's recent excitement -- sell HO calls (June -Aug), buy ng 
puts nov-jan

Ng-Disagree:
I think prices stay high through June. The big drop off come some where in 
July 15 to Aug 15 and downhill from there. (Looks like 1998)

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@schoolboard.edu>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Conference plans and presentation ideas

Hi Alex,

Your email got me really excited about our upcoming meeting and potential presentation! I love all three of your ideas, but I think the second one, "Engaging Students through Unconventional Teaching Methods," might be the most accessible and engaging for our audience. We could each share a few examples from our own classrooms and then discuss the broader implications for interdisciplinary collaboration.

As for meeting up, I've reached out to a couple of my colleagues who I think would be really interested in our work. They're both passionate about innovative teaching methods and have experience with cross-curricular projects. Would you be available for dinner on the Friday evening of the conference? We could have a more casual conversation and brainstorm some ideas for moving forward.

I'm looking forward to seeing you soon!
Jordan

Johnnie,

Thank you for meeting with me on Friday.  I left feeling very optimistic 
about the panel system.  I would like to find a way to incorporate the panels 
into the home design I showed you.  In order to make it feasible within my 
budget I am sure it will take several iterations.  The prospect of purchasing 
the panels and having your  framers install them may have to be considered.  
However, my first choice would be for you to be the general contractor.

I realize you receive a number of calls just seeking information about this 
product with very little probability of a sale.  I just want to assure you 
that I am going to build this house in the fall and I would seriously 
consider using the panel system if it truly was only a slight increase in 
cost over stick built.

Please email your cost estimates when complete.

Thank you,

Phillip Allen

cc:  
Subject: Site Location Advisory Service




I am pleased to inform you that one of Canada's leading business service
providers, Grant Thornton LLP, is now offering US firms a full Site Location
Advisory Service.

With over forty offices across Canada, Grant Thornton LLP knows Canada.  We
are finding that more and more US corporations are looking north as they are
faced with fewer satisfactory location alternatives in which to expand.
Canada, with its relatively large and well trained work force, not to
mention lower operating costs, is increasingly being considered by companies
such as yours.

Grant Thornton LLP would be pleased to discuss this service with you.  It is
a full service that includes, on your behalf, real estate sourcing, labor
force analysis and verification, tax analysis and comparison, and incentive
negotiations.

Should you be considering expanding your operations and interested in
discussing our service, please give us a call.  More and more United States
firms, from call centers to manufacturers are locating in Canada to serve
both their US and Canadian customers.

Based in Moncton, New Brunswick Canada, I can be reached at:

 Telephone     (506) 857-0100
 Cell Phone    (506) 381-1450
 E-Mail           mmacbride@grantthornton.ca


Michael S. MacBride, CMA
Senior Consultant

Grant Thornton LLP
Chartered Accountants
PO Box 1005
633 Main Street Suite 500
Moncton New Brunswick Canada  E1C 8P2


This e-mail is intended solely for the person or entity to which it is
addressed and may contain confidential and/or privileged information.  Any
review, dissemination, copying, printing or other use of this e-mail by
persons or entities other than the addressee is prohibited.  If you have
received this e-mail in error, please contact the sender immediately and
delete the material from any computer.

body:
<email>
From: Alex Ramirez <alex.ramirez@weatherwhiz.com>
To: Emily Chen <emily.chen@chemteacher.com>
Subject: RE: Collaborative project idea

Hi Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm thrilled that you're interested in collaborating on a project. I think your idea of exploring the connections between chemistry and weather is fascinating and has the potential to engage a wide audience.

I particularly like the idea of creating a series of blog posts and videos that break down complex concepts in both our fields. We could even consider creating a joint webinar or workshop for students and educators to showcase our work and engage with the audience through interactive activities and Q&A sessions.

I'm happy to discuss the logistics of the project further. Perhaps we can set up a call next week to brainstorm content ideas and establish a timeline for the project.

I'm excited to work together and create something impactful for science education!

Best regards,
Alex Ramirez

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@richmond.edu>
To: Daniel Evans <daniel.evans@boston.edu>
Subject: New Document Discovery

Hi Daniel,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some exciting news - I recently stumbled upon a previously unknown letter written by a Southern plantation owner in 1858. The letter discusses the economic impact of the proposed tariffs on the South and the growing tensions between the North and the South.

I think this document could be a game-changer for our research. It provides a unique perspective on the economic factors leading up to the Civil War. I'm attaching a scanned copy of the letter for you to review.

What do you think about incorporating this new information into our presentation for the Chicago conference? We might need to adjust our conclusions slightly, but I believe it will make our argument even stronger.

Let me know your thoughts.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Ethan Miller <emiller@earthscienceeducation.com>
To: Rivka Goldstein <rgoldstein@torahacademy.org>
Subject: Re: Interdisciplinary Lesson Plan

Hi Rivka,

I took a look at the lesson plan and I think it's great! You've done a fantastic job of weaving together the scientific and historical concepts. I have a few minor suggestions, but overall I think it's ready to go.

I was thinking we could schedule a video call to go over the lesson plan one more time and make sure we're both on the same page before we implement it in our classrooms.

Let me know when you're available to chat!

Ethan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@eslrocks.com>
To: Jordan Rivera <jrivera@langacq.com>
Subject: RE: Need your expertise!

Hi Jordan,

Thank you so much for all the helpful information! The word wall idea sounds fantastic. I can already envision how I could implement that in my classroom. I will definitely check out that ILA resource too.

Your point about giving students multiple ways to practice using the vocabulary really resonates with me. I'm always looking for ways to make language learning more interactive and meaningful.

I would love to chat more! Tuesday afternoon works great for me. How about 2 pm EST? Let me know if that time doesn't work for you.

I'm also curious to hear more about your thoughts on my potentially transitioning to a role more focused on language acquisition and content area literacy. I've been giving it a lot of thought and would value your perspective.

Looking forward to our call!

Best,
Emily
label: research

Message-ID: <2039389.1075857653810.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 20 Mar 2001 12:22:00 -0800 (PST)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: andrew.fairley@enron.com
Subject: Re: Trip to Houston
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Andrew Fairley
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Jun2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Andy:
Good to hear.  There continue to be a proliferation of new systems coming 
online in the US; two more start in the next two months.  We are pretty close 
to finalizing a plan to open our system to everyone in terms of accepting 
limit orders and posting best bid/offer regardless of whose it is.  In this 
framework, Enron would sleeve credit for free should two third parties be 
matched on our system.  However, we would hold the book, getting to see what 
everyone was doing at all times.  The idea is that if we can move the 
industry's order flow from 30-40% EOL to 60% EOL, we get a huge information 
advantage in addition to a couple trading advantages, namely we have first 
priority on all numbers even if we are joining a limit bid posted by a 
counterparty before us and second, we posess a proprietary stack manager that 
will allow us to transact on attractive limit orders faster than our 
competitors.  Still working on technical issues.  The decision to open EOL 
markets would be done on a product by product basis.  Give me a call if you 
want to discuss.




Andrew Fairley
03/13/2001 11:14 AM
To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Re: Trip to Houston  


John

Redmond & I have now had a few weeks to implement some of your advice with 
regard to EOL for UK gas.
We have managed to double our average daily volumes, and are capturing a 
considerably greater share of the market. (We estimate 50% now).
Spectron are getting about 20-30% of the number of trades we do. There are 
still some counterparties who insist on paying through our numbers and paying 
brokerage so they do not show us what we are doing!  As far as we are 
concerned we only use SpectronLive on UK gas when we are  executing the 
strategy you mentioned below. 

Once again, thanks for your help
All the best,

Andy





John Arnold
21/02/2001 04:26
To: Andrew Fairley/LON/ECT@ECT
cc:  

Subject: Re: Trip to Houston  

Andy:
Enjoyed meeting with you.  

One more thing I did not address.  My ultimate goal is to move all volume to 
EOL.  However, in addition to the NYMEX, we have about 6 other viable 
electronic trading systems.  We make it a point to never support these if 
possible.  We will only trade if the other system's offer is at or greater 
than our bid.  For instance, if we are 6/8 but have a strong inclination to 
buy and another system is at 7, I will simultaneously lift their 7's and move 
my market to 7/9.  The lesson the counterparty gets is he will only get the 
trade if I'm bidding 7 and he will only get executed when it is a bad trade 
to him.  People have learned fairly quickly not to leave numbers on the other 
systems because they will just get picked off.  If they don't post numbers on 
the other systems, the systems get no liquidity and die.

I mention this because I have heard that Enron is a fairly large trader on 
Spectron's system.  I don't know whether it is in regards to gas, power, or 
metals.  Just something to think about and maybe talk about with the other 
traders.
John



Andrew Fairley
02/20/2001 11:15 AM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scott 
Neal/HOU/ECT@ECT, Thomas A Martin/HOU/ECT@ECT, Barry Tycholiz/NA/Enron@ENRON, 
Keith Holst/HOU/ECT@ect
cc: David Gallagher/LON/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Trip to Houston


Thank you so much for your time last week.

David and I found the time especially valuable. We have spotted several 
issues helpful for our own market.
This should certainly help in the growth of our markets here in Europe. We 
trust it won't be too long before we see similarly impressive results from 
our side of the pond.

Best regards 


Andy

AM ---------------------------


Tanya Tamarchenko
06/07/2000 08:33 AM
To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Grant Masson/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Re: using new FF vols  

Hi, John,
following up the discussion with you on Friday we talked with Risk Control 
people who are not excited to use that FF vol curve
you sent to me. Also in order to use your curves we would have to have them 
for all the locations.
The suggested alternative solution was to calculate the Forward Forward vol 
curves from historical data.
I implemented this solution based on 18 last business days forward price 
curves for NG and 
all basis locations. I used exponential weights with 0.97 decay factor.
I enclose these curves in the spreadsheet below. And here are the VAR numbers 
based on these curves:

     5/30/00  5/31/00
AGG-STORAGE (production) 3,027,000  4,516,000
AGG-STORAGE (test, 0.97)  2,858,543  3,011,761
AGG-GAS        (production) 36,627,200  40,725,685
AGG-GAS       (test, 0.97)  29,439,969  31,207,225

You see that the numbers are stable, lower than the official numbers. 
I suggest that we use 0.94 decay factor as recommended by Risk Metrics which 
would give more weight to recent data.
We need to test this approach for a period of time and also to collect 
backtesting data for an educated choice of decay factor.

Tanya.




John Arnold
06/07/2000 07:40 AM
To: Tanya Tamarchenko/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: 

Tanya:
On Friday I emailed a new vol curve to use for VAR testing.  I was under the 
impression that you could apply this vol curve to the price book and storage 
book and have a new experimental VAR number by Monday. I have not received 
any response.  Please reply with status of this project.
John
