From: Olivia Nguyen <olivia.nguyen@student.university.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Reynolds <emily.reynolds@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Help with understanding waves and sound

Dr. Reynolds,

Thank you so much for the resources! I watched the Khan Academy videos and they were really helpful. I'd definitely appreciate if you could send over those practice problems with solutions.

One thing I'm still a bit confused about is the difference between longitudinal and transverse waves. I know that longitudinal waves move in the same direction as the wave, while transverse waves move perpendicular to the direction of the wave. But I'm not sure how this applies to sound waves. Are sound waves longitudinal or transverse?

Thank you again for all your help,
Olivia

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <anovak@university.edu>
To: Jordan Lee <jlee@observatory.org>
Subject: Exciting news about the James Webb Space Telescope!

Dear Jordan,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been a while since we last spoke, but I wanted to share some exciting news with you regarding the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST).

As you know, our team has been working tirelessly to analyze the data collected by the JWST, and we've made a groundbreaking discovery that I believe will have significant implications for our understanding of the early universe and galaxy formation.

I don't want to reveal too much in this email, but suffice it to say that the data has provided us with unprecedented insights into the properties and evolution of galaxies in the early universe. We've submitted a paper detailing our findings, and I'd be happy to share a preprint with you once it's available.

I was hoping we could schedule a video call to discuss this discovery in more detail and explore the potential for collaboration on a follow-up study. I'd love to hear your thoughts on the implications of our findings and how we might build upon them in future research.

Please let me know your availability for a call in the coming weeks. I'm excited to catch up and dive deeper into this fascinating topic with you.

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

> 2001 Natural Gas Production and Price Outlook Conference Call
>
>

> Call.doc>>
> Energy Research Group
> Analyst Access Conference Call
>
> 2001 Natural Gas  Production and Price Outlook
> Hosted by:
> Bob Morris and Michael Schmitz
>  Oil and Gas Exploration & Production Analysts
>
>  Date & Time:
> FRIDAY (February 23rd)
> 11:00 a.m. EST
>
> Dial-in #:
>  US:   800-229-0281 International:  706-645-9237
>
> Replay #: (Reservation: x 819361)
>  US:   800-642-1687 International: 706-645-9291
>
> Accessing Presentation:
> * Go to https://intercallssl.contigo.com
> * Click on Conference Participant
> * Enter Event Number:  x716835
> * Enter the participant's Name, Company Name & E-mail address
> * Click Continue to view the first slide of the presentation
>
> Key Points:
> 1. Natural gas storage levels appear to be on track to exit March at
> roughly 700-800 Bcf, compared with just over 1,000 Bcf last year at the
> end of the traditional withdrawal season.
> 2. Meanwhile, domestic natural gas production should rise 3.0-5.0% this
> year, largely dependent upon the extent of the drop in rig efficiency, or
> production added per rig.
> 3. Nonetheless, under most scenarios, incorporating numerous other
> variables such as the pace of economic expansion, fuel switching and
> industrial plant closures, it appears that storage levels at the beginning
> of winter will be near or below last year's 2,800 Bcf level.
> 4. Thus, it appears likely that the "heat" will remain on natural gas
> prices throughout 2001.
> 5. Consequently, we believe that many E&P shares will post solid gains
> again this year, spurred largely by mounting confidence in the
> sustainability of strong natural gas prices.
>
>

 - 2001 Natural Gas Conference Call.doc

Subject: RE: Exhibition progress update

Dear Akiko,

I completely agree with your suggestion to create a series of short videos for promotional purposes. Interviews with experts and behind-the-scenes footage will undoubtedly generate interest and anticipation for the exhibition. I will reach out to our marketing team to discuss the production of these videos.

I have also been thinking about the lectures and workshops we want to organize in conjunction with the exhibition. I suggest we invite Dr. Tanaka from the University of Tokyo and Dr. Lee from the National Museum of China as guest speakers. Their expertise in Meiji-era art and Chinese influences would be invaluable to our audience.

Please review the attached document outlining the proposed lecture and workshop schedule. Let me know if you have any suggestions or changes.

Thank you for your continued collaboration and dedication to this project.

Best regards,
Haruki

"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls


Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austin
that we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this project
should produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.
This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong as
Austin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range for
this market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that we
have uncovered to date in the Austin market.
The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  As
it is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austin
for preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be complete
in less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severe
water treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lot
improvement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in North
Austin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and street
widening.  Even though this property is not likely to require street
widening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pond
requirement, I used this data to be cautious.
 The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is not
expected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quite
successful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as the
adjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.
As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoods
is uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but may
only put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are far
preferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyer
preferences.
The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 and
an extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved site
plan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close into
an A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.
This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in the
profits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discuss
having you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entity
with your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a
1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is a
rental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would then
be the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with an
exchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in San
Antonio if you do not know anyone.
I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,
by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.
Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want to
schedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon as
your schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at any
time.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either
512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is
512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with you
on this project that is sure to be a major winner.
I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusual
events these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpg
downdrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.
One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled to
start the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enough
to knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it took
another week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to take
my wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebra
in her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden this
past week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realize
the enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks as
if she will be ok in the long run.
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC


 - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Emily Jennings <emily.jennings@historybuffs.com>
To: David Rosenberg <david.rosenberg@hrconsulting.com>
Subject: Rare stamp discovery

Hi David,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some exciting news with you regarding our project. I recently came across a rare stamp that is linked to a significant event in our city's history. It's called the "Centennial Exposition Stamp" and was issued in 1876 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the city's founding.

I think this stamp could be a great addition to our digital archive and possibly even a focal point for our presentation at the local history club meeting. I'm excited to hear your thoughts on this and how we can incorporate it into our project.

Also, I've been doing some research on the psychological impact of historical events on communities and would love to share my findings with you. It might provide some interesting insights for our project.

Let me know when you're free to meet up and discuss this further. I'm thinking we could meet at our usual spot, The Brew House, this Saturday afternoon if that works for you.

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Robert Sinclair <robert.sinclair@linguisticsresearch.org>
To: Emily Langton <emily.langton@oldenglishdict.com>
Subject: RE: Exciting manuscript discovery!

Emily,

I've been poring over the texts you sent, and I think we may need to reconsider our understanding of the Proto-Germanic verb system. The conjugations in Text 5 don't align with what we thought we knew.

However, I have a theory that could explain the discrepancies. If we consider the possibility of a previously unknown Proto-Germanic dialect influencing the development of Old English, it could account for these variations.

What do you think? I'd love to hear your perspective on this.

Also, I've made some progress on the grant proposal. With your contacts at the HRLF, I think our chances of securing funding are good.

Best,
Robert
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@rivertowncc.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@rivertowncc.edu>
Subject: RE: Advice on teaching hydrogen unit

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad you're looking to incorporate more real-world applications into your general chemistry curriculum. Hydrogen is a fascinating element with many important applications, and I'd be happy to help you design an engaging unit for your students.

One activity that I've found effective is a hands-on demonstration of hydrogen production using electrolysis. Students can use a simple setup with water, electrodes, and a power source to generate hydrogen gas, which they can then collect and observe. This helps them understand the process of electrolysis and the properties of hydrogen gas.

Another important aspect to cover is the role of hydrogen in renewable energy technologies, such as fuel cells. You could introduce the concept of hydrogen fuel cells and discuss their potential as clean energy sources. There are many online resources and videos that showcase how fuel cells work and their applications in various industries.

Lastly, I recommend incorporating some historical context by discussing the discovery of hydrogen and its significance in the development of chemistry. This can help students appreciate the importance of the element and its impact on scientific progress.

I'd be happy to lend you some resources and demonstration materials if you'd like. Let me know if you want to meet up and discuss this further. I'm free next Tuesday after lunch if that works for you.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: David Nguyen <david.nguyen@schoolmathguru.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@mathedpros.com>
Subject: RE: Research on manipulatives in algebra instruction

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad you reached out about this topic, as I've been experimenting with using manipulatives in my classroom quite a bit lately. In fact, I've recently started using 3D printing to create custom manipulatives tailored to specific algebra concepts.

I've found that these custom manipulatives have been particularly effective in helping students visualize and understand abstract algebraic concepts. For example, I created a set of 3D printed tiles representing different polynomial terms, which students can manipulate to learn about combining like terms and understanding the structure of expressions.

My students have responded very positively to using these manipulatives, and I've noticed a significant improvement in their understanding of algebraic concepts. I'd be happy to share more details about my experiences and even send you some pictures of the manipulatives I've created.

I'm curious to learn more about your research project and the specific aspects of manipulative use you're investigating. Perhaps we could collaborate on this further, and even consider submitting a joint proposal for a presentation at the next conference.

Let me know if you'd like to discuss this further or if there's any other way I can support your research.

Best regards,
David

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@harborhigh.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@harboruniversity.edu>
Subject: Questions about the Pilgrim Fathers and the Mayflower voyage

Dear Dr. Thompson,

I hope this email finds you well. I'm Emily, a student in your History of the Pilgrim Fathers and the Mayflower Voyage class. I've been really enjoying the course material, but I have some questions and concerns about the perspective being presented.

As someone interested in social policy and economic inequality, I'm curious about how the Pilgrim Fathers' journey and the establishment of the Plymouth colony may have impacted the indigenous populations and contributed to systems of inequality that persist today. I would love to discuss this further and learn more about your perspective on the topic.

If you have any recommended readings that present a different viewpoint, I would greatly appreciate it. I'm eager to engage with the material more deeply and understand the historical context from various angles.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson

Jennifer,

I hope you are doing well in the U.K., as my clock here says it is probably 
about 4:52pm in London...Here is an update on BMC:

Based on the following, I would say this:

1)  BMC has worked to clear up operational problems experienced by Net Works, 
and in one situation, appears to have done so successfully.
2)  Net Works has not acknowledged that the results of #1 were desired or 
acceptable, and instead offered another pushback (Win2K certif'ctn), therefore
3)  BMC doesn't appear to have been given further opportunity to identify 
what issues, if any, are still open at Net Works.
4)  I don't see evidence (either in these notes OR having come out from any 
of the many telephone conversations I've been in) that Net Works has provided 
any responses since 11/21 or so...Peter Goebel and I met w/Net Works & EBS on 
11/17, and I have had no calls or e-mails responding to my requests for 
information relative to "what are your top 3 problems in this BMC situation, 
Net Works?" from Net Works.
5)  So, I feel confident that there are more issues (left off the table by 
Net Works) than will be discussed, because
6)  Net Works doesn't want any of BMC's solutions.  Period.

7)  The Result:  EBS is on their own on their deal with BMC, as far as Net 
Works' folks are concerned.

In the "I don't want any surprises" mode, I thought I'd give George a 
heads-up re:  possible fallout around the BMC thing.  I told George in this 
morning's staff meeting what Jim Crowder said to the EBS origination team ("I 
don't see a problem here..."), and what you and I suggested EBS do - buy and 
implement $1M of BMC's stuff, pay $2M for "credit", which any ENE business 
unit could access, etc.  I also informed him that the EBS and BMC folks were 
likely to encourage Crowder to "lean on" Philippe (which I had recommended 
against).  George said he would take it up w/Jennie Rub.  

If you have any questions, please let me know.
Jeff

>    > Recap:

>    > There were 2 outstanding issues.
>    > 1) New Day process running 2-5 hrs.

>    lost
>    > connection with the NIS server for a greater period of time than what
>    the
>    > default settings were set.  The agent is set to retry every 120
>    seconds up
>    > to 12 times.  After this period, manual activation is required.  I
>    signed
>    > on as CTMAGENT user and ran ag_menu.  Ran option 2 which showed the
>    NIS as
>    > down.  I then signed on as the Control-M user and ran ctm_menu.

>    > I also ran a Trouble Shooting Report which produced a file
>    > (/var/home/ctlm00/report.1116001128)  from this file we could tell
>    when
>    > the Log filed filled up and when the Agent stopped.
>    >
>    > I set up 500 jobs to run daily on BMC with multiple dependencies.
> All
>    ran
>    > ok.
>    >
>    > I set up aprox. another 150 cyclic jobs with dependencies to run on
>    > OCSDEV-1.  They failed due to not using the correct Owner.  Rusty
>    knows
>    > what the correct owner should be.  I believed I used CTLM00.
>    >
>    > New Day process ran for approx. 12 mins.
>    >
>    > Right before leaving Rusty ran a clean_db script, which resulted in
>    > cleaning out the entire database.  Fortunately by design, we were
> able
>    to
>    > demonstrate the recoverability by uploading the tables from ECS to
> the
>    > Control-M Server.  In less than 5 minutes all was ok.
>    >
>    > When I left there were approx. 900 jobs running.  Of those approx.
> 400
>    > jobs were running cyclic, every 2 minutes.  Which meant on a daily
>    basis
>    > approx. 14,500 jobs ran per day.
>    >
>    > Larry, I know you asked for some type of hardware recommendations.
>    These
>    > is something that's very subjective.  As with almost any software the
>    more
>    > memory and faster CPU the better.  To do this correctly, we should
>    have
>    > our Professional Services come in and do some type of assessment of
>    your
>    > environment and the direction your heading.  How many jobs per day,
>    today,
>    > near future, etc....  How many Users of ECS?  How many Servers?
>    >
>    > In your test environment you should be able to run 2000 jobs without
> a
>    > major problem.  Your ECS NT box is on the small size, at least in the
>    > memory area.  So your responses might not be as fast as desired.
>    Please
>    > remember the out of the box default settings are not tuned to run a
>    large
>    > number of jobs.  Therefore database tuning is always recommended.
>    These
>    > tuning recommendations are provided by Professional Services.
>    >
>    > By tomorrow I will send you the daily utilities.
>    >
>    > Thanks,
>    >
>    > Ronnie Sapp
>    > bmcsoftware
>    > INCONTROL Business Unit
>    > Software Consultant Manager
>    > West Region
>    > 972-934-5065
>    > ronnie_sapp@bmc.com

Please respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>

To:   <jarnold@enron.com>
cc:
Subject:  try this one...


 Please read the following problem very carefully, and write in a number at
the end.  You should be ready to defend your answer.  Only a number is
allowed, not an algebraic equation.

Acquiring a Company

     In the following exercise you will represent Company A (the acquirer),
which is currently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means of
a tender offer.  You plan to tender in cash for 100% of Company T's shares
but are unsure how high a price to offer.  The main complication is this:
the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oil
exploration project it is currently undertaking.  Indeed, the very
viability
of Company T depends on the exploration outcome.  If the project fails, the
company under current management will be worth nothing--$0/share.  But if
the project succeeds, the value of the company under current management
could be as high as $100/share.  All share values between $0 and $100 are
considered equally likely.  By all estimates, the company will be worth
considerably more in the hands of Company A than under current management.
In fact, whatever the ultimate value under current management, the company
will be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than under
Company T.  If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share under
either
management.  If the exploration project generates a $50/share value under
current management, the value under Company A is $75/share.  Similarly, a
$100/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under Company
A,
and so on.

     The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine the
price
they should offer for Company T's shares.  This offer must be made now,
before the outcome of the drilling project is known.  From all indications,
Company T would be happy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at a
profitable price.  Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at all cost, the
potential of a takeover bid by any other firm.  You expect Company T to
delay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, then
accept or reject your offer before the news of the drilling results reaches
the press.

     Thus, you (Company A) will not know the results of the exploration
project
when submitting your price offer, but Company T will know the results when
deciding whether or not to accept your offer.  In addition, Company T will
accept any offer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value of
the company under current management.  Thus, if you offer $50/share, for
instance, Company T will accept if the value of the company to Company T is
anything less than $50.

     As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over price
offers
in the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offer at all) to
$150/share.  What price offer per share would you tender for Company T's
stock?

     $______ per/share

Take care, and I'll be in touch soon.

Best,
Alex

Please plan to attend a meeting on Friday, August 11 at 11:15 a.m. in 30C1 to 
discuss the transportation model.  Now that we have had several traders 
managing transportation positions for several months, I would like to discuss 
any issues you have with the way the model works.   I have asked Zimin Lu 
(Research), Mark Breese and John Griffith (Structuring) to attend so they 
will be available to answer any technical questions.   The point of this 
meeting is to get all issues out in the open and make sure everyone is 
comfortable with using the model and position manager, and to make sure those 
who are managing the books believe in the model's results.   Since I have 
heard a few concerns, I hope you will take advantage of this opportunity to 
discuss them.

Please let me know if you are unable to attend.

Pam,

Can you help with below?

David
 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Allen, Phillip K.  
Sent:	Monday, November 26, 2001 11:18 AM
To:	Oxley, David
Subject:	RE: Answer 

David,

For clarity, wherever you cite Section 6.2 in your response I assume you mean Section 6.3.  

Your response does not address the key points upon which I based my interpretation of the plan.  The beginning of Section 6.3 states "Notwithstanding any other provision of the plan?".   This implies that Section 6.3 contains the complete rules for an accelerated distribution.  I disagree with your translation of "a single sum distribution" as meaning all at once instead of a single amount.  I would like to meet to discuss or appeal to Greg W. or John L.   In addition, your response does not address Section 7.1.  This appears to be the relevant section if the PSA is to be paid in shares.  Additionally the Q & A section in the plan brochure (pg. 8) works through an example of adjusting the number of shares to retain a certain dollar value.  This is the methodology described in Section 7.1.

Tom Martin and Scott Neal share the above concerns.  Please advise of a convenient time we can all meet to discuss further.

Phillip  

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Oxley, David  
Sent:	Monday, November 26, 2001 8:31 AM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.
Cc:	Whalley, Greg; Joyce, Mary
Subject:	Answer 

For purposes of an accelerated distribution from the PSA,  a "single sum distribution," in Section 6.2 means that a PSA account is distributed all at once, as distinguished from another form of payout as may have been selected by a participant in his or her deferral agreement.  

Section 6.2 is clear in that the account balance shall be determined as of the last day of the month preceding the date on which the Committee receives the written request of the Participant.  A PSA account balance is reflected in shares of stock since the form of distribution is shares of stock.

Additionally, any portion of a PSA balance attributable to deferral of restricted stock is administered under Sections 3.5 and 3.6 and Exhibit A of the Plan. This section is applicable now as we are accelerating the distribution of PSA balances created with deferrals of restricted stock.  The Plan indicates that upon death, disability, retirement or termination, the share units are converted to shares which are issued to the executive according to the payment election made by the executive at the time of the deferral election.  

      Therefore the distribution you will receive in shares is correct and we do not agree with your interpretation of the plan.

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@scienceexplorers.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@scienceexplorers.org>
Subject: RE: Storybook manuscript for "The Adventures of Photon"

Hi Emily,

Thank you for your email! I'm glad to hear that you've made progress on the manuscript. I'd be more than happy to review it and provide my feedback.

I think it's crucial that we strike a balance between accuracy and simplicity when explaining physics concepts to young children. We want to spark their curiosity without overwhelming them with technical jargon.

I'm available for a call on Wednesday afternoon, between 2 PM and 4 PM. Please let me know if any of these times work for you, and we can set up a call to discuss the manuscript in more detail.

I'm looking forward to seeing what you've created!

Best,
Michael

Jeff,

I reviewed your revised offer sheet.  I am OK with the effective income of $484K.  Her records show basically no other income ($75/month), so I subtracted $3,000 from your number.  The expenses just need to reflect $20,000 more property taxes and the numbers should be right on.  $484 less $244 would be $240 of NOI.  I spoke to Jim Murnane this afternoon.  He feels this property would most likely warrant 7.5% and a 30 year amortization.  See the attached spreadsheets.

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@renewableenergy.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@riverdalehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: STEM Education Event Follow-up

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I enjoyed our conversation at the event as well. I'm always eager to connect with fellow educators and professionals who are passionate about STEM.

I would definitely be interested in keeping in touch and exploring the intersections between our work. In fact, I recently published a paper on a new catalyst that improves the efficiency of solar cells, and I think some of the concepts could be visualized using geometric principles. I'd be curious to hear your thoughts on that.

I'm also intrigued by the idea of collaborating on a project related to STEM education. If you have any ideas or opportunities in mind, please let me know. I'd be happy to contribute my expertise in any way I can.

I'm looking forward to continuing our discussion. Let's plan to grab that coffee soon!

Best regards,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Johnson <sjohnson@oakvilleschool.edu>
To: Mark Thompson <mthompson@oakvilleschool.edu>
Subject: Collaborative Project Idea

Hi Mark,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking about ways to incorporate more real-world applications into my math lessons, and I thought of you and your civic education classes. Would you be interested in collaborating on a project where my students use coding to simulate a democratic election, and your students learn about the math behind voting systems?

I think it could be a great way for our students to learn from each other and see how different subjects can work together. Let me know what you think!

Best,
Samantha
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@greenville.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@greenville.edu>
Subject: NSF Grant Application Update

Dear Dr. Thompson,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to touch base with you regarding the progress of our NSF grant application. I have completed the literature review section and outlined the preliminary results from our recent experiments. Please find the updated draft attached for your review and feedback.

Additionally, I have been in contact with Dr. Schneider's research group from the University of Zurich. They have provided some valuable insights and suggestions for our project, which I believe will strengthen our proposal. I have incorporated their feedback into the draft.

Could we schedule a meeting next week to discuss the grant application in more detail and finalize the budget? Please let me know your availability.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
label: research

"BS Stone" <bs_stone@yahoo.com> on 09/26/2000 04:47:40 AM
To: "jeff" <jeff@freeyellow.com>
cc: "Phillip K Allen" <Phillip.K.Allen@enron.com> 
Subject: closing



Jeff, 
?
Is the closing today?? After reviewing the  agreement?I find it isn't binding 
as far as I can determine.? It is  too vague and it doesn't sound like 
anything an attorney or title company  would?draft for a real estate 
closing--but, of course, I could be  wrong.? 
?
If this?closing is going to take place without  this agreement then there is 
no point in me  following up on this?document's validity.? 
?
I will just need to go back to my closing documents  and see what's there and 
find out where I am with that and deal with this as  best I can.
?
I guess I was expecting something that would be an  exhibit to a recordable 
document or something a little more exact, or  rather?sort of a contract.? 
This isn't either.? I tried to get a  real estate atty on the phone last 
night but he was out of pocket.? I  talked to a crim. atty friend and he said 
this is out of his area but doesn't  sound binding to him.? 
?
I will go back to mine and Phillip Allen's  transaction?and take a look at 
that but as vague and general as this is I  doubt that my signature? is even 
needed to complete this transaction.?  I am in after 12 noon if there is any 
need to contact me regarding the  closing.
?
I really do not want to hold up anything or  generate more work for myself 
and I don't want to insult or annoy anyone but  this paper really doesn't 
seem to be something required for a closing.? In  the event you do need my 
signature on something like this I would rather have  time to have it 
reviewed before I accept it.
?
Brenda
?
?

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Chen <emily.chen@radiantlabs.com>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Radiation and Vaccine Efficacy Study

Dear Alex,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been thinking about our discussion at the conference and I believe your expertise in immune response could greatly benefit my current study on radiation and vaccine efficacy.

I'm particularly interested in your insights on how radiation might affect the immunogenicity of vaccine candidates. If you're open to it, I'd like to schedule a call to discuss potential collaboration on this project.

Please let me know your availability in the coming weeks. I look forward to working with you.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Chen

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@student.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@historyteacher.com>
Subject: RE: Help with math concepts for new lesson plan

Emily,

I think your lesson plan outline sounds great! Starting with the historical context and then introducing the Enigma machine and its significance is a good way to engage the students and provide them with the necessary background information.

I can definitely create some encrypted messages for the students to decipher using modular arithmetic and congruences. We can even make it a competition or a team activity to see who can crack the code first!

One suggestion I have is to maybe include a brief explanation of how the Enigma machine works and its inner workings. I think the students would find it interesting to see the actual machine and understand the mechanical and mathematical principles behind it.

Let me know if you need any help with the historical aspects of the lesson plan as well. I'd be happy to assist in any way I can.
Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@riverviewschools.org>
To: Emily Walters <emily.walters@museuminstitute.org>
Subject: RE: Silk Road Exhibit Opening - Preparing Your Students

Emily,

Thank you so much for your generous offer! The resources you've put together sound perfect for helping my students grasp the importance of the Silk Road. I'm particularly excited about the curriculum guide, as it will provide a structured way for my students to explore the topic.

I'd love to schedule a time for you to come to my classroom and give a brief presentation on the Silk Road, perhaps touching on some key aspects that you think will be most relevant to the exhibit. This would really help set the stage for their visit and get them excited about what they'll be seeing.

Additionally, I've been thinking more about incorporating mindfulness and meditation practices into my teaching, as we discussed before. Do you have any suggestions for how I could tie these practices into our study of the Silk Road? I think it could be a powerful way to help my students connect with the material on a deeper level.

Thanks again for all your support. I'm looking forward to collaborating with you on this project!

Best,
Michael Thompson
5th Grade Social Studies Teacher
Riverview Elementary School
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <alex.novak@spacebuff.com>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@ridgetonhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting news from NASA!

Jordan,

I'm glad the timing works for you and your students. I'll see you on Tuesday!

Your lesson plan on the different roles in space missions sounds fantastic. I'd be happy to share my perspective and discuss how amateur astronomers can contribute to the space exploration community. In fact, I've been involved in a few citizen science projects where amateur astronomers collaborate with professional researchers to analyze data and make discoveries. I think this could be a great way to show your students that they don't have to be professional scientists to make a difference in the field.

I'll also share some stories about the incredible women and men who work on missions like Juno, highlighting the diverse backgrounds and skill sets that come together to make these missions possible. I think this could help your students see themselves in these roles and inspire them to pursue their passions in STEM.

If you're interested, I could also bring my telescope to school one evening and give your students a hands-on experience observing the night sky. It would be a great way to cap off our discussion and give them a tangible connection to the wonders of space.

Let me know what you think about these ideas, and if there's anything else I can do to support your lesson plan.

Best,
Alex
label: research

body: Hello Ms. Singh, I’m interested in becoming a part of your research group. Could you provide me with information about the application process and any requirements?

body:
<email>
From: Emily Dawson <emily.dawson@university.edu>
To: Liam Holloway <liam.holloway@university.edu>
Subject: New course idea and conference presentation

Hi Liam,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out to you about a new course I'm developing for the "Languages and Cultures" program. The course will explore the intersection of animal rights and language, and I think your expertise in sociolinguistics could help make it even more comprehensive.

I was also thrilled to hear that we'll be giving a joint presentation at the upcoming conference. I believe this could be a great opportunity to showcase our interdisciplinary collaboration and share our findings with the academic community.

Would you be available for a meeting next week to discuss these topics further? I'd love to get your input and brainstorm some ideas together.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Baker/HOU/ECT@ECT, Melissa Jones/NA/Enron@ENRON, Beth A Ryan/HOU/ECT@ECT, 
Shirley Crenshaw/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tamara Jae Black/HOU/ECT@ECT, Amy 
Cooper/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kay Chapman/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: (Reminder) Update GIS Information

This is a reminder !!!  If you haven't taken the time to update your GIS 
information, please do so.  It is essential that this function be performed 
as soon as possible. Please read the following memo sent to you a few days 
ago and if you have any questions regarding this request, please feel free to 
call Ted Bland @ 3-5275.

With Enron's rapid growth we need to maintain an ability to move employees 
between operating companies and new ventures.  To do this it is essential to 
have one process that will enable us to collect , update and retain employee 
data.  In the spirit of One Enron, and building on the success of the 
year-end Global VP/MD Performance Review Process, the  Enron VP/MD PRC 
requests that all Enron Vice Presidents and Managing Directors update their 
profiles. Current responsibilities, employment history, skills and education 
need to be completed  via the HR Global Information System.  HRGIS is 
accessible via the HRWEB home page on the intranet.  Just go to 
hrweb.enron.com and look for the HRGIS link.  Or just type eglobal.enron.com 
on the command line of your browser.

The target date by which to update these profiles is 7 July.  If you would 
like to have a hard copy of a template that could be filled out and returned 
for input, or If you need any assistance with the HRGIS application please 
contact Kathy Schultea at x33841.  

Your  timely response to this request is greatly appreciated.   


Thanks,


Dave

<email>
From: Samantha Lee <slee@harmonyelementary.org>
To: Daniel Rodriguez <drodriguez@harmonyelementary.org>
Subject: Multicultural Storybook Project Update

Hi Daniel,

I hope you're having a great week so far! I wanted to touch base with you regarding our multicultural storybook project. The students have been making fantastic progress on their pages, and I'm thrilled with the diversity of cultures and stories they've chosen to represent.

I've been thinking about the layout of the storybook and how we can best showcase each student's work. Do you have any thoughts or suggestions? I'd love to hear your ideas!

Also, have you had a chance to finalize the date and time for our multicultural music and storytelling event? I want to make sure we give our students and their families enough notice to plan accordingly.

Looking forward to hearing back from you and continuing to collaborate on this exciting project!

Best regards,
Samantha

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@university.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@lincolnhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Fascinating presentation at the "Genetics and Infectious Diseases" conference

Dear Emily,

I'm glad to hear that you and your students are eager to explore the resources I'll be sharing. Understanding the genetic factors behind disease susceptibility and resistance is indeed a crucial aspect of our work, and I'm happy to provide more information on that topic.

The project idea you described sounds fantastic. I'll be sure to send over a dataset that your students can work with to create their visualizations. I'm confident that their work will help make our research more accessible to a wider audience.

As for the guest lecture, the week of May 10th works perfectly with my schedule. I'll be happy to join your class via webinar at 10:00 AM CST on a date that suits you best. Please let me know which day within that week would be most convenient for you and your students.

Regarding the virtual science fair, I would be delighted to be your keynote speaker. It's an honor to be considered, and I'm always eager to engage with the next generation of scientists. I look forward to discussing the details with your organizing committee.

Thank you once again for reaching out and for your commitment to providing your students with valuable learning experiences. I'm excited to collaborate with you and your class, and I'm confident that this partnership will be mutually beneficial.

Best regards,
Michael Johnson, PhD
Department of Mathematics
University of South Africa

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <alex.novak@stellaris.edu>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@smallvilletownschool.edu>
Subject: Space Exploration Unit Resources

Hey Jordan,

I hope this email finds you well! I remember you mentioned that you were planning a unit on space exploration for your students. As promised, I've compiled some resources that you might find useful for your lesson plans.

I've attached a folder containing the latest images and data from our observations of Jupiter and its moons, particularly Io. You'll find high-resolution images, detailed maps, and some fascinating information about the unique geological features and volcanism on Io. I've also included a few articles and research papers that I thought might be accessible and engaging for your students.

Please feel free to use these materials in any way that suits your needs. If you have any questions or need further clarification on any of the content, just let me know. I'm always happy to help!

Best regards,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: David Spinelli <david.spinelli@university.edu>
To: Elena Petrova <elena.petrova@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Inquiry about philosophical influences on the Alaska Purchase

Dear Elena,

Thank you for reaching out, and apologies for the delayed response. Your research on the Alaska Purchase and its connection to the philosophical ideas of the time is fascinating. I would be delighted to discuss this further and explore the potential for collaboration.

I believe that the works of Spinoza, Hobbes, and Machiavelli could indeed have had a significant influence on the decision-making processes of the key figures involved in the purchase. Spinoza's ideas on the nature of the state and the role of reason in politics, Hobbes' concept of the social contract, and Machiavelli's pragmatic approach to power dynamics could all provide valuable insights into the motivations and strategies employed by the Russian and American negotiators.

I have a few resources that might be helpful for your research, and I would be happy to share them with you. Additionally, I think that our collaboration could lead to a compelling joint paper that explores the intersection of philosophy and history in this specific context. We could potentially present our findings at the upcoming interdisciplinary conference on "Philosophy and History: Reexamining the Past Through Multiple Lenses."

Please let me know your thoughts on this proposal, and if you're available for a meeting to discuss the project further.

Best regards,
David Spinelli

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@datavault.com>
To: Emily Chen <emily.chen@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expert opinion on a new data archiving solution

Emily,

Thank you for your quick response and for sharing your initial questions. I'll do my best to provide more context around the key features of our solution:

1. Data integrity and version control: Our solution leverages advanced checksum algorithms to ensure data integrity throughout the archiving process. We also provide a robust version control system that allows users to track changes and roll back to previous versions if needed.

2. Data retrieval and access: We have designed our solution to be highly interoperable with existing data analysis tools. We offer a range of APIs and connectors that enable seamless integration with popular platforms like Python, R, and SQL. Users can also access their archived data through a user-friendly web interface.

3. Data governance and compliance: Our solution includes built-in features for data governance and compliance, such as role-based access control, audit trails, and retention policies. We also offer a range of certifications and accreditations to ensure that our solution meets the highest standards for security and privacy.

I'd be happy to dive into more technical details on a call. Would next Tuesday or Wednesday work for you? I'm available most of the day.

Best,
John

From: Anna Svensson <anna.svensson@uppsala.edu>
To: Rajesh Kumar <rajesh.kumar@madrasuni.ac.in>
Subject: Collaborating on language curriculum design

Dear Rajesh,

It was great meeting you at the International Language Instructors' Conference in Berlin last month. I was impressed by your presentation on innovative approaches to Tamil language curriculum design, and I think we could benefit from sharing ideas and collaborating on our respective courses.

I'm currently working on redesigning my Swedish language and culture course to better engage students and improve their language acquisition. I'd love to hear more about the strategies you've implemented in your Tamil courses and discuss potential ways we could incorporate each other's ideas.

Would you be interested in setting up a video call to discuss this further? I'm free next week on Wednesday afternoon or Thursday morning, if that works for you.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

Best regards,
Anna Svensson
Senior Language Instructor
Department of Scandinavian Languages and Cultures
Uppsala University, Sweden

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <alex.rivera@equalhistory.org>
To: Samira Patel <samira.patel@herstoryeducators.com>
Subject: RE: National Conference Submission

Hi Samira,

Tuesday afternoon works great for me. Let's schedule our call for 2 pm EST. I'll send you a Zoom link closer to the date.

I completely agree about emphasizing the student-centered approach in our proposal. It's a crucial aspect of our curriculum, and it will showcase how our work empowers students to engage with history in a more meaningful way.

I'm also thinking about potential challenges we might face during the presentation, such as pushback or questions about the relevance of teaching women's rights and social justice in history classes. We should be prepared to address these concerns and highlight the importance of inclusive education.

Let me know if you have any other thoughts or suggestions for our proposal. I'm looking forward to our call and continuing our collaboration!

Best,
Alex

didn't see $15,000 applied against the purchase price.  Can you help clear

Assuming we clear up the $15,000, we need to get the property released.  
Keith and I are concerned about taking over the Bishop Corner partnership and 
the risk that there could be undisclosed liabilities.  On the other hand, 
conveyance of the partnership would be a time and money saver if it was 
clean.  What is your inclination?

Call as soon as you have a chance to review.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <athompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
To: Jamie Rivera <jrivera@westsideprep.org>
Subject: Inclusive Soccer Program Update

Hey Jamie,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to give you an update on the inclusive soccer program we've been working on. We've made some great progress, but we're facing a few challenges that I think we should discuss.

First, the good news: we've secured the grant funding we needed to get the program off the ground! The grant committee was impressed with our proposal and the potential impact our program could have on students with and without disabilities.

However, now that we're in the implementation phase, we're running into some scheduling conflicts. It's been difficult to find a time when both our schools can have students available for the program. I was wondering if you had any ideas for how we could work around this issue.

Another challenge we're facing is finding volunteers to help with the program. We need people who are knowledgeable about adaptive sports and can assist our students during practices and games. Do you have any suggestions for where we could find reliable volunteers?

I know we've got a lot to figure out, but I'm confident that we can make this program a success. I'd love to hear your thoughts on these challenges and any ideas you might have for overcoming them.

Let me know when you have a chance to chat,

Alex

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@plategeodynamics.edu>
To: Dr. Jacob Klein <jacob.klein@holocauststudies.org>
Subject: RE: Interdisciplinary Conference on Cataclysmic Events

Dear Dr. Klein,

I am thrilled to hear that you are as enthusiastic about our potential collaboration as I am. I completely agree that our respective fields can offer unique and valuable perspectives on the concept of resilience in the face of catastrophic events.

As for our video conference call, I would be available next Tuesday, April 12th, at 10:00 AM my time (Pacific Daylight Time). If this works for you, please let me know, and I will send you a meeting invite with the video conferencing details.

In the meantime, I have been thinking about the conference organizers' request for a proposal for a joint session at next year's conference. I believe that our paper on resilience could form the basis for an engaging and thought-provoking session. We could explore the parallels between geological and historical cataclysmic events and how humans have adapted and persevered in the face of these challenges. We could also discuss the implications of our findings for contemporary society and the challenges we face today.

I would love to hear your thoughts on this idea and any suggestions you may have for the joint session proposal. Please feel free to share any other ideas or topics you think would be worth exploring in our collaboration.

I look forward to our call next week and to further discussing our exciting collaboration.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Thompson

<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@ridgemont-high.edu>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@oakwood-middle.edu>
Subject: RE: Need advice on motivating students

Sarah,

Thank you so much for your thoughtful and detailed response. Your suggestions make a lot of sense, and I'm excited to try them out with my students. I especially like the idea of incorporating team-building activities and goal-setting exercises. I think that could make a real difference in helping them develop a sense of purpose and unity.

In fact, we have a big soccer tournament coming up next month where my students will have the opportunity to showcase their skills and progress. I think it will be a great opportunity to put some of your strategies into action and see how they respond.

Thanks again for your help and support. It means a lot to have a colleague like you to turn to for advice and guidance.

Best regards,
John

body:
<email>
From: Jessica Langford <jessica.langford@ecu.edu>
To: Michael Chen <michael.chen@dentalhealth.com>
Subject: Exciting news!

Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some exciting news with you – our paper on the environmental impact of dental products has been accepted for publication in the Journal of Environmental Health!

This is a huge accomplishment, and I couldn't have done it without your expertise and collaboration. I'm so proud of the work we've done together and the impact it will have on both the dental and environmental communities.

I've been invited to speak at the upcoming Green Dentistry Conference to present our findings. I would love for you to join me as co-presenters. It would be a great opportunity to share our research with a wider audience and network with other professionals in the field.

Let me know if you're interested and available to join me. I'm happy to provide more details about the conference.

Thank you again for being such a wonderful collaborator and friend. I'm looking forward to our next project together!

Best,
Jessica

From: Samantha Starry <samantha.starry@spaceexplorers.com>
To: Liam Landscapes <liam.landscapes@geographyguru.com>
Subject: RE: Exciting news about Mars mission!

Liam,

Thank you so much for sharing your stunning photographs! They're absolutely breathtaking, and they've reignited my wanderlust for exploring Earth's natural wonders. I can only imagine how incredible it must be to see these places in person.

I would love to set up a video call to discuss our project further. How about next Friday at 10am my time (which I believe is 1am your time)? I know it's a bit early for you, but I wanted to find a time that works with both our schedules. Let me know if that works for you.

I'm also attaching a recent article I came across about the potential for underground lakes on Mars. It ties in perfectly with our research, and I thought you might find it interesting.

Can't wait to dive deeper into this project with you!

Best,
Samantha

Subject: RE: WWII Technology and Renewable Energy

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm thrilled that you're interested in incorporating renewable energy into your WWII curriculum. The advancements in solar technology since then are truly remarkable. I'd be more than happy to share my knowledge and discuss how we can create an engaging educational resource for your students.

In fact, I'm currently working on a project to install solar panels at local schools and create educational materials to promote renewable energy. I could definitely use your expertise in crafting content that resonates with high schoolers and aligns with your curriculum.

Let me know when you're free for a call to brainstorm ideas. I'm excited to collaborate with you on this!

Alex

To: <Phillip.K.Allen@enron.com>
cc:  
Subject: leander and the Stage


Phillip,

I spoke with AMF's broker today, and they will be satisfied with the deal if
we can get the school to agree to limit the current land use restrictions to
the terms that are in the existing agreement.  They do not want the school
to come back at a later date for something different.  Doug Bell will meet
with a school official on Monday to see what their thoughts are about the
subject.  It would be hard for them to change the current agreement, but AMF
wants something in writing to that effect.  I spoke to AMF's attorney today,
and explained the situation.  They are OK with deal if AMF is satisfied.

AMF's broker said that they will be ready to submit their site plan after
the March 29 hearing.  We may close this deal in April.

The Stage is still on go.  An assumption package has been sent to the buyer,
and I have overnighted a copy of the contract and a description of the
details to Wayne McCoy.

I will be gone Thurs. and Fri. of this week.  I will be checking my
messages.

Jeff Smith

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Chen <echen@oakwood.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Russo <mrusso@oakwood.edu>
Subject: Syllabus for CHEM/SOC 101

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. As we discussed in the committee meeting, I've drafted a preliminary syllabus for our new course, CHEM/SOC 101: The Impact of Biochemistry on Society. I've attached the document for your review.

In the syllabus, I've outlined a series of lectures that cover the key concepts in carbohydrate synthesis and biological macromolecules, as well as their applications in medicine, agriculture, and industry. I've also included a section on the historical development of these fields and their societal implications.

Please let me know if you have any suggestions or changes you'd like to make. I look forward to working with you on this exciting new course!

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Maria Lopez <maria.lopez@happyschool.edu>
To: Olivia Johnson <olivia.johnson@creativeschool.edu>
Subject: Joint art project idea

Hi Olivia,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking about our conversation at the arts education conference and wanted to run an idea by you. I'm planning to do a unit on cultural and musical influences in art with my kindergarten class, and I thought it might be fun to do a cross-school art exchange with your class. 

The idea would be for each class to create a piece of art inspired by a different culture or musical genre, and then we could swap the artwork and have a video call to discuss our interpretations and experiences. I think it could be a great way to expose our students to diverse perspectives and encourage them to think critically about art.

What do you think? Would you be interested in collaborating on this project? I'd love to hear your thoughts and any ideas you might have for making it even better.

Best,
Maria

04:57 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls


Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austin
that we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this project
should produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.
This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong as
Austin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range for
this market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that we
have uncovered to date in the Austin market.
The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  As
it is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austin
for preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be complete
in less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severe
water treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lot
improvement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in North
Austin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and street
widening.  Even though this property is not likely to require street
widening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pond
requirement, I used this data to be cautious.
 The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is not
expected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quite
successful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as the
adjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.
As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoods
is uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but may
only put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are far
preferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyer
preferences.
The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 and
an extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved site
plan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close into
an A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.
This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in the
profits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discuss
having you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entity
with your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a
1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is a
rental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would then
be the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with an
exchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in San
Antonio if you do not know anyone.
I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,
by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.
Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want to
schedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon as
your schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at any
time.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either
512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is
512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with you
on this project that is sure to be a major winner.
I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusual
events these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpg
downdrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.
One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled to
start the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enough
to knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it took
another week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to take
my wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebra
in her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden this
past week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realize
the enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks as
if she will be ok in the long run.
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC


 - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

body:
Message-ID: <21035552.1075857570805.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 12 Dec 2000 02:03:00 -0800 (PST)
From: russell.dyk@enron.com
To: john.arnold@enron.com
Subject: LNG to California
Cc: jennifer.fraser@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: jennifer.fraser@enron.com
X-From: Russell Dyk
X-To: John Arnold
X-cc: Jennifer Fraser
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

John,
Following up on yesterday, there are two additional considerations. 

First, with regard to the idea of curtailing gas input at the Topock 
liquefaction plant, the pipeline bottleneck is actually downstream of the 
plant, so that wouldn't help. 

Second, it seems there are more of these "portable pipeline" units floating 
around than I thought. Besides the inoperable unit in Amarillo, both Transgas 
(in Massachusetts) and Minnigasco may have at least one. Moreover, PG&E has 
one at the end of a long lateral line on its system just south of Sacramento. 
Apparently it uses it mostly to augment linepack. The specs of that unit are 
about 4 times higher than the Amarillo one: it puts out 400,000 cubic 
feet/hour (about 9.6 mmcf/d or almost one contract) at 150 psi. As I said 
yesterday, these units are the only way that you could get gas into the 
pipeline system in California. 

This information I got from Jeff Beale, who runs CH-IV, a small-scale LNG 
consultant. He said that he'd had some similar calls about LNG, and also that 
he'd be willing to help Enron source equipment if we were really interested 
in looking further into transporting LNG into California. 

Assuming that we could get a few "portable pipelines" and some trucks, there 
are five liquefaction plants that could most conveniently supply LNG:

Location Owner  Liquefaction Capacity (gal/day)  Capacity (mmcf/d) Storage 
(gal) Storage (mmcf)
Topock, AZ ElPaso/ALT 90,000      7.4   100,000  8.2
LaPlata, CO Williams 20,000     1.64   100,000  8.2
Sacramento   57,600     4.72   132,000  10.8
LaBarge, WY Exxon  60,000     4.92      
Evanston, WY Amoco  95,000     7.8   100,000  8.2

Totals         26.48

Whether these plants have spare LNG to sell us is another question. The 
Sacramento plant, which I mentioned yesterday, is supposedly dedicated to 
providing methane for laboratory purposes. The others may have contracts with 
LNG fleet owners. 

I'll check back with you later today about the outcome of your meeting.

body:
<email>
From: James Thompson <jthompson@chicagopostalhistory.org>
To: Dr. Emily Carlisle <ecarlisle@londonuni.ac.uk>
Subject: Great meeting you at the World Stamp Show!

Hi Dr. Carlisle,

It was such a pleasure meeting you at the World Stamp Show last week. I really enjoyed our conversation about the history of postal services and philately. Your presentation on the impact of the postal system on 19th-century communication was fascinating!

I hope you had a smooth journey back to London. The conference was quite an experience, wasn't it? I've been to a few of these events before, but this one was by far the largest and most impressive.

I'd love to stay in touch and perhaps collaborate on some research projects in the future. If you come across any interesting stamps or postal history artifacts from your side of the pond, please do let me know. I'm always on the lookout for new additions to my collection.

Best regards,
James

X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Jun2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

I think you need to check your AGA model.  7.2 bcf/d seems awfully high.  
That's saying that had gas been at $2.5, the AGA for the week would have been 
151.  Look at the AGA history for last week, this week and next week.

   94 95 96 97 98 99 00 01 
3rd week of Feb  -64 -46 -64 -63 -77 -97 -136 -81
4th week of Feb  -132 -118 -62 -76 -47 -128 -74 -101 
1st week of Mar  -27 -132 -118 -57 -54 -69 -37 ??

Do you really think the # would have been 151 with no demand destruction?  It 
wasn't even really cold.  That would have been the highest AGA # of the three 
weeks by 15 bcf.  
Our guys are thinking 4.5 bcf/d.  Pira is saying that Feb as a whole averages 
3.5-4 bcf/d. That's just destruction and does not include new production, if 
any.  Further Pira estimates that March destruction will be about half of 
Feb.  Assuming that gets to equilibrium:  2 bcf/d demand destruction, 2 bcf/d 
more production, 2 bcf/d more gas generation demand.  Start with a 400 b 
deficit and 200 injection days gets you to flat against last years storage in 
current price environment.   I think we are fairly priced fundamentally, but 
with huge customer imbalance for hedging from buy side, surprises in the 
market right now are to the upside in my view.  Course hard to imagine $6 for 
J.   Just sell vol.

Subject: 4-URGENT - OWA Please print this now.


Current Notes User:

REASONS FOR USING OUTLOOK WEB ACCESS (OWA)

1. Once your mailbox has been migrated from Notes to Outlook, the Outlook 
client will be configured on your computer.
After migration of your mailbox, you will not be able to send or recieve mail 
via Notes, and you will not be able to start using Outlook until it is 
configured by the Outlook Migration team the morning after your mailbox is 
migrated.  During this period, you can use Outlook Web Access (OWA) via your 
web browser (Internet Explorer 5.0) to read and send mail.

PLEASE NOTE:  Your calendar entries, personal address book, journals, and 
To-Do entries imported from Notes will not be available until the Outlook 
client is configured on your desktop.

2. Remote access to your mailbox.
After your Outlook client is configured, you can use Outlook Web Access (OWA) 
for remote access to your mailbox.

PLEASE NOTE:  At this time, the OWA client is only accessible while 
connecting to the Enron network (LAN).  There are future plans to make OWA 
available from your home or when traveling abroad.

HOW TO ACCESS OUTLOOK WEB ACCESS (OWA)

Launch Internet Explorer 5.0, and in the address window type:  
http://nahou-msowa01p/exchange/john.doe

Substitute "john.doe" with your first and last name, then click ENTER.  You 
will be prompted with a sign in box as shown below.  Type in "corp/your user 
id" for the user name and your NT password to logon to OWA and click OK.  You 
will now be able to view your mailbox.

 

PLEASE NOTE:  There are some subtle differences in the functionality between 
the Outlook and OWA clients.  You will not be able to do many of the things 
in OWA that you can do in Outlook.  Below is a brief list of *some* of the 
functions NOT available via OWA:

Features NOT available using OWA:

-  Tasks
-  Journal
-  Spell Checker
-  Offline Use
-  Printing Templates
-  Reminders
-  Timed Delivery
-  Expiration
-  Outlook Rules
-  Voting, Message Flags and Message Recall
-  Sharing Contacts with others
-  Task Delegation
-  Direct Resource Booking
-  Personal Distribution Lists

QUESTIONS OR CONCERNS?

If you have questions or concerns using the OWA client, please contact the 
Outlook 2000 question and answer Mailbox at:

 Outlook.2000@enron.com

Otherwise, you may contact the Resolution Center at:

 713-853-1411

Thank you,

Outlook 2000 Migration Team

i actually started writing this on thursday.  got distracted and left late
morning to go to Vail.  Apparently I missed a little craziness.  My point
on v/x is that forward spreads, months 3/4 and back, don't necessarily
trade on value, they trade on drawing a forward curve that makes
equilibrium between hedging and spec demand.  Look at k/m... do you think k
cash will average 3 cents above m.  i don't really see that scenario.  yet
that's what it is worth because the market says jv is worth $x and to get
there k/m=3.  The same argument applies to v/x.  i think this summer will
be exceptionally strong as we try to inject 2 bcf/d more gas than last
year.  But cal 2 will lag the move.  It's the main thing customers are
selling right now because every equity analyst and even Pira are telling
their customers that cal 2 will average 3.50.  so either the v/x and x/z
spreads come in or f/g g/h h/j blow out.  After this winter, who in there
right mind wants to buy f/g or g/h again.  my thought is that the primary
juice will be h/j but v/x and x/z will be under some pressure.  i'm a
seller at 9 and buyer at 5-6.  Not much in it either way though.

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Taylor <jtaylor@university.edu>
To: Liam Thompson <lthompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: New course syllabus

Liam,

Great suggestions for additional readings! I've added them to the syllabus. I also like your idea of incorporating a debate or discussion component into the course. It would be a good way for the students to practice their critical thinking and argumentation skills.

I was thinking we could have the students debate topics such as:
1. The morality of using animals for food, clothing, and medical research
2. The role of individual responsibility vs. government regulation in environmental protection
3. The impact of cultural traditions on animal welfare practices

What do you think? Do you have any other ideas for debate topics?

I'm also thinking about how we can incorporate some non-traditional teaching methods into the course. Maybe we could have the students do a field trip to a local farm or wildlife sanctuary, or invite guest speakers from different cultural backgrounds to share their perspectives on environmental and animal welfare issues.

Let me know your thoughts!

Best,
Jordan

01:32 PM ---------------------------
   
	
	
	From:  Colleen Sullivan                           05/30/2000 09:18 AM
	

To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Transport p&l

Phillip--
I've noticed one thing on your intra-month transport p&l that looks strange 
to me.  Remember that I do not know the Northwest at all, so this may not be 
an issue, but I'll point it out and let you decide.  Let me know if this is 
O.K. as is, so I'll know to ignore it in the future.  Also, if you want me to 
get with Kim and the Sitara people to change the mapping, let me know and 
I'll take care of it..

On PG&E NW, it appears that PGEN Kingsgate is mapped to a Malin Citygate 
curve instead of a Kingsgate curve, resulting in a total transport loss of 
$235,019.   
(If the mapping were changed, it should just reallocate p&l--not change your 
overall p&l.)  Maybe there is a reason for this mapping or maybe it affects 
something else somewhere that I am not seeing, but anyway, here are the Deal 
#'s, paths and p&l impacts of each.
  139195  From Kingsgate to Malin     ($182,030)
  139196 From Kingsgate to PGEN/Tuscarora   ($    4,024)
  139197  From Kingsgate to PGEN Malin    ($    8,271)
  231321  From Kingsgate to Malin     ($  38,705)
  153771 From Kingsgate to Stanfield    ($     1,988)
 Suggested fix:  Change PGEN Kingsgate mapping from GDP-Malin Citygate to 
GDP-Kingsgate.

 Clay Basin storage--this is really a FYI more than anything else--I see five 
different tickets in Sitara for Clay Basin activity--one appears to be for 
withdrawals and the other four are injections.  Clay Basin is valued as a 
Questar curve, which is substantially below NWPL points.  What this means is 
that any time you are injecting gas, these tickets will show transport 
losses; each time you are withdrawing, you will show big gains on transport.  
I'm not sure of the best way to handle this since we don't really have a 
systematic Sitara way of handling storage deals.  In an ideal world, it seems 
that you would map it the way you have it today, but during injection times, 
the transport cost would pass through as storage costs.  Anyway, here's the 
detail on the tickets just for your info, plus I noticed three days where it 
appears we were both withdrawing and injecting from Clay Basin.  There may be 
an operational reason why this occurred that I'm not aware of, and the dollar 
impact is very small, but I thought I'd bring it to your attention just in 
case there's something you want to do about it.  The columns below show the 
volumes under each ticket and the p&L associated with each. 
 
Deal #  251327                  159540                   265229         
106300   201756
P&L  $29,503                ($15,960)                ($3,199)          
($2,769)   ($273)
Rec:   Ques/Clay Basin/0184   NWPL/Opal 543  NWPL/Opal   Sumas      NWPL/S of

Date: Tue, 24 Oct 2000 10:21:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: russell.dyk@enron.com
Subject: Re: CSFB Columbia/Appalachia Hedging Deal
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Russell Dyk
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Certainly encourage CSFP to transact all volumes with us.  If they shop the 
deal, everyone will front-run the volumes and they won't get a good price on 
the deal.  
Financial deals settle 5 days after the index has been published.  Physical 
deals settle much later.   My understanding is this is a financial deal.


   
	
	
	From:  Russell Dyk @ ENRON                           10/23/2000 12:43 PM
	

To: Paul Radous/Corp/Enron@ENRON
cc: Per Sekse/NY/ECT@ECT, Caroline Abramo/Corp/Enron@Enron, John 
Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sara Shackleton/HOU/ECT@ECT, William S 
Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: CSFB Columbia/Appalachia Hedging Deal

The New York office has been speaking to Credit Suisse First Boston for 
roughly 6 months about a producer hedging deal that is part of a strucutured 
deal they're putting together. It now looks as if it will get done in the 
next 3 weeks-1 month so we want to get all the necessary credit issues taken 
care of. 

In brief, the deal is a fixed price one, basis TCO (67% of the volumes) and 
CNG (33%) with a fixed price Nymex component as well. It will settle against 
the Inside FERC indices for both locations. The term of the deal is from 
December, 2000 to December 2012. The volumes decline throughout the term from 
roughly 22,000 mmBtu/d to 13,000 mmBtu/d. The average daily nominal volume is 
17,000 mmBtu/d. As I understand it, these volumes are about 65% of the 
producers' total volumes. I've attached a spreadsheet to this message with 
more details. 

There are a couple of contractual and credit issues that CSFB wants to 
clarify. 

First, there is a question of the monthly cash settlement. CSFB would like 
payment to take place on the fifteenth of the month following the date both 
the floating and fixed prices are known. As I understand it,  for the 
December settlement, which would be known in early December, cash payment 
would take place on February 15, 2000. 

Second, there is a question of a parent guarantee from Enron Corp. 
Apparently, there is an existing credit arrangement in place between ENA and 
Credit Suisse First Boston International - the same counterparty that we 
would be dealing with here - that has a $15 million guarantee from Enron 
Corp. CSFB would like to increase this guarantee to at least $100 million. 
(CSFB already has an unlimited guarantee from Enron Corp. for a deal they've 
done with us in Europe so in their opinion it should not be an issue). 

 There is another minor issue involving centralizing credit discussions with 
the aim of securing a similar credit arrangement for CSFB's dealings with 
EnronCredit.com - which may be an issue for London rather than Houston. 
However, CSFB agreed that this was a secondary issue in relation to this 
transaction.

CSFB would like to do the entire deal through us, rather than having to split 
it among one or more counterparties. Per, Caroline Abramo, and I are meeting 
with Paul tomorrow to discuss various credit issues, including this one. 
Ideally, CSFB would like to have a good idea of where they stand by the end 
of this week. 

Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Regards,
Russ
