body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@example.org>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@example.com>
Subject: RE: Grant Application - Game-based Learning Tool for Children with Hearing Impairments

Hi Sarah,

Thanks for sending over the latest draft of the project proposal. I've reviewed it and think you've done an excellent job outlining our goals and the potential impact of the game-based learning tool.

Regarding the game mechanics, I was thinking about incorporating some sort of reward system where children earn points or badges for completing certain tasks or reaching milestones in their hearing management. This could help motivate them to stay engaged with the game and reinforce positive habits.

I'd also like to explore ways to make the game adaptive, so that it can adjust the difficulty level based on the child's progress and individual needs. This could help ensure that the game remains challenging and effective for a wide range of children with different abilities and learning styles.

Let me know what you think about these ideas, and if you have any other suggestions for making the game as effective and engaging as possible.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Sophia Russo <sophiar@university.edu>
To: Liam Thompson <liam.t@institute.org>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Liam,

I'm thrilled to report that our grant proposal has been accepted! This is a huge step forward for our research and a testament to the strong case we made for the importance of studying the long-term impacts of catastrophic geological events.

I've been in touch with my department head, and they are fully supportive of this collaboration. We can start making arrangements for me to visit your field site at Mount Etna and for you to come to Mount Rainier. I think being able to collect data and samples together will be invaluable for our study.

In the meantime, I'll start working on the preliminary data analysis from the papers we've exchanged. I have a few ideas for how we can structure our comparative analysis, which I'd love to run by you.

Thank you for being such a wonderful collaborator and friend throughout this process. I have no doubt that our work together will lead to important discoveries and advancements in our field.

Can't wait to see you in person soon!

Best,
Sophia

Hey Jordan,

Great, I'll go ahead and book a rental car so I can pick you up from the airport. My drive should take around 4 hours, so I'll aim to arrive at the airport by 3 pm to give myself some buffer time. I'll send you the rental car details once I have them.

I completely agree about the real-world examples workshop – that's a great way to make geometry more relatable for students. We should also try to have dinner one evening to catch up properly.

Let me know if you have any other workshop suggestions or if there's anything else I can help with for the conference. I'm excited to learn and reconnect with you and other math educators!

Best,
Alex

To "Outstanding" Analysts and Associates:
I  am writing to inform of a possible opening on the natural gas derivatives 
trading desk.  It is an opportunity to work on one of the most profitable and 
demanding groups within Enron, as well as one of the largest financial 
commodity trading desks worldwide.  I envision the role as performing 
analysis initially, to grasp an understanding of gas fundamentals and become 
more familiar with the trading environment, and leading to a junior trading 
role.  Upside potential is limitless for the right person.

Candidates for the role need to possess the following qualities:
1. Have been ranked as outstanding on previous yearend reviews.
2. Excellent math and quantitative skills.  Candidates should have 700+ math 
SAT and/or 700+ GMAT
3. Basic understanding of economics including pricing differences under 
monopolistic and competitive market scenarios.
4. Ability to work under intense pressure.  

If you are interested please email with interest and attach a resume.  Do not 
call.

John Arnold
Vice President of Gas Derivatives Trading

"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls


Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austin
that we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this project
should produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.
This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong as
Austin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range for
this market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that we
have uncovered to date in the Austin market.
The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  As
it is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austin
for preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be complete
in less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severe
water treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lot
improvement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in North
Austin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and street
widening.  Even though this property is not likely to require street
widening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pond
requirement, I used this data to be cautious.
 The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is not
expected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quite
successful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as the
adjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.
As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoods
is uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but may
only put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are far
preferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyer
preferences.
The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 and
an extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved site
plan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close into
an A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.
This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in the
profits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discuss
having you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entity
with your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a
1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is a
rental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would then
be the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with an
exchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in San
Antonio if you do not know anyone.
I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,
by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.
Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want to
schedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon as
your schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at any
time.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either
512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is
512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with you
on this project that is sure to be a major winner.
I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusual
events these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpg
downdrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.
One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled to
start the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enough
to knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it took
another week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to take
my wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebra
in her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden this
past week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realize
the enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks as
if she will be ok in the long run.
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC


 - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <alex.rivera@historicdesigns.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@rivertown.gov>
Subject: RE: Grand Opening Event Planning

Emily,

The draft invitation and press release look great! I've made a few minor edits and suggestions, which I've highlighted in the attached documents. Feel free to modify them as you see fit.

I've reached out to the local media outlets, and the response has been very positive. I'm confident we'll have good coverage for the event.

As for the event schedule, I was thinking we could start with a welcome speech from you and me, followed by the ribbon-cutting ceremony. After that, we could have guided tours of the center and the interactive activities for the children. What do you think?

Looking forward to our call on Monday to finalize the details.

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Emily Davis <emily.davis@university.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: RE: RE: Faulkner's Symbolism in "The Sound and the Fury"

Dr. Thompson,

Thank you for your prompt response and your kind words. I'm glad you agree about the conference. I'll keep an eye out for your feedback on the conclusion.

In the meantime, I'll start preparing a brief outline for our presentation, focusing on the key points of our argument and the most significant insights we've uncovered. I'll share it with you as soon as it's ready for your input.

Once again, thank you for your guidance and support throughout this project. I've learned so much from our collaboration, and I'm excited to see where this research leads us in the future.

Best,
Emily
label: research

From: Lisa Hoot, Coordinator of Techxans Networking Social

You and your guests  are cordially invited to attend Techxans Holiday Party

=====================================
 IT'S ALL ABOUT PERSONAL RELATIONSHIPS
=====================================
WHAT: Techxans Holiday Party
        Happy Holiday!  Come join us to celebrate this Holiday Season!
        Don't miss this great opportunity to network with members from
        leading Houston technology associations.  Have fun, meet old
        friends, and make new ones.
        >> RSVP ONLINE: www.techxans.org/signup/holidaypartysignup.htm

WHEN: Thursday, December 13, 2001 from 6:00pm - 9:00pm

WHERE:  Gatsby Social Club
                    2540 University Blvd.   (713) 874-1310

WHO:  Techxans welcome all Technology and Industry
       Executives, CEO, CIO, VP, Directors, Analysts, Consultants,
       and Business Professionals!!  Dates Are Welcome!!
       >> INVITE YOUR FRIENDS & COWORKERS <<
       >> RSVP ONLINE: www.techxans.org/signup/holidaypartysignup.htm

DRESS:  Cocktail or Business

ADMISSION:  $10.00 (Cash or Check)  - a percentage of the admission
                         will be donated to selected charity

GET:    One (1) Free Drink / Appetizer / Win Cool Door Prizes

CORPORATE SPONSOR:
 > Applied Computer Research  ( http://www.acrhq.com)

EVENT SPONSOR:
 > Southwest Bio Conference - December 4-5 @Hyatt Downtown
       ( http://www.biosouthwest.com)

MEDIA SPONSOR:
 > Houston Business Journal
       ( http://bizjournals.bcentral.com/houston/ )

DONATION BENEFITING:
 > "Variety - The Children's Charity
        ( http://www.usvariety.org/main.html )


>> About Techxans (Networking Social Host)
The purpose of Techxans is to promote networking and community
among the professionals in Houston by providing an entertaining
environments for business, technology professionals, and
entrepreneurs to build new friendships, alliances and resources.
Each month we host "Happy Hours" that further promote networking
and social activities.  Join us by registering for our mailing
& invite list. This will allow us to notify you about our events.
Click to www.Techxans.org

>> Applied Computer Research  ( Major Corporate Sponsor )
Increase Your Sales And Marketing Assets!
Since 1972, the Directory of Top Computer Executives has been
the source that computer industry marketers turn to for up-to-date IT
management information. The Directory gives you immediate access to
more than 48,000 key decision makers at over 24,000 of the largest
U.S. and Canadian IT organizations. Plus, over 1,200 new sites are
added each year.
For more information, please visit - www.acrhq.com

>> Association of Information Technology Professional ( Co-Host )
AITP offers opportunities for Information Technology (IT) leadership and
education through partnerships with industry, government and academia. AITP
provides quality IT related education, information on relevant IT issues and
forums for networking with experienced peers and other IT professionals.
For more information, please visit - www.aitphouston.org

>> Association For Women In Computing ( Co-Host )
AWC's mission is to provide for the technical professional development of
computing specialists and to provide a formidable network, which is a source
of education, expert information and career opportunities for its members.
For more information, please visit - www.awchouston.org

>> Digital Eve ( Co-Host )
Houston's resource for women interested in technology and living a digital
lifestyle! We are part of an international, non-profit women's networking
group who are here to encourage, educate and empower women of all ages,
education levels and various interests in technology and new media.
For more information, please visit - www.digitalevehouston.org

>> Greater Houston Partnership ( Co-Host )
Do you want to be part of the tech community's voice by serving
as the eyes and ears of the local technology community?
Get involved with the Emerging Business Council by contacting
Linda Flores Olson at lfloresolson@houston.org or 713-844-3682.
For more information, please visit - www.houston.org

>> Houston Java User Group ( Co-Host )
HJUG is dedicated to the use of the Java(TM) Technology and Lifestyle.
We are one of the many Java User Groups worldwide. All of the HJUG
events, study groups and meetings are FREE to all Java enthusiasts. HJUG
has been created to satisfy all the educational needs about Java for all
levels. Therefore, HJUG proposes technical meetings, business meetings,
and study groups about Java.
For more information, please visit - www.hjug.org

>> MIT Enterprise Forum of Texas ( Co-Host )
Since 1984, the MIT Enterprise Forum of Texas, based in Houston,
Texas, has offered a basic group of services, which includes professional
seminars, start-up clinics, business plan workshops, case presentations,
and networking opportunities with peers, business specialists and venture
capitalists. Most of the local events are held at the Houston Engineering
and Scientific Society (HESS) building.
For more information, please visit - www.mitforumtexas.org

>> Women In Technology International ( Co-Host )
For more than a decade, WITI has successfully provided women in
technology inspiration, education, conferences, on-line services,
publications and an exceptional worldwide network of resources.
WITI is the first and only international organization solely dedicated to
advancing women through technology.  WITI's expansion includes the
development of web-based tools, products and services, innovative
support to women entrepreneurs, early-stage ventures, education,
technology centers, and media networks.
For more information, please visit - www.witi.org

>> About Southwest Bio conference (Event Sponsor)
December 4 - 5, 2001  Hyatt Regency Downtown Houston
The Southwest BIO Venture Conference and Symposium is one of the
nation's premier biotech and health science venture events.  This two-day
event will combine a venture educational symposium with an opportunity
for linking investors and related financial organizations with select
ventures in biotechnology, healthcare services, medical devices and
life sciences.  If you have an interest in emerging companies in the
biotechnology and health science industry, you need to attend.
Visit - www.biosouthwest.com


*** If you would like to be added to future event mailings,
     please click to www.Techxans.org or send an email to
     Lisa@Techxans.org

*** If you would like to be removed from future event mailings,
     please send an email request to REMOVE@Techxans.org .

*** PLEASE FORWARD THIS EMAIL TO ALL OF YOUR FRIENDS!!

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@university.edu>
To: Daniel Lee <daniel.lee@college.edu>
Subject: RE: Interesting article on slang evolution

Daniel,

I'd be happy to take a look at your project outline! It sounds like a fascinating angle to explore. Please feel free to send it my way whenever you're ready.

As for "sus," I've definitely heard it used by my students. It's interesting to see how quickly these terms spread across different age groups and regions. I wonder if social media is the main driver or if there are other factors at play.

I look forward to seeing your outline and discussing this further!

Best,
Emily

<email>
From: Samantha Thompson <samantha.thompson@riverdalehigh.edu>
To: Alex Rutherford <alex.rutherford@earthsciences.com>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on climate change education

Hi Alex,

The Trailhead Café sounds perfect – I love that place! 2 pm works great for me. I'm really looking forward to our brainstorming session.

A field trip to a local geological site is an amazing idea! It would give students a chance to see the real-world impact of climate change and hopefully inspire them to take action. I've been thinking about how we can make the trip both educational and engaging. Maybe we could have the students collect data or samples and then analyze them back in the classroom?

I'll start looking into potential sites and any necessary permissions we might need. Let's discuss the details on Tuesday!

See you soon,
Samantha

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@recoveryguru.net>
To: Emily Nakamoto <emily.nakamoto@datachronicles.com>
Subject: RE: Book project update

Hi Emily,

Thanks for the update! I'm glad to hear that the meeting with the publisher went well. I'll take a look at the magnetic storage chapter and provide my feedback by the end of the week.

I've been doing some research on the impact of cloud computing on data storage and preservation, and I think it would make for an interesting chapter. I can start working on an outline if you'd like.

Also, I wanted to remind you that we have a podcast recording scheduled for next Tuesday. The topic is "The Future of Data Storage: Trends and Predictions." Let me know if you have any ideas for discussion points or potential interviewees.

Looking forward to your thoughts on the cloud computing chapter idea!

Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Ethan Johnson <ejohnson@orbweavers.net>
To: Samantha Harris <sharris@jumpingspiders.com>
Subject: RE: Interesting article on Salticid mimicry

Hi Sam,

Thanks for sharing that article! I've been swamped with field work lately, but I'm always eager to discuss spider communication strategies. 

It's fascinating how Salticids have evolved such complex chemical mimicry alongside their visual displays. In orb weavers, we see a lot of chemical communication in courtship and web-building, but nothing quite as elaborate as what you're describing.

I'd love to collaborate on a paper exploring the parallels and differences between chemical communication in jumping spiders and orb weavers. Maybe we could even get some funding to do a comparative study?

I'm free to chat next week if you want to brainstorm ideas.

Cheers,
Ethan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Ethan Roberts <ethan.roberts@archaeologyuniversity.edu>
To: Anjali Patel <anjali.patel@telanganahistory.org>
Subject: RE: Guest Lecture Opportunity

Dear Anjali,

Thank you for reaching out and offering to be a guest lecturer for our study abroad program in Hyderabad. We are excited about the opportunity to have you share your expertise on the Telangana movement with our students.

Your insights will be invaluable in helping our students understand the historical and cultural context of the region they will be studying. We would be happy to schedule your lecture for the second week of the program, which will be in mid-June. Please let me know if this works for you.

Additionally, we would like to invite you to join us for a guided tour of some of the archaeological sites in the area. Your knowledge of the region's history would greatly enhance our students' experience.

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns. We look forward to working with you and ensuring our students have a memorable and educational experience in Hyderabad.

Best regards,
Dr. Ethan Roberts
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jessica Summers <jsummers@piedmontschools.org>
To: Liam Patel <liam.patel@genetech.com>
Subject: New genetics curriculum - need your input!

Hey Liam,

I hope you're doing well and enjoying your new job at Genetech. It's been a while since we last touched base, and I wanted to reach out because I could really use your help with something.

I've been awarded a grant to develop a new genetics curriculum for high schools in our district, and I'm feeling both excited and overwhelmed by the task. I want to create something that's engaging and meaningful for students, but I also want to make sure it's up-to-date with the latest developments in the field.

I was wondering if you'd be willing to take a look at what I have so far and provide some feedback? I'd be especially interested in any insights you might have about the current state of genetics research and how it could be incorporated into the curriculum.

Let me know if you have any time in the next few weeks to chat or meet up. I'd be happy to treat you to coffee or lunch in exchange for your expertise!

Best,
Jessica

Subject: New stress management workshop series

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I'm reaching out to you because I'm developing a new educational workshop series on stress management and its impact on gut health. I was thinking we could have a brainstorming session next week to discuss the content and structure of the workshops. I'd love to hear your thoughts on the latest research and how we can best support our clients in making lifestyle changes that promote better gut health.

Let me know if you're interested and when you're available to meet.

Best regards,
Emily

"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/10/2001 05:15:59 PM
Please respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>
To: <jarnold@enron.com>
cc:  
Subject: try this one...


 Please read the following problem very carefully, and write in a number at
the end.  You should be ready to defend your answer.  Only a number is
allowed, not an algebraic equation.

Acquiring a Company

 In the following exercise you will represent Company A (the acquirer),
which is currently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means of
a tender offer.  You plan to tender in cash for 100% of Company T's shares
but are unsure how high a price to offer.  The main complication is this:
the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oil
exploration project it is currently undertaking.  Indeed, the very viability
of Company T depends on the exploration outcome.  If the project fails, the
company under current management will be worth nothing--$0/share.  But if
the project succeeds, the value of the company under current management
could be as high as $100/share.  All share values between $0 and $100 are
considered equally likely.  By all estimates, the company will be worth
considerably more in the hands of Company A than under current management.
In fact, whatever the ultimate value under current management, the company
will be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than under
Company T.  If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share under either
management.  If the exploration project generates a $50/share value under
current management, the value under Company A is $75/share.  Similarly, a
$100/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under Company A,
and so on.

 The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine the price
they should offer for Company T's shares.  This offer must be made now,
before the outcome of the drilling project is known.  From all indications,
Company T would be happy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at a
profitable price.  Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at all cost, the
potential of a takeover bid by any other firm.  You expect Company T to
delay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, then
accept or reject your offer before the news of the drilling results reaches
the press.

 Thus, you (Company A) will not know the results of the exploration project
when submitting your price offer, but Company T will know the results when
deciding whether or not to accept your offer.  In addition, Company T will
accept any offer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value of
the company under current management.  Thus, if you offer $50/share, for
instance, Company T will accept if the value of the company to Company T is
anything less than $50.

 As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over price offers
in the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offer at all) to
$150/share.  What price offer per share would you tender for Company T's
stock?

 $______ per/share

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@ucla.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@nyuhistorians.org>
Subject: RE: Upcoming Conference Panel

Emily,

Thank you for reaching out. I'm excited to collaborate with you on this presentation. I agree that combining our research will provide a comprehensive understanding of the economic and social factors leading to the Civil War.

Your suggestion to start by outlining the main differences between the North and the South is a great idea. We could then delve into the specific issues, such as the slave economy, industrialization, and westward expansion, and how these factors heightened tensions between the two regions.

I think it would also be valuable to discuss the role of politics in exacerbating these divisions, such as the Missouri Compromise and the Kansas-Nebraska Act.

If you're agreeable, I can start working on an outline for the presentation, focusing on the economic aspects, and you can tackle the social factors. We can then combine our work and refine it together.

Let me know if you have any other ideas or suggestions. I'm looking forward to working with you on this project.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Stevens <michael.stevens@wellness.org>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@envirotech.org>
Subject: RE: Finalizing our conference presentation

Emily,

Thank you for your email and for taking the lead on the presentation slides. I agree that incorporating personal anecdotes is a great way to make our research more relatable and engaging. I have a story about a camping trip I took with my family last summer that I think would be perfect for the presentation. I'll draft up a short version and send it your way for feedback.

I also had an idea for a interactive activity we could do with the audience during the presentation. Since our research emphasizes the importance of spending time in nature, we could have attendees pair up and share their favorite outdoor activities or memories. This could help reinforce our message and create a more memorable experience for everyone.

Let me know what you think about this idea, and if you have any other suggestions for making our presentation even more impactful. I'm looking forward to seeing our hard work come to fruition at the conference!

Best,
Michael

From: anchordesk_daily@anchordesk.zdlists.com

Subject: Join me for my dinner with Bill Gates, part 2: The Q&A
Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

_____________________DAVID COURSEY_____________________

JOIN ME FOR MY DINNER WITH BILL GATES, PART 2: THE Q&A

    When I and 14 other journalists joined Microsoft's
         chairman for a private dinner after the Windows
         XP launch, he had a lot to say. In the second
         installment of this two-part story, Bill
         speaks out on XP's controversial activation
         technology, the company's upcoming tablet
         PC, wireless standards, and more.

http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1029/2820604:8593142


#


_____________________NEWS ANALYSIS_____________________

Patrick Houston

    SEND IN THE REBATES! APPLE HOPING TO BOOST INTEREST IN IMACS

    Apple is hardly immune from the slowdown
    in hardware sales--and now we're seeing
    the rebates to prove it. The company
    is giving cash back--or free toys--to
    anyone who buys its computers from now
    through December, borrowing a tactic
    from its PC-selling brethren. But is
    it too little, too late?

     PLUS:

     MICROSOFT RETURNS TO THE WEB BROWSER BATTLEFIELD

     SLASHDOT TO JOIN THE FOR-PAY CONTENT CROWD

http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1029/2820605:8593142





_____________________EXPERT ADVICE_____________________


David Berlind

  WHERE'S THE BEEF? AUDIENCES TIRED OF CEOS' EMPTY
  RHETORIC

   At a recent tech conference, Microsoft's
         Steve Ballmer and Sun's Scott McNealy played
         up the jokes, while HP's Carly Fiorina stuck
         to business. Can you guess who won the crowd's
         favor? David finds out that technology execs
         crave substance, not style.


http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1029/2820539:8593142


			> > > > >


Larry Dignan

  HOW CITRIX IS SHAKING OFF WORRIES OF A MICROSOFT
  INVASION

   Despite talk that Microsoft will encroach
         on its turf, software maker Citrix continues
         to deliver strong results. What's its secret?
         Larry explains why Citrix is one of the few
         companies that has been able to dance successfully
         with this 800-pound gorilla.


http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1029/2820527:8593142


			> > > > >


Preston Gralla

  NO THANKS, BILL. TRY 3 NON-MICROSOFT WAYS TO MANAGE
  PASSWORDS

   Sure, it's a pain trying to remember your username
         and password for the numerous Web sites you
         visit each day, but Microsoft's new Passport
         service is not the only solution. Preston
         digs up three programs that store and manage
         passwords--with no involvement from Redmond.



http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1029/2820525:8593142


			> > > > >


_____________________CRUCIAL CLICKS_____________________
Make sure you see these features on ZDNet today!

IS YOUR ASP REALLY MANAGING YOUR APPS?
http://www.zdnet.com/techupdate/stories/main/0,14179,2818244,00.html


CRM VENDORS DON'T WALK THE TALK
http://chkpt.zdnet.com/chkpt/adeskclicks/www.zdnet.com/techupdate/stories/main/0,14179,2819695,00.html

http://chkpt.zdnet.com/chkpt/adeskclicks/www.zdnet.com/products/stories/overview/0,8826,538007,00.html

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@hillcountrycommunitycenter.org>
To: Michael Rodriguez <michael.rodriguez@hillcountrycommunitycenter.org>
Subject: Solar Eclipse Event Collaboration

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! As you know, the community center is planning a special event to celebrate the upcoming solar eclipse. I think this is a fantastic opportunity for our history and science departments to collaborate and create something truly memorable for our community.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in meeting to discuss ideas for incorporating historical elements into the event. I think it would be fascinating to explore how eclipses have been viewed and interpreted by different cultures throughout history, particularly in the context of Texas-Mexico relations.

Please let me know if you have any initial thoughts or suggestions. I'm excited to work together on this!

Best regards,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Rahul Reddy <rahul.reddy@telanganauniversity.edu.in>
To: Nandini Patnaik <nandini.patnaik@odishauniversity.edu.in>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Nandini,

Thanks for your prompt response. I'm glad you're on board with the collaboration. Your suggestion to structure the paper around key historical events and movements sounds perfect. We can certainly draw interesting parallels between Telangana and Odisha.

Next week works well for me. How about Tuesday, 4:30 PM? I can set up a Zoom call. Please feel free to suggest another time if that doesn't suit you.

I've attached a few papers I thought might be relevant to our discussion. I'd be grateful if you could take a look and let me know your thoughts.

Looking forward to our call.

Cheers,
Rahul

Meeting dates and times are subject to change without notice. For current information, you can go to our website at www.capitolconnection.org  for a link to the FERC's page (you may need to Refresh your browser for the most current information to appear)  or you can go to the FERC's web page at www.ferc.gov  The FERC Office of the Secretary can be reached at 202.208.0400.
If you have an annual subscription to the Capitol Connection internet service, these meetings are included in the annual fee.  Please contact us if you are interested in signing up for either of these meetings or want to get an annual subscription to our internet service.
The Capitol Connection offers FERC meetings live via the Internet, as well as via phone bridge, and satellite, please visit our website at www.capitolconnection.org  or send e-mail to capcon@gmu.edu for more information. If there is a meeting you are interested in receiving, please call 703-993-3100.
Sincerely,
David Reininger

_____________________DAVID COURSEY_____________________

GRAB A SEAT, AND JOIN ME FOR MY DINNER WITH BILL GATES

    On the eve of Windows XP's launch, I joined
         14 other journalists for a private dinner
         with the chairman and chief software architect
         of Microsoft.  We had one thing in common: When
         Bill talks, we write about it. And on this night
         he was talking, and just to us. Here's part
         one of what Bill had to say.

http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1026/2820297:8593142


#


_____________________NEWS ANALYSIS_____________________

Patrick Houston

    WILL THE PATRIOT ANTI-TERRORIST BILL BETRAY US?

    A new anti-terrorism law, which significantly
    expands law enforcement powers, is
    speeding into law. So now we'll see:
    Whether Congress, with our assent,
    acted wisely or whether we allowed fear
    to lead us astray.

     PLUS:

      HEY, DON'T OVERLOOK THIS: NEW LINUX

Greg Shultz

http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1026/2820306:8593142


			> > > > >


David Berlind

  SERIOUS ABOUT SECURITY? BETTER DOUBLE YOUR OPTIONS

         element, such as an ID card, and the solution's

         the difficulties--of two-factor security.

Mr. Nowlan:

When we spoke several days ago, I had mentioned the meeting between Jeff 
Shankman and Larry Kellner, CFO, at Continental Airlines.  The meeting had 
been scheduled for December 11th, 2-3 PM in EB 3321.  I will know tomorrow if 
this date is confirmed.  Following our phone conversation, I did follow up 
with the persons you suggested -- Larry Gagliardi, Douglas Friedman and Mark 
Tawney -- as I completed an overview of our initiatives with Continental.

The meeting on December 11th will enable Enron and Continental to continue 
discussions on three initiatives listed in order of economic value:  (1) fuel 
management, (2) weather derivatives, and (3) plastics hedging -- VaR 
analysis.  

In order to verify attendees at this meeting, Jennifer Burns suggested that I 
follow up with you.  Please note the Continental attendees listed below.  Did 
you want to have the same origination team at the meeting or others?  I look 
forward to your response so I can coordinate with them and confirm their 
attendance.  Continental had requested that we keep the Enron attendance to 3 
or 4 persons; they will do the same.

Meeting Attendees from Continental Airlines:

Ron Howard, Vice President, Food Services
Larry Kellner, Chief Financial Officer
Greg Hartford, Vice President, Fuel Management Company
Jeff Misner, Vice President and Treasurer (tentative)


We appreciate your suggestions.
Thank-you.

Sarah-Joy Hunter
Enron Corporation
Global Strategic Sourcing
Business Development
#(713)-345-6541

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Davis <edavis@university.edu>
To: Alex Johnson <ajohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on cache memory optimization project

Dear Alex,

Thank you for reaching out. I am glad to hear that you are finding the concepts from our course applicable to your project on cache memory optimization. It is an interesting and challenging problem, and I would be happy to provide some guidance.

In terms of mathematical modeling, I suggest you start by breaking down the problem into smaller, more manageable components. Consider the various factors that influence cache performance, such as cache size, block size, and replacement policies. You may find that techniques like Markov chains or queuing theory could be useful in modeling these aspects of the system.

I would be happy to meet with you to discuss your project further. How about we schedule a meeting for next Tuesday at 3 pm in my office? Please let me know if this works for you.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Davis

Sent:	Monday, July 23, 2001 1:03 PM
To:	Allen, Phillip K.; Grigsby, Mike
Cc:	Presto, Kevin M.; Tholan, Scott; Turner, Nancy
Subject:	El Paso Update 7/23/011


Sources at OPS indicate that once OPS completes its review of line 1110 and approves it to come back online, there is no formal process to grant El Paso permission to bring the entire system back to full capacity at 1.1 bcf/d. Therefore, once the inspection/repairs are completed by El Paso, the company will seek permission from OPS to resume to full service. OPS would probably grant them approval within a matter of days. The uncertainty still lies in the time it will take to interpret pigging data and for OPS to conduct its review.
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@harboruniversity.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@harborhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Questions about the Pilgrim Fathers and the Mayflower voyage

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out and sharing your thoughts. I appreciate your engagement with the course material and your desire to understand the historical context from various perspectives.

I would be more than happy to meet with you to discuss your questions and concerns further. Understanding the impact of the Pilgrim Fathers' journey on indigenous populations and systems of inequality is an important aspect of studying history.

As for recommended readings, I suggest looking into "The Invasion of America" by Francis Jennings and "Mayflower" by Nathaniel Philbrick. Both books offer a different perspective on the events surrounding the Pilgrim Fathers and the Mayflower voyage.

Please let me know when you're available to meet, and we can continue our discussion in person.

Best regards,
Dr. Michael Thompson

<email>
From: John Smith <j.smith@historybuffs.org>
To: Sarah Thompson <sarah.t@mathwhiz.net>
Subject: Collaborating on history-math puzzles

Dear Sarah,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking about our recent discussion at the history club meeting about combining history and mathematics in puzzles. I believe we could create something truly unique and engaging for both our club members and a wider audience.

I have a vast collection of historical anecdotes and obscure records that could serve as the foundation for our puzzles. If you're interested, we could meet to brainstorm ideas and discuss how to incorporate your expertise in trigonometry and geometry.

Please let me know your thoughts and if you'd like to collaborate on this project.

Best regards,
John

body:
<email>
From: David Lee <dlee@university.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on the new STEM outreach course

Dear Emily,

I fully agree with the learning objectives you've outlined – they provide a clear and comprehensive foundation for the students to build upon. I believe that by achieving these objectives, we will have created a successful and impactful course.

I appreciate your offer to take the lead on the programming component, and I would be happy to focus on the chemistry side of things. This division of labor will allow us to create a well-rounded and cohesive course that effectively combines our expertise.

As we move forward with the course development, I suggest we schedule regular meetings to discuss our progress, share ideas, and ensure that the programming and chemistry components are well-integrated. I believe that our collaboration and shared vision for this course will result in a unique and engaging learning experience for the students.

Thank you for your enthusiasm and dedication to this project. I'm excited to work together and create something truly special for these young learners.

Best regards,
David

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@dentaltech.com>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@sunshineprimary.co.uk>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on dental health educational materials

Hi Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm thrilled that you found my presentation helpful and that you're interested in collaborating on educational materials for your students. I absolutely love the idea of making dental health fun and engaging for kids.

I'd be more than happy to meet up with you to discuss this project further. My schedule is quite flexible at the moment, so just let me know when works best for you. Perhaps we could meet at the community center again or grab a coffee somewhere?

I look forward to working with you on this exciting project!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Maria Ramirez <maria.ramirez@newmexicouniversity.edu>
To: John Smith <john.smith@texasuniversity.edu>
Subject: RE: Upcoming AHA Conference

Dear John,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm thrilled to hear that you'll be presenting at the conference as well. Your paper on 19th-century Texas-Mexico border disputes sounds fascinating, and I completely agree that our research areas overlap significantly.

I would love to meet up at the conference to discuss our work and explore potential collaborations. Perhaps we could even propose a joint panel for next year's conference.

I look forward to seeing you in Chicago!

Best,
Maria

Subject: RE: Earth Day Event Ideas

Hey Liam,

Great idea on the food vendors! I'll reach out to some of the local places and see if they're interested. A few of them have been very supportive of our community events in the past.

I'll send over the draft flyers and social media graphics by early next week for you to review. I'm also going to create a sign-up form for the kids who want to participate in the performances and research presentations.

Thanks for handling the park permits and rain date! I'll make sure to include that info on the promotional materials.

I'll be out of town next week for a family wedding, but I'll be available by email if you need anything. I'll make sure to have everything ready before I leave.

Looking forward to seeing this event come together! It's going to be such a great experience for the kids and the community.

Best,
Jenna

body:
<email>
From: Ethan Faulkner <ethanf@college.edu>
To: Amelia Novak <amnovak@university.edu>
Subject: Re: Collaborative paper - final revisions

Amelia,

That's fantastic news about the keynote invitation! I would be honored to join you as a co-presenter at the conference. It's a wonderful opportunity to showcase our work and engage with the broader academic community.

I agree that the latest draft of our paper is in good shape, but I think we could still strengthen the conclusion by tying our findings more explicitly to the broader debates in the field. Perhaps we could highlight how our work contributes to the ongoing scholarly conversation about the role of religious institutions in shaping scientific discourse during this period.

On a personal note, I wanted to thank you for all your support and encouragement throughout this project. Balancing research and family life can be challenging, but knowing that I have a colleague like you in my corner makes all the difference.

Let me know when you're available to discuss our conference presentation in more detail. I'm excited to get started!

Best,
Ethan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Reynolds <emily.reynolds@university.edu>
To: Olivia Nguyen <olivia.nguyen@student.university.edu>
Subject: RE: Help with understanding waves and sound

Hi Olivia,

I remember you from class! It's great that you reached out for help. Waves and sound can be tricky concepts to grasp, but I'm happy to provide some resources that might help.

First, I recommend checking out the Khan Academy videos on waves and sound. They have some great visualizations that can help make the concepts more clear:
https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/waves

I also have some practice problems with solutions that I can share with you. Let me know if you'd like me to send those over.

Feel free to reply with any specific questions you have, and I'll do my best to help!

Best,
Dr. Reynolds

<email>
From: Haruki Sato <haruki.sato@kyotomuseum.org>
To: Akiko Nakamura <akiko.nakamura@kyotomuseum.org>
Subject: RE: Exhibition progress update

Dear Akiko,

Your suggestion to add a workshop focused on the cultural significance of motifs in Japanese art is brilliant. This interactive element will provide our visitors with a unique opportunity to engage with the art on a deeper level. I will reach out to a few local artists and art historians to see if they would be interested in leading this workshop.

As we approach the final stages of preparation, I want to express my gratitude for your invaluable contributions to this project. Your expertise and dedication have been instrumental in creating an exhibition that will undoubtedly leave a lasting impact on our visitors.

Please let me know if there is anything else I can do to support you in the coming weeks.

Best regards,
Haruki

"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls


Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austin
that we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this project
should produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.
This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong as
Austin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range for
this market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that we
have uncovered to date in the Austin market.
The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  As
it is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austin
for preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be complete
in less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severe
water treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lot
improvement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in North
Austin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and street
widening.  Even though this property is not likely to require street
widening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pond
requirement, I used this data to be cautious.
 The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is not
expected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quite
successful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as the
adjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.
As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoods
is uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but may
only put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are far
preferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyer
preferences.
The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 and
an extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved site
plan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close into
an A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.
This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in the
profits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discuss
having you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entity
with your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a
1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is a
rental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would then
be the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with an
exchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in San
Antonio if you do not know anyone.
I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,
by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.
Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want to
schedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon as
your schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at any
time.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either
512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is
512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with you
on this project that is sure to be a major winner.
I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusual
events these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpg
downdrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.
One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled to
start the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enough
to knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it took
another week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to take
my wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebra
in her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden this
past week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realize
the enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks as
if she will be ok in the long run.
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC


 - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

body:
<email>
From: Sam Johnson <sam.johnson@plan9dev.com>
To: Alex Martinez <alex.martinez@neteng.com>
Subject: RE: Plan 9 and Unix integration advice

Alex,

Great to hear from you! I'm glad you reached out about this. I'd be happy to help in any way I can.

I remember the project I worked on a few years ago quite well. The biggest challenge was getting the two systems to communicate effectively, especially when it came to system calls and process management. I can share some of the strategies we used to overcome those hurdles.

I'm free for a call later this week if you'd like to discuss the specifics of your project. Just let me know what day and time work best for you.

On a separate note, I noticed you mentioned a recent hiking trip. I'm an avid hiker myself! I'd love to hear more about where you went and any recommendations you might have. I'm always on the lookout for new trails to explore.

Looking forward to catching up and helping out with your project!

Best,
Sam

To: Jonathan Evans <jonathan.evans@quakerhistory.org>
Subject: Draft of our article on sun safety history

Hi Jonathan,

I hope you're doing well! I've finished the first draft of our article on the history of sun safety and skin cancer prevention. I've attached it here for your review. I tried to incorporate the Quaker perspective on health and wellness that we discussed.

Let me know what you think and if you have any suggestions for improvements. I'm looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@email.com>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@email.com>
Subject: Great meeting you at the astronomy club!

Hi Emily,

It was great to meet you at the astronomy club meeting last night. I really enjoyed your presentation on the historical impact of celestial events on urban development. As someone who is passionate about space exploration and planetary science, I found your perspective fascinating.

I was particularly intrigued by your insights on how advancements in space technology have influenced urban development throughout history. It's a topic I've been thinking about a lot lately, and I'd love to continue our conversation.

If you're interested, I'd be happy to share some of the latest updates on the Cassini mission and the scientific discoveries that have come out of it. I think you might find it relevant to your work on historical disasters and urban transformation.

Let me know if you'd like to chat more about this or if you have any other ideas for collaboration. I'm always excited to connect with people who share my interests.

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@ridgewoodhigh.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@ridgewoodhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: New project idea - Vocab and Physics

Hi Emily,

I love the idea! I think it's a great way to get students to think about physics concepts in a new and creative way, and it's a perfect opportunity for them to expand their vocabulary at the same time. I'm definitely on board to collaborate with you on this project.

I was thinking we could have the students work in small groups and give them a list of physics concepts and vocabulary words to choose from. That way, they can collaborate and bounce ideas off each other, and we can make sure that each group is working on a different concept and set of words.

We could also have them present their stories or poems to the class and explain how they incorporated the physics concept and vocabulary words. That would give them a chance to practice their presentation skills and get feedback from their peers.

Let me know what you think about these ideas, and we can start planning out the details of the project. I'm excited to work on this with you!

Best,
Michael
label: research

Hi Emily,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out and see if you had any availability for an extra tutoring session this week. I have a big test coming up on Friday and I'm feeling pretty nervous about it. I've been working hard to understand the material, but I think I could really benefit from some extra help going over the concepts that will be on the test. 

If you have any time available, I would really appreciate it. Please let me know and I can work around your schedule. 

Thanks so much for all your help so far, it's made a big difference for me in chemistry class.

Best,
Jamie

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@university.edu>
To: Robert Thompson <robert.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: Environmental Justice course collaboration

Hi Robert,

I hope you're doing well! As you know, the department has asked us to co-teach the new Environmental Justice course next semester. I'm really excited about this opportunity to work together and bring our different perspectives to the course.

I've been thinking about how we can structure the course to incorporate both theoretical foundations and applied learning. I'd love to hear your thoughts on this, as well as your ideas for specific topics and readings we could include.

I'm also wondering if we could set up a time to meet and discuss our plans in more detail. I'm free next Wednesday afternoon if that works for you.

Looking forward to working with you on this!

Best,
Emily

Hi Alex,

It's great to hear from you! I completely agree that our areas of expertise could be a great fit for a collaborative project. The idea of drafting a proposal for an international treaty on the sustainable use of space and Earth's resources sounds fascinating and timely.

X-Origin: Allen-P

Jacques,

The agreement looks fine.   My only comment is that George and Larry might 
object to the language that "the bank that was requested to finance the 
construction of the project declined to make the loan based on the high costs 
of the construction of the Project".   Technically, that bank lowered the 
loan amount based on lower estimates of rents which altered the amount of 
equity that would be required. 

Did I loan them $1,300,000?  I thought it was less.

Regarding Exhibit A, the assets include:  the land, architectural plans, 
engineering completed, appraisal, and soils study.   Most of these items are 
in a state of partial completion by the consultants.  I have been speaking 
directly to the architect, engineer, and soils engineer.   I am unclear on 
what is the best way to proceed with these consultants.  

The obligations should include the fees owed to the consultants above.  Do we 
need to list balances due or just list the work completed as an asset  and 
give consideration of $5,875 for the cash paid to the engineer and appraisor.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Alex Chen <alex.chen@oakvilleschools.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@ridgemontschools.org>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Emily,

Thanks so much for reaching out! I'm excited to have connected with another teacher who is interested in integrating coding into math and science education. Your presentation on using spreadsheets to model exponential growth was really thought-provoking - I can definitely see how that could be adapted for use in my own classes.

I'd be happy to share some of the materials I've been using to teach coding concepts in my science classes. I've attached a couple of lesson plans that use Scratch to simulate different ecological relationships, like predator-prey dynamics and food webs. I've found that starting with these concrete, real-world examples helps students understand why coding and computational thinking are useful skills to have.

I'm also working on developing a series of activities that use Python to analyze and visualize data from our school's weather station. I'm still refining the curriculum, but I'm hoping to pilot it with my 8th graders next month. I'll keep you posted on how it goes!

I'd love to take you up on your offer to visit your school sometime. I'm actually going to be in the Ridgemont area for a conference in a couple of months. Maybe we could arrange for me to come by and do a guest lesson or activity with your students while I'm there?

Let me know what you think, and feel free to reach out anytime if you have any other questions or ideas to share.

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Gregory Howell <ghowell@botanyuniversity.edu>
To: Emily Hartley <ehartley@healthsciencewriting.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking expertise for an article on medicinal plants

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out, and please forgive my delayed response. I appreciate Dr. Thompson's recommendation and would be happy to assist you with your article series on medicinal plants.

Your timing is perfect, as I've recently published a paper on the reproduction and life cycles of plants with potential medicinal properties. I believe this information could be valuable for your work.

Please feel free to schedule a call at your convenience, and I'll be glad to share my insights with you. Additionally, I can provide you with relevant research papers and resources to support your articles.

I look forward to our collaboration and the opportunity to contribute to your important work.

Best regards,
Dr. Gregory Howell

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Ethan Wong <ethan.wong@diseaseprevention.org>
To: Olivia Green <olivia.green@treesforfuture.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from the Environmental Health Conference

Hi Olivia,

Tuesday at 2pm EST works for me. I'll keep an eye out for your calendar invite.

I think presenting at the Sustainable Forestry Conference is a great idea. It would be an excellent platform to share our work and get feedback from experts in the field. I'm happy to take the lead on putting together the proposal if you'd like.

In the meantime, I'll start gathering some data on Hantavirus cases in areas with different levels of forestry management. I think that could be a compelling piece of evidence for our presentation.

Looking forward to our call on Tuesday.

Best,
Ethan

body:
<email>
From: Rajesh Patel <rajesh.patel@telanganahistory.org>
To: Nusrat Ahmed <nusrat.ahmed@bangladeshstudies.net>
Subject: Request for Feedback on Telangana Movement Chapter

Dear Nusrat,

I hope this email finds you well. I am reaching out to you because I am currently working on a book about the Telangana movement, and I have just completed a chapter that I believe would benefit greatly from your insights.

The chapter focuses on the role of nationalism in the Telangana movement and draws parallels to other regional nationalist movements in South Asia. Given your expertise in the evolution and complexities of nationalism in Bangladesh, I would be incredibly grateful if you could take the time to review the chapter and provide your feedback.

If you are willing to help, I can send you the chapter draft by the end of this week. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Best regards,
Rajesh
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Marcus Patel <mpatel@healthbridge.org>
To: Dr. Evelyn Stewart <estewart@paleouniverse.com>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference and joint presentation

Dear Dr. Stewart,

Thank you for reaching out. It's a pleasure to make your acquaintance, and I'm equally excited about our joint presentation. The topic is fascinating, and I believe our combined expertise will lead to a thought-provoking discussion.

Sharing a room is a great idea. It will give us more opportunities to brainstorm and refine our presentation. Plus, it'll be nice to have some company in the evenings after the conference activities.

I have a confession to make – I'm a bit of a dinosaur enthusiast. As a child, I watched "Jurassic Park" countless times and dreamed of being a paleontologist. It's a pleasure to have the opportunity to work with someone who's made that dream a reality.

I look forward to meeting you in Cusco and embarking on this intellectual adventure together.

Best regards,
Marcus
label: research

Joe:
I just wanted to run this past you...
John
---------------------- Forwarded by John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 09/27/2000 12:05 
PM ---------------------------
To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Joseph Deffner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tim DeSpain/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Re:  

John:

I don't mind cleaning up their books at quarter end.  However,at year end I 
will want to keep the debt off of my books.  As we approach year-end this 
year could you please coordinate with Joe Deffner so that we take advantage 
of the margin lines we have available in order to minimize the debt on our 
books.

Thanks,

Ben



John Arnold
09/26/2000 07:12 PM
To: Ben F Glisan/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: 

Ben:
Jeff Shankman gave me your name.  I have assumed Jeff's old responsibilities 
as head of the natural gas derivatives trading group.  Our broker, EDF MAN, 
supplies us with $50 million of margin financing every night.  They are 
trying to clean up their books for end of quarter and/or year on Sep 30.  
They have asked if we can post the $50 million overnight on the 30th.  We did 
this last year as well.   Please advise,
John

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 10/03/2000 
04:30 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 10/03/2000 06:35:56 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate


Westgate

Enclosed are demographics on the Westgate site from Investor's Alliance.
Investor's Alliance says that these demographics are similar to the package
on San Marcos that you received earlier.
If there are any other questions or information requirements, let me know.
Then, let me know your interest level in the Westgate project?

San Marcos
The property across the street from the Sagewood units in San Marcos is for
sale and approved for 134 units.  The land is selling for $2.50 per square
foot as it is one of only two remaining approved multifamily parcels in West
San Marcos, which now has a moratorium on development.

Several new studies we have looked at show that the rents for our duplexes
and for these new units are going to be significantly higher, roughly $1.25
per square foot if leased for the entire unit on a 12-month lease and
$1.30-$1.40 psf if leased on a 12-month term, but by individual room.  This
property will have the best location for student housing of all new
projects, just as the duplexes do now.

If this project is of serious interest to you, please let me know as there
is a very, very short window of opportunity.  The equity requirement is not
yet known, but it would be likely to be $300,000 to secure the land.  I will
know more on this question later today.

Sincerely,

George W. Richards
President, Creekside Builders, LLC


 - winmail.dat

body:
<email>
From: Jamie Thompson <jamie.thompson@scienceworld.com>
To: Alex Petrov <alex.petrov@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Alex,

Thanks so much for your email and for sending along your paper. I really enjoyed our chat as well and found your research totally fascinating. I'd love to learn more about what you and your team are working on, so I'll definitely take you up on that offer to visit your lab sometime. 

I'm also going to be writing a follow-up piece to the article I wrote about the conference, and I'd love to feature some of your work. Would you be open to answering a few more questions over email or Skype? I think my readers would be really interested in learning more about the implications of your research for understanding earthquake hazards.

Looking forward to staying in touch,
Jamie

body:
<email>
From: Thomas Martin <thomas.martin@riverviewcc.edu>
To: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@riverviewcc.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on integrating classical literature into electronics curriculum

Emily,

I'm delighted to hear from you and am thrilled by your interest in incorporating classical literature into your electronics curriculum. I firmly believe that the themes and lessons from works like the Aeneid can be applied to various fields and can greatly benefit students' problem-solving and critical thinking skills.

I would be more than happy to collaborate with you on this exciting venture. In fact, I have a few ideas in mind already! For instance, we could explore the theme of "innovation and tradition" by analyzing how Aeneas balances honoring tradition with embracing new ideas and technologies. This could tie in nicely with the concept of technological advancements in the electronics field.

I'm available to meet next week on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning. Please let me know which time works best for you, and we can further discuss our plans for this cross-disciplinary project.

Looking forward to working together,
Thomas
label: research

From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: michael.gapinski@painewebber.com
Subject: RE: Buying back calls
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: "Michael Gapinski" <michael.gapinski@painewebber.com> @ ENRON
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Jun2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Michael:
Thanks for putting the paperwork together.  

I would have interest in meeting if you can present unique investment 
opportunities that I don't have access to now.  Most of my contact with 
financial advisors in the past has consisted of them suggesting a mutual 
fund, telling me to invest in Home Depot, Sun, and Coke, or trying to pass 
off their banks' biased research reports as something valuable.  The above 
services provide no value to me personally.  If you can present opportunities 
such as access to private equity or hedge funds, or other ideas with strong 
growth potential and low correlation to the S@P, I'd listen.

John





"Michael Gapinski" <michael.gapinski@painewebber.com> on 02/21/2001 08:23:04 
AM
To: "'John.Arnold@enron.com'" <John.Arnold@enron.com>
cc: "'Rafael Herrera'" <rafael.herrera@painewebber.com>

John -

We'll get the paperwork together and sent to you for naked options.  At some 
point, I'd like to talk about the diversification strategy in more detail -- 
perhaps over dinner or a quick meeting after the markets close?

Michael Gapinski

Sent: Tuesday, February 20, 2001 10:14 PM
To: michael.gapinski@painewebber.com
Subject: Re: Buying back calls


Michael:
Appreciate the idea.  However, with my natural long, I'm not looking to
really trade around the position.  I believe ENE will continue to be range
bound, but in case it is not, I don't want to forgo 50% of my option
premium.
I have price targets of where I would like to lighten up exposure to ENE
and will use calls to implement the stategy.  To that regards, I noticed I
was not approved to sell naked calls.  I would like that ability in order
to hedge some exposure I have of unexercised vested options.  Please look
into that for me.
John.




"Michael Gapinski" <michael.gapinski@painewebber.com> on 02/20/2001
06:28:27 PM

To:   "'Arnold, John'" <john.arnold@enron.com>
cc:
Subject:  Buying back calls


John -

I was looking at the recent pullback in ENE and thinking it might be an
opportunity to buy back the calls you sold.  Of course, you would then be
in a position to sell calls again if the stock makes a bounce.  I'm not
sure that ENE @ 75 is the place, but maybe @ 73.  Call me if you're
interested.

Michael Gapinski

Emery Financial Group

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Russo <mrusso@oakwood.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Chen <echen@oakwood.edu>
Subject: RE: Syllabus for CHEM/SOC 101

Emily,

Thank you for sharing the syllabus. I appreciate the thoroughness of your outline and the clear connections you've made between the scientific concepts and their real-world applications.

As I was reviewing the syllabus, I had a few thoughts on how we could incorporate more social studies and civic engagement elements into the course. I'd like to see if we can find ways to encourage students to critically examine the societal implications of the scientific advancements we'll be discussing, and to consider their own roles and responsibilities as citizens in relation to these issues.

For example, we could include case studies or discussion prompts that ask students to evaluate the ethical and social implications of certain scientific discoveries or technologies. We could also invite guest speakers from various fields (e.g., policy makers, activists, industry professionals) to share their perspectives and engage in dialogue with the students.

I'm happy to discuss these ideas further and work with you to revise the syllabus accordingly. Please let me know your thoughts!

Best,
Michael

Traveling to have a business meeting takes the fun out of the trip.  
Especially if you have to prepare a presentation.  I would suggest holding 
the business plan meetings here then take a trip without any formal business 
meetings.  I would even try and get some honest opinions on whether a trip is 
even desired or necessary.

As far as the business meetings, I think it would be more productive to try 
and stimulate discussions across the different groups about what is working 
and what is not.  Too often the presenter speaks and the others are quiet 
just waiting for their turn.   The meetings might be better if held in a 
round table discussion format.  

My suggestion for where to go is Austin.  Play golf and rent a ski boat and 
jet ski's.  Flying somewhere takes too much time.

Subject: RE: New Io data

Hi Samira,

Congratulations on securing the grant for the Jupiter mission! That's fantastic news, and I would be thrilled to join the team. Your project aligns perfectly with my research interests, and I believe I could make a significant contribution to the mission's success.

I'm looking forward to our call tomorrow to discuss both the Rome presentation and the new mission. Let's plan on meeting at 2 PM my time (EST), which should be 7 PM for you in Rome, if that works.

See you then!

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@nih.gov>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@who.int>
Subject: RE: Upcoming webinar and publication update

Emily,

Thanks for the update. The webinar date and time work well for me. I'll check with my calendar and get back to you if anything changes. Your speaker suggestions sound great, and I don't have any other names to add at the moment.

I've reviewed the revised sections of our publication, and I think they look much stronger. I made a few minor edits and suggestions, which I've attached to this email. Overall, I believe we're on track to submit this soon.

That's fantastic news about your contacts at the World Bank. A large-scale intervention study would be a significant undertaking, but I think it's a crucial next step in our research. Please keep me updated on the meeting, and let me know if there's anything I can do to help prepare.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Liam Thompson <liam.t@institute.org>
To: Sophia Russo <sophiar@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the conference!

Sophia,

This is fantastic news! I'm over the moon that our proposal was accepted. It's a testament to the hard work we've put in and the strength of our collaborative vision.

I've already started making arrangements for your visit to Mount Etna. My team is excited to meet you and learn from your expertise. I'll be in touch soon with more details on travel and accommodation.

I'm eager to hear your ideas for the preliminary data analysis. Your insights have been invaluable so far, and I'm confident that together we'll create a robust comparative framework for our study.

Thank you for your kind words and for being an incredible partner in this endeavor. I feel fortunate to have met you and to have the opportunity to work alongside such a brilliant and dedicated scientist.

Looking forward to our continued collaboration and to making some groundbreaking discoveries together!

Warmest regards,
Liam

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Liang Wei <wei.liang@oxford.edu>
To: Alice Thompson <athompson@olemiss.edu>
Subject: RE: Inquiry regarding the twenty-four solar terms and William Faulkner

Dear Alice,

Thank you for reaching out, and congratulations on your fascinating research topic! I am delighted to learn about your work on the influence of Chinese philosophy on Faulkner's writing, and I would be happy to share my insights on the twenty-four solar terms and their potential symbolic significance.

Your focus on the "eternal return" and the cyclical nature of the seasons resonates with the core principles of the solar terms, which divide the year into 24 periods based on the sun's position and the lunar calendar. Each solar term represents a distinct phase in the seasonal cycle and is associated with specific agricultural and cultural practices.

I would be particularly interested in discussing the ways in which Faulkner may have engaged with these ideas, either directly or indirectly, and how they might manifest in his use of seasonal imagery and themes. Perhaps we could explore the connection between the solar terms and the structure of some of his works, such as the cyclical narrative in "The Sound and the Fury."

I am also intrigued by the possibility of co-authoring a paper or presenting at a conference together, as our research interests seem to complement each other nicely. Please let me know if you would like to discuss this further.

I look forward to our continued exchange and the insights we may uncover together.

Best regards,
Liang Wei

body:
<email>
From: Hiroshi Nakamura <nakamura.hiroshi@japanese-university.ac.jp>
To: Samantha Nguyen <samantha.nguyen@caltech.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting new research opportunity

Samantha,

It's wonderful to hear from you! Congratulations on securing the grant for such an important project. I'm honored that you thought of me for the team.

The timing is perfect, as I've been wanting to dive deeper into the connection between climate change and volcanic activity. The opportunity to collaborate with you and other top researchers in the field is too good to pass up.

Please do send over the full research proposal. I'd love to see the details of what you have in mind. From what you've described, this project has the potential to make a real difference in understanding and mitigating the impacts of climate change on vulnerable communities.

I'm excited to discuss this further and explore how I can contribute to the project. Let me know when you're available for a call to talk more.

Best,
Hiroshi

I've been thinking more about your advice for my TED Talk and have been trying to incorporate more storytelling and relatable examples. I've attached the latest draft of my script if you have a chance to take a look and let me know what you think.

body:
<email>
From: Emily <emily.smith@medstudent.com>
To: Alex <alex.smith@springfieldhigh.edu>
Subject: Help with studying?

Hey Alex,

I hope you're doing well and that your classes are going great! I was wondering if you might be able to help me out with something. I'm currently taking a course on patient assessment in medical school, and I'm finding some of the physiological concepts a bit challenging. I was hoping you might be able to help me create a study guide or some visual aids to make the information a bit easier to grasp. I know you're great at breaking down complex topics!

In return, I'd be more than happy to help you out with anything you need for your U.S. history class. I remember how much I struggled with the 13 colonies when I was in high school, and I'd love to help you create some engaging activities for your students, especially any who might be struggling with the material.

Let me know if you're up for a little sibling brainstroming session! I'm free this weekend if you are.

Best,
Emily
label: research
