To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@countyhealth.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise on childhood environmental health

Hi Michael,

Thank you so much for your prompt response and willingness to collaborate. I really appreciate your enthusiasm and expertise.

Tuesday afternoon works perfectly for me. How about we schedule a call for 2 PM EST? I'll send you a Zoom link closer to the date.

In the meantime, I'll put together some initial thoughts and materials to share with you, so we can make the most of our conversation.

Thanks again, Michael. I'm looking forward to working together on this important initiative.

Best regards,
Emily

anything bullish can happen'





slafontaine@globalp.com on 02/08/2001 05:28:02 AM
To: jarnold@enron.com
cc:  
Subject: EarthSAT UPDATE



thats what we wanna hear
---------------------- Forwarded by Steve LaFontaine/GlobalCo on 02/08/2001
06:27 AM ---------------------------


"Matt Rogers" <mrogers@earthsat.com> on 02/08/2001 03:46:47 AM

To:   mrogers@earthsat.com
cc:    (bcc: Steve LaFontaine/GlobalCo)
Fax to:
Subject:  EarthSAT UPDATE




This morning's 6-10 day forecast models are showing somewhat better
agreement.  All three models move the main cold trough axis to the Great
Lakes area by the last half of the period.  This shift allows for cold
Polar/Arctic air to pour into the Midwest and Northeastern states by
days 9 and 10 (as early as day 8 on the American).  The Canadian and
European continue more troughing in the southern branch in the
Southwestern states, keeping that area cool, but also forcing continued
ridging in the Southern states--from Texas to the Southeast--keeping
them warmer and away from the cold.  The American eliminates this
southern branch cold air protection early (by day 8), while the Canadian
breaks it down by day 10, implying that even the South would see cold
weather at the beginning of the 11-15 day period.  The European appears
to hold out the longest in bringing cold air to the South. In all cases,
the West Coast should see some gradual warming by late in the period.
All three models also continue a very amplified flow pattern in Canada
with a plentiful supply of strong, cold air.

More details, including early information from the ensembles, will be
available with the 6:30am ET release.

-Matt Rogers

To: Ethan Patel <ethan.patel@oakridge.k12.ca.us> 
Subject: RE: Pilot school selections

Hi Ethan,

I completely agree with your suggestions for the professional development sessions. Handouts on the key instructional strategies and sample lesson/unit plans will be incredibly helpful for teachers. And I love the idea of incorporating interactive elements like role-playing and practice sessions. I think that will really help the teachers feel more confident and prepared to implement the curriculum.

You're welcome to take the lead on creating those training materials. I'll make sure the schools have the space and technology we need for those interactive components.

I heard back from both Jefferson and Washington - they're both on board to participate in the pilot! I'll coordinate with them on meeting dates and will send you the details once they're set.

Thanks again for all your partnership on this. I'm feeling really good about where we are and where we're headed!

Best,
Olivia

Kim,

I would like to either meet with you, or trade e-mails on your current and 
possible future target accounts list where GSS may be able to add value to 
your efforts.  Since we're ending 2000 and going into a new sales year, I 
want to make sure I'm not holding resource open on any accounts which may 
not, or should not be on the list of focus accounts which you and your team 
have requested our involvement with.  I also want to make sure I'm bringing 
resource to bear on the accounts which you DO want to engage.

For example, at one point Siemens was one of them, and with recent 
developments, may now be off your list...the last communication I received 
from the NYC office re:  Siemens was via telephone call on November 3rd, 
where they informed me that the primary opportunity looked like it would be 
with one of their medical groups based in Chicago.  After several 
unsuccessful follow-up attempts, I placed the Siemens account in the dormant 
category.  Yesterday, Jennifer forwarded me information requesting engagement 
with your team on CA (Computer Associates) and U.S. Internetworking, and 
today American Express has surfaced.  Consequently, I think it's probably a 
good idea for me to make sure I'm focused on the right accounts for you.  

I realize you may be in PRC today and/or tomorrow, so perhaps Friday would 
work?  If not, I would have Monday the 18th available late afternoon, or any 
time on December 27th, 28th, or 29th.  When would be good for you?  Please 
let me know!

Thank you,

Jeff

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Julian Patel <jpatel@physicsinstitute.org>
To: Amelia Hartman <amelia.hartman@university.edu>
Subject: Re: Request for expertise

Dear Amelia,

Thank you for sending over the list of terms. I've taken a look and provided definitions and explanations for each one. I've attached the document for your review. Please let me know if you need any further clarification or have additional terms to add.

Your suggestions for my upcoming lecture are incredibly helpful. I particularly like the idea of using analogies and visual aids to make the concepts more relatable. I'll definitely incorporate those strategies into my presentation. And I appreciate the advice on breaking up the lecture and encouraging audience engagement. I tend to get carried away with the details, so reminding myself to step back and check for understanding will be key.

As for Ethan Chen, I do remember him! He was a few years ahead of me at Weston, but I recall him being a brilliant student with a real passion for physics. Small world that you know him as well.

I'm attaching a draft of my lecture outline. I'd greatly appreciate any feedback you might have, particularly on the clarity and flow of the content. And please feel free to share the document with Ethan if you think he might have insights to offer.

Thank you again for your help and collaboration on both the dictionary project and my lecture. I'm grateful for your expertise and support.

Best regards,
Julian Patel
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Akira Nakamura <akira.nakamura@justice-matters.org>
To: Dr. Lila Patel <lila.patel@cosmic-ethics.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise on indigenous rights and space exploration

Dear Lila,

Thank you so much for your enthusiastic response and for sharing these thought-provoking ideas. I am excited to explore these themes further and to learn from your expertise.

I would like to invite you to contribute a piece to our exhibit catalog, which will feature essays and reflections from scholars and activists working on various aspects of displacement, resistance, and social justice. If you are interested, I would be honored if you could write about the potential impact of space exploration on indigenous land rights and cultural heritage sites, and how this relates to the broader history of displacement and colonization.

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns about this invitation. I am happy to provide more details about the catalog and the exhibit.

I look forward to our continued collaboration and to creating a powerful and thought-provoking exhibit.

Best regards,
Akira
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@oakwoodhigh.edu>
To: Oliver Reed <oliver.reed@oakwoodhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Interdisciplinary Project Update

Oliver,

Great, 2 pm at the café it is! I can't wait to dive deeper into our project and discuss the practical applications for our students. You make an excellent point about emphasizing the relevance of our work to politics and decision-making. We should definitely consider how to frame our presentation at the conference to make it engaging and thought-provoking for the audience.

I've been doing some research on recent controversies surrounding utilitarianism and its role in policy-making. I think incorporating some of these real-world examples could help illustrate the importance of our project and its potential impact. Let's brainstorm some ideas on Saturday.

See you then!

Emily

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Johnson <ejohnson@triassicreptiles.org>
To: Dr. Michael Smith <msmith@permianreptiles.com>
Subject: Upcoming conference presentation

Dear Michael,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to touch base with you about the upcoming paleontology conference where we've been invited to give a joint presentation. The organizers have asked us to submit a title and abstract for our talk by the end of the month.

I was thinking we could focus our presentation on the evolutionary relationships between Permian and Triassic reptiles, highlighting some of our recent findings from our collaborative research. What do you think? Do you have any specific aspects of our work that you'd like to showcase?

Also, we should start thinking about dividing up the work for the presentation. I'm happy to take the lead on creating the slides and outline, but I'd love your input on the content and any specific data or figures you'd like to include.

Let me know your thoughts, and we can schedule a call to discuss further if needed.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

<email>
From: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@powerplant.com>
To: Ryan Thompson <ryan.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Water treatment project idea

Ryan,

I'm glad you're on board with the project! I think this collaboration has the potential to be really impactful.

I'll gather some data on our current water treatment processes and send it your way. We can then schedule a call to discuss the project in more depth and start mapping out a plan.

I completely agree about the engineering club's competition. It would be fantastic to showcase our work and potentially win a prize. Let's aim to have a solid prototype ready for the competition deadline.

I'll be in touch soon with more information. Thanks for your enthusiasm and expertise!

Best regards,
Alex

To: epao@mba2002.hbs.edu
Subject: Re: Extra credit



rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's
you bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?
what you charge me play against you?)

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emilythompson@chemteach.com>
To: Michael Chen <michaelchen@chemstudent.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on educational videos

Hi Michael,

I love the idea of creating a companion website with additional resources! That will be a great way to supplement the video content and help students practice what they've learned. I can take on the task of creating the quizzes and practice problems.

I also think it would be a good idea to create a section on the website where students can ask questions and we can respond to them. This will help us engage with our audience and provide additional support.

As for the videos, I think we should aim to keep them around 10-15 minutes long, so that they're easy to digest. We can break down each topic into smaller subtopics and create separate videos for each one.

What do you think about this plan? I'm really excited to get started on this project!

Best regards,
Emily

Per my voicemail, I've included a list of the Investors' questions and 
preliminary answers.  The answers are attempts by our group, Bob Crane and 
Bryon Hoskins but need confirmation by you.  Would you mind giving us some 
feedback for #4 as well?  I could not find these numbers.  These are again 
going to be forwarded to Bain Capital, the potential equity investor in the 
pulp, paper and steel net works fund.  They are in their final stages of due 
diligence and are comparing pulp and paper facts with gas.  (They are under a 
confidentiality agreement).  
Please call with any questions
Thank you, 
Catherine Rentz Pernot
 X57654

1. # of years of NYMEX visibility on the typical gas curve.

3 years

2. # of daily trades on NYMEX, in total and for Enron specifically.

102,492 daily trades on NYMEX (11/28/00)and ours amounts to 8,061 per day 
(usually around 10% daily NYMEX trades)

3. length and nature of "price discovery" windows past the NYMEX portion of
the gas curve (e.g., 7 years of visibility provided by proprietary market
making past NYMEX, then 10 years of macro / industry average assumptions).

NYMEX price discovery equates to about 3 years. Liquidity of the market and 
proprietary market information equates to about 2 years after that with the 
remaining portion coming from more macro industry information.

4. trade volume data (# of daily trades as well) for each 5 year increment of
the gas curve beyond the NYMEX portion, in total and for Enron specifically. 

??

body:
<email>
From: Liam Thompson <liam.thompson@earthscienceinstitute.org>
To: Amelia Johnson <amelia.johnson@cosmosuniversity.edu>
Subject: RE: Following up on our conversation at the Planetary Geology Conference

Amelia,

Tuesday at 10 AM EST works perfectly for me. I'm looking forward to our discussion and the opportunity to brainstorm ideas for our project.

Your suggestion to review the current literature on permafrost stability and planetary volcanism is an excellent starting point. I'll gather the latest research on permafrost and its implications for Earth's climate, and I'll be sure to include any relevant studies on other planets as well.

Thank you for the papers you've attached. I've skimmed through them, and they're incredibly informative. Your work on Io's volcanism is truly groundbreaking, and I can already see potential connections with permafrost research.

As for potential outlets, I agree that the Journal of Geophysical Research: Planets and the Journal of Earth Science would be excellent choices. I also have a contact at the International Journal of Astrobiology who might be interested in our work, given the potential implications for life on other planets.

I'm attaching a few papers on permafrost degradation and its impact on Earth's climate. I thought they might provide valuable context for our project.

I'm eager to dive into this research and see where our collaboration leads us. Talk to you next Tuesday!

Best regards,
Liam

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@washforall.org>
To: Dr. Michael Chen <michael.chen@obesitycenter.com>
Subject: Following up from the Global Health Conference

Dear Dr. Chen,

It was great meeting you at the Global Health Conference last week. I really enjoyed our conversation about the potential link between WASH interventions and obesity prevention in developing communities. I've been thinking more about the ideas we discussed and would love to explore them further.

I did some research and found a few articles that support our hypothesis. For example, [this study](https://www.example.com/study) found that children in communities with poor sanitation were more likely to be stunted and have higher rates of obesity later in life. I think this could be a great starting point for our collaboration.

What do you think about conducting a joint research project on this topic? We could potentially do a study in one of the communities where WASH for All is already working. Let me know if you're interested, and we can set up a call to discuss further.

Best regards,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Rajesh Patel <rpatel@university.edu>
To: Aisha Khan <a.khan@institute.org>
Subject: Continuing our discussion on Kashmir

Aisha,

I enjoyed our spirited exchange during yesterday's research group meeting. While we may not see eye to eye on all aspects of the Kashmir conflict, I always appreciate your insightful and well-reasoned arguments.

I've been thinking more about the recent flare-up in violence and its potential implications for the region. As someone with deep knowledge of the historical and geopolitical context, I believe you could offer valuable perspective on this complex issue.

Would you be interested in collaborating on a paper analyzing the significance of the recent events and what they could mean for the future of the conflict? I think our different viewpoints, combined with our shared commitment to rigorous scholarship, could result in a thought-provoking and impactful piece.

Let me know what you think. I'm happy to discuss further and divide up the research and writing tasks in a way that plays to our respective strengths and interests.

Best regards,
Rajesh
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Smith <jordan.smith@university.edu>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@highschool.edu>
Subject: European travel advice

Hi Emily,

I hope you're doing well! As I mentioned during our last dinner, I'm planning a trip to Europe this summer and would love to get your expert advice on some historical sites to visit. I'll be traveling to London, Paris, and Berlin, and I'm particularly interested in places that have significance in the history of medicine and infectious diseases.

I know you're incredibly knowledgeable about European history, and I would be so grateful if you could point me in the right direction. If you have any colleagues in those cities who might be willing to share their insights, I would be even more appreciative!

Let me know if you have any suggestions or resources to share. I'm getting excited about this trip and can't wait to learn more about the history of these incredible cities.

Best,
Jordan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@environews.com>
To: Dr. Oliver Patel <oliver.patel@medresearch.ac.uk>
Subject: RE: New study on air pollution and lung health

Oliver,

Thank you so much for your insights and for offering to share your preliminary findings. I would be very interested in learning more about your ongoing research, as I'm sure my readers would be as well.

If you're open to it, I'd love to arrange a time for us to discuss your study in more detail. Perhaps we could set up a call or video chat next week? I'm happy to work around your schedule.

In the meantime, I'll be sure to include your comments in my article. I'll send you a link once it's published.

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@ridgemonthigh.edu>
To: Dr. James Fitzgerald <jfitzgerald@oceanresearch.org>
Subject: Guest Lecture Request

Dear Dr. Fitzgerald,

I hope this email finds you well. We met briefly at the science conference last month where you presented your fascinating research on cephalopods. I'm a high school math teacher and I was impressed by the mathematical aspects of your work, particularly the data analysis and modeling.

I was wondering if you would be interested in Skyping into my classroom to give a guest lecture on your research and how math plays a role in your findings. My students are currently learning about statistical analysis and graphing techniques, and I think hearing about a real-world application of these concepts would be incredibly valuable for them.

Please let me know if this is something you would be willing to do. I would be happy to work around your schedule and provide any necessary materials or resources.

Thank you for considering this request. I look forward to hearing back from you.

Best regards,
Sarah Thompson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakvillehigh.edu>
To: Liam Thompson <lthompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Interesting article on nutrient cycles in local ecosystems

Dear Liam,

I'm thrilled to hear that you found the article informative and inspiring! It's always a pleasure to see students like you who are passionate about making a difference in the world.

I would be more than happy to discuss the article with you in more detail and share some additional resources that may be of interest to you. In terms of research opportunities, I recommend looking into local environmental organizations and universities that offer internships or volunteer positions in the field of environmental science.

I'm confident that with your dedication and curiosity, you'll make a significant impact in the field. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need any further guidance or support.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: Lucas Silva <lsilva@brazilianuni.edu.br>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference in Rio

Lucas,

I'm getting more and more excited about our upcoming meeting and the potential for collaboration. Thank you for offering to introduce me to potential collaborators in Brazil – that would be incredibly helpful as I expand my research to include case studies of emerging economies.

I'll be staying at the Copacabana Palace Hotel, which I believe is not far from the conference venue. I'm arriving on the 9th and will be free most of the day on the 10th before the conference starts. Would you be available to meet for coffee or lunch that day? We could discuss our research ideas in more detail and start planning our grant proposal.

I'll be in touch with my flight details as the date approaches. Thank you again for all your help and support. I can't wait to experience Rio and work with you on this exciting project!

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Hey Jordan,

I've booked the rooms at the bed and breakfast, and they're all set for our arrival. I'll send you the confirmation details shortly.

Thanks for offering to drive! That would be great, as it will give me a chance to relax and enjoy the scenery on the way to Millersville. We can leave early and make a day of it, stopping for lunch or snacks along the way.

I'm really looking forward to our trip and the eclipse. It's going to be a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and I couldn't ask for a better astronomy buddy to share it with.

See you soon!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Ethan Jones <ejones@underwaterarchaeology.org>
To: Dr. Amelia Rivera <arivera@maritimehistory.org>
Subject: RE: Potential Collaboration

Dear Dr. Rivera,

Thank you for reaching out and for the kind words. I, too, found our conversation at the conference to be thought-provoking and engaging. A research project exploring the connections between prehistoric fish weirs and 19th-century whaling techniques sounds like an excellent opportunity to merge our expertise and contribute to the understanding of human maritime history.

I am particularly intrigued by the idea of examining the cultural significance of these structures and how they have evolved over time. Combining our knowledge of ancient and more recent maritime practices could provide valuable insights into the ways in which humans have adapted to and impacted their environments.

I am excited to work with you on this project and believe that a co-authored paper or museum exhibit would be a fantastic way to showcase our findings. Please let me know the next steps in moving forward with this collaboration.

Best regards,
Ethan Jones
Underwater Archaeologist and Pre-Columbian Structures Expert

Let me know if there's anything else I can do to help. I'm always happy to collaborate with you on projects like this.

Best,
Michael

<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@abcschools.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@xyzschools.org>
Subject: RE: Drama-based activities for Unit 3

Hi Michael,

I've finished developing the drama-based activities for Unit 3 and wanted to share them with you for feedback. I've attached the document for your review.

In these activities, students will engage in role-playing exercises that focus on the themes and vocabulary from the unit's reading passages. I've also included some prompts for class discussions to help students reflect on their learning and experiences.

Please let me know your thoughts and if you have any suggestions for improvements. I'd also love to see the scaffolding techniques you've been working on for this unit.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

Best,
Emily

body:
Message-ID: <33184956.1075855676310.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 2000 06:34:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\Discussion threads
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

George,

 Below is a list of questions that Keith and I had regarding the Westgate 
project:

 Ownership Structure

 What will be the ownership structure? Limited partnership? General partner?

 What are all the legal entities that will be involved and in what 
capacity(regarding ownership and 
 liabilities)?

 Who owns the land? improvements?

 Who holds the various loans?

 Is the land collateral?

 Investment
 
 What happens to initial investment?

 Is it used to purchase land for cash?Secure future loans?
 
 Why is the land cost spread out on the cash flow statement?

 When is the 700,000 actually needed? Now or for the land closing? Investment 
schedule?

 Investment Return

 Is Equity Repayment the return of the original investment?

 Is the plan to wait until the last unit is sold and closed before profits 
are distributed?

 Debt

 Which entity is the borrower for each loan and what recourse or collateral 
is associated with each 
 loan?

 Improvement

 Construction

 Are these the only two loans?  Looks like it from the cash flow statement.

 Terms of each loan?

 Uses of Funds

 How will disbursements be made?  By whom?

 What type of bank account?  Controls on max disbursement? Internet viewing 
for investors?

 Reports to track expenses vs plan?

 Bookkeeping procedures to record actual expenses?

 What is the relationship of Creekside Builders to the project?  Do you get 
paid a markup on subcontractors as a 
 general contractor and paid gain out of profits?

 Do you or Larry receive any money in the form of salary or personal expenses 
before the ultimate payout of profits?

 Design and Construction
 
 When will design be complete?

 What input will investors have in selecting design and materials for units?

 What level of investor involvement will be possible during construction 
planning and permitting?

 Does Creekside have specific procedures for dealing with subcontractors, 
vendors, and other professionals? 
 Such as always getting 3 bids, payment schedules, or reference checking?

 Are there any specific companies or individuals that you already plan to 
use? Names?

These questions are probably very basic to you, but as a first time investor 
in a project like this it is new to me.  Also, I want to learn as
much as possible from the process.

Phillip

Message-ID: <33220990.1075855727655.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Fri, 2 Feb 2001 08:40:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: stagecoachmama@hotmail.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: stagecoachmama@hotmail.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Lucy,

Please fix #41 balance by deleting the $550 in the "Rent Due" column.  The 
other questions I had about last week's rent are:

#15  Only paid 95 of their 190 on 1/19 then paid nothing on 1/26.  What is 
going on?

#25  Looks like she was short by 35 and still owes a little on deposit

#27 Switched to weekly, but paid nothing this week.  Why?

I spoke to Jeff Smith.  I think he was surprised that we were set up with 
email and MSN Messenger.  He was not trying to insult you.  I let Jeff know 
that he should try and meet the prospective buyers when they come to see the 
property.  Occasionally, a buyer might stop buy without Jeff and you can show 
them around and let them know what a nice quiet well maintained place it is.  

Regarding the raise,  $260/week plus the apartment is all I can pay right 
now.  I increased your pay last year very quickly so you could make ends meet 
but I think your wages equate to $10/hr and that is fair.  As Gary and Wade 
continue to improve the property, I need you to try and improve the 
property's tenants and reputation.  The apartments are looking better and 
better, yet the turnover seems to be increasing.  

Remember that as a manager you need to set the example for the tenants.  It 
is hard to tell tenants that they are not supposed to have extra people move 
in that are not on the lease, when the manager has a houseful of guests.  I 
realize you have had a lot of issues with taking your son to the doctor and 
your daughter being a teenager, but you need to put in 40 hours and be 
working in the office or on the property during office unless you are running 
an errand for the property.

I am not upset that you asked for a raise, but the answer is no at this 
time.  We can look at again later in the year.

I will talk to you later or you can email or call over the weekend.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@matheducator.com>
To: Raj Patel <raj.patel@climatejournalist.com>
Subject: Congrats on your recent article!

Hey Raj,

I just read your article on the increasing heatwaves in South Asia and wanted to say congratulations on such a well-researched and important piece. The data analysis you included was really compelling.

I've been working on a research project on effective ways to teach statistics to students, and I think some of the techniques you used in your article could be really useful for my work. I'd love to meet up for coffee and discuss it further if you're interested.

Let me know if you have time to chat!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Lee <jlee@observatory.org>
To: Alex Novak <anovak@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting news about the James Webb Space Telescope!

Alex,

It's great to hear from you, and congratulations on your team's incredible discovery! I've been eagerly following the developments with the JWST, and I'm thrilled to learn that you've made such a significant breakthrough.

I would be delighted to schedule a video call to discuss your findings in more detail. I'm confident that your discovery will have a profound impact on our field, and I'm eager to explore the possibilities for future collaboration.

I'm available for a call next week, either on Tuesday afternoon (2:00 PM - 4:00 PM) or Thursday morning (10:00 AM - 12:00 PM). Please let me know which time slot works best for you, and I'll send a calendar invite with the video conferencing details.

In the meantime, if you're able to share any preliminary results or insights, I'd be grateful for a sneak peek. Your research is always thought-provoking, and I'm curious to learn more about the specific observations and analyses that led to your discovery.

Looking forward to our call and the potential for exciting future collaborations!

Best regards,
Jordan

From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@languageacademy.com>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@languageacademy.com>
Subject: Professional Development Workshop

Hi Michael,

I have some exciting news! The school has asked us to present our collaborative curriculum at the upcoming professional development workshop on innovative teaching methods for ESL teachers. This is a great opportunity to share our experiences and ideas with our colleagues.

The workshop will take place on Saturday, September 15th, from 9 am to 4 pm. Our presentation is scheduled for 1 pm, and we'll have 45 minutes to present and answer questions.

I think we should create a PowerPoint presentation highlighting the key aspects of our curriculum, student feedback, and the benefits of our collaborative approach. We can also prepare some handouts for the participants.

Let's meet next Wednesday at 3 pm to discuss our presentation and divide the tasks.

What do you think?

Best,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@geothermenergy.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@renewablesolutions.org>
Subject: RE: Reconnecting and potential collaboration

Emily,

Thank you for your prompt response and for sharing your ideas. I completely agree that a lifecycle assessment and economic analysis would greatly enhance our proposal and demonstrate the long-term viability of our approach.

I am available next week for a discussion. How about we schedule a video call for Tuesday at 10 AM EST? That should give us enough time to prepare and gather our thoughts before the call.

In the meantime, I will review the grant application requirements and create an outline of the key points we should address in our proposal. I will send it to you before our call for your feedback and suggestions.

Looking forward to our collaboration and the potential impact we could have on the geothermal energy industry.

Best regards,
John
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@bellington.edu>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@bellington.edu>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on teaching Microeconomics

Dear Emily,

Thank you so much for your warm welcome and willingness to meet with me! I greatly appreciate your offer to share your teaching experiences and introduce me to other colleagues.

Next Tuesday at 10 AM in the faculty lounge works perfectly for me. I look forward to our conversation and the opportunity to learn from your expertise.

As for research collaborations, I'm currently working on a paper that examines the impact of competition policy on market structures in the telecommunications industry. I'd be happy to share my preliminary findings with you and get your feedback. If you have any suggestions for additional data sources or theoretical frameworks, I'd be grateful for your input.

I'm excited to work with you and contribute to the department's research output. Thank you again for your support and guidance.

Best regards,
John Smith

To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Rare Mendel book

Hi Sarah,

Thank you so much for thinking of me! I would absolutely love to borrow that book. It sounds like an incredible resource that my students would really benefit from. I appreciate your willingness to lend it to me, especially considering how rare it is.

If you could mail it to me, that would be fantastic. I promise to take great care of it and return it to you promptly. I'm also looking forward to catching up with you at the conference next month. It would be great to discuss my lesson plans with you and get your expert advice.

Thank you again for your generosity and support!

Best,
Michael

To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@nationalweatherservice.gov>
Subject: Hurricane Omar Update

Sarah,

I've been analyzing the latest radar data for Hurricane Omar, and it looks like the storm is intensifying more quickly than we initially predicted. We need to update our forecast and issue a new warning for the areas along the East Coast.

Can you take a look at the data and let me know if you agree with my assessment? We should also discuss how we want to present this information to the public and to the media.

Thanks,
John

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@foodtech.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@foodtech.com>
Subject: RE: Exciting news from the food science conference

Hey Emily,

Thanks for sharing this exciting news! I've heard about metabolomics before, but I haven't had the chance to dive into the details. It sounds like a fascinating technique that could really advance our understanding of food chemistry.

I'm currently working on a project to develop a new food product with improved nutritional value. I've been struggling to find the right combination of ingredients, and I think metabolomics could be the key to unlocking the answers. By analyzing the metabolites in our prototype, we might be able to identify the specific compounds that contribute to its nutritional profile and make adjustments accordingly.

I'd love to collaborate with you on this project and explore the potential applications of metabolomics in our research. Maybe we could set up a meeting to discuss our ideas and plan our next steps?

Looking forward to your thoughts!

Best,
Michael
label: research

Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: ed.mcmichael@enron.com, dutch.quigley@enron.com
X-From: McDaniel, Kirk </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=NOTESADDR/CN=151B1F73-1F0D9C60-8625697B-63E5AD>
X-To: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>, O'rourke, Tim </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=TOROURKE>, Frolov, Yevgeny </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=YFROLOV>
X-cc: McMichael Jr., Ed </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=EMCMICH>, Quigley, Dutch </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=DQUIGLE>
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Phillip/Tim/Yevgeny
Please review the two attachments below for final sign-off and Acceptance of this deliverable.

Phillip, you have approved these documents prior to Tim and my input reflected below, which primary consist of showing how the Knowledge system is connected to the simulation system (Tim's idea with some direct guidance from me to Accenture on how to reflect this in the flow chart). Thus it shows how the user can go to the knowledge system and get help during the simulation. This is reflected in the high level design flow chart.ppt

In addition, Accenture has added the following condition language to the High Level design. doc

	After sign-off on this document, the following things can be changed within the first two weeks of the content development phase:
?	Small story-line details (Example: company background, learner role)
?	Resources (reports and interviews) (Example: add a news article, remove a storage report)
?	Order and details of learner actions and decision (Example: add a sub-step where learner identifies the location of each risk; have the learner calculate net present value after choosing the best instrument rather than before)

Changes to any other High Level Design elements (Example: add a step where learner uses a pricing model to price a deal), or changes to anything after the first two weeks, will impact the budget and schedule. 


Issue: Do we agree to this condition. I recommend we agree. Although, we are in the content development phase the two week period begins from the time we accept this deliverable. I have confirmed this with Accenture and they will send another email with this change, but I do not want to hold up acceptance since we are on our clock. 

Thanks. Phillip, Tim & Yevgeny (if possible), please e-mail with your thumbs up or further input at your earliest convenience, but no later then COB 10/23.

Cheers
Kirk


---------------------- Forwarded by Kirk McDaniel/HOU/EES on 10/19/2001 07:58 AM ---------------------------


mery.l.brown@accenture.com on 10/18/2001 12:46:06 PM
To:	kmcdani@enron.com
cc:	donald.l.barnhart@accenture.com, laura.a.de.la.torre@accenture.com 
Subject:	Revised High Level Design


Kirk,

Attached are the latest High Level Design and Flow Chart with revisions
based on Tim's and your comments. Please let me know if you have any
questions.

(See attached file: High Level Design.doc)(See attached file: High Level
Design Flow Chart.ppt)

Mery

Mery - 30 minutes
Laura - 1 hour

Message-ID: <27155845.1075858639875.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 20 Jun 2001 08:09:31 -0700 (PDT)
From: k..allen@enron.com
To: jeff.dasovich@enron.com
Subject: RE: Call to Discuss Possible Options to Mitigate Effect of DWR
 Contracts--Privileged and Confidential
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-To: Dasovich, Jeff </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Notesaddr/cn=da220740-3e85e661-86256962-4f9c13>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Sent Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


jeff,

Is the problem that the energy DWR purchased is above market and not needed by CORE  or  just above market.  If the energy is needed by CORE wouldn't the deals just be blended in as costs like utility gen and QF supply?  If the energy is not needed now could the state sell back the excess then compute the exact loss and put a surcharge on rates for all or some customers that recoup that amount over time.  Once again there would be a CTC type recovery period but there would not be the risk that the market price must stay below a fixed price for the stranded costs to be recovered.  

Phillip
 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Dasovich, Jeff  
Sent:	Tuesday, June 19, 2001 5:11 PM
To:	Belden, Tim; Calger, Christopher F.; Steffes, James; Shapiro, Richard; skean@enron.com; Kaufman, Paul; Mara, Susan; Allen, Phillip K.; Yoder, Christian; Hall, Steve C.
Subject:	Call to Discuss Possible Options to Mitigate Effect of DWR Contracts--Privileged and Confidential
Sensitivity:	Confidential

PLEASE KEEP THIS NOTE, AND THE INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THE NOTE CONFIDENTIAL.

As folks are aware, we have been engaged in closed-door negotiations for the past two weeks regarding a possible market-based solution to California's electricity crisis.
In the room are the major large customer groups, environmentalists, small customers (TURN), Independent Energy Producers, labor, the Western States Petroleum Association, and Enron.
The negotiations were convened by the Speaker of the Assembly (Bob Hertzberg).
When Hertzberg convened the meeting, he told the parties that he wanted to achieve a core/noncore structure, similar to the structure in place in California's gas market (i.e., large customers are required to buy gas from the market, with Direct Access available to all other customers).
In effect, "core" customers (rez and small business) would be served by the utilities' retained generating assets and QF contracts; and large customers would go to market.  
The core/noncore structure would begin 1.1.03.
The negotiating group has struggled over the past two weeks, but is close devising a framework for core/noncore in Californis (but who pays for the utilities' past debts and the costs of DWR power purchased between January and today remain very contentious).
Unfortunately, with the release of the information regarding the DWR contracts last Friday, it is now clear that achieving a core/noncore structure will be very difficult unless something is done to mitigate the contracts.
The problem is that, if core is served by utility gen and QFs, and large customers are in the market, there is no (or very little) need for the DWR contracts.  Instead, they look like a signficant stranded cost.
Hertzberg and the negotiating group are looking to Enron for creative ways to address "the DWR contract problem" in order to prevent the contracts from 1) killing the core/noncore deal and 2) forcing California to accept a structure focused on a state power authority headed-up by David Freeman that does not include Direct Access.
Christian Yoder and Steve Hall are reviewing the contracts to analyze any "out clauses" that the buyer and/or the seller might have under the contract provisions.  (My cursory review of the contracts suggests that "outs" for the state are minimal or nonexistent.)
In addition, we've started batting around ideas about how the State might reform the contracts.
All this said, want to let everyone know that we have made it extremely clear that Enron fundamentally opposes any and all attempts to unilaterally abrogate anyone's contract rights.

We'd like to have a quick call tomorrow (30-60 minutes) to brainstorm some options that we can offer Hertzberg to handle the contracts and keep the core/noncore solution alive.  We'd like to try to have the the call at 1 PM PDT.  Please let me know if this works for you, and if it doesn't, please let me know if there's a time after 1 PM PDT that works for you.

Thanks,
Jeff

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakvillehigh.edu>
To: Liam Thompson <lthompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: Interesting article on nutrient cycles in local ecosystems

Dear Liam,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to share with you a recently published research article on nutrient cycles in local ecosystems that I thought might interest you, given your passion for environmental science.

The article discusses the impact of human activities on nutrient cycles and offers insights into potential solutions for mitigating these effects. I believe this could be a valuable resource for your studies and future endeavors in the field.

Please feel free to reach out if you'd like to discuss the article or if you have any questions about pursuing a career in environmental science. I'd be more than happy to provide guidance and support.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson

<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@autotech.com>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@university.edu>
Subject: Catching up

Hey Jordan,

It's been a while since we last talked. I hope everything is going well with your PhD research. I remember you mentioning something about studying new catalysts for hydrogen production. How's that coming along?

Things on my end have been pretty hectic. We're working on developing a new generation of speed sensors for electric vehicles, and it's been a challenging but exciting project. I've been spending a lot of time in the lab and attending conferences to stay up-to-date with the latest advancements in the field.

I was thinking, it would be great to catch up sometime. Maybe we could have a video call next week to discuss our work and share some of our experiences since graduation. Let me know if you're interested and when you're available.

Best regards,
Alex

Just an update: Today I set up a front month fixed price gas daily product 
priced at parity to NYMEX.  I thought the response was tremendous.  It really 
shows that we might have an angle to put out more of the curve and become the 
predominant benchmark for the industry rather than the exchange.  

One problem I had was linking 2 syncopated basis products.  I set up a new 
product for the prompt that was Nov GD/D Henry Hub that was a syncopated 
basis of 0/0 to the Nov Nymex.  However, since Dec Nymex is a syncopated 
basis to Nov Nymex, I could not set up a syncopated basis link around the Dec 
Nymex.  Any ideas?

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakwoodhigh.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakwoodhigh.edu>
Subject: Collaboration on Climate Change and Urbanization Project

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I'm reaching out because I'm currently working on a lesson plan about the human impacts of climate change. As I was brainstorming ideas, I thought about your expertise in human geography and urban studies. I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on a cross-curricular project for our students?

I think it would be really valuable for our students to explore the relationship between urbanization and climate change. We could have them work together on a project that examines this topic and present their findings to the school and local community.

Let me know what you think! I'd love to brainstorm some ideas together.

Best,
Emily

<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@arachnologyuniversity.edu>
To: Robert Smith <robert.smith@entomologyinstitute.org>
Subject: Exciting new data on Salticidae mimicry

Hi Robert,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to share some exciting new data we've collected on the mimicry behavior of Salticidae spiders. The results are even more compelling than we initially anticipated, and I believe they could have significant implications for our research.

Would you be available for a video call next week to discuss these findings in more detail? I'd love to get your thoughts and insights on how we should proceed with our collaboration.

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Smith <jordan.smith@university.edu>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@highschool.edu>
Subject: RE: European travel advice

Emily,

Thank you so much for all of these incredible suggestions! I had no idea there were so many fascinating places to visit that are directly related to my research interests. I'm particularly excited about the Wellcome Collection in London and the Pasteur Institute in Paris. I will definitely make sure to visit those museums and take the tours you recommended.

I really appreciate you connecting me with your colleagues in Paris and Berlin. I'll reach out to them and see if they have any specific recommendations or insights to share. It's so generous of you to make those introductions.

I promise to take lots of pictures and notes during my trip so I can share all the fascinating things I learn with you when I return. And of course, I'll bring back some delicious European chocolates for our next dinner!

Thank you again for all your help and support. I'm so grateful for your friendship and expertise.

Best,
Jordan

From: James Miller <james.miller@college.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Faulkner Symbolism Conference

Hi Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I had a wonderful time discussing Faulkner's use of symbolism with you as well. Collaborating on a paper sounds like a fantastic idea. I believe that combining our knowledge on the subject will result in a comprehensive and insightful piece.

I've been focusing on the Yoknapatawpha novels and how the symbolism employed contributes to the overall themes of the stories. I think it would be fascinating to explore how these symbols relate to the archetypal imagery you've been studying.

Let's set up a time to discuss our ideas further and outline the structure of the paper. I'm excited to work together on this project!

Best regards,
James

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! As you know, we've been asked to present our work on integrating coding into our classrooms at the upcoming staff meeting. I think this is a great opportunity to share our experiences and encourage others to give it a try.

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Thompson <jenna.thompson@natureforall.org>
To: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@birdconservation.org>
Subject: New project idea - migratory waterbirds and special education

Hi Alex,

I hope this email finds you well! It's been a while since we worked together on the "Nature for All" project, and I've been thinking about how much impact we made on those children. I believe we can do more!

I have an idea for a new project that combines our expertise in special education and bird conservation. What if we create a series of educational materials specifically focused on migratory waterbirds, designed for children with special needs? We could develop interactive lessons, sensory-rich activities, and engaging stories that cater to different learning styles.

I think this project could not only inspire a love for nature and conservation in these children but also provide valuable resources for educators and parents. 

What do you think? Are you interested in collaborating once again? I'd love to discuss this further and hear your thoughts.

Best regards,
Jenna

From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: keith.holst@enron.com
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Keith Holst
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 10/09/2000 
02:16 PM ---------------------------


Richard Burchfield
10/06/2000 06:59 AM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Beth Perlman/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list

Phillip,
 Below is the issues & to do list as we go forward with documenting the 
requirements for consolidated physical/financial positions and transport 
trade capture. What we need to focus on is the first bullet in Allan's list; 
the need for a single set of requirements. Although the meeting with Keith, 
on Wednesday,  was informative the solution of creating a infinitely dynamic 
consolidated position screen, will be extremely difficult and time 
consuming.  Throughout the meeting on Wednesday, Keith alluded to the 
inability to get consensus amongst the traders on the presentation of the 
consolidated position, so the solution was to make it so that a trader can 
arrange the position screen to their liking (much like Excel). What needs to 
happen on Monday from 3 - 5 is a effort to design a desired layout for the 
consolidated position screen, this is critical. This does not exclude 
building a capability to create a more flexible position presentation for the 
future, but in order to create a plan that can be measured we need firm 
requirements. Also, to reiterate that the goals of this project is a project 
plan on consolidate physical/financial positions and transport trade capture. 
The other issues that have been raised will be capture as projects on to 
themselves, and will need to be prioritised as efforts outside of this 
project.

I have been involved in most of the meetings and the discussions have been 
good. I believe there has been good communication between the teams, but now 
we need to have focus on the objectives we set out to solve.

Richard  
---------------------- Forwarded by Richard Burchfield/HOU/ECT on 10/06/2000 
08:34 AM ---------------------------


Allan Severude
10/05/2000 06:03 PM
To: Richard Burchfield/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Peggy Alix/HOU/ECT@ECT, Russ Severson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scott 
Mills/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kenny Ha/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list


From our initial set of meetings with the traders regarding consolidated 
positions, I think we still have the following issues:
We don't have a single point of contact from the trading group.  We've had 
three meetings which brought out very different issues from different 
traders.  We really need a single point of contact to help drive the trader 
requirements and help come to a consensus regarding the requirements.
We're getting hit with a lot of different requests, many of which appear to 
be outside the scope of position consolidation.

Things left to do:
I think it may be useful to try to formulate a high level project goal to 
make it as clear as possible what we're trying to accomplish with this 
project.  It'll help determine which requests fall under the project scope.
Go through the list of requests to determine which are in scope for this 
project and which fall out of scope.
For those in scope, work to define relative importance (priority) of each and 
work with traders to define the exact requirements of each.
Define the desired lay out of the position manager screen: main view and all 
drill downs.
Use the above to formulate a project plan.

Things requested thus far (no particular order):
Inclusion of Sitara physical deals into the TDS position manager and deal 
ticker.
Customized rows and columns in the position manager (ad hoc rows/columns that 
add up existing position manager rows/columns).
New drill down in the position manager to break out positions by: physical, 
transport, swaps, options, ...
Addition of a curve tab to the position manager to show the real-time values 
of all curves on which the desk has a position.
Ability to split the current position grid to allow daily positions to be 
shown directly above monthly positions.  Each grouped column in the top grid 
would be tied to a grouped column in the bottom grid.
Ability to properly show curve shift for float-for-float deals; determine the 
appropriate positions to show for each:
Gas Daily for monthly index,
Physical gas for Nymex,
Physical gas for Inside Ferc,
Physical gas for Mid market.
Ability for TDS to pull valuation results based on a TDS flag instead of 
using official valuations.
Position and P&L aggregation across all gas desks.
Ability to include the Gas Price book into TDS:
Inclusion of spread options in our systems.  Ability to handle volatility 
skew and correlations.
Ability to revalue all options incrementally throughout the trading day.  
Approximate delta changes between valuations using instantaneous gamma or a 
gamma grid.
Valuation of Gas Daily options.
A new position screen for options (months x strike x delta).  TBD.
Inclusion of positions for exotic options currently managed in spreadsheets.
Ability to isolate the position change due to changed deals in the position 
manager.
Ability to view change deal P&L in the TDS deal ticker.  Show new deal terms, 
prior deal terms, and net P&L affect of the change.
Eliminate change deals with no economic impact from the TDS deal ticker.
Position drill down in the position manager to isolate the impact of 
individual deals on the position total in a grid cell.
Benchmark positions in TDS.
Deployment of TDS in Canada. Currency and volume uom conversions. Implicit 
and explicit position break out issues.

-- Allan.

PS: Colleen is setting up a meeting tomorrow to discuss the direction for 
transport.  Hopefully we'll know much better where that part stands at that 
point.

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakwoodhigh.org>
To: Alex Rodriguez <arodriguez@oakwoodhigh.org>
Subject: RE: World War II Unit - Geography Integration

Alex,

Thank you so much for your response and for your willingness to collaborate on this project! I absolutely love the idea of having students create maps showcasing the key events and battles of the war. It's such a great way to help them visualize the geographic scope of the conflict.

I think it would be fantastic to have our students work together on this mapping project. We could have them collaborate in small groups, with each group focusing on a different region or theater of the war. They could research the key events and battles in their assigned region and create a detailed map that showcases their findings.

I'm so excited about this cross-curricular project and the opportunity for our students to learn from each other. Let's definitely set up a time to discuss this further and start planning the details.

Thank you again for your suggestions and your willingness to collaborate. I can't wait to get started on this!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@econcollege.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@econcollege.edu>
Subject: Collaborating on a Cost-Benefit Analysis Textbook

Hi Michael,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been considering writing a textbook on cost-benefit analysis and believe that your expertise in cost concepts would be invaluable to the project. I was wondering if you would be interested in collaborating with me on this endeavor?

I think our combined knowledge and experience could result in a comprehensive and engaging resource for economics students. If you're open to the idea, we could discuss the structure, content, and our respective roles in more detail.

As you may know, we'll both be attending the upcoming economics conference in Seattle. I was thinking we could meet in person there to further explore this opportunity and outline our collaboration. 

On a personal note, I'm an avid cyclist and have been looking forward to exploring some of the bike routes near the conference venue. If you're interested, perhaps we could join forces and go for a ride together?

I'd love to hear your thoughts on the textbook idea and the potential for our collaboration. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@cyberpsychresearch.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@innovativeschools.org>
Subject: RE: RE: RE: RE: Technology in Education Summit

Hi Emily,

Your proposed structure for the presentation looks great! I agree that dividing the sections based on our respective expertise is an excellent approach. I'll start working on the methodology and data collection section and will share my draft with you for feedback.

As for visual aids, I think it would be impactful to include some graphs and charts showcasing our key findings. We could also incorporate a short video clip of students engaging in the coding activities to help the audience visualize the learning process. I can work on creating these visual elements and send them your way for review.

I'll go ahead and book my flights and accommodation at the Hyatt Regency San Francisco, so we'll be in the same location. It will be great to have those two days to practice and refine our presentation together.

Thank you for taking the lead on organizing this, Emily. I'm confident that our presentation will be well-received and will spark some great discussions among the conference attendees.

I'll be in touch soon with updates on the visual aids and the presentation content.

Best regards,
Alex

It was wonderful to meet you at the conference last week and discover our shared interest in the Pilgrims and the Mayflower voyage. Let me know if you're free to meet up sometime in the next couple of weeks. I'd be curious to hear more about your research on the social and political impact of the Pilgrims' journey, and I can share some of my findings on their theological motivations.

Best,
David

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@healthsciencewriters.com>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@mededpro.org>
Subject: RE: Need your expertise on a new project

Michael,

Thank you so much for your positive response! I'm thrilled to have you on board for this project. I'll provide you with more details to help you evaluate how you can best contribute.

Project timeline:
- We aim to start production in mid-June and release the first set of videos in September.
- The series will consist of 12 videos, with each video being 5-7 minutes long.
- We'll need your input on script development, content review, and consultation during the production phase.

Target audience:
- The videos will target a general adult audience, with a focus on those who are interested in improving their health literacy and making informed decisions about their well-being.
- We aim to make the content accessible to people with varying levels of health knowledge, so your expertise in simplifying complex information is crucial.

Specific topics for your focus:
- "The Importance of Preventive Care and Screenings"
- "Understanding and Managing Stress"
- "Maintaining a Healthy Diet: Debunking Myths and Misconceptions"
- "The Role of Exercise in Physical and Mental Well-being"

Please let me know your thoughts on these topics and the overall project. I'm open to any suggestions or ideas you may have to make this series as impactful as possible.

Best,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Emily Ashton <emashton@seabrook.edu>
To: David Kim <dkim@environmentalethics.org>
Subject: Fwd: Keynote cancellation

David,

I just got this email from Dr. Simmons - she's had a family emergency and won't be able to give her keynote after all. This is a big blow to the program, especially given her expertise on coastal communities and climate change. Any thoughts on who we could approach as a replacement on such short notice? I'm thinking we should try to find someone who can speak to the human impacts of rising sea levels, to keep with our theme.

Also, I heard back from the city council about our request for a permit for the field trip to the coastal restoration site. They're supportive but want us to provide more details on our safety plan, given the recent storms. I can draft something up, but let me know if you have any specific ideas.

Thanks,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Rajesh Patel <rpatel@unicef.org>
To: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@washadvocates.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on community engagement challenges in CLTS project

Dear Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I remember our engaging conversations at the Global Health Conference and am glad to see that you're making progress on your CLTS project in Cambodia.

Regarding the community engagement challenges you're facing, I can certainly empathize. Mobilizing communities to take collective action is often one of the most difficult aspects of implementing CLTS projects. Based on my experience, a few strategies that have proven effective include:

1. Identifying and engaging local champions who can help spearhead the initiative and inspire their neighbors to take action.
2. Conducting participatory workshops that allow community members to actively discuss the issue of open defecation and its health implications, rather than simply delivering lectures.
3. Providing small, tangible incentives for households that build and use latrines, such as seeds or tools, to encourage early adopters and create a sense of momentum.

I recently returned from a field visit to a CLTS project in Laos, which employed many of these strategies with great success. I can put you in touch with the local NGO that led the project if you're interested in learning more about their approach.

As for potential partners in Southeast Asia, I can connect you with a few colleagues at UNICEF's regional office who have extensive networks in Cambodia. They may be able to introduce you to local organizations working on WASH issues that could support your project.

Please keep me updated on your progress, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any other questions or ideas to discuss. I'm always eager to collaborate with passionate WASH advocates like yourself.

Best wishes,
Rajesh
Dr. Rajesh Patel
Global WASH Specialist
UNICEF

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Liam Rodriguez <liam.rodriguez@rodentia.edu>
To: Jessica Novak <jnovak@spacepolicy.org>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference and joint presentation

Jessica,

"The Windup Girl" is one of my favorites! Bacigalupi's vision of a future shaped by biotechnology and environmental degradation is both haunting and thought-provoking. I'm glad to have found a fellow sci-fi enthusiast.

I think incorporating speculative elements into our presentation is a great idea. We could even draw some inspiration from the novels we've been discussing.

I'll do some more brainstorming on this and come prepared with a few ideas for our call on Wednesday. In the meantime, I'll also start working on an outline for our co-authored paper.

Best,
Liam

body:
<email>
From: Jamie Rivera <jrivera@westsideprep.org>
To: Alex Thompson <athompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Inclusive Soccer Program Update

Hi Alex,

Thanks for the update on the program. It's great to hear that we got the grant funding! That's a huge accomplishment, and it's a testament to all the hard work we've put into this project.

I totally understand the challenges you're facing with scheduling and volunteers. These are issues we'll need to tackle head-on if we want our program to succeed.

For the scheduling conflicts, what if we propose a rotating schedule? We could have the program take place at different times on different days, so that it doesn't always fall during the same class period or after school. That way, we might be able to accommodate more students and not conflict with other activities.

As for the volunteers, I have a few ideas. First, we could reach out to local colleges and universities with physical education or special education programs. They might have students who are interested in gaining experience working with adaptive sports. We could also try contacting local sports clubs or recreation centers to see if they have any volunteers who would be willing to help out.

I think it's important that we have a clear idea of what we're asking volunteers to do and what kind of training or experience they need. We should create a volunteer job description and application form to help us find the right people.

I'd love to brainstorm more ideas with you and figure out a game plan for tackling these challenges. Let me know when you're free to chat, and we can set up a call or video conference.

Looking forward to continuing this work with you,

Jamie

ann.s.chen@accenture.com on 11/20/2001 09:14:57 PM
To:	<Kmcdani@enron.com>
cc:	donald.l.barnhart@accenture.com 
Subject:	SMEs for expert stories


Hello Kirk --

Hope you are doing well!

Just wanted to let you know that I will be taking over the role of
producint the expert stories for our simulation.  I understand you will be
obtaining the SMEs who will be providing us with expert stories.  Thank you
for your help.  Here are a few guidlines to keep in mind:

Number of SMEs needed:  10
Number of expert stories: 20-25
Characteristics: SME needs to be willing to speak in front of the camera, a
mix of structurers, originators and traders


I've included below a slightly revised version of the process that we will
follow for working with the SMEs to develop and film the stories.  The main
difference is that we need to get the list of SMEs by 11/28, instead of
11/30.  By 11/30, we need to have contacted the SMEs and set up time with
them for the following week. I think that to contact 10 SMEs will take at
least 2 days, especially since one of the days is a Friday.

(11/26-11/28)
                         --Obtain contact information for expert story SMEs
(11/28-11/30)
                         --Contact SMEs to give them background regarding
the simulation, describe their role in the simulation, set up a time to
discuss ideas, and set up a time for video shoot.
(12/3-12/6)
               --Meet with SMEs to discuss the categories of content we
need and where they can provide stories.
                          --Send follow-up e-mail asking SMEs to review the
stories (questions and answers) that we will ask them during the video
shoot.
                          --Make changes to stories, if necessary.
                          --Send final stories and video shoot logistics to
SMEs
(12/10-12/12)
                          --Video shoot

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks,
Ann

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emma Larsson <emma.larsson@europeanuniversity.eu>
To: Dr. John Smith <john.smith@usahistorian.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborative project on the Pilgrims

Dear Dr. Smith,

Thank you for your email and for suggesting this collaboration. I am very excited about the prospect of working together on such an intriguing project. Your expertise on the religious aspects of the Pilgrims' settlement will undoubtedly enrich my research on the political implications of their journey and its impact on colonial America.

I agree that our work would complement each other well, and I would be delighted to discuss the structure and content of our joint research in more detail. Perhaps we could schedule a video call to brainstorm ideas and outline our approach?

I look forward to hearing from you and taking the first steps in this exciting collaboration.

Best regards,
Dr. Emma Larsson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Oliver Beckett <obeckett@university.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@pinegrove.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on new history curriculum

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out and for thinking of me for this exciting project. I would be delighted to collaborate with you on developing this new middle school history curriculum. Your passion for using technology to engage students in learning about history is truly inspiring, and I believe that my expertise in ancient European history could be a valuable asset to the project.

I have been doing some research on the interactions between the Celts, Romans, Saxons, and Vikings, and I recently uncovered some fascinating new evidence that challenges some of the commonly held beliefs about these groups. I would be happy to share this information with you and explore how we could incorporate it into the curriculum to make it more engaging and accurate.

I am particularly interested in developing interactive, technology-based learning modules that bring the past to life for students. For example, we could create a virtual reality simulation that allows students to experience what it was like to be a Celt living under Roman rule, or a Viking trader navigating the complex trade networks of the time.

I would love to set up a time to chat more about this project and brainstorm some additional ideas. Please let me know your availability in the coming weeks.

Best regards,
Dr. Oliver Beckett
Department of Archaeology
University of East Anglia
label: research

To: rebende@earthlink.net, jimgriffeth@compuserve.com, 
	kevinfinnan@compuserve.com
Subject: Bristol Babcock/Pagosa Energy - Well Master/Enron meeting notes
Cc: anthony.gilmore@enron.com, roy.hartstein@enron.com, 
	jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: anthony.gilmore@enron.com, roy.hartstein@enron.com, 
	jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
X-From: Jeff Youngflesh
X-To: Bender Rob <rebende@earthlink.net>, JimGriffeth@compuserve.com, KevinFinnan@compuserve.com
X-cc: Anthony Gilmore, Roy Hartstein, Jennifer Medcalf
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Meeting Minutes: Bristol Babcock, Pagosa Energy/Well Master, EBS, and GSS
Meeting Purpose:  Business overview, solutions identification/brainstorming
Date: 12/1/00

Enron

EBS Attendee:
Anthony Gilmore
Global Strategic Sourcing Attendee: 
Jeff Youngflesh

Bristol Babcock
Kevin Finnan
Jim Griffeth

Pagosa Energy/Well Master
Rob Bender


DISCUSSION POINTS:

1)  Bristol and Well Master feel that there is significant opportunity, with 
placement of enough BBI TeleFlow devices (integrated flow computer, 
corrector, recorder and controller/RTU) in North America that the data 
transmission needs would generate enough bandwidth demand that it would be of 
interest to EBS to provide some of its solutions to Bristol & Pagosa Energy 
"unified solutions" (quotes are mine - JKY) for the gas industry.  NOTE:  
this could take a longer term to reach the necessary "critical status", due 
to the need for a very large hardware install base since each TeleFlow 
generates only about 11 - 12,000 bytes of data per day in its report bursts.
1a)  In this scenario, the EBS opportunity would be primarily driven by sales 
of product solutions by BBI and Pagosa, which would include EBS network 
capacity.  (a "sell-through" effect for EBS)

2)  There could also be enough demand for bandwidth- or related EBS solutions 
to Bristol by including Bristol's own internal I/T bandwidth consumption that 
a near-term solutions engagement would be desirable.  NOTE:  this could 
accelerate to the necessary "critical status", bringing to EBS more solutions 
demand due to the addition of "sell-to".  The "sell-through" effect would be 
present with Bristol/Pagosa selling solutions which use EBS' solutions (a 
sales "channel"), as well as EBS "sell-to" BBI & Pagosa for their own 
internal consumption of bandwidth.
____________________________________________________________________


ACTION ITEMS:  
1)  Bristol will provide Anthony (Tony) Gilmore of Enron Broadband Services 
the necessary contact information for the appropriate people in FKI's 
(Bristol's parent co.) Info/Technology area.

2) Enron GSS contacts (J Youngflesh) will attempt to ascertain if there would 
be value to Enron (GPG?) and/or its customers if they had the ability to 
execute nomination control all the way to the ground (upstream of gas 
well-head).

3) EBS (Tony Gilmore) will begin working on the I/T discovery process, 
attempting to aggregate total Bandwidth demand: (usage patterns/volume/etc.) 
at Bristol and/or Pagosa.
3a)  Per Rob Bender, Tony Gilmore should be contacting Al Freimeyer (sp?) at 
Pagosa to understand the volum of data from their daily batches from 
well-to-vendor.  Rob provided Tony Al's telephone number on 12/1.

4)  Enron GSS to contact Ron Smith - waterSCADA.com - to investigate parallel 
opportunity (gas / water analog).

5)  EBS and BBI/Pagosa will begin (internal efforts) to figure out ways of 
getting the TeleFlow CDPD data onto the EBS "Enron Intelligent Network"

Next Meeting: TBD

Please let me know if I've missed anything.


Thank you, 

Jeff

Jeff Youngflesh
Director, Business Development
Global Strategic Sourcing
Enron Corp.
333 Clay Street, 11th Floor
Houston, TX 77002
t:  713-345-5968
f:  713-646-2450
c:  713-410-6716




	Bender Rob <rebende@earthlink.net>
	12/05/2000 08:50 AM
		 
		 To: jeff.youngflesh@enron.com
		 cc: Anthony_Gilmore@enron.net
		 Subject: Meeting 12-1-00

Dear Jeff:

It was a pleasure meeting with you last Friday with Jim Griffith and
Kevin Finnan of Bristol Babcock.  Perhaps by now you have had an
opportunity to review the  http://wells.pagosaenergy.com web site and
look at aspects of the "demo" section.  This is a very dynamic program
with changes, upgrades, and customization taking place all the time to
meet the individual needs of our customers.

There may well be a good fit here as we are seeking ever faster means of
communication and will be requiring a substantial infrastructure not
only for communications but for data base hosting as well.  While yet in
its infancy we have received very positive feedback and interest from
numerous oil and gas companies in the industry.  An alliance with Enron
to help us on the road to becoming the "Microsoft" of oil and gas well
automation would be a very alluring prospect.  I would like to keep a
dialog going between us to scope out areas of mutual benefit for our two
companies where such an alliance would make sense.

I hope to hear from you soon.

Sincerely,
Rob Bender,
President - PagosaEnergy.com
rob@pagosaenergy.com

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: Michael Lee <mlee@researchinstitute.org>
Subject: Congratulations on your recent publication!

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out and congratulate you on your recent publication in the Journal of Virology. I read your paper on the novel animal model for HIV and found it to be a fascinating and important contribution to the field.

I was particularly impressed by your team's approach to modeling the early stages of HIV infection and the insights you gained into the immune response. Your findings could have significant implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

I would love to discuss your work further and explore potential collaborations between our labs. Do you have any upcoming availability for a call or virtual meeting?

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

<email>
From: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@email.com>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@email.com>
Subject: RE: Cassini's Grand Finale

Hi Alex,

That's fantastic progress on your project! I'm really looking forward to seeing what you discover about Saturn's rings. If you need any help or want to bounce ideas off someone, feel free to reach out.

Now, about the total solar eclipse, I think that's an incredible idea! I've never witnessed one before, and it would be an amazing experience to share it with a fellow astronomy enthusiast. I'm definitely in!

Let's start planning the trip. Do you have any specific locations in mind for the best viewing spots? We should also consider accommodation and transportation options. I'm happy to help with the arrangements.

Excited for this adventure!

Cheers,
Jordan
