Subject: UPDATE - Supported Internet Email Addresses
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Enron Global Technology@ENRON
X-To: All Enron Worldwide@ENRON <??SAll Enron Worldwide@ENRON>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


Earlier this week, Enron Global Technology announced the plan to decommission the use of all non-standard Internet Email address formats. As mentioned in the previous communication, this was the first of several communications to be sent by the Enron Global Technology group and we will continue to provide more details in the coming weeks regarding this significant but necessary change to our Email environment.
 
We are working toward a cut-off date of January 14, 2002, at which time we will no longer support Email addresses that do not follow the standard format of firstname.lastname@enron.com (or firstname.middleinitial.lastname@enron.com if your name in Lotus Notes or Outlook has a middle initial in it). We understand that it will take time to make the necessary arrangements to begin using the standard Email address format, but it is important to begin making the change now.
 
If you have questions, please send an Email to Enron.Messaging.Administration@enron.com.
 
Thank you for your support.
 
Enron Global Technology
 
 
 
-----Original Message----- 
From: Enron Announcements/Corp/Enron@ENRON on behalf of Enron Messaging Administration 
Sent: Mon 10/15/2001 9:15 PM 
To: All Enron Worldwide@ENRON 
Cc: 
Subject: Supported Internet Email Addresses



Enron Global Technology is in the process of decommissioning the support for all non-standard Internet Email address formats. The only Internet Email address format that will be supported, once this effort is completed, is firstname.lastname@enron.com. We will no longer support Internet Email address formats such as name@enron.com, name@ect.enron.com, name@ei.enron.com  (where "name" is an abbreviation, acronym or alternative to an employees firstname and/or lastname). Every Enron employee has an Internet Email address of firstname.lastname@enron.com and must begin making the necessary arrangements to start using this Internet address format if they are not using it already.

Any new/existing application systems or business cards that reference a non-supported Internet Email address will need to be changed to reference the only supported firstname.lastname@enron.com Internet address format. It is important to remember to also notify any external contacts who are currently sending Internet email to any non-supported Internet Email addresses.

To determine what your supported Internet Email address is, take your name as it appears in Outlook or Lotus Notes and replace any "spaces" that appear in your name with periods and append @enron.com. For example in Outlook, Alan Smith, Robert (firstname = Robert, Lastname = Alan Smith) will have a supported Internet Email address of robert.alan.smith@enron.com.

IMPORTANT : If you need to update your business card(s) to reflect your supported Internet Email address, please ensure you test & confirm the delivery of Internet email to your supported email address prior to updating your business cards. If you experience any issues with delivery of Internet email to your supported Internet email address, please contact the Resolution Center.

We will communicate further details, including the cut-off date, in the coming weeks. Meanwhile, it is imperative that you begin making the necessary arrangements to change over to using the firstname.lastname@enron.com Internet Email address format. If you have questions regarding this email, send an Email to enron.messaging.administration@enron.com.

Thank you for participation, cooperation and support. 

Enron Messaging Administration

_____________________DAVID COURSEY_____________________

WINDOWS XP URBAN LEGENDS AND MYTHS--DEBUNKED!

    As the clamor about Windows XP grows--it's
         being officially launched tomorrow--so
         does the confusion. I'll take a look at the
         most common misconceptions and questions
         about licensing, authorization, and compatibility
         and give you some answers.

http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1024/2819735:8593142


#


_____________________NEWS ANALYSIS_____________________

Patrick Houston

    HOW WIN XP MARKS THE END OF THE PC'S PLANNED OBSOLESCENCE

    The debut of Windows XP could stand as
    an occasion more momentous than Microsoft
    itself anticipated. Reason: At the
    same time we're saying hello to the new
    OS, we could be saying goodbye to the
    Microsoft-Intel duopoly.

     PLUS:

     APPLE REVEALS ITS 'BREAKTHROUGH' GADGET


      AS TECH SHRINKS, SO DO THE PAYCHECKS


http://cgi.zdnet.com/slink?/adeskb/adt1024/2819777:8593142





_____________________EXPERT ADVICE_____________________


Robert Vamosi

  WINDOWS XP JUST DOESN'T CUT IT IN THE SECURITY DEPARTMENT

   Like those cheesy all-in-one stereos from
         the '70s, the components in Windows XP are
         inferior to their standalone counterparts--especially
         when it comes to security. Robert points out

Robert,

And please, do let me know how the projects go with your students. I'm always looking for ways to improve and refine these ideas, so any feedback you can provide will be incredibly valuable.

body:
<email>
From: Isabel Silva <isabel.silva@universidadebrasiliana.edu.br>
To: James Thompson <james.thompson@globalstudies.org>
Subject: RE: Your upcoming visit to São Paulo

James,

I'm glad to hear you're looking forward to your visit. The hotel and restaurant are aware of your vegetarian preference, so you can expect some delicious plant-based Brazilian dishes.

Thank you for sharing the article on Bolsa Família. It's a program I've been following closely, and I appreciate any new insights. I'll be sure to read it thoroughly.

As for hiking, there are some beautiful spots near São Paulo. I recommend the Cantareira State Park, which offers a variety of trails with stunning views of the Atlantic Forest. If you have time, you might also consider visiting the Ibitipoca State Park, about 200 km from São Paulo, known for its waterfalls and rock formations.

Safe travels, and see you soon!

Best,
Isabel

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 2000 11:27:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: frank.hayden@enron.com
Subject: Re: Re Larry May - REVISED
Cc: susan.scott@enron.com, dutch.quigley@enron.com, jeffrey.gossett@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: susan.scott@enron.com, dutch.quigley@enron.com, jeffrey.gossett@enron.com
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Frank Hayden
X-cc: Susan M Scott, Dutch Quigley, Jeffrey C Gossett
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Frank:
Susan Scott, Larry's risk manager, will compile and send you a spreadsheet of 
total p&l minus new deal p&l since June 1.   Can you review this data and 
compare it to the respective VAR numbers for these dates.  I think you will 
see the VAR numbers way overestimate his p&l volatility.
John


   
	Enron North America Corp.
	
	From:  Frank Hayden @ ENRON                           07/14/2000 05:17 PM
	

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Re Larry May - REVISED


John,
I apologize for the delay in responding, I was in class today.
We are having difficulty backtesting Larry May's VaR.   It looks as if during 
the month of June, the book administor  loaded the spreadsheets into ERMS but 
assigned multiple master deal ID's.  (the code is "NG-OPT-XL-PRC")
For example Larry May is showing the following during the month of June: 
June 1st  $797 million dollars loss
June 2nd +192 million dollars made
June 5th $300 million dollars made... (etc..)

This problem makes it impossible to backtest....

Second, regarding a different approach, the immediate solution was the 
allocation of an additional $5 million dollars of VaR, thereby temporarily 
increasing your limit to $45 million.  This limit increase is in effect until 
July 26th.  The game plan is that during this time period, a better solution 
can be devised..... 

I hope this helps.
Thanks,
Frank


 



John Arnold@ECT
07/14/2000 02:33 PM
To: Frank Hayden/Corp/Enron@Enron
cc:  

Subject: 

Frank:
Just following up on two topics.
One: Larry May's book continues to run at a VAR of 2,500,00 despite the fact 
his P&L is never close to that.  Can you check that his exotics book 
positions are being picked up in his VAR calcs.

Second:  Have you looked into applying a band-aid to the understating longer 
term Vol problem until we change formulas?

John

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@who.int>
To: John Smith <john.smith@washngo.org>
Subject: RE: Request for guidance on scaling our WASH project

Dear John,

It's great to hear from you! I remember our conversation at the conference and am glad to hear that your WASH project has been successful. Scaling up is an exciting next step, and I'd be happy to provide some guidance.

Based on my experience, the key to successful scaling is to have a clear strategy, robust monitoring and evaluation system, and strong partnerships. I can share some resources on these topics and also introduce you to a few colleagues who have worked on similar projects in the region.

If you can provide more details on your current project, such as the specific interventions, target population, and initial results, that would be helpful for me to give more targeted advice.

I'm also happy to schedule a call to discuss this further if that would be useful.

Looking forward to supporting your important work!

Best,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Smith <jenna.smith@nursing.edu>
To: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@biologyuniversity.edu>
Subject: Guest post opportunity for your respiratory physiology journey

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well and enjoying your studies. I remember how passionate you were about respiratory physiology when we first met during my clinical rotation at your high school. It's great to see you pursuing your interests in university!

I wanted to reach out because I've recently started a blog focused on respiratory health and patient education. I was wondering if you'd be interested in writing a guest post about your experiences as a student studying respiratory physiology. I think our readers would love to hear about your journey and learn about the resources you've found helpful in your studies.

If you're interested, I'd be happy to provide you with some guidelines and answer any questions you may have. I think this could be a great opportunity for you to showcase your knowledge and writing skills.

Let me know what you think!

Best regards,
Jenna Smith, RN

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@healthsciencewriters.com>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@animaladvocates.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking information on animal testing alternatives

Alex,

Thank you so much for your thoughtful response and for providing the expert contacts. Your insights on addressing potential resistance and highlighting the scientific and ethical advantages of alternative methods are incredibly valuable.

I will definitely reach out to the experts you recommended and include their perspectives in the resource I'm developing. Your input has been instrumental in shaping the direction of this project and ensuring that it presents a comprehensive and balanced view of the topic.

I appreciate your dedication to promoting humane research practices and your willingness to collaborate on this important initiative. It's clear that by working together and sharing knowledge, we can make a meaningful impact on the future of scientific research.

Once the resource is complete, I would be happy to share it with you and get your feedback. I'll also make sure to acknowledge your contributions and the insights you provided.

Thank you again for your time and expertise. I look forward to staying in touch and continuing to work towards a more compassionate future for research.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: dave forster
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Dave:
A couple of issues:

1.  We continue to have a number of transactions that fail because of credit 
exposure.  These are companies that have excellent credit, such as Duke, 
Dynegy, Equitable, Mieco, etc, but have a fixed credit line on EOL that they 
blow through periodically.  They get a failed trade and it often takes 5-10 
minutes to rectify the problem, at which time we've lost the trade.   We need 
the major counterparties to have unlimited credit on EOL, just as they have 
in normal trading.

2.  As a corrallary, I am under the impression that when a trade fails 
because of credit, the counterparty does not get an explanatory error message 
describing what happened and what to do.  When a credit failure happens, the 
counterparty will often keep clicking on the same product, getting the same 
error message

Subject: RE: Interesting article on particle physics education

David,

I'm so glad you found the article helpful! I'd be more than happy to brainstorm some ideas for interactive activities and demos. In fact, I've been working on a few myself for my research project. One idea I've been playing around with is using a giant inflatable balloon to demonstrate the concept of quark confinement. I think it could be a really engaging way to illustrate the idea that quarks are never found in isolation.

I'm also curious to know more about how you're structuring your new curriculum. Are you focusing on any particular topics or themes?

Looking forward to collaborating with you on this!

Emily

body:
<email>
From: Emily Starlight <estarlight@starsdale.edu>
To: Alex Greenfield <agreenfield@starsdale.edu>
Subject: Stargazing and Sustainable Farming Event Planning

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well! As we discussed, I think our interdisciplinary event "Stargazing and Sustainable Farming: A Night of Science and Wonder" has the potential to be really engaging and informative for the local community. 

To get the ball rolling, I've secured the university's observatory as our venue for the stargazing portion of the event. It has a great view of the night sky and plenty of space for attendees. I was thinking we could start the event with a brief presentation on the basics of astronomy and how it relates to our understanding of Earth and its place in the universe.

What do you think about having a few interactive stations set up where attendees can learn about sustainable farming practices and see some of the technologies we use in action? We could have a demo of soil moisture sensors, a virtual reality experience of a precision agriculture drone flight, and a hands-on activity where people can plant their own mini herb garden to take home.

Let me know your thoughts on this and if you have any other ideas for making the event engaging and memorable for our attendees. I'd love to brainstorm further and start promoting the event to the community.

Best,
Emily

body:
Message-ID: <21051369.1075849624623.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Mon, 4 Dec 2000 02:18:00 -0800 (PST)
From: jeff.youngflesh@enron.com
To: thadwhite@avaya.com
Subject: Enron/Avaya Meeting in Basking Ridge, wk of Jan 8, '01
Cc: kroswald@avaya.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: kroswald@avaya.com
X-From: Jeff Youngflesh
X-To: thadwhite@avaya.com
X-cc: kroswald@avaya.com
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Thad,

Would you please get the calendars of your execs synchronized, and tell us 
which 2-day period the week of January 8 - 12, 2001 works best for our mutual 
meetings?  We were originally looking at the 9th, 10th, or 11th as days to 
choose from primarily to avoid having the EBS executives located in the 
western U.S. travel from Portland, OR on Sunday for meetings on Monday in 
NJ.  Consequently, I had asked the EBS executives to pencil in the 9th - 11th 
of January, and got the final one to confirm late last week.  

However, Kim Godfrey at EBS may have some new requirements; which is why I 
need your help in an expedited way - I'll need to give Kim your executives' 
availability during that week, and then we'll get things locked in ASAP.The 
meetings would still be scheduled such that the 1st meeting day would be for 
the meetings to be held during the 2nd half of that day, from 2-4 hours of 
meeting time for the executives (VP & up, primarily) to discuss possible 
alignments and opportunities.  This would include two primary areas:

1)  EBS-sell-to-Avaya for Avaya internal use:  what types of potential 
solutions EBS could offer Avaya for Avaya's internal use; and
2)  EBS & Avaya join together in a product and/or marketing effort to 
determine what kinds of solutions which the could jointly propose to the 
(common) markets served:  "sell with" (each other); and "sell through" 
(channels type efforts), where either or both Avaya and EBS would act as 
sales channels for each other's sales forces.

These meetings would be followed by the 2nd day's session(s), which would 
include primarily development and marketing team members who would discuss 
areas in which Avaya and EBS could develop one or more joint value 
propositions, such that they would have a "jumping off point" for a 
go-to-market effort (item #2, above).  In addition, the technical aspects of 
some of the 
"EBS-would-like-to-sell-its-services-to-Avaya-for-Avaya-internal-use" (item 
#1, above) meetings from the Executive session the 1st day could then be 
addressed.

Please let me know which 2-day period looks like the most workable one for 
your executives at Avaya HQ during the week of 1/8/01, so that I can get to 
Kim to allow her to get the EBS executives' schedules locked into days 
synchronized with your executives'.  

Thank you,

Jeff

Jeff Youngflesh
Director, Business Development
Global Strategic Sourcing
Enron Corp.
333 Clay Street, 11th Floor
Houston, TX 77002
t:  713-345-5968
f:  713-646-2450
c:  713-410-6716

body:
<email>
From: Jessica Thompson <jthompson@oakvilleelementary.org>
To: Robert Martinez <rmartinez@oakvilleelementary.org>
Subject: RE: New Curriculum Update

Robert,

Thank you so much for your support and encouragement. I am excited to work with you on expanding this program and making a difference in our students' lives.

I am available next week on Tuesday from 2 pm to 4 pm and on Thursday from 1 pm to 3 pm. Please let me know which time works best for you, and I will make sure to be available.

I have also been thinking about how we can ensure the sustainability of this program, especially if I decide to pursue the curriculum development position at the district level. I would love to discuss this with you and get your insights on how we can continue the momentum we have built.

Thank you again for your support. I am looking forward to our meeting.

Best regards,
Jessica
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@university.edu>
To: Robert Thompson <robert.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Environmental Justice course collaboration

Hi Robert,

I'm glad you're open to discussing our different teaching styles. I think it's important for us to find a way to present a united front to our students, even if we have different perspectives on some issues.

I've been giving some thought to the potential pushback or criticism we might receive from colleagues or parents regarding the course content. I think it's important for us to have a clear rationale for our choices and to be prepared to address any concerns that arise.

I'm free next Wednesday at 2 pm if you'd like to meet then. We could discuss our ideas for the course structure and content, as well as our strategies for handling potential challenges.

Looking forward to our meeting!

Best,
Emily
label: research

To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@college.edu>
Subject: Great meeting you at the conference

Dear Emily,

It was a pleasure meeting you at the "Conflicts and Resolutions" conference in Chicago. I enjoyed our discussion during the Q&A session and found your perspective on the evolution of civil rights in the United States fascinating. I believe our research interests complement each other, and I would love to stay in touch and continue our conversation.

I've attached a link to my recent publication on the Kashmir conflict, which I thought you might find interesting. I would also be grateful for any recommendations you have on resources related to your work on social justice issues in the American context.

Looking forward to hearing from you and potentially collaborating in the future.

Best regards,
Sanjay

Effective Monday, October 22, 2001 the following changes will be made to the Autohedge functionality on EnronOnline.

The volume on the hedge will now respect the minimum volume and volume increment settings on the parent product. See rules below: 

?	If the transaction volume on the child is less than half of the parent's minimum volume no hedge will occur.
?	If the transaction volume on the child is more than half the parent's minimum volume but less than half the volume increment on the parent, the hedge will volume will be the parent's minimum volume.
?	For all other volumes, the same rounding rules will apply based on the volume increment on the parent product.

Please see example below:

Parent's Settings:
Minimum: 	5000
Increment:  1000

Volume on Autohedge transaction			Volume Hedged
1      - 2499							0
2500 - 5499							5000
5500 - 6499							6000

<email>
From: Alex Johnson <ajohnson@spacecraftdesigns.com>
To: Samantha Lee <slee@spacecraftdesigns.com>
Subject: NASA's latest update on the Mars 2020 mission

Hey Sam,

I hope you're doing well! I just came across this article about NASA's Mars 2020 mission and thought you'd find it interesting. They've released some new images from the Perseverance rover and the insights they've gained so far are incredible!

https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/mars-2020-new-images

I'm particularly fascinated by the rock samples they've collected and the potential implications for understanding Mars' geological history. It makes me even more excited about our own spacecraft project and the possibilities it holds for future exploration.

What do you think about the new findings? Have you had any breakthroughs on the software side of our project lately?

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <arivera@oakwoodes.org>
To: Jenna Thompson <jthompson@oakwoodes.org>
Subject: RE: Introducing myself and an idea

Hi Jenna,

It's great to meet you and I'm so glad you reached out! Welcome to Oakwood. I'm really excited to hear about your work with our DHH students and your idea for an arts-focused program for them. I think that's a fantastic concept and could be incredibly impactful.

A few initial thoughts:
- We could potentially incorporate some visual storytelling and theater elements to help the students express themselves and build confidence. I know a great organization in the city that does really innovative work in this area with kids who are DHH.
- Music could be a powerful way to engage the students as well, even if it needs to be adapted. I've seen some cool programs that use vibrations and visual cues to teach music to DHH kids.
- It would be great to get some of the students' families involved too, to help them support their child's learning and creativity at home.

I'd be really happy to help you brainstorm further and connect you with some other educators and organizations who could be great resources. I think this program has so much potential!

Also, I'd be glad to write a letter of support for your grant proposal. Just send me over the details and let me know what you need from me.

Let me know if you want to grab coffee sometime soon to chat more. I'm happy to introduce you to some of my colleagues as well who I think would be really interested in getting involved.

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@university.edu>
To: David Thompson <david.thompson@conservation.org>
Subject: Final touches on the grant proposal

Hi David,

I hope you're doing well. I've been reviewing our grant proposal and I think we've made some great progress. However, I have a few suggestions for the final revisions before we submit it.

1. In the introduction, I think we should emphasize the potential impact of our research on combating desertification more clearly. We could mention the recent droughts in the region and how our biodegradable polymers could help mitigate their effects.

2. In the methodology section, I suggest we provide more details on the specific types of polymers we plan to use and how they will be synthesized. This will give the reviewers a better understanding of the technical aspects of our project.

3. Finally, I think we should add a brief discussion on the potential scalability of our approach and how it could be applied to other regions facing similar issues.

Let me know your thoughts on these suggestions. If you agree, I can make the changes and send you the updated draft by Friday for your final review. Our deadline is next Monday, so we should have plenty of time to make any last-minute adjustments.

I appreciate your collaboration on this project. It's been a pleasure working with you.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

A conference call was held today with FERC staffers to discuss items of interest or concern to us.  Participating for FERC were Bob Pease (enforcement att'y), Stuart Fisher (economist) and Bruce Poole (engineer).  Alan Comnes, Dave Perrino and I weighed in for Enron.  The laundry list of topics discussed is attached.  We expressed the sentiment that the root cause of all these issues and concerns is the current composition (and non-independence) of the ISO board, and suggested that the ISO board situation should be the subject of the upcoming FERC audit of ISO.  We went on to discuss the audit further and the fact that there is no established or formal comment process.  However, we were invited to file written comments with the Commission on what we thought should be audited, and Alan is taking the lead on this.  We will try to get others to sign on to the comments.  Some of the discussion items that the staff was highly interested in included:

	ISO request for a bid from us to prop up the price (staff requested a copy of the transcript).
	Any unexplained decreases in ATC (staff asked to be advised in real time).
	Information related to ISO OOM purchases (and whether they were declining).

All in all, it was a successful, informal call lasting about 40 minutes.  Staff was receptive to and agreed to receive periodic calls from us in the future.  This allows them to keep up with what is going on industry, and of course gives us an opportunity to educate and alert them on issues of interest to us.  Ray

you can answer that.

 Developers guarantee note, not investors.

         Since this project appears so promising, it seems like we should

any way.  It is my desire to build a successful project with Creekside that 
leads to future opportunities.  I  am happy to provide you with any 
information that you need to evaluate myself or Keith as a business partner.

Sincerely,

Phillip Allen

body:
<email>
From: Juliana Santos <jmsantos@usp.br>
To: Rodrigo Almeida <ralmeida@unb.br>
Subject: RE: Great news!

Rodrigo,

Congratulations on getting our paper accepted! This is a huge accomplishment, and I'm so grateful for your hard work in finalizing the manuscript. I'm attaching a small gift to celebrate - a virtual bottle of Brazilian cachaca. Let's plan to have a virtual celebratory drink soon!

Regarding our next project, I've been thinking a lot about the current political climate in Brazil and how it relates to the historical themes we explored in our paper. One idea I had is to examine the role of social movements in shaping democratic institutions and processes in Brazil, particularly in the post-dictatorship era. There has been a resurgence of social activism in recent years, and I think it would be interesting to analyze how these movements are influencing political outcomes.

Another idea is to explore the impact of economic inequality on democratic stability in Brazil. As you know, Brazil has one of the highest levels of income inequality in the world, and there is a growing body of research suggesting that high levels of inequality can undermine democratic institutions. We could examine how economic disparities have shaped political participation, representation, and policy outcomes in Brazil.

Let me know what you think of these ideas, or if you have any other suggestions. I'm happy to take the lead on drafting a grant proposal for this project, but I would definitely want to collaborate closely with you on the research design and analysis.

I'm looking forward to continuing our partnership and tackling these important research questions together.

Cheers,
Juliana

body:
<email>
From: David Rosenberg <david.rosenberg@academia.com>
To: Emily Holloway <emily.holloway@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Upcoming Conference on Human Evolution

Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I would be delighted to join you as a co-presenter at the conference in Chicago. Our collaborative work has been well-received, and this would be an excellent opportunity to share our findings with a wider audience. I'm confident that our session will generate interesting discussions and feedback.

I'm available to discuss the details and coordinate our presentation. Please let me know the specific date and time of our session, and I'll make the necessary travel arrangements.

On a personal note, I hope we'll have some time to catch up during the conference. If you're up for it, maybe we could go for a hike in one of the city's parks, weather permitting. I know you enjoy hiking, and I'd love to hear more about your recent adventures.

Looking forward to working with you on this presentation and seeing you in Chicago!

Best regards,
David

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@invasivespecies.org>
To: Akira Tanaka <akira.tanaka@nationalmuseumofasianart.gov>
Subject: RE: Collaboration opportunity for upcoming exhibition

Dear Akira,

Thank you for your prompt response. I am excited to move forward with this collaboration and to contribute to the success of the exhibition.

I am available for a call next week on Tuesday, April 18th, either in the morning between 9 AM and 11 AM or in the afternoon between 2 PM and 4 PM (Eastern Time). Please let me know which time slot works best for you, and I will be sure to keep an eye out for your calendar invite.

I appreciate you preparing information about the specific art pieces you would like me to focus on. Having this context will be incredibly helpful as I begin to formulate my thoughts and recommendations for the exhibition.

I am also happy to provide you with any resources or literature that might be relevant to our collaboration. Please don't hesitate to let me know if there is anything specific you would like me to share with you.

I am eager to dive into this project and to work with you to create an exhibition that not only celebrates the beauty of Japanese art but also raises awareness about the importance of environmental conservation.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Johnson
Director, Center for Invasive Species Research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakvilleschool.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakvilleschool.edu>
Subject: RE: Staff meeting presentation

Hi Emily,

Thanks for reaching out about the presentation. I completely agree that this is a great opportunity to share our work and inspire others to incorporate coding into their classrooms.

I think your idea of showcasing some of the activities we've done and the impact we've seen is perfect. We could include some before-and-after examples of student work, as well as some quotes from students about how they've benefited from learning coding.

I'd also like to include some information about the resources and tools we've found most helpful, like the coding websites we've used and the lesson plan templates we've developed. Maybe we could even create a handout with links and tips for getting started?

As for specific examples, I've been really happy with how my students responded to the Scratch project we did last month. They were so creative and engaged, and I think it would be a great project to highlight.

Let me know what you think of these ideas. I'm happy to help with the presentation, too. How about we meet next Wednesday afternoon to work on it together?

Best,
Michael

<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@arthritiscare.com>
To: John Smith <john.smith@medschool.edu>
Subject: RE: Following up from the conference

Hi John,

Your proposed structure for the case report sounds great. I think starting with the patient's medical history and the challenges we faced is a strong approach. We can then delve into the interdisciplinary strategies we employed and the outcomes we achieved.

I agree that regular meetings will be essential as we work on this project. How about we schedule a follow-up meeting for the week after next to review our initial outlines and start discussing the draft in more detail?

I'm attaching a few relevant articles I came across that might be useful for our literature review. Let me know if you have any other resources to share.

Looking forward to our call on Wednesday!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Emily Jennings <emily.jennings@stem-educators.com>
To: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@chemistry-innovators.com>
Subject: RE: Chemistry Modules Update and Interactive Elements

Hi Alex,

Thank you for your suggestions on the interactive elements! I really like the idea of using PhET simulations and creating video demonstrations of key experiments. The interactive quizzes and assessments will also be a great addition to reinforce student understanding.

I'll start incorporating these elements into the modules and will send you the updated content outlines early next week for your review.

I'm so glad you enjoyed the mushroom risotto recipe! It's one of my favorites. I've been experimenting with different variations lately. Here's a link to a recipe I tried recently that adds a twist with truffle oil: [https://www.deliciouschemistry.com/recipes/truffle-mushroom-risotto](https://www.deliciouschemistry.com/recipes/truffle-mushroom-risotto). Let me know if you give it a try!

As we near the completion of this project, I was thinking about showcasing our work at the upcoming chemistry education conference. What do you think about submitting a proposal to present our collaborative effort? I think it would be a great opportunity to receive feedback from our peers and potentially inspire others in the chemistry education community.

Let me know your thoughts on the conference idea. I'm happy to take the lead on the proposal if you're interested.

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Richards <olivia.richards@foodtechinc.com>
To: Dr. Ethan Patel <ethan.patel@culinaryinstitute.edu>
Subject: RE: Interesting finding in our latest product

Ethan,

Thank you so much for taking the time to review the data and provide your insights. Your hypothesis about the Maillard reaction makes a lot of sense, and it aligns with some of our initial thoughts as well.

I'd be more than happy to share more information about the ingredients and processing conditions. In fact, I think collaborating on further research into this compound would be incredibly valuable. Your expertise in the science of cooking and flavor profiles would be a great asset to this project.

I'll put together a more detailed report on the product and its manufacturing process, and we can schedule a call to discuss the next steps for our research. I'm excited to work with you on this and see what we can discover together!

Thanks again for your help,
Olivia

To: Rebecca Artista <rebecca.artistica@lagalleria.com>
Subject: RE: Collaborative Project Ideas

Rebecca,

That's a great idea to bring in guest speakers! I know a few chemists who would be more than happy to talk to the students about the science behind pigments and color. And I love the idea of having local artists share their insights as well.

In fact, I was just talking to a colleague who works at the local science museum. She mentioned that they might be interested in hosting an exhibition of the students' work once the project is complete. I think that would be a great way to showcase what the students have learned and give them a real sense of accomplishment.

Let me know if you want me to reach out to the museum and see if they'd be interested in hosting the exhibition. In the meantime, let's start compiling a list of potential guest speakers and mentors.

Best,
Charles

01:53 PM ---------------------------


Jane M Tholt
04/12/2000 08:45 AM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: SW Gas


---------------------- Forwarded by Jane M Tholt/HOU/ECT on 04/12/2000 10:45 
AM ---------------------------


Laird Dyer
04/12/2000 08:17 AM
To: Jane M Tholt/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: SW Gas

Janie,

Thanks for the fax on SW Gas.

We are meeting with Larry Black, Bob Armstrong & Ed Zub on April 27th to 
discuss asset management.  In preparation for that meeting we would like to 
gain an understanding of the nature of our business relationship with SW.  
Could you, in general terms, describe our sales activities with SW.  What are 
typical quantities and term on sales?  Are there any services we provide?  
How much pipeline capacity do we buy or sell to them?  Who are your main 
contacts at SW Gas?

We will propose to provide a full requirements supply to SW involving our 
control of their assets.  For this to be attractive to SW, we will probably 
have to take on their regulatory risk on gas purchase disallowance with the 
commissions.  This will be difficult as there is no clear mandate from their 
commissions as to what an acceptable portfolio (fixed, indexed, collars....) 
should look like.  Offering them a guaranteed discount to the 1st of month 
index may not be attractive unless we accept their regulatory risk.  That 
risk may not be acceptable to the desk.  I will do some investigation of 
their PGA's and see if there is an opportunity.

As to the asset management:  do you have any preference on structure?  Are 
there elements that you would like to see?  Any ideas at all would be greatly 
appreciated.

Thanks,

Laird

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting New Teaching Method

Hi Emily,

Thanks for sharing this information about Modeling Instruction! I had a chance to look through the resources you attached, and it sounds like a really interesting approach. I like the idea of engaging students in building mental models and helping them develop a deeper understanding of chemical concepts.

I've been thinking about ways to make my lessons more interactive and engaging as well. I recently came across a few websites that offer virtual labs and simulations for chemistry students. I think these could be a great supplement to our regular lab activities and help students visualize some of the concepts we cover in class.

Here are a couple of the websites I found:
- https://chemcollective.org/
- http://www.chemdemos.uoregon.edu/

I'd be interested in hearing your thoughts on these resources and whether you think they might be useful for our students.

It would be great to find some time to chat more about both Modeling Instruction and these virtual labs. Do you have any availability next week to grab a coffee and discuss further?

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Liam Nakamura <liam.nakamura@cretaeceousdinofossils.com>
To: Olivia Jennings <olivia.jennings@montanamuseum.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting new theropod discovery!

Olivia,

I've reviewed the data and photographs you sent over, and I must say, this is a remarkable discovery! The unique features of this fossil are truly intriguing, and I agree that it has the potential to challenge our current understanding of theropod evolution.

However, I have some reservations about classifying it as a new clade or subfamily just yet. The features you've identified, while distinct, could potentially be attributed to individual variation or sexual dimorphism within an existing clade.

I think we need to approach this with caution and consider all possible explanations before proposing a new taxonomic classification. We should also consult with other experts in the field to get their input and insights.

That being said, I'm excited to delve deeper into this research and explore the implications of your discovery. Let's schedule a call early next week to discuss our strategy and outline the key points we want to address in the paper.

I appreciate your enthusiasm and dedication to this project. It's collaborations like these that drive scientific progress and expand our knowledge of the prehistoric world.

Looking forward to our call!

Best,
Liam

Date: Sun, 22 Oct 2000 10:52:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: adam.r.bayer@vanderbilt.edu
Subject: Re: How are you today
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: "Adam Bayer" <adam.r.bayer@vanderbilt.edu> @ ENRON
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Adam:
Hope your interview goes well.  Things are going crazy in the gas market so, 
unfotunately, I'm stuck at my desk and can't go up for interviews.  

As far as the interview goes, my advise would be the same as any interview.  
Be confident.  Answer the question asked.  Don't be afraid to say you don't 
know but don't make excuses.  Express interest in why you find Enron 
appealing compared to the other 100 companies interviewing.  

The trading training program is still in the works.  Few people outside the 
trading area are even aware of its existence at this point so I wouldn't ask 
any questions about it in the interviews.  If you receive an offer, it would 
probably be for a normal analyst position with the opportunity to enter the 
training program when you arrive.  Not sure about that last statement 
though.   The training program is geared towards our two most mature and pure 
trading business areas: gas and power.  There are still a large number of 
other trading spots in our developing commodities side that would not fall 
under the program.   That's a function of the program being developed by the 
head of these two businesses.  Not ready to take it corporate-wide yet.

Write me about how your interviews went.
Good luck:
John




"Adam Bayer" <adam.r.bayer@vanderbilt.edu> on 10/19/2000 03:28:57 PM
To: <john.arnold@enron.com>
cc:  
Subject: How are you today


Hi John,

How are you today?  You must be pleased with Enron's most recent numbers.
Could you tell me a little more about the trading training program?  You
mentioned you wanted to expand it to two years, but what does the extra year
entail?  I have been selected for an interview next Monday, and I look
forward to seeing you again.  Do you have any tips on approaching the
interview process?  I have poured over the company website, and if you have
any tips I would love to hear them.

Thanks for your time, and I hope to see you Monday.

Cordially,

Adam Bayer

rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you 
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with 
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your 
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's you 
bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?  what 
you charge me play against you?)

<email>
From: Jenna Thompson <jthompson@oakwoodes.org>
To: Alex Rivera <arivera@oakwoodes.org>
Subject: Introducing myself and an idea

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out and introduce myself - my name is Jenna Thompson and I'm the new special education teacher at Oakwood, focusing on working with our deaf and hard of hearing (DHH) students. I've heard great things about the arts-integrated programming you're doing and thought I'd reach out to connect.

I'm excited to get more involved in the school community and am especially interested in exploring ways to make arts education more accessible to our DHH students. I've been thinking about potentially starting an after-school club or program specifically for them that incorporates music, theater, visual arts, etc. in ways that support their learning and social development. I'd love to hear your thoughts on this idea and if you'd be open to collaborating in some way.

Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to chat more about this. I'm happy to provide more details on my vision and background. Looking forward to working with you!

Best,
Jenna

Dear Emily,

Thank you for the update. The progress you've made is indeed exciting, and I commend you for your hard work and dedication to the project.

I would be happy to meet with you next week to discuss the results in more detail. How about we meet on Tuesday afternoon, say around 2 PM, in my office? If that doesn't work for you, please suggest another time that suits you better.

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rodriguez <arodriguez@whitman.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakwoodhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Checking in and conference proposal

Emily,

Thanks for your email. I'm glad to hear that things are going well at Oakwood High. Here at Whitman, we've had a bit of a rocky start to the semester with some unexpected staffing changes, but we're starting to find our footing.

I did have a chance to review the conference proposal, and I think it looks great! You've done a fantastic job outlining our main points and supporting evidence. If it's okay with you, I'd like to add a brief section on the importance of fostering a growth mindset in chemistry students. I think it ties in nicely with our overall theme of effective teaching strategies.

As for your suggestion about including technology, I completely agree. I've been using a few different tools in my classes as well, and I think it would be valuable to share our experiences with the conference attendees. Perhaps we could each present one or two of our favorite tools and then facilitate a discussion with the audience about their own experiences and ideas.

I'm really excited about our proposal, and I think it will be a great session. I'm looking forward to fine-tuning it with you over the next few weeks.

Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Elena Petrova <elena.petrova@msu.ru>
To: James Thompson <james.thompson@loc.gov>
Subject: Exciting new find on the Alaska Purchase

James,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been doing some digging in the Russian State Archives and came across a previously unknown letter from Tsar Alexander II to his foreign minister, Prince Gorchakov, discussing the negotiations leading up to the Alaska Purchase. It sheds new light on the Russian motivations behind the sale and could significantly impact our argument about the geopolitical implications of the transaction.

I've attached a translation of the letter for you to review. I'd love to hear your thoughts on how we might incorporate this new information into our lecture and paper. Do you think it warrants a restructuring of our argument, or can we simply integrate it into our existing framework?

Looking forward to discussing this further and hearing your insights.

Best,
Elena
label: research

From: Dr. Emily Johnson <ejohnson@obgynassociates.com>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@obgynassociates.com>
Subject: RE: Patient Sarah Thompson - Vaccination Concerns

Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to touch base with you regarding our patient, Sarah Thompson. As you know, we've been closely monitoring her pregnancy due to her age and pre-existing diabetes. During her last appointment, she expressed concerns about receiving the recommended vaccinations, citing some misinformation she found online.

Given her high-risk status and the approaching due date, I believe it's crucial that we address her concerns and ensure she receives the necessary vaccinations. I was thinking we could set up a joint appointment to discuss this with her and provide her with accurate information to help her make an informed decision.

Please let me know your thoughts and availability for a joint appointment. I appreciate your input and collaboration on this case.

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@publichealth.gov>
To: James Thompson <jthompson@university.edu>
Subject: Re: Collaboration on vector-borne diseases and literature

Hi James,

I hope you're doing well. I've been thinking more about our discussion on the science journalist's story and how we could expand on it. I think there's potential for a book that explores the historical and social impact of vector-borne diseases in America, from colonial times to the present.

I envision a book that combines your expertise in 17th-century American literature and the works of Toni Morrison with my knowledge of disease prevention and control. We could structure it chronologically, with each chapter focusing on a different time period and the vector-borne diseases that were prevalent then. Your insights on how these diseases were depicted in literature and affected society would be invaluable.

What do you think? Would you be interested in co-authoring such a book? If so, we could start brainstorming potential publishers and how to divide the work between us.

Best,

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <enguyen@university.edu>
To: Robert Thompson <rthompson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: DNA project update

Hi Robert,

Thanks for reaching out! I'm glad to hear that you're making good progress on the historical aspects of our paper. You raise an excellent point about the biochemical aspects of DNA structure and how they might have influenced public perception.

As I've been researching the molecular structure of DNA, I've been struck by how the double helix model, with its complementary base pairing, seemed to naturally lend itself to the idea of genetic replication and inheritance. It's fascinating to consider how this relatively simple molecular structure has had such profound implications for our understanding of life and evolution.

I think it would be great to include a section in our paper discussing how the biochemical properties of DNA, as they were understood at the time, shaped the public's understanding of the molecule and its role in heredity. I can provide some insights on this from a biochemical perspective, and we can work together to integrate it with your historical analysis.

Let me know when you're available to discuss this further and coordinate our writing efforts.

Best,
Emily
label: research

Subject: Upcoming collaboration on dental care access study

Hey Liam,

I hope you're doing well! As you know, our department heads have asked us to collaborate on the upcoming study regarding dental care access and its impact on social welfare. I'm really excited to work with you on this project and combine our expertise.

To get started, I was thinking we could schedule a meeting to discuss our respective roles and responsibilities, as well as the timeline for the study. Are you available next week for a quick chat? Let me know what works best for you.

Best regards,
Olivia

<email>
From: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@powerplant.com>
To: Ryan Thompson <ryan.thompson@university.edu>
Subject: Water treatment project idea

Hey Ryan,

It was great meeting you at the engineering club meeting last week. I really enjoyed our discussion about optimizing systems and problem-solving. I've been thinking about our conversation and had an idea for a project we could work on together.

At my power plant, we're always looking for ways to improve our water treatment processes and increase efficiency. I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on a digital control system that could monitor water quality in real-time and automatically adjust treatment processes. I think your expertise in digital electronics and circuit design could be really valuable.

Let me know if you're interested, and we can set up a time to discuss the idea further.

Best regards,
Alex

From: Alex Mercer <alex.mercer@university.edu>
To: Samira Patel <samira.patel@research.org>
Subject: New Io data

Hi Samira,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some exciting news - I've come across a new dataset from the Juno mission that provides high-resolution images of Io's surface. The images reveal previously undiscovered volcanic features that could significantly impact our understanding of Io's geological processes.

I think this data could be a great addition to our presentation at the Rome conference. Would you be interested in taking a look and discussing how we might incorporate it into our talk?

Let me know when you have a chance to review the data. I'm happy to set up a video call to discuss further.

Best regards,
Alex

Cary,

Here is the picture of the house I have in mind.  I was going for a simple
farmhouse style to  place on 5 acres near Wimberley.

A few points that might not be obvious from the plans are:

There will be a double porch across the back just like the front
No dormers (Metal roof)
1/2 bath under stairs
Overall dimensions are 55 by 40


What I am looking for is a little design help in the kitchen.  More
cabinets, maybe a different shaped island, and a way to enlarge the pantry.
Reagan
suggested that I find a way to make the exterior more attractive.  I want
to keep a simple roof line to avoid leaks, but I was thinking about
bringing the left
side forward in the front of the house and place 1 gable in the front.
That might look good if the exterior was stone and stucco.  Also the front
porch would
be smaller.

I have 3 bids from builders all around $325,000.  I am ready to go ahead
and have the plans done so I can spec out all the finishings and choose a
builder.
I just wanted to give you the opportunity to do the work.  As I mentioned
my alternative is $0.60/ft.  I thought that since I had a such a detailed
sketch, you might consider the job for less than the $6,000 that Reagan
allowed.

Phillip Allen

Subject: Important Announcement Regarding Document Preservation
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Jim Derrick@ENRON
X-To: All Enron Worldwide@ENRON <??SAll Enron Worldwide@ENRON>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


As you know, Enron, its directors, and certain current and former officers are defendants in litigation in Federal and State court involving the LJM partnerships.

Enron has employed counsel and they will represent Enron and its interests in the litigation.

Under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act, we are required to preserve documents that might be used in the litigation. 

Accordingly, our normal document destruction policies are suspended immediately and shall remain suspended until further notice.

Please retain all documents (which include handwritten notes, recordings, e-mails, and any other method of information recording) that in any way relate to the Company's related party transactions with LJM 1 and LJM 2, including, but not limited to, the formation of these partnerships, any transactions or discussions with the partnerships or its agents, and Enron's accounting for these transactions.

You should know that this document preservation requirement is a requirement of Federal law and you could be individually liable for civil and criminal penalties if you fail to follow these instructions.

You should know that Enron will defend these lawsuits vigorously.  In the meantime, you should not discuss matters related to the lawsuits with anyone other than the appropriate persons at Enron and its counsel.  

If you have any questions, please contact Jim Derrick at 713-853-5550.

body:
<email>
From: Maria Luiza Almeida <marialuiza@usp.br>
To: Jamal Thompson <jthompson@theamplifier.net>
Subject: Checking in and an invitation

Dear Jamal,

I hope this message finds you well. I've been thinking about our conversation at the CFR conference last year and the parallels you drew between Brazil's transition to democracy and the current moment in the U.S. I'm reaching out because I've been working on a book about the role of the judiciary in consolidating democracy here and I think your insights on race and the media in the U.S. would be really valuable as I'm framing my argument.

I'd love to hear more about your work on the Black Lives Matter protests and police reform debates. I'm also writing to extend an invitation - the University of São Paulo is hosting an international symposium on "Law and Social Change" next month and I think you'd be a perfect fit for one of our keynote addresses. I know it's short notice but I would be thrilled if you could join us to speak about the role of the media in shaping public discourse around race and policing in the U.S. 

Please let me know if you might be available and if there's anything I can do to support your participation. I'm happy to cover your travel and accommodation expenses, of course.

I look forward to hearing from you and hopefully seeing you in São Paulo soon.

All the best,
Maria Luiza

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@unc.edu>
To: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@uwm.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborative research idea

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm always excited to collaborate with like-minded colleagues on research related to economics education. Your idea for a study on instructional methods in intro econ courses sounds fascinating.

I've been incorporating more active learning strategies in my classes, like problem-based learning and peer instruction, and have noticed some promising results in terms of student engagement and comprehension. I'd be very interested in formalizing this into a research study to see if the effects hold up empirically.

I'm happy to set aside some time to discuss this further and start brainstorming a study design. I'm fairly flexible in the coming weeks, so just let me know what works best for your schedule for a call.

I look forward to potentially working together on this project!

Best,
Michael

X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Scott,

 I emailed your question to a friend that works for the new company.  I think 
I know the answer to your questions but I want to get the exact details from 
him.  Basically, they will offer energy  online at a fixed price or some 
price that undercuts the current provider.  Then once their sales are large 
enough they will go to the wholesale market to hedge and lock in a profit.  
The risk is that they have built in enough margin to give them room to manage 
the price risk.  This is my best guess.  I will get back to you with more.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Alex Chen <alex.chen@urbaninnovations.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@cedartownschools.org>
Subject: RE: Community Center Project Update

Hi Emily,

Thanks for the update on the educational technology components. I've been really impressed with the work you've been doing and I'm excited to see the latest designs.

I'd be happy to meet next week to discuss your ideas for interactive learning tools. I have a conflict on Tuesday, but Thursday morning works well for me. How about we meet at the community center site at 10am? That way we can walk through the space together and visualize the possibilities.

I've also been thinking about how we can incorporate some geospatial data visualization into the design, to help students understand the relationship between the community center and the surrounding neighborhood. I'd love to get your thoughts on that as well.

Looking forward to our meeting!

Best,
Alex

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 09/19/2000 
04:35 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls


Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austin
that we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this project
should produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.
This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong as
Austin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range for
this market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that we
have uncovered to date in the Austin market.
The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  As
it is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austin
for preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be complete
in less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severe
water treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lot
improvement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in North
Austin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and street
widening.  Even though this property is not likely to require street
widening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pond
requirement, I used this data to be cautious.
 The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is not
expected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quite
successful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as the
adjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.
As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoods
is uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but may
only put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are far
preferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyer
preferences.
The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 and
an extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved site
plan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close into
an A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.
This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in the
profits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discuss
having you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entity
with your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a
1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is a
rental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would then
be the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with an
exchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in San
Antonio if you do not know anyone.
I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,
by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.
Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want to
schedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon as
your schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at any
time.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either
512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is
512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with you
on this project that is sure to be a major winner.
I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusual
events these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpg
downdrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.
One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled to
start the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enough
to knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it took
another week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to take
my wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebra
in her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden this
past week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realize
the enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks as
if she will be ok in the long run.
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC


 - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

body:
Message-ID: <16004214.1075855728430.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Mon, 22 Jan 2001 01:24:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: mike.grigsby@enron.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: mike.grigsby@enron.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

By STEVE EVERLY - The Kansas City Star
Date: 01/20/01 22:15

As natural gas prices rose in December, traders at the New York Mercantile 
Exchange kept one eye on the weather forecast and another on a weekly gas 
storage number. 

The storage figures showed utilities withdrawing huge amounts of gas, and the 
forecast was for frigid weather. Traders put the two together, anticipated a 
supply crunch and drove gas prices to record heights. 

"Traders do that all the time; they're looking forward," said William Burson, 
a trader. "It makes the market for natural gas." 

But the market's response perplexed Chris McGill, the American Gas 
Association's director of gas supply and transportation. He had compiled the 
storage numbers since they were first published in 1994, and in his view the 
numbers were being misinterpreted to show a situation far bleaker than 
reality. 

"It's a little frustrating that they don't take the time to understand what 
we are reporting," McGill said. 

As consumer outrage builds over high heating bills, the hunt for reasons -- 
and culprits -- is on. Some within the natural gas industry are pointing 
fingers at Wall Street. 

Stephen Adik, senior vice president of the Indiana utility NiSource, recently 
stepped before an industry conference and blamed the market's speculators for 
the rise in gas prices. 

"It's my firm belief ... that today's gas prices are being manipulated," Adik 
told the trade magazine Public Utilities Fortnightly. 

In California, where natural gas spikes have contributed to an electric 
utility crisis, six investigations are looking into the power industry. 

Closer to home, observers note that utilities and regulators share the blame 
for this winter's startling gas bills, having failed to protect their 
customers and constituents from such price spikes. 

Most utilities, often with the acquiescence of regulators, failed to take 
precautions such as fixed-rate contracts and hedging -- a sort of price 
insurance -- that could have protected their customers by locking in gas 
prices before they soared. 

"We're passing on our gas costs, which we have no control over," said Paul 
Snider, a spokesman for Missouri Gas Energy. 

But critics say the utilities shirked their responsibility to customers. 

"There's been a failure of risk management by utilities, and that needs to 
change," said Ed Krapels, director of gas power services for Energy Security 
Analysis Inc., an energy consulting firm in Wakefield, Mass. 


Hot topic 

Consumers know one thing for certain: Their heating bills are up sharply. In 
many circles, little else is discussed. 

The Rev. Vincent Fraser of Glad Tidings Assembly of God in Kansas City is 
facing a $1,456 December bill for heating the church -- more than double the 
previous December's bill. Church members are suffering from higher bills as 
well. 

The Sunday collection is down, said Fraser, who might have to forgo part of 
his salary. For the first time, the church is unable to meet its financial 
pledge to overseas missionaries because the money is going to heating. 

"It's the talk of the town here," he said. 

A year ago that wasn't a fear. Wholesale gas prices hovered just above $2 per 
thousand cubic feet -- a level that producers say didn't make it worthwhile 
to drill for gas. Utilities were even cutting the gas prices paid by 
customers. 

But trouble was brewing. By spring, gas prices were hitting $4 per thousand 
cubic feet, just as utilities were beginning to buy gas to put into storage 
for winter. 

There was a dip in the fall, but then prices rebounded. By early November, 
prices were at $5 per thousand cubic feet. The federal Energy Information 
Administration was predicting sufficient but tight gas supplies and heating 
bills that would be 30 percent to 40 percent higher. 

But $10 gas was coming. Below-normal temperatures hit much of the country, 
including the Kansas City area, and fears about tight supplies roiled the gas 
markets. 

"It's all about the weather," said Krapels of Energy Security Analysis. 

Wholesale prices exploded to $10 per thousand cubic feet, led by the New York 
traders. Natural gas sealed its reputation as the most price-volatile 
commodity in the world. 


Setting the price 

In the 1980s, the federal government took the caps off the wellhead price of 
gas, allowing it to float. In 1990, the New York Mercantile began trading 
contracts for future delivery of natural gas, and that market soon had 
widespread influence over gas prices. 

The futures contracts are bought and sold for delivery of natural gas as soon 
as next month or as far ahead as three years. Suppliers can lock in sale 
prices for the gas they expect to produce. And big gas consumers, from 
utilities to companies such as Farmland Industries Inc., can lock in what 
they pay for the gas they expect to use. 

There are also speculators who trade the futures contracts with no intention 
of actually buying or selling the gas -- and often with little real knowledge 
of natural gas. 

But if they get on the right side of a price trend, traders don't need to 
know much about gas -- or whatever commodity they're trading. Like all 
futures, the gas contracts are purchased on credit. That leverage adds to 
their volatility and to the traders' ability to make or lose a lot of money 
in a short time. 

As December began, the price of natural gas on the futures market was less 
than $7 per thousand cubic feet. By the end of the month it was nearly $10. 
Much of the spark for the rally came from the American Gas Association's 
weekly storage numbers. 

Utilities buy ahead and store as much as 50 percent of the gas they expect to 
need in the winter. 

Going into the winter, the storage levels were about 5 percent less than 
average, in part because some utilities were holding off on purchasing, in 
hopes that the summer's unusually high $4 to $5 prices would drop. 

Still, the American Gas Association offered assurances that supplies would be 
sufficient. But when below-normal temperatures arrived in November, the 
concerns increased among traders that supplies could be insufficient. 

Then the American Gas Association reported the lowest year-end storage 
numbers since they were first published in 1994. Still, said the 
association's McGill, there was sufficient gas in storage. 

But some utility executives didn't share that view. William Eliason, vice 
president of Kansas Gas Service, said that if December's cold snap had 
continued into January, there could have been a real problem meeting demand. 

"I was getting worried," he said. 

Then suddenly the market turned when January's weather turned warmer. 
Wednesday's storage numbers were better than expected, and futures prices 
dropped more than $1 per thousand cubic feet. 


Just passing through 

Some utilities said there was little else to do about the price increase but 
pass their fuel costs on to customers. 

Among area utilities, Kansas Gas Service increased its customers' cost-of-gas 
charge earlier this month to $8.68 per thousand cubic feet. And Missouri Gas 
Energy has requested an increase to $9.81, to begin Wednesday. 

Sheila Lumpe, chairwoman of the Missouri Public Service Commission, said last 
month that because utilities passed along their wholesale costs, little could 
be done besides urging consumers to join a level-payment plan and to conserve 
energy. 

Kansas Gas Service had a small hedging program in place, which is expected to 
save an average customer about $25 this winter. 

Missouri Gas Energy has no hedging program. It waited until fall to seek an 
extension of the program and then decided to pass when regulators would not 
guarantee that it could recover its hedging costs. 

Now utilities are being asked to justify the decisions that have left 
customers with such high gas bills. And regulators are being asked whether 
they should abandon the practice of letting utilities pass along their fuel 
costs. 

On Friday, Doug Micheel, senior counsel of the Missouri Office of the Public 
Counsel, said his office would ask the Missouri Public Service Commission to 
perform an emergency audit of Missouri Gas Energy's gas purchasing practices. 

"Consumers are taking all the risk," Micheel said. "It's time to consider 
some changes." 


To reach Steve Everly, call (816) 234-4455 or send e-mail to 
severly@kcstar.com. 



------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--
All content , 2001 The Kansas City Star

"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 02/21/2001 06:32:15 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <LLEWTER@austin.rr.com> 
Subject: SM134 Proforma2.xls


There have been some updates to the cost.  The principal change is in the
addition of masonry on the front of the buildings, which I estimate will
costs at least $84,000 additional.  Also, the trim material and labor costs
have been increased.  I still believe that the total cost is more than
sufficient, but there will be additional updates.

The manager's unit is columns J-L, but the total is not included in the B&N
total of rentable units.  Rather, the total cost for the manager's unit and
office is included as a lump sum under amenities.  I may add this back in as
a rentable unit and delete is as an amenity.

The financing cost has been changed in that the cost of the permanent
mortgage has been deleted because we will not need to obtain this for the
construction loan approval, therefore, its cost will be absorbed when this
loan is obtained.

George W. Richards

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nakamoto <emily.nakamoto@datachronicles.com>
To: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@recoveryguru.net>
Subject: Book project update

Hey Alex,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to give you an update on our book project. I've finished the chapter on the history of magnetic storage, and I think it's shaping up nicely. I've attached the draft for your review.

I also had a meeting with a potential publisher last week, and they seem really interested in our project. They're especially excited about the angle we're taking, focusing on the historical context of data storage and its impact on society.

Let me know your thoughts on the chapter and if you have any updates on your end. I'm excited to keep moving forward with this!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Henry Postcardson <henry.postcardson@historian.org>
To: Emily Stampworth <emily.stampworth@collector.net>
Subject: RE: Rare airmail stamp discovery!

Emily,

That's an incredible find! The Curtis Jenny Invert is a true gem in the world of philately. The fact that you found it in such great condition is simply amazing. I've been researching the history behind this particular stamp, and it played a significant role in promoting airmail services in the early days.

I'm attaching a document with some of the information I've gathered so far. I think it'll be a valuable addition to our project.

I'm equally excited about our upcoming meeting at the convention. It's always a pleasure to catch up and share our latest discoveries. Maybe we can even give a presentation about our research there!

Best wishes,
Henry

Hi David,

Thanks for your response! I've gone ahead and booked our flights. We'll be leaving on Thursday morning and returning on Sunday evening. I also booked a hotel room with two beds, so we should be all set on accommodations.

I love the idea of including a live demo in our presentation! We could show how to use the graphing calculators to analyze data sets and create visualizations. We could even have the audience participate in a mini activity.

label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <anovak@university.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Clarke <eclarke@highschool.edu>
Subject: Seeking advice for particle physics educational videos

Hi Dr. Clarke,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been great corresponding with you over the past few months, and I've found your insights on physics education to be incredibly valuable.

I'm reaching out today because I'm working on a new project that I think you might be interested in. I'm developing a series of educational videos aimed at explaining particle physics concepts to a general audience. As you know, particle physics can be quite complex and intimidating for those without a strong physics background, so my goal is to create content that is engaging and accessible to viewers with varying levels of knowledge.

I was wondering if you might have any advice or suggestions for making the videos as effective as possible. I would be particularly interested in hearing your thoughts on:

1. What topics or concepts are most important to cover in an introductory particle physics series?
2. What teaching methods or strategies have you found to be most effective for engaging students and making complex ideas more accessible?
3. Are there any common misconceptions or difficulties that students tend to encounter when learning about particle physics?

I would be incredibly grateful for any insights or recommendations you might have. If you have the time and inclination, I would also love to hear about your experiences writing textbooks and teaching high school physics.

Thank you in advance for your time and consideration. I look forward to hearing back from you.

Best regards,
Alex Novak
