body:
<email>
From: David Patel <dpatel@vaxinovate.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@biotechlabs.com>
Subject: RE: Grant proposal update

Hi Emily,

Great to hear from you! I'm glad you've been making progress on the experimental design. I'd be happy to hop on a call later this week to discuss your ideas. How about Friday afternoon?

Regarding the commercialization of our vaccine, I agree that it's a exciting possibility. I think partnering with a pharma company could help us bring the vaccine to market more quickly and efficiently, but you're right that there are a lot of factors to consider. We should definitely discuss this further and weigh the pros and cons.

On a personal note, I hope you and your family are doing well! It's been a while since we caught up outside of work. Let me know if you're free for a virtual coffee chat sometime.

Best,
David

Can you take a look and get back to me with the bullish case?

thanks,

Phillip

Dear  John,

First of all, congratulations. You have made headlines in Brazil.
Whenever you come to our country, let me know, so I can provide you with
assitance.

When convenient, please let me know Jeff Shenkman's(Enron Global Markets)
email, so I can get in contact.

All the best,

Cacio Carvalho


____________________________________________________

Dear Jeff,
After reading a series of reports on Enron Global Markets,  I decided to get
in contact.
I live in Brazil and had a chance to meet Jim Ballantine whom was(until
recently) heading Enron's operations in Brazil.
Currently, I work as an Strategic Planning Manager at Copergas, a Natural
Gas Distributor located in Northeast Brazil (partly owned by Enron).
Jim once mentioned that EOL intends to come to Brazil. According to the
press, Enron Global Markets will be responsable for expanding the EOL
platform worldwide.
I want you to know that my professional background includes IT, Government,
Marketing and Business Development. When Enron Global Markets decides to
expand into Brazil, let me know.  I will be more than happy to join such an
outstanding team.
My best  and a SUPER 2001,
Cacio Carvalho

X-From: Oxley, David </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=DOXLEY>

X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

For purposes of an accelerated distribution from the PSA,  a "single sum distribution," in Section 6.2 means that a PSA account is distributed all at once, as distinguished from another form of payout as may have been selected by a participant in his or her deferral agreement.  

Section 6.2 is clear in that the account balance shall be determined as of the last day of the month preceding the date on which the Committee receives the written request of the Participant.  A PSA account balance is reflected in shares of stock since the form of distribution is shares of stock.

Additionally, any portion of a PSA balance attributable to deferral of restricted stock is administered under Sections 3.5 and 3.6 and Exhibit A of the Plan. This section is applicable now as we are accelerating the distribution of PSA balances created with deferrals of restricted stock.  The Plan indicates that upon death, disability, retirement or termination, the share units are converted to shares which are issued to the executive according to the payment election made by the executive at the time of the deferral election.  

      Therefore the distribution you will receive in shares is correct and we do not agree with your interpretation of the plan.

body:
<email>
From: Emily Stone <emily.stone@archaeoexperts.com>
To: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@techsolutions.net>
Subject: Historical Society Website Update

Hi Michael,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to touch base with you regarding the progress on the historical society's website. I've been going through the content you sent me last week, and I think it looks great! The images of the burial sites are really striking, and I think they'll be a great addition to the exhibit.

I did have a couple of questions about the DNS configuration. I noticed that the domain name we originally chose (ancientburialsofsometown.org) is already taken. Do you have any suggestions for alternative domain names? I was thinking something along the lines of "sometownancientburials.org" or "sometownneolithicburials.com". Let me know what you think.

Also, I wanted to thank you again for all the hard work you've put into this project. Your expertise has been invaluable, and I really appreciate your dedication to making this exhibit a success.

Best regards,
Emily

David </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Dduran>, Robinson, Mitch </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Mrobins>, Curry, Mike </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Mcurry>, Heizenrader, Tim </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Theizen>, Belden, Tim </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Tbelden>, White, Stacey W. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Swhite>, Steffes, James D. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Jsteffe>, Aucoin, Berney C.  </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Baucoin>, Roberts, Mike A. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Mrobert>, Oxley, David </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Doxley>
X-cc: Lavorato, John </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=JLAVORA>
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Jan2002_1\Allen, Phillip K.\Inbox
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen (Non-Privileged).pst

The New Year has arrived and we really to finalize a lot of the work with regards to moving into NETCO.  Obviously we still do not have a deal but the deadline is approaching and preparations need to be finalized.

The main areas to focus on over the next week are:-

(i) 	Re-start/Integration Plans (due on Jan 7)				To be forwarded to Louise	
	These plans need to be detailed and show clear detailed timelines and detailed responsibilities for getting us up and running as soon as possible.  
	The current restart date is January 21, 2001 but may be pushed forward to January 14, 2002.	
(ii)	Budget (due Jan 3, 2002)						To be forwarded to Faith Killen 
	First year budget to include all start up costs (some of which can be amortized)
(iii)	Seating Plans								Tammy Shepperd to co-ordinate
	We need to start the planning process for seating as we will be living on floors 5 & 6 of the Enron South building.
	I have asked Tammy Shepperd to commence the seating plan and we would look to start the moves as soon as possible but with a large number occuring around January 11,2002.
(iv)	Due Diligence
	We continue the process with two new companies this week (Wednesday and Thursday). Andy Zipper is taking the lead for the company arriving on Wednesday, please help him with his requirements.

I would ask that both John and I are notified of any changes to the Netco personnel list on a timely fashion and that the list is maintained on a continual basis.  Please forward all alterations to Jeanie Slone who has responsibility for the master list.

Communication - I believe that the New Year combined with a internal communication issues may be a good time to review what we want to say on Netco and what our policies are.  I am asking David Oxley to co-ordinate with all of you on this.  I know a lot of you believe that we need to only communicate once we have retention programme in place for the estate which may be a good idea but we we need to make sure that we lose as few people as possible.

If you are unavailable this week, please ensure you delegate this work out.

Happy New Year

Louise

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Davis <edavis@fossilfrontiers.com>
To: Alex Johnson <ajohnson@spacepolicy.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from the Earth & Space Conference

Dear Alex,

Thank you for reaching out! I really appreciate your kind words about my research. I'm excited about the potential for collaboration between our fields as well.

I would be very interested in exploring the use of satellite imagery to identify fossil sites. That's a fascinating idea that I haven't considered before. If you could put me in touch with your contacts at NASA, I would be happy to discuss this further and see if we can put together a proposal.

Your work on space debris and the long-term impacts of human activity in space is also fascinating. I think there are definitely some interesting parallels with my research on the preservation of delicate fossils and the potential impacts of our excavation and transportation methods. I'd love to hear more about your thoughts on this.

On a personal note, I was excited to hear about your love of hiking and nature photography. I share those passions as well. Have you ever been to Dinosaur National Monument? It's one of my favorite places to hike and explore.

I look forward to continuing our conversation and hopefully working together on some exciting projects.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Tom:
My assistant spoke to Judy Smith about myself and my partner grabbing an 
extra seat on the jet to Tampa. 

My partner and I were invited to the game by a couple of gentlemen from New 
York that I do business with.  Unfortunately, since I run the nat gas 
derivatives desk and February expiration is next Monday, the only way we 
could go is if the jet were coming back Sunday night.  No commercial flights 
would get us back in time.  

Judy indicated it was fine if we caught a ride on the way back, so my 
contacts in NY booked the trip, including buying game tickets.  I am now 
hearing that you may be leaving early Sunday night.  I was just wondering if 
your plans had firmed up.  Obviously, it would be tremendously helpful to me 
if the plane were leaving after the game.  

Please advise,
John

body:
<email>
From: Rabbi Jonah Cohen <jcohen@beitmidrash.org>
To: Ariel Goldstein <ariel.goldstein@torahacademy.org>
Subject: RE: Thoughts on the mysticism unit

Ariel,

Thank you for sharing these ideas. I completely agree that focusing on themes of spiritual longing, divine connection, and personal transformation could be very meaningful for our students. I think you're right that these are questions and struggles that many young adults grapple with, and that the Zohar and other mystical texts can offer powerful insights and guidance.

I was thinking about the idea of spiritual longing in particular, and how it can manifest in different ways – as a longing for connection with God, for a sense of purpose and meaning, for a deeper understanding of oneself and one's place in the world. I wonder if we could have our students reflect on their own experiences of spiritual longing, and then explore how different mystical texts and practices can help to address or transform that longing.

In terms of specific texts, I'm thinking about some of the Zohar's teachings on the soul and its divine origins, as well as some of the Hasidic stories and teachings about the power of prayer and devekut (cleaving to God). I also think it could be powerful to incorporate some contemplative practices, like meditation or chanting, to give students a direct experience of some of these mystical ideas.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this, and to keep brainstorming ways to make this unit as engaging and transformative as possible. I'm really excited about the potential of this curriculum to help our students connect more deeply with their Jewish identities and spiritual lives.

Best,
Jonah
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Eleanor Archer <eleanor.archer@wordsmithdictionaries.com>
To: Dr. Liam Patel <liam.patel@healthwise.org>
Subject: RE: Help with a medical term etymology

Liam,

Thank you so much for your detailed explanation of "quinsy." It's incredible how the meaning of the term has evolved alongside our understanding of the condition.

Your insights have sparked my interest in exploring the broader topic of how medical terminology has changed over time. In fact, I'm working on an article for our dictionary publication about the history of medical terms and their linguistic roots. I think this could be an excellent opportunity to showcase the connection between language and medical knowledge.

I was wondering if you would be interested in collaborating on this article. With your expertise in medicine and my focus on etymology, I believe we could create a comprehensive and engaging piece that highlights the fascinating history of medical language.

Please let me know your thoughts. I would be thrilled to work with you on this project.

Best regards,
Eleanor

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Rivera <jordan.rivera@gmail.com>
To: Alex Wong <alex.wong@sciencemag.com>
Subject: RE: Gene editing article series - need your expert input!

Hey Alex,

Great to hear from you! I'm flattered that you thought of me for this. I'd be happy to help out however I can.

Gene editing is such a fascinating and rapidly evolving field - it's been a while since I've written about it, but I'm sure I can rustle up some thoughts. Off the top of my head, I think it's crucial to emphasize the potential benefits (e.g. treating genetic diseases, improving crops) while also acknowledging the very real risks and unknowns (unintended consequences, "designer babies," etc.).

I think our role as science journalists is to provide a balanced, nuanced perspective and to help our readers understand the complexities of these issues. We need to go beyond the hype and really dig into the science, while also considering the broader societal implications.

I'm pretty swamped with deadlines next week, but I'd love to grab that coffee/breakfast and chat more in person. Let me know when you're free and we'll make it happen.

Looking forward to catching up!

Jordan

Ray Alvarez@ENRON
04/25/2001 11:48 AM
To:	Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:	 
Subject:	Re: This morning's Commission meeting delayed   

Phil,  I suspect that discussions/negotiations are taking place behind closed doors "in smoke filled rooms", if not directly between Commissioners then among FERC staffers.  Never say never, but I think it is highly unlikely that the final order will contain a fixed price cap.  I base this belief in large part on what I heard at a luncheon I attended yesterday afternoon at which the keynote speaker was FERC Chairman Curt Hebert.  Although the Chairman began his presentation by expressly stating that he would not comment or answer questions on pending proceedings before the Commission, Hebert had some enlightening comments which relate to price caps:

Price caps are almost never the right answer
Price Caps will have the effect of prolonging shortages
Competitive choices for consumers is the right answer
Any solution, however short term, that does not increase supply or reduce demand, is not acceptable
Eight out of eleven western Governors oppose price caps, in that they would export California's problems to the West

This is the latest intelligence I have on the matter, and it's a pretty strong anti- price cap position.  Of course, Hebert is just one Commissioner out of 3 currently on the Commission, but he controls the meeting agenda and if the draft order is not to his liking, the item could be bumped off the agenda.  Hope this info helps.  Ray




Phillip K Allen@ECT
04/25/2001 02:28 PM
To:	Ray Alvarez/NA/Enron@ENRON
cc:	 

Subject:	Re: This morning's Commission meeting delayed   

Are there behind closed doors discussions being held prior to the meeting?  Is there the potential for a surprise announcement of some sort of fixed price gas or power cap once the open meeting finally happens?

body:
<email>
From: Elena Petrova <elena.petrova@russianstudies.ru>
To: Alexei Ivanov <aivanov@americanhistory.gov>
Subject: New insights on the Alaska Purchase?

Dear Alexei,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been making some progress on my paper about the Alaska Purchase and the broader context of Russo-American relations in the 19th century. I was wondering if you might be willing to take a look at the draft and share your thoughts? I know you've done extensive research on Russian expansionism during this period, and I would greatly value your insights.

I'm particularly interested in your thoughts on how the Alaska Purchase fits into the larger pattern of Russian imperial ambitions and the shifting balance of power in the Pacific Northwest. I think your work on the Russian-American Company and the colonization of Alaska could really help shed light on this.

Please let me know if you'd be willing to take a look at the draft. I'm happy to reciprocate by reviewing any of your work in progress as well.

Best regards,
Elena
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Hartley <emily.hartley@sydneyhikingclub.org>
To: Oliver Thompson <oliver.thompson@fitpro.edu.au>
Subject: Fascinating article on the Blue Mountains' geological history

Hey Oliver,

I came across this article about the unique geological history of the Blue Mountains and thought you might find it interesting. It discusses the formation of the sandstone cliffs and the impact of erosion over millions of years.

https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-05-17/blue-mountains-geological-history-sandstone-cliffs/100144428

I'm curious to know your thoughts on how these geological processes might have influenced the local flora and fauna, and how it affects our hikes in the area.

Cheers,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Ethan Reed <ereed@militaryhistories.net>
To: Emily Hartman <ehartman@kindergartencreations.com>
Subject: RE: Introducing the "Art of War" exhibit

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out and introducing yourself. I am familiar with your work in elementary art education and commend your efforts to enrich young minds through cultural and musical experiences.

I am intrigued by the "Art of War" exhibit concept and would be honored to collaborate with you on this project. The interplay between art, propaganda, and the logistical systems that support their creation and dissemination is a fascinating topic that deserves exploration.

I am particularly interested in discussing how the distribution networks for wartime art and propaganda may have influenced their content and style. Additionally, I believe examining the role of cultural and musical propaganda in shaping morale both on the home front and among troops could provide valuable insights into the psychological aspects of warfare.

Please let me know when would be a good time for us to have a more in-depth discussion about our potential collaboration. I look forward to working with you on this exciting exhibit.

Best regards,
Dr. Ethan Reed

X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

a couple of observations from here:
cash/futures getting whacked.  whereas last weekend cash traded $1 over G, 
this weekend will probably trade $.15 over.  the lack of weather giving the 
market time to regroup.  good thing because another week of cold and the 
system was going to break.   certainly still has that chance in feb.  saw 
utilities recently staying on a verystrict withdrawal schedule and meeting 
any extra demand through spot market.  in effect, they said we're not 
withdrawing anymore so we'll buy marketers storage.  they had to encourage 
marketers to sell it to them, so cash was extremely strong in periods of even 
normal demand and should continue to be if/when any weather comes again.  
this week demand so low that utilities can meet demand without buying much in 
mkt.  g/h getting whacked in sympathy.  
probably priced 25 term deals through broker market  and own originators in 
past two days.  24 were from the buy side.  it's as if pira came in and told 
everyone term was cheap.  however, they've got the opposite view.  customers 
just seeing gas at $4 anytime as being okay now.  don't see any let up in 
back support for a while.  
front spreads the hardest call right now.  g/h h/j j/k ??? can't decide what 
to do with them and from the volatility in them, appears neither can anybody 
else.  almost think best play is taking feb gas daily against march, hoping 
for a cold spell that breaks the system and get a couple $20+ prints in 
cash.  probably as likely to happen in g as h and g/h has much less 
downside.  

doing well here.  actually having the best month ever 11 days in.  played 
front short against term length.  got out of front shorts today.   probably 
early but gas has a history of getting off the canvas when least expected.  
will keep term length meanwhile.   i've hated summer backwardation forever.  
agree about u/h.  a little less crazy about  the trade now because i think 
the easy money was made over the past two days.  unbelievable spec demand for 
next winter over past week kept summer winter spread constant on rally up and 
crushed on move down.  jv/xh went from 22 to 3.5 in 5 days while front 
virtually unchanged.

don't know what to think of this summer longer term.  certainly not as easy 
as it was last summer when it was obvious $3 was not equilibrium for gas.  
now $6 for this summer, i don't know.  we're gonna have to inject the hell 
out of gas and keep some demand priced out for a long time.  but we will feel 
production increase hit the market.  just buy vol.




slafontaine@globalp.com on 01/11/2001 04:48:32 PM
To: slafontaine@globalp.com
cc: jarnold@enron.com 
Subject: Re: ngas and economy



im getting really bullish mar/may-deliverabulty ayt these propective stx gonna
be hampered big time-thyre expensive but im not sure the mkt has a feeling for
what gas can do yet with normal weather and implications on the economy-as a
real estate owner getting a little scared. ngas is going to wreck morot 
gasoline
now-watch it go next then maybe heating oil

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@university.edu>
To: David Nguyen <david.nguyen@college.edu>
Subject: Urgent: Intro Econ textbook progress

David,

I hope you're doing well. I just got off the phone with my department chair, and it sounds like our rivals are making serious headway on their own intro econ textbook. We need to move quickly if we want to secure that grant and get our project to market first.

I've been working on integrating some modern econometric techniques into our chapters, but I'm struggling to find compelling real-world examples to illustrate the concepts. Any ideas? I'd love to bounce around some thoughts and strategize our next steps.

Let me know when you're free to chat. I'm happy to meet in-person or jump on a call, whichever works best for you.

Best,
Emily

George,

Here is a spreadsheet that illustrates the payout of investment and builders 
profit.  Check my math, but it looks like all the builders profit would be 
recouped in the first year of operation.  At permanent financing $1.1 would 
be paid, leaving only .3 to pay out in the 1st year.



Since almost 80% of builders profit is repaid at the same time as the 
investment, I feel the 65/35 is a fair split.  However, as I mentioned 
earlier, I think we should negotiate to layer on additional equity to you as 
part of the construction contract.  

Just to begin the brainstorming on what a construction agreement might look 
like here are a few ideas:

 1.  Fixed construction profit of $1.4 million.  Builder doesn't benefit from 
higher cost, rather suffers as an equity holder.

 2.  +5% equity for meeting time and costs in original plan ($51/sq ft, phase 
1 complete in November)
      +5% equity for under budget and ahead of schedule
      -5% equity for over budget and behind schedule

This way if things go according to plan the final split would be 60/40, but 
could be as favorable as 55/45.  I realize that what is budget and schedule 
must be discussed and agreed upon.

Feel free to call me at home (713)463-8626


Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Emily Jennings <emily.jennings@live.com>
To: Dr. Alex Rivera <arivera@university.edu>
Subject: Book club discussion on "Guns, Germs, and Steel"

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well! I couldn't help but think about our last book club meeting and the fascinating discussion we had on "Guns, Germs, and Steel." I was particularly intrigued by your insights on the impact of geography and resources on the development of ancient civilizations.

As someone who studies pre-Columbian Mesoamerican civilizations, I was wondering if you could recommend any books or resources that delve deeper into the topic. I'm especially interested in learning more about the role of technology and trade in these societies.

I'd love to hear your thoughts and suggestions!

Best regards,
Emily

body:
Message-ID: <19034252.1075855687825.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 26 Sep 2000 09:28:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: kholst@enron.com
Subject: Investment Structure
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: kholst@enron.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 09/26/2000 
04:28 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/26/2000 01:18:45 PM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net>, "Claudia L. Crocker" 
<clclegal2@aol.com> 
Subject: Investment Structure


STRUCTURE:
Typically the structure is a limited partnership with a corporate (or LLC)
general partner.  The General Partner owns 1% of the project and carries the
liability of construction.

LAND OWNERSHIP & LOANS
The property would be purchased in the name of the limited partnership and
any land loans, land improvements loans and construction loans would be in
the name of the limited partnership.  Each of the individual investors and
all of the principals in Creekside would also personally guarantee the
loans.  If the investor(s) do not sign on the loans, this generally means
that a larger amount of cash is required and the investor's share of profits
is reduced.

All loans for residential construction, that are intended for re-sale, are
full recourse loans.  If we are pursuing multifamily rental developments,
the construction loans are still full recourse but the mortgage can often be
non-recourse.

USE OF INITIAL INVESTMENT
The initial investment is used for land deposit, engineering &
architectural design, soils tests, surveys, filing fees, legal fees for
organization and condominium association formation,  and appraisals.  Unlike
many real estate investment programs, none of the funds are used for fees to
Creekside Builders, LLC.  These professional expenses will be incurred over
the estimated 6 month design and approval period.

EARLY LAND COSTS
The $4,000 per month costs listed in the cash flow as part of land cost
represent the extension fees due to the seller for up to 4 months of
extensions on closing.  As an alternative, we can close into a land loan at
probably 70% of appraised value.  With a land value equal to the purchase
price of $680,000 this would mean a land loan of $476,000 with estimated
monthly interest payments of $3,966, given a 10% annual interest rate, plus
approximately 1.25% of the loan amount for closing costs and loan fees.

EQUITY AT IMPROVEMENT LOAN
Once the site plan is approved by the City of Austin, the City will require
the development entity to post funds for fiscal improvements, referred to as
the "fiscals".  This cost represents a bond for the completion of
improvements that COA considers vital and these funds are released once the
improvements have been completed and accepted by COA.  This release will be
for 90% of the cost with the remaining 10% released one year after
completion.  Releases can be granted once every 90 days and you should
expect that the release would occur 6 months after the start of lot
improvement construction.  These fiscals are usually posted in cash or an
irrevocable letter of credit.  As such, they have to be counted as a
development cost, even though they are not spent.  Because they are not
spent no interest is charged on these funds.

The lot improvement loan is typically 75% of the appraised value of a
finished lot, which I suspect will be at least $20,000 and potentially as
high as $25,000.  This would produce a loan amount of  $15,000 on $20,000
per lot.  With estimated per lot improvement costs of $9,000, 'fiscals' at
$2,000 and the land cost at $8,000 , total improved lot cost is $19,000
which means $0 to $4,000 per lot in total equity.  The investment prior to
obtaining the improvement loan would count towards any equity requirement
provided it was for direct costs.  Thus, the additional equity for the
improvement loan would be $0-$184,000.   Even if the maximum loan would
cover all costs, it is unlikely the bank would allow reimbursement of funds
spent. The higher estimates of equity investments are shown in the
preliminary proforma to be on the safe side.  The engineer is preparing a
tentative site layout with an initial evaluation of the phasing, which can
significantly reduce the cash equity requirement.

Phasing works as follows.  If the first phase was say 40 units, the total
lot improvement cost might average $31,000 per lot.   Of this, probably
$13,000 would be for improvements and $19,000 for the land cost.  The
improvements are higher to cover large one time up front costs for design
costs, the entry road, water treatment costs, perimeter fencing and
landscaping, and so on, as well as for 100% of the land.  The land loan for
undeveloped lots would be 70% of the appraised raw lot value, which I would
estimate as $10,000 per lot for a loan value of $7,000 per lot.  Then the
loan value for each improved lot would be $15,000 per lot.  This would give
you a total loan of $992,000, total cost of $1,232,645 for equity required
of $241,000.  This was not presented in the initial analysis as the phasing
is depended on a more careful assessment by the Civil Engineer as the
separate phases must each be able to stand on its own from a utility
standpoint.

CONSTRUCTION LOANS
There are three types of  construction loans.  First, is a speculative
(spec) loan that is taken out prior to any pre-sales activity.  Second,  is
a construction loan for a pre-sold unit, but the loan remains in the
builder/developers name.  Third, is a pre-sold unit with the construction
loan in the name of the buyer.  We expect to have up to 8 spec loans to
start the project and expect all other loans to be pre-sold units with loans
in the name of the builder/developer.  We do not expect to have any
construction loans in the name of the buyers, as such loans are too
difficult to manage and please new buyers unfamiliar with the process.

Spec loans will be for 70% to 75% of value and construction loans for
pre-sold units, if the construction loan is from the mortgage lender,  will
be from 80% to 95% of value.

DISBURSEMENTS
Disbursements will be handled by the General Partner to cover current and
near term third party costs, then to necessary reserves, then to priority
payments and then to the partners per the agreement.  The General Partner
will contract with Creekside Builders, LLC to construct the units and the
fee to CB will include a construction management and overhead fee equal to
15% of the direct hard cost excluding land, financing and sales costs.
These fees are the only monies to Creekside, Larry Lewter or myself prior to
calculation of profit, except for a) direct reimbursement for partnership
expenses and b) direct payment to CB for any subcontractor costs that it has
to perform.  For example, if CB cannot find a good trim carpenter sub, or
cannot find enough trim carpenters, etc., and it decides to undertake this
function, it will charge the partnership the same fee it was able to obtain
from third parties and will disclose those cases to the partnership.
Finally, CB will receive a fee for the use of any of its equipment if it is
used in lieu of leasing equipment from others.  At present CB does not own
any significant equipment, but it is considering the purchase of a sky track
to facilitate and speed up framing, cornice, roofing and drywall spreading.

REPORTING
We are more than willing to provide reports to track expenses vs. plan.
What did you have in mind?  I would like to use some form of internet based
reporting.

BOOKKEEPING
I am not sure what you are referring to by the question, "Bookkeeping
procedures to record actual expenses?"  Please expand.

INVESTOR INPUT
We are glad to have the investor's input on design and materials.  As always
the question will be who has final say if there is disagreement, but in my
experience I have always been able to reach consensus. As you, and I presume
Keith, want to be involved to learn as much as possible we would make every
effort to be accommodating.

CREEKSIDE PROCEEDURES
CB procedures for dealing with subs, vendors and professionals is not as
formal as your question indicates.  In the EXTREMELY tight labor market
obtaining 3 bids for each labor trade is not feasible.  For the professional
subs we use those with whom we have developed a previous rapport.  Finally,
for vendors they are constantly shopped.

PRE-SELECTED PROFESSIONALS, SUBS AND VENDORS
Yes there are many different subs that have been identified and I can
provide these if you are interested.

I know I have not answered everything, but this is a starting point.  Call
when you have reviewed and we can discuss further.

Sincerely,

George Richards
President, Creekside Builders, LLC

The method for distribution of the weekly reports has changed.  Hard copies will now be distributed through your administrative assistant.  

To receive a paper copy of the report, please send me an e-mail request including you location and admin.  

The information in these reports is for internal use only and should not be the basis for investment decisions.  

Please let me know if you have any questions or comments,

James Bruce	
Enron North America		(503) 464-8122
West Power Desk		(503) 860-8612 (c)
121 SW Salmon, 3WTC0306	(503) 464-3740 (fax)
Portland, OR 97204		James.Bruce@Enron.com

										Don't miss this member-only opportunity to see a quick snapshot of the 
activity on all 48 interstate gas pipelines.

body: Dear OSL, Please let us know what the policy if for cancelling a room booking. We have booked 10 rooms for our event. It is highly probable that we might not need all of them. Thanking you. Regards, Lavanya.

Andrew Brown

body:
Message-ID: <719350.1075855687850.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 26 Sep 2000 09:26:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: pallen70@hotmail.com
Subject: Investment Structure
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: pallen70@hotmail.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 09/26/2000 
04:26 PM ---------------------------


"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/26/2000 01:18:45 PM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net>, "Claudia L. Crocker" 
<clclegal2@aol.com> 
Subject: Investment Structure


STRUCTURE:
Typically the structure is a limited partnership with a corporate (or LLC)
general partner.  The General Partner owns 1% of the project and carries the
liability of construction.

LAND OWNERSHIP & LOANS
The property would be purchased in the name of the limited partnership and
any land loans, land improvements loans and construction loans would be in
the name of the limited partnership.  Each of the individual investors and
all of the principals in Creekside would also personally guarantee the
loans.  If the investor(s) do not sign on the loans, this generally means
that a larger amount of cash is required and the investor's share of profits
is reduced.

All loans for residential construction, that are intended for re-sale, are
full recourse loans.  If we are pursuing multifamily rental developments,
the construction loans are still full recourse but the mortgage can often be
non-recourse.

USE OF INITIAL INVESTMENT
The initial investment is used for land deposit, engineering &
architectural design, soils tests, surveys, filing fees, legal fees for
organization and condominium association formation,  and appraisals.  Unlike
many real estate investment programs, none of the funds are used for fees to
Creekside Builders, LLC.  These professional expenses will be incurred over
the estimated 6 month design and approval period.

EARLY LAND COSTS
The $4,000 per month costs listed in the cash flow as part of land cost
represent the extension fees due to the seller for up to 4 months of
extensions on closing.  As an alternative, we can close into a land loan at
probably 70% of appraised value.  With a land value equal to the purchase
price of $680,000 this would mean a land loan of $476,000 with estimated
monthly interest payments of $3,966, given a 10% annual interest rate, plus
approximately 1.25% of the loan amount for closing costs and loan fees.

EQUITY AT IMPROVEMENT LOAN
Once the site plan is approved by the City of Austin, the City will require
the development entity to post funds for fiscal improvements, referred to as
the "fiscals".  This cost represents a bond for the completion of
improvements that COA considers vital and these funds are released once the
improvements have been completed and accepted by COA.  This release will be
for 90% of the cost with the remaining 10% released one year after
completion.  Releases can be granted once every 90 days and you should
expect that the release would occur 6 months after the start of lot
improvement construction.  These fiscals are usually posted in cash or an
irrevocable letter of credit.  As such, they have to be counted as a
development cost, even though they are not spent.  Because they are not
spent no interest is charged on these funds.

The lot improvement loan is typically 75% of the appraised value of a
finished lot, which I suspect will be at least $20,000 and potentially as
high as $25,000.  This would produce a loan amount of  $15,000 on $20,000
per lot.  With estimated per lot improvement costs of $9,000, 'fiscals' at
$2,000 and the land cost at $8,000 , total improved lot cost is $19,000
which means $0 to $4,000 per lot in total equity.  The investment prior to
obtaining the improvement loan would count towards any equity requirement
provided it was for direct costs.  Thus, the additional equity for the
improvement loan would be $0-$184,000.   Even if the maximum loan would
cover all costs, it is unlikely the bank would allow reimbursement of funds
spent. The higher estimates of equity investments are shown in the
preliminary proforma to be on the safe side.  The engineer is preparing a
tentative site layout with an initial evaluation of the phasing, which can
significantly reduce the cash equity requirement.

Phasing works as follows.  If the first phase was say 40 units, the total
lot improvement cost might average $31,000 per lot.   Of this, probably
$13,000 would be for improvements and $19,000 for the land cost.  The
improvements are higher to cover large one time up front costs for design
costs, the entry road, water treatment costs, perimeter fencing and
landscaping, and so on, as well as for 100% of the land.  The land loan for
undeveloped lots would be 70% of the appraised raw lot value, which I would
estimate as $10,000 per lot for a loan value of $7,000 per lot.  Then the
loan value for each improved lot would be $15,000 per lot.  This would give
you a total loan of $992,000, total cost of $1,232,645 for equity required
of $241,000.  This was not presented in the initial analysis as the phasing
is depended on a more careful assessment by the Civil Engineer as the
separate phases must each be able to stand on its own from a utility
standpoint.

CONSTRUCTION LOANS
There are three types of  construction loans.  First, is a speculative
(spec) loan that is taken out prior to any pre-sales activity.  Second,  is
a construction loan for a pre-sold unit, but the loan remains in the
builder/developers name.  Third, is a pre-sold unit with the construction
loan in the name of the buyer.  We expect to have up to 8 spec loans to
start the project and expect all other loans to be pre-sold units with loans
in the name of the builder/developer.  We do not expect to have any
construction loans in the name of the buyers, as such loans are too
difficult to manage and please new buyers unfamiliar with the process.

Spec loans will be for 70% to 75% of value and construction loans for
pre-sold units, if the construction loan is from the mortgage lender,  will
be from 80% to 95% of value.

DISBURSEMENTS
Disbursements will be handled by the General Partner to cover current and
near term third party costs, then to necessary reserves, then to priority
payments and then to the partners per the agreement.  The General Partner
will contract with Creekside Builders, LLC to construct the units and the
fee to CB will include a construction management and overhead fee equal to
15% of the direct hard cost excluding land, financing and sales costs.
These fees are the only monies to Creekside, Larry Lewter or myself prior to
calculation of profit, except for a) direct reimbursement for partnership
expenses and b) direct payment to CB for any subcontractor costs that it has
to perform.  For example, if CB cannot find a good trim carpenter sub, or
cannot find enough trim carpenters, etc., and it decides to undertake this
function, it will charge the partnership the same fee it was able to obtain
from third parties and will disclose those cases to the partnership.
Finally, CB will receive a fee for the use of any of its equipment if it is
used in lieu of leasing equipment from others.  At present CB does not own
any significant equipment, but it is considering the purchase of a sky track
to facilitate and speed up framing, cornice, roofing and drywall spreading.

REPORTING
We are more than willing to provide reports to track expenses vs. plan.
What did you have in mind?  I would like to use some form of internet based
reporting.

BOOKKEEPING
I am not sure what you are referring to by the question, "Bookkeeping
procedures to record actual expenses?"  Please expand.

INVESTOR INPUT
We are glad to have the investor's input on design and materials.  As always
the question will be who has final say if there is disagreement, but in my
experience I have always been able to reach consensus. As you, and I presume
Keith, want to be involved to learn as much as possible we would make every
effort to be accommodating.

CREEKSIDE PROCEEDURES
CB procedures for dealing with subs, vendors and professionals is not as
formal as your question indicates.  In the EXTREMELY tight labor market
obtaining 3 bids for each labor trade is not feasible.  For the professional
subs we use those with whom we have developed a previous rapport.  Finally,
for vendors they are constantly shopped.

PRE-SELECTED PROFESSIONALS, SUBS AND VENDORS
Yes there are many different subs that have been identified and I can
provide these if you are interested.

I know I have not answered everything, but this is a starting point.  Call
when you have reviewed and we can discuss further.

Sincerely,

George Richards
President, Creekside Builders, LLC

<email>
From: Ethan Wu <ethan.wu@lightingdesigns.com>
To: Olivia Novak <olivia.novak@starrynights.org>
Subject: LED Technology for Astronomy Exhibits

Hi Olivia,

Thanks for sending over the article about LED technology for interactive astronomy exhibits. It's really fascinating stuff! I can definitely see how we could use this in our educational initiative to create engaging and hands-on experiences for students.

I've been doing some research on the latest advancements in LED lighting and control systems. There are some incredible possibilities for creating dynamic, responsive environments that could really bring the wonders of the universe to life.

I'm attaching a document with some of my findings and ideas. Let's discuss this further during our call on Tuesday.

Looking forward to it!

Best,
Ethan

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Liam Patel <liam.patel@wildlifeconservation.org>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@greensboroalliance.org>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on the Greensboro Environmental Alliance Event

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm thrilled to hear about your interest in collaborating for the Greensboro Environmental Alliance event. It's wonderful to see educators like you working to engage students in environmental issues and real-world applications of mathematics.

I would be more than happy to discuss how we can work together to make this event a success. I think it's a great idea to incorporate some of my research into your lesson plans, and I'm open to any suggestions you have for making the presentations engaging and interactive.

One idea I had was to have the students participate in a mini-workshop where they analyze some of the data we've collected on local wildlife populations and create visualizations to communicate their findings. This could be a great way to showcase their mathematical skills and spark their interest in environmental conservation.

I'm also happy to provide you with any resources or information you need to incorporate conservation genetics and wildlife immunology into your curriculum.

Please let me know your thoughts on these ideas, and feel free to suggest any other ways we can collaborate. I'm looking forward to working with you and your students!

Best regards,
Liam Patel
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Samira Patel <spatel@genimmune.org>
To: Alex Chen <achen@radiacell.com>
Subject: RE: Exciting results from the latest round of experiments

Hi Alex,

Fantastic news! I had a chance to review the data, and I'm really encouraged by what I see. The enhanced immune response is particularly intriguing. I agree that we should consider moving up the animal trials, but we'll need to make sure our protocols are airtight.

I'm happy to chat on Friday, but I have a family wedding that's taken over my weekend. Would Monday work instead? I can carve out some time in the afternoon.

Also, I meant to ask - how are you liking your new city? I've heard great things about the research community there.

Cheers,
Samira

body:
<email>
From: Ingrid Andersson <ingrid.andersson@uppsala.edu>
To: Erik Lindström <erik.lindstrom@stockholmuniversity.se>
Subject: RE: Revising the Swedish language course

Erik,

Thank you so much for your insightful suggestions! I really appreciate you taking the time to share your expertise with me. The ideas you've provided will be incredibly helpful as I continue to refine the course content.

I'm particularly interested in the textbook you mentioned. If it's not too much trouble, I would love to borrow a copy and take a closer look. It sounds like it could be a valuable resource for my students.

Your suggestions for incorporating authentic materials and comparative cultural activities are also spot-on. I will definitely be integrating these elements into the curriculum.

Thank you again for your support and willingness to collaborate. I'm excited to continue working together to create a truly engaging and effective language course.

Best regards,
Ingrid

Houston, TX? 77002-7361

Subject: Bishops Corner, Ltd. -- Restructure or Buyout

Dear Phillip and Keith: 

We are prepared to sell Bishops Corner, Ltd. for reimbursement of our cash 
expenditures; compensation for our management services and your assumption of 
all note obligations and design contracts.? 

As shown on the attached summary table, cash expenditures total $21,196 and 
existing contracts to the architect, civil engineer, soils testing company, 
and appraisal total $67,050.? The due on these contracts is $61,175, of which 
current unpaid invoices due total $37,325.

Acting in good faith, we have invested an enormous amount of time into this 
project for more than five months and have completed most of the major design 
and other pre-construction elements.? As it is a major project for a firm of 
our size, it was given top priority with other projects being delayed or 
rejected, and we are now left with no project to pursue.? 

Two methods for valuing this development management are 1) based on a 
percentage of the minimum $1.4MM fee we were to have earned and 2) based on 
your prior valuation of our time.? For the first, we feel that at least 25%, 
or $350,000, of the minimum $1.4MM fee has been earned to date.? For the 
second, in your prior correspondence you valued our time at $500,000 per 
year, which would mean this period was worth $208,333.? Either of these 
valuations seem quite fair and reasonable, especially as neither includes the 
forfeit of our 40% interest in the project worth $0.8--$1.2MM. ?However, in 
the hope that we can maintain a good relationship with the prospect of future 
projects, we are willing to accept only a small monthly fee of $15,000 per 
month to cover a portion of our direct time and overhead.? As shown in the 
attached table, this fee, plus cash outlays and less accrued interest brings 
the total net buyout to $78,946.? 

We still believe that this project needs the professional services that we 
offer and have provided.? However, if you accept the terms of this buyout 
offer, which we truly feel is quite fair and reasonable, then, we are 
prepared to be bought out and leave this extraordinary project to you both.? 
If this is your 



choice, either contact us, or have your attorney contact our attorney, 
Claudia Crocker, no later than Friday of this week.? The attorneys can then 
draft whatever minimal documents are necessary for the transfer of the 
Bishops Corner, Ltd. Partnership to you following receipt of the buyout 
amount and assumption of the outstanding professional design contracts.

Thank you.

?

Sincerely,

[IMAGE]

?

?

?

George W. Richards 

President

P.S.????? Copies of contracts will be forwarded upon acceptance of buyout.

?

cc:??????? Larry Lewter
??????????? Claudia Crocker

James,

Thank you so much for agreeing to do this! I'm thrilled that my students will have the opportunity to learn from you and your research.

The best time for my class would be on Friday, April 28th at 1:00 PM EST. If that works for you, I'll send you the Skype link and any other necessary details a few days before.

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@equalrightsacademy.org>
To: Alex Rodriguez <arodriguez@socialjusticehigh.edu>
Subject: Collaboration on Women's Rights & American Social Movements Lesson Plans

Hi Alex,

It was great meeting you at the history teachers' conference last week! I really enjoyed our conversation about incorporating social justice and women's rights into our curricula. As promised, I'm reaching out to propose a collaboration on developing a series of lesson plans that focus on the intersection of these topics.

I think our schools' participation in the city-wide gender equality and social justice education initiative presents a great opportunity to showcase our work. What do you think about presenting our collaboration as part of this initiative?

Let me know if you're interested, and we can set up a time to discuss our ideas further.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Finn Collins <fcollins@oakwood.edu>
To: Reverend Dr. Eleanor Thompson <ethompson@oakwood.edu>
Subject: RE: Interdisciplinary Lecture Series - Your Participation

Dear Dr. Thompson,

Thank you for your kind invitation to participate in the upcoming lecture series. I am flattered that you value my perspective and believe it would contribute to the discussion on early American history. I would be delighted to give a lecture on the role of marine ecosystems in shaping early America.

I am also honored that you appreciate my nature photography. I would be happy to lend some of my images for your promotional materials. Please let me know the specifications, and I will send you a selection of my best marine ecosystem photographs.

I must admit, I am quite intrigued by the intersection of our fields and look forward to learning more about the religious and historical aspects of early America through this series. It is a fascinating concept to explore, and I commend you for bringing together such a diverse group of scholars.

Please keep me informed of the event details as they develop. I am excited to be a part of this unique and interdisciplinary initiative.

Best regards,
Dr. Finn Collins
Department of Marine Biology
Oakwood University
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Javier Rodríguez <rodriguez@riverview.edu>
To: Emily Nguyen <nguyen@riverview.edu>
Subject: Re: Econometrics and Linguistics Collaboration

Emily,

Thanks for your email. Your ideas about the dataset and statistical methods are very helpful. I agree that finding a suitable corpus with economic data from the same regions and time periods will be crucial for our analysis.

Regarding the statistical methods, mixed-effects models sound like a good choice, especially since they can handle both fixed and random effects. We could also consider using Bayesian methods, which might allow us to incorporate prior knowledge about the relationships between economic and linguistic variables.

I have a few ideas for potential corpora we could use, such as historical newspapers or government documents. I'll do some more research on this and send you a list of options.

One other thing I wanted to mention is that we should think about how to present our findings to both econometricians and linguists. We'll need to make sure our paper is accessible to readers from both fields, which might mean explaining some of the more technical aspects of our analysis in a clear and concise way.

Looking forward to continuing our collaboration!

Best,
Javier

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <jsmith@university.edu>
To: Emily Davis <edavis@graduate.edu>
Subject: Exciting research opportunity in carbohydrate synthesis

Dear Emily,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out and share some exciting news with you. As you may know, I recently received a grant to study the synthesis of complex carbohydrates involved in cell signaling. The project is expected to yield significant findings and has the potential to open up new avenues for targeted drug delivery.

Given your excellent work in my lab during your graduate studies and your expertise in carbohydrate chemistry, I would like to invite you to collaborate on this project. I believe that your skills and insights would be invaluable to the team. Additionally, I would like to offer you a postdoctoral position in my lab, starting in the fall.

I understand that you may have other offers from prestigious institutions, but I sincerely hope that you will consider joining us. We can discuss the details of the position and the project in person or over a video call at your convenience.

Please let me know if you have any questions or if you would like to discuss this opportunity further. I look forward to hearing back from you soon.

Best regards,
John Smith, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Biochemistry
University of Somewhere
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Rajiv Patel <rpatel@blocklearn.io>
To: Samantha Jones <sjones@edutech.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from the Emerging Tech in Education conference

Hi Samantha,

Thanks for reaching out! I really enjoyed our conversation at the conference as well, and I'm excited about the potential for collaboration. Your idea of creating a pilot program that combines educational modules with Arduino-based learning kits is fascinating, and I think it aligns well with my vision for using blockchain technology to create more open and accessible learning opportunities.

I've been doing some research into the technical requirements for creating a blockchain-based platform for sharing educational resources, and I think we could leverage some existing tools and frameworks to get started. In terms of the learning kits, I have some experience with Arduino and other open-source hardware platforms, so I'd be happy to take the lead on designing and prototyping the kits.

I think the next step would be to put together a more detailed proposal for the pilot program, including a timeline, budget, and key milestones. We should also start thinking about potential funding sources and partnerships. I'd be happy to set up a call to discuss this further and start brainstorming next steps.

Looking forward to working together on this!

Best,
Rajiv

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Julian Patel <jpatel@physicsinstitute.org>
To: Amelia Hartman <amelia.hartman@university.edu>
Subject: Re: Request for expertise

Dear Amelia,

Thank you for reaching out and for your kind words about my lecture. I'm flattered that you would consider my insights valuable for your project, and I would be happy to assist in any way I can.

I'm particularly intrigued by the idea of creating a dictionary of scientific terms that accurately captures the nuances and complexities of these concepts. As someone who has struggled to communicate my own work to a broader audience, I recognize the importance of clear and precise language in science.

I would be glad to provide definitions and explanations for the physics terms you are working on. Please send me a list of the concepts you need help with, and I'll do my best to break them down in a way that is both accurate and accessible.

Also, I wanted to mention that I'm planning to give a public lecture on gravitational expansion in a few months. If you have any tips on how to make my ideas more engaging and understandable for a non-expert audience, I would greatly appreciate your input.

Thank you again for reaching out, and I look forward to working with you on this project.

Best regards,
Julian Patel
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Erik Lindström <erik.lindstrom@university.se>
To: Nisha Patel <nisha.patel@lawresearch.in>
Subject: Collaborating on a new course

Dear Nisha,

I hope this email finds you well. It was great to meet you at the interdisciplinary conference last month. I've been thinking about our conversation and I believe your expertise in constitutional law could be invaluable for a new course I'm developing on the legal and political systems of Sweden.

The course will explore the historical development of the Swedish Constitution, the structure of the Swedish government, and the role of law in Swedish society. I would greatly appreciate your input on the key aspects of constitutional law that should be covered, as well as any suggestions you might have on how to incorporate comparative perspectives.

I would also like to invite you to be a guest lecturer for a session on Indian constitutional law and its cultural context. I think our students would benefit immensely from hearing about your work and the insights you can provide on the Indian legal system.

Please let me know if you would be interested in collaborating on this course and if you have any availability to discuss it further.

Best regards,
Erik
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Marcus Aurelius <marcus.aurelius@romeuniversity.edu>
To: Akiko Nakamura <akiko.nakamura@tokyomuseum.jp>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise on Roman water management systems

Dear Akiko,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad to know that my expertise could be of help in your exhibition project. The topic of the influence of Roman water management systems on Asian garden designs is indeed fascinating and not widely explored.

From my research, I can tell you that the Romans were highly skilled in hydraulic engineering, and their techniques for moving and controlling water were unparalleled at the time. They built aqueducts, fountains, and even intricate plumbing systems that allowed for the precise control of water flow.

It's entirely possible that these techniques were adopted and adapted in other cultures, including in the garden designs of China, Korea, and Japan. I've seen some evidence of similar water control features in Asian gardens, such as the use of channels and water wheels to circulate water.

I'd be happy to delve deeper into this topic and provide you with more detailed information and resources. I'll also look through my archives for any relevant papers or articles that could be useful for your research.

I'd love to see the photos you took of the Roman aqueducts in Italy. It would be interesting to compare them to the water features in the Japanese gardens you're studying.

Please let me know if there's anything else I can do to help with your exhibition. I'm excited to see the results of your work!

Best regards,
Marcus
label: research

body:
Message-ID: <27637909.1075855726396.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Mon, 5 Mar 2001 07:21:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
Subject: 
Cc: llewter@austin.rr.com, jacquestc@aol.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: llewter@austin.rr.com, jacquestc@aol.com
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
X-cc: llewter@austin.rr.com, jacquestc@aol.com
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

George,

I am back in the office and ready to focus on the project.  I still have the 
concerns that I had last week.  Specifically that the costs of our project 
are too high.  I have gathered more information that support my concerns.  
Based on my research, I believe the project should cost around $10.5 
million.  The components are as follows:

 Unit Cost, Site work, &
 builders profit($52/sf)   $7.6 million

 Land      1.15

 Interim Financing     .85

 Common Areas       .80

 Total     $10.4

Since Reagan's last 12 units are selling for around $190,000, I am unable to 
get comfortable building a larger project at over $95,000/unit in costs.  

Also, the comps used in the appraisal from Austin appear to be class A 
properties.  It seems unlikely that student housing in San Marcos can produce 
the same rent or sales price.  There should adjustments for location and the 
seasonal nature of student rental property.  I recognize that Sagewood is 
currently performing at occupancy and $/foot rental rates that are closer to 
the appraisal and your pro formas, however, we do not believe that the market 
will sustain these levels on a permanent basis.  Supply will inevitablely 
increase to drive this market more in balance.

After the real estate expert from Houston reviewed the proforma and cost 
estimates, his comments were that the appraisal is overly optimistic.  He 
feels that the permanent financing would potentially be around $9.8 million.  
We would not even be able to cover the interim financing.

Keith and I have reviewed the project thoroughly and are in agreement that we 
cannot proceed with total cost estimates significantly above $10.5 million.   
We would like to have a conference call tomorrow to discuss alternatives.

Phillip
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Wong <alex.wong@sciencemag.com>
To: Jordan Rivera <jordan.rivera@gmail.com>
Subject: Gene editing article series - need your expert input!

Hey Jordan,

I hope you're doing well! I know it's been a while since we've chatted, but I could really use your help on a new series I'm working on about gene editing technologies (CRISPR, etc.). I remember you did some great pieces on this topic last year, and I'd love to get your thoughts on the current state of the field, potential risks and benefits, and any other insights you might have.

I'm particularly interested in exploring the ethical and societal implications of these technologies. How do you think we, as science journalists, can best communicate these complex issues to our readers? I'd really appreciate any input or suggestions you might have.

Let me know if you have time for a quick call sometime next week to discuss further. I'm happy to buy you a coffee (or a beer!) if you're up for meeting in person.

Thanks in advance for your help!

Best,
Alex
label: research

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

George,

 The San Marcos project is sounding very attractive.  I have one other 
investor in addition to Keith that has interest.  Some additional background 
information on Larry and yourself would be helpful.

 Background Questions:
 
 Please provide a brief personal history of the two principals involved in 
Creekside.

 Please list projects completed during the last 5 years.  Include the project 
description, investors, business entity, 

 Please provide the names and numbers of prior investors.

 Please provide the names and numbers of several subcontractors used on 
recent projects.


 With regard to the proposed investment structure, I would suggest a couple 
of changes to better align the risk/reward profile between Creekside and the 
investors. 


 Preferable Investment Structure:

 Developers guarantee note, not investors.

 Preferred rate of return (10%) must be achieved before any profit sharing.

 Builder assumes some risk for cost overruns.

         Since this project appears so promising, it seems like we should 
tackle these issues now.  These questions are not intended to be offensive in 
any way.  It is my desire to build a successful project with Creekside that 
leads to future opportunities.  I  am happy to provide you with any 
information that you need to evaluate myself or Keith as a business partner.

Sincerely,

Phillip Allen

body:
<email>
From: Jamie Thompson <jthompson@ucl.ac.uk>
To: Alex Chen <achen@u.washington.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting new data from the Cascades

Alex,

Great to hear from you, and thanks for sending along the draft! I had a chance to read through it this morning and the data indeed looks really compelling. The similarity to the Iceland findings is quite remarkable.

I completely agree this could be the seed of an important new project. Being able to tie together data from different volcanic arcs like the Cascades and Iceland could really elevate the modeling work we want to do. 

I'm definitely in for collaborating on a grant proposal. If we can get the right funding, I think we could put together a dream team to really advance the science on this.

I'll start sketching out some ideas for the proposal and will send you my thoughts early next week. In the meantime, let's set up a call for later in the week to discuss further.

Looking forward to diving into this more with you! I'll be in touch soon.

All the best,
Jamie

Bob,

 Patti Sullivan held together the scheduling group for two months while Randy 
Gay was on a personal leave.  She displayed a tremendous amount of commitment 
to the west desk during that time.  She frequently came to work before 4 AM 
to prepare operations reports.  Patti worked 7 days a week during this time.  
If long hours were not enough, there was a pipeline explosion during this 
time which put extra volatility into the market and extra pressure on Patti.  
She didn't crack and provided much needed info during this time.

 Patti is performing the duties of a manager but being paid as a sr. 
specialist.  Based on her heroic efforts, she deserves a PBR.  Let me know 
what is an acceptable cash amount.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@sciencewriter.com>
To: David Patel <david.patel@healthcommunicator.net>
Subject: Our book is finally done!

Hi David,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share the exciting news that our book, "The Science of Sleep: Understanding the Mysteries of Rest," is finally complete and ready for publication. It's been a long journey, but I'm so proud of the work we've done together.

I've attached the final manuscript for your review. Please let me know if you have any last-minute suggestions or changes. Otherwise, I'll send it off to the publisher next week.

I'm also thinking about how we can promote the book and get it into the hands of as many readers as possible. Do you have any ideas for marketing or events we could organize? I'm open to suggestions!

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts and celebrating this milestone with you.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Rachel Nguyen <rachelnguyen@oceansidehigh.org>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@lakesideschool.edu>
Subject: RE: Service-Learning Trip to Guatemala

Hi Emily,

Thanks for sending over the trip overview. I had a chance to review it, and it looks like an incredible opportunity for your students. I'm particularly interested in learning more about the partnership with the local organization and how you went about selecting the projects and activities for the trip.

I've also been thinking about how we could structure a similar trip for our students and what kinds of projects might be most impactful and meaningful for them. I'd love to brainstorm some ideas with you on our call.

I'm looking forward to our conversation on Wednesday at 2 pm EST. In the meantime, feel free to reach out if you have any other questions or thoughts you'd like to share.

Best,
Rachel
label: research

<email>
From: Samantha Johnson <s.johnson@americanhist.org>
To: Alexei Volkov <alex.vol@spbhistory.ru>
Subject: RE: Draft chapter on Russian-American negotiations

Alexei,

Thanks for sending over the updated draft. I'm impressed with the new section on the Russian-American Company – it really adds depth to our understanding of the economic factors at play.

I made a few minor edits and added some additional sources I came across. I think we're almost ready to move on to the next chapter. What do you think about tackling the aftermath of the purchase and its impact on both countries next?

I hope you're doing well in St. Petersburg. It's been unseasonably warm here in D.C., which has been a nice change of pace.

Best,
Sam

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@nationalweatherservice.gov>
To: John Smith <john.smith@nationalweatherservice.gov>
Subject: RE: Hurricane Omar Update

John,

I agree with your assessment of the radar data. The storm is definitely intensifying more quickly than we anticipated. We need to act fast to update our forecast and get the word out to the public.

I suggest we hold a joint press conference with the National Hurricane Center to discuss the updated forecast and the potential impacts of the storm. We should also reach out to our colleagues at the local weather offices to make sure they have the latest information and are prepared to issue warnings for their areas.

Let me know what time works best for you to meet and finalize our plan.

Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Rachel Steinberg <rsteinberg@paleouniverse.org>
To: Alex Chen <achen@oakvilleschools.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from the conference

Hi Alex,

I'm thrilled that you're interested in incorporating my research into your teaching! I would be more than happy for you to use my data in your lessons, and I'm glad you'll be properly citing my work. I think it's so important for students to understand the real-world applications of scientific research.

I'd be happy to provide guidance on how to present the information in an engaging way for your students. We could set up a call to discuss the specific data you're interested in using and brainstorm some ideas for lessons or activities.

I also love the idea of having your students participate in a virtual paleontology project. I think it could be a great way for them to gain hands-on experience with the scientific process and see how paleontological data is collected and analyzed. We could have them work with real fossil data and guide them through the process of interpreting it.

Let me know what you think about all of this, and we can start planning our next steps!

Best,
Rachel

body:
<email>
From: David Chen <david.chen@education.org>
To: Sarah Al-Hayani <sarah.al-hayani@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Following up from the conference

Hi Sarah,

The script sounds great! I'm excited to see how you've structured the lesson and presented Jabir ibn Hayyan's life and work. Including the historical context of the Islamic Golden Age is a fantastic idea. It will give students a more holistic understanding of the time period and its impact on scientific progress.

As for platforms, I've had good experiences using Canvas and Google Classroom for hosting educational content. They both offer a range of features for creating interactive lessons and tracking student progress. Let me know if you have any other preferences, and I can look into them.

I'll start working on the visual elements for the lesson, such as illustrations and animations to help explain complex concepts. I'll keep you updated on my progress.

Thanks for your collaboration on this project. I'm confident that we'll create something truly valuable for students and educators!

Best,
David

Jacques,

George finally sent me some information.  Please look over his email.  He 
wants us to buy him out.  Keith and I think this is a joke.  

We still need to speak to his engineer and find out about his soil study to 
determine if it has any value going forward.  I don't believe the architect 
work will be of any use to us.  I don't think they deserve any compensation 
for their time due to the fact that intentional or not the project they were 
proposing was unsupportable by the market.  

My version of a buyout is attached.

I need your expert advise.  I am ready to offer my version or threaten to 
foreclose.  Do they have a case that they are due money for their time?  
Since their cost
and fees didn't hold up versus the market and we didn't execute a contract, I 
wouldn't think they would stand a chance.  There isn't any time to waste so I 
want to respond to their offer asap.

Call me with your thoughts.

Phillip

Phillip Allen

Keith Holst

ENRON

1400 Smith Street

Houston, TX? 77002-7361

Subject: Bishops Corner, Ltd. -- Restructure or Buyout

Dear Phillip and Keith: 

We are prepared to sell Bishops Corner, Ltd. for reimbursement of our cash 
expenditures; compensation for our management services and your assumption of 
all note obligations and design contracts.? 

As shown on the attached summary table, cash expenditures total $21,196 and 
existing contracts to the architect, civil engineer, soils testing company, 
and appraisal total $67,050.? The due on these contracts is $61,175, of which 
current unpaid invoices due total $37,325.

Acting in good faith, we have invested an enormous amount of time into this 
project for more than five months and have completed most of the major design 
and other pre-construction elements.? As it is a major project for a firm of 
our size, it was given top priority with other projects being delayed or 
rejected, and we are now left with no project to pursue.? 

Two methods for valuing this development management are 1) based on a 
percentage of the minimum $1.4MM fee we were to have earned and 2) based on 
your prior valuation of our time.? For the first, we feel that at least 25%, 
or $350,000, of the minimum $1.4MM fee has been earned to date.? For the 
second, in your prior correspondence you valued our time at $500,000 per 
year, which would mean this period was worth $208,333.? Either of these 
valuations seem quite fair and reasonable, especially as neither includes the 
forfeit of our 40% interest in the project worth $0.8--$1.2MM. ?However, in 
the hope that we can maintain a good relationship with the prospect of future 
projects, we are willing to accept only a small monthly fee of $15,000 per 
month to cover a portion of our direct time and overhead.? As shown in the 
attached table, this fee, plus cash outlays and less accrued interest brings 
the total net buyout to $78,946.? 

We still believe that this project needs the professional services that we 
offer and have provided.? However, if you accept the terms of this buyout 
offer, which we truly feel is quite fair and reasonable, then, we are 
prepared to be bought out and leave this extraordinary project to you both.? 
If this is your 



choice, either contact us, or have your attorney contact our attorney, 
Claudia Crocker, no later than Friday of this week.? The attorneys can then 
draft whatever minimal documents are necessary for the transfer of the 
Bishops Corner, Ltd. Partnership to you following receipt of the buyout 
amount and assumption of the outstanding professional design contracts.

Thank you.

?

Sincerely,

[IMAGE]

?

?

?

George W. Richards 

President

P.S.????? Copies of contracts will be forwarded upon acceptance of buyout.

?

cc:??????? Larry Lewter
??????????? Claudia Crocker

body:
<email>
From: Lina Andersson <lina.andersson@stockholmuniversity.se>
To: Erik Lindström <erik.lindstrom@stockholmuniversity.se>
Subject: Swedish Language Course - Final Prep

Erik,

I hope you're doing well. As we approach the start of the new semester, I wanted to touch base with you regarding our Swedish language course. I've been reviewing the course materials and syllabus, and I think we've put together a solid foundation for our students to learn and grow.

I was wondering if you could take a look at the attached assessment rubrics and provide your feedback. I'd like to ensure that we're aligning our expectations and grading criteria with the course learning objectives. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or changes you'd like to make.

Also, I wanted to confirm our plans for the first day of class. Are you still comfortable with the proposed icebreaker activity and course introduction? I think it's a great way to engage the students right from the start and set the tone for the semester.

Looking forward to your thoughts and to a successful launch of our Swedish language course!

Best regards,
Lina
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thorne <emily.thorne@oldenglishdictionary.com>
To: James Fitzgerald <james.fitzgerald@middleenglishinstitute.edu>
Subject: Fascinating Proto-Germanic roots

Dear James,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been digging deeper into the Proto-Germanic roots of some Old English words and stumbled upon a fascinating connection between the words "hēafod" (head) and "hæft" (haft). It seems that both words share a common ancestor in Proto-Germanic, which suggests a link between the concepts of "head" and "handle."

I found an article on the subject that I thought you might find interesting: [link to article]

What do you think about this connection? Have you come across any similar discoveries in your research?

Best regards,
Emily
