body:
<email>
From: Alex Chen <alex@soundarchitecture.com>
To: Emily Thompson <emily@prenatalcareclinic.com>
Subject: RE: Acoustic Solutions for Our New Prenatal Care Clinic

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out, and I'm excited to work on this project with you. Creating a calming and peaceful environment is crucial for the well-being of expectant mothers, and I'm glad you recognize the importance of acoustics in achieving that goal.

Based on the information you provided, I have a few initial recommendations:

1. Sound-absorbing materials: Incorporating sound-absorbing materials such as acoustic panels, bass traps, and carpeting can help reduce echo and reverberation, creating a more peaceful environment.

2. Background noise control: Implementing a sound masking system can help minimize the impact of external noises and create a consistent, soothing background sound.

3. Soundproofing: Ensuring proper soundproofing, especially in the walls and windows, can help prevent outside noises from entering the clinic.

I would love to schedule an in-person meeting to assess the space and provide a more detailed proposal. How about next Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon? Please let me know which day works best for you.

Looking forward to working together on this project!

Best regards,
Alex Chen

<email>
From: David Lee <dlee@techdocs.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@edtech.edu>
Subject: RE: Follow-up from OpenEdTech conference

Hi Emily,

Thanks for reaching out! I'm glad you found my presentation useful. I'd be happy to help you with creating documentation for your learning management system.

From what I understand, open-source learning management systems can be quite complex, with a lot of different features and options. When creating user guides, it's important to focus on the most essential tasks and workflows, and to explain them in a clear and concise way.

I can share some templates and best practices for creating user guides and tutorials. I'm also happy to review any drafts you have and provide feedback.

Let me know what kind of help you need and we can set up a time to discuss further.

Best regards,
David

<email>
From: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@restorativedentistry.com>
To: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@dentaltech.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on dental prosthetics research

Emily,

Thank you for sharing the research project outline. I appreciate the time and effort you've put into developing this proposal. After reviewing the document, I must say that I'm impressed by your thorough understanding of the subject matter and the potential implications of your research.

The project's focus on advanced biomaterials and their applications in dental prosthetics aligns well with my own research interests. I believe that collaborating on this project could lead to valuable insights and contribute to the advancement of restorative dentistry.

I have a few suggestions and questions regarding the methodology and expected outcomes, which I'd like to discuss with you further. Would you be available for a video call next week to iron out the details and establish a clear roadmap for our collaboration?

Please let me know your availability, and we can schedule a meeting at a mutually convenient time.

Best regards,
Dr. Michael Thompson

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@lincolnhigh.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Fascinating presentation at the "Genetics and Infectious Diseases" conference

Dear Dr. Johnson,

Thank you so much for your prompt response and for agreeing to share resources with us. My students and I are eager to dive into the materials you'll be sending our way. We're particularly interested in learning more about the genetic factors that contribute to disease susceptibility and resistance in different populations.

The project idea you mentioned sounds perfect! My students would be thrilled to work with real data and create visualizations to help communicate your findings. I think this experience will give them a deeper understanding of the practical applications of genetics and the importance of scientific research in addressing global health challenges.

As for the guest lecture, we would be honored to have you speak to our class. I think a webinar format would work best, given the current circumstances. If you're available, I was thinking we could schedule it for the week of May 10th, during our regular class time (10:00 AM - 11:30 AM CST). Please let me know if that works with your schedule.

Lastly, I wanted to mention that our school is planning a virtual science fair in June, and I think your work would be a perfect fit for our theme of "Genetics and Global Health." If you're interested, I would be happy to put you in touch with the organizing committee to discuss the possibility of having you as our keynote speaker.

Thank you again for your willingness to collaborate with us. I'm looking forward to working with you and introducing my students to the exciting world of research and scientific discovery.

Best regards,
Emily Thompson
Lincoln High School

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: David Lee <dlee@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on the new STEM outreach course

Hi David,

I love your ideas for the chemistry component! Focusing on the periodic table, chemical bonding, and basic chemical reactions is perfect for this age group and will give them a solid foundation for understanding more advanced concepts in the future. The idea of having them build elements and simulate reactions in Minecraft is brilliant – it's engaging, interactive, and really drives home the concepts in a way that's fun and memorable.

In terms of learning objectives and outcomes, I think we should aim for the students to:
1. Gain a basic understanding of fundamental programming concepts like loops, conditionals, and variables.
2. Understand the structure of the periodic table and be able to identify key elements and their properties.
3. Grasp the basics of chemical bonding and how different elements interact to form compounds.
4. Apply their programming skills to create a game or simulation that demonstrates a chemistry concept they've learned.

I think if we can achieve these objectives, we'll have done a great job of introducing these subjects to the students and inspiring them to explore further.

What do you think? I'm open to any suggestions or modifications you might have. I'm also happy to take the lead on the programming component if you'd like to focus on the chemistry side of things.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best,
Emily

Ray Alvarez@ENRON
04/25/2001 11:48 AM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Re: This morning's Commission meeting delayed  

Phil,  I suspect that discussions/negotiations are taking place behind closed 
doors "in smoke filled rooms", if not directly between Commissioners then 
among FERC staffers.  Never say never, but I think it is highly unlikely that 
the final order will contain a fixed price cap.  I base this belief in large 
part on what I heard at a luncheon I attended yesterday afternoon at which 
the keynote speaker was FERC Chairman Curt Hebert.  Although the Chairman 
began his presentation by expressly stating that he would not comment or 
answer questions on pending proceedings before the Commission, Hebert had 
some enlightening comments which relate to price caps:

Price caps are almost never the right answer
Price Caps will have the effect of prolonging shortages
Competitive choices for consumers is the right answer
Any solution, however short term, that does not increase supply or reduce 
demand, is not acceptable
Eight out of eleven western Governors oppose price caps, in that they would 
export California's problems to the West

This is the latest intelligence I have on the matter, and it's a pretty 
strong anti- price cap position.  Of course, Hebert is just one Commissioner 
out of 3 currently on the Commission, but he controls the meeting agenda and 
if the draft order is not to his liking, the item could be bumped off the 
agenda.  Hope this info helps.  Ray




Phillip K Allen@ECT
04/25/2001 02:28 PM
To: Ray Alvarez/NA/Enron@ENRON
cc:  

Subject: Re: This morning's Commission meeting delayed  

Are there behind closed doors discussions being held prior to the meeting?  
Is there the potential for a surprise announcement of some sort of fixed 
price gas or power cap once the open meeting finally happens?

body:
<email>
From: Michael Lee <mlee@acmeinc.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@acmeinc.com>
Subject: RE: Project Update - Data Storage Strategy

Hi Emily,

Thanks for the update. I completely agree with your assessment of the key areas we need to focus on. Preserving our historical data is crucial, and I've been researching some promising solutions for migrating this data to a more modern and accessible platform.

As for optimizing our storage infrastructure, I think we have a great opportunity to leverage cloud-based solutions to achieve the scalability and flexibility we need. I've been in discussions with a few vendors who offer some innovative products that I believe could fit our requirements.

I'm happy to meet next week to discuss these topics in more detail. I'm available on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning, so please let me know which works best for you.

Looking forward to our continued collaboration on this important project.

Best,
Michael

To: Alex Rivera <arivera@unm.edu>
Subject: Following up from SEHP conference

Hi Alex,

It was great to meet you at the SEHP conference last month and learn more about your work in environmental archaeology. I've been thinking a lot about our conversation on the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration, and I'm excited to explore potential synergies between our fields.

I'm particularly interested in learning more about how archaeological research can inform the siting and design of urban green spaces. As you know, my work focuses on promoting healthy environments for children, and I believe that incorporating insights from archaeology could help us create spaces that are not only beneficial for health, but also culturally meaningful and historically significant.

Would you be open to a call to discuss this further? I'd love to hear your thoughts on how we might be able to work together.

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: David Lee <dlee@numericalcoder.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@triassicreptiles.com>
Subject: RE: Need help with paleontology data analysis

Hi Emily,

Thank you for providing the sample dataset and the detailed outline of the analyses you'd like to perform. I've reviewed the data and the document, and I think I have a good understanding of what you need.

I'll start by designing the database schema to efficiently store the fossil measurements and associated metadata. Then, I'll write programs in C++ to perform the statistical analyses you described, including the descriptive statistics, PCA, and phylogenetic analyses. I'll also create functions to generate the visualizations you requested, such as scatterplots, histograms, and phylogenetic trees.

Throughout the development process, I'll keep you updated on my progress and share any preliminary results or visualizations. Please feel free to provide feedback or request any changes or additional features as we go along.

I'm excited to dive into this project and contribute to your research. Combining my programming skills with your expertise in paleontology is a unique opportunity, and I'm eager to see what insights we can uncover from your fossil data.

Best regards,
David Lee

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Nguyen <enguyen@uw.edu>
To: Mike Thompson <mthompson@lincolnhs.org>
Subject: RE: Need advice on teaching ball control skills

Hi Mike,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad the resources I shared have been helpful. 

I completely understand the struggle of having players who are struggling with fundamental technical skills. It can be really frustrating, especially when it's impacting the team's performance. 

Based on my research, one thing that can be effective is providing a lot of augmented feedback, especially in the early stages of learning a new skill. This means giving specific, skill-related feedback very frequently during practice. So for dribbling, you might provide feedback on things like the angle of their foot, the pace they're dribbling at, their body positioning, where they're looking, etc. Research has shown that this type of frequent, specific feedback can really accelerate learning.

Another thing to consider is the structure of your practices. Block practice, where players repeat the same skill over and over, is often less effective than random or variable practice, where they're switching between different but related skills. So for example, instead of having them just dribble in straight lines for 20 minutes, you might have them dribble in different patterns, pass the ball to each other, do 1v1 drills, etc. The cognitive demand of switching between tasks can actually help with learning.

I've attached a couple articles that go into more detail on these concepts that you might find useful.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions or if there's anything else I can do to support you. And keep me posted on how it goes with your team!

Best,
Emily

<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@maritimehistory.org>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@caribbeanarchaeology.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting discovery in Jamaica!

Emily,

Wednesday afternoon works great for me. Let's schedule the call for 2 PM EST. I'll send you a meeting invite with the Zoom link.

Thank you for sending the preliminary data and images. I'm reviewing them now, and I must say, this is truly remarkable. The design and construction of the fish weir suggest a level of sophistication and knowledge that challenges our current understanding of ancient Caribbean cultures.

I have a few initial ideas for further research, which I'll share with you during our call. I'm also reaching out to a colleague who specializes in ancient Caribbean pottery. She may be able to provide additional insights into the dating and cultural context of the site.

I'm thrilled to be a part of this groundbreaking project, and I'm confident that our collaboration will yield significant results.

Best,
Michael

To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakwoodhigh.org>
Subject: RE: World War II Unit - Geography Integration

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad you're interested in incorporating geography into your World War II unit. I think it's a fantastic idea to help students understand the scope of the war and its impact on different regions.

One idea that comes to mind is having students create maps that showcase the key events and battles of the war. They could use different colors and symbols to represent the Allied and Axis powers, as well as important geographic features like mountains, rivers, and strategic locations.

I would be more than happy to collaborate with you on this project and share my expertise in geography. We could even have our students work together on the mapping project, which could be a great opportunity for cross-curricular collaboration.

Let me know what you think, and we can set up a time to discuss this further.

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakwoodms.org>
To: Dr. David Theriot <dtheriot@ulafayette.edu>
Subject: RE: Inquiry about Acadian history resources

Dear Dr. Theriot,

I couldn't agree more with your proposed structure for the blog series. It provides a logical progression through the key events and developments in Acadian history, while also highlighting their lasting impact on Louisiana's culture.

I think starting with the origins of the Acadians in the Maritime provinces is a great way to set the stage for their journey and the challenges they faced. From there, we can delve into their migration and settlement in Louisiana, exploring the factors that led to their relocation and how they adapted to their new environment.

Finally, examining the development of the Cajun identity and its connection to Acadian history will be a fascinating way to bring the series full circle and demonstrate the ongoing significance of this cultural group in our state.

As we develop each post, I will focus on creating engaging lesson plans and activities that bring the history to life for students. I will also provide suggestions for incorporating primary sources and technology tools to enhance the learning experience.

In addition to the blog series, I was wondering if you would be interested in presenting our collaborative project at the upcoming Louisiana History and Education Conference in New Orleans. It would be a great opportunity to share our work with a broader audience and potentially inspire other educators to incorporate Acadian history into their curricula.

I'm excited to get started on this project and can't wait to see what we create together!

Best regards,
Emily Johnson

October 17, 2001

Jeff:

I talked to your dad and he has mentioned that you might be interested in 
having our class build a shed for you.  We pretty much make whatever you 
would like to the specifications that you prefer. All of our buildings are 
durable and solidly constructed.  We build them in our shop and the ownner 
is rersponsible for their delivery.  There is no labor cost so you are only 
charged for the materials.

Our most popular size and style is the 8' x 12' barn . This is the most 
economical building that we construct and it is an easier one to haul to a 
given site. This building has an exterior of T-111 siding which is cedar 
style grooved exterior plywood which can be stained and sealed. We have 
usually build them with a 3'-10 1/2" wide door opening.  I would think that 
would be wide enough for a four wheeler, but you would have to have your 
dad measure your vehicle to make sure.. We have probably built and sold 
over 30 of these in the past ten years. The price on this shed usually 
varies between $800 and $900.



Your dad also indicated an interest in a 10 x 12 gable style shed which is 
a bit bigger and ofcourse more expensive.  It has vinyl siding and aluminum 
soffit/overhang, I am attaching a picture of one we made for Joe 
Pronschinske.  This project is a bit harder to transport as it is oversize 
and legally you are  to obtain an oversize laod permit to haul it.   Your 
dad indicated that Joe would possibly haul it though.
The picture I am attaching shows a common 3' entry door.  We are presently 
building a structure for Nolan Goplin that has a overhead 6' wide roll up 
door.  The price on a 10' x 12' shed with a 6' wide roll-up door would be 
roughly $1500.


We will build either style and can modify the plans to meet your 
needs.  With the time we have left in the semester the 8 x 12 would be the 
easiest for us to build, but if you let me know right away, by Monday 
October 22, that you would like a 10 x12 size we would still be able to 
finish that one on time.

If you have any questions just e-mail me or call:
	Whitehall School Disctrict 715-538-4364
	My Home number 715-985-3063.

Have a good one and take with you later.

Sincerely,

Mel Nelson

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Johnson <sjohnson@marineresearch.org>
To: Alex Thompson <athompson@sciencelearninghub.com>
Subject: Collaborating on whale migration project

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well! It's been great to stay in touch since the conference, and I've been really excited about the idea of collaborating on a project together. I think your skills in science communication and education would be a perfect fit for sharing the findings from my research on whale migration patterns and coastal ecology with a wider audience.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in meeting up for a video call to discuss the project in more detail? I'd love to hear your thoughts on how we can make the topic engaging and accessible, and brainstorm some ideas for the articles, infographics, and videos we could create.

Let me know if you have any availability in the coming weeks to chat!

Best,
Samantha
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@hillsideacademy.edu>
To: Michael Chen <michael.chen@oakwoodschool.org>
Subject: Great meeting you at the workshop!

Hi Michael,

It was great meeting you at the "Coding Across Curricula" workshop last weekend. I really enjoyed our conversation about integrating coding into math lessons and was impressed by your experience with cross-curricular projects.

I'd love to stay in touch and exchange ideas on how we can further incorporate coding into our classrooms. If you're interested, I can send you some of the resources I've found helpful, and I'd be curious to hear more about the projects you've done with your students.

Let me know if you'd like to chat further!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Liam Patel <lpatel@quantumresearch.edu>
To: Olivia Rivera <olivia.rivera@washforchange.org>
Subject: RE: Great to meet you at the science festival!

Dear Olivia,

Thank you for reaching out and for the kind words about our panel discussion. It was indeed a pleasure to meet you and learn about the important work you're doing with WASH for Change. I'm glad to hear that you found our conversation thought-provoking.

I wholeheartedly agree with you on the need to make scientific research more accessible and engaging for the general public. Your idea of combining WASH concepts with fundamental physics principles in educational materials is fascinating and has the potential to make a real impact. I would be delighted to collaborate with you on this project.

I believe that by leveraging our complementary skills and knowledge, we can create something truly unique and effective. I'm particularly interested in exploring how we can use hands-on activities and real-world examples to make the concepts more tangible and relatable for the students and communities we aim to reach.

Please do let me know when would be a good time for you to have a call to discuss this further. I'm excited to dive deeper into this collaboration and see where it leads us.

Best regards,
Liam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Eleanor McDougall <eleanor.mcdougall@orkneyarchaeology.org>
To: Finn Mackenzie <finn.mackenzie@volcanostudies.com>
Subject: Neolithic Burial Site in the Orkneys

Dear Finn,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out to you regarding a fascinating Neolithic burial site I've been studying here in the Orkney Islands. As you know, the islands are rich in archaeological treasures, and this particular site has captured my attention due to its unique features and potential connection to a nearby volcanic eruption.

I was wondering if you might be willing to share your expertise in volcanology to help me better understand the geological context of the site. I believe that your insights could greatly enhance my research and provide valuable information about how the eruption may have affected the ancient population.

If you're interested in collaborating, I would be more than happy to share my findings with you and discuss the project in more detail. I'm particularly eager to learn more about the specific volcanic event that occurred in the region and how it might have influenced the burial practices of the Neolithic people.

Please let me know if you have any availability to discuss this further. I'm excited about the potential of this project and believe that our combined expertise could lead to some groundbreaking discoveries.

Best regards,
Eleanor
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <ajohnson@oakwood.edu>
To: Sam Patel <spatel@oakwood.edu>
Subject: RE: Titration Project Update

Hi Sam,

Thanks for your email. I'm glad to hear that you've made progress on the data analysis, and the concentration of the unknown acid seems reasonable based on our initial predictions. I'd be happy to meet up with you tomorrow afternoon to review the calculations together. How about we meet at the library at 2 pm? That should give us enough time to go over everything and make any necessary revisions.

Also, have you started working on the introduction and conclusion sections of the report? I think it would be a good idea for us to divide up the writing tasks to ensure that we can submit the report on time.

Looking forward to meeting with you tomorrow!

Best,
Alex

From: kim.godfrey@enron.com
To: bob.jordan@compaq.com, david.spurlin@compaq.com
Subject: Compaq / EBS Relationship
Cc: jim.crowder@enron.com, everett.plante@enron.com, tracy.prater@enron.com, 
	derrick.deakins@compaq.com, gil.melman@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: jim.crowder@enron.com, everett.plante@enron.com, tracy.prater@enron.com, 
	derrick.deakins@compaq.com, gil.melman@enron.com
X-From: Kim Godfrey
X-To: bob.jordan@compaq.com, david.spurlin@compaq.com
X-cc: Jim Crowder, Everett Plante, Tracy Prater, derrick.deakins@compaq.com, Gil Melman
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

David and Bob,

We look forward to working with you to strengthen the Compaq and EBS 
relationship.   EBS has identified potential server business opportunities 
(storage, streaming media) where our two organizations can work together.  
After our meeting on Dec 14th, EBS now understands to utilize David Spurlin 
as the point person for these communications.  EBS had prior direction from 
Compaq to direct our discussions to Derrick Deakins, Rob Senders, Keith 
McAuliffe or Kent Major.  Tracy Prater and myself look forward to spending 
additional time with David to ensure that he is aware of the EBS business 
opportunities and issues.  

EBS had invested significant dollars, time and energy with Compaq to develop 
the streaming media server solutions.  We discussed during the Dec 14th 
meeting that there are decisions to be made regarding the existing Product 
and Server Supply Agreement that are contingent on those streaming media 
solutions.  EBS and Compaq have both acted in good faith to achieve the 
intent of the Product and Server Supply Agreement in pursuing these 
solutions.  To that end, EBS has had internal discussions regarding the 
appropriate next steps to further our relationship.  

The January 2000 Product and Service Supply Agreement is the legal framework 
for our relationship until both parties mutually agree to change.  Until 
those changes are made:
1) 2000 Compaq Annual Purchase of ECI Services:  Per the Agreement, Compaq 
was invoiced for the 2000 Minimum Annual Purchase of ECI Services on November 
7, 2000 as per Sections 3.1, 3.2 and 3.3.  Compaq had agreed  to the invoice 
amount.  EBS expects payment for the total invoice as outlined in Section 3.0 
on or before December 31,2000.   
2) Potential for Agreement Termination:  Prior to the Dec 14th meeting, 
Compaq (Keith and Rob) have discussed this with EBS (Jim Crowder, myself).   
The understanding between both Parties was that EBS would need a written 
notice and payment by Compaq of $2,500,000.  The concept to start over with a 
new contractual agreement was again discussed during the Dec 14th meeting.  
EBS strongly believes in the value of the Compaq and EBS relationship, if 
Compaq believes that to start over with a new agreement is necessary then we 
look forward to working with Compaq to achieve that goal.  

Again, we look forward to working with yourselves to identify and create 
strategic business opportunities for both EBS and Compaq.   

Kim Godfrey
Director, Enterprise Services
Enron Broadband Services
phone : 713 345 8813
cell :      713 501 8105
fax:        713 853 7354

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Chen <mchen@westchester.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <ethompson@oakwoodes.k12.il.us>
Subject: RE: Excited about our upcoming workshop!

Emily,

Your email brightened my day! I'm equally excited about our collaboration and the opportunity to share our knowledge with a wider audience. Your suggestion for the workshop structure sounds fantastic. Starting with the overview and then delving into specific strategies is a great way to engage the participants.

I love the idea of including interactive elements! Perhaps we could have participants work in small groups to apply a technique to a hypothetical student profile. This would allow them to practice the strategy and discuss their thoughts with their peers.

As for travel, I haven't booked my flights yet, but I'm planning to do so this week. Arriving on Thursday evening and leaving on Sunday afternoon works well for me, too. I'll probably stay at the conference hotel for convenience. Do you have any other must-see recommendations for Atlanta?

I'm attaching a few articles I thought might be relevant to our workshop. I'd love to hear your thoughts on them and if you think we should incorporate any of the information into our presentation.

I'm so glad we connected at the conference last year. It's rare to find a colleague who shares your passion and enthusiasm for special education. I can't wait to see what we create together!

Best,
Michael
label: research

X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Chaz and Steve,

Here's the latest, in a nutshell.  Basically, the testing is not fully 
completed, even where we might have felt that it was close (because there is 
also a financial component which needs to be exercised - the TCO part of the 
purchase decision).  As you know, both Randy Matson and Bob McAuliffe are out 
on vacation, so getting a decision from them is not likely before Christmas.  
However, it looks like there has been enough feedback to/through them to 
surmise that BMC is not in the driver's seat in either situation.

In a meeting today, it became apparent that BMC's revenue opportunity with 
the Net Works organization is much lower than BMC has projected to you at 
EBS.  The primary opportunity for BMC in Net Works is for their Schema 
Manager tool, and the rest of the opportunities look increasingly dim, 
especially given the time constraints imposed in your situation.  

Still, the Net Works team has not completely ruled BMC out as a potential 
vendor; but neither is there a commitment (written OR verbal) to make a BMC 
purchase at this point.  I will be on vacation next week, but will be 
checking in on Monday the 18th and Tuesday the 19th.  Jennifer or I will keep 
you posted if we are able to report opportunity changes in your favor.

I have sent you a paraphrased version of Doug's most recent communication to 
me.  The overall message would apply fairly universally to the other Net 
Works teams in question:  more testing, but looks like BMC's total sales 
opportunity to Enron is not going to get to the amount necessary to get your 
deal done.  The issues mentioned in the other summary update note from 
yesterday still apply.

Thank you,

Jeff

----- Forwarded by Jeff Youngflesh/NA/Enron on 12/15/2000 05:15 PM -----

	Douglas Cummins@ECT
	12/15/2000 04:14 PM
		
		 To: Jeff Youngflesh/NA/Enron@ENRON
		 cc: 
		 Subject: Re: BMC Summary to-date

Jeff,

We backed away from Patrol for monitoring - we feel that a competitor's 
solution is a better one for us.

My group still considers BMC's Schema Manager tool to be an excellent 
product, and would consider it to be a viable option for purchase.  I believe 
Net Works will still evaluate more similar tools, and related design tools, 
before making a decision.

Regards,
Douglas

> 2001 Natural Gas Production and Price Outlook Conference Call
>
>
>  <<...OLE_Obj...>> Salomon Smith Barney <<2001 Natural Gas Conference
> Call.doc>>
> Energy Research Group
> Analyst Access Conference Call
>
> 2001 Natural Gas  Production and Price Outlook
> Hosted by:
> Bob Morris and Michael Schmitz
>  Oil and Gas Exploration & Production Analysts
>
>  Date & Time:
> FRIDAY (February 23rd)
> 11:00 a.m. EST
>
> Dial-in #:
>  US:   800-229-0281 International:  706-645-9237
>
> Replay #: (Reservation: x 819361)
>  US:   800-642-1687 International: 706-645-9291
>
> Accessing Presentation:
> * Go to https://intercallssl.contigo.com
> * Click on Conference Participant
> * Enter Event Number:  x716835
> * Enter the participant's Name, Company Name & E-mail address
> * Click Continue to view the first slide of the presentation
>
> Key Points:
> 1. Natural gas storage levels appear to be on track to exit March at
> roughly 700-800 Bcf, compared with just over 1,000 Bcf last year at the
> end of the traditional withdrawal season.
> 2. Meanwhile, domestic natural gas production should rise 3.0-5.0% this
> year, largely dependent upon the extent of the drop in rig efficiency, or
> production added per rig.
> 3. Nonetheless, under most scenarios, incorporating numerous other
> variables such as the pace of economic expansion, fuel switching and
> industrial plant closures, it appears that storage levels at the beginning
> of winter will be near or below last year's 2,800 Bcf level.
> 4. Thus, it appears likely that the "heat" will remain on natural gas
> prices throughout 2001.
> 5. Consequently, we believe that many E&P shares will post solid gains
> again this year, spurred largely by mounting confidence in the
> sustainability of strong natural gas prices.
>
>

 - 2001 Natural Gas Conference Call.doc

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@dentaltech.com>
To: Dr. Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@dentalinnovations.com>
Subject: Challenging case and new dental implant

Dear Dr. Lee,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been a while since we met at the dental conference, and I've been meaning to reach out to you regarding a challenging case I've been working on.

I have a patient with several missing teeth, and I've been considering using the new dental implant you mentioned in your presentation. I was wondering if you could provide some insights into the suitability of this implant for my patient's specific case. I would greatly appreciate your expert opinion.

Additionally, I recently read about your latest research on tooth regeneration using stem cells. The findings are fascinating, and I'm curious to know more about the potential applications in dental prosthetics.

I'm also interested in attending the upcoming conference on advances in dental materials. Would you be interested in meeting up there to discuss the latest developments?

Looking forward to hearing back from you.

Best regards,
Alex Thompson

closing--but, of course, I could be  wrong.?

Brenda

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Smith <jenna.smith@oncologytimes.com>
To: Mark Johnson <mark.johnson@envirobeat.com>
Subject: Need your expertise on a story

Hey Mark,

I hope you're doing well! I'm reaching out because I'm working on a piece about the connection between climate change and the rising rates of skin cancer. I know this is a bit outside your usual beat, but given your background in earth science and environmental reporting, I thought you might have some insights or sources to share.

I'm particularly interested in how rising temperatures and more intense UV radiation are affecting skin cancer rates, and what steps people can take to protect themselves. If you have any thoughts or could point me in the right direction, I'd really appreciate it.

Also, I'd love to catch up sometime soon. It's been too long! Let me know if you're free for a virtual coffee chat.

Best,
Jenna

<email>
From: Sam Chen <schen@techschools.org>
To: Alex Rivera <arivera@techschools.org>
Subject: RE: Grant application submitted!

Hi Alex,

That's great news about the grant application! I have a good feeling about it. We've put together a really strong proposal.

I love the idea of writing about our co-teaching experience for the blog. It was such a great example of how game-based learning can work in a classroom setting. Feel free to draft something up and send it my way. I'll take a look and add in some thoughts.

For other blog ideas, maybe we could do a post on how we got started with Minecraft in our classrooms in the first place? I know a lot of educators are interested in trying it but aren't sure where to begin. We could share some tips and resources for getting started.

I'll keep my fingers crossed on the grant! Talk to you soon,
Sam

Hi Emily,

Thanks for the quick response. I've reviewed the latest changes and I'm happy with the proposal as well. I think we've done a great job of highlighting the importance of our research and the potential benefits it could bring.

Subject: NASA's Latest Discovery

Hey Amina,

I hope you're doing well! I just came across this article about NASA's latest discovery on Mars, and I thought you might find it interesting. It seems they've found evidence of an ancient lakebed that could have once supported life. 

I know you're always looking for ways to make your science lessons more engaging, so I was wondering if this could be something you could incorporate into your curriculum? I'd love to hear your thoughts on how you could use this information to capture your students' imaginations.

Looking forward to catching up soon!

From: k..allen@enron.com
To: scott.neal@enron.com
Subject: FW: Competitive Analysis Update #4- US Terrorism Attacks
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ANSI_X3.4-1968
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-To: Neal, Scott </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Sneal>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Sent Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst



 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Johnston, Robert  
Sent:	Wednesday, September 12, 2001 5:12 AM
To:	Lay, Kenneth; Frevert, Mark; Mcconnell, Mike; Sherriff, John; Brown, Michael - COO London; Shankman, Jeffrey A.; McMahon, Jeffrey; Bowen Jr., Raymond; Lavorato, John; Kitchen, Louise; Seyfried, Bryan; Fiala, Markus; Kinneman, Jeff; Gonzales, Eric; Whitehead, Jonathan; Nowlan Jr., John L.; White, Bill; Schroeder Jr., Don; Maffett, Randal; Sekse, Per; Presto, Kevin M.; Belden, Tim; Heizenrader, Tim; Grigsby, Mike; Allen, Phillip K.; Kaminski, Vince J; Bradley, Michael; Kean, Steven J.; Robertson, Linda; Shapiro, Richard; Hirl, Joseph; Thirsk, Jeremy; O'Day, Nicholas; Greene, John; Fuller, Robert; Gordon, Michael; Tholan, Scott; Roth, Jim; Fitzsimmons, Brendan; Seigle, Clayton; Whitman, Britt; Aganon, Rommel; Landry, Kimberly; Holman, Kelly; Walsh, Kristin; Turner, Nancy; Lawlor, Dave; Kemp, John; Brindle, John; Cromley, David; Ewald, Laura; Scott, Eric; Reed, Andrea V.; Garner, Bruce
Subject:	Competitive Analysis Update #4- US Terrorism Attacks 
Importance:	High

Report is divided into Market Updates; Transportation/Infrastructure Updates; and Political Updates.  For further information, contact:

Robert Johnston x39934
Clay Seigle x31504 (oil/politics)
Brendan Fitzsimmons x34763 (financial markets)
Kelly Holman x39844 (gas/power infrastructure)

A.	Market Updates

U.S. Markets

?	NYSE and NASDAQ officially closed today.  First time NYSE closed on consecutive days since WW2.  Equity exchange officials to conference call later today to determine restart.
?	NYMEX officially closed today.  No new information on restart.
?	CBOT and CME officially closed today.  No new information on restart.
?	The Group of Seven (G-7) major countries are in talks on emergency policy coordination to prevent further turbulence in global financial markets following the terror attacks against the United States.  No official word yet on coordinated intervention.
?	Lower Manhattan trading infrastructure devastated, but generally backed-up offsite.  Clearinghouse Interbank Payment System (CHIP) continues to operate.
?	Key World Trade Center losses affect insurance, metals trading, major financial houses.  Biggest victims include MSDW, Cantor Fitzgerald, Mizuho Holdings, Bank of America, AON, Lehman Brothers
?	Congress to resume budget debate today; new focus on defense and intelligence spending; likely calls for further fiscal stimulus to reassure consumers.
?	AGA offices in DC to reopen today. AGA report on weekly storage data scheduled for today.

Japan Overnight

Nikkei ended down 6.6% at 9610; TOPIX down 6.4% at 990.80  
Nikkei below 10,000 and lower than Dow for first time since 1950s, now at Dec 1983 levels (w/o accounting for Mar. 2000 tech re-weight); more importantly, the TOPIX went through and closed below 1000 breaking down to early 1998 financial crisis lows.
Citibank market operations "normal," and no problem with settlements today despite evacuation of NY office
Japanese officials report no discussion of FX intervention but that cooperative G-7 intervention available if necessary; BoJ injected Y2 trillion to provide liquidity
Next regular BOJ policy meeting Sept. 18-19.

Europe
?	Currency trading is steady, with the dollar holding firm in European trading.
?	European bourses experience volatility, but drift into negative territory on thin trading.  Institutional investors are largely sidelined.  US stocks cross-listed on European exchanges were hit hard, especially airlines, insurance, and financials.   

Oil Markets

?	Some brokers think it likely IPE Brent trade willinish early, around 1630 GMT, Wed in the absence of Nymex.
?	Bearish Factors: Suspension of commercial air travel and possible mass cancellations once resumed; Falloff in energy demand due to shut businesses; Possible decline in equity markets and renewed fears over recession
?	Bullish Factors: Fear of increased Mideast instability; Possible stockpiling of jet fuel for military use
?	As of this morning, bearish factors seem to have the edge, with Brent Crude trading lower in London.  Bullish factors will depend on how the investigation/response develop
Canada

?	Provincial, territorial and federal mines and energy ministers cancelled the second day of their two-day meeting in Quebec City.
?	Toronto Stock Exchange expected to remain closed today.	


B.	Transportation/Infrastructure Updates


Gas/Power Infrastructure

?	The US Nuclear Regulatory Commission placed all nuclear power plants, research reactors, nuclear fuel facilities and gaseous diffusion plants on the highest level of security alert Tuesday.  No companies have reported a curtailment of generation as a result of yesterday's attack.
?	According to the NY ISO (Independent System Operator) the NY grid was functioning normally following the attacks on the WTC.
?	ConEd went into a "thunderstorm alert", increasing in-city generation.  Electricity, gas and steam service was suspended in an area in SW Manhattan.
?	Natural Gas Intelligence is quoting a source that a force majeure could be declared by pipeline operators as a result of  "confusion regarding accurate registration of nominations."  No other confirmation was available.
?	The Interstate Natural Gas Association of America, which represents the nation's interstate natural gas pipelines, sent out an advisory urging its members follow procedures to increase security.
?	Kinder Morgan's Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America (NGPL) froze the status of its flowing gas volumes no longer accepting any changes to confirmed and scheduled volumes.  Gas scheduled for Tuesday, Sept. 11 will roll forward and this situation will continue until further notice.
?	Enbridge, Alliance, and TransCanada report increased security along pipeline facilities, but no expectations of supply/delivery interruption
BPA operating on skeleton crew.  All non-essential personnel was evacuated, however, no threats against the hydro generator have been issued.
FERC cancelled regular Wednesday meeting, not rescheduled.
Authorities in Chicago barricaded the entrances to power plants and pumping facilities with concrete blocks and heavy trucks.
?	Grand Coulee Dam and powerhouse in Washington state operational, but locked down
?	Hoover Dam on Nevada-Arizona line is locked down.

Refineries/Crude/Products

?	Tosco refinery in Linden NJ closed.  
?	Force Majeure likely to be declared by major crude product receivers in US ports; 
?	LA/Long Beach inspecting all incoming shipping-all incoming ships anchoring seven miles outside port.
?	Louisiana Offshore Oil Port operations suspended pending security inspections.
?	Reports 
?	Despite these problems, The American Petroleum Institute announced overnight that US energy markets were continuing to function smoothly, with oil deliveries "flowing normally" to the country's wholesale and retail markets.

Telecommunications

?	Verizon switch on 10th floor of World Trade Center gone; 50,000 Manhattan lines taken out; Sprint and Verizon report all other data system busy, but operating normally

Air Travel

?	FAA ban on outbound flights until noon EST today at the earliest.
?	Huge logistics headaches and delays expected by airlines and air traffic controllers once US flights resume.
?	Air cargo delays considerable due to rigorous inspections.

Maritime Transportation Conditions

?	St. Lawrence Seaway reopened.  Coast Guard inspections stepped up.
?	New York Port closed, not receiving refined projects- Colonial Pipeline deliveries expected to "catch big premiums."

Border Crossings

?	Security at all US-Canada border crossings on maximum alert.  Bridges/tunnels closed.  Freight forwarders reporting that freight movements over the border have slowed to a trickle.
?	Rail freight moving normally across Canada-US border.
?	US-Mexico border reopen, but subject to delays and inspections on US side.  Mexican officials request that Mexican citizens delay trips to the US.


Political Update

International

US Arab allies (Egypt, Saudi, Jordan, Kuwait, UAE) walking a fine line.  Masses believe US got what it deserves, but leaders have to condemn attacks to maintain relations with Washington.  Moderate Arab leaders are concerned that support for attacks at home -- and possible US reactions to strike -- will increase instability and could lead to major upheaval in their countries.  Saudi sources expect "state of confusion" to exist for immediate period ahead.

In the West, no intelligence or law enforcement agency has anything concrete yet. Everything is therefore speculation, albeit logical speculation. Most importantly, the sophistication means someone bigger than bin Laden was involved, even if he was the final perpetrator. 

Oil Politics

OPEC's Rodriguez has reassured oil markets on supplies, but no high-level Saudi officials have officially echoed this sentiment (nothing from Oil Minister Naimi).  Unofficially, we have reports that Saudi officials reporting that the terrorist incident "relieves pressure on us to make anti-US moves" in oil policy.
label: corporate

body:
Message-ID: <30624982.1075862163455.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Sat, 24 Nov 2001 09:49:48 -0800 (PST)
From: kirk.mcdaniel@enron.com
Subject: Re: Futures and Options Topics - Dutch Quigley
Cc: tim.o'rourke@enron.com, yevgeny.frolov@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@wildlifeconservation.org>
To: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@earthadvocates.net>
Subject: Excited for the Global Conservation Summit!

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to touch base and see if you're still planning to attend the Global Conservation Summit in Cape Town next month. I just booked my flights and accommodations, and I'm really looking forward to it. It's been a while since we've had the chance to catch up in person!

I've been reading up on some of the speakers and sessions, and there are quite a few that I think would be particularly interesting for our work with the Pangolin project. I'd love to compare notes and see if we can come up with some new strategies for raising awareness and pushing for stronger protections.

Let me know if you have any other must-see sessions or events in mind. It would be great to coordinate our schedules and make sure we have some time to brainstorm together.

Looking forward to seeing you in Cape Town!

Best,
Emily

Jacques,

The agreement looks fine.   My only comment is that George and Larry might 
object to the language that "the bank that was requested to finance the 
construction of the project declined to make the loan based on the high costs 
of the construction of the Project".   Technically, that bank lowered the 
loan amount based on lower estimates of rents which altered the amount of 
equity that would be required. 

Did I loan them $1,300,000?  I thought it was less.

Regarding Exhibit A, the assets include:  the land, architectural plans, 
engineering completed, appraisal, and soils study.   Most of these items are 
in a state of partial completion by the consultants.  I have been speaking 
directly to the architect, engineer, and soils engineer.   I am unclear on 
what is the best way to proceed with these consultants.  

The obligations should include the fees owed to the consultants above.  Do we 
need to list balances due or just list the work completed as an asset  and 
give consideration of $5,875 for the cash paid to the engineer and appraisor.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: David Thompson <david@datadeveloper.io>
To: Emily Johnson <emily@cyberguardians.com>
Subject: RE: Database Design for CyberGuardians Educational Platform

Dear Emily,

Thank you for sending over the platform overview. I had a chance to review the document and must say that I am impressed by the thoughtfulness and comprehensiveness of your approach to teaching digital literacy and online safety to young learners.

Based on the information provided, I have a few initial thoughts and questions to discuss during our call:

1. User Roles and Access Control: Given the various user types (students, teachers, parents) and the need for different access levels, we should consider implementing a role-based access control system within the database.

2. Data Security: As the platform deals with sensitive user information, particularly that of minors, we must prioritize data encryption, secure authentication mechanisms, and regular security audits.

3. Scalability and Performance: To accommodate the platform's growth and ensure a smooth user experience, we should design the database with scalability in mind, considering options like sharding or partitioning.

4. Progress Tracking and Analytics: To effectively track user progress and provide valuable insights, we may need to implement a separate analytics database that can handle complex queries and reporting.

I look forward to discussing these points and any other requirements or concerns you may have during our call on Tuesday.

Best regards,
David Thompson
Database Developer, DataDeveloper.io

I apologize if I didn't make myself clear over the phone.  There is a process 
that we must follow for software upgrades to ensure compatibility with 
existing applications and supportability for the helpdesk staff, even if it 
is for a small subset of the population.  Furthermore, all applications must 
be packaged by Application Integration before it gets rolled out to the 
desktops.  As you can see, it is more than dispatching desktop support to 
install the application itself.

Have you guys look at other technologies such as NetMeeting?  It is installed

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@healthsciencewriters.com>
To: Dr. Emily Davis <emily.davis@envirosciences.org>
Subject: Interview Request for Upcoming Article Series

Dear Dr. Davis,

I hope this email finds you well. As you may recall, we met at the medical conference last year where you presented your fascinating research on the effects of microplastics on human health. I was truly intrigued by your work and have been following your progress ever since.

I am reaching out to you today because I am currently working on a series of articles about the impact of environmental factors on human health, and I believe your expertise on microplastics and pollution would be invaluable to my readers. I would be honored if you could spare some time for an interview to discuss your recent study and its implications for human health.

I understand that you will be speaking at the upcoming medical conference in Chicago next month, and I will be in attendance as well. If you are available, I would love to schedule a time to meet with you in person for the interview. Please let me know your availability and any other preferences you may have.

Thank you for considering my request. I look forward to the opportunity to collaborate with you on this important topic.

Best regards,
Sarah Johnson
Health Science Writer

 Thanks for the research report on EOG.  Here are my observations:

  Gas Sales 916,000/day x 365 days = 334,340,000/year
  
  Estimated Gas Prices $985,721,000/334,340,000= $2.95/mcf

  Actual gas prices are around $1.00/mcf higher and rising. 

   Recalc of EPS with more accurate gas prices:
  (334,340,000 mct X $1/mcf)/116,897,000 shares outst = $2.86 additional EPS 
X 12 P/E multiple = $34 a share


 That is just a back of the envelope valuation based on gas prices.  I think 
crude price are undervalued by the tune of $10/share.

 Current price 37
 Nat. Gas 34
 Crude  10

 Total  81

 
 Can you take a look at these numbers and play devil's advocate?  To me this 
looks like the best stock to own Also can you send me a report on Calpine, 
Tosco, and SLB?


Thank you,

 Phillip

<email>
From: Dr. John Reynolds <jreynolds@skincancerresearch.org>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@healthnews.com>
Subject: Re: Request for Interview - Article on Skin Cancer Treatments

Dear Emily,

I am glad to hear that the interview was helpful for your article. I appreciate your dedication to providing accurate and informative content to your readers.

Regarding additional resources, I suggest including links to reputable organizations such as the American Academy of Dermatology (https://www.aad.org/) and the Skin Cancer Foundation (https://www.skincancer.org/) for readers who may want to learn more about skin cancer prevention and treatment.

I look forward to reading the final article. Please do send me the link once it is published.

Thank you for your hard work in raising awareness about skin cancer and the importance of ongoing research in this field.

Best regards,
Dr. John Reynolds

Hi Kirk,

Here are the answers to some of your questions and concerns on the Topic
Frameworks.  These updates, along with discussions with SMEs, took a total
of one hour.

Accounting and Reporting - (1) Deal Flow - <<According to Berney Aucoin>>
there is no difference between an Orginator/Marketer  on the deal flow,
they stated that a deal is a deal and it is the same for everyone.  (2)
Roles associated within the Desk - <<According to Berney Aucoin >> Admin
support and Commerical support should not be added.  We are concentrating
on the major roles within a desk, any more granular could be inaccurate
because it is different for every company.  Admin support - answers the
phones and Commerical support runs the books in the back office.

Commodity Fundamentals - (1) Broker fees and Margin calls were added in the
overview, <<According to Berney Aucoin>> it was worth mentioning, but
wholesale is exempt from fees and taxes.  (2) Industrial, Retail and
Wholesale was added as an i.e., by consumption by consumer

Organizational Structure - (1) Communication - Inter/Intra department
communications were added into the Challenges of Managing Trading Function
and Trading System. Inter department communication (i.e., between
departments within organization) and Intra department communications (i.e.,
between roles on a desk after a trade/deal) (between desks, internal
communication between Marketer, Originator, Structurer and Trader, after a
trade and reconciling position reports)

Risk Management Inputs - Consequences within VaR guidelines was added to
"Trading outside of prescribed VaR guidelines

Swaps - Types of credit classifications was added to Credit Review under
Protecting Againist Loss.

The note for the references used was included on every topic framework -
*Note: Please note in your assignments when using additional resources
other than the BRM course material and your own knowledge. Please do not
copy and paste from Derivatives 1 or any other resource material. This will
significantly help us deter any copyright infringements. Thank you

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@university.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@college.edu>
Subject: Feedback on our curriculum draft

Dear Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I've just finished reviewing the feedback we received on our curriculum draft from our colleagues. Overall, I think the response has been quite positive, but there are a few areas where I believe we could make some improvements.

First, I think we need to spend more time in the introductory chapter explaining the importance of understanding the U.S. political system and how it impacts our daily lives. Several reviewers mentioned that this would help engage students from the beginning.

Second, I think we could benefit from including more real-world examples and case studies throughout the curriculum. This would help illustrate the concepts we're teaching and make the material more relatable to students.

Lastly, I think we should consider adding a chapter on the role of media in politics. This is a topic that is becoming increasingly important, and I think our students would benefit from a deeper understanding of how media influences the political landscape.

What do you think about these suggestions? I'm happy to take the lead on incorporating them into the next draft if you agree. Let me know if you have any other ideas or feedback.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Ethan Wilson <ethan.wilson@historynerds.com>
To: Olivia Thompson <olivia.thompson@revolutionarytales.com>
Subject: RE: Podcast collaboration ideas

Olivia,

I like your idea of mixing narrative storytelling with expert interviews. It could help us provide a more well-rounded perspective on each topic. We could reach out to some of the historians we've cited in our blog posts and see if they'd be interested in participating.

For the social media campaign, I think creating teaser videos and graphics is a great idea. We could also do a countdown to the launch date and share some behind-the-scenes content to build anticipation. Offering a sneak peek to our email subscribers is a fantastic way to incentivize sign-ups and create a sense of exclusivity.

I'm available for a call this Friday at 2 PM EST. Let me know if that works for you.

Looking forward to our collaboration!

Ethan

Jenna

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@berkeley.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@berkeley.edu>
Subject: Progress update on our research project

Dear Dr. Thompson,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to share some exciting progress updates on our research project.

We have successfully synthesized the first batch of carbohydrate molecules and have begun testing their binding affinity to the target protein. The initial results look promising, with several compounds showing high binding affinity and specificity.

I have also been working closely with the team from Oxford to analyze the X-ray crystallography data. We have obtained some high-resolution structures of the carbohydrate-protein complexes, which will provide valuable insights into the molecular basis of their interactions.

I would like to schedule a meeting with you next week to discuss these findings in more detail and plan our next steps. Please let me know your availability.

Best regards,
Emily

From: Kristin Walsh/ENRON@enronXgate on 05/04/2001 04:32 PM CDT
To: John J Lavorato/ENRON@enronXgate, Louise Kitchen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tim Belden/ENRON@enronXgate, Jeff 
Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Chris Gaskill/ENRON@enronXgate, Mike 
Grigsby/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tim Heizenrader/ENRON@enronXgate, Vince J 
Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Rob 
Milnthorp/CAL/ECT@ECT, Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT@ECT, Claudio 
Ribeiro/ENRON@enronXgate, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, James D 
Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Mark Tawney/ENRON@enronXgate, Scott 
Tholan/ENRON@enronXgate, Britt Whitman/ENRON@enronXgate, Lloyd 
Will/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: California Update 5/4/01

If you have any questions, please contact Kristin Walsh at (713) 853-9510.

Bridge Loan Financing Bills May Not Meet Their May 8th Deadline Due to Lack 
of Support
Sources report there will not be a vote regarding the authorization for the 
bond issuance/bridge loan by the May 8th deadline.   Any possibility for a 
deal has reportedly fallen apart.  According to sources, both the Republicans 
and Democratic caucuses are turning against Davis.  The Democratic caucus is 
reportedly "unwilling to fight" for Davis.  Many legislative Republicans and 
Democrats reportedly do not trust Davis and express concern that, once the 
bonds are issued to replenish the General Fund, Davis would "double dip" into 
the fund.  Clearly there is a lack of good faith between the legislature and 
the governor.  However, it is believed once Davis discloses the details of 
the power contracts negotiated, a bond issuance will take place.  
Additionally, some generator sources have reported that some of the long-term 
power contracts (as opposed to those still in development) require that the 
bond issuance happen by July 1, 2001.  If not, the state may be in breach of 
contract.  Sources state that if the legislature does not pass the bridge 
loan legislation by May 8th, having a bond issuance by July 1st will be very 
difficult.

The Republicans were planning to offer an alternative plan whereby the state 
would "eat" the $5 billion cost of power spent to date out of the General 
Fund, thereby decreasing the amount of the bond issuance to approximately $8 
billion.  However, the reportedly now are not  going to offer even this 
concession.  Sources report that the Republicans intend to hold out for full 
disclosure of the governor's plan for handling the crisis, including the 
details and terms of all long-term contracts he has negotiated, before they 
will support the bond issuance to go forward.

Currently there are two bills dealing  with the bridge  loan; AB 8X and AB 
31X.  AB 8X authorizes the DWR to sell up to $10 billion in bonds.  This bill 
passed the Senate in March, but has stalled in the Assembly due to a lack of 
Republican support.  AB 31X deals with energy conservation programs for 
community college districts.  However, sources report this bill may be 
amended to include language relevant to the bond sale by Senator Bowen, 
currently in AB 8X.  Senator  Bowen's language states that the state should 
get paid before the utilities from rate payments (which, if passed, would be 
likely to cause a SoCal  bankruptcy). 
 
According to sources close to the Republicans in  the legislature, 
Republicans do not believe there should be a bridge loan due to money 
available in the General Fund.  For instance, Tony  Strickland has stated 
that only 1/2 of the bonds (or approximately $5 billion)  should be issued.  
Other Republicans reportedly do not support issuing any  bonds.  The 
Republicans intend to bring this up in debate on  Monday.  Additionally, 
Lehman Brothers reportedly also feels that a  bridge loan is unnecessary and 
there are some indications that Lehman may  back out of the bridge loan.
 
Key Points of the Bridge Financing
Initial Loan Amount: $4.125 B
Lenders:  JP Morgan  $2.5 B
   Lehman Brothers  $1.0 B
   Bear Stearns  $625 M
Tax Exempt Portion: Of the $4.125 B; $1.6 B is expected to be tax-exempt
Projected Interest Rate: Taxable Rate  5.77%
   Tax-Exempt Rate  4.77%
Current Projected 
Blended IR:  5.38%
Maturity Date:  August 29, 2001
For more details please contact me at (713) 853-9510

Bill SB 6X Passed the Senate Yesterday, but Little Can be Done at This Time
The Senate passed SB 6X yesterday, which authorizes $5  billion to create the 
California Consumer Power and Conservation  Authority.    The $5 billion 
authorized under SB 6X is not the  same as the $5 billion that must be 
authorized by the legislature to pay for  power already purchased, or the 
additional amount of bonds that must be authorized to pay for purchasing 
power going forward.  Again, the Republicans are not in support of these 
authorizations.  Without the details of the long-term power contracts the 
governor has  negotiated, the Republicans do not know what the final bond 
amount is that must  be issued and that taxpayers will have to pay to 
support.   No further action can be taken regarding the implementation of  SB 
6X until it is clarified how and when the state and the utilities get paid  
for purchasing power.    Also, there is no staff, defined purpose, etc. for  
the California Public Power and Conservation Authority.  However, this can  
be considered a victory for consumer advocates, who began promoting this 
idea  earlier in the crisis.
 
SoCal Edison and Bankruptcy
At this point, two events would be likely to trigger a SoCal bankruptcy.  The 
first would be a legislative rejection of the MOU between SoCal and the 
governor.  The specified deadline for legislative approval of the MOU is 
August 15th, however, some decision will likely be made earlier.  According 
to sources, the state has yet to sign the MOU with SoCal, though SoCal has 
signed it.  The Republicans are against the MOU in its current form and Davis 
and the Senate lack the votes needed to pass.  If the legislature indicates 
that it will not pas the MOU, SoCal would likely file for voluntary 
bankruptcy (or its creditor - involuntary) due to the lack operating cash.  

The second likely triggering event, which is linked directly to the bond 
issuance, would be an effort by Senator Bowen to amend SB 31X (bridge loan) 
stating that the DWR would received 100% of its payments from ratepayers, 
then the utilities would receive the residual amount.  In other words, the 
state will get paid before the utilities.  If this language is included and 
passed by the legislature, it appears likely that SoCal will likely file for 
bankruptcy.  SoCal is urging the legislature to pay both the utilities and 
the DWR proportionately from rate payments.

body:
<email>
From: Rabbi Sarah Silverstein <rabbisilverstein@jccchicago.org>
To: Avraham Cohen <avraham.cohen@jts.edu>
Subject: RE: Seeking guidance on a historical Jewish ritual

Avraham,

It's wonderful to hear from you! I am so pleased to learn about your studies in Jerusalem and the depth of your research into Jewish history and traditions. It sounds like you are making the most of this incredible opportunity.

Regarding the ritual of "X," you raise an excellent question. The conflicting interpretations you mention are indeed a topic of debate among scholars. In my experience, the most widely accepted theory traces the origin of the ritual to the Second Temple period, based on archaeological evidence and references in ancient texts.

I would be happy to discuss this further with you and share some resources that I believe will be helpful in your research. If you are available, I suggest we schedule a video call to discuss this in more detail. Please let me know your availability, and we can find a time that works for both of us.

I am thrilled to see how far you have come in your studies, Avraham. Your dedication to learning and teaching is truly inspiring. Please keep me updated on your progress, and don't hesitate to reach out if there is anything else I can assist you with.

Best regards,
Rabbi Sarah Silverstein

<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@eastsidehobbyists.com>
To: Alex Chen <alex.chen@nonferrousmetals.com>
Subject: Re: Puzzle help

Hey Alex,

Thanks for your email and for offering to help with the geometric puzzle I mentioned. I've attached a diagram of the puzzle and the problem statement. I've been trying to apply some of the techniques we discussed at the last club meeting, but I keep hitting a wall. I'd love to hear your thoughts and any fresh ideas you might have!

On another note, I'm curious to hear more about your work project with the copper-based alloys. It sounds fascinating, and I'm always eager to learn about how mathematical principles can be applied in different fields. Do you have any updates or insights you're willing to share?

Looking forward to hearing back from you!

Best,
Emily

Laird Dyer
04/27/2000 01:17 PM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Christopher F Calger/PDX/ECT@ECT, Michael McDonald/SF/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Re: SW Gas  

Mike McDonald and I met with SW Gas this morning.  They were polite regarding 
asset management and procurement function outsourcing and are willing to 
listen to a proposal.  However, they are very interested in weather hedges to 
protect throughput related earnings.  We are pursuing a confidentiality 
agreement with them to facilitate the sharing of information that will enable 
us to develop proposals.  Our pitch was based upon enhancing shareholder 
value by outsourcing a non-profit and costly function (procurement) and by 
reducing the volatility of their earnings by managing throughput via a 
weather product.

As to your other question.  We have yet to identify or pursue other 
candidates; however, Mike McDonald and I are developing a coverage strategy 
to ensure that we meet with all potential entities and investigate our 
opportunities.  We met with 8 entities this week (7 Municipals and SWG) as we 
implement our strategy in California.

Are there any entities that you think would be interested in an asset 
management deal that we should approach?  Otherwise, we intend to 
systematically identify and work through all the candidates. 

Laird

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Johnson <samanthaj@envirochange.org>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.t@nurse4health.org>
Subject: National Conference Presentation

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to touch base with you about our upcoming presentation at the National Conference on Climate Change and Public Health. As you know, this is a fantastic opportunity for us to share our work with a wider audience and potentially secure funding for our educational initiative.

I've been working on the slides for our presentation and wanted to get your input. Could you take a look at the attached file and let me know your thoughts? I think we have a strong message, but I want to make sure we're covering all the key points effectively.

Also, I was thinking about how we could make our presentation more engaging. Perhaps we could include some interactive elements, like a Q&A session or a short activity for the audience? Let me know if you have any ideas!

Looking forward to hearing back from you soon.

Best,
Samantha

Subject:=094-URGENT - OWA Please print this now.


Current Notes User:

REASONS FOR USING OUTLOOK WEB ACCESS (OWA)

1. Once your mailbox has been migrated from Notes to Outlook, the Outlook c=
lient will be configured on your computer.
After migration of your mailbox, you will not be able to send or recieve ma=
il via Notes, and you will not be able to start using Outlook until it is c=
onfigured by the Outlook Migration team the morning after your mailbox is m=
igrated.  During this period, you can use Outlook Web Access (OWA) via your=
 web browser (Internet Explorer 5.0) to read and send mail.

PLEASE NOTE:  Your calendar entries, personal address book, journals, and T=
o-Do entries imported from Notes will not be available until the Outlook cl=
ient is configured on your desktop.

2. Remote access to your mailbox.
After your Outlook client is configured, you can use Outlook Web Access (OW=
A) for remote access to your mailbox.

PLEASE NOTE:  At this time, the OWA client is only accessible while connect=
ing to the Enron network (LAN).  There are future plans to make OWA availab=
le from your home or when traveling abroad.

HOW TO ACCESS OUTLOOK WEB ACCESS (OWA)

Launch Internet Explorer 5.0, and in the address window type:  http://nahou=
-msowa01p/exchange/john.doe

Substitute "john.doe" with your first and last name, then click ENTER.  You=
 will be prompted with a sign in box as shown below.  Type in "corp/your us=
er id" for the user name and your NT password to logon to OWA and click OK.=
  You will now be able to view your mailbox.

=09

PLEASE NOTE:  There are some subtle differences in the functionality betwee=
n the Outlook and OWA clients.  You will not be able to do many of the thin=
gs in OWA that you can do in Outlook.  Below is a brief list of *some* of t=
he functions NOT available via OWA:

Features NOT available using OWA:

-  Tasks
-  Journal
-  Spell Checker
-  Offline Use
-  Printing Templates
-  Reminders
-  Timed Delivery
-  Expiration
-  Outlook Rules
-  Voting, Message Flags and Message Recall
-  Sharing Contacts with others
-  Task Delegation
-  Direct Resource Booking
-  Personal Distribution Lists

QUESTIONS OR CONCERNS?

If you have questions or concerns using the OWA client, please contact the =
Outlook 2000 question and answer Mailbox at:

=09Outlook.2000@enron.com

Otherwise, you may contact the Resolution Center at:

=09713-853-1411

Thank you,

Outlook 2000 Migration Team

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@programmer.net>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@student.com>
Subject: RE: Help with C++ FAQ list

Sarah,

Thank you so much for agreeing to help with this project. I really appreciate your enthusiasm and willingness to contribute.

Your idea of listing the questions you had while learning C++ is perfect. We can start with the basics, such as syntax, data types, and control structures, and then move on to more advanced topics like pointers, memory management, and object-oriented programming concepts.

Please feel free to add any questions you think are relevant, even if they seem basic. Sometimes, it's the simple concepts that trip up students the most.

I look forward to seeing your list and working together to create a comprehensive FAQ for C++ learners.

Best regards,
John

body:
<email>
From: Michael Chen <michaelchen@chemstudent.com>
To: Emily Thompson <emilythompson@chemteach.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on educational videos

Hi Emily,

Thanks for your email! I really like your idea of focusing on atomic structure and periodic trends for our video series. I agree that starting with an introduction to atomic structure and then moving on to electron configurations and periodic trends is a great way to organize the content.

I think alternating between us explaining the concepts is a great idea, and using simple animations and visual aids will definitely help make the content more engaging. I can take on the task of creating the animations and visual aids if you'd like.

I also think we should consider creating a companion website where we can post additional resources, such as quizzes, practice problems, and links to further reading. This will help students deepen their understanding of the concepts we cover in the videos.

Let me know what you think about this idea, and if you have any other suggestions for the video series.

Best regards,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Emily Chen <emily.chen@pineridge.org>
To: Jake Thompson <jake.thompson@oakhill.edu>
Subject: Great hiking and brainstorming today!

Hi Jake,

It was wonderful to meet you at the conference and then spend some time hiking and chatting today. I really enjoyed our conversation and appreciate the insights you shared about using media in your ESL lessons. I've been thinking about how I could incorporate similar strategies into my geometry classes, and I'd love to bounce some ideas off you.

Would you be interested in meeting up for coffee or a virtual chat sometime soon to brainstorm? I'm free next Wednesday afternoon or anytime on Friday. Let me know what works for you!

I've attached a few resources I mentioned during our hike that I think you might find useful for your intermediate ESL students. Feel free to use them and let me know if you need anything else.

Looking forward to staying in touch and collaborating more in the future!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Rajesh Patel <rpatel@unicef.org>
To: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@washadvocates.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on community engagement challenges in CLTS project

Emily,

I'm glad to hear that the strategies I shared resonated with you and that you found them valuable. I have no doubt that with your dedication and the approaches you're implementing, you'll be able to make significant progress in your project.

I've reached out to my contacts in Laos and at UNICEF's regional office, and they are more than happy to connect with you. I'll introduce you via email in the next few days so that you can take the conversation forward directly.

Collaborating with local organizations is indeed crucial, and I'm confident that the connections we make will be beneficial for your project. It's always inspiring to see passionate individuals like you making a difference on the ground.

Please do keep me posted on your progress, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need any further support or advice. I'm always here to help.

I look forward to hearing about the great work you'll undoubtedly accomplish in Cambodia, and I hope we can continue to exchange ideas and explore collaboration opportunities in the future.

Best wishes,
Rajesh
Dr. Rajesh Patel
Global WASH Specialist
UNICEF
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jessica Novak <jnovak@spacepolicy.org>
To: Dr. Liam Rodriguez <liam.rodriguez@rodentia.edu>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference and joint presentation

Liam,

I like the way you think! The parallels between invasive species on Earth and biological contamination in space are definitely worth exploring. I've also been thinking about how we might incorporate some speculative elements into our presentation, perhaps drawing on science fiction themes.

By the way, I remember you mentioning your interest in sci-fi literature. Have you read "The Windup Girl" by Paolo Bacigalupi? It explores some fascinating themes related to biotechnology and sustainability.

Looking forward to our call on Wednesday!

Best,
Jessica
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Akira Nakamura <akira.nakamura@toshokan.jp>
To: Yumi Sato <yumi.sato@nihonbunka.org>
Subject: RE: Connecting after the Japanese Art Conference

Dear Yumi,

That's a fantastic idea! Co-authoring a paper or exhibition catalog would be an excellent way to showcase our collaborative research and provide a comprehensive understanding of the relationship between textiles and art in the Meiji period.

I'm looking forward to our call on Monday, and I'm excited about the potential of our collaboration. Thank you for the proposal, and I'll be prepared to discuss it further during our conversation.

Best regards,
Akira Nakamura
