Message-ID: <196928.1075855676621.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Thu, 28 Sep 2000 06:17:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: lkuch@mh.com
Subject: San Juan Index
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Lkuch@mh.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\Discussion threads
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 09/28/2000 
01:09 PM ---------------------------
   
	
	
	From:  Phillip K Allen                           09/28/2000 10:56 AM
	


Liane,

 As we discussed yesterday, I am concerned there may have been an attempt to 
manipulate the  El Paso San Juan monthly index.  It appears that a single 
buyer entered the marketplace on both September 26 and 27 and paid above 
market prices ($4.70-$4.80) for San Juan gas.  At the time of these trades, 
offers for physical gas at significantly (10 to 15 cents) lower prices were 
bypassed in order to establish higher trades to report into the index 
calculation.  Additionally, these trades are out of line with the associated 
financial swaps for San Juan.

 We have compiled a list of financial and physical trades executed from 
September 25 to September 27.  These are the complete list of trades from 
Enron Online (EOL), Enron's direct phone conversations, and three brokerage 
firms (Amerex, APB, and Prebon).  Please see the attached spreadsheet for a 
trade by trade list and a summary.  We have also included a summary of gas 
daily prices to illustrate the value of San Juan based on several spread 
relationships.  The two key points from this data are as follows:

 1.  The high physical prices on the 26th & 27th (4.75,4,80) are much greater 
than the high financial trades (4.6375,4.665) on those days. 

 2.  The spread relationship between San Juan and other points (Socal & 
Northwest)  is  consistent between the end of September and 
       October gas daily.  It doesn't make sense to have monthly indices that 
are dramatically different.


 I understand you review the trades submitted for outliers.  Hopefully, the 
trades submitted will reveal counterparty names and you will be able to 
determine that there was only one buyer in the 4.70's and these trades are 
outliers.  I wanted to give you some additional points of reference to aid in 
establishing a reasonable index.  It is Enron's belief that the trades at 
$4.70 and higher  were above market trades that should be excluded from the 
calculation of index.

 It is our desire to have reliable and accurate indices against which to 
conduct our physical and financial business.  Please contact me 
anytime I can assist you towards this goal.

Sincerely,

Phillip Allen

imagine you have a gas well in the middle of west texas and you only have one 
pipeline running to your well.  the guy who owns the pipeline can fuck you 
because you have no choice but to flow your gas that way.  split connect 
means you have at least 2 options to flow your gas so the price the producer 
receives is more competitive and if anything happens to one pipeline you 
don't have  to shut your gas in because you move it to another pipe.

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Olivia Davis <odavis@suffragehistory.org>
To: Emily Jennings <emily.jennings@harmonyhigh.org>
Subject: RE: Help with new women's history elective

Emily,

Congratulations on your pregnancy! That's wonderful news. I know it can be daunting to think about balancing work and family, but you'll find a way to make it work. And remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it.

I've had a chance to review your lesson plans, and I think you've done a great job. I love how you've incorporated a variety of primary sources and have structured the lessons to encourage critical thinking and discussion.

I have a few suggestions for additional resources and some minor tweaks, but overall, I think this is a strong unit. I've made some comments and suggestions directly on the document and attached the updated file.

As for me, I'm hoping to take a research trip to some archives in the South this summer. It will be a lot of work, but I'm excited to dig into some new sources.

Please keep me updated on your pregnancy and the new course. I'm always here if you need support or just want to chat.

Best,
Olivia

<email>
From: Alex Chen <achen@autocadguru.net>
To: Emily Jones <ejones@fossilrecordanalysis.com>
Subject: RE: Introduction and Collaboration on Paleontology Course

Hi Emily,

Thank you for your feedback on the course outline. I've reviewed your suggestions and agree that including the geological context is crucial for learners to fully understand the significance of the fossils. I've incorporated your changes and updated the outline accordingly.

Please find the revised outline attached to this email. If you're happy with the changes, I think we can move forward with creating the content for each module. I'll start working on the AutoCAD tutorials, and we can discuss the best way to integrate them with your scientific content.

I've sent a calendar invite for our call on Wednesday morning. Looking forward to our discussion and getting started on this exciting project!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Rafiq Ahmed <rafiq.ahmed@bdhealth.org>
To: Alice Kamau <alice.kamau@washforkenya.org>
Subject: RE: MHM Education Materials

Alice,

Thank you for sharing the MHM education materials! I had a chance to review them, and I must say, they are excellent. The content is well-structured, and the visuals are engaging. I particularly liked the activity sheets for the younger age group. I believe these materials will be very effective in creating awareness and promoting good MHM practices among schoolgirls.

Regarding our handwashing campaign, we've made some progress, but we're facing a few challenges. One of the main issues is the lack of reliable water supply in some areas, which makes it difficult for people to practice regular handwashing. We're working with the local government to address this issue and exploring alternative solutions like handwashing stations.

I'm excited to learn more about the results of your MHM project. Keep me posted on the progress.

Best wishes,
Rafiq

<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@preschool.com>
To: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Catching up and seeking your expertise

Alex,

I'm so glad our work is aligning in such interesting ways! I have a ton of observations and examples from my classroom that I think could be really valuable for your research. For instance, I've noticed that children are much more engaged when the technology incorporates elements of play and discovery, like interactive stories or virtual manipulatives.

I'd love to share these insights with you and brainstorm ways to incorporate them into your software. I'm available for a video call next Tuesday at 3 PM. Just let me know if that works for you and send me the meeting link.

Thank you so much for reaching out and for your willingness to collaborate. It means a lot to have your support and expertise as I navigate this new territory.

Best,
Emily

To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@nettechsolutions.com>
Subject: Long time no talk!

Hey Sarah,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been a while since we last caught up, and I was just reminiscing about our time working together on the NetTech project. Those were some intense but rewarding times, huh?

How have you been? I'd love to hear about what you've been up to lately, both professionally and personally. Are you still at NetTech, or have you moved on to new adventures?

As for me, I've been diving deeper into network programming and exploring some new ideas. I've been thinking a lot about our discussions on creating our own startup one day. There's a particular project I've been working on that I think could have real potential.

Anyway, I don't want to bore you with all the details in this email. If you're interested in catching up and maybe brainstorming some ideas, I'd love to grab a coffee or have a video call sometime.

Let me know when you're free!

Best,
John

body:
<email>
From: Michael Chen <michael.chen@cybersecure.com>
To: Samantha Jones <samantha.jones@cybersecure.com>
Subject: RE: Urgent: Multiple clients targeted by sophisticated malware attack

Samantha,

I've reviewed the logs you sent, and you're right – it looks like the attackers had help from someone inside the client's organization. This complicates matters significantly, as we now have to consider the possibility of a mole within the client's ranks.

I suggest we approach this cautiously and limit the information we share with the client until we can verify their employees' trustworthiness. In the meantime, we should focus on containing the malware, identifying the extent of the damage, and gathering evidence to trace the attackers.

Let's discuss our game plan in more detail during our call at 2 PM.

Best,
Michael

Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise on Kashmir and climate change

Hi Alex,

I'm looking forward to our collaboration! Tuesday afternoon works perfectly for me. Let's meet in my office at 3 PM. I'll send you the room number separately.

I'll prepare some key points from my paper and think about how best to present the information to your students. If you have any specific topics or questions you'd like me to address during the guest lecture, please let me know in advance.

Thank you for your commitment to providing your students with a comprehensive understanding of global issues. I'm confident that our interdisciplinary approach will be valuable for them.

Best regards,
Sanjay

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <anovak@hillsidehigh.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Chen <emchen@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Stargazing event advice

Emily,

Thank you so much for your helpful suggestions and generous offer to assist with the presentation. I really appreciate your willingness to support our event and help inspire my students.

I love your idea of giving a short presentation beforehand to provide context and build excitement. I think it would be great if you could join us for that part of the event, if you're available. The students would be thrilled to hear from an expert like you, and I know they would find your insights fascinating.

I'll make sure to have plenty of hands-on activities and opportunities for exploration during the observing portion of the event. I want the students to feel like they're actively engaging with the universe, not just passively observing.

Please let me know if you have any other suggestions as we get closer to the event. I'm hoping for clear skies and plenty of astronomical wonders to share with the students!

Thanks again for your help,

Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: David Martinez <dmartinez@ucsd.edu>
To: Emily Hernandez <ehernandez@utaustin.edu>
Subject: RE: Finalizing our paper on the Mexican-American War and Texas-Mexico relations

Emily,

Thank you for your email and for the edits you made to the introduction and conclusion. I agree that they help tie our arguments together more effectively. I have a few minor suggestions for further revisions, which I'll send your way in a separate email.

Regarding conferences, I think the Western History Association and the Latin American Studies Association are excellent options. I have a colleague who presented at the WHA last year and had a great experience. LASA might be a good choice as well, given the focus on Latin American Studies.

I've also been giving some thought to the idea of expanding our project into a book. I think our research could be of interest to a broader audience, and a book would allow us to delve deeper into certain aspects of the topic. What do you think about this idea?

Best,
David
label: research

Message-ID: <1901975.1075855714954.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 28 Mar 2001 08:03:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: rlehmann@yahoo.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: rlehmann@yahoo.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\Sent
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Reagan,

Thank you for the quick response on the bid for the residence.  Below is a 
list of questions on the specs:

1.  Is the framing Lumber #2 yellow pine?  Wouldn't fir or spruce warp less 
and cost about the same?

2.  What type of floor joist would be used?  2x12 or some sort of factory 
joist?

3.  What type for roof framing?  On site built rafters? or engineered trusses?

4.  Are you planning for insulation between floors to dampen sound?  What 
type of insulation in floors and ceiling?  Batts or blown?  Fiberglass or 
Cellulose?

5.  Any ridge venting or other vents (power or turbine)?

6. Did you bid for interior windows to have trim on 4 sides?  I didn't know 
the difference between an apron and a stool.

7.  Do you do anything special under the upstairs tile floors to prevent 
cracking?  Double plywood or hardi board underlay?

8.  On the stairs, did you allow for a bannister?  I was thinking a partial 
one out of iron.  Only about 5 feet.

9.  I did not label it on the plan, but I was intending for a 1/2 bath under 
the stairs. A pedestal sink would probably work.

10.  Are undermount sinks different than drop ins?  I was thinking undermount 
stainless in kitchen and undermount cast iron in baths.

11.  1 or 2 A/C units?  I am assuming 2.

12.  Prewired for sound indoors and outdoors?

13.  No door and drawer pulls on any cabinets or just bath cabinets?

14.  Exterior porches included in bid?  Cedar decking on upstairs?  Iron 
railings?

15.  What type of construction contract would you use?  Fixed price except 
for change orders?

I want to get painfully detailed with the specs before I make a decision but 
this is a start.  I think I am ready to get plans drawn up.  I am going to 
call Cary Kipp to
see about setting up a design meeting to see if I like his ideas.

Phillip
I

body:
<email>
From: Ingrid Bauer <ingrid.bauer@frankfurt-schule.de>
To: Hans Müller <hans.mueller@uni-heidelberg.de>
Subject: RE: Neues Lehrmaterial für Anfänger

Hallo Hans,

herzlichen Dank für deine Email und die spannenden neuen Lehrmaterialien! Es ist wirklich eine interessante Idee, die Schüler selbst die Regeln entdecken zu lassen. 

Ich habe die Übungen durchgesehen und finde sie sehr gut durchdacht. Eine Idee für eine Ergänzung: Könnten die Schüler nachdem sie die Regeln entdeckt haben, einen kleinen Dialog verfassen, in dem sie die gelernten Strukturen verwenden? Das wäre eine gute Möglichkeit, das Gelernte zu festigen und zu üben.

Was authentische Materialien angeht: In diesem Jahr haben wir uns auf deutsche Musik konzentriert. Die Schüler haben Lieder gehört, die Texte analysiert und die Handlung gezeichnet. Das hat sehr gut funktioniert, besonders mit Liedern von Mark Forster und Helene Fischer. Vielleicht probierst du das ja auch einmal aus.

Ich würde mich auch sehr freuen, wenn du mir einige authentische Ressourcen empfehlen könntest, die du in deinem Unterricht verwendet hast und von denen du denkst, dass sie meinen Studenten gefallen könnten. 

Ich freue mich auf deine Gedanken und hoffe, dass es dir und deinen Studenten gut geht.

Viele Grüße,
Ingrid

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@stemresources.com>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@oakvillehighschool.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on Chemistry Educational Resources

Hi Michael,

Tuesday afternoon works perfectly for me. How about we schedule our call for 2 PM EST? That way, we'll have plenty of time to discuss our ideas and plan our next steps.

I've been thinking about our collaboration, and I believe we could create a series of modular learning units that cover key chemistry concepts while incorporating hands-on activities and real-world applications. We could also develop assessments to measure student understanding and engagement.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this approach and any ideas you have for specific topics or activities we could include.

See you on Tuesday!

Best regards,
Emily Johnson

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

X-To: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Inbox
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Phillip, there are a number of alternative systems that will allow the same
level of energy efficiency. I would wait a bit for Wink's bid though. You
say that your panel costs are $20,000 additional. that sounds like a lot. I
just did a panel house with a 2100 sq ft footprint and the total panel cost
was about $25,000 with 8 inch walls and 10 inch roof. Stay in touch and we
can discuss alternatives if that becomes necessary. If your budget is $85-90
per sq. ft.  excluding land costs your costs will be on the low end of the
true custom home level but should be achievable with good management.
Richard Morgan
Manager, Green Building Program
Austin Energy
721 Barton Springs Rd.
Austin, TX 78704-1194
Ph. 512.505.3709
Fax 512.505.3711
e-mail richard.morgan@austinenergy.com


-----Original Message-----
From: Allen, Phillip K. [mailto:Phillip.K.Allen@ENRON.com]
Sent: Wednesday, October 10, 2001 9:19 AM
To: Morgan, Richard
Subject:


Richard,

I spoke to you earlier this week with questions about building with
SIP's.  I am planning to build a home in San Marcos as soon as I can
decide on a builder and materials.  I already have my blueprints
completed.  What I took from our conversation  was to use the SIP's with
8.5" roof panels and use a metal roof.

I have been working with Johnnie Brown, a builder from San Antonio that
is also a Creative Panel rep.  The problem is that I have a budget of
$85-$90/sf and it does not appear that he will be able to stay within
that budget.  I don't want to settle for a conventional stick built
house.  I was wondering about alternatives.  Would some combination of a
radiant barrier and non-CFC spray insulation provide close to the same
energy savings at a lower cost than SIP's. For example, I just spoke to
a sales rep for Demilec.  He will spray foam insulation at $1.30/sf.
That would be approximately $10,000 compared to over $20,000 additional
costs for the panels.  But would the foam insulation be as effective?
Do you have any suggestions of materials or contractors that would help
me construct the best home for the money.  I am trying to get a bid from
Wink with Premier based on you reference.

Thank you for your help.

Phillip Allen
pallen@enron.com
713-853-7041

Hi Alex,

It was great meeting you at the community center last week. I really enjoyed your presentation on dental health for children. As I mentioned, I'm a primary school teacher and I'm always looking for ways to make learning more engaging for my students.

I think your expertise in dental health would be a fantastic resource for creating educational materials for my students. Would you be interested in collaborating on this project? I'd love to brainstorm some ideas with you and see how we can make dental health fun and interesting for kids.

Best regards,
Emily

<email>
From: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@mathgurus.net>
To: Alex Ramirez <alex.ramirez@mathexperts.com>
Subject: RE: New Interactive Graphing Software

Hi Alex,

Thanks for reaching out about GraphMaster! I haven't heard of it before, but it sounds like an exciting tool that could really enhance our students' learning experience.

I'm particularly interested in how it could be used to create interactive visualizations for probability concepts. I've been working on a new unit on probability and have been trying to find ways to make it more engaging for students. If GraphMaster can help with that, I'd be eager to explore it further.

Would you be open to setting up a time for us to discuss this in more detail? I'd love to hear your thoughts on how it could be applied to our specific lesson plans and any ideas you have for incorporating it into our classrooms.

Also, I wanted to share that I recently discovered a new approach to teaching the concept of standard deviation that has been really effective in my classes. I'd be happy to share it with you if you're interested.

Looking forward to collaborating more on this!

Best,
Jordan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: MariaHuber@gmx.de
To: drjones@pawspatients.com
Subject: Heartworm prevention for German Shepherds

Hi Dr. Jones,

I hope you're doing well! As you know, I've been considering adopting a German Shepherd, and I wanted to get your expert advice on heartworm prevention for this specific breed. Are German Shepherds more susceptible to heartworm disease compared to other breeds? If so, what special precautions should I take to keep my future furry friend healthy?

I'm really excited about the upcoming pet adoption event at the community center. I want to make sure I'm well-informed about heartworm prevention so I can be a responsible dog owner and perhaps even help other adopters at the event.

Thank you in advance for your help!

Best regards,
Maria Huber

Subject: RE: Collaboration on Lyme Disease Awareness Campaign

Hi Jenna,

It's great to hear from you! I'm also excited about this collaboration and the potential impact our campaign can have on raising awareness about Lyme disease.

I like your idea of focusing on prevention, symptoms, and treatment in our key messages. We should also consider including information on the signs and symptoms of Lyme disease in dogs, as many people may not be aware that their pets can also be affected.

I'm available for a call next Wednesday afternoon or Friday morning. Please let me know what works best for you, and I'll send a calendar invite.

I look forward to our discussion and to working together on this important campaign.

Best,
Mark

From:  Rudi Zipter

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Vladimir Gorny/HOU/ECT@ECT, Minal Dalia/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sunil 
Dalal/Corp/Enron@ENRON 
Subject: Option Analysis on NG Price Book

John,

Several months ago we talked about the development of an option analysis tool 
that could be used to stress test positions under various scenarios as a 
supplement to our V@R analysis.  We have recently completed the project and 
would like to solicit your feedback on the report results.

We have selected your NG price position for April 4, 2000 (POST-ID  753650) 
for the initial analysis.  Attached in the excel file below you will find:

Analysis across the various forward months in your position 

Underlying vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L 
Volatility vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L
Time change vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L


Summary of your Overall Position analysis

Underlying vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L 
Volatility vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L
Time change vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L


Multiple Stress Analysis

The attached Word document demonstrates the multiple stress choices.  I have 
included a tab in the excel file that demonstrates the theoretical P/L 
resulting from shifts in both volatility and underlying price.  


Please note that the percentage changes across the column headers are not in 
absolute terms (for example, if the ATM volatility in a given month is 40% 
and the stress is -10% then the analysis is performed under a volatility 
scenario of 36%)









Thanks,

Rudi

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@healthresources.org>
To: Marcus Thompson <marcus.thompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: Following up from the Educators Conference

Hi Marcus,

It was great meeting you at the Educators Conference last week. I really enjoyed our conversation about the importance of creating inclusive educational materials. As I mentioned, I'm a health science writer and medical librarian, and I'm always looking for ways to make our resources more diverse and representative.

I was impressed by your passion for African American studies and your commitment to integrating diverse perspectives into your teaching. I think there could be a great opportunity for us to collaborate on a project together.

Would you be interested in working on a series of educational resources that highlight the contributions of African Americans in the field of medicine and health science? I think it would be a valuable addition to both of our fields and could help inspire the next generation of diverse health professionals.

Let me know if you're interested, and we can set up a time to chat further.

Best regards,
Emily

From: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@willowbrookcc.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@willowbrookcc.org>
Subject: RE: Workshop planning - Coding and Healthy Aging

Hi Emily,

Thank you for the update on the coding workshop. The computer lab at Willowbrook Middle School sounds perfect, and the date you proposed works well for me. I'll start promoting the event and reaching out to potential participants.

As for the healthy aging and swallowing safety workshop, I was thinking we could hold it at the Willowbrook Senior Center on Saturday, March 21st, from 10 am to 12 pm. This would give us enough time to cover the essential topics and allow for a Q&A session. I'll need to coordinate with the senior center to ensure we have the necessary space and resources.

I'm also excited to learn that our children attend the same school! It's always nice to have a connection outside of our committee work. Perhaps we could arrange a playdate for them sometime.

Please keep me posted on any further developments, and let me know if there's anything I can do to assist with the coding workshop.

Best regards,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Ananda Subramanian <ananda.subramanian@buddhiststudies.edu>
To: Emily Nakamura <emily.nakamura@asianartmuseum.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise for our new exhibit

Emily,

It's always a pleasure to hear from you, and I'm thrilled to be able to contribute to your new exhibit. I've reviewed the draft layout and descriptions you sent over, and I must say, you've done an outstanding job. Your deep understanding of the art and its cultural significance shines through in every word.

I did have a few minor suggestions and corrections, which I've noted in the attached document. But overall, I think you've created something truly special that will undoubtedly captivate and educate your visitors.

As for your potential career change, I am more than happy to mentor and guide you as you explore the world of museum curation. It's a field that I believe you would excel in, given your passion for Asian art and your dedication to sharing its beauty with others. Let's set up a time to chat further about your goals and how I can support you in this transition.

On a personal note, I hope your daughter is doing well. My son has been asking about her lately, as he's been delving deeper into his studies of Eastern philosophy. Perhaps we can arrange for them to meet and discuss their shared interests sometime.

Thank you again for reaching out, Emily. I look forward to working with you on this exhibit and beyond.

Warmest regards,
Ananda

body:
<email>
From: Akira Nakamura <akira.nakamura@justice-matters.org>
To: Dr. Lila Patel <lila.patel@cosmic-ethics.com>
Subject: Seeking your expertise on indigenous rights and space exploration

Dear Dr. Patel,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Akira Nakamura, and I am a historian and curator at the Justice Matters Museum in San Francisco. I recently attended the "Space Exploration and Indigenous Rights" conference where I had the pleasure of hearing your presentation on the potential impact of space missions on indigenous communities and their land rights.

I was deeply impressed by your insights and the sensitivity with which you approached this complex topic. As someone who is committed to raising awareness about social justice issues, I believe your work is crucial in ensuring that the benefits of space exploration are shared equitably and that the rights of indigenous peoples are respected.

I am currently curating a new exhibit at our museum titled "Internment, Displacement, and Resistance: A Global Perspective." The exhibit aims to draw connections between the Japanese American internment and the experiences of other marginalized communities throughout history, including indigenous peoples affected by space exploration and resource extraction.

I would be immensely grateful if you could share your thoughts on how we might incorporate perspectives from astrobiology and environmental science into this exhibit. I believe your expertise could provide valuable context and help us tell a more comprehensive story.

If you are interested in collaborating, I would be happy to arrange a call to discuss this further. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Best regards,
Akira Nakamura

Hi David,

Your outline looks great! I really like the idea of including interactive elements to make the lesson more engaging. We could also incorporate some historical context about the Islamic Golden Age and how it fostered scientific advancements.

I've started drafting a script for the lesson, focusing on Jabir ibn Hayyan's life, his major works, and his influence on later chemists. I'll send it your way once it's ready for review.

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Johnson <ejohnson@maternityclinic.com>
To: Linda Martinez <lmartinez@maternityclinic.com>
Subject: Update on Sarah Thompson's case

Dear Linda,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to update you on Sarah Thompson's case. As you know, we've been closely monitoring her gestational diabetes throughout her pregnancy. Unfortunately, her condition has worsened, and I believe it's in the best interest of both Sarah and the baby to induce labor early.

I've discussed the risks and benefits of induction with Sarah, and she has agreed to the procedure. Can you please schedule some time with her to go over the induction process in more detail and answer any questions she may have?

Also, please make sure she understands the importance of monitoring her blood sugar levels closely during the induction process and after delivery. We'll need to keep a close eye on both her and the baby in the hours and days following the birth.

Let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Johnson

body:
<email>
From: Anders Jensen <anders.jensen@ku.dk>
To: Elin Nilsson <elin.nilsson@stockholmuni.se>
Subject: RE: Our research project on language education and income inequality

Dear Elin,

Thank you for your email and for taking the initiative to get our project started. I am equally excited about our collaboration and the potential impact of our research.

I agree that a video conference call is a good first step. I am available next week on Tuesday from 10am to 12pm CET, or Thursday from 2pm to 4pm CET. Please let me know which time works best for you.

In preparation for our call, I have been reviewing the literature on language education policies and outcomes in the Nordic countries. I look forward to discussing this research and how it might inform our project.

Best regards,
Anders

FYI. I spoke with Steve. Seems like they have not been successful with plan 
A, i.e. to get their investors to give them authority to trade OTC as well as 
futures. They have moved on to plan B which is to take one of their domestic 
funds (approx. $500mm under mgt) off the floor (futures only) and into OTC 
trading. Still has the rating problem with Enron, but I am trying to get him 
to arrange a conference call with their CFO so I can discuss ways around it. 
He will try to do so this week. Mind you, I left it at this point the last 
time I spoke with him a couple of months ago and it seemed to stall. I'll 
keep chasing it.  Per

Swerzbin/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Wow

Do not underestimate the effects of the Internet economy on load growth.  I 
have been preaching the tremendous growth described below for the last year.  
The utility infrastructure simply cannot handle these loads at the 
distribution level and ultimatley distributed generation will be required for 
power quality reasons.

The City of Austin, TX has experienced 300+ MW of load growth this year due 
to server farms and technology companies.  There is a 100 MW server farm 
trying to hook up to HL&P as we speak and they cannot deliver for 12 months 
due to distribution infrastructure issues.  Obviously, Seattle, Porltand, 
Boise, Denver, San Fran and San Jose in your markets are in for a rude 
awakening in the next 2-3 years.

To: John D Suarez/HOU/ECT@ECT, Suresh Vasan/Enron Communications@ENRON 
COMMUNICATIONS@ENRON
cc:  
Subject: 

Internet Data Gain Is a Major Power Drain on
                  Local Utilities 

                  ( September 05, 2000 ) 


                  In 1997, a little-known Silicon Valley company called Exodus
                  Communications opened a 15,000-square-foot data center in 
Tukwila. 

                       The mission was to handle the Internet traffic and 
computer servers for the
                  region's growing number of dot-coms. 

                       Fast-forward to summer 2000. Exodus is now wrapping up 
construction
                  on a new 13-acre, 576,000-square-foot data center less than 
a mile from its
                  original facility. Sitting at the confluence of several 
fiber optic backbones, the
                  Exodus plant will consume enough power for a small town and 
eventually
                  house Internet servers for firms such as Avenue A, 
Microsoft and Onvia.com. 

                       Exodus is not the only company building massive data 
centers near Seattle.
                  More than a dozen companies -- with names like AboveNet, 
Globix and
                  HostPro -- are looking for facilities here that will house 
the networking
                  equipment of the Internet economy. 

                       It is a big business that could have an effect on 
everything from your
                  monthly electric bill to the ease with which you access 
your favorite Web sites.

                       Data centers, also known as co-location facilities and 
server farms, are
                  sprouting at such a furious pace in Tukwila and the Kent 
Valley that some
                  have expressed concern over whether Seattle City Light and 
Puget Sound
                  Energy can handle the power necessary to run these 24-hour, 
high-security
                  facilities. 

                       "We are talking to about half a dozen customers that 
are requesting 445
                  megawatts of power in a little area near Southcenter Mall," 
said Karl
                  Karzmar, manager of revenue requirements for Puget Sound 
Energy. "That is
                  the equivalent of six oil refineries." 

                       A relatively new phenomenon in the utility business, 
the rise of the Internet
                  data center has some utility veterans scratching their 
heads. 

                       Puget Sound Energy last week asked the Washington 
Utilities and
                  Transportation Commission to accept a tariff on the new 
data centers. The
                  tariff is designed to protect the company's existing 
residential and business
                  customers from footing the bill for the new base stations 
necessary to support
                  the projects. Those base stations could cost as much as $20 
million each,
                  Karzmar said. 

                       Not to be left behind, Seattle City Light plans to 
bring up the data center
                  issue on Thursday at the Seattle City Council meeting. 

                       For the utilities that provide power to homes, 
businesses and schools in the
                  region, this is a new and complex issue. 

                       On one hand, the data centers -- with their amazing 
appetite for power --
                  represent potentially lucrative business customers. The 
facilities run 24 hours a
                  day, seven days a week, and therefore could become a 
constant revenue
                  stream. On the other hand, they require so much energy that 
they could
                  potentially flood the utilities with exorbitant capital 
expenditures. 

                       Who will pay for those expenditures and what it will 
mean for power rates
                  in the area is still open to debate. 

                       "These facilities are what we call extremely dense 
loads," said Bob Royer,
                  director of communications and public affairs at Seattle 
City Light. 

                       "The entire University of Washington, from stadium 
lights at the football
                  game to the Medical School, averages 31 megawatts per day. 
We have data
                  center projects in front of us that are asking for 30, 40 
and 50 megawatts." 

                       With more than 1.5 million square feet, the Intergate 
complex in Tukwila is
                  one of the biggest data centers. Sabey Corp. re-purchased 
the 1.35 million
                  square-foot Intergate East facility last September from 
Boeing Space &
                  Defense. In less than 12 months, the developer has leased 
92 percent of the
                  six-building complex to seven different co-location 
companies. 

                       "It is probably the largest data center park in the 
country," boasts Laurent
                  Poole, chief operating officer at Sabey. Exodus, ICG 
Communications,
                  NetStream Communications, Pac West Telecomm and Zama 
Networks all
                  lease space in the office park. 

                       After building Exodus' first Tukwila facility in 1997, 
Sabey has become an
                  expert in the arena and now has facilities either under 
management or
                  development in Los Angeles, Spokane and Denver. Poole 
claims his firm is
                  one of the top four builders of Internet data centers in 
the country. 

                       As more people access the Internet and conduct 
bandwidth-heavy tasks
                  such as listening to online music, Poole said the need for 
co-location space in
                  Seattle continues to escalate. 

                       But it is not just Seattle. The need for data center 
space is growing at a
                  rapid clip at many technology hubs throughout the country, 
causing similar
                  concerns among utilities in places such as Texas and 
California. 

                       Exodus, one of the largest providers of co-location 
space, plans to nearly
                  double the amount of space it has by the end of the year. 
While companies
                  such as Amazon.com run their own server farms, many 
high-tech companies
                  have decided to outsource the operations to companies such 
as Exodus that
                  may be better prepared for dealing with Internet traffic 
management. 

                       "We have 2 million square feet of space under 
construction and we plan to
                  double our size in the next nine months , yet there is more 
demand right now
                  than data center space," said Steve Porter, an account 
executive at Exodus in
                  Seattle. 

                       The booming market for co-location space has left some 
in the local utility
                  industry perplexed. 

                       "It accelerates in a quantum way what you have to do 
to serve the growth,"
                  said Seattle City Light's Royer. "The utility industry is 
almost stunned by this, in
                  a way."

<email>
From: Liam O'Connor <liam.oconnor@university.edu.au>
To: Emily Ashton <emily.ashton@university.co.uk>
Subject: RE: Draft chapter for review

Hi Emily,

Great to hear that you've finished reviewing the manuscript. I'll take a look at your final suggestions and make any necessary changes.

Good idea about the acknowledgments section. I'll draft something up and send it your way for feedback.

It's been a pleasure working with you on this project. I can't wait to see the finished product and share our research with the world.

All the best,
Liam

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@linguist.com>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@cybersecure.com>
Subject: RE: Nepal travel plans

Hi Sarah,

It's great to hear from you! I'm so excited that you've decided to take me up on my offer. I think you'll really enjoy meeting my friends in Nepal - they're a great group of people and are always happy to welcome visitors.

As for VPNs, I personally use ExpressVPN and have found it to be reliable in Nepal. It's also a good idea to make sure your devices are updated and that you have a strong password and two-factor authentication set up. I know cybersecurity is your area of expertise, but let me know if you have any other questions!

I'm happy to give you some Nepali lessons over video chat before your trip. Just let me know what times work best for you.

Looking forward to seeing you in Nepal!

Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@university.edu>
To: David Patel <david.patel@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Congratulations on your new paper!

Hi David,

I would be absolutely thrilled to collaborate with you on this project! It sounds like a fantastic opportunity to bring together our different areas of expertise and potentially make some groundbreaking discoveries.

I'm happy to help with the remote sensing and geospatial analysis components of the research. I have a lot of experience working with satellite imagery and GIS data for monitoring mangrove ecosystems, and I think we could use similar approaches to study the fossil sites you mentioned.

I'm also very interested in the idea of co-authoring a paper on the broader implications of our findings for understanding the intersections between human evolution and environmental change. I think this could be a really exciting direction for our collaboration.

Let's set up a time to discuss the grant application and start putting together a plan for the research trip. I'm attaching a draft of a project proposal that I've been working on that might be relevant to our discussions.

I can't wait to get started on this collaboration!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Linh Nguyen <ln@healthycities.org>
To: Jordan Ellis <jellis@baptistseminary.edu> 
Subject: RE: Seeking advice for upcoming research trip to Vietnam

Jordan,

It's great to hear from you! I'd be happy to offer some tips for staying healthy while traveling in Vietnam. The key is mostly just being very careful about the water - always drink bottled or boiled water, and avoid raw or undercooked foods from street vendors. I can send you a list of my favorite restaurants in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City that I trust.

I'm really intrigued by your research into early Protestant missions and would love to learn more. In my work, I've found some evidence that the spread of certain parasites may have been influenced by the migration patterns of different religious groups, so I think our areas of study could definitely inform each other. I'd be interested in getting your thoughts on how the religious practices and diets of those early missionaries might have impacted the local food systems.

I'm traveling for a conference next week but I'd be glad to set up a call the week after, if that works for you? Let me know your availability.

Best,
Linh
label: research

Jennifer, 

This is apparently the type of deal flip-flop which BMC has been blessing EBS 
with.  In the note from Doug Cummins which contained his updated spend 
projections, he had the "Professional Services" highlighted with a bunch of 
question marks.  It is at the bottom of his sheet, and lists a qty of 30 @ 
$2000 per = $60,000 --- I assume that's $2K/hour or per day.  Either way, 
it's not something that appears palatable to them (Net Works).  I'll be going 
over there in a few minutes, and will try to check w/each of the guys.  I'll 
keep you posted.

Jeff

	12/13/2000 02:10 PM
		
		 To: Chaz Vaughan/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: Jeff Youngflesh/NA/Enron@ENRON, Brad Nebergall/Enron 
Communications@Enron Communications
		 Subject: Re: BMC Update

Clarification on the below.

Point #1 our position has been $3MM on software (they are saying they need 
$4MM to get the deal done.)

Additionally, they want Maintenance and professional services to go with the 
dollar amount.  $2.4MM is their position here.  I need your help to clarify 
with each group who is on board with maintenance and profesional services.  
BMC's #2 guy Jeff Hawn told Jim Crowder this was critical for them.

Thanks,

Steve


Steve Morse
Enron Broadband Services
713-853-7137-work
713-569-7912-cell
email:  stephen_morse@enron.net



	Chaz Vaughan
	12/12/00 07:29 PM
		
		 To: Jeff Youngflesh/NA/Enron@ENRON
		 cc: Stephen Morse/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 Subject: Re: BMC Update

Jeff,

Thank you for your efforts on the BMC deal.  We are making real progress.  
Here are the answers to your questions:

1.  How much do they want you to guarantee them in BMC revenue?  
$4 MM in software and $2.4 MM in maintenance and professional services
2.  Are you still looking at a $13MM TCV over 5 years?  
No, our current TCV over 5 years is $10 MM 
3.  Have I properly conveyed the "accepable-to-BMC method" of proving 
purchase commitment from Enron?  
Not sure what you mean here
4.  Your note re:  getting the Prof'nl Svcs contract signed says it has to be 
done by 6pm the 14th...what if you don't get it until the morning of the 15th?
We prefer the 14th, but if we can't get it until the 15th, that will work


Please let me know if you have any other questions.  I will call you tomorrow 
to touch base.

Thanks,

Chaz Vaughan
Enron Broadband Services
1400 Smith Street
Houston, TX  77002
Ph:  713-345-8815
Cell: 713-444-3074
Fax: 713-853-7354
Chaz_Vaughan@enron.net 



	Jeff Youngflesh@ENRON
	12/12/00 04:43 PM
		 
		 To: Stephen Morse/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Chaz 
Vaughan/Enron Communications@Enron Communications
		 cc: Jennifer Medcalf/NA/Enron@Enron, Brad Nebergall/Enron 
Communications@Enron Communications, Eric Merten/Enron Communications@Enron 
Communications
		 Subject: BMC Update

Steve/Chaz - 

I have taken your EBS Professional Services contract through our contracts 
folks, and we have ended up with it now being in EBS' contracts dept w/one of 
your attorneys.  Our contracts Director, Tom Moore, and I spoke w/Eric Merten 
(PDX) early this afternoon, and he now has the contract.  EBS may have some 
Intellectual Property issues related to ownership of BMC Consultant-developed 
materials (while being paid by Enron).  Eric is in the driver's seat with the 
contract at this point.  

I have sent notes to all of the Net Works directors currently engaged in one 
form or another with BMC product and/or personnel.  In it, they have been 
requested to help us understand our opportunity from a number of angles:  
Application(s) considered, attractiveness of the new pricing, attractiveness 
of the BMC flexibility w/regard to "purchase commitment", etc.  In addition, 
I have re-iterated the time urgency.

I have followed up the note w/telephone calls & messages to all of them:  
Doug Cummins, Randy Matson, Bob Martinez, Jim Ogg, and Bruce Smith.  I am 
meeting with Bob Martinez on Wednesday at 3pm.  Matson, Ogg, and Smith have 
me in their voicemailbox, Cummins was in a meeting and he said he would call 
me back.

Would either one of you please let me know what BMC wants EBS to do for 
them:  how much do they want you to guarantee them in BMC revenue?  Are you 
still looking at a $13MM TCV over 5 years?  Have I properly conveyed the 
"accepable-to-BMC method" of proving purchase commitment from Enron?  Your 
note re:  getting the Prof'nl Svcs contract signed says it has to be done by 
6pm the 14th...what if you don't get it until the morning of the 15th?

I will call you to follow up on this note.

Thank you,

Jeff Youngflesh

body:
<email>
From: Alex Ramirez <alex.ramirez@oakvilleelementary.org>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@oakvilleelementary.org>
Subject: RE: Idea for an art-science collaboration

Emily,

I absolutely love this idea! Combining art and geology is a fantastic way to engage our students and help them appreciate the world around us. I'm definitely on board for this collaboration.

As we plan the project, I think it would be great to invite a local geologist to speak to the students and provide some inspiration for their artwork. It could be really enriching for them to hear from an expert in the field.

What do you think about organizing an art exhibition at the end of the project to showcase their work? We could hold it at the Oakville Community Center and invite families and community members to attend.

I'm excited to start brainstorming ideas for this project! Let me know when you're free to meet and discuss further.

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Hiro Nakamura <hiro.nakamura@origamimaster.com>
To: Emily Langton <emily.langton@olddictionary.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on an article about paper and folding

Hello Emily,

Thank you for sending over your initial research. It's fascinating to see the connections between the linguistic roots of words related to paper and folding in Old English and Proto-Germanic languages. I can definitely see how incorporating the history and techniques of origami could add depth to your article.

I've attached a document with some information on the specific terms used in origami, along with their English translations and a brief explanation of their origins. I think you'll find it interesting to see how many of these terms have roots in Japanese culture and have been adapted or adopted into the English language.

I've also included a few resources on the history of origami and its influence on Japanese art and culture. I hope these will provide valuable context for your research.

As for our discussion, I'm available next Tuesday afternoon or Wednesday morning, if either of those times work for you. Please let me know what suits you best.

Thank you again for the opportunity to collaborate on this project. I'm excited to see how our combined knowledge will enhance the article!

Best regards,
Hiro

Recently we signed Letters of Interest (LOI's) with three brokers.  The 
letters contemplate our interest in providing these brokers with the ability 
to execute on behalf of their customers on EnronOnline.  Below are the terms 
of these transactions as outlined in the LOI's.  I have contacted many of the 
desk heads prior to entering into the LOI's and outlined the general terms of 
these transactions (J Arnold, J Nowlan, K McGowan, U Ek, S Hastings, K 
Presto,J Hawthorn).  We are also in discussions with the following brokers E 
D & F Man (US Gas and US Power), GFI (global gas, power, coal and emissions), 
PVM (European Crude and Products), and Prebon (world-wide gas & power).  We 
would appreciate if you could give us the names of additional brokers we 
could talk to that are active in your products.

Please pay particular attention to the Amerex terms which include the ability 
to initiate executions telephonically using website prices.  Enrons 
obligation to transact telephonically on website prices are good faith only.  
This term allows Amerex to get around a exclusivity clause with Altra which 
they are trying to negotiate out of.

Please review the terms and contact me at (ext 3-0397) concerning any 
comments or concerns that need to be addressed prior to the execution of 
definitive agreements. 

Amerex Natural Gas I, Ltd./Amerex Power, Ltd.

 Products:   Worldwide Gas, Power, Crude, Crude Products and Bandwidth
 Broker Fee:   No fee for transactions executed on EnronOnline (or initiated 
with a website price)
 Other:    Ability to initiate execution telephonically using a website price 
with good faith effort by Enron.
 License Fee:   $250,000
 Term:    One year
 Liquidated Damages:  Payable on broken transactions up to dollar amount of 
collateral deposit and accounts payable due to broker.  No limit on      
Broker fraud or misrepresentation.

Natsource LLC

 Products:   US Gas and US Power
 Broker Fee:   No fee for transactions executed on EnronOnline 
 License Fee:   $250,000
 Term:    One year
 Liquidated Damages:  Payable on broken transactions up to dollar amount of 
collateral deposit and accounts payable due to broker.  No limit on      
Broker fraud or misrepresentation.

Power Merchant Group

 Products:   Nymex Natural Gas
 Broker Fee:   No fee for transactions executed on EnronOnline
 License Fee:   $100,000
 Term:    One year
 Liquidated Damages:  Payable on broken transactions up to dollar amount of 
collateral deposit and accounts payable due to broker.  No limit on      
Broker fraud or misrepresentation.

body:
<email>
From: Rajesh Patel <rajeshrpatel@universityofdelhi.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emilyt@globalpolicy.org>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference on Kashmir

Emily,

Thank you for sharing your draft presentation. I read through it and found your analysis of the partition process to be thorough and well-supported. However, I think you may be underestimating the strategic importance of Kashmir to India's national security, particularly given its border with China and Pakistan.

I've outlined some counterpoints in the attached document, which I hope will enrich our discussion at the conference. I'm looking forward to a lively and informative panel.

Best regards,
Rajesh

Date: Mon, 9 Oct 2000 07:00:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: keith.holst@enron.com
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Keith Holst
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 10/09/2000 
02:00 PM ---------------------------


Richard Burchfield
10/06/2000 06:59 AM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Beth Perlman/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list

Phillip,
 Below is the issues & to do list as we go forward with documenting the 
requirements for consolidated physical/financial positions and transport 
trade capture. What we need to focus on is the first bullet in Allan's list; 
the need for a single set of requirements. Although the meeting with Keith, 
on Wednesday,  was informative the solution of creating a infinitely dynamic 
consolidated position screen, will be extremely difficult and time 
consuming.  Throughout the meeting on Wednesday, Keith alluded to the 
inability to get consensus amongst the traders on the presentation of the 
consolidated position, so the solution was to make it so that a trader can 
arrange the position screen to their liking (much like Excel). What needs to 
happen on Monday from 3 - 5 is a effort to design a desired layout for the 
consolidated position screen, this is critical. This does not exclude 
building a capability to create a more flexible position presentation for the 
future, but in order to create a plan that can be measured we need firm 
requirements. Also, to reiterate that the goals of this project is a project 
plan on consolidate physical/financial positions and transport trade capture. 
The other issues that have been raised will be capture as projects on to 
themselves, and will need to be prioritised as efforts outside of this 
project.

I have been involved in most of the meetings and the discussions have been 
good. I believe there has been good communication between the teams, but now 
we need to have focus on the objectives we set out to solve.

Richard  
---------------------- Forwarded by Richard Burchfield/HOU/ECT on 10/06/2000 
08:34 AM ---------------------------


Allan Severude
10/05/2000 06:03 PM
To: Richard Burchfield/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Peggy Alix/HOU/ECT@ECT, Russ Severson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scott 
Mills/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kenny Ha/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list


From our initial set of meetings with the traders regarding consolidated 
positions, I think we still have the following issues:
We don't have a single point of contact from the trading group.  We've had 
three meetings which brought out very different issues from different 
traders.  We really need a single point of contact to help drive the trader 
requirements and help come to a consensus regarding the requirements.
We're getting hit with a lot of different requests, many of which appear to 
be outside the scope of position consolidation.

Things left to do:
I think it may be useful to try to formulate a high level project goal to 
make it as clear as possible what we're trying to accomplish with this 
project.  It'll help determine which requests fall under the project scope.
Go through the list of requests to determine which are in scope for this 
project and which fall out of scope.
For those in scope, work to define relative importance (priority) of each and 
work with traders to define the exact requirements of each.
Define the desired lay out of the position manager screen: main view and all 
drill downs.
Use the above to formulate a project plan.

Things requested thus far (no particular order):
Inclusion of Sitara physical deals into the TDS position manager and deal 
ticker.
Customized rows and columns in the position manager (ad hoc rows/columns that 
add up existing position manager rows/columns).
New drill down in the position manager to break out positions by: physical, 
transport, swaps, options, ...
Addition of a curve tab to the position manager to show the real-time values 
of all curves on which the desk has a position.
Ability to split the current position grid to allow daily positions to be 
shown directly above monthly positions.  Each grouped column in the top grid 
would be tied to a grouped column in the bottom grid.
Ability to properly show curve shift for float-for-float deals; determine the 
appropriate positions to show for each:
Gas Daily for monthly index,
Physical gas for Nymex,
Physical gas for Inside Ferc,
Physical gas for Mid market.
Ability for TDS to pull valuation results based on a TDS flag instead of 
using official valuations.
Position and P&L aggregation across all gas desks.
Ability to include the Gas Price book into TDS:
Inclusion of spread options in our systems.  Ability to handle volatility 
skew and correlations.
Ability to revalue all options incrementally throughout the trading day.  
Approximate delta changes between valuations using instantaneous gamma or a 
gamma grid.
Valuation of Gas Daily options.
A new position screen for options (months x strike x delta).  TBD.
Inclusion of positions for exotic options currently managed in spreadsheets.
Ability to isolate the position change due to changed deals in the position 
manager.
Ability to view change deal P&L in the TDS deal ticker.  Show new deal terms, 
prior deal terms, and net P&L affect of the change.
Eliminate change deals with no economic impact from the TDS deal ticker.
Position drill down in the position manager to isolate the impact of 
individual deals on the position total in a grid cell.
Benchmark positions in TDS.
Deployment of TDS in Canada. Currency and volume uom conversions. Implicit 
and explicit position break out issues.

-- Allan.

PS: Colleen is setting up a meeting tomorrow to discuss the direction for 
transport.  Hopefully we'll know much better where that part stands at that 
point.

Hi Eric,


Please find below the detailed terms of a possible deal that we have been
talking about during our phone conversation this morning.


Nature of deal : If the transaction takes place, Societe Generale would sell a
financial fixed price swap (flat price, not basis differential) to Enron. The
monthly settlement would be financial. There would not be any  exchange of
physical product.


Period of the deal : June 1st, 2001 to January 31st, 2021.


Used Reference :  Natural Gas-Houston Ship Channel Index Inside FERC , monthly
settlement.



Volumes of the financial swap transaction : Please find below the volumes 
given
month by month in MMBTU.

(See attached file: volumes-10-5-01-for-Enron.xls)

Since there is a tiny chance that the deal trades today, could you please 
check
if you have credit with SG for this period.
If not, could you find out how much time it approximately takes to get the
credit.
In terms of credit, SG is good with Enron for this period.

Thank you,

Alexander Werner

Date: Thu, 28 Sep 2000 06:17:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: lkuch@mh.com
Subject: San Juan Index
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Lkuch@mh.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 09/28/2000 
01:09 PM ---------------------------
   
	
	
	From:  Phillip K Allen                           09/28/2000 10:56 AM
	


Liane,

 As we discussed yesterday, I am concerned there may have been an attempt to 
manipulate the  El Paso San Juan monthly index.  It appears that a single 
buyer entered the marketplace on both September 26 and 27 and paid above 
market prices ($4.70-$4.80) for San Juan gas.  At the time of these trades, 
offers for physical gas at significantly (10 to 15 cents) lower prices were 
bypassed in order to establish higher trades to report into the index 
calculation.  Additionally, these trades are out of line with the associated 
financial swaps for San Juan.

 We have compiled a list of financial and physical trades executed from 
September 25 to September 27.  These are the complete list of trades from 
Enron Online (EOL), Enron's direct phone conversations, and three brokerage 
firms (Amerex, APB, and Prebon).  Please see the attached spreadsheet for a 
trade by trade list and a summary.  We have also included a summary of gas 
daily prices to illustrate the value of San Juan based on several spread 
relationships.  The two key points from this data are as follows:

 1.  The high physical prices on the 26th & 27th (4.75,4,80) are much greater 
than the high financial trades (4.6375,4.665) on those days. 

 2.  The spread relationship between San Juan and other points (Socal & 
Northwest)  is  consistent between the end of September and 
       October gas daily.  It doesn't make sense to have monthly indices that 
are dramatically different.


 I understand you review the trades submitted for outliers.  Hopefully, the 
trades submitted will reveal counterparty names and you will be able to 
determine that there was only one buyer in the 4.70's and these trades are 
outliers.  I wanted to give you some additional points of reference to aid in 
establishing a reasonable index.  It is Enron's belief that the trades at 
$4.70 and higher  were above market trades that should be excluded from the 
calculation of index.

 It is our desire to have reliable and accurate indices against which to 
conduct our physical and financial business.  Please contact me 
anytime I can assist you towards this goal.

Sincerely,

Phillip Allen

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@university.edu>
To: Michael Rodriguez <michael.rodriguez@research.org>
Subject: RE: Velociraptor feeding habits

Michael,

Thank you so much for agreeing to review my research! I really appreciate your expertise and insight. I'll send over the draft paper and the fossil images by the end of the week.

The new theropod fossil sounds absolutely fascinating. I can't wait to learn more about it and see how it fits into the bigger picture of theropod evolution.

As for the research trip to Mongolia, I'm definitely interested! It sounds like an incredible opportunity and I would love to be a part of it. Let me know the details and I'll start making arrangements.

Thanks again for reaching out and I look forward to catching up soon.

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Smith <samantha.smith@oncologynews.com>
To: Dr. Michael Chen <mchen@skinoncology.com>
Subject: Interview Request for Article on New Melanoma Treatment

Dear Dr. Chen,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Samantha Smith, and I'm a science writer focusing on oncology. We met briefly at the Skin Cancer Research Conference last year, where I was covering the event and interviewing experts in the field. I remember being impressed by your work on innovative treatments for melanoma.

I'm reaching out because I'm currently working on an article about a new treatment for melanoma that has shown promising results in early-stage clinical trials. As one of the lead researchers on this study, I would be grateful to have your insights and expertise for my article.

Would you be available for a short interview via phone or email to discuss the treatment, its potential implications, and the next steps for your research? I would be happy to work around your schedule and provide you with more details about the article.

Thank you for considering my request. I look forward to hearing back from you.

Best regards,
Samantha Smith
Science Writer, Oncology News
label: research

I can do it either way but would much rather just make it the simple average 
of prices, 5 per week.



   
	
	
	From:  Gary Taylor                           10/05/2000 07:25 PM
	

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Griffith/Corp/Enron@Enron
cc:  
Subject: SMUD deal Asian options

John(s),

How will the Asian options we purchased from the gas desk settle with respect 
to weekends... will the average of every day's gas daily settle mean the 
average of only the days on which Gas Daily is published?  or will it triple 
count each Friday's or Monday's price to account for the weekend (with a 
similar calculation on weekends).  I assume it is the former, not the 
latter.  Is this correct?  Are you indifferent if we want to switch to the 
latter?  Intuitively, it would seem to me that at this point, it wouldn't 
matter (because Friday or Monday prices are just as likely to be above the 
average as below the average), but you're wearing the risk, not us - so let 
me know.

Frankly, we don't have a preference as a desk, except that we need the 
settlement to be consistent with the deal we are entering into with SMUD.  
SMUD has questioned our calculation and I need to know how much I need to 
argue for one or the other.

Regards,
Gary
x31511

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <arivera@ancientaquatics.org>
To: Jordan Lee <jlee@maritimehistory.net>
Subject: RE: Exciting new fish weir discovery

Hi Jordan,

I'm thrilled that you're interested in collaborating on this project! I think our combined expertise will be invaluable in unlocking the secrets of this site and its broader implications.

To get the ball rolling, I suggest we schedule a call for early next week to discuss our research objectives and start outlining the grant proposal. I'm free on Tuesday afternoon or Wednesday morning, if either of those times work for you.

In the meantime, I'll start compiling a more detailed site report and literature review to share with you before our call. I'll also reach out to a few colleagues who may be able to provide additional insights or resources.

Please let me know if you have any other thoughts or suggestions as we move forward with this exciting collaboration!

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@university.edu>
To: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@observatory.org>
Subject: RE: New telescope proposal

Hi Michael,

That's great to hear that you're interested in collaborating! I think your work on dark matter halos and star formation rates would be a perfect fit for this proposal. We could potentially even expand the scope to include some of your simulation results as part of the science case.

As for the timeline, I'm hoping to submit the proposal to the NSF by the end of the summer. That would give us a few months to refine the science goals, draft the proposal, and get feedback from other collaborators. Let me know if that works for you and if there are any specific parts of the proposal you'd like to take the lead on.

I'm attaching a draft of the science justification section that I've been working on. Feel free to take a look and let me know your thoughts. I'd be happy to set up a call to discuss further if you have any questions or ideas.

Best,
Sarah
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Rebecca Jennings <rebecca.jennings@westfieldacademy.org>
To: Amanda Patel <amanda.patel@westfieldacademy.org>
Subject: Feeling a bit stuck

Hey Amanda,

I hope you're doing well and enjoying the last few days of school before break. I've been thinking about our last conversation and I wanted to reach out. 

As much as I love teaching, lately I've been questioning whether I'm really cut out for this. The pushback from some parents has me second-guessing my whole approach. I know in my heart that student-centered, experiential learning is the way to go, but it's hard not to doubt myself sometimes. I'm worried I'm not tough enough for this job.

I don't mean to dump all my angst on you, I just don't know many other teachers as innovative as you who could relate. Do you ever feel this way? How do you stay motivated and true to your vision in the face of resistance? I'd love any words of wisdom you have.

I hope you have some fun plans for summer break! I'm thinking of doing a language immersion program in Spain, but we'll see. 

Anyway, I'd love to catch up more sometime soon. Let me know if you want to grab lunch or a drink after school lets out.

Take care,
Rebecca
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <athompson@sciencelearninghub.com>
To: Samantha Johnson <sjohnson@marineresearch.org>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on whale migration project

Hi Samantha,

It's great to hear from you! I've been really looking forward to working together on this project, and I think it's a fantastic opportunity to share your important research with a broader audience.

I'd love to set up a video call to discuss the project in more detail. How about next Friday, April 15th at 1pm EST? If that doesn't work for you, let me know some other times that might be better.

I've been giving some thought to potential angles for the articles and videos, and I'm excited to bounce ideas off you and get your input. I think we could create some really compelling content that highlights the significance of your work and its implications for marine conservation.

Looking forward to chatting more next week!

Best,
Alex

X-cc:

X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Hey:
Haven't had the best of months.  Like you had some good positions but others 
wiped out everything.  Unbelievable how the whole curve moves as one for 6 
months and then separates completely.  The z/f/g and f/g/h flies are 
amazing.  Something definitely out of whack.  Hard to believe cash in Z will 
be cantango to F and front spread, F/G, will be 40.  Spreads definitely 
implying we will see some $10+ prints on daily cash at the hub this winter.  
Hell, already seeing it in the West.  The system is just broken there.  
interesting to see if it is a sign of what can come in the east later.  
definitely more flexibility in the east so the blowouts won't occur until 
latter part of the winter.   the inelasticity of demand continues to be 
unbelievable.  who would have thunk it.   Gas can be 3 times what it was one 
year ago and not a significant loss of demand.   
market definitely trained to buy the dips at this point.  continues to be a 
very trending market.  most days finish on the intraday high or low.  
Pira told the boys to hedge jv and cal 2 and the impact has been 
significant.  i quote bids on term strips 5 times a day.   understand they 
are changing their view somewhat tomorrow.  wait and see if it relieves some 
back pressure.  very surprised at lack of spec long interest in jv at 4.5 
considering the scenario that's being painted.   




slafontaine@globalp.com on 11/21/2000 01:06:40 PM
To: jarnold@enron.com
cc:  
Subject: re:mkts



johnny, hope things re treating you well. this month has been frustrating for
me-generally caught many mkt moves but had 2 postions that nearly cancelled 
all
the rest. im finding it really really hard to assess risk now in oil and gas
therefore im taking a step back esp in front of holidays and year end. was 
long
mar gas vs backs which worked great but i took profits waayyy too early
  flat px i think is pretty clear-if weather stays normal to below we keep a
flaoor at 5.80-6.00 bucks for another 40 days at least. if we have sustained
aboves we drop like a rock in part due to back en d pressure.

   but spreads-what the hell do we do with em?????????? was just saying to 
mark
silverman there is a huge opportunity here staring us in the face but i hve no
idea what it is-i have equal arguements for why sprds shud fall or move out. 
any
great insites? hope all is well and enjoy the long weeknd-we both deserve it.
   guess the curve will stop blowing out when/if we see the back end selling 
dry
up??

rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's
you bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?
what you charge me play against you?)

<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@econinstitute.edu>
To: David Lee <dlee@decisionpsych.com>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference on "Decision-Making in Organizations"

David,

Thank you for your prompt response. Thursday morning works well for me, so let's schedule our call for then. I'll send you a calendar invite with the video call details.

I'm intrigued by the study you mentioned and would love to discuss it further. I have some thoughts on how it relates to the work I've been doing on regulatory capture and how it can influence market competition.

Looking forward to our call and the conference!
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Chen <emily.chen@medmail.com>
To: Jordan Walters <jordan.walters@medmail.com>
Subject: RE: Interesting case study on idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

Hi Jordan,

Thanks for sharing the case study! I read through it and found the anatomical insights fascinating. The way the fibrotic changes in the lung tissue lead to impaired gas exchange is truly intriguing.

I'd be happy to collaborate on an article for our group. In fact, I've been working on a similar project, trying to create educational content about lung anatomy and physiology for students. If you're interested, we could combine our efforts and create something more comprehensive.

Let me know what you think!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Liam Nakamura <liam.nakamura@cretaeceousdinofossils.com>
To: Olivia Jennings <olivia.jennings@montanamuseum.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting new theropod discovery!

Olivia,

Your email couldn't have come at a better time! I'm thrilled to hear about your new discovery. I'd be more than happy to collaborate with you on this research paper. From what you've described, it sounds like this fossil could shed new light on theropod evolution during the Cretaceous period.

I've been doing some work on the phylogenetic relationships of theropods lately, and this new fossil might just be the missing piece we've been looking for. I can't wait to see the data and specimens you've collected.

Please send over any relevant information, and let's set up a time to discuss our approach for the paper. I'm confident that with our combined expertise, we can make a significant contribution to the field.

Looking forward to working with you on this exciting project!

Best,
Liam
label: research

body:
Regarding Today's discussion:

I went through the code on Stack overflow and like I was trying to explain earlier in the office today, We have broadly done the same thing as the code shared by you. We have masked  the rows and columns with missing values, However since our way of masking out is slightly more complicated , therefore may take more time incase of larger matrices. Hence using the code on Stackoverflow would be beneficial. Also, the code provided on Stack-Overflow is only for the case of non-negative least squares, so needs to be used accordingly.

body:
<email>
From: Sam Nakamura <sam.nakamura@lincolnhigh.edu>
To: Alex Rivera <alex.rivera@jeffersonhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Social Justice in Earth Science

Alex,

Thanks so much for sending those resources! I've been reading through them and they're really inspiring. I love the idea of creating a lesson together that we could co-teach. 

I was thinking we could focus on the disproportionate impact of climate change on marginalized communities and tie that into a lesson on climate science and the greenhouse effect. We could have students analyze data on climate impacts in different communities and discuss the historical and social factors that contribute to these disparities.

I'd be happy to come up with a draft outline for the lesson and send it your way. Then we can bounce ideas back and forth and refine it together.

Excited to collaborate on this!

Sam
