body:
<email>
From: Dr. Ethan Patel <epatel@university.edu>
To: Dr. Olivia Richards <orichards@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Upcoming excavation in Africa

Dear Dr. Richards,

Thank you for your email. I am thrilled to be part of this groundbreaking project and to have the opportunity to work alongside you and the team.

I have been reviewing the latest research on Homo erectus and early human migrations, and I believe we have a strong foundation for our excavation. I will make sure to have all the necessary documents and equipment ready for our departure.

Please let me know when you would like to schedule the team meeting. I am available anytime next week, except for Tuesday afternoon when I have a lecture to give.

If you have any specific topics or research questions you would like me to focus on during the meeting, please let me know. I am happy to prepare any additional materials or presentations beforehand.

I look forward to our adventure in Africa and the discoveries that await us.

Best regards,
Ethan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Mark Johnson <mark.johnson@weatheragency.com>
To: Jenna Smith <jenna.smith@noaa.gov>
Subject: RE: Severe weather event - need your expert advice

Hi Jenna,

It's great to hear from you, although I'm sorry to hear about the challenges you're facing. I'd be more than happy to help you incorporate satellite data into your forecasts. It's a great way to improve accuracy, especially during severe weather events.

I'm free next Tuesday afternoon if you'd like to set up a call. We can go over the basics and I can share some resources that might be helpful for you and your team.

In the meantime, feel free to reach out if you have any specific questions or if there's anything else I can do to help.

Best,
Mark
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Stanton <emily.stanton@university.edu>
To: Daniel Lee <daniel.lee@envirosolutions.org>
Subject: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Daniel,

It was great meeting you at the Sustainability and Human Evolution conference last week. I really enjoyed your presentation on sustainable agriculture and climate change mitigation. I think there could be some fascinating intersections between your work and my research on early human migrations and adaptations.

I mentioned that I'm planning a research trip to Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania later this year. If you're interested, I would love for you to join me. I think your expertise in environmental science and sustainability could bring a valuable perspective to the project.

Let me know if you'd like to discuss this further. I'd be happy to set up a call or exchange some more information about the trip.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Fisher <jfisher@nationalweatherservice.gov>
To: Liam Evans <levans@nationalweatherservice.gov>
Subject: Our research paper submission

Hey Liam,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to let you know that I submitted our research paper on using machine learning for radar-based weather prediction to the Journal of Meteorological Research last night. I'm really excited about the potential impact our work could have on the field.

I was thinking, while we await the peer review process, we should start preparing for the upcoming International Meteorological Conference. If our paper is accepted, we'll have the opportunity to present our findings to a global audience of meteorologists and researchers. It would be a great chance to get feedback and make some valuable connections.

Let me know if you have any ideas for our presentation. I think we should focus on the key findings from our paper and the potential applications of our techniques for real-time weather forecasting.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best,
Jordan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@cybersecure.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@cybersecure.com>
Subject: RE: New malware targeting financial institutions

Hi Emily,

Great, I'll see you tomorrow at 2 PM in the conference room. I've also been digging into FinStealer and have found some additional information that I think will be helpful in our efforts to combat this malware.

I've reached out to a few of my contacts in the cybersecurity community, and it seems that FinStealer has been responsible for several high-profile breaches in the past few months. The attackers behind the malware are believed to be a sophisticated criminal organization with ties to Eastern Europe.

I'll put together a summary of what I've learned and share it with you before our meeting tomorrow. We'll need to develop a comprehensive strategy to detect, prevent, and mitigate the impact of FinStealer on our clients' systems.

Looking forward to working with you on this, Emily. Let's show these cybercriminals that we mean business!

Best,
John

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@telecomtech.com>
To: John Smith <john.smith@autotech.com>
Subject: RE: Webinar planning

Hi John,

Thanks for reaching out! I'm excited to collaborate with you on this webinar. I agree that focusing on edge computing, IoT, and speed sensor technologies is a great idea. We could also consider covering topics like data security and privacy in autonomous vehicles, as these are becoming increasingly important concerns.

As for speakers, I have a few ideas:

1. Dr. Sarah Thompson, a renowned expert in edge computing from the University of Technology
2. Michael Chen, the CTO of a leading automotive company who has been working on autonomous vehicle projects
3. Dr. David Lee, a professor specializing in IoT technologies at the Institute of Advanced Automotive Studies

We could also reach out to some of our contacts in the industry to see if they'd be interested in participating.

To promote the webinar, we could create a dedicated website and social media accounts, as well as reach out to relevant online communities and industry publications.

Let me know what you think, and we can schedule a call to discuss the details further.

Best,
Emily
label: research

Jeff,

That is good news about Leander.  

Now for the stage.  I would like to get it sold by the end of March.   I have 
about $225K invested in the stagecoach, 
 it looks like I need to get around $745K to breakeven.  

I don't need the cash out right now so if I could get a personal guarantee 
and Jaques Craig can 
work out the partnership transfer, I would definitely be willing to carry a 
second lien.  I understand second liens are going for 10%-12%.
Checkout this spreadsheet.





These numbers should get the place sold in the next fifteen minutes.   
However,  I am very concerned about the way it is being shown.  Having Lucy 
show it is not a good idea.  I need you to meet the buyers and take some 
trips over to get more familar with the property.  My dad doesn't have the 
time and I don't trust 
Lucy or Wade to show it correctly.  I would prefer for you to show it from 
now on.  

I will have the operating statements complete through December by this 
Friday. 


Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@gamedesigntheorist.com>
To: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@mail.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on game design and economics

Dear Alex,

Thank you for reaching out and for your kind words about my work. It's always a pleasure to connect with someone passionate about exploring the intersection of game design and economics.

I'd be happy to share some insights and resources with you. One key concept to understand is the role of incentives and rewards in driving player behavior. By carefully designing the economic systems within your game, you can encourage players to engage in desired actions and create a sense of progression and achievement.

Some resources that might be helpful for you include:

1. "The Art of Game Design: A Book of Lenses" by Jesse Schell - This book provides a comprehensive overview of game design principles and includes discussions on economics and player motivation.
2. "Rules of Play: Game Design Fundamentals" by Katie Salen and Eric Zimmerman - Another excellent resource that covers the fundamentals of game design, including the role of rules and systems.
3. The Extra Credits YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/user/ExtraCredits) - They have several videos that delve into game design and economics, such as their series on "The Problem with Video Game Economies."

Feel free to explore these resources and let me know if you have any specific questions. I'm always happy to discuss these topics further and provide more tailored advice based on your project.

Best of luck with your game development journey!

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Nguyen

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Nguyen <jnguyen@vaccineresearch.org>
To: Liam Patel <lpatel@immunology.org>
Subject: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Liam,

It was wonderful to meet you at the Vaccine Development Conference in Santa Barbara last week. I really enjoyed our discussions about the potential applications of radiation in vaccine development and the challenges we face in this field.

I was impressed by your presentation on the latest advancements in immunology research and how it can inform vaccine development strategies. I believe our research interests align quite well, and I would love to explore potential collaborations.

If you're interested, I'd be happy to share some of the data from my recent experiments on the effects of radiation on viral proteins. I think it could complement your work on immune system response to viral antigens.

Let me know if you'd like to chat more about this or meet up for a virtual coffee sometime.

Best regards,
Jenna

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@cyberpsychresearch.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@innovativeschools.org>
Subject: RE: RE: Technology in Education Summit

Hi Emily,

Thank you for thinking of me and for the invitation to co-present with you at the Technology in Education Summit! I am honored and excited about the opportunity to share our research findings with a broader audience.

I am definitely interested and available to join you in San Francisco for the conference. I think it's a fantastic opportunity to showcase our collaborative work and potentially open doors for future research projects. I'm happy to contribute to the presentation preparation and would love to meet up a few days early to practice and ensure we are aligned in our messaging.

Please let me know the details of your travel plans, and I'll book my flights and accommodation accordingly. I'm also happy to help with creating visual aids and structuring our presentation to make it engaging and informative for the audience.

Thank you again for this opportunity, and I look forward to working with you on this presentation!

Best regards,
Alex

<email>
From: Emily Stone <estone@geotherm.org>
To: David Patel <dpatel@hivax.org>
Subject: Following up from GIRI conference

Hi David,

It was great meeting you at the GIRI conference in Newbridge last month. I really enjoyed our conversation about the potential for interdisciplinary collaboration between our fields. I've been thinking more about how geothermal energy could be used to power facilities involved in vaccine production and research.

I'd love to hear more about your latest work on HIV vaccine development. Have you made any breakthroughs since we last spoke? I'm curious to know if there are any specific challenges in your research that might benefit from a fresh perspective or input from the geothermal energy field.

Let me know if you're interested in catching up further. I'm happy to discuss potential collaborations or just share ideas.

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <athompson@university.edu>
To: Jenna Nguyen <jnguyen@university.edu>
Subject: Workshop on Critical Thinking and Reasoning Skills

Hi Jenna,

I hope you're doing well. I'm reaching out because I'm organizing a workshop on critical thinking and reasoning skills for our students. As part of the workshop, I'd like to incorporate some math-related activities that promote logical thinking. I was wondering if you have any suggestions or resources that could help me achieve this goal.

I believe that your expertise in elementary math education could provide valuable insights into creating engaging and educational activities for the students. If you have any ideas or materials that you think would be suitable for the workshop, please let me know.

I'd be happy to discuss this further and hear your thoughts on the matter. Please feel free to reply whenever convenient for you.

Best regards,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@college.edu>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Draft of the dictionary project

Hi Sarah,

Thanks for sending over the draft! I'm really impressed with the work you've done so far. I'll definitely take a closer look and provide some detailed feedback in the next few days.

As for your idea about co-authoring a paper, I think it's a great suggestion. Our research could definitely make a valuable contribution to the field, and it would be fantastic to share our findings with others. I'm happy to discuss this further and start brainstorming ideas for the paper.

On a personal note, I wanted to let you know that I recently adopted a puppy. He's a energetic little guy and keeps me on my toes! I'll have to send you a picture sometime.

Looking forward to your response and continuing our work together.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@maritimehistory.org>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@caribbeanarchaeology.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting discovery in Jamaica!

Emily,

This is incredible news! I've been eagerly following your work on prehistoric fish weirs, and this discovery sounds like a major breakthrough. I would be thrilled to collaborate with you on this project.

As you know, I'm currently writing a book on the history of commercial fishing in the Caribbean, and this new evidence could significantly enhance my research. I'm considering taking a sabbatical next semester to focus on the book and your excavation project.

I have a few ideas on how we might approach the historical context and implications of this discovery. Would you be available for a call next week to discuss the project in more detail?

Best,
Michael

body:
Message-ID: <13784328.1075858635528.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 24 Oct 2001 13:50:19 -0700 (PDT)
From: no.address@enron.com
Subject: Jeff McMahon Named CFO
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Ken Lay- Chairman of the Board@ENRON
X-To: All Enron Worldwide@ENRON <??SAll Enron Worldwide@ENRON>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


Today we announced the appointment of Jeff McMahon as Enron's chief financial officer.  In my continued discussions with the financial community yesterday and today, it became clear that this move was required to restore investor confidence.  Jeff has unparalleled qualifications and a deep and thorough understanding of Enron.  He is already on the job and hard at work on the issues before us.  Andy Fastow will be on a leave of absence from the company.  

Jeff had been serving as chairman and CEO of Enron Industrial Markets. He joined Enron in 1994 and spent three years in the London office as chief financial officer for Enron's European operations.  Upon returning to the U.S., Jeff was executive vice president of finance and treasurer for Enron Corp.  In 2000, he was named president and chief operating officer of Enron Net Works.

I know all of you are concerned about the continuing decline in our share price.  I am too, and we are working very hard to turn it around.  Appointing Jeff as CFO is one important step in that process.  But most of the solution involves just continuing to do our jobs with excellence.  The fundamentals of our business are strong, and I think the market will begin to see that as we continue to perform.

Please join me in giving Jeff your full support, and thank you for all of your continued hard work.

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Smith <jordan.smith@university.edu>
To: Liam Nguyen <liam.nguyen@research.org>
Subject: Exciting new developments in our project!

Hey Liam,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share some exciting news about our collaborative project. We've just secured additional funding from the National Science Foundation to expand our fieldwork and data collection efforts. This means we'll be able to collect an even more comprehensive dataset and really dive deep into the stratigraphy of the Morrison Formation.

I'm thrilled about the potential implications this could have for our understanding of the Late Jurassic ecosystems in North America. With the extra resources, we'll be able to bring on a couple of graduate students to assist with the fieldwork and data analysis, which should help us make even more progress.

I've attached a draft of the revised project proposal for your review. Let me know if you have any suggestions or feedback. I'm also happy to discuss further over the phone or video chat if you prefer.

Looking forward to your thoughts and to our continued collaboration!

Best,
Jordan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jamal Williams <jamal.williams@internationalschool-berlin.de>
To: Petra Müller <petra.muller@internationalschool-berlin.de>
Subject: RE: Jamaican Adventure!

Petra,

I'm glad you're as excited as I am about this trip! Your English is already fantastic, but I'm sure you'll have plenty of opportunities to practice while we're in Jamaica.

I've booked our flights and found a great guesthouse in Kingston that's close to all the main attractions. It has excellent reviews and a friendly atmosphere, so I think we'll feel right at home. I'll send you the booking confirmation and details shortly.

As for the accommodations in Ocho Rios and Montego Bay, I have a few family members who might be able to host us for a night or two. It would be a great opportunity for you to experience true Jamaican hospitality! Let me know if you're comfortable with that, and I'll make the necessary arrangements.

I'll also make a list of the places we absolutely must visit and send it your way. Can't wait to share my culture with you!

Best,
Jamal

body:
<email>
From: Liam Patel <liam.patel@university.edu>
To: Grace Thompson <grace.thompson@riverdalehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Guest lecture invitation

Dear Grace,

Thank you for reaching out and for the kind invitation to speak to your class. I would be delighted to give a guest lecture on the role of women in early human societies. 

I think it's crucial for students to understand the deep history of gender roles and how they have evolved over time. I can provide an overview of what the archaeological and fossil evidence tells us about the lives of early human females, and how that compares to modern human societies.

I'm happy to work with you to ensure the lecture is appropriate for your students' level and fits well with your curriculum. Please let me know what date and time would work best for you, and if there are any specific topics or themes you'd like me to focus on.

Looking forward to collaborating with you on this!

Best,
Liam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@matheduniversity.edu>
To: David Okafor <david.okafor@historyuniversity.edu>
Subject: Following up from the conference

Hi David,

It was great to meet you at the conference last week and learn more about your work on colonialism in Africa. I was really intrigued by your talk on the economic impact of colonialism and found myself thinking about the ways in which history and mathematics education could intersect.

I'm writing to share a bit more about my own research on using data analysis to improve math instruction. I've attached a recent paper I published on the topic. I'd be curious to hear your thoughts on how this kind of approach could be applied in history education as well.

Looking forward to continuing our conversation and exploring potential collaborations.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@electronerd.com>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@measurerific.com>
Subject: New component for our multimeter project

Hey Emily,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share some exciting news with you. I recently came across a new component that could significantly improve the accuracy of our open-source multimeter project. It's called the "SuperAccurate ADC" and it's supposed to have an incredibly low noise floor and high resolution.

I was thinking we could try to incorporate this component into our design and see if it makes a noticeable difference in our measurements. What do you think? Have you heard of this component before?

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best regards,
John

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Raj Patel <rpatel@infectiousdiseases.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@vectorhealth.org>
Subject: RE: Concerns about the new Zika strain

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out, and I'm glad you brought this to my attention. The new Zika strain is indeed a cause for concern, and I believe it requires a coordinated effort from public health professionals like ourselves to mitigate its impact.

I would be more than happy to share with you the details of our vector control program here in Singapore. Our multidisciplinary approach, which includes public education campaigns, targeted vector control measures, and close monitoring of disease transmission, has proven to be effective in reducing the incidence of vector-borne diseases in our city.

I'm available for a call next Tuesday, April 20th, at 10 AM EST. Please let me know if this works for you, and feel free to invite any other colleagues who might benefit from the discussion.

In the meantime, I'll gather some resources and case studies that I think will be useful for our conversation.

Best regards,
Dr. Raj Patel
Infectious Disease Specialist
National University of Singapore

<email>
From: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@biologyuniversity.edu>
To: Jenna Smith <jenna.smith@nursing.edu>
Subject: Draft of my guest post - "My Journey in Respiratory Physiology"

Hi Jenna,

I hope you're doing well. I've finished the draft of my guest post and wanted to share it with you for your review and feedback.

Please find the draft attached. I've tried to include the points you suggested and have cited my sources using APA format.

I had a lot of fun writing this post and reflecting on my journey so far. I hope your readers find it interesting and informative.

Please let me know if you have any suggestions for improvements or changes. I'm happy to revise the post based on your feedback.

I look forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best regards,
Alex Johnson

Subject:=09FERC Order on Reporting CA gas sales

Attached is the Commission's "Order Imposing Reporting Requirement on Natur=
al Gas Sales to California Market," which was issued late yesterday.

In the order, the Commission finds that if does have the authority to reque=
st the information as set out in the May 18 order proposing the requirement=
s.  =20

The information is to cover August 1, 2001 through Sept. 30, 2002 (the end =
date coincides with the end of the Commission's mitigation plan re: wholesa=
l prices in California and the West).
Specific info gas sellers and LDCs file concernign purchase and sales trans=
actions is exempt from FOIA disclosure
Also, respondents may request privileged treatment of "other portions of th=
eir responses subject to the.....Commission's regulations"
Some of the questions have been modified based on comments received based o=
n comments received on the May 18th proposal
Transaction by transaction data is required; FERC will aggregate the inform=
ation
The information request will NOT be expanded beyond California
FERC is providing the reporting format as a data template to be available o=
n RIMS.

The order is attached here, and the appendix listing specific questions is =
below.     =20

=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=

APPENDIX

Answers to all questions below that require a statement of volumes should s=
et forth the requested volumes on an MMBtu basis.

For Interstate Natural Gas Pipelines:

1.=09On a daily basis for the period August 1, 2001 to January 31, 2002, pl=
ease provide the following information for each contract for transportation=
 to the California border:

a.=09the transaction or contract identification number;
b.=09the terms and effective date of the contract;
c.=09contract demand by shipper;
d.=09the daily scheduled volume by shipper;
e.=09the daily nominated volume by shipper;
f.=09the daily delivered volume by shipper;
g.=09whether the service is firm or interruptible;=20
h.=09the rate charged in $$/MMbtu;
i.=09primary receipt and delivery points associated with the contract; and,
j.=09whether the shipper is affiliated with the pipeline.

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=
esponse to this question.  Please provide this information in Excel version=
 97 or 2000 or comma separated value (CSV) format.

2.=09For the period August 1, 2001 to January 31, 2002, please provide the =
following information for each capacity release transaction for transportat=
ion to the California border:

a.=09the transaction or contract identification number, or offer number;=20
(This number should tie to contract number reported in Question 1,a., above=
)
b.=09the name of the releasing shipper;
c.=09the name of the acquiring shipper;
d.=09the contract quantity;
e.=09the acquiring shipper's contract rate; and,
f.=09the releasing shipper's contract rate.

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=
esponse to this question.  Please provide this information in Excel version=
 97 or 2000 or comma separated value (CSV) format.
Docket No. RM01-9-000=09- 6 -

3.=09On a daily basis for the period August 1, 2001 to January 31, 2002, pl=
ease provide the following system information:

a.=09the maximum peak day design capacity;
b =09the daily maximum flowing capacity;
c =09the daily scheduled system volume;
d.=09the daily delivered system volume;
e.=09the daily scheduled volume at each California delivery point;
f.=09an explanation of each instance that the daily maximum flowing capacit=
y is below the maximum peak day design capacity; and,

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=
esponse to this question.  Please provide this information in Excel version=

4.=09On a daily basis for May 1999 and May 2000, please provide the followi=
ng system information:

For Sellers of Natural Gas to the California Market:

1.=09State whether the seller is affiliated with an interstate or intrastat=

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=

 97 or 2000 or comma separated value (CSV) format.

3.=09For each sales contract, identify separately the transportation compon=
ent and the gas commodity component of the price.  If the sales contract sp=
ecifies the transportation component of the price, the seller shall report =
that amount.  If the sales contract only includes an overall price, then th=
e seller shall report the transportation cost it incurred in moving the gas=
 from the point where it purchased the gas to the point where it sold the g=
as and how it determined that amount.  If the sale was made at the same poi=
nt where the gas was purchased, and there is no transportation element in t=
he sale, the seller shall respond "n.a."

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=

4.=09For the period August 1, 2001 to January 31, 2002, please provide the =

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=

For Local Distribution Companies In California:=09

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=

b.=09the term of the sales contract (beginning and ending dates);=20

d.=09the price paid by purchaser.

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=

 97 or 2000 or comma separated value (CSV) format.

4.=09On a daily basis for the period August 1, 2001 to January 31, 2002, pl=

a.=09the purchase contract's identification number;
b.=09the term of the purchase contract (beginning and ending dates);=20
c.=09the volumes (on a MMBtu basis) bought;
d.=09the price paid;=20
e.=09whether the price is fixed or indexed (identify the index); and,
f.=09identify the point where (name of local distribution company) took tit=
le to the gas.=20

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=
esponse to this question.  Please provide this information in Excel version=
 97 or 2000 or comma separated value (CSV) format.

5.=09On a daily basis for the period August 1, 2001 to January 31, 2002, pl=

 service your system has under contract.  At each receipt point, provide ma=
ximum peak day design capacity, the daily maximum flowing capacity, the dai=

Along with the hard copy response, please provide a CD-ROM containing the r=

6.=09On a daily basis for the period August 1, 2001 to January 31, 2002, pl=

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Adams <jordan.adams@suniversity.edu>
To: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@stargazer.org>
Subject: Exciting new solar observation technique

Hi Sarah,

I hope you're doing well! I just read your recent paper on the new solar observation technique, and I must say, I'm truly impressed. The implications of this technique for our understanding of solar dynamics are fascinating.

I was wondering if you could elaborate on how this technique could be applied to my research on historical solar observations. I'm particularly interested in how it might help us uncover new insights into past solar events and their impact on Earth.

I would be grateful for any advice or suggestions you might have. Perhaps we could even collaborate on a project combining our expertise?

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best regards,
Jordan
label: research

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Vladimir Gorny/HOU/ECT@ECT, Minal Dalia/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sunil 
Dalal/Corp/Enron@ENRON 
Subject: Option Analysis on NG Price Book

John,

Several months ago we talked about the development of an option analysis tool 
that could be used to stress test positions under various scenarios as a 
supplement to our V@R analysis.  We have recently completed the project and 
would like to solicit your feedback on the report results.

We have selected your NG price position for April 4, 2000 (POST-ID  753650) 
for the initial analysis.  Attached in the excel file below you will find:

Analysis across the various forward months in your position 

Underlying vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L 
Volatility vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L
Time change vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L


Summary of your Overall Position analysis

Underlying vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L 
Volatility vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L
Time change vs. Greeks, theoretical P&L


Multiple Stress Analysis

The attached Word document demonstrates the multiple stress choices.  I have 
included a tab in the excel file that demonstrates the theoretical P/L 
resulting from shifts in both volatility and underlying price.  


Please note that the percentage changes across the column headers are not in 
absolute terms (for example, if the ATM volatility in a given month is 40% 
and the stress is -10% then the analysis is performed under a volatility 
scenario of 36%)









Thanks,

Rudi

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sthompson@riverdalems.org>
To: Dr. Michael Johnson <mjohnson@earlyamerica.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborative project idea - History and Art

Dear Dr. Johnson,

I'm writing to share some fantastic news! The students have completed their digital art pieces, and they are truly impressive. We've created an online gallery to showcase their work, and the response from the school community has been overwhelmingly positive.

I'd like to invite you to the virtual exhibition, which will take place next Friday at 7:00 pm. You'll have the opportunity to view the students' artwork, hear them present the historical significance behind each piece, and provide feedback.

Please let me know if you can attend, and I'll send you the link to join the exhibition.

Thank you once again for your invaluable contribution to this project. The students have learned so much about early American history and have developed a deeper appreciation for the artistic process.

Best regards,
Sarah Thompson

body:
<email>
From: Marie Vermeulen <marie.vermeulen@ecole.be>
To: Jacques Dubois <jacques.dubois@historicalsociety.be>
Subject: Collaborative project proposal

Dear Jacques,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out to you regarding our recent discussion about creating a collaborative art project for my kindergarten class based on local historical landmarks. I think this could be a wonderful opportunity for the students to learn about the rich history of our region while also expressing their creativity through art.

I was thinking we could focus on the World War I fortifications you spoke about at the historical society meeting. Perhaps you could provide some historical context and photographs of the sites, and I could guide the students in creating paintings or drawings inspired by these landmarks.

What do you think? I would love to hear your thoughts and ideas on how we could make this project a success. Please let me know if you're interested in collaborating and if you have any suggestions for other historical sites we could include.

Best regards,
Marie

<email>
From: Alex Glycogen <aglycogen@windor.edu>
To: Becca Sucrose <bsucrose@lakeside.edu>
Subject: RE: Your thoughts on my latest paper?

Hi Becca,

I'm thrilled that you found the paper interesting and see potential for a collaboration! Your ideas on using the synthetic carbohydrates in cell models sound fantastic. A virtual coffee chat to discuss this in more detail would be great - how about next Wednesday at 10 AM my time (which should be 1 PM for you)? Let me know if that works.

Absolutely, let's plan to meet up at the symposium! I'll be presenting a poster on our latest findings on Thursday afternoon. We could grab lunch and discuss our collaboration plans in person then.

Looking forward to working together again!

Best,
Alex

Subject: Updates to our Video Production Timeframes and Scope


Hello Steve and Chris -

Recently, there were changes to the overall number of our scenarios in our
simulation. There will be seven scenarios versus the nine we have been
discussing. These changes result in:
        Deletion of 2 intro and 2 exit videos
        Deletion of six interview questions (see more detail below)
        No additional characters. We will still need all characters (and
        talent) that we have casted for.

Laura has been working with John to make the required edits to the scripts.
We have recieved today (mid-day).

Based on our last discussion, I'd like to recommend we set the date for our
shoot for the end of the first week in Dec. Specifically, Dec. 6th and 7th.
This recommendation is based on the response I received from our project
manager in regards to the time it will take to have Legal review our
scripts.

Please let me know if you have any questions. Thank you and have a
wonderful Thanksgiving!

Sheri A. Righi

body:
<email>
From: Robert Thompson <robert.thompson@baptisthistory.org>
To: Grace Nguyen <grace.nguyen@mathgeometryhelp.com>
Subject: Request for help with geometry in the Mayflower voyage

Dear Grace,

I hope this email finds you well. We interacted briefly in the "History Buffs" online forum a few months ago, and I was impressed by your clear explanations of the geometric principles behind ancient architecture. I'm reaching out because I need some help with a project I'm working on.

I'm a church historian and theologian, and I'm currently writing a book about the Pilgrim Fathers and the Mayflower voyage. I want to include a chapter about the geometric principles used in the design and navigation of the ship, but I'm not as well-versed in mathematics as I would like to be.

Would you be willing to help me understand and explain these concepts in an accessible way? I would be incredibly grateful for your expertise and insight. Please let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to discuss this further.

Best regards,
Robert Thompson

X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


Is there any chance that the request to gather data on financial trades is implemented?  Our understanding was that the commission had no jurisdiction over financial markets.
 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Fulton, Donna  
Sent:	Tuesday, June 19, 2001 9:19 AM
To:	Steffes, James; Nicolay, Christi; Novosel, Sarah; Lawner, Leslie; Cantrell, Rebecca; Miller, Stephanie; Allen, Phillip K.
Cc:	Alvarez, Ray
Subject:	El Paso Merchant Comments on Reporting Requirements

El Paso Merchant filed comments yesterday in the Reporting Requirements docket.  They did not argue against the collection of the new proposed data, but rather argued that the Commission needed to add to the information to be gathered to include financial market data.  El Paso states that the financial market is believed to be ten times as large as the physical market.  El Paso suggests the following information be collected:
the name of the counter party to the financial trade
the quantitiy of gas underlying the financial trade
all the pricing terms of the trade stated in price per MMBtu
the time period of the trade, including starting and ending dates
the date on which the deal was entered into
the type of trade

El Paso Merchant also argues for confidential treatment and a sunset date for the collection of the data (tied to when EIA finds supply and demand in California in balance.)

I have a fax of the comments, but do not yet have them electronically.  Let me know if you want a copy faxed.

body:
<email>
From: Emily Davis <edavis@graduate.edu>
To: John Smith <jsmith@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting research opportunity in carbohydrate synthesis

Dear Dr. Smith,

Thank you so much for your email and for thinking of me for this exciting opportunity. I am thrilled to hear about the grant and the potential impact of the research project. It is an honor to be considered for a postdoctoral position in your lab, and I am truly grateful for your continued support and guidance.

After careful consideration, I have decided to accept your offer and join your lab in the fall. I am eager to work with you and the team on this groundbreaking project and contribute to the advancement of our understanding of carbohydrate synthesis in cell signaling.

Please let me know the next steps in the process and any paperwork I need to complete. I would also appreciate it if you could provide me with more details about the project and the specific role you envision for me.

Thank you once again for this opportunity, and I look forward to working with you and the team.
Best regards,
Emily Davis

Will/HOU/ECT@ECT, Doug Gilbert-Smith/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mike 
Swerzbin/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Wow

Do not underestimate the effects of the Internet economy on load growth.  I 
have been preaching the tremendous growth described below for the last year.  
The utility infrastructure simply cannot handle these loads at the 
distribution level and ultimatley distributed generation will be required for 
power quality reasons.

The City of Austin, TX has experienced 300+ MW of load growth this year due 
to server farms and technology companies.  There is a 100 MW server farm 
trying to hook up to HL&P as we speak and they cannot deliver for 12 months 
due to distribution infrastructure issues.  Obviously, Seattle, Porltand, 
Boise, Denver, San Fran and San Jose in your markets are in for a rude 
awakening in the next 2-3 years.
---------------------- Forwarded by Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT on 09/05/2000 
03:41 PM ---------------------------
   
	Enron North America Corp.
	
	From:  John D Suarez                           09/05/2000 01:45 PM
	

To: Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Dana Davis/HOU/ECT@ECT, Paul J 
Broderick/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jeffrey Miller/NA/Enron@Enron
cc:  
Subject: 


---------------------- Forwarded by John D Suarez/HOU/ECT on 09/05/2000 01:46 
PM ---------------------------


George Hopley
09/05/2000 11:41 AM
To: John D Suarez/HOU/ECT@ECT, Suresh Vasan/Enron Communications@ENRON 
COMMUNICATIONS@ENRON
cc:  
Subject: 

Internet Data Gain Is a Major Power Drain on
                  Local Utilities 

                  ( September 05, 2000 ) 


                  In 1997, a little-known Silicon Valley company called Exodus
                  Communications opened a 15,000-square-foot data center in 
Tukwila. 

                       The mission was to handle the Internet traffic and 
computer servers for the
                  region's growing number of dot-coms. 

                       Fast-forward to summer 2000. Exodus is now wrapping up 
construction
                  on a new 13-acre, 576,000-square-foot data center less than 
a mile from its
                  original facility. Sitting at the confluence of several 
fiber optic backbones, the
                  Exodus plant will consume enough power for a small town and 
eventually
                  house Internet servers for firms such as Avenue A, 
Microsoft and Onvia.com. 

                       Exodus is not the only company building massive data 
centers near Seattle.
                  More than a dozen companies -- with names like AboveNet, 
Globix and
                  HostPro -- are looking for facilities here that will house 
the networking
                  equipment of the Internet economy. 

                       It is a big business that could have an effect on 
everything from your
                  monthly electric bill to the ease with which you access 
your favorite Web sites.

                       Data centers, also known as co-location facilities and 
server farms, are
                  sprouting at such a furious pace in Tukwila and the Kent 
Valley that some
                  have expressed concern over whether Seattle City Light and 
Puget Sound
                  Energy can handle the power necessary to run these 24-hour, 
high-security
                  facilities. 

                       "We are talking to about half a dozen customers that 
are requesting 445
                  megawatts of power in a little area near Southcenter Mall," 
said Karl
                  Karzmar, manager of revenue requirements for Puget Sound 
Energy. "That is
                  the equivalent of six oil refineries." 

                       A relatively new phenomenon in the utility business, 
the rise of the Internet
                  data center has some utility veterans scratching their 
heads. 

                       Puget Sound Energy last week asked the Washington 
Utilities and
                  Transportation Commission to accept a tariff on the new 
data centers. The
                  tariff is designed to protect the company's existing 
residential and business
                  customers from footing the bill for the new base stations 
necessary to support
                  the projects. Those base stations could cost as much as $20 
million each,
                  Karzmar said. 

                       Not to be left behind, Seattle City Light plans to 
bring up the data center
                  issue on Thursday at the Seattle City Council meeting. 

                       For the utilities that provide power to homes, 
businesses and schools in the
                  region, this is a new and complex issue. 

                       On one hand, the data centers -- with their amazing 
appetite for power --
                  represent potentially lucrative business customers. The 
facilities run 24 hours a
                  day, seven days a week, and therefore could become a 
constant revenue
                  stream. On the other hand, they require so much energy that 
they could
                  potentially flood the utilities with exorbitant capital 
expenditures. 

                       Who will pay for those expenditures and what it will 
mean for power rates
                  in the area is still open to debate. 

                       "These facilities are what we call extremely dense 
loads," said Bob Royer,
                  director of communications and public affairs at Seattle 
City Light. 

                       "The entire University of Washington, from stadium 
lights at the football
                  game to the Medical School, averages 31 megawatts per day. 
We have data
                  center projects in front of us that are asking for 30, 40 
and 50 megawatts." 

                       With more than 1.5 million square feet, the Intergate 
complex in Tukwila is
                  one of the biggest data centers. Sabey Corp. re-purchased 
the 1.35 million
                  square-foot Intergate East facility last September from 
Boeing Space &
                  Defense. In less than 12 months, the developer has leased 
92 percent of the
                  six-building complex to seven different co-location 
companies. 

                       "It is probably the largest data center park in the 
country," boasts Laurent
                  Poole, chief operating officer at Sabey. Exodus, ICG 
Communications,
                  NetStream Communications, Pac West Telecomm and Zama 
Networks all
                  lease space in the office park. 

                       After building Exodus' first Tukwila facility in 1997, 
Sabey has become an
                  expert in the arena and now has facilities either under 
management or
                  development in Los Angeles, Spokane and Denver. Poole 
claims his firm is
                  one of the top four builders of Internet data centers in 
the country. 

                       As more people access the Internet and conduct 
bandwidth-heavy tasks
                  such as listening to online music, Poole said the need for 
co-location space in
                  Seattle continues to escalate. 

                       But it is not just Seattle. The need for data center 
space is growing at a
                  rapid clip at many technology hubs throughout the country, 
causing similar
                  concerns among utilities in places such as Texas and 
California. 

                       Exodus, one of the largest providers of co-location 
space, plans to nearly
                  double the amount of space it has by the end of the year. 
While companies
                  such as Amazon.com run their own server farms, many 
high-tech companies
                  have decided to outsource the operations to companies such 
as Exodus that
                  may be better prepared for dealing with Internet traffic 
management. 

                       "We have 2 million square feet of space under 
construction and we plan to
                  double our size in the next nine months , yet there is more 
demand right now
                  than data center space," said Steve Porter, an account 
executive at Exodus in
                  Seattle. 

                       The booming market for co-location space has left some 
in the local utility
                  industry perplexed. 

                       "It accelerates in a quantum way what you have to do 
to serve the growth,"
                  said Seattle City Light's Royer. "The utility industry is 
almost stunned by this, in
                  a way."

<email>
From: Dr. Liam Patel <lpatel@nanomed-research.org>
To: Jessica Thompson <jthompson@stem-education.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from the conference

Dear Jessica,

Thank you for reaching out! I really enjoyed our conversation at the conference and I'm excited about the possibility of collaborating on educational materials. I believe it's crucial to inspire the next generation of scientists and help them understand the real-world impact of research like ours.

I'd be happy to set up a call to discuss potential project ideas. I have some thoughts on how we could create interactive modules that explore the role of nanotechnology and gene therapy in treating various diseases. I think we could design something that would be both educational and engaging for high school students.

Please let me know your availability in the coming weeks and we can schedule a time to chat further.

Best,
Liam

	From:  Vladimir Gorny                           07/17/2000 07:30 PM
	

To: John J Lavorato/Corp/Enron@Enron, Ted Murphy/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vince J 
Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: VaR Methodology Change

Gentlemen,

Below is a plan of action for moving along with the VaR methodology change 
related to forward-forward volatility:

1. Finalize the methodology proposed (Research/Market Risk)

 - determine the time period used to calculated forward-forward vols vs. 
correlations (20 days vs. 60 days)
 - stabilize the calculation for curves and time periods where the curve does 
not change based on historical prices, implying volatility of 0%

2. Get approval for the methodology change from Rick Buy (see draft of the 
memo attached) - John Lavorato and John Sherriff



3. Develop and implement the new methodology in a stage environment 
(Research/IT)

4. Test the new methodology (Market Risk, Traders)

5. Migrate into production (Research/IT)

Please let me know if this is reasonable and meets everyone's expectations. 
Vlady.

Hi Lucas,

That's fascinating about your research on the impact of climate change on vegetation in Arizona. I'd love to learn more about it. How about we grab coffee next week? I'm free on Wednesday afternoon if that works for you.

I've done some research on the Superstition Mountains and found a few trails that look promising. There's one that leads to a natural spring and another that offers panoramic views of the desert. I'll send you the details, and we can decide which one we want to tackle.

I'm excited for our next adventure! It's always great to explore new places with a good friend.

body:
<email>
From: Jamie Thompson <jthompson@smilesu.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Chen <emily.chen@dentalinnovations.com>
Subject: Seeking advice on a challenging prosthodontics case

Dear Dr. Chen,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Jamie Thompson, and I am a third-year dental student at Smiles University. I recently attended your lecture on advanced prosthodontics techniques and was truly inspired by your expertise and passion for the field.

I am currently working on a complex case during my clinical rotations and would greatly appreciate your advice. The patient is a 45-year-old male with multiple missing teeth and compromised oral health. We are considering various treatment options, including dental implants and fixed bridges, but the case presents several challenges due to the patient's unique anatomy and medical history.

Would it be possible to discuss this case with you further? I would be immensely grateful for any insights or recommendations you could provide. Please let me know if you have any availability in the coming weeks for a brief phone call or virtual meeting.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Best regards,
Jamie Thompson

Dear Dr. Chen,

Our upcoming video call and in-person meetings are marked on my calendar, and I am eagerly counting down the days. Thank you for arranging access to the pieces not currently on display. I am confident that they will provide valuable insights into our research.

I appreciate your offer of assistance with my travel arrangements. I will be sure to reach out if I have any questions or concerns.

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <alex.novak@stargazer.edu>
To: Dr. Lena Patel <lena.patel@bioinfo.org>
Subject: Exciting collaboration opportunity

Dear Lena,

I hope this email finds you well. It was great to catch up with you at the recent astronomy and biology event. I've been thinking about our conversation and have an idea for a project that combines our expertise.

I'd like to propose creating an educational resource that explores the intersection of astronomy and biology, focusing on the conditions necessary for life to exist on other planets and the role of planetary systems in the origin and evolution of life. I believe that our combined knowledge in astronomy and systems biology could lead to a unique and engaging resource for students and the public.

What do you think? Would you be interested in collaborating on this project? If so, I think we could apply for a grant to fund our work. Let me know your thoughts!

Best regards,
Alex

<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@oaktreemiddle.org>
To: Michael Chen <michael.chen@oaktreemiddle.org>
Subject: Great conference and a new resource to share!

Hey Michael,

I hope you made it back home safely after the conference. I wanted to reach out and thank you for carpooling with me and for your collaboration during our workshop. It was great to have your support and insights throughout the event.

I came across a fantastic online resource that I think you'll find useful in your geometry classes. It's called "Geometry Gizmos" (www.geometrygizmos.com) and it offers interactive lessons and activities that help students visualize and understand geometric concepts. I think it could be a great supplement to our existing curriculum.

Let me know if you have any other resources or ideas to share from the conference. I'm always looking for ways to improve my teaching and help our students succeed.

Thanks again for being such a great colleague and friend. I look forward to brainstorming more ways to engage our students in the wonderful world of geometry!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Davis <emily.davis@electrotech.com>
To: John Smith <john.smith@techvoc.edu>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on curriculum update

Hi John,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad you reached out, and I'd be more than happy to help you with your curriculum update.

I recently published a paper on a new type of electronic measurement equipment that I think would be a great addition to your curriculum. It's called the XYZ Analyzer, and it's been a game-changer in our latest projects. The manufacturer also offers educational discounts, so it might be worth looking into.

I've attached a copy of my paper for you to review. Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like me to elaborate on anything.

On a separate note, are you planning on attending the upcoming Advancements in Electronic Measurement and Testing Conference? I'll be there presenting my findings, and it would be great to catch up in person.

Looking forward to your thoughts on the paper and potentially seeing you at the conference.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@renewablesolutions.org>
To: John Smith <john.smith@geothermenergy.com>
Subject: RE: Reconnecting and potential collaboration

John,

Tuesday at 10 AM EST works perfectly for me. I will make sure to have my thoughts organized and ready for our discussion.

I appreciate you taking the time to review the grant application requirements and create an outline. Your attention to detail and organization will undoubtedly help us create a compelling and well-structured proposal.

In preparation for our call, I will gather some additional data on the potential environmental and economic benefits of our approach, as well as some case studies that support our claims. I will send this information to you before our call for your review.

I am thrilled about the opportunity to work with you again and contribute to the global effort to combat climate change through the advancement of renewable energy technologies. Our collaboration has the potential to make a significant impact, and I am eager to see where this project leads us.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@wildlifeprotectors.org>
To: Lucas Oliveira <lucas.oliveira@icmbio.gov.br>
Subject: Exciting conservation opportunity in the Amazon

Dear Lucas,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been a while since we worked together on the Amazon conservation project, and I often think back on our time in the field and the amazing work we accomplished.

I recently came across a new conservation project that I thought you might be interested in. It focuses on protecting the critically endangered black-faced uakari, a primate species found only in the Amazon rainforest. The project aims to establish a protected area specifically for this species and develop community-based conservation initiatives to ensure its long-term survival.

Given your expertise and experience in the region, I would love to explore the possibility of collaborating with you and your agency on this project. I believe that by combining our resources and knowledge, we could make a significant impact on the conservation of this unique species and its habitat.

Please let me know if you're interested in discussing this further. I'd be happy to provide more details and answer any questions you may have.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

<email>
From: Sanjay Patel <spatel@ridgemont.edu>
To: Alex Thompson <athompson@ridgemont.edu>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise on Kashmir and climate change

Hi Alex,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad you reached out about this topic. I completely agree that including the Kashmir conflict in your lesson plan would provide a valuable perspective for your students.

As it happens, I recently published a paper on the intersection of the Kashmir conflict and environmental issues in the region. I'd be more than happy to share my findings with you and discuss how they could be incorporated into your lesson plan.

I'm available to meet for coffee next week, and I'd also be happy to give a guest lecture to your class if you think that would be beneficial for your students. Just let me know what works best for you.

Best regards,
Sanjay

body:
<email>
From: Jan van der Meer <jan.vandermeer@coastalprotection.nl>
To: Emily Sinclair <emily.sinclair@university.edu.au>
Subject: RE: Draft of our paper

Emily,

Thank you for sending the draft! I've had a chance to read through it and I'm impressed by the depth of research and the compelling connections you've made between ancient Aboriginal adaptations and contemporary coastal management challenges. Your writing style is engaging and clear.

I have a few suggestions for further strengthening the paper:

1. In the introduction, could you provide a bit more context on the current state of Aboriginal cultural heritage sites threatened by sea level rise? Some specific examples would help ground the discussion.

2. In the section on natural adaptation processes, I think we could expand on the role of sediment transport in shaping coastlines. I can provide some additional data from our North Sea studies if that would be helpful.

3. I wonder if we could include a brief case study of a modern coastal community that has successfully implemented adaptation strategies informed by ancient knowledge. This could help illustrate the practical applications of our research.

Overall, this is a strong start and I'm excited to continue working with you on this important paper. Let me know your thoughts on my suggestions.

Best regards,
Jan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Nguyen <jordan.nguyen@datavizpros.com>
To: Alex Reyes <alex.reyes@earthsciences.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on visualizations for my research project

Alex,

Thanks for the additional details on your goals for the visualizations. I think we can definitely create something that meets your needs and effectively communicates the complex concepts in your research.

I'll start by reviewing the data you send over and exploring some initial visualization ideas. I'm thinking we could create a series of linked visualizations that allow users to explore the different data sets and how they relate to each other. We could also incorporate interactive elements like sliders or dropdowns that let users control which data is displayed and how it's visualized.

I'll put together some initial sketches and mockups and send them your way for feedback. We can then iterate on the designs until we have a set of visualizations that effectively convey the key findings and concepts in your research.

In terms of timeline, I think we should aim to have the initial designs completed within the next month, with time for revisions and final tweaks after that. That should give us plenty of time to get the visualizations finalized before your paper submission deadline.

Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns. I'm excited to get started on this project and see what we can create together!

Best,
Jordan

Subject: Re: Extra credit



rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's
you bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?
what you charge me play against you?)

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Harris <sharris@jumpingspiders.com>
To: Ethan Johnson <ejohnson@orbweavers.net>
Subject: Interesting article on Salticid mimicry

Hey Ethan,

I hope you're doing well! I came across this fascinating article on chemical mimicry in Salticidae spiders and thought of you. It discusses how some jumping spiders use chemical cues to mimic the pheromones of other species to avoid predation or even lure prey. I know you've done some work on chemical communication in orb weavers, so I thought you might find it intriguing.

Let me know if you have time to chat about it sometime. I'd love to get your thoughts on how this might compare to the chemical strategies used by your study species.

Best,
Sam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Lee <michael.lee@university.edu>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Reagents for the next phase of the project

Hi Sarah,

Thank you for your email. I understand the importance of accurate solutions for the success of our research project. I will start working on the preparations right away and will keep you updated on the progress.

Regarding the timeline, I should be able to have the 0.1 M HCl and 0.05 M NaOH solutions ready by the end of this week. The 1% (w/v) SDS solution will take a bit longer, as I need to ensure the proper dissolution of the SDS. I expect to have it ready by early next week.

Please let me know if this timeline works for you. If you need the solutions earlier, I can try to prioritize the preparations.

Best regards,
Michael

<email>
From: Jake Thompson <jake.thompson@email.com>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@email.com>
Subject: Chemistry homework help

Hey Emily,

I hope you're doing well! I know we have that big chemistry test coming up next week, and I'm really struggling with the material. I was wondering if you might have some time to help me out with the homework assignments we've been given to prepare for the test? I would really appreciate any guidance you could provide.

Let me know if you're available to meet up and study together. I'm free most afternoons after school, or we could even meet at the library over the weekend if that works better for you.

Thanks so much for considering! I know I can count on you.

Best,
Jake

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@languageacademy.com>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@languageacademy.com>
Subject: New intermediate curriculum project

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out because we've been assigned to collaborate on developing a new curriculum for our intermediate level students. I'm excited to work with you and combine our teaching styles to create a comprehensive program.

As you know, I focus on task-based learning and collaborative activities, while you specialize in instructional design for beginner students. I believe that by working together, we can create a balanced curriculum that incorporates both of our strengths.

Let's set up a meeting to discuss our ideas and plan our next steps. Are you available next Tuesday at 2 pm? We can meet in the teacher's lounge.

Looking forward to collaborating with you!

Best regards,
Sarah

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Chen <michael.chen@sfclinic.com>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@seattleschools.org>
Subject: RE: Master's program advice

Emily,

You're very welcome! I'm glad I could provide some helpful information. The University of Washington is an excellent choice, and I'm sure you'll find their program to be both challenging and rewarding.

Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need any advice along the way. I'm always happy to help a fellow educator and advocate for early childhood learning.

Best of luck with your application, and I look forward to hearing about your journey!

Mike
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@berkeley.edu>
To: Ethan Chen <ethan.chen@berkeley.edu>
Subject: Computer vision in spider research

Hi Ethan,

I hope you're doing well! I was thinking about our last conversation and wanted to pick your brain a bit more about using computer vision technology in my spider research. I'm particularly interested in analyzing the visual signals that spiders use to communicate with each other, and I think computer vision could be a powerful tool for quantifying these signals and understanding how they vary across different species and contexts.

Do you have any suggestions for good resources or tutorials to help me get started with computer vision? I'm also curious to hear your thoughts on the best programming languages and software packages to use for this kind of analysis. Any advice you have would be much appreciated!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <ajohnson@pacifictech.edu>
To: Emily Chen <emchen@quantum-measure.com>
Subject: Seeking advice on high-frequency measurement setup

Hi Emily,

It's Alex Johnson from Pacific Tech. We met last month at the Electrical Measurement Innovations Conference in San Francisco. I enjoyed our conversation about advances in high-frequency signal analysis and was impressed by your expertise in the field.

I'm currently working on a project involving high-frequency signal measurement and am running into some challenges with my current setup. I was wondering if you might have some insights or suggestions to help optimize my measurement approach. I'd be happy to provide more details on my specific challenges.

Any advice you could offer would be greatly appreciated. I'm also interested in learning more about your recent work in this area, as I'm looking to update my electrical measurement courses with the latest industry trends.

Thank you in advance for your time and expertise.

Best regards,
Alex

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Keith Holst
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\Discussion threads
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 10/09/2000 
02:00 PM ---------------------------


Richard Burchfield
10/06/2000 06:59 AM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Beth Perlman/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list

Phillip,
 Below is the issues & to do list as we go forward with documenting the 
requirements for consolidated physical/financial positions and transport 
trade capture. What we need to focus on is the first bullet in Allan's list; 
the need for a single set of requirements. Although the meeting with Keith, 
on Wednesday,  was informative the solution of creating a infinitely dynamic 
consolidated position screen, will be extremely difficult and time 
consuming.  Throughout the meeting on Wednesday, Keith alluded to the 
inability to get consensus amongst the traders on the presentation of the 
consolidated position, so the solution was to make it so that a trader can 
arrange the position screen to their liking (much like Excel). What needs to 
happen on Monday from 3 - 5 is a effort to design a desired layout for the 
consolidated position screen, this is critical. This does not exclude 
building a capability to create a more flexible position presentation for the 
future, but in order to create a plan that can be measured we need firm 
requirements. Also, to reiterate that the goals of this project is a project 
plan on consolidate physical/financial positions and transport trade capture. 
The other issues that have been raised will be capture as projects on to 
themselves, and will need to be prioritised as efforts outside of this 
project.

I have been involved in most of the meetings and the discussions have been 
good. I believe there has been good communication between the teams, but now 
we need to have focus on the objectives we set out to solve.

Richard  
---------------------- Forwarded by Richard Burchfield/HOU/ECT on 10/06/2000 
08:34 AM ---------------------------


Allan Severude
10/05/2000 06:03 PM
To: Richard Burchfield/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Peggy Alix/HOU/ECT@ECT, Russ Severson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scott 
Mills/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kenny Ha/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: Consolidated positions: Issues & To Do list


From our initial set of meetings with the traders regarding consolidated 
positions, I think we still have the following issues:
We don't have a single point of contact from the trading group.  We've had 
three meetings which brought out very different issues from different 
traders.  We really need a single point of contact to help drive the trader 
requirements and help come to a consensus regarding the requirements.
We're getting hit with a lot of different requests, many of which appear to 
be outside the scope of position consolidation.

Things left to do:
I think it may be useful to try to formulate a high level project goal to 
make it as clear as possible what we're trying to accomplish with this 
project.  It'll help determine which requests fall under the project scope.
Go through the list of requests to determine which are in scope for this 
project and which fall out of scope.
For those in scope, work to define relative importance (priority) of each and 
work with traders to define the exact requirements of each.
Define the desired lay out of the position manager screen: main view and all 
drill downs.
Use the above to formulate a project plan.

Things requested thus far (no particular order):
Inclusion of Sitara physical deals into the TDS position manager and deal 
ticker.
Customized rows and columns in the position manager (ad hoc rows/columns that 
add up existing position manager rows/columns).
New drill down in the position manager to break out positions by: physical, 
transport, swaps, options, ...
Addition of a curve tab to the position manager to show the real-time values 
of all curves on which the desk has a position.
Ability to split the current position grid to allow daily positions to be 
shown directly above monthly positions.  Each grouped column in the top grid 
would be tied to a grouped column in the bottom grid.
Ability to properly show curve shift for float-for-float deals; determine the 
appropriate positions to show for each:
Gas Daily for monthly index,
Physical gas for Nymex,
Physical gas for Inside Ferc,
Physical gas for Mid market.
Ability for TDS to pull valuation results based on a TDS flag instead of 
using official valuations.
Position and P&L aggregation across all gas desks.
Ability to include the Gas Price book into TDS:
Inclusion of spread options in our systems.  Ability to handle volatility 
skew and correlations.
Ability to revalue all options incrementally throughout the trading day.  
Approximate delta changes between valuations using instantaneous gamma or a 
gamma grid.
Valuation of Gas Daily options.
A new position screen for options (months x strike x delta).  TBD.
Inclusion of positions for exotic options currently managed in spreadsheets.
Ability to isolate the position change due to changed deals in the position 
manager.
Ability to view change deal P&L in the TDS deal ticker.  Show new deal terms, 
prior deal terms, and net P&L affect of the change.
Eliminate change deals with no economic impact from the TDS deal ticker.
Position drill down in the position manager to isolate the impact of 
individual deals on the position total in a grid cell.
Benchmark positions in TDS.
Deployment of TDS in Canada. Currency and volume uom conversions. Implicit 
and explicit position break out issues.

-- Allan.

PS: Colleen is setting up a meeting tomorrow to discuss the direction for 
transport.  Hopefully we'll know much better where that part stands at that 
point.

body:
Message-ID: <25140503.1075855687800.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Thu, 28 Sep 2000 05:56:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: jeffrey.hodge@enron.com
Subject: San Juan Index
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Jeffrey T Hodge
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Liane,

 As we discussed yesterday, I am concerned there has been an attempt to 
manipulate the  El Paso San Juan monthly index.  A single buyer entered the 
marketplace on both September 26 and 27 and paid above market prices 
($4.70-$4.80) for San Juan gas with the intent to distort the index.  At the 
time of these trades, offers for physical gas at significantly (10 to 15 
cents) lower prices were bypassed in order to establish higher trades to 
report into the index calculation.  Additionally, these trades are out of 
line with the associated financial swaps for San Juan.

 We have compiled a list of financial and physical trades executed from 
September 25 to September 27.  These are the complete list of trades from 
Enron Online (EOL), Enron's direct phone conversations, and three brokerage 
firms (Amerex, APB, and Prebon).  Please see the attached spreadsheet for a 
trade by trade list and a summary.  We have also included a summary of gas 
daily prices to illustrate the value of San Juan based on several spread 
relationships.  The two key points from this data are as follows:

 1.  The high physical prices on the 26th & 27th (4.75,4,80) are much greater 
than the high financial trades (4.6375,4.665) on those days. 

 2.  The spread relationship between San Juan and other points (Socal & 
Northwest)  is  consistent between the end of September and 
       October gas daily.  It doesn't make sense to have monthly indeces that 
are dramatically different.


 I understand you review the trades submitted for outliers.  Hopefully, the 
trades submitted will reveal counterparty names and you will be able to 
determine that there was only one buyer in the 4.70's and these trades are 
outliers.  I wanted to give you some additional points of reference to aid in 
establishing a reasonable index.  It is Enron's belief that the trades at 
$4.70 and higher  were above market trades that should be excluded from the 
calculation of index.

 It is our desire to have reliable and accurate indeces against which to 
conduct our physical and financial business.  Please contact me 
anytime I can assist you towards this goal.

Sincerely,

Phillip Allen

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Taylor <olivia.taylor@weatherlab.gov>
To: Dr. Ethan Johnson <ethan.johnson@spaceuni.edu>
Subject: RE: Fascinating presentation at the conference!

Hi Ethan,

Thank you for your enthusiastic response! I'm thrilled that you see potential in this idea and are willing to collaborate with me on it.

I agree that exchanging papers and research would be a great starting point. I'll send you some of my work on radar technology and its applications in meteorology and atmospheric science. I'm particularly interested in how we might adapt these techniques to detect and track NEOs, especially those that could pose a threat to Earth.

I'm also curious to learn more about your research on asteroid impacts and mass extinctions. It's a fascinating topic with significant implications for our understanding of Earth's history and future.

Perhaps we could set up a call next week to discuss our respective research in more detail and brainstorm some ideas for a potential joint project. Let me know your availability, and I'll send over some reading material in the meantime.

Best regards,
Olivia

X-To: Cash, Michelle </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=MCASH>, sheri.a.righi@accenture.com, Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-cc: O'rourke, Tim </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=TOROURKE>, Frolov, Yevgeny </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=YFROLOV>, mery.l.brown@accenture.com, laura.a.de.la.torre@accenture.com, donald.l.barnhart@accenture.com
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Inbox
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Michelle
Here are my very minor comments. However we still need to wait on any additions, based on meeting with SME's today. One concern is the firing of the learner who performs  bad in the final two scenarios. Do we face any copyright issues using the CNN type themes? In addition, I think we need to stay clear of anything that remotely seems like California or anything that really happen with Enron? (i.e. So-cal Waha) In addition, comments on regulatory issues may be a problem (i.e. California Legislature).

Sheri

When you read all the scripts together and due to the similar mechanics being taught it appears very repetitious. Thus I do believe we need to maybe use a "Dateline" type theme for one, and a "60 Minute" type theme for another scenario vice just the CNN type theme. In the last two scenarios can we include a promotion out of the associate program for the stellar performers (i.e. title change to manager)? 


 

Cheers Kirk

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@oakvillehigh.edu>
To: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: National Teaching Conference

Hey Sarah,

I hope you're having a great week! I wanted to touch base with you about the upcoming national teaching conference in New York City. As you know, we've been invited to present our school-wide vocabulary challenge, and I couldn't be more excited!

I was wondering if you had any thoughts on how we should structure our presentation. I think it would be great to start with an overview of our school and the challenges we faced with vocabulary instruction. Then, we could dive into the details of the challenge and share some success stories from our students.

Let me know what you think! I'm open to any suggestions or ideas you might have. We should also start thinking about booking our flights and hotel soon. I'd be happy to take care of that if you'd like.

Looking forward to working with you on this amazing opportunity!

Best,
Emily
