body:
<email>
From: David Lee <david.lee@mathedresearch.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@mathedconsulting.com>
Subject: RE: Exciting new teaching strategy - Mathematical Modelling with Technology

Hi Emily,

Thank you so much for the detailed information and resources on MMT! I really appreciate you taking the time to share your knowledge and experiences.

GeoGebra sounds like a fantastic tool for creating and manipulating mathematical models. I'm excited to explore it further and start incorporating it into my lesson plans. The sample lesson plans you attached are incredibly helpful and will give me a great starting point.

I love the idea of having students work in small groups or pairs to create and analyze their models. It's such a powerful way to foster collaboration, communication, and critical thinking skills. I can see how presenting their findings to the class would be an excellent opportunity for formative assessment and peer feedback.

I will definitely keep you posted on how it goes when I implement MMT in my classroom. I'm planning to start with a simple projectile motion problem and gradually build up to more complex scenarios. I'm curious to see how my students respond to this approach and how it impacts their understanding and problem-solving skills.

Thank you again for sharing this exciting strategy with me. I'm so grateful to have a colleague like you to learn from and collaborate with. Let's definitely keep in touch and continue to share our experiences and ideas.

Best wishes,
David
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Olivia Evans <olivia.evans@techcommprofessor.com>
To: Jamie Lee <jamie.lee@medstudent.com>
Subject: RE: Patient Assessment Advice

Hi Jamie,

It's great to hear from you! I'm happy to help in any way I can. Patient assessment and documentation can be challenging, especially in complex cases. Here are a few resources and strategies that might be helpful:

1. [The SBAR Technique](https://www.ihi.org/resources/Pages/Tools/SBARToolkit.aspx) - This is a standardized approach to communication that can help you organize your thoughts and present information clearly.

2. [The SOAP Note Format](https://www.aafp.org/fpm/2015/0900/p30.html) - This is a common format for documenting patient encounters, which can help you ensure you're capturing all the necessary information.

3. [The PEWS Scale](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5418848/) - This is a tool that can help you assess a patient's condition and identify potential deterioration.

If you'd like, I'd be happy to take a look at your documentation and provide some feedback. Just send it over whenever you're ready.

I hope these resources are helpful, and please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any other questions.

Best of luck with your rotations!

Olivia

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@foodscience.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@educate.com>
Subject: RE: Zoo field trip advice

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! It's a pleasure to meet you, and I'm happy to help with your zoo field trip.

I think focusing on the diets of the animals is a great way to make the trip both educational and engaging for your students. One aspect you could highlight is how the zoo works to replicate the natural diets of the animals as closely as possible to support their health and well-being.

For example, did you know that many zoos have dedicated nutritionists on staff who work to create balanced diets for each species? They take into account factors like the animals' natural habitat, activity levels, and life stage when determining what to feed them.

If you're able to arrange it, a behind-the-scenes tour of the zoo's food preparation facilities could be a fascinating addition to your trip. Seeing the care and attention that goes into preparing the animals' meals might help your students appreciate the importance of a balanced diet for all living things.

I recently attended a conference where I heard a presentation on the role of nutrition in animal behavior and welfare. The researchers found that animals who are fed a diet that closely mimics what they would eat in the wild exhibit more natural behaviors and have better overall health outcomes. I can send you the conference proceedings if you're interested in learning more.

Please let me know if you have any other questions or if there's anything else I can do to help make your field trip a success. I'm happy to brainstorm further ideas or provide additional resources.

Best regards,
Michael Thompson

body:
Message-ID: <5352030.1075849631744.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Sun, 13 May 2001 07:52:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: david.forster@enron.com
Subject: Re:
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: David Forster
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Oct2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

David:
Do you have a simulation set up that will allow me to simulate trades by 
pushing a buy or sell button and will move the two way so i can try 
simulating actual market cicumstances?


From: David Forster/ENRON@enronXgate on 05/08/2001 09:55 AM
To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Savita Puthigai/ENRON@enronXgate 
Subject: 


John,

You might recall we spoke a few weeks ago about a system with more 
intelligence for out-of-hours trading than just leaving the products on Last 
Trade is Mid.

Attached is a suggestion for how such a system might work. It builds on 
Offset to Last Trade functionality.

The simplified description is: It tracks two variables: Intensity(Speed) and 
Bias (Buy or Sell emphasis).  As Intensity increases, the Spread increases. 
As Bias increases, the Offset increases.

I'll call later to see what you think of the idea.

Dave

 

Program Criteria

The formula which defines the trading decision-making program will need to 
work with several criteria/inputs/definitions. These might be:

Intensity (Speed) - The average time between transaction attempts, regardless 
of whether they are buys or sells. Measured as a moving average over the last 
[Intensity Factor] transactions by comparing the timestamp of the transaction 
Tibco messages for the Product.
Obviously, the lower the Intensity calculation, the higher the transaction 
flow. Therefore a high Intensity number indicates low transaction flow.
Intensity Factor - The number of transactions to be included in the moving 
average Intensity calculation. A possible value for this might be [4].
#Buys - The number of Buys which have occurred.
#Sells - The number of Sells which have occured.
Transaction Count - Could be either #Buys or #Sells (whichever last occured).}
Buy Offset - The Offset value which will be applied if a Buy occurs.
Sell Offset - The Offset value which will be applied if a Sell occurs.
Offset Reversion Ratio (ORR)- The amount by which the Buy Offset should be 
reduced if a Sell occurs (or amount Sell Offset should be reduced if a Buy 
occurs). A possible value for this might be [0.3]. If the application of the 
ORR results in a reduction of less than 1, then the reduction shall be 1.
Transaction Reversion Ratio (TRR)- The amount by which #Buys should be 
reduced if a Sell occurs (or amount #Sells should be reduced if a Buy 
occurs). A possible value for this might be [0.3]. If the application of the 
TRR results in a reduction of less than 1, then the reduction shall be equal 
to 1.
Spread Minimum - The minimum Spread value allowed. A possible value for this 
might be [0.04]
Spread Maximum - The maximum Spread value allowed. A possible value for this 
might be [0.50]
Offset Minimum - The minimum Offset allowed for both Buys and Sells. A 
possible value for this might be [0].
Offset Maximum -The maximum offset allowed for both Buys and Sells. A 
possible value for this might be [0.50]
Initial Offset - The Buy and Sell Offset used when the program is started
Initial Spread - The Spread used when the program is started
Spread-Offset Minimum - The minimum amount by which Spread must exceed 
Offset. Prevents a possible arbitrage opportunity for the customer. A 
possible value for this might be [0.01]
Dead Interval - The period of time which must pass before the program will 
recalculate the above Criteria, if no transactions have taken place during 
the Dead Interval. A possible value for this might be [240] seconds.

Program Outputs

The program should output the following variables as a result of combining 
the above Criteria in a user-defined Formula:

Spread (integer) - as per current Stack Manager
Offset (integer) - as per current Stack Manager
Suspension (boolean) - Whether or not the Product should be suspended. 
Normally "False"


Program Interface and Operation Principles

The user should be provided with a GUI which will allow them to define a 
relationship among the above Criteria, which will produce and apply the 
Outputs to a particular Product. This relationship would be defined with 
Intensity Formulas and Transaction Formulas. 

Every time a Transaction occurs, or a Dead Interval passes, the Criteria will 
be recalculated and the user-defined formulas will be reviewed by the 
program. If a Dead Interval passes without any transactions taking place, 
then Intensity = Intensity +240 and #Buys=#Buys-TRR and #Sells=#Sells-TRR and 
Buy Offset = Buy Offset- ORR and Sell Offset = Sell Offset - ORR. 

If the user-defined Formulas (see following) indicate that a change in spread 
should occur, then if the Offset is zero (in the case of a trade occurring) 
or if no trade has occured (during the passing of a Dead Interval), the 
system shall perform a Last Trade is Mid calculation around the last 
transaction, adjusting the buy and sell prices according to the new Spread 
value.

Any adjustment to the Spread shall respect the Spread-Offset Minimum. If a 
reduction in the Spread should violate the Spread-Offset Minimum, then the 
Buy Offset (or Sell Offset, or both as appropriate) shall be reduced 
accordingly. Similarly, if the Offset is increased by a Transaction Formula 
to a level greater than the Spread, the Spread shall be increased to maintain 
the Spread-Offset Minimum.

GUI/Formulas Example:

Constants
Intensity Factor: [4]
Dead Interval: [240]
Offset Reversion Ratio (ORR): [0.3]
Transaction Reversion Ratio (TRR): [0.3]
Spread Minimum [0.04]
Spread Maximum [0.50]
Offset Minimum [0]
Offset Maximum [0.49]
Spread-Offset Minimum [0.01]

         INPUTS           OUTPUTS
Intensity Formula
Formula # Intensity   Spread Offset  Suspension
S1  >220   -0.01 n/a F
S2  <30   +0.01 n/a F
S3  <10   +0.02 n/a F

Transaction Formula
Formula # # Transactions  Spread Offset  Suspension
V1  <4   n/a -0.01 F
V2  >3   n/a +0.01 F
V3  >5   +0.01 +0.02 F
V4  >10   +0.02 +0.04 F
V5  >15   +0.04 +0.15 F
V6  >20   n/a n/a T
    
Note that #Transactions would be #Buys or #Sells, as appropriate. Note also 
that #Buys and #Sells are not intended to be an absolute count, but rather 
are a moving measure of the number of buys or sells which have recently 
occured.

In this example, all Constants and Formulae are editable by the user through 
the GUI.


Simulation

Obviously, if we want to proceed, we will want to conduct several simulations 
to prove concepts and evaluate responsiveness. However, to give some idea of 
how the above might work when a market starts to run in a particular 
direction, please see the attached:




Additional Features

System Notifications

There should be two kinds of notifications for the Robotrader, which will be 
similar to Stack Manager Garbage Checks: Warning and Failure levels for both 
Offset and Price. The warning levels will trigger a pager message. The 
Failure levels will trigger a pager message and the product will be 
automatically suspended. The Price checks will be against prices input by the 
trader (not relative price movements, but actual price). There should be both 
maximum and minimum price checks (e.g. gas is trading at $5.50. The 
notification levels could be $8 at the top end and $2 at the bottom end). 
Offset checks will only be against a maximum value.




Dave

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Chen <emilychen@university.edu>
To: Jordan Smith <jordansmith@email.com>
Subject: RE: Help with physical science homework?

Hi Jordan,

I'm glad to hear the visual aids were helpful! The periodic table is organized based on the number of protons (also known as the atomic number) in each element. The elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic number, with the elements with similar properties being placed in the same column (called a group).

Think of it like this: if our cells were arranged based on the number of organelles they contained, and cells with similar functions were grouped together, it would be a bit like the periodic table. The elements in each group have similar properties because they have the same number of electrons in their outer shell, which determines how they interact with other elements.

I hope this helps clarify things! Remember, understanding the periodic table is a key part of understanding chemistry. Keep up the good work and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any other questions.

Best,
Dr. Chen

<email>
From: Dr. Orion Galax <oriongalax@ari-newland.edu>
To: Dr. Stella Cosmos <stellacosmos@ari-newland.edu>
Subject: RE: NNSF Early Career Award

Stella,

Thank you for bringing this up. I can understand your concerns about the potential awkwardness within the group. However, I've already made significant progress on my own proposal, which focuses on a different aspect of early galaxy formation than our collaborative work.

I think it would be best if we each submitted our own proposals, highlighting our individual contributions and ideas. I'm confident that the review panel will be able to recognize the merit of both proposals, even if they are in the same general field.

I hope this doesn't negatively impact our collaboration on the JWST data analysis. I still believe we can produce an excellent paper together.

Best,
Orion

Jeff:
Sorry for my cryptic answer in regards to the LNG deal on Friday; I was a bit 
confused by the question. 
In terms of the gas pricing, this is a deal that should be done.  Market 
conditions are very conducive to hedging a fair amount of the gas.  
Obviously, a deal this size would require Enron to wear a considerable amount 
of the risk in the short term, but the risk-reward of the position looks very 
favorable.
I am certainly willing to sign off on this deal around the $3.00 level.
John
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thornburg <emily.thornburg@fossilfinders.com>
To: Jordan Ellis <jordan.ellis@riverdalehigh.edu>
Subject: Seeking some advice from a seasoned educator

Hey Jordan,

I hope you're having a great week so far. I wanted to reach out because I've been giving some serious thought to a career change. As much as I love my work in paleontology, I can't help but feel a pull towards teaching, especially after our last book club discussion about the importance of science education.

I know you've been teaching English at Riverdale High for a while now, and I was wondering if you'd be open to chatting about your experience and any advice you might have for someone considering a similar path. I'm particularly interested in teaching science at the high school level, and of course, I'd love to hear more about your perspective on working with teenagers.

Let me know if you have any free time in the coming weeks to grab a coffee or, even better, go on that hike we've been talking about for months!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <alex@historybuffblog.com>
To: Samir Patel <samir.patel@inclusiveschools.org>
Subject: Usenet and Accessible History

Hey Samir,

I hope you're doing well! I recently published a blog post about the history of Usenet and thought you might find it interesting. I included some information about modern Usenet service providers and how they've made this classic technology more accessible to a wider audience.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on the article and if you think Usenet could be a useful tool for your students. I'm also curious to learn more about the types of interactive content you're looking to incorporate into your social skills curriculum.

Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to brainstorm some ideas together!

Best,
Alex

body:
Message-ID: <28900518.1075855716032.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Mon, 5 Mar 2001 07:21:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
Subject: 
Cc: llewter@austin.rr.com, jacquestc@aol.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: llewter@austin.rr.com, jacquestc@aol.com
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
X-cc: llewter@austin.rr.com, jacquestc@aol.com
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\Sent
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

George,

I am back in the office and ready to focus on the project.  I still have the 
concerns that I had last week.  Specifically that the costs of our project 
are too high.  I have gathered more information that support my concerns.  
Based on my research, I believe the project should cost around $10.5 
million.  The components are as follows:

 Unit Cost, Site work, &
 builders profit($52/sf)   $7.6 million

 Land      1.15

 Interim Financing     .85

 Common Areas       .80

 Total     $10.4

Since Reagan's last 12 units are selling for around $190,000, I am unable to 
get comfortable building a larger project at over $95,000/unit in costs.  

Also, the comps used in the appraisal from Austin appear to be class A 
properties.  It seems unlikely that student housing in San Marcos can produce 
the same rent or sales price.  There should adjustments for location and the 
seasonal nature of student rental property.  I recognize that Sagewood is 
currently performing at occupancy and $/foot rental rates that are closer to 
the appraisal and your pro formas, however, we do not believe that the market 
will sustain these levels on a permanent basis.  Supply will inevitablely 
increase to drive this market more in balance.

After the real estate expert from Houston reviewed the proforma and cost 
estimates, his comments were that the appraisal is overly optimistic.  He 
feels that the permanent financing would potentially be around $9.8 million.  
We would not even be able to cover the interim financing.

Keith and I have reviewed the project thoroughly and are in agreement that we 
cannot proceed with total cost estimates significantly above $10.5 million.   
We would like to have a conference call tomorrow to discuss alternatives.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Nathan Pierce <nathan.pierce@yale.edu>
To: Emily Sinclair <emily.sinclair@ucsd.edu>
Subject: RE: Theropod dentition project update

Emily,

This is incredible! Your findings align perfectly with some of the morphological data I've been analyzing. It seems that this species had a more complex jaw musculature than other theropods, which could have allowed it to generate the necessary force to process tough plant material.

I agree that we need to move quickly to get our paper published. I'll start working on the manuscript and will send you a draft by the end of the week. In the meantime, could you work on refining the dental tissue analysis and preparing some high-quality images for the figures?

I also think we should reach out to Dr. Olivia Chen at the Royal Tyrrell Museum. She has some expertise in this area and might be able to provide some valuable insights. Plus, having her as a co-author could give our paper more credibility and increase our chances of getting published in a top-tier journal.

Let's touch base on Friday to discuss our progress and strategize our next steps. I'm happy to book a video call if you prefer.

Best,
Nathan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@envirohealth.org>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@countyhealth.org>
Subject: RE: Finalizing project materials

Hi Emily,

Thanks for your email. I've reviewed the materials and I think they look great! I agree with the edits you made and don't have any further suggestions. I think we should prepare a joint presentation for the conference. It will be more impactful to show the collaboration between our organizations and highlight the combined efforts that went into this project.

I was also thinking, once the project is launched and we've presented at the conference, it might be a good idea to write a paper on our work for a peer-reviewed journal. What do you think?

Let me know if you need anything else from me as we wrap up the project.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Lila Gupta <lila.gupta@linguistics.edu>
To: Alex Green <alex.green@ecoadvocate.org>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference and potential collaboration

Dear Alex,

I couldn't agree more about the importance of combining our expertise to create a meaningful impact. I'm confident that our collaboration will yield valuable insights that can contribute to the ongoing efforts in promoting sustainability.

I would be happy to provide you with some data and examples from my previous research on the language used in eco-friendly marketing campaigns. I think it would be a great starting point for our collaboration.

I will definitely attend your presentation on "The Role of Packaging in Reducing Plastic Pollution." It sounds like a fascinating topic, and I'm eager to learn more about your work.

In the meantime, I will start drafting an outline for our potential research paper or blog post. I will share it with you for your feedback and suggestions.

I look forward to our collaboration and to meeting you at the conference.

Best regards,
Dr. Lila Gupta

The table of the on-going FERC issues and proceedings will be updated for use on today's conference call, and distributed by Bernadette Hawkins.  It is available to all team members on the O drive. Please feel free to revise/add to/ update this table as appropriate.

FERC Order of May 25 clarifying the April 26 Order re market monitoring and price mitigation.

ISO de-rating of ATC complaint- status (item 20)

EPSA intervention and protest re CAISO compliance filing and proposed tariff amendment  (item 32)

EPSA rehearing request of FERC market monitoring and mitigation order in EL00-95-12 (item 9d)


Miscellaneous information items:

CA legislators' suit against FERC.

 RTO conference is to be planned and held by FERC in the near future.


Please feel free to communicate to the group any additional agenda items you may have.

Message-ID: <18295626.1075849625294.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Thu, 7 Dec 2000 04:03:00 -0800 (PST)
From: colleen.koenig@enron.com
To: jennifer.medcalf@enron.com
Subject: Universal/Vivendi
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Colleen Koenig
X-To: Jennifer Medcalf
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Nov2001\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: ARNOLD-J
X-FileName: jarnold.nsf

Jennifer,
Due to the Vivendi merger, the Universal deal has taken on a whole new 
scope.  On a lead from Jeff Y., I contacted Kim Monk, Dr. Corp. Alliances, 
who reports to Nebergall.  Kim was interested in discussing this further and 
working on best leveraging BU strategies.  We are to catch up when she 
returns to Houston, but this is what we discussed in our quick phone call 
today:

Vivendi 
Enron delivered an MOU to Vivendi (Kim may forward)
Currently 5-6 initiatives including:
Vivendi overall - bandwidth, co-location, dark fiber, PAN European network, 
cable 
Havas (Viviendi subsidiary) - discussions with Havas CEO for distance 
learning, bandwidth, ASP and streaming initiatives
Initiatives in other subsidiaries including:  Canal Plus, Digitel

Blockbuster
Due to restructuring of Vivendi/Universal, EBS to work on Blockbuster's 
year-end (Phase I) initiatives first and then (Phase II & III) 3Q next year
Cox speaking with Universal in LA as content and distribution partner 
(although this is Blockbuster's obligation, Enron is also working as a third 
party to secure)

Enron-Vivendi Relationship
Vivendi sees Enron as both a competitor and partner depending upon the segment

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Thompson <jenna.thompson@cityenviro.gov>
To: Liam Patel <liam.patel@greenearth.org>
Subject: RE: Catching up over coffee?

That coffee shop sounds perfect! I've heard great things about their eco-friendly practices. Wednesday afternoon works well for me, too. Let's say 2 PM?

I'm really excited to discuss our respective projects and see if there might be some synergy between them. With your grassroots approach and my policy-focused work, I think we could make a real impact in our city.

See you on Wednesday!

Jenna
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Martinez <jmartinez@envirogeo.org>
To: Alex Rivera <arivera@envirogeo.org>
Subject: RE: Mapping project update

Hi Alex,

A hiking trip sounds like a great idea! I'm always eager to explore the natural world and see the geological features we're studying up close. It would be a nice break from the office and could definitely help inform our work.

As for the project, I think reaching out to urban planners and emergency services is a great idea. I can start putting together a list of potential contacts and draft some emails to see if they'd be interested in collaborating with us.

I'm also happy to set up a meeting for early next week to discuss our next steps and start putting together some preliminary maps. I'll send out a calendar invite and book a conference room.

I'm really excited about the direction this project is going and can't wait to see what we can accomplish together!

Best,
Jordan

Let's have Matt start on the following:

daily activity by backing out receipts, using ISO load actuals and backing 
out real time imports to get in state gen numbers for gas consumption, and 
then using temps to estimate core gas load.  Back testing once he gets 
database created should help him forecast core demand.

Update Socal and PG&E forecast sheets.  Also, break out new gen by EPNG and 
TW pipelines.

Mike

body:
<email>
From: Thomas Green <thomasgreen@gardeningexpert.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@ridgemontschools.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking gardening advice for student project

Dear Emily,

It's great to hear from you, and I'm more than happy to help with your students' project. I think it's fantastic that they're combining coding and computational thinking with sustainable gardening. It's a wonderful opportunity for them to apply their skills to a real-world problem.

I'd be delighted to share my knowledge of gardening in our specific climate zone and provide guidance on their garden layouts and planting schedules. I believe this project has the potential to not only educate your students but also promote eco-friendly practices in our community.

If you're interested, I could come to your classroom to give a brief presentation on the basics of gardening in Hardiness Zone 8 and answer any questions your students might have. I could also provide resources and support throughout the project.

Additionally, I've been thinking about ways to expand this initiative. What if we collaborate on a grant proposal to secure funding for a school-community garden project? The project could aim to educate students and community members about sustainable gardening practices while providing fresh produce to local food banks and shelters. I'd be happy to discuss this idea further with you.

Please let me know when would be a good time to discuss this project in more detail. I'm excited to work with you and your students on this wonderful initiative.

Best regards,
Thomas Green
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Elin Nilsson <elin.nilsson@uppsala.edu>
To: James Thompson <james.thompson@oxford.edu>
Subject: Implementing new language assessment framework

Dear James,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been a while since we last touched base, but I was hoping to pick your brain about something. I'm considering implementing a new language assessment framework in my Swedish language and culture course, and I remember you mentioning that you had successfully implemented a similar framework in your English courses. I was wondering if you could share some insights on the implementation process and any challenges you encountered along the way.

I'd also like to discuss the upcoming guest lecture you'll be giving at our university. I think it would be great if you could touch on the topic of language assessment frameworks during your talk, as it's a subject of growing interest among our faculty.

Lastly, I wanted to bring up the research project we're working on together. I've made some progress on my end and would love to hear about any developments from your side. We should start thinking about how we want to present our findings at the next conference.

I hope you're doing well and that we can catch up soon. Let me know when would be a good time for a call or video chat.

Best regards,
Elin
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Akira Nakamura <akira.nakamura@toshokan.jp>
To: Yumi Sato <yumi.sato@nihonbunka.org>
Subject: Connecting after the Japanese Art Conference

Dear Yumi,

It was a pleasure meeting you at the International Conference on Japanese Art and Culture last week. I enjoyed our conversation about the cultural significance of motifs in Japanese art, and I believe your expertise in traditional Japanese textiles could be invaluable for a project I'm currently working on.

I'm in the process of curating an exhibition focusing on the Meiji period and the cultural significance of motifs in Japanese art. I would love to learn more about your work with traditional textiles from that era and explore the possibility of collaborating on this project.

Would you be available for a call next week to discuss this further? I look forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,
Akira Nakamura
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emma Nakamura <emma.nakamura@spacetech.edu>
To: Liam Johnson <liam.johnson@spacepolicy.org>
Subject: RE: Following up on our discussion at ISSS

Hi Liam,

Next Tuesday at 10am your time (6pm my time) works perfectly for our call. I'll send you a Zoom link tomorrow to confirm.

I've reviewed the updated outline and I think it's shaping up very well. I've added some additional sections on the current state of space debris, the limitations of existing mitigation guidelines, and the potential role of commercial space companies in debris removal efforts. Please let me know what you think.

I've also done some preliminary research on existing international agreements and legal frameworks related to space activities. It looks like there may be some opportunities to build on and expand the Outer Space Treaty and the Liability Convention in our proposal.

I'm attaching a few key documents that I think will be useful for our research. Let me know if you need anything else.

I'm really excited about the direction this project is heading and I'm looking forward to our call next week.

Best,
Emma
label: research

rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's
you bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?
what you charge me play against you?)

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Johnson <mjohnson@earlyamerica.edu>
To: Sarah Thompson <sthompson@riverdalems.org>
Subject: RE: Collaborative project idea - History and Art

Dear Sarah,

I'm equally excited about the project and the events we've chosen. The shared folder with resources is a great idea, and I've added a few more documents that I think the students will find useful.

I'm looking forward to seeing the students' initial ideas for their digital art pieces. Please keep me informed of their progress, and let me know if there's anything I can do to support their research and creativity.

I'm confident that this project will not only engage the students in learning about American history but also showcase their artistic talents and digital skills. It's a pleasure collaborating with you, and I'm eager to see the final results.

Best regards,
Dr. Michael Johnson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@email.com>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@email.com>
Subject: Cassini's Grand Finale

Hey Jordan,

I hope you've been following the news about Cassini's final moments. It's incredible to think that after nearly two decades in space, the mission is coming to an end. I can't help but feel a bit emotional about it.

Have you seen the latest images it sent back? They're simply breathtaking. I'm curious to know your thoughts on the scientific discoveries made by Cassini during its time at Saturn. Do you think we'll see another mission like this in our lifetime?

Looking forward to your thoughts!

Best,
Alex
label: research

"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:35:20 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net>, "Diana Zuniga" 
<invest@bga.com> 
Subject: Sagewood Town Homes


I was aware that Regan Lehman, the lot developer for the entire 70 lot
duplex project, was selling his units in the $180's,  He does have a much
lower basis in the lots than anyone else, but the prime differences are due
to a) he is selling them during construction and b) they are smaller units.
We do not know the exact size of each of his units, but we believe one of
the duplexes is a 1164/1302 sq ft. plan.  This would produce an average sq
footage of 1233, which would be $73.80 psf at $182,000.  (I thought his
sales price was $187,000.)  At this price psf our 1,376 sf unit would sell
for $203,108.
What is more important, in my view, is a) the rental rate and b) the
rent-ability.  You have all of our current rental and cost data for your own
evaluation.  As for rent-ability, I believe that we have shown that the
3-bedroom, 3.5 bath is strongly preferred in this market.    In fact, if we
were able to purchase additional lots from Regan we would build 4 bedroom
units along with the 3-bedroom plan.
Phillip, I will call you today to go over this more thoroughly.
Sincerely,
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC

body:
<email>
From: Elsa Svensson <elsa.svensson@phoenixu.edu>
To: Lucas Harrison <lucas.harrison@asu.edu>
Subject: Photos from our Sedona adventure

Hey Lucas,

I hope you're doing well! I just wanted to share some of the photos I took during our amazing hiking trip to Sedona last weekend. Here's a link to the album: https://www.photostock.com/sedona-adventure

I can't believe how stunning the red rocks and desert landscapes are. It's so different from the forests and lakes in Sweden, but equally breathtaking. I'm thinking of using some of these photos in my upcoming Swedish culture course to show the diversity of natural environments in different parts of the world.

How's your research on desert ecosystems going? I remember you mentioned some interesting findings about the impact of climate change on the vegetation in Sedona. I'd love to learn more about it.

Let's plan our next hiking adventure soon! Maybe we can explore the Superstition Mountains next time.

Take care,
Elsa
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Avraham Cohen <avraham.cohen@jts.edu>
To: Rabbi Sarah Silverstein <rabbisilverstein@jccchicago.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking guidance on a historical Jewish ritual

Rabbi Silverstein,

Thank you so much for your prompt and thoughtful response. I am truly grateful for your willingness to guide me in my research and for sharing your expertise on this topic.

I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to discuss this further with you over a video call. I am available next week on Wednesday afternoon (Jerusalem time) or Thursday morning. Please let me know if either of these times works for you, and I will send you a calendar invite with the video call link.

Thank you again for your support and encouragement. It means a great deal to me, especially as I navigate this new chapter in my studies. I will keep you updated on my progress, and I look forward to catching up with you soon.

Best regards,
Avraham

body:
Message-ID: <32239363.1075857595807.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 24 Oct 2000 10:21:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: russell.dyk@enron.com
Subject: Re: CSFB Columbia/Appalachia Hedging Deal
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Russell Dyk
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Certainly encourage CSFP to transact all volumes with us.  If they shop the 
deal, everyone will front-run the volumes and they won't get a good price on 
the deal.  
Financial deals settle 5 days after the index has been published.  Physical 
deals settle much later.   My understanding is this is a financial deal.


   
	
	
	From:  Russell Dyk @ ENRON                           10/23/2000 12:43 PM
	

To: Paul Radous/Corp/Enron@ENRON
cc: Per Sekse/NY/ECT@ECT, Caroline Abramo/Corp/Enron@Enron, John 
Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sara Shackleton/HOU/ECT@ECT, William S 
Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: CSFB Columbia/Appalachia Hedging Deal

The New York office has been speaking to Credit Suisse First Boston for 
roughly 6 months about a producer hedging deal that is part of a strucutured 
deal they're putting together. It now looks as if it will get done in the 
next 3 weeks-1 month so we want to get all the necessary credit issues taken 
care of. 

In brief, the deal is a fixed price one, basis TCO (67% of the volumes) and 
CNG (33%) with a fixed price Nymex component as well. It will settle against 
the Inside FERC indices for both locations. The term of the deal is from 
December, 2000 to December 2012. The volumes decline throughout the term from 
roughly 22,000 mmBtu/d to 13,000 mmBtu/d. The average daily nominal volume is 
17,000 mmBtu/d. As I understand it, these volumes are about 65% of the 
producers' total volumes. I've attached a spreadsheet to this message with 
more details. 

There are a couple of contractual and credit issues that CSFB wants to 
clarify. 

First, there is a question of the monthly cash settlement. CSFB would like 
payment to take place on the fifteenth of the month following the date both 
the floating and fixed prices are known. As I understand it,  for the 
December settlement, which would be known in early December, cash payment 
would take place on February 15, 2000. 

Second, there is a question of a parent guarantee from Enron Corp. 
Apparently, there is an existing credit arrangement in place between ENA and 
Credit Suisse First Boston International - the same counterparty that we 
would be dealing with here - that has a $15 million guarantee from Enron 
Corp. CSFB would like to increase this guarantee to at least $100 million. 
(CSFB already has an unlimited guarantee from Enron Corp. for a deal they've 
done with us in Europe so in their opinion it should not be an issue). 

 There is another minor issue involving centralizing credit discussions with 
the aim of securing a similar credit arrangement for CSFB's dealings with 
EnronCredit.com - which may be an issue for London rather than Houston. 
However, CSFB agreed that this was a secondary issue in relation to this 
transaction.

CSFB would like to do the entire deal through us, rather than having to split 
it among one or more counterparties. Per, Caroline Abramo, and I are meeting 
with Paul tomorrow to discuss various credit issues, including this one. 
Ideally, CSFB would like to have a good idea of where they stand by the end 
of this week. 

Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Regards,
Russ

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Bryan, Gary  
Sent:	Wednesday, July 11, 2001 9:19 AM
To:	Neal, Scott; Shively, Hunter S.; Martin, Thomas A.; Tycholiz, Barry
Cc:	Vickers, Frank W.; Luce, Laura; Grass, John; McMichael Jr., Ed; Boyt, Eric; Kelly, Katherine L.; Roberts, Linda; Brawner, Sandra F.; Redmond, Brian; Miller, Kevin; Lagrasta, Fred; Whitt, Mark; Zivley, Jill T.; Martinez, Jennifer
Subject:	

Hunter, Scott, Tom & Barry,
We have been meeting with the Ocean Energy, Inc. ("OEI") management team over the last several months discussing the asset management of OEI's gas, as well as  Enron's ability to provide additional Producer Services (including the operations of certain pipeline facilities, outsourcing services and Enron systems outsourcing). We are moving forward with the project and have divided it into two phases. Phase 1: will be the purchase of OEI's natural gas in North America, both operated and non-operated properties, and Phase 2: will evaluate the opportunity to provide OEI additional services. 
For Phase 1, OEI is soliciting bids for their North American supply for the period beginning on October 1, 2000 through September 30, 2002. Bids on this gas are due August 15, 2001, with expected daily production for the bid cycle to exceed 450,000 MCF/d of natural gas. The gas is currently under contract to Duke Energy  until September 30, 2001. 
Phase 2 will follow a parallel path. We are continuing to have meetings with OEI to discuss our Producer One product as well as evaluating OEI's Havre Pipeline system in Montana for a pipeline outsourcing opportunity. 
OEI is one of the largest independent oil and gas exploration and production companies in the United States with proved reserves of 460 million barrels of oil equivalent. North American operations are focused in the shelf and deepwater areas of the Gulf of Mexico, South and East Texas, and the Mid-continent, Permian Basin and Rocky Mountain regions. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, OEI has interests in more than 300 Gulf of Mexico blocks, including 83 in the deepwater. They plan to spend $300 to $350 million in 2001 to grow its reserve base through delineation of recent discoveries and additional deepwater exploration.  Ocean's deepwater expenditures will include continued development of its commercial discoveries, including the Nansen and Boomvang projects in the East Breaks area and the Magnolia discovery on Garden Banks Block 783. They will continue to be aggressive in the drilling of its inventory of core shelf holdings. 
The North America Onshore division of Ocean Energy is organized into five operating regions: the Rocky Mountains, Permian Basin, Arklatex, Anadarko and East Texas. In 2001, Ocean Energy plans to grow production and reserves from its long-life assets while increasing its number of high-potential exploration prospects in core areas, including the Bossier Play in East Texas and the Permian Basin. 
This opportunity will provide gas across North America for Enron with the majority of the gas supply located in the GOM. Once we complete our due diligence on the properties, we will be working with structuring, the wellhead desk and each of the respective desks to request  bids for each of the gas packages.
The attached file will give you an idea of the location and volume of the gas available in Phase 1. Also included on the spreadsheet is a pricing reference point for each package. If you have any questions regarding this opportunity, please contact me at X-36784. 
  << File: OEI.xls >>

Hi Robert,

I hope you're doing well. I've been looking over our outline for the conference paper, and I think we have a solid foundation to build upon. I was wondering if you had a chance to delve into the symbolism of the character Benjy in "The Sound and the Fury"? I believe his narrative provides a unique perspective on the themes we're discussing.

Let me know your thoughts, and we can schedule a meeting to discuss our progress further.

Best,
Emily

I hope this email finds you well. It was great meeting you at the photography exhibition last week and discussing the potential collaboration between our fields. I've been thinking about how we can combine chemistry concepts with your stunning wildlife photography to create engaging educational materials for students.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this idea and explore how we can work together to make it a reality. Perhaps we could set up a call or meeting to discuss our ideas further?

Looking forward to hearing from you!

Emily

X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Jan2002_1\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen (Non-Privileged).pst


As some of you might already know, I resigned today.  I feel fortunate and blessed to have had this experience here at Enron.  Not only have I learned a tremendous amount, but I also have met some very talented and unique people.  I am not 100% sure what I will do at this point, but I will probably be heading up to NYC in January.  I feel sad to end this chapter, yet excited as I begin a new one in my life.  

As always, it has been a pleasure working with you!  Keep in touch.  I will be interested to see what happens.

Carole C. Frank
Enron Net Works

713.345.3960 work
713.446.9307 cell
713.467.3860 home
carole_frank@excite.com

label: Other

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily@historyandcultureblog.com>
To: Dr. Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@birdwatchingexpert.com>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on bird watching history series

Michael,

Thank you so much for your email and for your willingness to collaborate on this series! I'm thrilled to have your expertise and insights.

I love your idea of focusing on the cultural significance of certain bird species in North American history. That's a fascinating angle that I hadn't considered before. I think it could add a lot of depth and context to the series.

And I would be honored if you would write a guest post for my blog! I think it's a great idea to introduce the topic and get readers excited about the series. I'm open to any ideas you have for the post, and I'm happy to provide any support or resources you need.

I'm also wondering if you might be interested in collaborating on a series of educational videos about bird watching and its historical context. I think it could be a great way to reach a wider audience and engage people in a different way. Let me know if that's something you'd be interested in exploring!

Thank you again for your willingness to collaborate. I'm really looking forward to working with you and learning from your expertise.

Best,
Emily

body:
Message-ID: <14057356.1075858635068.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 24 Oct 2001 11:34:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: wise.counsel@lpl.com
To: k..allen@enron.com
Subject: Huntley update
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: "Robert W. Huntley, CFP" <wise.counsel@lpl.com>@ENRON
X-To: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Greetings Phillip,

I received your phone message.  Thanks for the update.  I have been talking
with contractors and Spring Valley.  At this point we are trying to
determine whether the addition over the garage would be workable.  Heather
probably told you that I am meeting with a contractor on 11/7 at your home
to get a firm bid on the project.  I spoke today with the Spring Valley
building consultant and faxed him some detail.  There are a couple of
possible problems he is looking at and we'll possibly need to get a variance
from the decision makers when the time comes.

In the meantime, I printed out the earnest money contract and sellers
disclosure forms from the website you found.  We are waiting on the final
word from Spring Valley to move ahead.  I'll let you know when we have some
new information.

Thanks,

Bob Huntley

----- Original Message -----
From: <Phillip.K.Allen@enron.com>
To: <wise.counsel@lpl.com>
Sent: Thursday, October 18, 2001 9:18 AM
Subject: RE: Huntley followup question


Bob,

I do have a survey of the sight at home.  I will get you a copy tomorrow.

Regarding contracts, the Texas Real Estate Commission website has copies of
the contracts we need.  The website is below.  I believe the relevant
contracts are form #20-4(One to Four Family Residential Contract) and form
#OP-H (Seller's Disclosure of Property Condition).  A coworker is about to
close on a home without using a broker and these are the forms he used.

I

Phillip

http://www.trec.state.tx.us/formsrulespubs/forms/forms-contracts.asp





      -----Original Message-----
     From:   "Robert W. Huntley, CFP" <wise.counsel@lpl.com>@ENRON
     Sent:   Wednesday, October 17, 2001 2:26 PM
     To:     pallen@enron.com
     Subject:  Huntley followup question


     Phillip,

     I forgot to ask if you have a recent survey of the  lot from when you
     closed?  I would like to see if we'll have any easement  problems
     above or around the garage area to consider.

     If you find something and it's faxable, please send  it to my fax at
     281-858-1127.  Feel free to call first if you have any  comments.

     Thanks,

     Bob Huntley
     281-858-0000

body:
Message-ID: <31697227.1075855690545.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Thu, 22 Jun 2000 00:26:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: scott.carter@chase.com
Subject: Re: The New Power Company
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: "Carter, Scott" <Scott.Carter@chase.com> @ ENRON
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Scott,

 I emailed your question to a friend that works for the new company.  I think 
I know the answer to your questions but I want to get the exact details from 
him.  Basically, they will offer energy  online at a fixed price or some 
price that undercuts the current provider.  Then once their sales are large 
enough they will go to the wholesale market to hedge and lock in a profit.  
The risk is that they have built in enough margin to give them room to manage 
the price risk.  This is my best guess.  I will get back to you with more.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Wallace <jwallace@theropodresearch.org>
To: Laura Stevens <lstevens@dinodiscoveries.edu>
Subject: New theropod fossils - your input needed!

Hi Laura,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out to you because I recently acquired some fascinating new fossil samples that I think could shed light on the evolution of the Allosauroidea group of theropods. The fossils appear to show some unique anatomical features that I haven't seen before, and I'd love to get your thoughts on their potential implications.

Would you be available for a video call next week to discuss these fossils in more detail? I'm hoping to get your expert opinion on how they might fit into our current understanding of allosauroid evolution and what further analyses we might want to pursue.

Please let me know if you have any availability next week, and we can set something up. I look forward to hearing your thoughts on these exciting new finds!

Best regards,
Jordan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Jennings <olivia.jennings@montanamuseum.org>
To: Liam Nakamura <liam.nakamura@cretaeceousdinofossils.com>
Subject: RE: Exciting new theropod discovery!

Liam,

I'm so glad you're on board with this project! I'll send over the preliminary data and photographs of the fossil specimens later today. I've also been giving some thought to the phylogenetic implications, and I think you'll find the results surprising.

Based on the unique features of this fossil, I believe it may challenge some of our current assumptions about theropod diversification during the Cretaceous. It could potentially represent a new clade or subfamily, which would have significant implications for our understanding of theropod evolution.

I'm curious to hear your initial thoughts once you've had a chance to review the data. We can then schedule a call to discuss our strategy for the paper and how we want to present our findings.

Thanks again for your collaboration on this project. I have a feeling it's going to be a game-changer!

Best,
Olivia
label: research

<email>
From: Dr. Stella Cosmos <stellacosmos@ari-newland.edu>
To: Dr. Orion Galax <oriongalax@ari-newland.edu>
Subject: New JWST data release

Hi Orion,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to let you know that the latest data release from the James Webb Space Telescope is now available. There are some exciting observations of high-redshift galaxies that I think could be relevant to our research on early galaxy formation.

I was thinking of setting up a meeting with the group next week to discuss how we can use this data in our projects. Would you be interested in collaborating on a paper analyzing some of these new observations?

Best regards,
Stella

body:
<email>
From: Robert Thompson <rthompson@university.edu>
To: Emily Nguyen <enguyen@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on Spider Communication Project

Emily,

Thank you for reaching out and for the project overview. I am intrigued by your research and can see how my knowledge of linguistics could potentially apply to understanding non-verbal communication in spiders. However, I must apologize for the late response, as I have been dealing with some personal matters and an impending deadline for my book.

I would love to discuss this further and explore how we can collaborate, but I am not sure when I will be able to devote the necessary time and attention to your project. I don't want to commit to something I can't fully invest in at the moment.

Could we schedule a meeting to discuss this in more detail? I am happy to provide feedback on your project overview and share some initial thoughts, but I want to be upfront about my current constraints.

Best,
Robert

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@ridgemont-high.edu>
To: David Thompson <david.thompson@ridgemont-high.edu>
Subject: National Education Conference Proposal

Hi David,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to reach out about an exciting opportunity that I think you'd be perfect for. I've been invited to present a workshop at the National Education Conference this summer on the topic of "Adapting Algebra Instruction for Diverse Learners." I immediately thought of you and your incredible work in the math department.

I was hoping we could collaborate on this presentation, given our shared passion for helping students with diverse learning needs excel in math. I think our combined expertise could make for a really impactful workshop.

What do you think? Are you interested in joining me for this presentation? I'd love to brainstorm some ideas together and start putting together a proposal.

Let me know your thoughts!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@nyu.edu>
To: Oliver Thompson <othompson@ucl.ac.uk>
Subject: RE: Research retreat plans

Hi Oliver,

Fantastic news about your flight bookings! It's going to be such a productive week. I'm glad you like the plan for the retreat. I'll send you the Airbnb details once I have them.

Thanks for the update on your progress with the British slang data. I'm eager to see what you've found! I've been working on a similar compilation for American slang terms, focusing on regional variations and how they've evolved over time. I'll send you my draft by the end of the week as well.

In the meantime, I've been thinking about how we might structure our paper. I think it would be interesting to start with an overview of the history of slang in both American and British English, then dive into our specific findings and analysis. What do you think? 

I'll also create a shared Google Doc for us to collaborate on the paper during the retreat. That way, we can both access it easily and make edits in real-time.

Looking forward to catching up and working together in person!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@mathematics.edu>
To: Samantha Green <samantha.green@envirosustain.org>
Subject: RE: Invitation to Speak at Environmental Sustainability Seminar

Dear Samantha,

Thank you for your kind words and the invitation to speak at the "Mathematical Models for Environmental Sustainability" seminar. I am honored to be considered and would be delighted to participate.

Your organization's mission resonates with me, and I believe that applying mathematical models to environmental issues is crucial for finding sustainable solutions. I would be happy to present my research and engage in discussions with the attendees.

The proposed date of October 15th works well with my schedule. Please let me know the specific time slot you have in mind for my presentation and any other details regarding the event, such as the expected audience size and any technical requirements for the presentation.

I appreciate the opportunity to contribute to this important seminar and look forward to working with you and the Environmental Sustainability Alliance.

Best regards,
Dr. Michael Johnson
Department of Mathematics

Subject: RE: New podcast episode idea - need your expertise!

Richard,

Thank you so much for your suggestions and ideas! The topics and activities you mentioned are perfect and I will definitely incorporate them into the podcast episode. 

I would be absolutely thrilled to be a guest speaker at your professional development workshop! It's such an honor to be asked and I'm excited to have the opportunity to share my passion for astronomy with other educators. Please let me know the details and how I can prepare.

I've been thinking, since we both have a common interest in science education, would you be interested in collaborating on creating a set of astronomy lesson plans and activities that can be used in primary school classrooms? We could share these resources with other educators through a website or blog. What do you think?

I look forward to discussing this further and working together to make astronomy more accessible and engaging for students.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@pineridgehigh.edu>
To: Alex Chen <alex.chen@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Interesting article on the history of genetics

Hi Alex,

That's fantastic! I'm so excited to hear about your research project. It sounds like a valuable contribution to the field, and I'm eager to learn more about the lesser-known female geneticists you've been studying.

How about we meet on Wednesday, May 18th at 3 pm? There's a great coffee shop near the conference center called "The Brewed Awakening." I'll be wearing a blue blouse with a silver pendant necklace, so I should be easy to spot.

I've been considering writing a book about the history of genetics and was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on the project. Your research would be a perfect fit, and I think it could be a great opportunity for both of us.

Let me know if the meeting time and location work for you, and if you're interested in discussing the book collaboration further.

Best,
Emily
label: research

Hi Sarah,

Thanks for the email! I'm definitely excited about the conference and think the session on drama techniques sounds perfect for our project. I'll make sure to mark it down on our schedule.

I took a quick look at the ReadWriteThink website and it seems like a goldmine of resources! I appreciate you sharing it with me. I'll dive deeper into it this weekend and let you know if I find any particularly useful lesson plans or activities.

On a related note, I was thinking about our curriculum development project and how we can incorporate more culturally responsive teaching practices to better support our English language learners. I'd love to brainstorm some ideas with you sometime next week, perhaps over a virtual coffee chat?

Looking forward to the conference and continuing our collaboration!

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Maria Rodriguez <maria.rodriguez@university.edu>
To: James Thompson <james.thompson@institute.org>
Subject: Conference proposal submission

Dear James,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been thinking about our discussion on the intersection of the heliocentric theory and the Scientific Revolution, and I believe we have a compelling topic for our joint presentation at the upcoming conference.

As we've previously discussed, I'll focus on the development of the heliocentric theory and its conflicts with the Catholic Church, while you'll explore the role of Renaissance scientists in the Scientific Revolution. Together, we can create a cohesive narrative that highlights the significance of these events in shaping the relationship between science and religion.

Please let me know your thoughts on this proposal and if you have any suggestions for improving it. I'd be happy to collaborate on the abstract and outline for our presentation.

Looking forward to your response and working together on this exciting project!

Best regards,
Maria

body:
<email>
From: Akiko Tanaka <atanaka@kyotomuseum.jp>
To: Hiroshi Nakamura <hnakamura@tokyouniversity.edu>
Subject: Meiji Art Exhibition Catalog Essay

Dear Professor Nakamura,

I hope this email finds you well. As you know, we've been collaborating on the research project exploring the influence of early Japanese history on Meiji-era art for the past year. I'm now in the process of organizing an exhibition featuring Meiji-era art at the Kyoto Museum, and I was wondering if you would be interested in contributing an essay to the exhibition catalog.

Your expertise in early Japanese history would be invaluable in providing context for the artworks and helping our visitors better understand the cultural significance of the Meiji period. The essay would need to be around 2,000 words and submitted by the end of next month.

Please let me know if you would be willing to contribute and if you have any questions about the project.

Best regards,
Akiko Tanaka
Curator, Kyoto Museum

From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: frank.hayden@enron.com
Subject: Re: Stress Testing
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Frank Hayden
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Frank:
One of the most likely scenarios for a VAR blowout would be a severe cold 
front hitting the country in the middle to latter part of the winter.  In 
such a circumstance, cash may separate from prompt futures similar to how 
Midwest power traded $5000+ on specific days last year while prompt futures 
were $200.  The correlation between prompt and cash is normally very strong, 
and is indicated by the small VAR associated with a spread position 
currently.  But in the winter that may change.
Another thing to keep in mind while developing this scenario is the 
assymetric risk presented by having a spread position on.  Assuming we enter 
the winter with normal to below normal storage levels, a position of long 
cash, short prompt futures has a long tail only on the positive p&l side.   
While such a trade in an efficient market has expected payout of 0, the 
payout probabilities may look like the following:

20%  $ -.05
40%     $ -.02
20% $ 0
19% $ .03
1% $ 1
   


   
	Enron North America Corp.
	
	From:  Frank Hayden @ ENRON                           07/20/2000 02:12 PM
	

To: Fletcher J Sturm/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Stress Testing

RAC is working on developing some "canned" stress tests regarding VaR.  For 
example, one test could be called "hurricane", were the prompt month is 
"stressed" on both price and vols, holding all other inputs constant. 

Anyway, I would like to know of any likely/realistic stress scenarios you can 
think of....

Let me know,
Frank
label: research

13:18 GMT 7 December 2000 DJ Cal-ISO Pays $10M To Avoid Rolling Blackouts
Wed -Sources
(This article was originally published Wednesday)
LOS ANGELES (Dow Jones)--The California Independent System Operator paid
about $10 million Wednesday for 1,000 megawatts of power from Powerex and
still faced a massive deficit that threatened electricity reliability in the
state, high-ranking market sources familiar with the ISO's operation told
Dow Jones Newswires.
But the ISO fell short of ordering rolling blackouts Wednesday for the third
consecutive day.
The ISO wouldn't comment on the transactions, saying it is sensitive market
information. But sources said Powerex, a subsidiary of British Columbia
Hydro & Power Authority (X.BCH), is the only energy company in the Northwest
region with an abundant supply of electricity to spare and the ISO paid
about $900 a megawatt-hour from the early afternoon through the evening.
But that still wasn't enough juice.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power sold the ISO 1,200 megawatts
of power later in the day at the wholesale electricity price cap rate of
$250/MWh. The LADWP, which is not governed by the ISO, needs 3,800 megawatts
of power to serve its customers. It is free sell power instate above the
$250/MWh price cap.
The LADWP has been very vocal about the amount of power it has to spare. The
municipal utility has also reaped huge profits by selling its excess power
into the grid when supply is tight and prices are high. However, the LADWP
is named as a defendant in a civil lawsuit alleging price gouging. The suit
claims the LADWP sells some of its power it gets from the federal Bonneville
Power Administration, which sells hydropower at cheap rates, back into the
market at prices 10 times higher.
Powerex officials wouldn't comment on the ISO power sale, saying all
transactions are proprietary. But the company also sold the ISO 1,000
megawatts Tuesday - minutes before the ISO was to declare rolling blackouts
- for $1,100 a megawatt-hour, market sources said.
The ISO, whose main job is to keep electricity flowing throughout the state
no matter what the cost, started the day with a stage-two power emergency,
which means its operating reserves fell to less than 5%. The ISO is having
to compete with investor-owned utilities in the Northwest that are willing
to pay higher prices for power in a region where there are no price caps.
The ISO warned federal regulators, generators and utilities Wednesday during
a conference call that it would call a stage-three power emergency
Wednesday, but wouldn't order rolling blackouts. A stage three is declared
when the ISO's operating reserves fall to less than 1.5% and power is
interrupted on a statewide basis to keep the grid from collapsing.
But ISO spokesman Patrick Dorinson said it would call a stage three only as
a means of attracting additional electricity resources.
"In order to line up (more power) we have to be in a dire situation,"
Dorinson said.
Edison International unit (EIX) Southern California Edison, Sempra Energy
unit (SRE) San Diego Gas & Electric, PG&E Corp. (PCG) unit Pacific Gas &
Electric and several municipal utilities in the state will share the cost of
the high-priced power.
SoCal Edison and PG&E are facing a debt of more than $6 billion due to high
wholesale electricity costs. The utilities debt this week could grow by
nearly $1 billion, analysts said. It's still unclear whether retail
customers will be forced to pay for the debt through higher electricity
rates or if companies will absorb the costs.
-By Jason Leopold, Dow Jones Newswires; 323-658-3874;
jason.leopold@dowjones.com
(END) Dow Jones Newswires 07-12-00
1318GMT Copyright (c) 2000, Dow Jones & Company Inc
13:17 GMT 7 December 2000 DJ Calif ISO, PUC Inspect Off-line Duke South Bay
Pwr Plant
(This article was originally published Wednesday)
LOS ANGELES (Dow Jones)--Representatives of the California Independent
System Operator and Public Utilities Commission inspected Duke Energy
Corp.'s (DUK) off-line 700-MW South Bay Power Plant in Chula Vista, Calif.,
Wednesday morning, a Duke spokesman said.
The ISO and PUC have been inspecting all off-line power plants in the state
since Tuesday evening to verify that those plants are shut down for the
reasons generators say they are, ISO spokesman Pat Dorinson said.
About 11,000 MW of power has been off the state's power grid since Monday,
7,000 MW of which is off-line for unplanned maintenance, according to the
ISO.
The ISO manages grid reliability.
As previously reported, the ISO told utilities and the Federal Energy
Regulatory Commission Wednesday that it would call a stage three power alert
at 5 PM PST (0100 GMT Thursday), meaning power reserves in the state would
dip below 1.5% and rolling blackouts could be implemented to avoid grid
collapse. However, the ISO said the action wouldn't result in rolling
blackouts.
The ISO and PUC also inspected Tuesday plants owned by Dynegy Inc (DYN),
Reliant Energy Inc. (REI) and Southern Energy Inc (SOE).
Duke's 1,500-MW Moss Landing plant was also inspected by PUC representatives
in June, when some units were off-line for repairs, the Duke spokesman said.


   -By Jessica Berthold, Dow Jones Newswires; 323-658-3872;
jessica.berthold@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires 07-12-00
1317GMT Copyright (c) 2000, Dow Jones & Company Inc
13:17 GMT 7 December 2000 =DJ Calif Regulators Visit AES,Dynegy Off-Line
Power Plants
(This article was originally published Wednesday)

   By Jessica Berthold
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES

LOS ANGELES (Dow Jones)--AES Corp. (AES) and Dynegy Inc. (DYN) said
Wednesday that representatives of California power officials had stopped by
some of their power plants to verify that they were off line for legitimate
reasons.
The California Independent System Operator, which manages the state's power
grid and one of its wholesale power markets, and the California Public
Utilities Commission began on-site inspections Tuesday night of all power
plants in the state reporting that unplanned outages have forced shutdowns,
ISO spokesman Pat Dorinson said.
The state has had 11,000 MW off the grid since Monday, 7,000 MW for
unplanned maintenance. The ISO Wednesday called a Stage 2 power emergency
for the third consecutive day, meaning power reserves were below 5% and
customers who agreed to cut power in exchange for reduced rates may be
called on to do so.
As reported earlier, Reliant Energy (REI) and Southern Energy Inc. (SOE)
said they had been visited by representatives of the ISO and PUC Tuesday
evening.
Representatives of the two organizations also visited plants owned by AES
and Dynegy Tuesday evening.
AES told the visitors they couldn't perform an unannounced full inspection
of the company's 450-megawatt Huntington Beach power station until Wednesday
morning, when the plant's full staff would be present, AES spokesman Aaron
Thomas said.
Thomas, as well as an ISO spokesman, didn't know whether the representatives
returned Wednesday for a full inspection.

   AES Units Down Due To Expired Emissions Credits

The Huntington Beach facility and units at two other AES facilities have
used up their nitrogen oxide, or NOx, emission credits. They were taken down
two weeks ago in response to a request by the South Coast Air Quality
Management District to stay off line until emissions controls are deployed,
Thomas said.
AES has about 2,000 MW, or half its maximum output, off line. The entire
Huntington plant is off line, as is 1,500 MW worth of units at its Alamitos
and Redondo Beach plants.
The ISO has asked AES to return its off line plants to operations, but AES
has refused because it is concerned the air quality district will fine the
company $20 million for polluting.
"We'd be happy to put our units back, provided we don't get sued for it,"
Thomas said. "It's not clear to us that the ISO trumps the air quality
district's" authority.
As reported, a spokesman for the air quality district said Tuesday that AES
could have elected to buy more emission credits so that it could run its off
line plants in case of power emergencies, but choose not to do so.

   Dynegy's El Segundo Plant Also Visited By PUC

Dynegy Inc. (DYN) said the PUC visited its 1,200 MW El Segundo plant Tuesday
evening, where two of the four units, about 600 MW worth, were off line
Wednesday.
"I guess our position is, 'Gee, we're sorry you don't believe us, but if you
need to come and take a look for yourself, that's fine,'" said Dynegy
spokesman Lynn Lednicky.
Lednicky said one of the two units was off line for planned maintenance and
the other for unplanned maintenance on boiler feedwater pumps, which could
pose a safety hazard if not repaired.
"We've been doing all we can to get back in service," Lednicky said. "We
even paid to have some specialized equipment expedited."
Lednicky added that the PUC seemed satisfied with Dynegy's explanation of
why its units were off line.
-By Jessica Berthold, Dow Jones Newswires; 323-658-3872,
jessica.berthold@dowjones.com
(END) Dow Jones Newswires 07-12-00

<email>
From: Alexei Ivanov <alexei.ivanov@spbhistory.ru>
To: Maria Petrova <maria.petrova@spbhistory.ru>
Subject: RE: Alaska Purchase Exhibit - Educational Component

Maria,

I'm glad you're on board with this project! It's a great opportunity to showcase our museum's exhibits and educational programs. I think combining our expertise in history and science will create a truly engaging experience for visitors of all ages.

I'm available to meet next Tuesday, April 18th, at 10 am. We could meet in the museum's conference room to discuss our ideas and plan our next steps. I'll bring some initial concepts for the interactive component, and we can brainstorm together.

Also, don't forget about the special event we're planning to showcase our new exhibits and programs. We should start thinking about how to promote it and ensure its success. Perhaps we could create some engaging content that combines history and science to appeal to both adults and children.

Looking forward to our collaboration!

Best,
Alexei

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Finn Collins <fcollins@oakwood.edu>
To: Reverend Dr. Eleanor Thompson <ethompson@oakwood.edu>
Subject: RE: Interdisciplinary Lecture Series - Your Participation

Dear Dr. Thompson,

I am happy to provide you with the high-resolution images for the promotional materials. I will go through my collection and select some of my best marine ecosystem photographs that I believe will complement your lecture series theme. I will send them to you by the end of next month, as requested.

Regarding the virtual component of the series, I would be more than happy to assist you with the technical setup and troubleshooting. As someone who frequently uses technology in my research and teaching, I understand the importance of a smooth and glitch-free presentation. I am glad to share my knowledge and experience with you.

Please let me know a few dates and times that work well for you in the coming weeks, and we can schedule a meeting to go over the technical requirements and ensure that everything is in place for the virtual component of the series. I am more than willing to help in any way I can.

Thank you once again for the opportunity to be a part of this fascinating lecture series. I am looking forward to our collaboration and to learning more about the religious and historical aspects of early America from your perspective.

Best regards,
Dr. Finn Collins
Department of Marine Biology
Oakwood University

<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@cybersafekids.org>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@digitalliteracyforall.org>
Subject: National Digital Literacy Conference

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I have some exciting news to share. We've been invited to speak at the National Digital Literacy Conference in Washington D.C. next month! This is an incredible opportunity for us to showcase our work and connect with other experts in the field.

I think we should focus our presentation on the successful implementation of our program in the schools we've worked with so far, and our plans for expanding to other cities and states. We could also highlight the importance of collaboration between cybersecurity experts and educators in creating effective digital literacy initiatives.

Let me know your thoughts on this, and if you have any ideas for our presentation. We should also start looking into travel arrangements and lodging.

Looking forward to your feedback!

Best,
Emily

st=20
two years.  These informal, interactive forums
will be 90 minutes in length and held several times per year.

indicated a strong desire to express opinions, share
ideas, and ask questions to the Office of the Chairman. Although not=20
mandatory to attend, the forums are designed to address those issues.  They=

executive team, describe plans and initiatives, do =01&reality checks=018, =

 =01&same=20
page=018 about where Enron is going---and why.

u=20
will attend only one session.)

______ Friday, March 30, 2001 from 2:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. in EB50M

presentations.=20

questions and express your own opinions.

.

limited to: the direction of Enron, business   goals/results, M&A activitie=
s,=20
projects/initiatives, culture, leadership, management practices, diversity,=

o=20

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Evelyn Stewart <estewart@paleouniverse.com>
To: Dr. Marcus Patel <mpatel@healthbridge.org>
Subject: Upcoming conference and joint presentation

Dear Dr. Patel,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Dr. Evelyn Stewart, and I'm a paleontologist specializing in dinosaur biology and theropod evolution. I'll be one of your co-presenters at the upcoming science conference in Cusco, Peru.

The conference organizers have paired us together to give a joint presentation on the similarities between the extinction of dinosaurs and the current global fight against viral infections. I'm really excited about this interdisciplinary approach and the potential for sparking interesting discussions.

As the conference is being held at a high altitude, the organizers have recommended that we arrive a few days early to acclimate. I was wondering if you'd be interested in sharing a room to save on expenses and to get to know each other better before our presentation. Let me know what you think.

Looking forward to meeting you in person and working together on our presentation.

Best regards,
Evelyn
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Jennings <emily.jennings@university.edu>
To: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@techsolutions.com>
Subject: Digital archiving advice needed!

Hey Alex,

I hope you're doing well! I was thrilled to hear about your recent promotion at Tech Solutions. Congratulations!

I'm reaching out because I could use your expert advice. As you might remember, I'm working on my dissertation about William Faulkner's lesser-known works, and I've been granted the opportunity to travel to his hometown in Mississippi to conduct research. I'll have access to some incredible primary sources, but I'm worried about properly archiving and backing up the materials I'll be working with.

I know you're the go-to person for all things digital preservation, so I was hoping you could point me in the right direction. What software or tools do you recommend for archiving documents and notes while I'm on the road? I want to make sure I don't lose any valuable information during my trip.

Thanks in advance for any advice you can offer! I promise to return the favor with some Faulknerian insights once I'm back.

Best,
Emily
