body:
Message-ID: <31307130.1075857655193.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Sat, 3 Mar 2001 12:10:00 -0800 (PST)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: slafontaine@globalp.com
Subject: Re: friday
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: slafontaine@globalp.com @ ENRON
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Jun2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

so according to your analysis, had we been at $2.5 gas and we were not 
bordering on a recession, we would have had the highest AGA number of 
recorded history for this week, last week, or next week by 15 bcf?  seems a 
little far fetched to me.  Our analysis is saying: gas at 2.50 we would have 
had 4.5 bcf a day more demand.  that includes commercial residential 
industrial switching processing...    
as far as 2 bcf/d  power gen demand- that counts the fact that last year was 
extremely mild versus expectation of normal summer this year, west will be 
running every gas unit virtually all hours as power demand is growing maybe 
5% still and hydro way down.  every molecule that can will flow west from 
waha this summer versus little last year.  east power prices really havent 
reached point of priceing out demand and heat rates healthy enough to where 
gas can go up without raising power prices to cut demand.  some concern of 
more efficient replacing less but hard to quantify.  we're trying to build 
the stack now to estimate.  
frac margins now positive for all but most inefficient processors.  will 
continue coming back.  a little concerned about 2 oil prices.  bordering 
right there now for places like florida and actually saw fl demand rise 
100,000 last week as gas got to parity.  
let me look into inj capability.  definitely bigger when field is empty from 
engineering standpoint so any problems really wont arise until fall when gen 
demand low and inj capacity lower...my initial thoughts.
bo seems as neutral as everyone else in the market right now.  really 
inactive.
to clarify, not raging bull.  i like everybody want to see what the inj 
numbers in april look like.  nobody putting a position on until that starts 
to clarify.  just think that hedging demand is making market a little short 
right now making next move up more likely.  would be scale up seller though
not really sure why cash trades at 10-15 back.  doesnt make any sense.  
however as more fields start turning around throughout month, the stg arb to 
great in my opinion to keep spread there.  must close one way or the other.  
notice that spread tightened to 6-8 towards end of trading friday?
in general think that gas is reaching the elasticity stage right here.  50 
cents lower and no switching, no processing, and gain back some demand.  
market needs to see some big stg numbers first.   
i think the best play right now is to start buying longer  term put spreads.  
Jan 4/3.5 look great to me.  if we get back to 2.8 and don't match last 
year's early weather, bombs away.   




slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/03/2001 07:03:14 AM
To: jarnold@enron.com
cc:  
Subject: friday



this doesnt allow for new generation demand-which is unclear cuz it requires
power px, also doesnt accrue for more eficient gen replacing inneficient,
weather of course. but 2bcf/d sounds hi-esp shudnt happen until loads peak in
july-shud be marginal in apr-jun
   if you notice im not alot diff than your guys-4.6 demand destruction is
implied but im including a factor for R/C energy conservation-ie poor guys 
like
me turning lites off and thermostat down-its making a difference- that will be
less factor in shoulder demand months-reason why i think y on y s&d swing will
be closer to 5 bcf apr-jun, if px doesnt fall and electricity spikes i think
we'll see conservation return cuz i wont turn on my air cnditioner
     now rember the 7.4 is vs gas at sub 6.00 ie february which is approx 
where
we are today
    all that being said yes some demand has come back-but it is as i consider
extraordinary demand destruction-those things which never really have occured
before-like the level for fuel switching in jan and fractionation margins(ie
liquids) which were all non existent a year ago save for residual fuel. some
ammonia/fert prod  has come back as well. but when you get down to 2 -3 bcf/d
industrial in the more i think of it-may not be destruction anymore as mucha
unction of an economic slowdown.
    anyway -i think i only know two guys that are bearish-me and one of your 
big
fund customers(ospraie). we'll see.  is collins bullish as well-he seems 
quieter
in the mkt lately.
  heres another one-what you guys think the industry capacity for injection is
on a weekly basis? we sud test it...in other words if the max is say 105 then
means the basis will uttery colpase on daily cuz mkt will keep futs too hi and
be unable to inject all the gas available? thots
    also, you any idea why cash at the hub alway seems to hold a 10-15 ct
discount lately daily vs next month futs? why not 5 or 30 cts? i dont get it 
bt
wondering if its transportation or storage cost related.
  have a good weekdn my man

 if all these are done add them to the summary sheet in usable formula

show you what i mean

check this out-using the regression you did for nov-march 99/00 came to a draw

on y supply demand swing. ie 1.5 bcf prod

Jennifer,

I spoke w/Jenny Rub about almost every BMC/EBS issue, except for this one.  I 
did not know about the issue which Bruce Smith has sent (blue text, below) to 
Jenny and Bob McAuliffe.  When I spoke w/Jenny, I was unaware of BMC's 
retraction.  It is new news to me, and at the very least, doesn't seem very 
"customer-focused" on BMC's part.  I certainly agree w/Bruce's statement to 
the effect that BMC needs to meet w/Philippe about their pricing!

JKY

----- Forwarded by Jeff Youngflesh/NA/Enron on 12/14/2000 04:39 PM -----

	Jenny Rub
	12/14/2000 04:21 PM
		 
		 To: Jeff Youngflesh/NA/Enron@ENRON
		 cc: 
		 Subject: FW: BMC DEAL --- UPDATE


----- Forwarded by Jenny Rub/Corp/Enron on 12/14/2000 04:21 PM -----

	Bruce Smith/ENRON@enronXgate
	12/14/2000 02:50 PM
		 
		 To: Bob McAuliffe/ENRON@enronXgate, Jenny Rub/Corp/Enron@Enron
		 cc: 
		 Subject: FW: BMC DEAL --- UPDATE

Not that it matters but wanted you to know:
BMC rep left message recanting the fact that we would still have the 45 % 
discount if SAP modules were purchased at some other time.  He states now 
that if not purchased now the discount would only be 10-20 % range at a later 
date.


Bruce

 -----Original Message-----
From:  Smith, Bruce  
Sent: Wednesday, December 13, 2000 8:35 PM
To: McAuliffe, Bob; Rub, Jenny
Cc: Robinson, Larry
Subject: BMC DEAL 
Importance: High

Jenny/Bob

Per the BMC deal, here is where we are with Batch Processing:

TidalSoft, Sysadmiral
Approx.  90 k  ( current quote covers us and GPG and does not include SAP ) 
We have added a couple of pieces to this and it could bring the cost to 125 k 
worst case.  This quote covers consulting and maintenance.  They are trying 
very hard to get a deal done this year  and we could probably get our 
additional components at the current quote price if we signed.  

BMC, Control -M
Approx. 325 k   This is after we remove the SAP modules and components from 
the quote. Quote that was sent over from Jeff Youngflesh (Enron GSS) was for 
a total of 628 k

Hardware for either product is approx. 300 k. 

We have conferred with the SAP team and they are not desperate for us to take 
over their scheduling but think it is a good idea to include them in our long 
term strategy. They actually do not recommend either of these product's SAP 
modules and mentioned a third party product (Autosys) that has connectors 
into BMC.  We are not sure at this point about a connector into TidalSoft 
(Larry if you have info on this please comment).

Larry's and his team have eval'd both products and although they are leaning 
towards Sysadmiral they are satisfied that both products are acceptable.  You 
guys make the call as to whether the additional 200 k is worth the weight it 
will lend to the EBS/BMC deal.  FYI - BMC rep said that we still get 45% 
discount if we cut the SAP modules.  BMC needs to sit down with PB and learn 
how over priced their products are !

Let me know what you think.  If we go TidalSoft I need to push this through 
or be advised to let it go till the New Year.

Thanks
Bruce


*****
Also in Quote sent over from Youngflesh :
BMC, Control SA
1.3 M     NOT EVALUATED AT THIS TIME  - Is a candidate for future 
consideration for the Security Admin space but not enough info to speculate 
as to whether to try and leverage current deal with EBS.   I guess they put 
this quote together from info they received from Henry Moreno

Traveling to have a business meeting takes the fun out of the trip.  Especially if you have to prepare a presentation.  I would suggest holding the business plan meetings here then take a trip without any formal business meetings.  I would even try and get some honest opinions on whether a trip is even desired or necessary.

As far as the business meetings, I think it would be more productive to try and stimulate discussions across the different groups about what is working and what is not.  Too often the presenter speaks and the others are quiet just waiting for their turn.   The meetings might be better if held in a round table discussion format.  

My suggestion for where to go is Austin.  Play golf and rent a ski boat and jet ski's.  Flying somewhere takes too much time.

body:
<email>
From: Jenna Davis <jenna.davis@hearingeducation.org>
To: Mark Ramirez <mark.ramirez@inclusiveschools.net>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference presentation

Hi Mark,

Thank you for your thoughtful feedback and edits on the presentation! I agree that the slides look great and the additional data points you added really strengthen our argument. I think we're in good shape for the conference.

Your suggested Q&A questions are spot-on. I'll add them to our prep document along with some potential responses. If you have any other questions that come to mind, please let me know.

I'm definitely interested in co-authoring a paper on our research! It would be a fantastic opportunity to share our findings and contribute to the field. I think a good first step would be to outline the structure and divide up the writing tasks as you suggested. Would you be available for a call next week to discuss this further and get the ball rolling?

Looking forward to our presentation and excited about the potential paper!

Best,
Jenna
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Amelia Novak <amnovak@university.edu>
To: Ethan Faulkner <ethanf@college.edu>
Subject: Re: Collaborative paper - final revisions

Ethan,

Friday morning works great for me - let's plan on 10am? I'll keep an eye out for the Zoom link.

I think your ideas for the grant applications are spot-on. Highlighting the significance of our research and its potential implications for contemporary debates is exactly the right approach. I'd be thrilled to collaborate with you on this - it's a great opportunity to build on the work we've already done together.

If you're willing to take the lead on drafting some of the key sections, I'd be happy to provide feedback and help with editing. We could aim to have a first draft ready by the end of the month, if that works with your schedule.

I'm really excited about this next phase of our collaboration. It's wonderful to have a partner who is not only brilliant but also a true pleasure to work with.

See you on Friday!

Best,
Amelia
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Amelia Hartman <amelia.hartman@university.edu>
To: Dr. Julian Patel <jpatel@physicsinstitute.org>
Subject: Request for expertise

Dear Dr. Patel,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Amelia Hartman, and I am a linguistics researcher at Westfield University. I am currently working on a project to create a new dictionary of scientific terms, and I was hoping to seek your expertise on some of the more complex physics concepts.

I recently attended your lecture on gravitational expansion at the annual physics conference and was impressed by your innovative ideas and engaging presentation style. I believe your insights would be invaluable in helping me accurately define and explain these concepts in my dictionary.

If you would be willing to assist me with this project, I would be immensely grateful. I am happy to provide more details about the scope and timeline of the work, and of course, I would acknowledge your contributions in the final publication.

Thank you for considering my request. I look forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,
Amelia Hartman
label: research

From: Johannes Müller <j.muller@sprachwissenschaft.de>
To: Lena Albrecht <lena.albrecht@chemie.uni-heidelberg.de>
Subject: Bilingual Chemistry Glossary Project

Dear Lena,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been thinking about our recent discussions and the idea of creating a bilingual glossary of chemistry terms. I believe this project could be a great opportunity for both of us to combine our expertise and create something valuable.

As we have discussed, I will focus on the German translations and etymologies of the terms, while you will provide the scientific explanations and ensure the accuracy of the content.

I suggest we start by creating a list of the most common chemistry terms and their German equivalents. We can then work on the etymologies and explanations, and finally, organize the glossary in a clear and user-friendly manner.

Please let me know your thoughts on this project and if you have any suggestions for additional features or resources we could include.

Best regards,
Johannes
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@pinesacademy.org>
To: Alex Smith <alex.smith@networkgenius.com>
Subject: Congratulations on your recent achievement!

Dear Alex,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out and congratulate you on your recent contribution to the Linux kernel! I read about it in the latest issue of Linux Journal, and I couldn't be prouder of what you've accomplished.

It's been a few years since you graduated from Pines Academy, and I've enjoyed watching your career take off. Your success is a testament to your hard work and the passion you developed for computer science during your time here.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in coming back to Pines Academy to speak to my current students about your experience in the industry and what it's like to work on such a high-profile open-source project. I think it would be incredibly inspiring for them to hear from someone who was once in their shoes and has gone on to achieve great things.

Please let me know if you'd be open to this opportunity. I'd love to discuss potential dates and topics for your visit.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
label: research

body: Dear Sir/Ma'am, LR201 has been accidentally allotted to both the CS society and the debating society. Please allot another room to the Debating society. Warm Regards, Debsoc
label: student

body:
<email>
From: Ava Whitman <ava.whitman@university.edu>
To: Liam Patel <liam.patel@turbotech.com>
Subject: Faulkner, Thermodynamics, and Power Generation

Dear Liam,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out because I've been working on a paper for an upcoming literary conference that explores the use of symbolism in William Faulkner's works to examine themes of power and energy. As I was delving into the research, I couldn't help but think about our conversations at the book club and how your expertise in thermodynamics and power generation systems could provide valuable insights into my work.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on this project. I believe that combining our knowledge in literature and engineering could lead to a fascinating exploration of the intersection between the humanities and STEM fields. Perhaps we could meet up to discuss the possibility of working together on a presentation for the conference?

Let me know your thoughts!

Best regards,
Ava

body:
<email>
From: David Lee <david.lee@behavioraleconomics.com>
To: Sarah Turner <sarah.turner@conservation.org>
Subject: RE: Reconnecting after the sustainability conference

Hi Sarah,

It's great to hear from you! I've also been reflecting on our conversation and thinking about how my research could potentially apply to your snow leopard conservation project.

I've recently been studying the impact of cognitive biases like optimism bias and status quo bias on decision-making in environmental organizations. These biases can lead to underestimating the severity of environmental threats and resisting necessary changes to conservation strategies.

I'd be very interested in learning more about the specific challenges you're facing in your project and discussing how these biases might be playing a role. Perhaps we could explore ways to design interventions that account for these cognitive factors and promote more effective decision-making.

I'm available for a call next week. How about Tuesday afternoon, around 2 pm my time (EST)? Let me know if that works for you.

Looking forward to continuing our discussion!

Best,
David

Hi Jamie,

I'm glad to hear that you've been finding our tutoring sessions helpful! I completely understand the stress of a big test coming up. I have some availability this week and would be more than happy to have an extra session with you to go over the material that will be on the test.

How about Wednesday afternoon, around 4pm? We can meet in the library like usual. I'll prepare some practice problems and review sheets for the concepts that are likely to be on the test.

body:
<email>
From: David Thompson <dthompson@denverresearch.org>
To: Emily Sanders <esanders@uchicago.edu>
Subject: RE: Meeting up at the GSA conference

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you, and I'm glad to know that you're making progress on your Niobrara Formation project. It sounds like a really interesting study, and I'd be happy to take a look at your data and offer any insights I can.

I'll definitely be at the GSA conference in Salt Lake City, so let's definitely plan on meeting up. I'm free on the afternoon of the second day of the conference, if that works for you. We could grab lunch at the hotel restaurant and have a good chat about your research.

I'm curious to learn more about the statistical methods you've been using to analyze the fossil distribution patterns. It would be great if you could bring along any maps or diagrams that illustrate your key findings so far. I might be able to suggest some additional analytical techniques that could help you refine your interpretations.

Looking forward to catching up in person and hopefully sparking some new ideas for our research. See you in Salt Lake City!

Best,
David
label: research

To: David Thompson <dthompson@thinktank.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from the conference

Hi David,

Thanks so much for your response! I really appreciate your willingness to provide feedback on my research. Early April works perfectly for me. I'll send you an email next week with a few potential dates and times for our call, and we can find a time that works for both of us.

In the meantime, I'll put together a brief summary of my preliminary findings and send it your way, so you have a better idea of what I'm working on.

Thanks again for your help, and I look forward to our discussion!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Alex Johnson <ajohnson@student.university.edu>
To: Dr. John Smith <jsmith@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Research Opportunity - Monopolistic Competition

Dear Dr. Smith,

Thank you for the meeting on Friday. I found our discussion enlightening and came away with a clearer understanding of our research objectives.

I have begun gathering data on the market structures of the telecommunications and pharmaceutical industries, as you suggested. I will compile my findings and share them with you by next Monday.

I have also been thinking about the implications of product differentiation in monopolistic competition. I believe this could be a crucial aspect of our research and would like to explore it further.

Please let me know if you have any suggestions or feedback on my progress so far.

Best regards,
Alex Johnson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Avraham Cohen <avraham.cohen@jts.edu>
To: Rabbi Sarah Silverstein <rabbisilverstein@jccchicago.org>
Subject: Seeking guidance on a historical Jewish ritual

Dear Rabbi Silverstein,

I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to you from Jerusalem, where I am currently studying for a semester at the Hebrew University. As you know, I have been deeply immersed in the study of Jewish history and traditions, and I have encountered a question that I believe you may be able to help me with.

In my research, I have come across conflicting interpretations of the historical significance of the ritual of "X." Some scholars argue that it originated during the Second Temple period, while others claim that it dates back to the time of the Babylonian exile. As I delve deeper into this topic, I find myself unsure of which interpretation to trust.

I remember the many insightful discussions we had about Jewish rituals and their origins during my time at the JCC in Chicago, and I am hoping you might be able to shed some light on this matter. If you have any resources, insights, or guidance you could share with me, I would be immensely grateful.

Thank you for your time and consideration. I look forward to hearing from you and catching up on how things are going back in Chicago.

Best regards,
Avraham
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <anovak@university.edu>
To: Jordan Lee <jlee@observatory.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting news about the James Webb Space Telescope!

Jordan,

Thank you for your enthusiastic response and congratulations! It means a lot coming from someone whose work I greatly admire.

I've just sent a calendar invite for next Tuesday at 2:00 PM. I look forward to our call and the opportunity to discuss our findings in greater detail.

As for a sneak peek, I can share that our discovery revolves around the detection of a previously unknown population of galaxies in the early universe. These galaxies appear to be much more numerous and luminous than previously thought, challenging our current models of galaxy formation and evolution.

I'm attaching a figure that illustrates the unexpected luminosity function we've observed. I'd be interested to hear your initial thoughts on the implications of this finding for our understanding of the early universe.

See you next Tuesday!

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@geothermenergy.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@renewablesolutions.org>
Subject: RE: Reconnecting and potential collaboration

Emily,

I am equally excited about our collaboration and the potential for our work to make a real difference in the fight against climate change. The data and case studies you plan to gather will be invaluable for our proposal and will help us make a strong case for the environmental and economic benefits of our approach.

I will send you the outline for our proposal by Monday afternoon, giving you ample time to review it before our call on Tuesday. Please feel free to make any suggestions or changes you deem necessary.

In the meantime, I will continue to research the latest developments in geothermal energy and machine learning applications to ensure that our proposal is at the cutting edge of the industry.

I look forward to our call and the fruitful collaboration ahead.

Best regards,
John

cc: Louis Allen/EPSC/HOU/ECT@ECT, Raquel Lopez/Corp/Enron@ENRON 
Subject: Enron Center Garage

The Enron Center garage will be opening very soon.

Employees who work for business units that are scheduled to move to the new 
building and currently park in the Allen Center or Met garages are being 
offered a parking space in the new Enron Center garage.

This is the only offer you will receive during the initial migration to the 
new garage. Spaces will be filled on a first come first served basis. The 
cost for the new garage will be the same as Allen Center garage which is 
currently $165.00 per month, less the company subsidy, leaving a monthly 
employee cost of $94.00.

If you choose not to accept this offer at this time, you may add your name to 
the Enron Center garage waiting list at a later day and offers will be made 
as spaces become available. 

The Saturn Ring  that connects the garage and both buildings will not be 
opened until summer 2001. All initial parkers will have to use the street 
level entrance to Enron Center North until Saturn Ring access is available. 
Garage stairways next to the elevator lobbies at each floor may be used as an 
exit in the event of elevator trouble. 

If you are interested in accepting this offer, please reply via email to 
Parking and Transportation as soon as you reach a decision. Following your 
email, arrangements will be made for you to turn in your old parking card and 
receive a parking transponder along with a new information packet for the new 
garage.

The Parking and Transportation desk may be reached via email at Parking and 
Transportation/Corp/Enron or 713-853-7060  with any questions. 

(You must enter & exit on Clay St. the first two weeks, also pedestrians, 
will have to use the garage stairwell located on the corner of Bell & Smith.)

X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Tim,

Can you authorize access to the west power site for Keith Holtz.  He is our 
Southern California basis trader and is under a two year contract.

On another note, is it my imagination or did the SARR website lower its 
forecast for McNary discharge during May.  It seems like the flows have been 
lowered into the 130 range and there are fewer days near 170.  Also the 
second half of April doesn't seem to have panned out as I expected.  The 
outflows stayed at 100-110 at McNary.  Can you email or call with some 
additional insight?

Thank you,

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Emily Chen <emily.chen@automationtech.com>
To: Jordan Smith <jordan.smith@university.edu>
Subject: RE: RE: Conference Follow-up

Hi Jordan,

I'm so glad you reached out! I've been thinking about our conversation non-stop since the conference. I'm really excited about the potential for our collaboration and can't wait to get started.

I'm free on Tuesday afternoon, so let's plan on chatting then. Do you want to meet in person or just have a phone call? Let me know what works best for you.

I've been doing some research on the latest advancements in 3D scanning technology and I think I have some ideas that could be really useful for your work. I'm also curious to learn more about your current research and how you think motion control systems could be applied.

Looking forward to our chat on Tuesday!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@cityhospital.org>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@cityhospital.org>
Subject: RE: New study on vaccine safety during pregnancy

Emily,

Thank you for sharing this study. It's great to have more evidence to support the safety and efficacy of the Tdap vaccine during pregnancy. I think we should definitely include this information in our patient education materials and discuss it during our counseling sessions.

Regarding the meeting with the hospital administration, I agree that we should go over the presentation together. I was thinking we could highlight the potential benefits of our initiative, such as increased vaccine uptake rates, reduced incidence of pertussis among infants, and improved overall maternal and infant health outcomes. We could also emphasize the potential cost savings associated with preventing vaccine-preventable diseases.

Let's schedule a time to meet and finalize our presentation. I'm available next Tuesday afternoon or Wednesday morning. Please let me know what works best for you.

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@oakvilleschool.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@oakvilleschool.edu>
Subject: Sports and Math Event Planning

Hey Emily,

I hope you're doing well! As you know, our school is planning a Sports and Math event for the students, and we've been asked to organize it. I think this is a great opportunity to showcase our collaboration and get the students excited about both subjects.

I was thinking we could have stations set up for different activities, like calculating the trajectory of a soccer ball, analyzing player statistics, and even having students participate in mini-games that incorporate math problems. What do you think?

Let's set up a meeting to brainstorm more ideas and start planning the event. I'm free this Friday after school if that works for you. Let me know!

Best regards,
John
label: research

cc: Rick Buy/HOU/ECT@ECT, John.J. Lavorato@enron.com, David 
Haug/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Jeffrey A Shankman/HOU/ECT@ECT, 
Jeff Skilling/Corp/Enron@ENRON 
Subject: 

Doug:
To confirm the pricing of the LNG dela::

I can show a $3.01 bid for the Nymex portion of 160,000 mmbtu/day for the 
time period Jan 2003-Dec 2014.  The bid on Henry Hub basis for same time 
period is -$.0025 resulting in fix price of $3.0075; the bid on Sonat basis 
is -$.0175 translating into a bid of $2.9925.

Notional volume = 70,128 contracts.
PV volume = 37,658 contracts.
Exposure per $.01 move = $3,760,000

John
label: corporate

body: Hi Professor Sharma, I would love to join your research lab. Could you let me know what the requirements are and how I can apply?
label: student

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@washadvocates.org>
To: Dr. Rajesh Patel <rpatel@unicef.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on community engagement challenges in CLTS project

Dear Rajesh,

Thank you so much for your thoughtful response and for sharing those valuable insights from your experience. The strategies you mentioned, particularly identifying local champions and conducting participatory workshops, resonate with me and align with the approach we've been trying to take. We will definitely incorporate the idea of providing small incentives for early adopters – that could be a game-changer in creating momentum within the community.

I would be incredibly grateful if you could connect me with the local NGO in Laos. Learning about their successful approach and hearing their stories could provide us with the inspiration and guidance we need to overcome the challenges we're facing.

And of course, any introductions you could facilitate with potential partners in Cambodia through your colleagues at UNICEF's regional office would be immensely appreciated. Collaborating with local organizations could help us tap into valuable local knowledge and resources that could make a real difference in our project's impact.

I will definitely keep you updated on our progress and will be sure to reach out if any other questions or ideas come up. Thank you again for your support and for being such a valuable resource in the WASH community. I hope we can continue to exchange ideas and perhaps even explore opportunities to collaborate on advancing WASH access in the future.

Best regards,
Emily
Emily Nguyen
Public Health Advocate
WASH Advocates NGO
label: research

<email>
From: Michael Smith <michael.smith@research.org>
To: Emily Chen <emily.chen@university.edu>
Subject: RE: New research grant opportunity

Hi Emily,

It's great to hear from you! Thanks for reaching out about this grant opportunity. The focus on innovative approaches to HIV vaccine development aligns perfectly with my current research direction.

I'd be more than happy to discuss your proposal further and provide any insights or suggestions I can. I'm fairly flexible next week, but Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning would work best for me. Let me know what time suits you, and we can set up a call.

Looking forward to catching up and exploring this opportunity together.

Best,
Michael

Message-ID: <31396092.1075858639743.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Fri, 15 Jun 2001 14:09:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: k..allen@enron.com
To: melick@texas1031.com
Subject: Texas1031_homepage
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-To: 'melick@texas1031.com'
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Sent Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Carlos,

Can you help me with several 1031 exchange questions?  I spoke to your office and they thought it best that I address my questions to you directly.  

Here is my situation.  I purchased a 32 acre tract in Leander about 8 months ago.  I have a contract to sell the property which should close around July 18th.  

I expect to realize a gain of around $400,000.  See calculations below:

Sales price:		2,100,000
Purchase price		1,200,000
Fees&Devel costs	  500,000

Profit			 400,000

The cash generated at the sale will be close to $1 million after repayment of a loan.

I am interested in protecting this gain through a 1031 exchange.

I am already involved in a couple of other real estate transactions that might qualify. 

 First, there is a 10 acre tract that was purchased by Bishops Corner, Ltd for $1.15 million six months ago.  I lent the partnership the cash to buy the land with the intent of working with the developer to build a multifamily project.  We could not come to terms for the development, so the partnership was conveyed to me.  The loan still exist.  I am an 80% limited partner.  Another investor is the other limited partner.  We have set up a Corporation to be the general partner.  We intend to develop the property. Is there a creative way to use the land purchase in a 1031 exchange?

Second,  I have a small tract in New Braunfels under contract for $400,000.  I am applying for FHA financing for a 180 unit apartment complex and hope to receive an invitation letter prior to closing.  I would need to place this property in a limited partnership eventually, but is there a way to buy the property hold it in my name long enough to satisfy the IRS then move it to a LP.

If neither of these deals qualify, I would still like to find another piece of property.  My two biggest concerns are tying up too much cash and holding property in my own name.  Is there a way to insure during the 1st year then move a different entity?

Thank you in advance for your help.

Phillip Allen	
8855 Merlin Ct
Houston, TX 77055
pallen70@hotmail.com
wk 713-853-7041
hm 713-463-8626

From: k..allen@enron.com

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Allen, Phillip K. </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=PALLEN>
X-To: 'gthorse@keyad.com'
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Jan2002_1\Allen, Phillip K.\Sent Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen (Non-Privileged).pst

 


Greg,

I plugged the data on Colonial Oaks into your format.  The actual NOI for 2001 is around 305,000.  But there is not a professional management company.  Subtracting $25,000 for management costs the NOI would be $280,000.  However, I increased the taxes and a few other expenses to bring total expenses up to $3,000/unit.  This would yield an NOI of $240,000.  Comparing the rents charged to the other 17 properties, it doesn't look like the rents have a great deal of upside.  

The asking price is $2,700,000.  Using $240,000 would make this an 8.9 cap.  Using the seller's NOI of $280,000 would be a 10.4 cap.  The cost per unit is $33,750 for a 1969 project.  The cost per square foot is 36.58.  

The numbers would be better if the property was offered at $2.5 million.  Jeff Smith claims that $2.7 million is as low as the seller will go.  This property has not been on the market.  So I would like your input of what the market would pay for it.  If $280,000 is a reasonable NOI, then I would thing it would be sold fairly quickly for $2.7 million.  It does have the benefit of all brick exterior and elderly tenants.  Plus the location is by far the most convenient.

Financing is the other consideration.  I am assuming 25 year, 7%,  and 25% down.  What do you think could actually be achieved?  Can you put me in contact with a lender?

I will follow up with a phone call.

Thanks,

Phillip
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Ethan Johnson <ethan.johnson@spaceuni.edu>
To: Olivia Taylor <olivia.taylor@weatherlab.gov>
Subject: RE: Fascinating presentation at the conference!

Hi Olivia,

I've just finished reading the papers you sent over, and I'm impressed by the potential of radar technology for NEO detection. The sensitivity and resolution of modern radar systems are truly remarkable, and I can see how they could be a valuable tool in our efforts to monitor and track potentially hazardous asteroids.

I've also been thinking more about the implications of our research for planetary defense. If we can develop a reliable radar-based system for detecting and tracking NEOs, it could significantly improve our ability to predict and mitigate the risks posed by asteroid impacts. This could have a major impact on public policy and international cooperation in the field of space exploration and planetary protection.

I'm eager to continue our collaboration and explore the possibilities for a joint research project. I'm available for a call next week, anytime after 2 PM on Tuesday or Thursday. Please let me know what works best for you.

Looking forward to our continued partnership!

Best regards,
Ethan
label: research

the market had to get to a price whereby these guys shut down.  there is just 
not enough gas to allow everybody who wants to to burn it.  the elasticity of 
demand is in the industrial sector.  million dollar question is have we 
gotten to a high enough price whereby we end the year with gas in the ground 
and deliverability to meet a late cold snap.  shutdown of processing, 
distillate and resid switching, loss of industrial load...maybe we have.
good holidays,
john




slafontaine@globalp.com on 12/22/2000 07:11:26 AM
To: slafontaine@globalp.com
cc:  
Subject: Plants Shut Down and Sell the Energy



Subject:  Plants Shut Down and Sell the Energy



Plants Shut Down and Sell the Energy
By Peter Behr
Washington Post Staff Writer
Thursday, December 21, 2000; Page E01
Kaiser Aluminum Corp. had planned to spend December making aluminum at its
giant smelters in the Pacific Northwest, run by electricity from the
Bonneville Power Administration's Columbia River dams. Then it saw a better
deal. With California desperate for power and electricity prices hitting
unheard-of peaks, Kaiser shut down its two U.S. smelters last week. It is
selling the electricity it no longer needs -- for about 20 times what it
pays Bonneville under long-standing contracts.
It is a measure of this winter's fuel crunch: Some big industrial firms in
energy-intensive sectors such as paper, fertilizers, metals and even
oil-field operations can make more money by selling their electricity or
natural gas than manufacturing their products. The shifts by such large
industrial consumers of energy -- described as unprecedented by analysts --
will free up more fuel for households and businesses this winter. But they
also are sowing seeds of potential problems next year. Shortages of aluminum
and fertilizer, for example, are likely to give another upward jolt to
consumer prices and further weaken the economy, analysts said.
"The fertilizer picture is particularly worrying us because we don't know
what they're going to use to grow crops with," said David Wyss, chief
economist at Standard & Poor's. Some economists have recently increased
their warnings about the damaging impact of this winter's heating bills on
an already weakening economy. Goldman Sachs analysts last week estimated
that gas heating bills will double this winter to more than $1,000 for a
typical U.S. household.
That and higher electricity prices will cost consumers $20 billion in higher
energy costs compared with a year ago, they estimated, cutting the expected
growth in the nation's economic output by one percentage point on an annual
rate in the first three months of next year. "Overall, the recent energy
price developments have thus added to the risk of a sharp economic
slowdown," the Goldman Sachs report concluded. Terra Industries Inc., in
Sioux City, Iowa, has closed three of its six U.S. ammonia plants, which use
natural gas as a main ingredient for fertilizer production. Like Kaiser, the
company realized it would be much more profitable to stop production in
December and sell the natural gas back to the market at current prices,
which are much higher than the price Terra was obligated to pay under its
existing December supply contract, said Mark Rosenbury, chief administrative
officer.
"We looked at these [current] prices and said, 'This is crazy,' " he said.
Terra hasn't disclosed the profit it will make selling its gas, but
Rosenbury said it would be "substantial."  In coming months, Terra's good
fortune could be reversed. It usually buys gas a month at a time, and the
prices for January delivery most likely will be well above its break-even
point. That would keep Terra's plants closed, Rosenbury said, but eliminate
the opportunity to sell the natural gas at a profit. "If this persists,"
Rosenbury said, "it's going to be a real problem."
He estimates that out of a total annual U.S. production capacity of 18
million tons of ammonia, about 4 million tons of production isn't operating
now. "Could we be short of fertilizer next spring? It's possible that
farmers will not have as much as they want," Rosenbury said. Royster-Clark
Inc., a Norfolk and New York City-based fertilizer manufacturer and
distributor, has shut down its one plant in East Dubuque, Ill.,
indefinitely, and 72 production workers will be laid off, beginning next
month. The story is the same -- natural gas prices are too high to justify
continued production. "We believe it's likely this is a speculative bubble
[in natural gas prices] that will burst and in a few weeks we'll be able to
buy gas at a more reasonable price, but that remains to be seen," said Paul
M. Murphy, the company's managing director for financial planning. A
continuation of high natural gas prices would likely shrink production and
raise fertilizer prices to a point that could affect farmers' decisions to
plant feed corn, he said. "It's sticker shock."
According to Wyss, if this winter remains unusually cold and natural gas
remains above $7 per million cubic feet -- double the level a year ago --
farm products could rise significantly a year from now and into 2002. In the
aluminum industry, several smaller producers have joined Kaiser, the
industry's No. 2 manufacturer, in closing down, noted Lloyd O'Carroll, an
analyst with BB&T Capital Markets in Richmond.
Aluminum production in November was 8.3 percent below that of November 1999,
and December's production will be lower still, he said. "We'll get more
production cut announcements, I think," he said. A slowing in the U.S. and
world economies next year could ease the impact of reduced aluminum
supplies. "But if the world economy doesn't fall completely apart, then
[aluminum] prices are going to rise, and they could rise significantly more
than the current forecast," he said. In Kaiser's case, it's an open question
how much of its electric windfall it will keep. Kaiser is contractually
entitled to buy electricity from Bonneville at $22.50 a megawatt per hour,
says spokesman Scott Lamb. That is the power it has sold back to Bonneville
for $550 a megawatt hour for December.
But the Bonneville Authority is pressuring Kaiser to use these and future
profits from power resales to compensate employees at the shut-down plants,
to invest in new electric generating capacity, or even to refund to
Bonneville's other customers, said Bonneville spokesman Ed Mosey. Kaiser and
Bonneville have negotiated a new power purchase deal to take effect after
next October, but the power authority says it intends to reduce deliveries
to Kaiser if the company tries to pocket the electricity sale profits. "Out
here, a deal is a deal, but it has to be a moral deal. There has to be an
ethical dimension to this and we're not shy in trying to make sure they live
up their advantage in having access to this publicly-owned power," Mosey
said.
, 2000 The Washington Post Company

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@globalhealthinstitute.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@pineridgeelementary.org>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on a multicultural art project

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm thrilled to hear about your multicultural art project and would be delighted to collaborate with you and your students.

I believe that combining art, culture, and health is a powerful way to engage young minds and promote a deeper understanding of the world around us. I'd be happy to provide you with information on various traditional health practices and their cultural significance, which could serve as inspiration for your students' art pieces.

Additionally, I think it would be valuable to include a culinary aspect in the project, as food is often a central element in many cultural traditions. Students could create art pieces inspired by the traditional dishes of different communities, while also learning about the nutritional and health implications of these foods.

Please let me know your thoughts on this idea, and we can discuss further details on how to best integrate these concepts into your project.

Best regards,
Michael Thompson
Medical Anthropologist
Global Health Institute

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@washngo.org>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@who.int>
Subject: RE: Request for guidance on scaling our WASH project

Dear Sarah,

Thank you so much for your prompt response and willingness to help. I greatly appreciate your support and expertise.

As for our project, we have been focusing on the following interventions:
1. Construction and rehabilitation of boreholes and wells to improve access to clean water
2. Promotion of household latrines and community sanitation facilities
3. Hygiene education campaigns, including handwashing and safe water storage practices

We have been implementing these interventions in 5 villages, reaching approximately 2,500 people. The initial results have been promising, with a significant reduction in waterborne diseases and improved sanitation practices.

However, we are now looking to expand our reach to 20 villages in the region, targeting around 10,000 people. Our main challenges are ensuring the sustainability of the interventions, securing funding, and building local capacity.

I would be grateful for any resources or insights you can share on these topics. A call to discuss this further would be extremely helpful.

Thank you once again for your support. I look forward to learning from your experience and expertise.

Best regards,
John
label: research

X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst


GMAT REVIEW AT ENRON

The next GMAT review course at Enron will begin Monday, November 26th:
The schedule is:
     Course # 7019-00:  Monday nights, Nov 26 - Jan 28 (no class Dec 24 or
Dec 31)

This course is identical to the courses that started in October.  It is
being offered now for the benefit of employees who would like to take the
GMAT before January 31 for the purposes of applying to business school.

Course details:
     - Class is held at Enron in room ECN560 and is restricted to Enron
		employees
     - Each course is limited to eight students
     - Meets once a week for eight weeks
     - Hours are 6:00-9:00 PM (first session will run til 10:00 pm to
          include initial exam)
     - Expect 4-5 hours of homework per week
     - Course includes a total of four practice GMAT exams
     - Ends the second week of December, allowing employees to take the
          GMAT in December and meet a January application deadline.
     - Special discount of $200 off the regular Princeton Review tuition

Enron has allowed this program to be hosted in the Enron Building for
convenience of its employees.  Individuals are responsible for paying their
own fees.  Financial support from Enron is at manager's discretion and is
subject to the usual tuition reimbursement constraints around budget and
relevance to organizational performance.


HOW TO ENROLL:
     1.  Print out the attached registration form.
     2.  Complete the form, but please note the following
          SPECIFIC INSTRUCTIONS:
          A.  Fill out the student information completely, including
               your email address.
          B.  In the Enrollment section, where it says "Please enroll
               me in GMAT Class Size-8 Course # _________",
          C.  In the Payment section:  For the course at Enron, the
               tuition is discounted by $200, to $899.
               FULL PAYMENT of this amount by credit or debit card is
required on the registration form.  Be sure to indicate complete cardholder
information.
     3.  Fax the completed form to Princeton Review at (713) 688-4746.

Faxes are time-stamped by the receiving fax machine at Princeton Review.
The first eight valid registration forms received for each course will be
honored.  Registrations received after the first eight will be placed on a
waiting
list for the course or courses indicated.  Enrollments and waitlists will be
confirmed by email.

Employees who are not able to take the course at Enron can take a course at
the Princeton Review office at the same $200 discount.  
Call (800)2REVIEW to register or to receive a list of course schedules.

IMPORTANCE OF THE GMAT:
     The GMAT score is a critical part of your application to business
school.  Indeed, in many cases, it is the single most decisive statistic
that admissions offices use in evaluating applicants.  While work
experience, GPA, essays, and interviews are all important components of
your application, the GMAT is the one objective factor that you can
substantially improve in a short period of time.

THE TEXAS MBA TOUR:
     All interested Enron employees are invited to attend the Texas MBA
Tour, which will be in Houston on Wednesday, January 23. The Texas MBA
Tour, of which The Princeton Review is a partner, is a group of six business
schools that host a joint MBA panel discussion and admissions fair.  The
participating schools are Texas, Rice, SMU, Baylor, TCU, and Texas A&M.
The Princeton Review has agreed to handle registration for the event, so
call
(800) 2REVIEW to register.

http://home.enron.com:84/messaging/gmatregform.pdf

body:
<email>
From: Alice Johnson <ajohnson@university.edu>
To: Robert Smith <rsmith@archaeology.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting new discovery at the German site!

Robert,

I'm so glad you're interested in the new artifact! I'll send over the data and my initial thoughts later this week. I really value your input and expertise.

I completely agree with your assessment of the situation with Dr. Müller and the French site. We should definitely proceed with caution, but I think the potential benefits outweigh the risks. Let's start working on the grant application and see where it takes us.

Your new hypothesis about the role of religion in the agricultural transition sounds fascinating. I'd love to hear more about it. Perhaps we can set up a video call next week to discuss both of our projects in more detail? Let me know what works for your schedule.

It's always a pleasure collaborating with you, Robert. I'm looking forward to our continued work together.

Best,
Alice
label: research

Save it to your Shockmachine now! 

Every frog has his day - games, too. Frogger had a great run as an 
arcade classic, but it is leaving the shockwave.com pond soon. The 
good news is that you can download it to your Shockmachine and 
own it forever! 

Don't know about Shockmachine? You can download Shockmachine for free 
and save all of your downloadable favorites to play off-line, 
full-screen, whenever you want. 

Download Frogger by noon, PST on June 30th, while it's still on 
the site! 

the shockwave.com team

Lucy,

Here is a draft of a memo we should distribute to the units that are subject 
to caps.  I wrote it as if it were from you.  It should come from the manager.

It is very important that we tell new tenants what the utility cap for there 
unit is when they move in.  This needs to be written in on their lease.

When you have to talk to a tenant complaining about the overages emphasize 
that it is only during the peak months and it is already warming up.  

Have my Dad read the memo before you put it out.   You guys can make changes 
if you need to.





Next week we need to take inventory of all air conditioners and 
refrigerators.  We have to get this done next week.  I will email you a form 
to use to record serial numbers.  The prospective buyers want this 
information plus we need it for our records.  Something to look forward to.

It is 2 PM and I have to leave the office.  Please have my Dad call me with 
the information about the units at home 713-463-8626.  He will know what I 
mean.

Talk to you later,

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <alex.novak@spacegov.org>
To: Priya Singh <priya.singh@scilang.com>
Subject: Great meeting you at the conference!

Hi Priya,

It was wonderful to meet you at the Sustainable Space Exploration Conference last week. I really enjoyed our conversation about the intersection of space sustainability and scientific computing. Your work on developing a programming language tailored for space-related applications sounds fascinating!

I've been thinking about our discussion on promoting sustainable practices in our respective fields, and I believe there could be some interesting synergies between our work. I'm curious to learn more about the specific challenges you face when it comes to ensuring the efficiency and sustainability of scientific computing in space missions.

Would you be interested in scheduling a call to further explore potential collaborations or sharing of best practices? I'd be happy to provide more details about my research on space debris mitigation policies and how they might relate to your work.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Robert Martinez <rmartinez@oakvilleelementary.org>
To: Jessica Thompson <jthompson@oakvilleelementary.org>
Subject: RE: New Curriculum Update

Jessica,

Thank you for sharing this exciting news with me. I am thrilled to hear about the positive results you've seen in your class. I have always been a strong advocate for innovative teaching methods, and I believe that your approach aligns perfectly with our school's mission to provide a well-rounded education to our students.

I would be more than happy to meet with you to discuss the expansion of this program. In fact, I have been thinking about how we can allocate some of the funds from the recent grant to support this initiative. I believe that with the right resources and support, we can make a significant impact on our students' learning outcomes.

Please let me know your availability for next week, and we can set up a meeting to discuss the details. I am looking forward to working with you on this exciting project.

Best regards,
Robert

Communications, Steve Pearlman/Enron Communications@Enron Communications,

		 Subject: RE: Enron / Avaya meetings: calendar


Mission/Purpose:  Coordinate EBS Executive Calendars 
for EBS' trip to Avaya HQ in Basking Ridge, NJ

This is targeted as a one-day trip for the Enron executives
Daily objectives highlighted in red, further below.  

Individual items per person follow immediately:

Jim, 

I have spoken w/Nancy Young, and we have penciled in 
that you could possibly make the trip on December 19th, 
20th, or 21st; OR January 9th, 10th, or 11th.  If Larry and Everett 
can also join on one of the same days you are penciled in 
for, I would like to book your time for the meeting.

Larry,

I have left you a voicemail, and this note.  Please let me 
know ASAP which of the days that I have penciled in for 
Jim Crowder's attendance would also work for you.

Everett,

I have called Marie Thibaut and left her the information on 
her voicemail.  Since she's out, I'll send this to you directly, 
as well.  Will you also let me know which days (above) 
work best for you?

Steve Pearlman, 

You and I have spoken, I have your availability info.  Thank you.  


+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

To clarify the purpose of the Avaya trip:  the first day (only) 
is for executives to investigate the following items --
1)  what value can EBS deliver to Avaya for Avaya internal 
use (product/service solutions, financing, etc.)  EBS sell 
EBS' solutions to Avaya for Avaya internal use
2)  ideas for opportunities for Avaya and EBS to enter into 
a "sell through/sell with" arrangement, whereby some type 
of joint marketing efforts could be enjoined.  EBS sell with, 
and/or through the Avaya sales organization


The second day (only) would be for Avaya and EBS 
development/technical staff to meet and brainstorm the:   
1) results of the executive meetings' output from 1&2 above, 
discuss output of day 1 meetings, & technical issues 
and opportunities
and 2) what technical hurdles or opportunities exist which 
could enable successful EBS efforts to sell EBS solutions 
 to Avaya and through Avaya or with Avaya's sales & 
marketing team.  Larry Ciscon may choose to attend both 
days due to the nature of his mission.


++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Please let me know as soon as you can which day or 
days would work best for you to make the trip.  I need to 
get things coordinated with my counterpart at Avaya so 
he can schedule his executives' time, and their briefing 
center facility.

Thank you,

Jeff

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@abcschools.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@xyzschools.org>
Subject: RE: Drama-based activities for Unit 3

Hi Michael,

Thank you so much for your feedback on the drama-based activities! I appreciate your suggestions and have incorporated them into the final version.

Regarding the conference presentation, I think you're right that we should focus on the unique aspects of our curriculum. Perhaps we could start with an overview of the challenges we faced in teaching language arts and how we came up with the idea to develop this curriculum. Then, we can highlight a few key activities and scaffolding techniques that showcase our approach. We could even do a short demonstration of one of the drama-based activities if time allows.

What do you think? I'm open to any other ideas you might have.

Also, I wanted to share some exciting news. My principal has given me the green light to pilot our curriculum in my classroom next semester! I'm thrilled to have the opportunity to see it in action and gather feedback from students and parents.

I hope things are going well with your end of the curriculum development. Please keep me updated on your progress!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Stevens <samantha.stevens@weatheragency.gov>
To: David Lee <david.lee@meteorologyinstitute.org>
Subject: RE: Upcoming conference on radar technology

David,

I love your idea for the presentation! A case study showcasing the challenges and successes of the project would be highly relevant and engaging for the conference audience. I'm confident that our collaboration and the concrete results we achieved will make for a compelling story.

I'm happy to collaborate on the abstract and proposal. How about we set up a call next week to brainstorm and divide up the tasks? I can send you a few potential time slots that work for me.

Also, I wanted to mention that I've been working on a side project related to using machine learning algorithms to improve radar data interpretation. I'd love to get your thoughts and feedback on it when we chat.

Excited to work together again and see you at the conference!

All the best,
Samantha

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: David Smith <dsmith@university.edu>
Subject: Interesting article on Homo erectus diet

Hey David,

I hope you're having a great time in Africa and that your research is going well. I can't wait to hear all about it when you get back.

I came across this article yesterday and thought you might find it interesting: [URL] It discusses some new evidence about the diet of Homo erectus and how it may have differed from what we previously thought. I was wondering if you had seen this article and what your thoughts are on it. Do you think this new information could have any implications for our research on early human migrations?

Looking forward to hearing back from you and hopefully catching up soon!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Rivera <jrivera@environmentalethicsuniversity.edu>
To: Alex Chen <achen@appliedethicscollege.org>
Subject: Guest Lecture Invitation - "Climate Change and Its Moral Implications for Humans and Animals"

Dear Alex,

I hope this email finds you well. I was recently thinking about our conversations on the moral implications of climate change and how it affects both human and non-human animals, and I thought it would be fantastic to have you as a guest speaker in my "Environmental Justice and Animal Rights" class this semester.

I believe your insights on this topic would be invaluable to my students, and it would be a great opportunity for them to engage with a leading expert in the field. If you're interested, the lecture could be titled "Climate Change and Its Moral Implications for Humans and Animals."

Please let me know your thoughts and availability. I would be thrilled to have you join us and contribute to the conversation.

Best regards,
Jordan

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <nguyen@riverview.edu>
To: Javier Rodríguez <rodriguez@riverview.edu>
Subject: Re: Econometrics and Linguistics Collaboration

Hi Javier,

I hope you're doing well. I've been thinking more about our potential research project, and I had a few ideas I wanted to share with you.

One of the challenges we might face is finding a suitable dataset that contains both economic and linguistic variables. We could potentially use a corpus of texts from different regions and time periods, and then collect economic data for those same regions and time periods. What do you think?

I also wanted to discuss the statistical methods we might use for the analysis. Since we'll be working with both numerical and categorical variables, we'll need to choose models that can handle this type of data. I have some experience with mixed-effects models, but I'm open to other suggestions.

Let me know your thoughts on these ideas. I'm excited to continue brainstorming with you!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Michael Smith <msmith@university.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Interdisciplinary Course Planning

Emily,

Thank you for your email and for sharing your ideas. I agree that we should focus on key concepts in evolutionary biology and use innovative teaching methods to help students understand these complex topics.

However, I think we should also consider incorporating some current research findings on the evolution of glycosylated proteins and their functions in mammalian organisms. This could provide students with a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying evolution and how they relate to the bigger picture.

In terms of teaching methodologies, I believe we should also include some computer simulations and modeling activities to help students visualize and explore evolutionary processes. This could complement the other teaching methods you mentioned and provide a more comprehensive learning experience.

I'm happy to work with you to further develop these ideas and create a course that effectively combines our expertise in biology and education. Please let me know your thoughts and if you have any suggestions for incorporating glycosylated proteins into the course.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@historyteacher.com>
To: Alex Johnson <alex.johnson@student.com>
Subject: Help with math concepts for new lesson plan

Hey Alex,

I hope your pre-calculus class is going well! I'm reaching out because I could use your help with some math concepts for a new lesson plan I'm developing. I'm creating a unit on the role of mathematics and cryptography during World War II, focusing on Alan Turing and the Enigma machine.

I know you're studying modular arithmetic and congruences right now, which is directly related to the math used in the Enigma machine. Would you be willing to help me understand these concepts better so I can incorporate them into my lesson plan? I'd really appreciate your expertise!

Let me know if you have any questions or if you're interested in collaborating on this project. I think it could be a great way to combine our interests and create an engaging learning experience for my students.

Thanks in advance,
Emily

Subject: RE: Book chapter revisions

Hi Samantha,

Thank you so much for your thoughtful feedback on my chapters! I agree that we should expand on the potential side effects and long-term impacts of the treatments. I'll make those revisions and send the updated draft back to you by early next week.

I've also been thinking about our presentation at the medical conference. I love the idea of incorporating some of the patient stories from the book. I think it will help to make the information more relatable and impactful for the audience. I can work on putting together an outline for our talk and send it your way for feedback.

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@historian.org>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@university.edu.au>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise on early colonial interactions

Emily,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad to see that you're delving into such an important topic. I've recently come across a fascinating primary source that I think might be of interest to you. It's a journal entry from a First Fleet officer that provides a detailed account of their initial interactions with the Indigenous people they encountered. I believe it could offer some valuable insights for your project.

I'd be happy to share a copy of the journal entry with you. Additionally, I can recommend a few other resources that might be relevant to your research. There's a book titled "Encounters: The First Fleet and Aboriginal Australians" that I found to be particularly informative.

I'm also considering attending a seminar on Indigenous land rights next month. I think it could be a great opportunity to learn more about the ongoing impact of colonial settlement on Indigenous communities. Would you be interested in joining me?

I look forward to discussing your project further and seeing what you uncover.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Dr. James Tremblay <jtremblay@university.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Holloway <eholloway@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Conference preparations and travel arrangements

Emily,

Thanks for your email. I've just finished reviewing the latest draft of our paper, and I must say, it looks excellent! The revisions you made really tie our arguments together nicely. I have a few minor suggestions for the conclusion, but overall, I believe we have a strong and compelling case.

As for the travel arrangements, I haven't booked my flights yet, but I will do so today. I agree that it would be best to coordinate our schedules to make the most of the pre-conference events. I'll let you know my flight details as soon as I have them.

I'm also excited about the potential impact our work could have on the field. The evidence we've uncovered challenges some long-held beliefs about Homo erectus and Neandertal interactions. I'm eager to see how our colleagues respond and engage with our findings.

Keep me posted on any further updates, and let's touch base again early next week to finalize our presentation.

Best,
James

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Hawkins <ehawkins@university.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Chen <mchen@usgs.gov>
Subject: New paper on fossil spatial analysis

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share with you my latest paper on a new statistical method for analyzing the spatial distribution of fossils in rock layers. I think you might find it interesting, given your work in geochronology and paleontology.

The paper is titled "A novel approach to quantifying the spatial structure of fossil assemblages using multi-scale point pattern analysis" and was just published in the Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology. I've attached a copy for your reference.

In the paper, I present a new method that combines geo-spatial analysis techniques with statistical tools to identify patterns in the distribution of fossils within rock layers. The method allows for a more detailed understanding of ancient ecosystems and can help us test hypotheses about the environmental factors that influenced the distribution of species in the past.

I'd be really interested to hear your thoughts on the paper and whether you think this approach could be useful for your own research. Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to discuss further!

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Reynolds <alex.reynolds@autotech.com>
To: Dr. Emily Chen <emily.chen@healthcareadvice.com>
Subject: Collaborating on an educational project

Hey Emily,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking about our conversations at the community center and how we both share a passion for breaking down complex topics for a general audience. I've been considering starting a blog or YouTube channel to share my knowledge of automotive electronics, and I think your teaching style and ability to make complex information easy to understand would be a great asset.

I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on a project that combines our expertise in automotive electronics and medication management. I think we could create some really engaging and informative content that would help people better understand these topics.

Let me know what you think! If you're interested, we could meet up for coffee sometime to discuss the idea in more detail.

Best regards,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Emily Chen <emily.chen@automationtech.com>
To: Jordan Smith <jordan.smith@university.edu>
Subject: RE: RE: RE: RE: Conference Follow-up

Hi Jordan,

I'm getting excited for our call on Tuesday! I've been doing some brainstorming and I think I have a few ideas that could really help with your fossil excavation process. I can't wait to share them with you and get your feedback.

Your research on archosaurs sounds absolutely fascinating. I've always been interested in the evolution of dinosaurs and their close relatives, so I'm eager to learn more about your latest discoveries. It's amazing how much we can learn about the past by studying fossils.

I also wanted to mention that I'm a big fan of hiking and spending time outdoors. If our collaboration goes well, maybe we could celebrate with a hiking trip sometime! I know a few great trails in the area that offer some stunning views.

Anyway, I don't want to ramble on too much before our call. I'll see you on Tuesday!

Best,
Emily

<email>
From: Emily Stone <estone@geotherm.org>
To: David Patel <dpatel@hivax.org>
Subject: RE: Following up from GIRI conference

Hi David,

That's fantastic news about the progress in your research! Identifying new vaccine targets is a critical step forward. I'd be very interested to hear more about the challenges you're facing in optimizing immunogenicity. There might be some parallels with challenges in geothermal energy research that could inspire fresh approaches.

Setting up a call is a great idea. I'm generally available next week, either Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning. Let me know which works best for you, and we can find a suitable time slot.

In the meantime, I'll do some digging into the potential applications of geothermal energy in vaccine research facilities. I might have some colleagues who have looked into similar concepts, so I'll touch base with them as well.

Looking forward to our discussion!

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Sophia Nguyen <sophia.nguyen@who.int>
To: Liam O'Connor <liam.oconnor@littlelearnersdaycare.com>
Subject: Collaborating on a project to promote child health through storytelling

Dear Liam,

It was great meeting you at the Child Health and Development Conference last month. I was impressed by your presentation on the power of storytelling in early childhood education and thought your approach could be a great complement to my work on adolescent non-communicable diseases prevention at WHO.

I'm reaching out to explore the possibility of collaborating on a project that combines our expertise. I believe that by integrating health education and storytelling, we could create engaging and effective educational materials for young children to promote healthy habits and prevention strategies.

Would you be interested in discussing this further? I'd love to hear your thoughts and ideas on how we could work together to make a positive impact on child health and education.

Best regards,
Sophia

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@lincolnhigh.org>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@lincolnhigh.org>
Subject: Collaborating on a genetics and history project?

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I was at a conference recently and was inspired to create a project for our students that combines genetics and the history of its discovery. I immediately thought of you and your amazing work with primary sources and digital archives in history class.

Would you be interested in collaborating on this project? I think it could be a great way to engage students and help them see the connections between science and history. We could create lesson plans that incorporate primary sources related to key figures and events in the history of genetics, and design activities that encourage critical thinking and analysis.

Let me know what you think! I'd love to brainstorm ideas with you and see if this is something we could pursue.

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@childdev.org>
To: Alex Chen <alex.chen@codecraftedu.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting collaboration opportunity

Dear Alex,

Thank you for reaching out! I have also been reflecting on our stimulating discussions at the conference. The potential of combining our approaches to create a comprehensive educational experience is truly exciting.

I would be delighted to have a more in-depth conversation about this collaboration. Next week works well for me. How about we schedule a call for Tuesday afternoon, say 2 pm EST? That way, we can align our visions and start outlining a plan for moving forward.

I look forward to speaking with you and exploring the possibilities of this partnership.

Best regards,
Emily Nguyen, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor, Department of Developmental Psychology
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Priya Patel <priya.patel@greentech.com>
To: Alex Chen <alex.chen@ecoecon.com>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the Eco-Econ Summit!

Alex,

Thank you for reaching out! I equally enjoyed meeting you and our engaging discussions during the conference. Your insights on market structures and competition in the green economy were truly eye-opening.

I would be delighted to continue our conversation and explore potential research opportunities together. Please do send over the articles and papers you mentioned. I'm particularly interested in the work you referenced on economic incentives for adopting sustainable technologies.

I'll be in Boulder again next month for a workshop, and I would love to take you up on that hike or meal. Let me know your availability, and we can plan something.

Looking forward to collaborating with you!

Best,
Priya

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <alex.rivera@ancientaquatics.org>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@nativeconservation.net>
Subject: Exciting discovery - need your expertise!

Hi Jordan,

I hope this email finds you well. I was just reminiscing about our time at the conference and the great discussions we had about the intersection of our fields. I've made an incredible discovery that I think you'll be particularly interested in.

While conducting a survey in a remote area, I stumbled upon what appears to be a previously unknown fish weir site. The structure is remarkably well-preserved, and I believe it could provide valuable insights into the ancient fishing practices and the surrounding ecosystem at the time of its construction.

I immediately thought of you and your expertise in native plant species. I was hoping you could join me on this project and help me analyze the plant life in and around the site. Your input could be crucial in dating the weir and understanding its environmental context.

I know you're busy, but I would be thrilled to have you on board. Please let me know if you're interested, and we can discuss the details further.

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Ethan Thompson <ethan@pastandpresentblog.com>
To: Dr. Olivia Chen <ochen@innovativeoncology.com>
Subject: Collaboration opportunity

Hey Olivia,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking a lot about our conversations and your fascinating work in thermal medicine. I truly believe that my readers would be captivated by your research and the potential of this alternative treatment. 

I know you're hesitant about writing for a blog, but I have a proposal for you. What if we collaborated on a guest post? You could provide the technical details and findings, and I would help make it accessible and engaging for a general audience. It would be a great way to raise awareness about your work and the future of cancer treatment.

Let me know what you think! If you're interested, I can send you some more information about my blog, audience, and the kind of content I usually produce. I'm excited about the possibility of working together and sharing your groundbreaking research with the world.

Best regards,
Ethan
