From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: tom.wilbeck@enron.com
Subject: Re: technical help for interviewing traders
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Tom Wilbeck
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Jun2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

In regards to gas:
what signals do you for in determining your view?
what resources do you use to formulate a price view?
give example of complex transaction you've structured for a customer.
where is storage now relative to history? what is the highest and lowest 
level we've been at in past 5 years?
what are your short, medium, and long term views of gas market?
what major basis changes have occured in the market over the past 5 years? 
What do you expect in the next 5?
how should a storage operator decide whether or not to inject on any given 
day?

In regards to derivatives in order of difficulty
What are delta/gamma/theta?
if you buy a put spread, is your delta positive, negative, or zero?
Is swap price equal to simple average of futures contracts?
If interest rates go up what happens to option prices all else equal?
what is the value of a european $1 call expiring in 12 months if 
corresponding futures are trading $5?
what happens to delta of an option if volatility increase?




From: Tom Wilbeck/ENRON@enronXgate on 03/23/2001 03:35 PM

Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT

Subject: technical help for interviewing traders

Jeanie Slone was telling me that you were among the best interviewers in the 
trading group.  Because of your expertise in this area, I was wondering if 
you could help me put some technical questions together that you've found to 
be effective in interviewing Gas Traders.

Norma Hasenjager is in our Omaha office needs this information ASAP in order 
to help her screen some candidates.  It would be great if you could respond 
to this with two or three questions that you've used in the past to select 
good Gas Traders.

Thanks for your help.

Tom Wilbeck
EWS Training and Development

From: Emily Jones <ejones@fossilrecordanalysis.com>
To: Alex Chen <achen@autocadguru.net>
Subject: RE: Introduction and Collaboration on Paleontology Course

Hi Alex,

Thank you for your email and the course outline you shared. I really like your idea of including interactive 3D models of fossils – it will definitely enhance the learning experience. However, I think we should also include some additional content on the geological context of these fossils and how they fit into the larger picture of Earth's history.

I've made some suggestions and edits to the outline, which I've attached to this email. Please feel free to review and provide your thoughts. I'm open to further discussion and refinement.

Regarding our call, Wednesday morning works great for me. Please send over the calendar invite whenever convenient.

I'm excited to see how this course takes shape and am looking forward to our collaboration!

Best,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Evelyn Blackwell <e.blackwell@paleospiders.com>
To: Samuel Grey <s.grey@arachnidsuniverse.edu>
Subject: RE: Intriguing discussion at the ICA conference

Dear Samuel,

Thank you for reaching out, and I'm glad to hear that our discussions at the conference left a lasting impression. Your research on the new species of Salticidae jumping spider with unique mimicry abilities sounds truly remarkable, and I would be very interested in learning more about your findings.

The potential link between modern spider behavior and their ancient ancestors is a fascinating area of research, and I believe that our combined expertise could indeed lead to some groundbreaking discoveries. The newly discovered fossil site in Mongolia is an extraordinary opportunity to gather valuable data and specimens that could shed light on the evolutionary history of spider mimicry and communication.

I would be delighted to discuss the possibility of a collaboration and the joint grant application in more detail. Perhaps we could set up a video call next week to share our latest research findings and explore the potential for a joint project?

Looking forward to hearing back from you soon.

Best regards,
Evelyn Blackwell, PhD
Associate Professor of Palaeoarachnology
Paleospiders Institute
label: research

To:	Frevert, Mark; Whalley, Greg; Lavorato, John; Kitchen, Louise; Mcconnell, Mike; Piper, Greg; Horton, Stanley; Sherriff, John; Glisan, Ben; Colwell, Wes; Deffner, Joseph; Presto, Kevin M.; Duran, W. David; Calger, Christopher F.; Belden, Tim; Allen, Phillip K.; Milnthorp, Rob; Palmer, Mark S.; Dyson, Fernley; Despain, Tim; Lawyer, Larry; Fallon, Jim; Cox, David; Rice, Ken
Cc:	Rieker, Paula
Subject:	Goldman Comment re: Enron issued this morning - Revised Price Target of $68/share

For your information - 

This morning Goldman issued a brief report following their visit with Enron Management on Monday.  
Their revised price target is $68/share.  
Many of the recent issues driving causing downward pressure on the stock are discussed.

body:
<email>
From: Dr. David Theriot <dtheriot@ulafayette.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakwoodms.org>
Subject: RE: Inquiry about Acadian history resources

Dear Ms. Johnson,

Thank you for reaching out, and I'm delighted to hear about your curriculum project. As someone who is passionate about Acadian history and its role in shaping the unique culture of Louisiana, I would be more than happy to assist you in any way I can.

I think it's wonderful that you're incorporating primary sources and historical documents into your lessons. Some excellent resources to consider include:

1. The "Memorial of the French Inhabitants of Louisiana to the King of France" (1755)
2. The "Treaty of Paris" (1763)
3. First-hand accounts from Acadian deportees during the Grand Dérangement (1755-1764)
4. Newspaper articles from the time period discussing the Acadians' plight

In terms of engaging lesson ideas, I've found that role-playing activities, where students take on the perspectives of different historical figures, can be incredibly effective in helping them understand the complexities of the time period.

I'm also happy to provide some broader historical context and analysis to help frame the materials you incorporate into your lessons.

Please feel free to reach out with any other questions or requests. I look forward to working with you on this important project.

Best regards,
David Theriot
label: research

[IMAGE]	Fantasy Football Newsletter	
  November 23, 2001  		


	
     [IMAGE]Fantasy Sports     [IMAGE]Fantasy Football     [IMAGE]CBS SportsLine.com 	
	


  Welcome to another edition of the 2001 Fantasy Football Newsletter!      The Fantasy Football newsletter will arrive in your e-mail inbox every Friday. We'll include news about the web site; tips on using all the features available; and answers to your player-related questions from the "Gridiron Guru."   	[IMAGE]	Inside      ? Thanksgiving Football   ? Sortable Standings   ? Gridiron Guru   ? Tip of the Week   	


 [IMAGE]  [IMAGE]  [IMAGE]  	


    Thanksgiving Football     Remember that two NFL games will be played on Thursday: Packers vs. Lions at 12:30 PM ET and Broncos vs. Cowboys at 4:05 PM ET. Fantasy 2001 players, if you have players from these four teams on your roster, they must have their final status (active or reserve) set 5 minutes before the start of their game. Please keep in mind that you also will not be able to enter any new add/drops for the week starting one hour prior to Thursday's first kickoff. Football Commissioner players, check with your league's commissioner to see how your lineup deadline is handled this week.  	


    Sortable Standings     Did you know that every column on your Standings page is sortable? Click the category name at the top of any column to sort the report by the results of that category. In head- to-head leagues, the Standings report is displayed in order of the teams with the best win/loss percentage. However, you can click the PF (Points For) column to display the top point-scoring teams at the top; or the PA (Points Against) column to display, in descending order, the teams with the most fantasy points scored against them.  	


    Gridiron Guru     Welcome to Gridiron Guru, where we'll answer your questions about players and offer Fantasy Football roster advice. We invite you to send your own scouting reports and comments on players to: gridguru@commissioner.com . You'll get the chance to be heard by thousands of Fantasy players just like yourself!   	


  Question - Marcus Howell     Who would you start in Week 11: Brian Griese  at Dallas or Jake Plummer at San Diego?    Answer - GG     Griese's receiving corps has been crippled by injuries  this season, and with Rod Smith questionable with an ankle  injury, the outlook gets dimmer. The Denver QB has been  bothered by physical problems this year as well. Plummer  seems like a better choice after a superb Week 10 outing. But  remember that he was facing the 0-9 Lions, and Plummer has  never been able to string many good performances together in  the past. He will be facing a San Diego defense that will be  primed for a good performance after getting burned badly by  Oakland last week. Go with Griese, who should at least post  respectable numbers at Dallas.  	


  Question - Eric Fernau     Which three running backs should I start?  I  have Corey Dillon, Ricky Williams, Duce Staley, Priest  Holmes and Garrison Hearst.    Answer - GG     Dillon is a must-start player every week. Holmes is  facing a Seattle defense that looks good statistically, but  will have a lot of trouble containing him on the outside.  Staley should have little trouble ripping through the  Washington front wall. It's hard to ignore Hearst at  Indianapolis or Williams in any week, but we like Dillon,  Holmes and Staley, especially the latter in an NFC East game.  	


  Question - Jay Rassat     Who do I start this week at quarterback? I have  Tom Brady, Aaron Brooks and Trent Green. The defenses they  play against are all decent (N.O., N.E. and Seattle).    Answer - GG     Brady and Brooks square off against each other, and  each is facing a secondary that can give up the big play.  Green will be facing a Seattle team that won't offer much of  a pass rush, but he is less explosive than Brooks or Brady.  With Brady having the advantage of playing at home, and Drew  Bledsoe looking over his shoulder, we'll go with the New  England QB.  	


    Tip of the Week      Ryan Carter, Watertown, CT: Ricky Watters' decision to not  have shoulder surgery is bad news for him, but great news for  people like me, who have Shaun Alexander. I would not be  surprised to see Watters not play again this year. Ricky's a  great back, and I wish him well, but you cannot replace a  back like Alexander.  	


  This message has been provided free of charge and free of obligation. If you prefer not to receive emails of this nature please send an email to remove@commissioner.com . Do not respond to this email directly.

body:
<email>
From: Maria Rodriguez <maria.rodriguez@university.edu>
To: David Hernandez <david.hernandez@university.edu>
Subject: Exciting discovery in Puerto Rico!

David,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share some incredible news with you. While digging through the archives at the University of Puerto Rico, I stumbled upon a collection of letters between Puerto Rican independence activists from the late 19th century. The letters discuss the role of genetics in shaping the island's identity and resisting colonial oppression.

I immediately thought of our research project and how these letters could provide valuable context for our work. I've attached a few scanned copies of the most relevant letters for you to take a look at.

What do you think about incorporating these letters into our study? I believe they could offer a unique perspective on the intersection of history, genetics, and social justice in Puerto Rico.

Let me know your thoughts!

Best regards,
Maria
label: research

Subject: Summary of Today's Meeting
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: mery.l.brown@accenture.com@ENRON
X-To: pallen@enron.com
X-cc: donald.l.barnhart@accenture.com, kmcdani@enron.com, Frolov, Yevgeny </O=ENRON/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=YFROLOV>
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Deleted Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Phillip,

Here are the key points that came out of today's meeting:

1. We will move Conversion and Arbitrage from the Simulation layer into the
Knowledge System layer. We will incorporate 5-10 problems of each type.

2. You will provide us with the name(s) of people who can give us content
for these problems. We will set up two rounds of meetings; one early next
week to gather content and a second meeting for review.

3. We will change "Gas Daily Risk" to "Intra-Month Risk" throughout the
simulation. Can you provide us with a definition of Intra-Month risk?

4. Just to clarify: For conversion, we were planning to cover problems
where there is no perfect hedge so the learner has to find creative ways to
hedge, as opposed to conversion of mmBTU to decatherms, conversion of oil
volumes to natural gas volumes, etc. Is that what you had in mind too?

Thank you in advance for your help. Have a great Thanksgiving.
Mery

<email>
From: Jenna Thompson <jenna.thompson@dhhedconsultant.com>
To: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@inclusiveschools.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on creating an inclusive environment

Hi Alex,

Thank you for your ongoing support and encouragement. It means so much to me to have a trusted colleague and mentor like you to turn to as I navigate this new role.

I love your idea of co-authoring an article or presenting at a conference together! That could be a fantastic way to share our insights and experiences with a broader audience and to amplify our impact. I would be thrilled to collaborate with you on a project like that. Let's touch base soon to brainstorm some specific ideas and to identify potential outlets or events where we could share our work.

In the meantime, I will keep you posted on my progress and will definitely reach out with any questions or updates. I'm so grateful for your partnership and for the opportunity to work together to create more inclusive and equitable schools.

Thank you again for everything!
Warmly,
Jenna

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, Timothy M Norton/HOU/ECT@ECT, John 
Griffith/Corp/Enron@Enron, Dutch Quigley/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Re: SMUD deal Asian options  

John,

Thank you for your flexibility regarding the asian option we purchased from 
you (average Feb-Aug GD HH settle).  Unfortunately, our customer would like 
to settle on 7 days, using the preceding day for any day for which Gas Daily 
is not published (i.e., Friday prices would be used for Saturday and Sunday) 
- so I know it's not your preference, but I need to take advantage of your 
offer.

Regards,
Gary
x31511





John Arnold
10/08/2000 02:05 PM
To: Gary Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Re: SMUD deal Asian options  

I can do it either way but would much rather just make it the simple average 
of prices, 5 per week.



   
	
	
	From:  Gary Taylor                           10/05/2000 07:25 PM
	

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Griffith/Corp/Enron@Enron
cc:  
Subject: SMUD deal Asian options

John(s),

How will the Asian options we purchased from the gas desk settle with respect 
to weekends... will the average of every day's gas daily settle mean the 
average of only the days on which Gas Daily is published?  or will it triple 
count each Friday's or Monday's price to account for the weekend (with a 
similar calculation on weekends).  I assume it is the former, not the 
latter.  Is this correct?  Are you indifferent if we want to switch to the 
latter?  Intuitively, it would seem to me that at this point, it wouldn't 
matter (because Friday or Monday prices are just as likely to be above the 
average as below the average), but you're wearing the risk, not us - so let 
me know.

Frankly, we don't have a preference as a desk, except that we need the 
settlement to be consistent with the deal we are entering into with SMUD.  
SMUD has questioned our calculation and I need to know how much I need to 
argue for one or the other.

Regards,
Gary
x31511

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: torrey.moorer@enron.com
X-From: Peter Berzins
X-To: David Forster, John Arnold, Dutch Quigley
X-cc: Torrey Moorer
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

The EOL Reporting Database treats any distinct deal number as a separate 
unique deal.  An example would be a deal done with KUKUI Inc. on November 
8th, 2000.  It is booked as deal numbers Q86409.1, Q86409.2, Q86409.3, and 
Q86409.4.  These are four separate and unique deal numbers and therefore 
count as a total of four deals.     

We understand that the trade desk may consider the deal in this example as 
just one large deal with 4 different parts.  Unfortunately,  the EOL 
Reporting Database has no way of telling whether or not these types of deals 
are distinct different deals or part of one larger deal.  Since this 
currently can not be known, the EOL Reporting Database uses the most 
conservative approach and counts them all as individual deals.  This results 
in a higher OTC deal count and thus a lower EOL percentage of all deals.

If you have any further questions , please don't hesitate to ask.

Pete Berzins
x57597
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
To: Daniel Lee <dlee@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Conference preparations

Hi Daniel,

I'm so glad you like the revisions! I'll incorporate your suggestions for additional examples this weekend. Dinner on the 15th sounds great - I'll do some research on the best restaurants in the area and send you my top picks.

I completely agree with you about the potential impact of our research. It's been such a rewarding collaboration, and I'm excited to see where it takes us next. Speaking of which, have you given any more thought to the idea of publishing our work in an academic journal? I think it could really help us reach a wider audience and get more feedback from our peers.

Let me know what you think, and I'll start looking into potential journals that might be a good fit for our paper.

See you soon in Chicago!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <arivera@underwater-heritage.org>
To: Jordan Lee <jlee@chem-research.edu>
Subject: RE: Visiting your lab during my trip to Oakville

Jordan,

Thank you so much for accommodating my visit on such short notice. I'm thrilled that we'll have the opportunity to discuss our research in person.

If possible, I'd love to learn more about the chemical analysis techniques you use for dating and understanding the composition of archaeological materials. I think this could be particularly relevant to my work on prehistoric fish weirs and the materials used in their construction.

I'm also interested in any insights you might have on how the mole concept could be applied to archaeological chemistry. I've been reading up on it since our last conversation, and I think there could be some exciting possibilities for our collaboration.

Please let me know if there's anything I can do to prepare for our meeting. I'm eager to learn from you and your team.

Best,
Alex
label: research

rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's
you bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?
what you charge me play against you?)

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Liam O'Connor <loconnor@agpestcontrol.com.au>
To: Dr. Amelia Hoffman <ahoffman@radiationbiology.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting research opportunity

Dear Amelia,

Next Friday, April 16th, at 10 AM AEST works perfectly for me. I'll send you a calendar invite with the video conference details. I've also reached out to my contacts at the Australian Research Council and have a meeting scheduled with them next week to discuss our project.

I'm glad to hear that your daughter, Sophia, is also interested in science. Finn would be thrilled to meet her. Let's plan a weekend get-together once we have made some progress on our project. Perhaps we could visit a local science museum or organize a picnic in a park where the kids can explore nature together.

I'm equally excited about the potential impact our collaboration could have on public health and agriculture. With our combined expertise, I believe we can make significant strides in this innovative research.

Looking forward to our video conference next week.

Best regards,
Liam

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@vectorhealth.org>
To: Dr. Raj Patel <rpatel@infectiousdiseases.com>
Subject: Concerns about the new Zika strain

Dear Dr. Patel,

I hope this email finds you well. I recently came across some disturbing news about a new strain of the Zika virus that has been identified in our region. As you know, we've been working together to address vector-borne diseases for years now, and I believe this development warrants our immediate attention.

Given your expertise in infectious diseases and your connections in Singapore, I was wondering if you might have any insights or recommendations on how we can tackle this emerging threat. I'm particularly interested in learning more about the vector control program you mentioned during our last webinar, as I believe it could be a valuable model for us to consider here in Miami.

Would you be available for a call next week to discuss this further? I'd love to brainstorm some ideas and explore potential collaborative efforts to address this outbreak.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
Vector-Borne Disease Prevention and Control
City of Miami

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Rivera <jordan.rivera@archaeologist.com>
To: Alex Patterson <alex.patterson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Triassic-Human Interaction Project Update

Alex,

Thanks for the update! I'm thrilled to hear about the new fossil data and can't wait to dive into your analysis. I'll review everything this weekend and send you my feedback early next week.

I'm also excited about the hiking plans you've been working on. It's going to be incredible to see these sites in person and imagine what life was like for both the reptiles and humans who inhabited the region millions of years ago.

On a separate note, I came across an interesting article about the use of reptile bones as tools by early humans in the American Southwest. I'll forward it to you, as I think it could provide some valuable context for our research.

I'm looking forward to our call next week and discussing our next steps for the project. Let me know if there's anything else I can do to help in the meantime.

Best,
Jordan

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Chen <echen@gihealth.com>
To: Alex Thompson <athompson@networkgenius.com>
Subject: RE: Annual Hiking Trip - Your Input Needed!

Hi Alex,

It's great to hear from you! I'm thrilled that you're taking the lead on planning our hiking trip this year. Both the Rocky Mountains and the Pacific Northwest sound amazing, but I think I'd lean towards the coastal hike. There's just something magical about the ocean breeze and the rugged coastline that I find incredibly refreshing.

As for your gastroenterologist appointment, try not to worry too much. The doctor will likely start with a thorough medical history and physical exam, and then discuss any necessary tests or procedures. Remember, they're there to help you, so don't hesitate to ask questions or voice any concerns you may have. If you'd like, I can recommend a fantastic gastroenterologist in your area who I think you'd really like.

On another note, I've been giving a lot of thought to that job offer I mentioned. It's a fantastic opportunity, but the thought of leaving my current practice and moving away from friends and family is really weighing on me. I know I can always count on your objective perspective, so I'd love to chat more about this when we have a chance.

Let me know what you think about the coastal hike, and we can start making more concrete plans. I'm excited to get out on the trails with you again!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Samantha Jones <samantha.jones@cybersecure.com>
To: Michael Chen <michael.chen@cybersecure.com>
Subject: RE: Urgent: Multiple clients targeted by sophisticated malware attack

Michael,

Thanks for your prompt response. I've just finished analyzing the network traffic logs from one of the affected clients, and I found something disturbing. The malware seems to have been delivered through a spear-phishing email that originated from within the client's own network. This suggests that the attackers may have had help from an insider.

I've attached the relevant logs for your review. Can you take a look and let me know your thoughts?

Also, I'll join the call at 2 PM. In the meantime, I'll continue working on identifying the extent of the damage and gathering more evidence.

Best,
Samantha

Date: Mon, 30 Apr 2001 03:37:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: keith.holst@enron.com
Subject: Request from Steve Kean
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Keith Holst
X-cc: 
X-bcc:

X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 04/30/2001 
10:36 AM ---------------------------


Alan Comnes
04/27/2001 01:38 PM
To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Joe Hartsoe/Corp/Enron@ENRON 
Subject: Request from Steve Kean

Phillip,

I got this request.  On the gas side, I think Kean/Lay need an update to a 
table you prepared for me a few months ago, which I've attached..  Can you 
oblige?  Thanks,

Alan Comnes



---------------------- Forwarded by Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT on 04/27/2001 01:42 
PM ---------------------------


Janel Guerrero@ENRON
04/27/2001 12:44 PM
To: Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron
cc: Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron 

Subject: Request from Steve Kean

Alan,

Steve has asked that you update the power point below so that it reflects all 
of the "stupid regulatory/legislative decisions" since the beginning of the 
year.  Ken wants to have this updated chart in his briefing book for next 
week's "Ken Lay Tour" to CA.  

He also wants a forward price curve for both gas and power in CA.  Can we get 
these three documents by Monday afternoon?
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@languageacademy.com>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@languageacademy.com>
Subject: Workshop feedback and future collaborations

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to thank you again for your fantastic collaboration during the professional development workshop. The feedback we received from our colleagues was overwhelmingly positive, and I believe our presentation made a significant impact.

Several teachers approached us after the workshop, expressing their interest in implementing some of our strategies in their classrooms. I think this is a testament to the effectiveness of our collaborative approach.

I'd love to continue working with you on more projects and share our knowledge with other teachers in the school. Perhaps we can organize a series of workshops or create a resource bank for our colleagues to access.

Let me know your thoughts, and let's schedule a meeting to discuss our next steps.

Best regards,
Sarah
label: research

body:
Message-ID: <20263860.1075857578123.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 2000 03:41:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: andy.zipper@enron.com
Subject: Re:
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Andy Zipper
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Thanks.




Andy Zipper@ENRON
07/19/2000 08:27 AM
To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Re:  

By the version of EOL do you mean the new version of stack manager ? If you 
do, we should have finished testing by today. That means we will roll out 
today or tomorrow, but Louise wants a more developed roll out plan, so that 
might slow things down a bit. Not to make excuses, but we have had some 
serious technical problems with the new release and have had to redesign 
whole parts of the back end of the system. The problem is around how many 
things can be linked to a single product and stack manager performance, 
obviously a serious issue. It has taken us, obviously, a lot longer than we 
thought to fix it. I think there are still some minor issues that we should 
discuss, but they should not get in the way of release.

If you mean by new version, the phase II website version with sexy content, 
we are scheduled (cum grano salis) to roll that out in mid august.

any questions please feel free to call.

-andy
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@publichealth.gov>
To: Alex Novak <alex.novak@unexplainedmedia.net>
Subject: RE: Strange occurrences and vector-borne diseases

Alex,

Thank you for your prompt response. I'm glad to hear you're as intrigued by this mystery as I am. I would be more than happy to discuss my experience in Pineville and any potential environmental factors I noticed during my trip.

Next week works well for me to set up a call and plan our research trip to Willow Creek. I'm available on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning, if either of those times work for you. I'll also start gathering any relevant data and resources we might need for our field research.

I'm looking forward to working together on this project and uncovering the truth behind these mysterious occurrences.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Ellis <j.ellis@cei.edu>
To: Emily Nguyen <e.nguyen@cei.edu>
Subject: RE: Unusual feature on Io

Hi Emily,

Great to hear that you're as excited about this finding as I am! I'm glad you agree that it could be a significant discovery. I think collaborating with our colleagues at the institute is an excellent idea. Their expertise in planetary geology and volcanism will be invaluable in interpreting this data.

I'm available next Monday and Wednesday afternoons if that works for you. We could meet in the lab and go over the data together. Let me know what time suits you best.

Your section on Europa's subsurface ocean sounds fascinating! I think it will be a great addition to our presentation. I agree that highlighting the interdisciplinary nature of our research will showcase the strength of our collaboration.

I'll send you the latest draft of my section by the end of this week for your feedback. I'm happy to make any adjustments based on your suggestions.

Looking forward to our meeting next week!

Best,
Jordan
label: research

body:
Message-ID: <12558609.1075855378931.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 25 Apr 2001 18:57:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: ned.higgins@enron.com
Subject: Re: Unocal WAHA Storage
Cc: mike.grigsby@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: mike.grigsby@enron.com
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Ned Higgins <Ned Higgins/ENRON@enronXgate@ENRON>
X-cc: Mike Grigsby <Mike Grigsby/HOU/ECT@ECT>
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Jan2002_1\Allen, Phillip K.\'Sent Mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen (Non-Privileged).pst

Ned,

Regarding the Waha storage, the west desk does not have a strong need for this storage but we are always willing to show a bid based on the current summer/winter spreads and cycling value.  The following assumptions were made to establish our bid:  5% daily injection capacity, 10% daily withdrawal capacity, 1% fuel (injection only), 0.01/MMBtu variable injection and withdrawal fees.  Also an undiscounted  June 01 to January 02 spread of $0.60 existed at the time of this bid.

Bid for a 1 year storage contract beginning June 01 based on above assumptions:  $0.05/ MMBtu/Month ($0.60/Year).  Demand charges only.

I am not sure if this is exactly what you need or not.  Please call or email with comments.

Phillip Allen

---------------------- Forwarded by Jennifer N Stewart/NA/Enron on 12/04/2000 
08:45 AM ---------------------------
   
	
	
	From:  Jim Rountree                           12/04/2000 07:50 AM
	

To: Don Hawkins/OTS/Enron@Enron, Jennifer N Stewart/NA/Enron@Enron
cc:  

Subject: Vengas venue / Venezuela

I want to pass on my sincere appreciation for the excellent work and 
assistance from Colleen Koenig during last weeks crisis management program in 
Venezuela.  Colleen was more than helpful and provided services that I found 
invaluable.  She was extremely well liked by the senior management of Vengas 
and spent a great deal of time with them in creating an environment conducive 
to teamwork and productivity.  Her language skills, knowledge and personality 
provided an incredible resource.  Thanks for allowing my program her services 
and I look forward to working with her again in the future.

Jim Rountree
label: corporate

Russell:
My risk group frequently uses the New Counterparty label for internal 
counterparties that do not have a trading book.  This transaction was a hedge 
for the acquisition of the paper plant we announced recently.  I'm not sure 
who the internal group is that did the transaction.  Dutch Quigley should be 
able to help.
John.

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: New Counterparty Transaction

John

A trade came across our morning report listed as a 'New Counterparty'.  It 
was about 17BCF Swap from Sep "00  - Aug '07.  Can you give me some details 
on the counterparty.

Thank you,

Russell

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@stargazer.edu>
To: Alex Chen <alex.chen@cosmosresearch.org>
Subject: Following up from the Solar Physics Conference

Hi Alex,

It was great meeting you at the Solar Physics Conference last week! I really enjoyed our discussion about the historical advancements in solar research methodologies. I'm writing to share the article I mentioned about the application of machine learning techniques in analyzing solar data. I thought you might find it interesting given your research focus.

Let me know if you'd like to chat more about this topic or if you come across any other relevant articles. I'm always eager to learn from others in the field.

Best regards,
Emily

Subject: El Paso Energy Corporation Reports Record Second Quarter Earnings 
Per Share


http://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/000711/tx_el_paso_2.html

Tuesday July 11, 5:42 pm Eastern Time
Company Press Release
SOURCE: El Paso Energy Corporation
El Paso Energy Corporation Reports Record Second Quarter Earnings Per Share
HOUSTON, July 11 /PRNewswire/ -- El Paso Energy Corporation (NYSE: EPG
<http://finance.yahoo.com/q?s=epg&d=t> - news </n/e/epg.html>) today
announced second quarter 2000 adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.69,
an increase of 73 percent over second quarter 1999 adjusted diluted earnings
per share of $0.40. The second quarter 2000 results exclude $0.13 per share
of one-time merger-related items. Diluted average common shares outstanding
for the second quarter 2000 totaled 242 million. Consolidated adjusted
earnings before interest expense and income taxes (EBIT) for the second
quarter increased by 55 percent to $408 million, compared with $263 million
in the year-ago period.
EBIT from the company's non-regulated businesses more than tripled in the
quarter to $246 million, and represented 60 percent of consolidated EBIT.
``Outstanding growth in Merchant Energy and continued strong performance in
our other non-regulated segments produced these record results,'' said
William A. Wise, president and chief executive officer of El Paso Energy
Corporation. ``Reflecting our long-standing strategy of building a portfolio
of flexible gas and power assets, Merchant Energy's earnings continued to
accelerate in the second quarter.''
For the first six months of 2000, adjusted diluted earnings per share
increased 84 percent to $1.40 per share, compared with $0.76 for the first
six months of 1999. Consolidated EBIT for the six months, excluding
non-recurring items, increased 55 percent to $798 million compared with $515
million in the year-ago period.
Second Quarter Business Segment Results
The Merchant Energy segment reported record EBIT of $152 million in the
second quarter 2000, compared with $6 million in the same period last year
and $50 million in the first quarter 2000. The physical and financial gas
and power portfolio developed over the past several years is creating
significant value in the current volatile energy environment. Enhanced
trading opportunities around our asset positions, continued strong wholesale
customer business, and management fees from Project Electron (the company's
off-balance sheet vehicle for power generation investments) all contributed
to the record second-quarter performance.
The Production segment reported a 30-percent increase in second quarter EBIT
to $52 million compared with $40 million a year ago, reflecting higher
realized gas and oil prices and lower operating costs following the
reorganization of its business in 1999. Weighted average realized prices for
the quarter were $2.26 per million cubic feet (MMcf) of natural gas and
$19.21 per barrel of oil, up 12 percent and 29 percent, respectively, from
the year-ago levels. Average natural gas production totaled 512 MMcf per day
and oil production averaged 14,275 barrels per day.
The Field Services segment reported second quarter EBIT of $30 million,
nearly double an adjusted $16 million in 1999. The increase was due
primarily to higher realized gathering and processing margins, together with
the acquisition of an interest in the Indian Basin processing plant in March
2000. Second quarter gathering and treating volumes averaged 4.1 trillion
Btu per day (TBtu/d), while processing volumes averaged 1.1 TBtu/d.
Coming out of one of the warmest winters on record, the Natural Gas
Transmission segment reported second quarter EBIT of $190 million compared
with an adjusted $187 million a year ago, reflecting the realization of cost
savings from the Sonat merger. Overall system throughput averaged 11.3
TBtu/d. During the quarter, Southern Natural Gas received Federal Energy
Regulatory Commission approval of its comprehensive rate case settlement
filed in March.
The International segment reported second quarter EBIT of $12 million
compared with $16 million in 1999. Higher equity income from projects in
Brazil and Argentina largely offset lower equity earnings from the company's
investment in the Philippines.
Telecom Update
``We have made substantial progress in the development of our
telecommunications business, El Paso Global Networks,'' said William A.
Wise. ``Reflecting our market-centric approach to developing new businesses,
we have named Greg G. Jenkins, the current president of El Paso Merchant
Energy, to head our telecommunications business. Our expertise in building
businesses in rapidly commoditizing markets, as demonstrated by our Merchant
Energy success, provides us with a key competitive entry point in the
telecommunications marketplace.''
Quarterly Dividend
The Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.206 per share on
the company's outstanding common stock. The dividend will be payable October
2, 2000 to shareholders of record as of the close of business on September
1, 2000. There were 237,786,853 outstanding shares of common stock entitled
to receive dividends as of June 30, 2000.
With over $19 billion in assets, El Paso Energy Corporation provides
comprehensive energy solutions through its strategic business units:
Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company, El Paso Natural Gas Company, Southern
Natural Gas Company, El Paso Merchant Energy Company, El Paso Energy
International Company, El Paso Field Services Company, and El Paso
Production Company. The company owns North America's largest natural gas
pipeline system, both in terms of throughput and miles of pipeline, and has
operations in natural gas transmission, merchant energy services, power
generation, international project development, gas gathering and processing,
and gas and oil production. On May 5, the stockholders of both El Paso
Energy and The Coastal Corporation overwhelmingly voted in favor of merging
the two organizations. The combined company will have assets of $35 billion
and be one of the world's leading integrated energy companies. The merger is
expected to close in the fourth quarter of this year, concurrent with the
completion of regulatory reviews. Visit El Paso Energy's web site at
www.epenergy.com <http://www.epenergy.com>.
Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements
This release includes forward-looking statements and projections, made in
reliance on the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation
Reform Act of 1995. The company has made every reasonable effort to ensure
that the information and assumptions on which these statements and
projections are based are current, reasonable, and complete. However, a
variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from the
projections, anticipated results or other expectations expressed in this
release. While the company makes these statements and projections in good
faith, neither the company nor its management can guarantee that the
anticipated future results will be achieved. Reference should be made to the
company's (and its affiliates') Securities and Exchange Commission filings
for additional important factors that may affect actual results.

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@nettechsolutions.com>
To: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@nettechsolutions.com>
Subject: RE: Long time no talk!

Sarah,

That's fantastic to hear that you're still at NetTech and working on projects you're passionate about. I've always admired your expertise in low-level network programming and your ability to optimize system performance. It's no wonder they've kept you around!

As for my startup idea, I've been developing a novel network protocol that aims to improve the efficiency and security of data transmission in distributed systems. I believe it could have applications in various industries, from cloud computing to IoT devices.

I'd love to share more details and get your input. How about we schedule a video call for next Tuesday at 3 PM? That way, we can discuss it in real-time and maybe even do a quick screen share if needed.

Let me know if that works for you, and feel free to bring any ideas you've been working on as well. I'm excited to collaborate and see what we can create together!

Best,
John

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@lexicography.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@conservationbiology.org>
Subject: RE: Conference proposal

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to follow up on our last email about the conference proposal. I've been thinking about our discussion and I think we have a really strong case for presenting our findings on the language used in scientific literature related to invasive species. 

I've attached a draft of the proposal for your review. Let me know what you think and if you have any suggestions for improvements. We can also discuss this further when we have our call next week.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Best,
Emily

George,

 Below is a list of questions that Keith and I had regarding the Westgate 
project:

 Ownership Structure

 What will be the ownership structure? Limited partnership? General partner?

 What are all the legal entities that will be involved and in what 
capacity(regarding ownership and 
 liabilities)?

 Who owns the land? improvements?

 Who holds the various loans?

 Is the land collateral?

 Investment
 
 What happens to initial investment?

 Is it used to purchase land for cash?Secure future loans?
 
 Why is the land cost spread out on the cash flow statement?

 When is the 700,000 actually needed? Now or for the land closing? Investment 
schedule?

 Investment Return

 Is Equity Repayment the return of the original investment?

 Is the plan to wait until the last unit is sold and closed before profits 
are distributed?

 Debt

 Which entity is the borrower for each loan and what recourse or collateral 
is associated with each 
 loan?

 Improvement

 Construction

 Are these the only two loans?  Looks like it from the cash flow statement.

 Terms of each loan?

 Uses of Funds

 How will disbursements be made?  By whom?

 What type of bank account?  Controls on max disbursement? Internet viewing 
for investors?

 Reports to track expenses vs plan?

 Bookkeeping procedures to record actual expenses?

 What is the relationship of Creekside Builders to the project?  Do you get 
paid a markup on subcontractors as a 
 general contractor and paid gain out of profits?

 Do you or Larry receive any money in the form of salary or personal expenses 
before the ultimate payout of profits?

 Design and Construction
 
 When will design be complete?

 What input will investors have in selecting design and materials for units?

 What level of investor involvement will be possible during construction 
planning and permitting?

 Does Creekside have specific procedures for dealing with subcontractors, 
vendors, and other professionals? 
 Such as always getting 3 bids, payment schedules, or reference checking?

 Are there any specific companies or individuals that you already plan to 
use? Names?

These questions are probably very basic to you, but as a first time investor 
in a project like this it is new to me.  Also, I want to learn as
much as possible from the process.

Phillip

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@sciencejournal.com>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Following up on our collaboration

Emily,

Thank you for sending your paper. I've just finished reading it, and I'm impressed by your findings. The correlation between linguistic patterns and genetic evidence is striking, and I believe our collaboration has the potential to make a significant impact on our understanding of human history.

I have a few ideas for our next steps:

1. Identify key linguistic and genetic markers that we can use to trace migration patterns more accurately.
2. Collaborate with other experts in the field to gather additional data and insights.
3. Outline a timeline for our research and publication goals.

I'd love to discuss these ideas further and hear your thoughts. Are you available for a video call next week?

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
Message-ID: <29039422.1075857570959.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Mon, 11 Dec 2000 05:27:00 -0800 (PST)
From: russell.dyk@enron.com
To: john.arnold@enron.com
Subject: LNG on the road
Cc: jennifer.fraser@enron.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: jennifer.fraser@enron.com
X-From: Russell Dyk
X-To: John Arnold
X-cc: Jennifer Fraser
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Re: trucking LNG to California - 

The short answer is that trucking LNG to California is not a feasible option 
for endusers other than companies with LNG-fueled vehicle fleets. There are a 
couple of reasons for this. 

First, California has a relative abundance of LNG fueling stations but only 
two plants capable of regasification. One serves Borrego Springs, a small, 
affluent desert community near San Diego. The other is dedicated to military 
and industrial supply near Sacramento. I spoke this morning to Applied LNG 
Technologies, which is based in Amarillo and has the second largest LNG truck 
fleet (after Transgas in Massachusetts). It shouldn't be a surprise that I 
was not the first to call regarding this question. While ALT's fleet is 
operating at capacity - trucking LNG from liquefaction plants in Wyoming and 
Topock, Arizona - it's serving its normal fleet customers in Southern 
California and Nevada, and Arizona. The Topock, AZ plant is owned jointly by 
ALT and El Paso, and receives gas from El Paso for liquefaction and 
subsequent loading onto trucks.

Second, LNG trucks, unlike LNG tankers, carry an extremely small volume. The 
average truck carries 10,000 gallons of LNG, which translates roughly into 
820,000 cubic feet. ALT has about 23 vehicles so potentially one could 
deliver 18.8 mmcf. However, these trucks don't regasify LNG, they merely 
transfer it into storage. 

The only really viable option for putting gas into the pipeline system would 
be a portable pipeline unit, of which ALT has the only one (it's under 
repair). It can deliver high pressure gas at 1800 cubic feet/minute (2.6 
mmcf/day if it runs 24 hours). It has connections for two LNG trucks at a 
time - one live and one backup, so it can operate continuously. In the past, 
ALT has used the unit to cover industrials who had a supply outage for some 
reason. 

I'm going to continue gathering info on domestic LNG peakshaving plants, etc. 
I think the opportunity may lie more in future, more strategically located 
peakshaving plants rather than LNG trucking arbitrage. 

Please let me know if you have specific questions.

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rodriguez <alex.rodriguez@endangeredspeciespolicy.org>
To: Jenna Erickson <jenna.erickson@wildlifeprotectors.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting news about the proposed amphibian protection policy!

Hi Jenna,

It's great to hear from you! Thanks for reaching out about this policy proposal. I've been following its development closely, and I'm thrilled that it's gaining traction. You're right, this could be a huge win for the Woodland Elktoad and other endangered amphibians.

I'd be more than happy to collaborate with you on this. My experience with policy advocacy, combined with your expertise in field conservation, could make a real difference in getting this proposal passed. I'm confident that together, we can make a strong case for the importance of protecting these critical habitats.

I'm available for a call on either Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning next week, so let me know which works best for you. In the meantime, I'll start gathering some data and case studies to support our arguments.

Looking forward to working with you on this important initiative!

Best,
Alex

<email>
From: Ethan Miller <ethan.miller@university.edu>
To: Olivia Nguyen <olivia.nguyen@researcher.com>
Subject: RE: Seeking your expertise on my War of 1812 book project

Olivia,

Thank you so much for your email and for sharing that fascinating diary excerpt. I can already see how it will be valuable for my research. I'll definitely check out Dr. Chen's work as well.

I'm thrilled to hear you'll be in D.C. next month! I'll be there for the same conference, so it would be wonderful to meet up. I'll be staying at the Marriott near the convention center. Let me know if you're free for coffee or dinner one evening.

Once again, I really appreciate your help and insights. It's always a pleasure to collaborate with a brilliant colleague like yourself.

All the best,
Ethan
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@university.edu>
To: Dr. Emily Chen <emily.chen@radiantlabs.com>
Subject: RE: RE: Radiation and Vaccine Efficacy Study

Dr. Chen,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm flattered that you consider my input valuable and I'm certainly interested in collaborating with you on this exciting project.

I've been doing some preliminary research on the potential effects of radiation on vaccine immunogenicity and I believe I have some insights that could contribute to your study. I'd be happy to discuss this further with you.

I'm available for a call next week, preferably in the afternoons. Please let me know what works best for your schedule.

Best,
Alex Thompson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@dentaltech.com>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@prosthodontics.com>
Subject: Seeking advice on a challenging prosthodontics case

Dear Dr. Thompson,

I hope this email finds you well. We met at the dental conference last month where you gave an excellent lecture on impression making techniques. Your insights were truly inspiring, and I was wondering if you might be willing to offer some guidance on a particularly challenging case I'm working on.

I'm a dental lab technician specializing in restorative dentistry, and I've been struggling to create a precise dental prosthesis for a patient with a complex case. I would greatly appreciate any advice or suggestions you might have to help me improve my technique and ensure the best possible outcome for my patient.

If you have any time in the coming weeks, I would be incredibly grateful for the opportunity to discuss this case with you further. Please let me know if you might be available for a brief phone call or video chat.

Thank you for considering my request. I look forward to hearing back from you.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: David Yang <david.yang@berkeley.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@virginia.edu>
Subject: RE: Following up on our discussion at the CFR conference

Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! It was a pleasure meeting you at the CFR conference as well, and I echo your sentiments on the value of our conversation. Your presentation on the effectiveness of conflict resolution strategies in post-war Iraq was quite insightful, and I believe our research interests align quite well.

I would be delighted to stay in touch and explore potential collaborations. As someone who has been in the field for some time now, I always appreciate the opportunity to work with bright, young scholars like yourself. Perhaps we could start by sharing some of our recent publications and discussing how they might inform a joint research project?

I'm particularly interested in the idea of examining the long-term consequences of military interventions, both in terms of their impact on regional stability and their implications for international relations more broadly. If you're open to it, I'd like to propose that we consider submitting a grant application to fund a more extensive study on this topic.

Please let me know your thoughts on this, and feel free to send over any materials you think might be relevant to our discussion. I'm looking forward to the possibility of working together.

Best regards,
David

Dear Ms. Johnson,

Thank you so much for sharing this article with me. I found it incredibly informative and inspiring. The research conducted on the impact of human activities on nutrient cycles has given me a deeper understanding of the challenges we face in preserving our local ecosystems.

I would love to discuss the article further with you and learn more about your experiences in the field of environmental science. If you have any recommendations for further reading or research opportunities, I would be grateful for your guidance.

Best regards,
Liam Thompson

Dear Lucas,

I hope you're doing well! I'm reaching out because I'm planning a research trip to Rio de Janeiro next month and I was hoping to get some advice from you, since you did your fieldwork there. I'll be there for about two weeks doing interviews and archival research related to my project on Brazil's transition to democracy.

Do you have any recommendations for places to stay, archives to visit, or people to talk to? I'd also love any general tips you have for navigating the city and making the most of my time there.

I know you're busy so no worries if you don't have time to write back in detail. But I'd really appreciate any thoughts you have!

All the best,
Ana

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@ridgewoodhigh.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@ridgewoodhigh.edu>
Subject: New project idea - Vocab and Physics

Hey Michael,

I hope you're having a great week so far! I wanted to run a new project idea by you that I think could be really engaging for our students. I was thinking about how we could combine vocabulary development with physics concepts, and I came up with an idea for a project called "The Physics of Language."

The basic premise is that students would choose a physics concept (like gravity, friction, or momentum) and then write a short story or poem that incorporates vocabulary words related to that concept. The story or poem would need to demonstrate an understanding of the physics concept and use the vocabulary words in a meaningful way.

I think this project could help our students see the connections between language and science, and it would give them a chance to be creative while also learning important concepts in both subjects. What do you think? Would you be interested in collaborating on this project with me?

Let me know your thoughts!

Best,
Emily
label: research

Enron employees not participating in contract parking are eligible to receive Metro Bus Passes or Woodlands Express Passes.  You may pick up a bus pass from the Parking & Transportation Desk, on Level 3 of the Enron Building, from 8:30 AM to 4:30 PM. 


All Metro passes offered through the Enron Parking & Transportation desk will be the Metro 30 Day Zone Pass.  When you use a 30-day zone pass, bus service is divided into four zones w/ unlimited rides.  The zone pass is time activated, which means that it will not become active until the first time it is used and will not expire until 30 days after it was used for the first time.  New passes will be available to Enron employees upon expiration of the 30 day time period. Each zone does have a different fare values based on the distance the bus travels. This is important to any buser who wants to transfer to or travel in a higher-cost zone than the zone pass they have, in this case the difference must be paid in cash.  If they are traveling in a lower cost zone, then there is no extra cost.

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Olivia Thompson <othompson@university.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@ridgewoodhigh.org>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on women's rights and politics lesson plan

Dear Emily,

It's wonderful to hear from you! I remember our meeting at the conference and am thrilled to hear that my talk had a lasting impact on you. I would be more than happy to assist you in developing your lesson plan on the intersection of women's rights and politics in the 20th century.

Some key figures and events that I believe are essential to include are:

1. The women's suffrage movement and the passage of the 19th Amendment in 1920
2. The role of women in the workforce during World War II and the subsequent push for equal pay
3. The Civil Rights Movement and the intersection of gender and race in the struggle for equality
4. The women's liberation movement of the 1960s and 70s, including the fight for reproductive rights and the Equal Rights Amendment
5. The impact of Title IX on women's education and athletics

As for resources, I highly recommend the following books:

- "The Woman Suffrage Movement in America" by Corrine M. McConnaughy
- "The Feminine Mystique" by Betty Friedan
- "Sisterhood is Powerful" edited by Robin Morgan
- "The Second Sex" by Simone de Beauvoir

I would be happy to discuss these topics further and provide additional resources if needed. Please feel free to reach out with any questions or concerns.

Best of luck with your lesson plan!

Warm regards,
Dr. Olivia Thompson
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Eleanor Wordsworth <eleanor.wordsworth@lexiconvilleuni.edu>
To: Dr. Benjamin Bateman <benjamin.bateman@batconservation.org>
Subject: Re: Bat Etymology Project

Dear Dr. Bateman,

I hope this email finds you well. I've been making excellent progress on our bat etymology project, and I wanted to share some of my latest findings with you.

I've discovered that the Old English term for "bat" was "flēogebȳgen," which literally translates to "flying bug." It's fascinating to see how the understanding of bats has evolved over time, and I believe this etymology could provide valuable insights into the historical perception of these creatures.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this and any other bat-related terms you think would be relevant to our research. Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Best regards,
Dr. Eleanor Wordsworth
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Davis <emily.davis@bellington.edu>
To: John Smith <john.smith@bellington.edu>
Subject: RE: Seeking advice on teaching Microeconomics

Dear John,

Welcome to the economics department at Bellington! It's great to hear about your interest in teaching Microeconomics and your enthusiasm for learning from colleagues.

I'd be more than happy to meet with you and share some of my experiences and strategies for teaching the course. We can discuss the syllabus, textbook choices, assignments, and any other aspects of the course you'd like to cover.

How about we meet for coffee next Tuesday at 10 AM in the faculty lounge? That way, we can have a relaxed conversation and I can introduce you to some of our other colleagues who teach in the micro area.

I'm also excited to hear about your research interests in industrial organization. It's always a pleasure to collaborate with new faculty who share similar research interests. Perhaps we can explore potential research collaborations once you've settled into your new role.

Looking forward to our meeting next week!

Best,
Emily Davis

body:
<email>
From: Emily Novak <enovak@university.edu>
To: Luca Moretti <lmoretti@research.eu>
Subject: RE: Exciting findings from the James Webb Telescope data!

Luca,

I'm thrilled to hear you're on board! I've made some progress on the theoretical side of things and have a few ideas I'd like to run by you. I think we have a strong case for challenging the current models of galaxy formation.

I'm available for a video call on Monday at 10 AM my time (4 PM yours). Does that work for you? We can discuss our findings in more detail and start outlining the structure of our paper.

I agree that presenting at the Geneva conference would be an excellent opportunity to share our work with the astrophysics community. We should aim to submit our paper to the journal by the end of next month to ensure we meet the conference deadline.

I'm attaching the latest data and my preliminary analysis for your review. Let me know if you need anything else.

Looking forward to our call on Monday!

Best,
Emily

Subject: RE: Science Fair Follow-up

Dear Emily,

Wednesday at 3 pm works perfectly for me. Thank you for setting that up!

I would absolutely love to attend Dr. Sarah Thompson's lecture. It sounds like an incredible opportunity, and I really appreciate you offering to send me the details. I'm excited to learn more about the latest developments in genetics.

Thank you again for all your support and guidance. I'm looking forward to our meeting and the lecture.

Best regards,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Alex Chen <alex.chen@genomeinstitute.org>
To: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@tech.edu>
Subject: RE: Collaborative project update

Hi Sarah,

Thanks for your email! I'm glad to hear you're excited about the project and the upcoming conference. I completely understand your concerns about simplifying the genetic concepts for our target audience. It's a challenge, but I'm confident we can find a way to make it accessible and engaging.

I think the key is to focus on the big picture and the real-world applications of these concepts. For example, instead of delving into the technical details of DNA sequencing, we could start with a basic explanation of what DNA is and why it's important. Then, we could discuss how sequencing DNA can help us understand genetic diseases and develop new treatments.

Here are a few resources that might help:

1. "DNA 101" video series by the National Human Genome Research Institute: https://www.genome.gov/video/dna-101-video-series
2. "Your Genes, Your Health" interactive website: http://www.ygyh.org/
3. "Genetic Testing: What It Means for Your Health" article by the U.S. National Library of Medicine: https://medlineplus.gov/genetictesting.html

I'd be happy to discuss these resources further and brainstorm ways to incorporate them into our educational materials. Let me know what you think!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@bostoncollege.edu>
To: Jenna Smith <jenna.smith@bostonuniversity.edu>
Subject: RE: Our research collaboration

Jenna,

Thanks for sharing your outline. I've had a chance to review it and I'm really impressed with your ideas. I think you've identified some key areas where our expertise can intersect in a meaningful way.

I've added a few notes and suggestions to the document, but overall I think we have a strong foundation to build upon. I'm particularly excited about the idea of examining historical disease patterns in colonial America and comparing them to modern-day vaccine development strategies.

I'll do some more digging in the historical records and see if I can find any relevant data to support our hypotheses. Let's discuss this further when we meet next week.

Best,
Michael

body:
<email>
From: Robert Thompson <rthompson@uva.edu>
To: Emily Jennings <ejennings@uva.edu>
Subject: RE: Exhibit stress and summer plans

Emily,

It's great to hear from you, although I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling so stressed about the exhibit. I completely understand what you're going through. When I was in the final stages of writing my book, I felt like I was constantly on edge, questioning every word and worrying about meeting my deadline.

The most important thing, I think, is to remember to take care of yourself. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and taking breaks when you need them. It's easy to let work consume you, but you'll be more productive and creative if you give yourself time to recharge.

It's also helpful to lean on your support system during times like these. Talk to your family and friends about what you're going through, and don't be afraid to ask for help if you need it. And remember, even though it feels like the world is ending if this exhibit isn't perfect, there will be other opportunities and other exhibits. This is just one moment in your career.

I'm excited to hear about your potential trip to Mongolia! That sounds like an incredible opportunity, and I'm sure you'll discover some amazing fossils. I know it can be daunting to plan a trip like that, but I bet once you're out there, you'll be so caught up in the excitement of the research that you won't even think about the challenges.

As for our summer plans, yes, we are still hoping to get to the beach. We're thinking about renting a house on the Outer Banks for a week in July. I'm looking forward to some quality family time and a chance to relax after the intensity of the past year.

I'd love to get together soon to catch up in person. How about lunch next week? I can come to your neck of the woods, and we can talk more about your exhibit and your trip.

Hang in there, Emily. You're doing amazing work, and I know the exhibit will be a huge success. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything.

Best,
Robert
label: research

December 14th in 3 Allen Center 11C1.  You would have the opportunity to

body:
<email>
From: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@historyuniversity.edu>
To: Michael Johnson <michael.johnson@civilwarinstitute.org>
Subject: RE: Paper for American Historical Review

Hi Michael,

I've been looking over the latest draft of our paper, and I think we're making great progress. However, I have a few concerns about the section on the economic factors leading up to the war. I feel like we're not giving enough weight to the role of the cotton industry in the South. What are your thoughts on this? I think we should discuss this further before we submit the paper.

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
Message-ID: <19379347.1075855727458.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 7 Feb 2001 01:58:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: jacquestc@aol.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: jacquestc@aol.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Jacques,

Can you draft the partnership agreement and the construction contract?  

The key business points are:

1.  Investment is a loan with prime + 1% rate

2.  Construction contract is cost plus $1.4 Million

3.  The investors' loan is repaid before any construction profit is paid.

4.  All parties are GP's but 3 out 4 votes needed for major decisions?

5.  60/40 split favoring the investors.

With regard to the construction contract, we are concerned about getting a 
solid line by line cost estimate and clearly defining what constitutes 
costs.  Then we need a mechanism to track the actual expenses.  Keith and I 
would like to oversee the bookkeeping.  The builders would be requred to fax 
all invoices within 48 hours.  We also would want online access to the 
checking account of the partnership so we could see if checks were clearing 
but invoices were not being submitted.

Let me know if you can draft these agreements.  The GP issue may need some 
tweaking.  

Phillip Allen
713-853-7041
pallen@enron.com

By the version of EOL do you mean the new version of stack manager ? If you 
do, we should have finished testing by today. That means we will roll out 
today or tomorrow, but Louise wants a more developed roll out plan, so that 
might slow things down a bit. Not to make excuses, but we have had some 
serious technical problems with the new release and have had to redesign 
whole parts of the back end of the system. The problem is around how many 
things can be linked to a single product and stack manager performance, 
obviously a serious issue. It has taken us, obviously, a lot longer than we 
thought to fix it. I think there are still some minor issues that we should 
discuss, but they should not get in the way of release.

If you mean by new version, the phase II website version with sexy content, 
we are scheduled (cum grano salis) to roll that out in mid august.

any questions please feel free to call.

-andy

body:
Message-ID: <13273237.1075858638174.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Fri, 4 May 2001 13:51:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: john.lavorato@enron.com
Subject: Re:
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: John J Lavorato <John J Lavorato/ENRON@enronXgate@ENRON>
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Sent Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Traveling to have a business meeting takes the fun out of the trip.  Especially if you have to prepare a presentation.  I would suggest holding the business plan meetings here then take a trip without any formal business meetings.  I would even try and get some honest opinions on whether a trip is even desired or necessary.

As far as the business meetings, I think it would be more productive to try and stimulate discussions across the different groups about what is working and what is not.  Too often the presenter speaks and the others are quiet just waiting for their turn.   The meetings might be better if held in a round table discussion format.  

My suggestion for where to go is Austin.  Play golf and rent a ski boat and jet ski's.  Flying somewhere takes too much time.
